headline: Overlooked Napoli Makes Opponents Pay
text: Mike Napoli had to smile to himself when, standing in the on-deck circle in the third inning Saturday, he saw Yankees catcher Chris Stewart extend his right arm, signaling an intentional walk for David Ortiz, loading the bases for the Red Sox.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (AMC) THE KILLING With the killer of Rosie Larsen finally revealed at the end of the second season, this series — which was canceled and then revived — returns with a new case, which the network says will be solved in a single year. And while Sarah Linden (Mireille Enos, above) is no longer working as a Seattle detective, she is drawn back into that life by her former partner Stephen Holder (Joel Kinnaman). During a search for a runaway girl, he discovers a string of gruesome murders seemingly connected to an investigation she headed several years earlier. Peter Sarsgaard joins the cast as Tom Seward, the psychopath who was convicted in those murders and is just weeks away from execution. Still, even with new colleagues, victims and suspects, “Season 3 looks an awful lot like the first two: brooding clouds; menacing, slate-colored skies; and leaden seas are still featured players,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “The creators take a fresh start but cling to the sepulchral atmospherics that too often take the place of narrative. The series is still suspenseful, but the dread that once again follows Sarah through damp forests, deserted tenements and shadowy, rain-washed streets diminishes with overuse.”

headline: ‘Doctor Who’ Star Matt Smith Is Leaving the Series
text: Somewhere, the Daleks are waving their telescopic appendages in celebration that another Doctor has been exterminated. But there is no joy among fans of “Doctor Who,” the long-running British science-fiction adventure series, whose lead actor, Matt Smith, will depart at the end of the year, the BBC said.

headline: President or Puppet?
text: There’s an ayatollah pulling the strings in the Iranian presidential race.

headline: Egypt Court Chips Away at Influence of President
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s Supreme Constitutional Court ruled Sunday that the laws that governed the election of the country’s only operating house of Parliament as well as the body that drafted the country’s postrevolutionary Constitution were invalid.

headline: Why a Widowed Mom Sends Her Son to Camp All Summer
text: I should be the last person sending her son to camp for the entire summer. I’m the widowed mother of one, and there’s no one in the world who would fault me for keeping him close. Except me.

headline: Head Talking Soon
text: I almost forgot — I did a taping for Fareed Zakaria, which I think will be showing this morning.

headline: A Sad Story — I Mean, AS-AD Story (Wonkish)
text: Peter Dorman argues that the AS-AD model — that’s “aggregate demand-aggregate-supply” for those of you who ignored the “wonkish” label — plays no role in the economic blogosphere, and suggests that its fairly prominent role in textbooks is there only to “occupy student brain cells” until something actually useful comes up. Mark Thoma says he’s wrong, and among other things provides several examples (including one of my own) of the AS-AD framework being applied to current issues.

headline: The Rail Bookshelf: The Racehorse That Brought Us Together
text: The last good time I had with my father was June 9, 1973, watching Secretariat win the Belmont Stakes.

headline: Disruptions: The Echo Chamber of Silicon Valley
text: In San Francisco, a bad habit can be the spark that leads to starting a company.

headline: Spared Demolition, an 1889 Building Gets a Second Life
text: To create a modern subway interchange in Lower Manhattan, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority first had to contend with an exquisite antique, one that stood eight stories tall.

headline: French Appear Ready to Soften Law on Media Piracy
text: SERRAVAL, France — A French experiment in cracking down on digital media piracy by threatening to kick copyright cheats offline is about to end — without solving the problem.

headline: Transport Madness
text: Oh, boy — this is truly amazing. I guess I’m not surprised that the WSJ doesn’t like the idea of providing New York with a European-style system of rental bikes. But accusing Bloomberg and company of being “totalitarians” for the vicious crime of … making bright blue bikes available to tourists … seems like it has to be parody.

headline: Youth Coach Helped Djokovic Fulfill Many of His Hopes
text: PARIS — It was Wimbledon they dreamed about together, Jelena Gencic and Novak Djokovic. And it was easy for a golden boy to dream when Gencic, with her luminous blue eyes and soothing voice, kept telling him that such big things were possible.

headline: Excerpt: 'Far From Heaven'
text: Kelli O’Hara and Isaiah Johnson sing the number “Miro” from the new musical at Playwrights Horizons.

headline: Will Smith and ‘After Earth’ Have Dismal Opening
text: A box office era ended over the weekend, as Will Smith, once Hollywood’s most dependable summer performer, imploded in spectacular fashion at North American theaters. Mr. Smith’s “After Earth,” a Sony Pictures Entertainment movie that cost $135 million to produce and roughly $100 million to market worldwide, took in an estimated $27 million from Friday to Sunday — or 18 percent less than the lowest of prerelease expectations.

headline: McCain Says Assad Has Gained the ‘Upper Hand’ in Syria
text: Senator John McCain, back from a surprise trip to Syria, offered his bleakest assessment yet of the hostilities there on Sunday, saying that opposition fighters were being “massacred” and that President Bashar al-Assad, with growing outside support, was tightening his grip on power.

headline: Trial on E-Book Price-Fixing Puts Apple in Spotlight
text: Government lawyers are set to face off against Apple this week in a Manhattan courtroom, trying to prove that the company conspired with publishers to raise prices in the e-book market.

headline: In China, Concern About a Chill on Foreign Investments
text: China was booming, and Nina Wang, a Hong Kong billionaire, wanted a piece of the action.

headline: Chasing the Storm, but Hoping Not to Catch It
text: When Tim Samaras began chasing tornadoes more than two decades ago, he was one of a small, mostly anonymous group of scientists and thrill seekers armed with paper maps, weather radios and a sense of wonder.

headline: The Miracle of a Ditz With Depth
text: It’s not easy playing dumb. But Jean Stapleton, who died on Friday in Manhattan at 90, did it spectacularly for more than 200 episodes of “All in the Family,” a watershed television show that never would have worked without her daft, poignant portrayal of Edith Bunker.

headline: France Puts UBS Under Investigation in Tax Evasion Inquiry
text: New York — A unit of the Swiss bank UBS has been placed under formal investigation in France following allegations that it designed investments to help its clients evade taxes.

headline: The Other Women, Still Trying to Find Their Place
text: Summer beach reading for those with portable video capability has arrived. “Mistresses” makes its debut on Monday night on ABC, and it’s everything you want a beach book to be: sexy but not pornographic; nontaxing yet not idiotic; and peppered with enough decent writing that you can tolerate its clichés.

headline: Apple Is Said to Be Pressing for Internet Radio Deals
text: After months of stalled negotiations over its planned Internet radio service, Apple is pushing to complete licensing deals with music companies so it can reveal the service as early as next week, according to people briefed on the talks.

headline: Red Bulls Rewind: A Break After Streak Ends
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The Red Bulls will have 21 days to ponder an opportunity squandered after a steamy 2-1 loss to the visiting Vancouver Whitecaps on Saturday night.

headline: Federer Falls, but Not Out of Contention, Rallying to Victory
text: PARIS — When his right toes caught in the clay and Roger Federer tumbled to the ground Sunday, he looked, for a rare moment, like a clumsy weekend player out for a hit. Federer’s grace is his calling card, and to see him stumble is as unusual as the thought of him failing to make a deep run at one of tennis’s most important tournaments.

headline: Clarinet, With Cicada Chorus
text: As billions of cicadas enter the brief, noisy mating stage of their 17-year life cycle, David Rothenberg performs with some of the insects to show how animals use musical sounds to communicate.

headline: F.D.A. to Reconsider Restrictions on Diabetes Drug
text: Three years ago, in one of the more notable drug-safety scandals in recent history, the diabetes drug Avandia was all but banned from use in the United States after researchers found that thousands of people had heart problems after taking it. Today, it is a drug of last resort for people with diabetes who are so sick that a heart attack is worth the risk.

headline: A Place for Cicadas
text: At a hub of cicada history and scholarship in Connecticut, the 17-year periodical cicada is the subject of study and respect.

headline: Here, Cicadas Get a Warm Welcome
text: HAMDEN, Conn. — Lawrence F. Gall, an entomologist at the Peabody Museum of Natural History at Yale, bushwhacked his way through the muddy thickets leading to the River Road colony here, the epicenter of what is believed to be the world’s only preserve dedicated to Magicicada septendecim, the 17-year periodical cicada.

headline: Gay, Hispanic, Adoptive: A Triple-Threat Family
text: “The Fosters” is a conventional family dramedy about an insistently unconventional family: lesbian mothers (a white police officer and a black charter-school administrator), the officer’s biological son, adopted Hispanic twins and a foster daughter fresh out of juvie.

headline: Hibbert’s Remarks Result in a Fine
text: The N.B.A. fined Indiana Pacers center Roy Hibbert $75,000 Sunday, hours after Hibbert apologized for using an antigay slur and an obscenity in a news conference after his team’s victory against the Miami Heat in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals.

headline: Ripples of Rumination
text: VENICE — They park their hulking yachts with names like “Lady Nag Nag,” “Wally’s Love” and “Sea Force One” on the choppy waters of the lagoon just outside the main entrance to the Venice Biennale. Every two years, scores of superrich collectors arrive here by sea, joined by museum directors, curators, artists and auction-house experts. They come to see and be seen and to take the temperature of contemporary art today.

headline: Sharing a Festive Touch Of Iceland and Korea
text: There are two schools of thought about how to proceed when confronted with unfamiliar music, particularly a new piece. One school embraces a kind of Zen approach: the listener faces each work with no predisposition or prejudice, accepting and interpreting whatever comes. The other endorses coming to the encounter armed with some basic knowledge: since composers haven’t worked in a single, common style for centuries now, comprehension and appreciation are enhanced by knowing where a creator was — geographically, temperamentally, stylistically — when a given piece emerged.

headline: Joining Forces for a Nostalgic Journey Through Jazz
text: The last thing that Wynton Marsalis’s “Swing Symphony” needed was another movement.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Delegates Visit Moscow for Insight on Boston Attack
text: MOSCOW — Members of a Congressional delegation visiting Moscow to investigate the background of the Boston Marathon bombing suspects said Sunday that the attack might have been prevented by greater cooperation between the United States and Russia on intelligence issues and counterterrorism efforts.

headline: How Obama Prevailed in 2012
text: Jonathan Alter’s revealing 2010 book, “The Promise,” provided a detailed look at President Obama’s first year in office, tracing his decision-making process on issues like health care reform and the Afghanistan war. Mr. Alter’s highly informed, energetically reported but often tiresomely familiar new book, “The Center Holds: Obama and His Enemies,” is less a sequel than a chronicle of the president’s fight to win re-election and his continuing battles with an obstructionist Republican party.

headline: Kentucky Derby Winner Looks Sharp and Will Join the Belmont’s Field
text: Todd Pletcher sat in the center of Belmont Park’s grandstand, binoculars pressed to his eyes and stopwatch in hand. His perfectly combed silver hair gave him away, not his subdued demeanor.

headline: Eastern States Regional in Manhattan
text: R. Jay Becker of New York City was the most successful player at the Eastern States Regional in Manhattan last month. He won three events, the Thursday A/X Pairs with Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J.; the Friday Round Robin Teams with Michael Kopera and Eric Robinson of New York City, and Kamil; and the Reisinger Knockout Teams with Chris Willenken, Jared Lilienstein and Michael Polowan of New York City.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Weiner Gets Mixed Reception at Israel Day Parade
text: As he marched on Sunday in his first Israel Day Parade since resigning from Congress, Anthony D. Weiner encountered plenty of fans, as well as the first real sustained display of hostility toward his New York City mayoral ambitions.

headline: Defying Naysayers, ‘Gatsby’ Proves a Box-Office Winner
text: LOS ANGELES — “If history is any indication,” a Forbes report read on May 3, “ ‘The Great Gatsby’ will bomb rather hard.” BoxOffice.com at one point projected very soft opening-weekend sales of about $24 million. Early on, several studios were so worried about the movie’s multiplex prospects that they passed on making it.

headline: Oklahoma Campus, Ravaged by a Tornado, Draws Attention to Storm Shelters
text: EL RENO, Okla. — It takes imagination to picture the Canadian Valley Technology Center as it used to be. Hundreds of adults and teenagers packed the classrooms at the vocational education campus here in the daytime and evenings, studying the art of welding, cosmetology and graphic design and learning to fix airplanes and cars by working on actual airplanes and cars.

headline: As Harvey Struggles, the Mets Are Swept
text: MIAMI — Matt Harvey was not the Matt Harvey the Mets have grown accustomed to seeing this year. Neither was Ike Davis.

headline: Nonstop Screwball Antics, Choreographed and Less So
text: The sounds of gunshots — and laughter — rang through the playhouse of Abrons Arts Center on Thursday as Yvonne Meier remounted her aggressively absurd 2006 work “This is not a pink pony.” The plastic deer onstage did not fall, but the three straight-faced screwballs did, many times. Then came the premiere of “This is not a pink pony 2.”

headline: Satire Born in the Face of Horror
text: “The Last Cyclist” isn’t participatory theater in any of the usual senses. No one is called up from Row C to answer trivia questions or dance a jig onstage. But if you’re attending this intriguing exercise in Holocaust history, you should plan to show up in character. To appreciate what you’re going to see, you need to be not a 21st-century theatergoer but rather a prisoner at Theresienstadt, the Nazi concentration camp near Prague.

headline: A Tornado Chaser Falls Doing Extreme Science
text: The fleets of camera-laden sport utility vehicles that race around Tornado Alley stalking funnel clouds these days are mainly racing into harm’s way to gather gripping video and, as a result, spiking TV ratings or Web views.

headline: Shoulder Injury Sidelines Conductor
text: Julian Wachner, a Grammy-nominated conductor and the director of music and the arts at the Trinity Church near Wall Street in Lower Manhattan, will put down his baton for a short time after injuring his shoulder.

headline: Turkish Leader Says Protests Will  Not Stop Plans for Park
text: ISTANBUL — Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey dismissed the tens of thousands of protesters who battled for two days with police officers in the streets of Istanbul as “looters” and “bums” on Sunday. He vowed to push ahead with plans to demolish a public park — a trigger for the spasm of public anger that left Istanbul’s main commercial district strewn with graffiti and broken glass.

headline: If Chorus Lines Be the Food of Love
text: Revelatory is not too strong a word to describe “Brush Up Your Shakespeare: The Bard and the Broadway Musical,” the rousing season finale of the 92nd Street Y’s Lyrics & Lyricists series. The program, directed and hosted by Mark Lamos, who wrote the script with Deborah Grace Winer, explores the ways in which Shakespeare’s plays and poems have been adapted not only for Broadway but also for jazz experiments and the movies.

headline: Buzz and Bleep
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — I don’t recall ever solving a puzzle that made me consider changing my dietary habits before, but I’m thinking of becoming a vegetarian.

headline: Non-prophet Economics
text: A few days ago Noah Smith had a good piece on the many people who beat their breasts and loudly boast about having “predicted the crisis”. As he says, by and large, the louder the boasting, the thinner the evidence for any special achievement. And anyway, also as he says, there’s the question of what you’re predicting. The housing bust? The fall of Lehman? The sluggishness of the recovery?

headline: Wit, Poetry and Shadows
text: As Alexei Ratmansky’s fascinating, poetic, enigmatic and bittersweet new “Shostakovich Trilogy” proceeds, it includes overlapping expressions of ebullience, struggle, heroism, community, affection, wit, brilliance and inspiration — but also of fear, vigilance, alarm, apprehension and grief. And the movement, more than with any previous works by Mr. Ratmansky, is often powerfully charged by qualities of strain and tension; you notice how dancers move from one position to the next, sometimes as if the air is heavier than water, sometimes as if holding onto each other while the rest of life is pulling them asunder.

headline: The “Spat”
text: Aha. That piece of my interview with Fareed Zakaria is here. There was a lot more in the interview, but anyway, in this bit I think I said what had to be said.

headline: A Contemporary Conversation With Beethoven’s Sonatas
text: Mannes College the New School for Music has offered an institute focusing on Beethoven for each of the past 12 years. This is the first season, the pianist Thomas Sauer said before a concert there on Friday, that Beethoven has shared the bill with a contemporary composer.

headline: Wiggling Worms and Fluttering Birds
text: It was an odd menagerie that slithered, swam and fluttered onto the gallery floor at the Tenri Cultural Institute on Friday evening. A pair of dolphins. A pica pica and an ortolan. A belly-dancing worm.

headline: A Band Sends Blaylock a Get-Well Wish After a Crash
text: The news that Mookie Blaylock, a former N.B.A. point guard, was involved in a car accident over the weekend hit the members of Pearl Jam like a tragedy in the family. In many ways, it was one.

headline: Courting Thrifty Shoppers With Value and Quality
text: ALMOST five years after the financial crisis, the economy has improved significantly, but remains uncertain enough that millions of worried Americans continue to watch how they spend. That has left marketers and agencies trying to figure out the right tone and tack to take in selling products as varied as cars and cans of soup.

headline: Protests Continue in Turkey
text: Thousands of Istanbul residents marched from Besiktas district to Taksim Square, in a massive public protest to the government’s plans to redevelop the public park.

headline: Economic Reports to Be Released This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week includes the ISM manufacturing index for May, construction spending for April and domestic car and truck sales for May (Monday); United States trade deficit figures for April (Tuesday); the ADP jobs report for May, the ISM purchasing manager index for May, factory orders for April and the Federal Reserve’s Beige Book (Wednesday); weekly initial jobless claims (Thursday); and federal unemployment figures for May (Friday).

headline: Player Ratings: Germany (3) vs. United States (4)
text: The United States national team celebrated U.S. Soccer’s 100th anniversary by breaking out of its offensive slump on Sunday, defeating Germany, 4-3, in an exhibition match at sweltering R.F.K Stadium in Washington.

headline: Two Studies Challenge Avastin’s Effectiveness Against a Rare Brain Cancer
text: CHICAGO — Two new studies have found that the widely used cancer drug Avastin does not prolong the lives of patients with a deadly form of brain cancer, raising questions about the role of the drug in treating that disease.

headline: After Impressive Win Over Germany, U.S. Has Smaller Fish to Fry
text: WASHINGTON — Sunday was supposed to be for looking back, a day for the United States soccer team to celebrate its history. A gala here Saturday honored the organization’s centennial. Banners thanking the fans for 100 years of support were plastered all over R.F.K. Stadium. The players even wore retro jerseys, modeled after the team’s 1916 uniforms, in the day’s exhibition match against Germany.

headline: Few Women on Some Senate Committees
text: Explore current and past committee assignments for women in the Senate.

headline: A Billionaire Dreams of Steering Europe’s Future
text: PARIS — Outside the secure elevator leading to his penthouse hotel suite at Le Bristol, Nicolas Berggruen handed a visitor his key.

headline: Fighting to Save an Oyster Industry
text: Apalachicola Bay, in Florida, which once supplied 90 percent of the state’s oyster harvest, is at a crisis point.

headline: A Fight Over Water, and to Save a Way of Life
text: APALACHICOLA, Fla. — If these were ordinary times, Leroy Shiver would be scissoring his heavy tongs along the shallows of Apalachicola Bay and hauling up bushels of oysters for hours on end.

headline: Bank of Ireland Bond Sale Confirms a Credit Boom
text: Investors’ appetite for Bank of Ireland bonds has changed a lot in the last four years.

headline: Google’s Washington Insider
text: WASHINGTON — Susan Molinari had wrapped up her second week as Google’s chief Washington lobbyist when she got a call at home late on a Friday that blindsided her: the Federal Communications Commission was fining Google $25,000 for having “deliberately impeded and delayed” an investigation into its Street View mapping project.

headline: Devoted to Politics, MSNBC Slips on Breaking News
text: At MSNBC they view it as rooting against death and destruction: the last thing the channel wants is more months like the last two, filled with terror bombings, tornadoes and plant accidents.

headline: With Latest Hit, a Penguin Further Injures His Image
text: PITTSBURGH — Penguins forward Matt Cooke is finding it hard to escape his reputation as a dangerous cheap-shot artist.

headline: Merck Has Solid Results in a Cancer Drug Trial
text: CHICAGO — An experimental drug from Merck that unleashes the body’s immune system significantly shrank tumors in 38 percent of patients with advanced melanoma, putting the company squarely in the race to bring to market one of what many experts view as the most promising class of drugs in years.

headline: Pettitte Considers Reducing Workouts
text: Many times in his 18-year career, Andy Pettitte has had to retreat to the clubhouse to have his shoulder or arm kneaded to ease a knot, a spasm or some other muscular discomfort.

headline: On Way Out? A Backhand Still Very In
text: PARIS — It is a tennis truism that the one-handed drive backhand is inexorably on its way out, a victim of power, preparation time and the need for those who are learning the game to generate pace and resistance with two hands to compete successfully as juniors.

headline: Obama’s Covert Trade Deal
text: WASHINGTON — THE Obama administration has often stated its commitment to open government. So why is it keeping such tight wraps on the contents of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the most significant international commercial agreement since the creation of the World Trade Organization in 1995?

headline: A Simple Way to Reduce Suicides
text: EVERY year about a million Americans attempt suicide. More than 38,000 succeed. In addition, each year there are around 33,000 unintentional deaths by poisonings. Taken together, that’s more than twice the number of people who die annually in car accidents.

headline: Protests in Turkey Reveal a Larger Fight Over Identity
text: ISTANBUL — Across this vast city, a capital for three former empires, cranes dangle over construction sites, tin walls barricade old slums, and skyscrapers outclimb the mosque minarets that have dominated the skyline for centuries — all a vanguard for more audacious projects already in the works.

headline: Senator McCaskill on Military Assaults
text: Claire McCaskill discusses the record number of women on the Senate Armed Services Committee and their impact on the debate about sexual assault in the military.

headline: The Geezers Are All Right
text: Last month the Congressional Budget Office released its much-anticipated projections for debt and deficits, and there were cries of lamentation from the deficit scolds who have had so much influence on our policy discourse. The problem, you see, was that the budget office numbers looked, well, O.K.: deficits are falling fast, and the ratio of debt to gross domestic product is projected to remain roughly stable over the next decade. Obviously it would be nice, eventually, to actually reduce debt. But if you’ve built your career around proclamations of imminent fiscal doom, this definitely wasn’t the report you wanted to see.

headline: Secrets and Leaks
text: CONGRESSMAN Ted Poe and I are not what you’d call kindred spirits. He’s a shrink-the-government-then-drown-it-in-the-bathtub Texas Republican, a global warming denier, an N.R.A. 100-percenter, a devout foe of abortion rights. He comes from a political tribe that regards the mainstream media as a hive of Bolsheviks. Yet Poe and I see eye to eye on one thing. He is the main House sponsor of a bill intended to protect journalists from being compelled to give up information about their government sources, even when the sources have divulged matters of national security.

headline: Polishing Antique Idea, Club Recruits Caddies
text: When Joan Small and Carolyn Argento met at the Lawrence Yacht and Country Club on Long Island for a round of golf on a recent Saturday morning, they shared a bad feeling. It was not about the gloomy weather forecast.

headline: Women in the Senate Confront the Military on Sex Assaults
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Claire McCaskill wandered down the dais at the Senate Armed Services Committee’s first hearing of the year and noticed a startling tableau: women to the left, women to the right.

headline: Washington Talk Isn’t Always Cheap
text: The harvesting of what is called nonpublic information is one of the secretive arts of Washington, where power resides in staying ahead of developments and profiting from inside information. The absolute masters of this murky enterprise have come to be known as political intelligence operatives — a growing specialty of former Congressional members and staffers and veterans of the executive branch who make regular rounds to schmooze with well-situated acquaintances and discover what is in the works that is not yet on the public radar.

headline: Protests in Turkey
text: Three days of violent protests in Istanbul and other cities in Turkey over the weekend are posing the most serious challenge yet to the decade-long rule of the prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Instead of addressing the legitimate concerns that propelled tens of thousands of people to take to the streets, Mr. Erdogan’s inclination is to respond to grievances with disproportionate force.

headline: Time to Change Military Justice
text: In his commencement address at the United States Military Academy late last month, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel urged the newest graduates of the two-centuries-old academy to help stamp out the “scourge” of sexual assaults in the military. His call had special resonance. It had been revealed just days before that a sergeant responsible for advising cadets had been charged with secretly videotaping female cadets in the shower — just one of an alarming cascade of incidents in recent weeks evidencing the depth, frequency and sheer brazenness of the military’s sexual misconduct problem.

headline: For Today’s PGA Pros, the 19th Hole Is a Fitness Trailer
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — In golf, a waist has seldom been a terrible thing to mind.

headline: In Congress, Legislation and Scandals Vie for Attention
text: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers will return to the Capitol on Monday from a weeklong recess, facing a critical juncture on immigration legislation and controversies at the Internal Revenue Service and the Justice Department that will test Congress’s ability to balance its twin responsibilities of legislating and investigating.

headline: Chinese Bid for U.S. Pork Had Links to Wall Street
text: When a Chinese company bid $4.7 billion last week to take over Smithfield Foods, America’s biggest pork producer, the deal was announced by the company’s Chinese executives.

Hedge Fund, Under Fire, Braces for Withdrawals
text: The embattled hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is bracing for investors to pull out as much as several billion dollars by a Monday deadline. Withdrawals have stepped up as a separate deadline looms for law enforcement officials investigating the firm.

headline: Rev. Dr. Roger L. Shinn, Theologian, Dies at 96
text: The Rev. Dr. Roger L. Shinn, an educator, administrator and author who championed the ecumenical movement and social activism in Protestant churches as their growth peaked in the 1950s and ’60s, died on May 13 at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 96.

headline: Yes, We’re Pregnant! Oxbow’s Dam and Sire Expecting Another Foal.
text: Oxbow, the winner of last month’s Preakness Stakes, will have another full brother or sister next year. His dam, Tizamazing, was given an ultrasound Monday morning and was confirmed 14 days in foal to his sire, Awesome Again.

headline: In Georgia Town, Hints of More Diverse Future for Major Leagues
text: STONE MOUNTAIN, Ga. — Greg Goodwin pointed to a striking baseball photograph on his office wall at Redan High School.

headline: Mayoral Candidates Wrestle Over Waste Removal
text: It is the most local of local controversies, pitting New York City officials citing fairness against residents upset at the thought of garbage trucks clogging the streets. Yet late last week, the long-simmering dispute over a planned marine waste transfer station on the Upper East Side suddenly erupted in the mayoral campaign, setting off a bitter war of words between two of the leading Democratic candidates.

headline: Pressure Grows to Create Drugs for ‘Superbugs’
text: Government officials, drug companies and medical experts, faced with outbreaks of antibiotic-resistant “superbugs,” are pushing to speed up the approval of new antibiotics, a move that is raising safety concerns among some critics.

headline: Kuchar, Steady Across the Board, Cruises to His Second Win of the Year
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — Though he hid his discomfort behind a smile, the bristly stuff bothered Matt Kuchar. Not the unruly rough at Muirfield Village Golf Club, which swallowed one contender after another at the Memorial Tournament. Kuchar’s scraggly beard was his main irritant as he cruised to his second victory this year and the fifth of his PGA Tour career.

headline: A Paradise and a Prison
text: When Kelli O’Hara sings the word “garden,” an arid landscape blossoms into lushness. This poetic note is sounded halfway through the first act of the generally prosy new musical “Far From Heaven,” which opened on Sunday night at Playwrights Horizons. And all your senses come to attention, the way they do on one of those days when an early, full-blown spring seems to have broken through winter without warning.

headline: Unsettling Moment of Truth for Heat
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Nerves and alliances have been frayed, anxieties heightened and an aura diminished. Across 11 days and 6 games of these Eastern Conference finals, the Miami Heat have been stress-tested and stretched to their limits by the Indiana Pacers and now face a trial they surely never anticipated: Game 7.

headline: Sorry, Eloise. No More Room Service.
text: It is the perk that comes with expense accounts, the silver tray that wakes lovers in the morning, and the frequent indulgence of the superspy James Bond.

headline: Fighting the Image of the ‘Burning’ Borough
text: The Bronx has been trying to remove the scorch marks from its name since the 1970s, when arson fires, rampant crime and poverty pushed residents out in droves; made the borough a national symbol of urban decay; and saddled it with the apocalyptic phrase, “the Bronx is burning.”

headline: Through a New Lens
text: Times coverage from the late 1960s and the 1970s shows the South Bronx as a crumbling, desolate and dangerous place. Ángel Franco, a Times photographer, revisited neighborhoods featured in that coverage to see how the view has changed.

headline: Jack Vance, Novelist of the Fantastical, Is Dead at 96
text: Jack Vance, who in dozens of fantastical novels created alternative worlds, past and present, imagining their alien societies in evocative detail, died on May 26 at his home in Oakland, Calif. He was 96.

headline: Robredo Remains Focused, and Stays Alive at Roland Garros
text: Watching Spain’s Tommy Robredo come back to win his third straight match after losing the first two sets and stun his more powerful countryman Nicolas Almagro, was to witness clay court tennis at its most sublime. Robredo rallied from 4-1 in the third set, 4-2 in the fourth, and 2-0 in the fifth — in one of the most remarkable matches I’ve ever watched — to advance at the French Open with a 6-7 (5), 3-6, 6-4, 6-4, 6-4 victory.

headline: China Is Reaping Biggest Benefits of Iraq Oil Boom
text: BAGHDAD — Since the American-led invasion of 2003, Iraq has become one of the world’s top oil producers, and China is now its biggest customer.

headline: After Ivanovic, Radwanska Expects Grueling Test From Errani
text: PARIS — Agnieszka Radwanska lived up to her reputation as one of the most watchable players on the tour as she out-thought Ana Ivanovic on Sunday, producing a few contenders for shot of the tournament along the way.

headline: A Producer Who Knew When to Have Marilyn Monroe on Hand
text: An enduring New York mystery is the sheeplike behavior of Broadway playgoers who line up by the hundreds outside theaters long before the curtain goes up. They have assigned seats. There is no reason for them to stand out there like robots. Nothing about this ritual makes sense.

headline: Stifled by Time’s Passage, Fewer Fans Visit the Bunkers’ TV Home
text: Years ago, they came in droves: the fans who knocked on the door, begged to be shown around the living room, and snapped photos in front of the little row house in Queens that, on their television screens, anyway, belonged to Archie Bunker and his wife, Edith.

headline: Teacher Assessments Extending to Art and Gym
text: New York City students have grown accustomed to the restless routine of state tests in math and reading every year. But soon they will face assessments in subjects typically spared from standardized testing, including art, gym and foreign languages.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 3
text: “When I raised the issue of rape in the military seven years ago, there was dead silence. Clearly they are changing things around here.”

headline: New Test for Bike Sharing: Tourists on City Streets
text: They snap photographs of the mundane — before, after and, occasionally, during their rides. They pedal past in clothes, recently purchased, that bear the words “New York.” They ask for directions.

headline: Mortgaged Diplomas
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

text: Politico, the Web site for those addicted to the machinations of Washington, has made a hire that will stir its own intrigue in the nation’s capital.

headline: Helping Children Play Safely in Sports
text: Millions of children participate in organized sports, activities that are important to their social and physical development. While sports also may place children at risk of injuries, most are preventable if participants, their parents and their coaches heed some well-researched safety measures.

headline: Rushing to Aid in Syrian War, but Claiming No Side
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — Inside the cordon of government checkpoints that ring the Syrian capital, residents are used to the crack of outgoing mortar fire. Scores of shells fly each day from bases atop Mount Qasioun, overlooking the city. For most people, their impact is left to the imagination, as state-run news media contend they are hitting “terrorists,” rebels led by foreign fighters who are bent on destroying the ancient, diverse culture of Damascus.

headline: Word of the Day | monotheism
text: monotheism •\ˈmä-nə-(ˌ)the-ˌi-zəm\• noun

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 4:15 P.M. (Sundance) GALLIPOLI (1981) The director Peter Weir follows two fleet-footed young Australians (Mark Lee and Mel Gibson) as they journey from the countryside to Perth and into the disastrous World War I battle in the Ottoman Empire. Beginning with a footrace, “the film approaches the subject of war so obliquely that it can’t properly be termed a war movie,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “Besides, it is prettier than any war film has ever been, which makes its emotional power something of a surprise. Mr. Weir’s work has a delicacy, gentleness, even wispiness that would seem not well suited to the subject. And yet his film has an uncommon beauty, warmth and immediacy, and a touch of the mysterious, too.”

headline: Soups With Spinach, Five Ways
text: Last week, at a cooking class I taught with my friend and colleague Clifford A. Wright, we demonstrated different versions of the same Andalusian spinach and chickpea soup, a dish that is packed with spinach. Cliff uses lots of olive oil and cooks his for a long time, the way the authentic dish would be produced; I use less olive oil and add the spinach at the end because I prefer the flavor and look of spinach when it’s barely cooked.

headline: Hezbollah and Rebels of Syria in Border Fight
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian rebels battled fighters from the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah early on Sunday in a border region between the two countries, a Lebanese security official said, leaving as many as 12 fighters dead in the latest sign that Lebanon is being pulled into Syria’s lengthy civil war.

headline: What to Watch on Day 9 at the French Open
text: With half the men’s and women’s quarterfinalists determined Sunday, the other eight fourth round singles matches remain for Monday’s singles slate, which is again confined solely to the tournament’s two biggest stages. A preview of Monday’s eight singles matches, by court and order of play.

headline: Buchholz Flummoxes Yanks, and a Storm Finishes Them
text: The way Clay Buchholz was pitching Sunday night, it seemed the only thing that could stop him was some kind of heavenly intervention, and that was close to what happened. Buchholz, the undefeated right-handed pitcher for the Boston Red Sox, was flashing his finest, most electric stuff, stifling the Yankees through five innings.

headline: Chinese Developer Gets Minority Stake in G.M. Building
text: The General Motors Building in Midtown Manhattan, already the most valuable office tower in the United States, is worth even more after two prominent foreign families bought a large piece of it last week.

headline: Palestinian Authority Selects Professor to Be Next Premier
text: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Sunday appointed the president of a large West Bank university to serve as his next prime minister, replacing Salam Fayyad, who resigned in mid-April, and settling months of political uncertainty, at least temporarily.

headline: News Quiz | June 3, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Buchholz Unbothered by Earlier Injury, or Yankee Hitters
text: Quieting the Yankees’ offense is hardly an achievement these days. They have scored one or fewer runs in five of their past seven games. In that stretch they have been shut down by such less notable names as the Mets’ Dillon Gee and the Red Sox’ Felix Doubront.

headline: Seven Die in Iran After Drinking Homemade Alcohol
text: TEHRAN — A batch of illegally distilled alcohol has killed seven people, sent dozens to the hospital and blinded several others in the southern Iranian city of Rafsanjan, local news media reported Sunday.

headline: An Icon and a Symbol of Two Nations’ Anger
text: TSUSHIMA, Japan — Over the centuries, this mountainous island in the strait separating Japan and Korea has seen some of the most violent episodes between those ancient Asian rivals, serving as a hide-out for pirates, a forward base for invaders and a desperate first line against attack. But in recent years that troubled history seemed hazily remote in Tsushima’s sleepy fishing hamlet of Kozuna, where villagers have gathered for generations in a tiny temple to pray before a statue of the Buddhist deity of compassion that is centuries old.

text: Dear Diary:

headline: 24 Years Later, Tensions Continue Over Crushed Chinese Protests
text: BEIJING — Early June in Beijing is always tense, with tighter security and special workplace orders affecting some in the city as the authorities try to prevent public commemorations of the crushing of the student-led democracy movement of 1989.

headline: Waste, Not Wanted
text: Boos and talk of environmental racism surfaced at a mayoral forum in March when candidates debated the planned East 91st Street marine transfer station, where garbage would be shipped out of the city.

headline: Over 100 Die in Fire at Chinese Poultry Plant
text: HONG KONG — Explosions and fire tore through parts of a poultry processing plant in northeast China on Monday, killing at least 120 people in one of the country’s worst factory disasters in years.

headline: Manufacturing Growth in China Appears to Be Stabilizing
text: HONG KONG — Two surveys that take the temperature of China’s manufacturing sector showed an economy that appears to have stabilized for now, but that is struggling to recover some of the momentum it lost at the start of the year.

headline: Why the Return of Kashmiri Pandits Is Still a Distant Dream
text: On April 24, Kamal, a 35-year-old unemployed Kashmiri Hindu, died in the Jagti refugee settlement on the outskirts of the city of Jammu, the winter capital of the north Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir. His body was found a few days after his death. More than three weeks later, the Jammu Tribune reported that the young man, who was living alone after his parents died some time ago, was mentally disturbed and had died of starvation after the state government’s relief department stopped his monthly stipend for unknown reasons.

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 3
text: NEWS A long struggle over urban spaces is erupting as a broader fight over Turkish identity, where difficult issues of religion, social class and politics intersect. Tim Arango reports from Istanbul.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 3, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “California Faces a New Quandary, Too Much Money.”

headline: What Are Your Favorite Names?
text: What are your feelings about your first name? Do you know why that name was chosen?

text: If patience is a virtue, Tim Laman will be in great shape if there’s an afterlife.

headline: Violent Storms Again Strike Oklahoma
text: In the article “Deadly Storms in Oklahoma Bring Flooding and More Tornadoes,” Manny Fernandez and Marc Santora write about the new damages to the already storm-battered state.

headline: Leaders in Britain Tackle Radicalization
text: LONDON — Two men accused of hacking an off-duty British soldier to death on a south London street last month appeared in separate courts for hearings on Monday as politicians met to seek ways of thwarting what the government has termed the “poisonous narrative” of militant Islamic radicalization.

text: This week, The Choice is publishing its monthly Counselor’s Calendar, which is intended to keep students on track during the college admission process.

headline: Daily Report: Google’s Power Broker in Washington
text: Susan Molinari had wrapped up her second week as Google’s chief Washington lobbyist when she got a call at home late on a Friday that blindsided her: the Federal Communications Commission was fining Google $25,000 for having “deliberately impeded and delayed” an investigation into its Street View mapping project, Edward Wyatt reports in The New York Times on Monday.

headline: The Tawana Brawley Story
text: Retro Report: In 1988, the nation learned the truth about the alleged crimes against Tawana Brawley, but the shocking story was far from over.

headline: Revisiting a Rape Scandal That Would Have Been Monstrous if True
text: The news reports at the time, in the late 1980s, were horrific. Tawana Brawley, a 15-year-old African-American girl from the New York City area, was said to have been abducted and repeatedly raped by six white men. She was found with “KKK” written across her chest, a racial epithet on her stomach and her hair smeared with feces. She was so traumatized, according to reports, that at the hospital she answered yes-or-no questions by blinking her eyes. Making the crime even more vile, if that were possible, she and her lawyers later claimed that two of the rapists were law enforcement officials.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Ben Austen on Reclaiming Abandoned Homes
text: Ben Austen, a contributing editor at Harper’s Magazine, wrote this week’s cover story on housing activism in Chicago. He is working on a book about the history of the Cabrini-Green housing project.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Healthier Owners
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: British Water Utility Rejects $7.7 Billion Takeover Offer
text: LONDON – The British water utility Severn Trent has again rejected a takeover offer from a consortium of investment firms that had valued the company at up to $7.7 billion.

headline: Monday Reading: Helping Children Play Safely in Sports
text: Helping children play safely in sports, minutes count in the New York real estate market, an app that makes travel a game and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: SAC Capital’s Deadline for Withdrawals
text: Investors with SAC Capital Advisors may withdraw several billion dollars from the embattled hedge fund by a scheduled quarterly deadline on Monday, DealBook’s Peter Lattman and Ben Protess report. Investors are mindful of a separate deadline for law enforcement officials; over the next several weeks, the authorities must decide whether to bring a criminal case against SAC related to suspicious trading in two drug stocks.

headline: A Photographic Feast in the South of France
text: Many photography festivals take place in southern France from the spring to fall, and the three-year-old Photomed, one of the newest and fastest rising, just opened in Sanary-sur-Mer, southeast of Marseille. The festival focuses on Mediterranean photographers and images, and is under the artistic direction of Jean-Luc Monterosso, founder and director of the Maison Européenne de la Photographie in Paris. Mr. Monterosso and his team have been successfully striking a balance between exhibiting big-name photographers — the edition this year includes Nino Migliori, Gabriele Basilico, Fouad Elkoury and the filmmaker Costa-Gavras — and showcasing the young and lesser-known, with the spotlight this year on Lebanon.

text: Dilbert!

headline: Turks Abroad Show Support for Protests at Home
text: LONDON — Around the world this weekend, members of a widely scattered Turkish diaspora staged peaceful demonstrations in solidarity with the protests at home against the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
