text: Season 6, Episode 9

headline: The Triumph of Peter Kenen, The Revenge of Robert Mundell
text: In America, it’s sad when your friends move away; in Europe, it may be a tragedy.

headline: India Has Tough Road to Champions Trophy
text: MUMBAI —As India prepares for the prestigious eight-nation Champions Trophy, which starts in England on Thursday, there is much at stake for the national team, including its credibility and reputation, after the spot-fixing scandal involving three Indian Premier League players.

headline: Waltz With Vladimir
text: MOSCOW — On Saturday morning we had our hair done. Then my two older kids and I put on our finest party clothes — we looked like we were going to a prom — and drove from our dacha into the city.

headline: Q&A: Exploring New Subscription Plans for Flickr
text: Q.

headline: Turkish Premier Blames Extremists for Protests as Two Are Killed
text: ISTANBUL — As protests continued for a fourth day in major Turkish cities on Monday, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said the demonstrations were the work of extremists led by political opponents trying to overthrow his government. But Turkey’s president, Abdullah Gul, called for calm from all sides and said protests and demonstrations were a natural part of democracy.

headline: Romancing the Brands
text: Regarding “The romantic advantage” (Views, June 1): It is pretty clear that David Brooks is only using the subject of China’s soulless brand names — which for most consumers are less important than the word “China” next to them, meaning “very good for the money with a slight risk of being unsafe” — to have a go at his beloved “bo-bo” class, an expression that Brooks himself minted but that caught on more here in France, where there are also lots of well-off people who go around looking like bums. This said, he is quite right to make fun of the semi-Socialists who buy one kind of shoe rather than another because it gives them a morally feel-good sensation, and also to point to the loftily “romantic” associations that advertising gurus astutely build into them.

headline: Britain and Ecuador May Discuss Assange Status
text: LONDON — The Ecuadorean foreign minister is scheduled to travel to London this month and has offered to meet his British counterpart to discuss the impasse over the Julian Assange case, officials from both countries said on Monday.

headline: A New Way to Harvest Wind Energy at Sea
text: With Department of Energy backing, a small offshore wind turbine was launched into Maine waters on Friday.

headline: China’s Development a ‘Threat’ to Democracies, Authors Say
text: BEIJING — When China’s Foreign Ministry spokesman, Hong Lei, told the United States late on Saturday that it should “correctly treat China’s development,” what did he mean?

headline: The Fed and Inequality
text: Is the Federal Reserve a driving force behind the post-recession growth in inequality? It’s a provocative idea, voiced by writers including Neil Irwin and Robert Frank.

headline: Fishing for Islands
text: China makes a big deal out of some small islands.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Guardian: What’s the right way to boil an egg, and to open up the top when you’re ready to eat it? And should the bread that accompanies the egg be toasted? Tony Naylor answers these important questions. –Jeff Gordinier

headline: Frank Lautenberg, New Jersey Senator in His 5th Term, Dies at 89
text: Frank R. Lautenberg, who fought the alcohol and tobacco industries and promoted Amtrak as a five-term United States senator from New Jersey, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 89.

headline: Fill-In | In the Himalayas, Journeys of Faith and Flowers
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first eight paragraphs of the article “In the Himalayas, Journeys of Faith and Flowers” by Michael Benanav.

headline: Sprint Says Dish’s Bid for Clearwire Violates Delaware Law
text: Sprint Nextel pushed back on Monday against Dish Network’s attempt to stymie its bid for full control of Clearwire, accusing Dish of breaking Delaware law with its tender offer.

headline: An iPhone Case for Your Earbuds
text: While smartphones and their cases tend to be neatly sleek, the earbuds and their cables are anything but. People try wrapping the buds around the phone, storing them in separate cases and winding them into little skeins, among other strategies.

headline: Racism, Unintended
text: TEL AVIV — Superland, an Israeli amusement park, is a land of separation. Last week Khaled Shakra, a school teacher, called the park’s front desk to set up a visit for his students. At first the receptionist proposed three dates, but when he said the school was from Jaffa, an Arab city, there was a silence. Shakra was put on hold and then told that the dates he had just been offered were already taken. An hour later he called again pretending to be a teacher from a Jewish school, and the dates were free.

headline: Why Haven’t the Marines Shown Stronger Support for Women?
text: As an Army officer, I worked with Marines in Iraq and was always impressed by their professionalism, combat readiness and physical strength. But recently, I learned some things about the Marine Corps that shocked and saddened me to my core.

headline: The Macroeconomics of European Disunion
text: Wolfgang Münchau makes a point that isn’t new, but still gets overlooked too often: the euro area is, for practical macroeconomic purposes, a single unit — and one that doesn’t really do all that much trade with the rest of the world. Aggregate euro area policy, monetary and fiscal, should therefore be subject to more or less the same rules that apply to the United States.

headline: In Performance: Courtney B. Vance
text: The New York Times invited Tony nominees to perform scenes on location in New York. Here, Courtney B. Vance performs a cinematic interpretation of a scene from Nora Ephron’s play “Lucky Guy.”

headline: Excerpt: 'The Killing'
text: The crime drama returns to AMC on Sunday.

headline: Where Fernando and Humberto Campana Get Their Ideas
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Wildfire Forces Evacuation of Thousands in Northern Los Angeles County
text: Fire crews continued Monday to battle a raging wildfire in northern Los Angeles County that has burned more than 25,000 acres since Thursday, destroying a half-dozen homes and prompting the evacuations of more than 3,000 people.

headline: Lilly Awards for Women in Theater Go to Lois Smith, Mimi Kilgore
text: The veteran New York actress Lois Smith and the playwriting patron Emilie Kilgore are among the recipients of the fourth annual Lilly Awards, which honor women working in the theater.

headline: Vine, Twitter’s New Video Tool, Hits 13 Million Users
text: At the start of this year, Twitter introduced the mobile video app Vine, which let people shoot and share bite-size, six-second looping video clips. The service captivated users, who began making and uploading quirky short films, comedy bits and stop-motion animation, among other things.

headline: No Easy Fix for Insider Trading
text: The government has made it a priority to root out insider trading, pursuing prominent hedge funds and securing dozens of convictions in recent years. And yet, a more comprehensive solution to end the illegal practice is elusive.

headline: Seized Properties for Sale, But Shapes and Sizes Vary
text: A $17.75 million cooperative on Park Avenue; a two-bedroom condominium in the Financial District; a $4.495 million mansion on Long Island, owned by Peter B. Madoff; and a three-family apartment building in the South Bronx with a rat problem.

headline: Pacers Starters’ Minutes Negate a Weak Bench
text: The Miami Heat won 66 regular-season games, six more than any other team in the N.B.A. They had the league’s most potent offense and were captained by LeBron James, the N.B.A. most valuable player and consensus best player in the world.

headline: Koch’s Sister to Amplify His Support for Quinn
text: Christine C. Quinn’s mayoral campaign will be graced by a touch of Koch after all.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘I’m Not Using the Word Love’
text: This poem, one of 12 winners of our fourth annual Found Poem Student Contest, was written by Jameson, 23, from New York City.

headline: The Hidden Costs of Starting a Company
text: I was at a StartupsUncensored event some time ago where a speaker, Jason Nazar, the founder and chief executive of Docstoc, said: “You can have your start-up and one thing. You can have your start-up and your health. You can have your start-up and your family. Or you can have your start-up and your significant other, but you can’t have multiples. If you try to have multiples, you’ll be poor at all of them.”

headline: From Dominant to Merely Mighty
text: For some reason, the Miami Heat and the Chicago Blackhawks find themselves hitched together at the cosmic hip again this season. People were once debating their dominance — whether the Heat’s 27-game winning streak was more or less impressive than the Blackhawks’ season-opening 24-game point streak — and now they are openly wondering if this superteam business is not all it is cracked up to be. Because these two teams spent large chunks of the regular season and the early stage of the playoffs looking like the only big kids on the playground, and suddenly they are together at Six Flags with metal bars over their shoulders, bracing for the next big drop.

headline: Believe Your Ears: B.J. Thomas Is Still at It
text: A few weeks ago I had “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on the TV when, from the next room, I heard a voice from my adolescence: that of B.J. Thomas. He was about the most popular male singer in my pop-music-attuned house in the late ’60s and ’70s, and he was pretty big everywhere else, too, with chartbusting hits like “Hooked on a Feeling” and “Raindrops Keep Falling on My Head.” I hadn’t heard anything about Thomas in decades, and I wondered why Fallon was playing his records on the show, because the voice sounded just the same as it did on all his classics.

headline: Justices Allow DNA Collection After an Arrest
text: WASHINGTON — The police may take DNA samples from people arrested in connection with serious crimes, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday in a 5-to-4 decision.

headline: In the Pursuit of Longevity
text: At some point between George Washington and Colonel Sanders, white hair and a cane turned from symbols of elegance to suggestions of decrepitude, and an industry was born. Not that the fountain of youth wasn’t always sought after. But to look young, think young, feel young — those are distinctly modern goals.

headline: Really? Cycling Is the Top Sport for Head Injuries
text: THE FACTS

headline: Trial Portrays Two Sides of Private in Leak Case
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — The court-martial of Pfc. Bradley Manning, whose secret release of a vast archive of military and diplomatic materials put WikiLeaks into an international spotlight, opened here Monday with dueling portrayals of a traitor who endangered the lives of his fellow soldiers and of a principled protester motivated by a desire to help society who carefully selected which documents to release.

headline: F.D.A. Scientists Find No Serious Misconduct in Avandia Drug Tests
text: A review of a disputed clinical trial on the safety of the controversial diabetes drug Avandia did not uncover serious misconduct or fraud, according to findings by scientists at the Food and Drug Administration that were made public Monday.

headline: The S.E.C. Is ‘Bringin’ Sexy Back’ to Accounting Investigations
text: In April 2003, a New York Times article discussed the push by federal prosecutors to crack down on accounting fraud in which one expert said, “These have become the hot, sexy cases.”

headline: Rituparno Ghosh, Bengali Film Director, Dies at 49
text: Rituparno Ghosh, an award-winning, internationally known Bengali director whose films about women, sexuality and urban life challenged conservative sensibilities in India, died on Thursday in Calcutta. He was 49.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: May 31-June 2, 2013
text: On Thursday, 70-year-old retired U.S. Army Lt. Col. Ralph Wald, who found his wife, Johnna Lynn Flores, 41, having sex with another man on their living room floor in Tampa in March, was acquitted of second-degree murder after invoking Florida’s Stand Your Ground law. His defense? He thought the man, 32-year-old Walter Conley, was raping his wife. In fact, Conley was later found to be Flores’s paramour, a fact that didn’t seem to faze his legal team one bit.

headline: Artificial Connections
text: Q. When you get a joint replacement, like a knee or hip, how exactly is the muscle attached to the artificial implant?

headline: Commuters Nearly Double Manhattan’s Daytime Population, Census Says
text: If New York’s bars and restaurants seem crowded at night, consider this: during the day, commuters from the other boroughs and outside the city nearly double Manhattan’s population, from 1.6 million to 3.1 million.

headline: The Rectangled Square Puzzle
text: Our puzzle this week was suggested by a Numberplay regular, Joe Fendel.

headline: Step Aside, Jon Stewart: John Oliver Prepares to Host ‘The Daily Show’
text: For a little while on Thursday, while “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” was on hiatus, John Oliver had the offices all to himself. In an otherwise deserted conference room on Manhattan’s West Side, Mr. Oliver, 36, the British-born comedian and “Daily Show” correspondent, was dressed casually and lounging beneath a giant National Geographic map of the world. Asked how he was doing, he replied, “I’m fine.” He paused. “I’m excited.” Another pause. “I’m nervous.”

headline: Tony Awards: In Performance With Courtney B. Vance
text: For this year’s Tony Awards edition of In Performance, The New York Times ditched the studio and went on location. As always, the videos capture short excerpts of songs or monologues performed without costumes or makeup. But instead of using our regular backdrop, we asked selected Tony nominees to shoot a scene at a New York City locale that reflects the personality of their character and the spirit of their show. Where would a no-nonsense newspaper editor from the play “Lucky Guy” go to vent about a high-strung journalist? Where would a modern-day Cinderella spend a romantic afternoon with her prince? You get the picture.

headline: A Minimalist Jam? Well, Less Showy
text: It’s a familiar but risky business strategy: underpromise and overdeliver.

headline: Ford Is Recalling 465,000 Vehicles Over Possible Fuel Leaks
text: About 465,000 2013 Fords are being recalled worldwide because of concern about fuel leaks, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Ford says the Explorer, Taurus, Flex, Fusion and police models – the Interceptor Utility and Interceptor Sedan – are included in the recall, as are the Lincoln MKS, MKT and MKZ.

headline: The Long Road Ahead for Tesla
text: The chief executive of Tesla, Elon Musk, has to sell 540,000 electric vehicles a year. At least that is what may be needed for the automaker to be worth $43 billion, according to a Breakingviews calculator.

headline: China Heads to Space Again This Month
text: HONG KONG — China’s next space mission begins this month when a capsule carrying three astronauts will dock with an orbiting module, a spokesman for the space program said Monday.

headline: Two Principal Dancers to Leave Royal Ballet
text: Alina Cojocaru and Johan Kobborg, two of most admired principal dancers on the roster of the Royal Ballet, in London, announced on Monday that they would leave the company at the end of the current season. Their final performance at the Royal Opera House will be in “Mayerling” on Wednesday, although they will remain with the company for a visit to Japan, with performances in Tokyo on July 11 and 12.

headline: Image of the Day: June 3
text: India’s manufacturing output in May fell for the first time in more than four years.

headline: For Kidd, a Tough End to a Brilliant Career
text: He affected games without looking at the basket, made pinpoint bounce passes in transition to teammates and often left fans wondering what he was going to do next. Jason Kidd was the ultimate point guard for much of his 19-year career in the N.B.A., but at the end of his one season with the Knicks, his magic was no more.

headline: A Mosquito That Won’t Ruin a Barbecue
text: There are good evolutionary reasons that some species of mosquito developed a taste for humans: We tend to live in groups and are never far from water, which mosquitoes need to breed.

headline: Oxbow’s Pedigree Is Rife With Belmont Success
text: Oxbow’s pedigree is littered with big names — Deputy Minister, Mr. Prospector, Raise A Native. His ancestors have had plenty of success at Belmont Park: Bold Reasoning set a new track record there for six furlongs when he was 4 years old, and Northern Dancer ran a surprising third in the 1964 Belmont Stakes. But two stars in particular jump out from his bloodline when thoughts turn to winning the Belmont: Man o’ War and Seattle Slew.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Stewart Tames the Monster Mile
text: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uN_oc5bcUUQ

headline: Death of Senator Places Christie in Difficult Spot
text: The death of Frank R. Lautenberg on Monday has left Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey with the kind of opportunity that politicians usually covet: the chance to give away a seat in the United States Senate. But the decision is fraught with pitfalls, none bigger than having to choose between improving his party’s fortunes in Washington and furthering his own political ambitions at home.

headline: Street Style: Denim on Denim
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of May 27.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: The Sud de France Festival, which celebrates the food and culture of France’s Languedoc-Roussillon region, begins Monday and will feature several dinner parties, wine tastings, concerts, seminars, festive bus tours, a sommelier competition and more. The festival runs through June 23 and it starts Monday at 7:30 p.m. with a party at The Park’s penthouse, 118 10th Avenue in Chelsea, with wine and live music. A series of dinners are scheduled at restaurants across the city that will feature food from the south of France, in particular the region of Languedoc-Roussillon, with dishes like cassoulet and cod brandade.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Ayzenberg Group, Pasadena, Calif., is opening an office in London, its first outside the United States. The office is being opened within the office of Holmes & Marchant, a London branding agency; the two agencies will work together in their respective areas of expertise.

headline: 11 Afghan Children Killed in 2 Taliban Bombings
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban attacks in eastern Afghanistan on Monday killed 2 American soldiers and 17 Afghans, including at least 11 children, adding to a particularly deadly season for civilians this year.

headline: The Pirate-Warden of Richmond
text: Capt. George Washington Alexander dressed for intimidation.

headline: Bringing New York City Dance Into the Limelight
text: Some of the best-remembered moments in entertainment are dances set in New York City, in shows and movies like “Guys and Dolls,” “On the Town,” “West Side Story,” “42nd Street” and “The Band Wagon.” Now comes a campaign that urges New Yorkers to support dance as an art form.

headline: Floods Sweep Through Central Europe
text: Tens of thousands of people were evacuated, some carried on the backs of rescuers or by boat, in Central Europe as heavy rainfall in the past week swelled rivers that spilled over their banks and flooded streets, businesses and houses. News reports said at least seven people were killed.

headline: Ex-President of Taiwan Attempts Suicide in Prison
text: BEIJING — Chen Shui-bian, a former president of Taiwan who is serving a 20-year prison sentence for corruption, tried to kill himself on Sunday, the Ministry of Justice said in a statement.

headline: Ben Bernanke Endorses A 73 Percent Tax Rate
text: OK, he didn’t actually say that in so many words. But if you follow through on the logic of his excellent speech at Princeton yesterday, that’s where you end up.

headline: Lautenberg’s Death Continues Sharp Decrease in Military Veterans in Senate
text: The death Monday of Frank R. Lautenberg, the five-term Democratic senator from New Jersey, brought the number of World War II veterans in the Senate to zero, the first time the Senate has been without a World War II veteran since the war itself.

headline: Dealing With Breast Cancer (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Patients With Disabilities (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Judge Says Ft. Hood Shooting Suspect May Act as His Own Lawyer in Court
text: HOUSTON — The Army psychiatrist accused of killing 13 people in a shooting rampage at Fort Hood, Tex., in 2009 will represent himself when his trial begins next month, the latest twist in a long-delayed case that is likely to raise numerous legal questions and could provide him with a stage to promote his radical Islamic beliefs, experts in military law said.

headline: Haas Gains Quarterfinals After Youzhny’s Meltdown
text: PARIS — Tommy Haas of Germany rolled past Mikhail Youzhny of Russia in straight sets to join the lineup for the men’s quarterfinals at the 2013 French Open.

headline: Bill Cunningham’s On the Street, Spoke Spinners
text: Always-rushing New Yorkers finally have a chance to discover the joy, freedom and speed of the new rental Citi Bikes. No waiting for cabs or buses, or on sweaty subway platforms: just unlock one and pedal off. Some have taken to scooters that can be folded up and carried into the office. Aside from the August closing of Park Avenue on Saturdays for cyclists, a few rules to follow: stay close to the curb, avoid pedestrians (who encroach on bike lanes at rush hour) and watch for cab doors being flung open. Despite the hazards, this pedaler, who has had about 30 bikes stolen, still enjoys the mobility of two wheels. Just don’t lock your own bike to a Citi Bike terminal.

headline: Snapshots From Venice
text: Highlights from the Venice Biennale by the chief art critic Holland Cotter with updates each day.

headline: Why Young People Don’t Vote Republican
text: There has been no shortage of Republican post-mortems on the 2012 presidential election — and no shortage of apologists who claimed the party need only change its rhetoric (and stop nominating members of the legitimate-rape caucus) to attract women, minorities and young people.

headline: Jordan Blocks Local Access to News Sites
text: AMMAN, Jordan — The Jordanian government has blocked local access to about 300 news Web sites under a new law that the sites’ editors and international journalism experts have derided as dangerous censorship aimed at quelling criticism of King Abdullah II.

headline: Sharon Jones Postpones Tour to Seek Cancer Treatment
text: The soul singer Sharon Jones has been diagnosed with cancer and has postponed a tour and the release of her next album, she announced on her band’s Web site. The singer said she has stage 1 bile duct cancer, which has yet to spread, and will have surgery immediately to remove the tumor.

headline: Ford Showing Its Vigor as Industry Recovers
text: For decades in Detroit, there was a clear pecking order among automakers: General Motors sold the most cars in the United States, followed by Ford Motor Company and then the Chrysler Group.

headline: Shifting Cargo May Have Doomed Plane That Crashed Near Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Crash investigators in Afghanistan said Monday that quickly shifting cargo of heavy military vehicles contributed to the crash of a civilian cargo plane on April 29 in which all seven people aboard were killed.

headline: Checking Trees as Hurricane Season Starts
text: Hurricane season began on Saturday, and the federal government is predicting an “active or extremely active” year. So if you live in a hurricane-prone area, now is a good time to inspect trees near your home for possible weakness that could lead to damage during a storm with strong winds.

headline: Graceful Aging and Loss in Paris
text: PARIS — For a French Open that has yet to have a major upset, it has surely been a tournament full of big surprises and big swings of emotion.

headline: Our Driven Elite (Trivial and Time-Wasting)
text: Like many of us, Atrios is still having fun with the hysterical WSJ screed against rental bicycles. Unusually for him, however, I think he fails to fully recognize the role of class in the whole discussion. He writes,

headline: Australian Teen Goes from Main Draw Upset to Junior Defeat
text: PARIS — It was a rare moment of triumph for a junior player allowed into the men’s main draw at a major when Nick Kyrgios, 18, a wild card entrant from Australia,carved out a masterful three-set upset of Radek Stepanek of the Czech Republic in the first round of the French Open last week. But on Monday, Kyrgios found himself on the opposite end of an upset, when he lost in the first round of the junior championship, where he was the top seed.

headline: Live Streaming: TimesTalks With ‘The Leading Women of Broadway’
text: 9:21 p.m. | Updated  Tonight ArtsBeat live streamed a conversation with six award-winning actresses on Broadway this season: Judith Light and Jessica Hecht from “The Assembled Parties”; Cicely Tyson from “The Trip to Bountiful”; Kristine Nielsen from “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike”; Holland Taylor from “Ann”; and Maura Tierney from “Lucky Guy.” Click on the image above to watch the event, which was moderated by Patrick Healy, the theater reporter for The New York Times.

headline: Manning Supporters Are Loud and Online
text: WASHINGTON — Call it Pfc. Bradley Manning Inc.

headline: Wheelies: The More Subarus Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: What Did You Think of ‘What’s Going On in This Picture’?
text: Last October we introduced a new feature in which, each Monday morning this school year, we posted a New York Times photograph without a caption, then invited students to answer three deceptively simple questions about it:

headline: Angelina Jolie Does Modern Grecian in London
text: The Girl: The actress (and recent New York Times Op-Ed contributor) at the world premiere of “World War Z,” the apocalyptic horror film starring her fiancé, in London.

headline: The Distasteful Side of Social Media Puts Advertisers on Their Guard
text: As social media sites pursue advertising in a bid for new revenue, they are finding that they must simultaneously create a safe space for the advertisers they attract.

headline: Roving Runner, Turned Roving Biker
text: Brian Fidelman, who writes a running column for the Well blog, shares his experience with Citi Bike, New York’s bike sharing system.

headline: Ask About the 17-Year Cicada
text: Update, June 28 | We are no longer accepting questions for this article. Thanks for all your questions!

headline: Walkabout – 6/3: National Parks’ Graying Constituency; Less Revealing Body Scans at Airports
text: Old Faithfuls When it comes to supporting national parks like Yosemite, above, few traveler sets have been as reliable as baby boomers. But this critical constituency is also a graying one. (New York Times)

headline: Left-Right Problems, Cicadaphobia, Bike-Sharing Around New York
text: What can happen when your body doesn’t know its left from its right; the 17-year cicada as the stuff of nightmares; the Roving Runner picks up a Citi Bike.

headline: Lautenberg’s Seat and Booker’s Chance
text: The Times’s David M. Halbfinger discusses the legacy of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who died Monday, and how Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark could benefit.

headline: Conservative Party Endorses Lhota for Mayor
text: The Conservative Party of New York State endorsed Joseph J. Lhota, a Republican, for mayor on Monday, all but ensuring that Mr. Lhota and his chief rival for the Republican nomination, John A. Catsimatidis, will both carry their campaigns into the November general election.

headline: Growing Left, Growing Right
text: One day in 1788, students at the Hunterian School of Medicine in London were opening a cadaver when they discovered something startling. The dead man’s anatomy was a mirror image of normal. His liver was on his left side instead of the right. His heart had beaten on his right side, not his left.

headline: Plastic Bags to Keep Premature Babies Warm
text: In the United States, some very premature babies are swaddled in sterile plastic wrap to keep their body temperature from dropping dangerously. Now a study of newborns in Zambia suggests that the technique can be duplicated cheaply and effectively in poorer countries — using simple plastic bags.

headline: Ray of Light in European Economic Data
text: FRANKFURT — In what passes for good news in Europe these days, a survey Monday showed that manufacturing in the euro zone was deteriorating more gradually than preliminary estimates had indicated. The slight improvement in economic data fed hope that the euro zone was in a temporary downturn and not stuck in a recession that could last for years.

headline: Disputed Banksy Work Brings $1.1 Million at Auction
text: In the latest and perhaps final installment of one of the art world’s most amusing controversies of 2013, “Slave Labor (Bunting Boy),” the satirical work stenciled by the graffiti artist Banksy on a wall in North London, was sold at a private auction held by the London-based Sincura Group — which describes itself as “concierge specialists who pride themselves on obtaining the unobtainable” — on Sunday for what the BBC reported was more than £750,000, or about $1.1 million.

headline: App Smart Extra: Timer Apps to Keep Track of Your Life
text: If you could have listened to the App Smart column the other week instead of just reading it, you’d have heard the tick-tock of timer apps counting down. Far more flexible than kitchen timers of old, or even wristwatch timers, timer apps for smartphones and tablets can be very useful in helping you keep track of all sorts of timings.

headline: Opening New Frontiers of Backyard Cookery
text: Meet a new gas-powered weapon to your outdoor cooking arsenal.

headline: Videos and Final Tweets From Storm Chasers Killed in Oklahoma
text: In his final post on Twitter, Tim Samaras, a highly respected storm chaser whose work has been featured on the Discovery Channel and in National Geographic, shared his concern on Friday about the “dangerous day ahead” for Oklahoma.

headline: Breaking Symmetry
text: A tiny pit lined with cilia helps the developing embryo distinguish left from right.

headline: Frying Outdoors? It’s No Mistake
text: Last year we became converts to gas. The odd thing about this is that we’ve spent 20 years and nine cookbooks very pointedly avoiding gas grills. So when we tell friends we have added a gas-powered weapon to our outdoor cooking arsenal, we get very skeptical looks.

headline: Mozart and Haydn? He’s Jazzed
text: A magical moment arrives in every concert I have seen involving the conductor Nicholas McGegan, and it comes before any music has been made. It happened on Saturday night as the Orchestra of St. Luke’s sat onstage at Carnegie Hall, ready for a program of canonical works by Mozart and Haydn. The stage door opened, and Mr. McGegan bounded out to the podium, beaming and exuding enthusiasm. This, not the opening bars of Mozart’s Symphony No. 29 in A (K. 201), was the real start of the concert, which turned out to be one of the most appealing, satisfying performances I have heard this season. (The concert was originally scheduled for last November, but was postponed because of Hurricane Sandy.)

headline: Jason Kidd Leaves the Game
text: Images of point guard Jason Kidd, who announced his retirement from the N.B.A. on Monday after 19 seasons.

headline: Men’s Use of Testosterone on the Rise
text: The number of middle-aged men with prescriptions for testosterone is climbing rapidly, raising concerns that increasing numbers of men are abusing the powerful hormone to boost their libidos and feel younger, researchers reported on Monday.

headline: One Early Bird Restores Lineage of Another
text: Since its discovery in 1860, Archaeopteryx was widely considered to be the earliest known bird. But in 2009 a team of scientists decided it was more dinosaurlike than avian. Because of its reptilian metabolism and growth rate (slower than that of a bird), the transitional species should be removed from the bird family tree, the scientists said.

headline: A New Baton for the Little Orchestra Society
text: James Judd, a British conductor who has been music director of the Florida Philharmonic – with which he made an acclaimed recording of Mahler’s First Symphony – and the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra, has taken over his first New York ensemble, the Little Orchestra Society. He succeeds Dino Anagnost, who led the orchestra from 1979 until his death in 2011, and is the third director in the ensemble’s history, which goes back to 1947, when it was founded by Mr. Anagnost’s predecessor, Thomas Scherman.

headline: Check In | A Hotel in Dallas Where the Art Is as Impressive as the Rooms
text: Over the past decade, Dallas philanthropists have carried out a Texas-size effort to reinvent their city as a contemporary art and architecture capital. Now, visitors drawn to destinations like the vast new  Warehouse, the Nasher Sculpture Center and the revitalized Dallas Museum of Art have an equally enticing place to stay. Thanks to a $78 million renovation and expansion by the local oil and real-estate magnate and film financier Tim Headington, the Joule Hotel is now the city’s go-to boutique hotel. But it’s also an art destination to rival its neighbors in the nearby Arts District.

headline: A Love Letter to New York, Written by Consensus
text: There’s a tacit understanding in jazz circles that one path to success involves a sturdy, identifiable working band, and that another rests on high concept, or at least a central idea. The bassist Chris Lightcap has long been associated with the first camp: each of his three albums has featured a version of the same group, with two tenor saxophones out front. He calls it Bigmouth — after his second album, released a decade ago — and uses the band to bridge the gap between the rougher hinterlands of postbop and its calm stylistic center.

headline: A Contemporary Dialogue With Beethoven’s Sonatas
text: Mannes College the New School for Music has offered an institute focusing on Beethoven for each of the past 12 years. This is the first season, the pianist Thomas Sauer said before a concert there on Friday, that Beethoven has shared the bill with a contemporary composer.

headline: Stamp! Clap! It’s Their 30th
text: For the company Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana to survive in New York, as it has, for 30 years, Carlota Santana, the co-founder and artistic director, must have made many sage decisions. But when the troupe opened its anniversary season at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday, one particular decision stuck out: her hiring of the dancer Ángel Muñoz.

headline: Another Butter Location
text: Alex Guarnaschelli, Scott Sartiano and Richie Akiva,who have owned Butter on Lafayette Street in NoHo for 10 years, plan to open an uptown branch in July. The new restaurant, which will also be called Butter, will have a garden, and the owners plan to open that in about two weeks to take advantage of the season. They will serve cocktails and light food outdoors.

headline: However You Spell It, a Knaidel Tastes Good
text: Arvind V. Mahankali of Bayside, Queens, won the Scripps National Spelling Bee last week on the strength of his mastery of “knaidel,” a Yiddish word of German origin (and, it turns out, somewhat ambiguous spelling) for the dumplings that go into, among other things, matzo ball soup.

headline: Obama to Nominate 3 to Fill Posts on Key Appeals Court
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will nominate a slate of three candidates on Tuesday to fill the remaining vacancies on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, a White House official said Monday.

headline: Kerry Says U.S. Came Late to Syrian Peace Effort
text: WASHINGTON — The United States came “late” to efforts to find a political settlement to the war in Syria, Secretary of State John Kerry said Monday, as the crisis there deepened with the political uncertainty in neighboring Turkey.

headline: What Makes a Jewish Mother
text: I was 42 when my husband and I began trying to have a child. Three years later, I finally accepted it wasn’t going to happen naturally. We narrowed our options to two: use eggs donated by another woman, or adopt.

headline: Tony Contenders in Battle of the Box Office
text: The new Broadway musicals “Kinky Boots” and “Matilda” may be the front-runners for the Tony Award for best musical to be announced on Sunday, but there’s no contest between the two shows at the box office so far. “Kinky Boots” has beaten “Matilda” nine out of the 13 weeks that they have been running head-to-head, including last week, when “Kinky Boots” grossed $1,340,238 while “Matilda” took in $1,157,633.

headline: A Renewed Effort to Rename a Street Honoring a Soviet Spy
text: When Susan LaRosa became director of marketing for the Henry Street Settlement a few years ago, she peered out her window at the plaza below and wondered about its namesake: Who was Samuel Dickstein?

headline: Rising Aggression Against Turtle Conservationists Preceded Costa Rica Slaying
text: The Tico Times in Costa Rica has been providing valuable updates since the murder late last week of Jairo Mora Sandoval, a 26-year-old guardian of sea turtle nests on Moín Beach on the country’s Caribbean coast near the town of Limón. Read on for an excerpt from the latest dispatch, which shows clearly that the threat to conservationists, including Sandoval, had been building before he was kidnapped, bound, beaten, shot in the head and left on the sand.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Tumblr and College Admissions, and an X-Rated App for Google Glass
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.How College Admissions Officers Vet Students Onlinebuzzfeed.com | Yes, they know about your Tumblr. – Jenna Wortham

headline: Ask the Next Mayor a Question
text: The Editorial Board would like your help. New York City is getting a new mayor, and we’re getting ready to decide — from a field of about a dozen candidates — who we think it should be.

headline: Apocalypse and Other Love Stories
text: Summer’s here, and so is the end of the world.

headline: Damon, Baranski Join Lineup for Delacorte Event on ‘Shakespeare, Money and Morals’
text: Matt Damon, Christine Baranski and Gloria Reuben will join the lineup of noted actors scheduled to appear at “What Are We Worth? Shakespeare, Money, And Morals,” a one-night free event at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park on Monday, June 17 at 8 pm.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Turkey, China, Gaza City and Afghanistan.

headline: The Light Switches Are in Manhattan, the Power’s From New Jersey
text: Not that they would have noticed, but some Manhattanites are now using electricity imported from New Jersey through a new underwater connection.

headline: Continental Grain to Walk Away From Smithfield
text: 5:19 p.m. | Updated One of Smithfield Foods‘ biggest investors plans to drop its fight against the pork processor in light of its planned $4.7 billion sale to a Chinese meat producer.

headline: Slathering on Sunscreen Shows Results
text: People who diligently use sunscreen every day can slow or even prevent for a time the development of wrinkles and sagging skin, a new study found. Although dermatologists have long told people to use sunscreen to prevent aging, this is the first research to show an actual effect on the appearance of skin, researchers said.

headline: Girl Group Just Wants to Be Famous (Again)
text: The Electric Barbarellas was the name of a girl group and of an MTV reality show featuring the group that ran for six episodes in the spring of 2011. Both would have come and gone largely unnoticed, if Sumner Redstone hadn’t picked up the phone.

headline: In This Play Festival, There Are No Second Acts
text: Ensemble Studio Theater’s annual one-act-play marathon is always entertaining and rich in solid performances, but each of the bills — Series A, B and C — often has one play that stands out. For Series B this year it’s “A Sunrise in Times Square,” by Sharr White (“The Other Place,” on Broadway). The play may be no better written than others on the program, but the marvelous performances by Julie Fitzpatrick and Joseph Lyle Taylor carry it to another level.

headline: Still Balanchine’s Students
text: The three ballets performed by the School of American Ballet last weekend in its annual Workshop presentation were a heady infusion of beauty, consisting of pure dancing — nothing but dancing to music. The choreography for each was by Balanchine; the music was by Mozart, Ravel and Gounod and finely played by the Workshop Orchestra, conducted with élan by Daniel Capps. Attending the first of the three performances on Saturday afternoon, I regretted that the busiest period of New York’s ballet year prevented me from seeing the others.

headline: Microsoft Weighs Restructuring
text: Microsoft is considering mixing up the responsibilities of its top executives as it seeks to further its transformation into what Steve Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, calls a “devices and services company.”

headline: A Case of Cicadaphobia
text: For some the coming of the 17-year cicada is less a marvel of science, more a nightmare scenario.

headline: Harmless, but They May Cause Paralysis
text: In 2004, when the cicadas of Brood X crawled out of the ground in and around Washington, Lori Milani, then a full-time student, would not set foot outside her apartment. Terrified of insects, she shut her windows tight, sometimes with the blinds drawn, for five weeks. She stocked up on food, canceled her summer classes and had friends run essential errands for her.

headline: A Girl’s Secret Sin, Then Rarefied Exile
text: The ingredients of Anton DiSclafani’s first novel, “The Yonahlossee Riding Camp for Girls,” sound as if they’d been plucked from two genres: the young-adult category and the historical romance. Ms. DiSclafani gives us an elite boarding school where wealthy debutantes perfect their riding skills and prepare for the big spring horse show; an impetuous, headstrong heroine, who often seems like a 1930s version of Scarlett O’Hara; and a mysterious accident that has left one teenager brain-damaged and two others guilty and haunted. In her story there are echoes of “A Separate Peace,” John Knowles’s 1959 prep-school classic about two friends on the eve of World War II, as well as of Curtis Sittenfeld’s more recent boarding school novel,  “Prep.”

headline: Hot 97’s Summer Jam in East Rutherford
text: Nicki Minaj, 2 Chainz, ASAP Rocky and Kendrick Lamar were among the performers at the 20th edition of the annual concert.

headline: Making Sense of the Air
text: Advances in 3-D printing and cellphone connectivity are allowing citizens to monitor the air pollution in their own neighborhoods.

headline: Who Is Xi Jinping?
text: The Times’s China correspondents discuss the country’s new president, Xi Jinping, who will meet with President Obama this week.

headline: Microsampling Air Pollution
text: Near the corner of Tillary and Jay Streets in Brooklyn, Michael Heimbinder stood near a blue mailbox, head down, poking at his smartphone. A graph appeared: a single line plotting ambient carbon monoxide exposure in the neighborhood.

headline: Maxwell’s in Hoboken to Close in July
text: Maxwell’s, the Hoboken restaurant and bar that has been one of the most influential indie-rock clubs in New Jersey, is closing down at the end of July, The Star-Ledger reported.

headline: U.S. Cites Phone Calls in Apple Pricing Case
text: The United States government said on Monday that there were 100 phone calls among top executives of the publishing industry in the weeks leading up to Apple’s introduction of the iPad in 2010, when they had to decide whether to sign on to a deal with Apple that would raise the prices of e-books.

headline: Finding a High-Yield Checking Account
text: Interest rates on most savings and checking accounts remain anemic. But for those who are comfortable with electronic banking and who are active debit-card users, high-yield checking accounts offered by smaller, regional banks and credit unions can be a more lucrative option.

headline: At 90, Still Riveting the Mind’s Eye
text: Ellsworth Kelly has been on earth for 90 years — his birthday was Friday — and he has been making abstract art for over 60 of them. Now the New York art world is treating him, and us, to a big party. His boldly colored, emblematic paintings and reliefs can be seen in five exhibitions around town. In unusually gorgeous terms, they attest to a lifelong fusion of austerity and high spirits, and a narrow yet deep exploration of pure colors and simple shapes.

headline: Photographs From the Week in Sports
text: From the French Open to baseball to the European handball championship, a look at sports action from across the world during the week of May 27.

headline: Leading Women: Responsible Entertainers
text: Part 2: The actresses talk about the tension they feel between entertaining and giving the audience something deeper.

headline: Leading Women: Blew the Roof Off
text: Part 13: The actresses discuss how to make theater in New York more accessible and affordable for a broader audience.

headline: Leading Women: Dead Silence
text: Part 14: The actresses explain why it’s important to keep a performance honest and consistent.

headline: Leading Women: I’m Ill-Equipped
text: Part 12: The actresses recall the decisive turns that have brought them to this point in their careers.

headline: Leading Women: Intro
text: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the actresses Holland Taylor, Judith Light, Kristine Nielsen, Maura Tierney, Cicely Tyson and Jessica Hecht.

headline: Leading Women: Just Like Church
text: Part 7: The actresses share what they’ve learned from the occasional onstage disaster.

headline: Leading Women: Wild Card Performers
text: Part 5: The actresses discuss the unpredictable element of theater acting.

headline: Leading Women: Having the Chutzpah
text: Part 3: The actresses reflect on their experiences working with the material of different playwrights.

headline: Leading Women: It Fell on Me
text: Part 9: The actresses recall the origins of their current productions.

headline: Leading Women: My Stomach Churns
text: Part 11: The actresses talk about what attracts them to the roles they choose.

headline: Leading Women: Comfort Zones
text: Part 10: The actresses reflect on the difficulty and importance of creating a genuine dynamic onstage.

headline: Leading Women: The Fun Part
text: Part 4: The actresses explore the relationship between performer and audience.

headline: Leading Women: Divine Choreography
text: Part 8: The actresses talk about how roles for women in theater have evolved.

headline: TimesTalks | Leading Women: Preview
text: The actresses Holland Taylor, Judith Light, Kristine Nielsen, Maura Tierney, Cicely Tyson and Jessica Hecht discuss their varied stage careers and share their insights on the craft of theater acting.

headline: Leading Women: Going Up
text: Part 6: The actresses reminisce about the times when they’ve forgotten their lines.

headline: A Room of One’s Own — With a Tub
text: I have an original design sketch by the legendary interior decorator Albert Hadley (above) that my mom gave me. It is my dream room: a luxurious hideaway that combines the dressing room and study with an oversize tub. If it were mine, I would have to be wrenched from the space. And some of the finer-heeled working mothers in London seem to feel the same. Last week I went with a friend to look at a potential new house where, on the second floor, there was a double reception room split by a central staircase. We instantly felt that the oversize space should become the master bedroom suite and devised the perfect boudoir floor plan on a napkin in Tom’s Deli after the viewing. The bath would go in the center of the room, opposite the fireplace. A folding screen would double as shelving for bath products on one side, and a bulletin board — covered in felt and trellised with ribbon — for the desk on the other side. It would also add an element of privacy, blocking the tub from the door that opens off the landing.

headline: Ancient Plants, a Cosmic Fund-Raiser, Atoms in Motion and More
text: In science, popular ideas are often discarded once new evidence comes along, then revived in the face of still newer evidence. In the Observatory column this week, Douglas Quenqua reports on the long-running debate over whether the early winged creature Archaeopteryx ought to be considered a bird or a dinosaur. Paleontologists have gone back and forth on the issue, but the discovery of a dinosaur even older than Archaeopteryx has now given comfort to the bird camp.

headline: Improving Stephens Exits With 2 Other U.S. Women
text: PARIS — Two days ago, Sloane Stephens noted that she was 20 and could do whatever she wanted. The statement seemed less the mutterings of an entitled athlete as it was a recognition by Stephens that as many complications as her newfound success might cause, she has to remember her life — from serves to shopping sprees — is pretty enjoyable for someone of any age.

headline: Albums by Queens of the Stone Age and John Mellencamp
text: QUEENS OF THE STONE AGE

headline: Hand Me a Scalpel, and a Mirror
Racial Disparity in Marijuana Arrests
text: Blacks were nearly four times as likely to be arrested for marijuana possession than whites in 2010.

headline: Roving in the Park With Those Restless Russian Bohemians
text: “Too many characters,” the young woman to my right announced. Her friend had just read the program summary of “The Seagull.” We were seated on the grass in Central Park off 103rd Street, facing what is known as the Pool but looks like a lake, in a grove of grand old trees.

headline: How Work Is Rebounding (or Not) Globally
text: A report on employment from the International Labor Organization paints a picture of a world still struggling to create jobs after the global recession.

headline: Fitting Anniversary for Casey’s Whiff
text: Strikeouts have been soaring in the major leagues over the past decade as our colleague Tyler Kepner documented earlier this season. And the breeze at home plate has been blowing even more frequently in 2013.

headline: Intersection: East Village Style Grit
text: Alexandra Larson, a jewelry designer and East Village resident, explains how her neighborhood is a cornucopia of style.

headline: ‘Cotton Tenants: Three Families’
text: James Agee’s unpublished 1936 article for Fortune about Alabama sharecroppers is being released on Tuesday as a book, with photos by Walker Evans.

headline: A Paean to Forbearance (the Rough Draft)
text: In 1936 Fortune magazine’s editors assigned a relatively unknown and disgruntled staff writer named James Agee to travel to Alabama for the summer and chronicle the lives of sharecroppers. When Agee returned, he was inspired by the subjects he had met and lived with, but frustrated by the limitations of the magazine format. His subjects, he argued, warranted far more than an article.

headline: Continuing to Reduce Costs, Zynga Lays Off 520 Employees
text: Zynga has been trying to leap the yawning gap from Web-based games, where it thrived, to the entirely different and more brutal world of mobile. Monday, it fell into the abyss.

headline: A Tale of Wall St. Excess
text: Turney Duff, former stock trader, recovering cocaine user and first-time author, stepped out the front door of his new home, the ground floor of a modest split-level house in a sleepy Long Island neighborhood.

headline: G.M. to Replace Heinz in the S.&P. 500
text: General Motors is on its way to repaying American taxpayers for its 2009 bailout, but this week the carmaker will distinguish another milestone.

headline: Behind the Rise in House Prices, Wall Street Buyers
text: The last time the housing market was this hot in Phoenix and Las Vegas, the buyers pushing up prices were mostly small time. Nowadays, they are big time — Wall Street big.

headline: Violent Crime in U.S. Rises for First Time Since 2006
text: Violent crime rose in the United States in 2012 for the first time in six years, led by an increase in major crimes in large cities, according to preliminary data released Monday by the F.B.I.

headline: Intel’s New Slogan Shifts Its Focus to the Present
text: THE “sponsors of tomorrow” have determined that consumers are more interested in the present than the future.

headline: Justice Department Defends Holder’s Testimony
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Monday formally told House Republicans that Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s testimony before a Congressional committee last month was “accurate and consistent” with the facts.

headline: Treatment Still Harsh for Roma in France
text: PARIS — In the last three weeks alone, the French police have dismantled Roma encampments in Saint-Denis, just outside Paris, and along the Var River west of Nice. In Lyon, 200 Roma were temporarily housed in a gymnasium when someone set fire to their squat in a disused factory, killing two women and a 12-year-old.

headline: L.I. Representative Faces Treatment for Lung Cancer
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Carolyn McCarthy, a Democrat from Long Island, announced on Monday that she has a treatable form of lung cancer.

headline: An Earlier Hedge Fund Inquiry May Have Led to the SAC Capital Case
text: Some trades by Raj Rajaratnam’s younger brother in a technology stock nearly seven years ago may have inadvertently put SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund behemoth founded by Steven A. Cohen, on regulators’ radar, government documents show.

headline: Stewardesses Blazed a Trail in Feminism
text: A COUPLE of weeks ago I inadvertently stirred up the ire of some flight attendants when I wrote that they complain about working conditions even more than those champion complainers, pilots.

headline: Wall Street Transfixed by SAC Deadline
text: For most of the day Monday, a report about the investor exodus at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors was the most-viewed article on the Bloomberg data terminals that permeate Wall Street trading floors.

headline: U.S. Manufacturing Gauge Falls to June 2009 Level
text: WASHINGTON — A measure of United States manufacturing fell in May to its lowest level since June 2009 as slumping overseas economies and a pullback in business spending reduced new orders and production.

headline: A Youthful Corps Whose Esprit Comes From Hustle
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Every morning before dawn breaks, Mujeeb Hamdard awakes in the mud-walled house where he lives in east Kabul, and starts his trek toward the place he feels most at home.

headline: State Department Offers Rewards for Terrorist Leaders
text: The State Department announced that it was offering rewards for information leading to the location of the leaders of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, as well as other terrorist organizations operating in North and West Africa. The rewards, the first for the region, include $5 million each for the leader of the Qaeda regional franchise, Yahya Abu el-Hamman, and for Mokhtar Belmokhtar, the leader of a group that carried out a raid on a gas plant in Algeria that led to the deaths of at least 37 hostages, including 3 Americans. The department offered up to $7 million for information on Abubakar Shekau, the leader of Boko Haram, an Islamist group in Nigeria.

headline: Egypt: Activist Sentenced to Prison for Insulting Morsi
text: An Egyptian court sentenced an activist to six months in prison on Monday on charges that he insulted President Mohamed Morsi and circulated false news on television. The prison sentence is the first for insulting the president since Mr. Morsi came to power last year. The activist, Ahmed Douma, was expected to post bail and be released on Monday pending the appeal of his case. He was arrested in April after calling Mr. Morsi a killer and criminal, which the court ruled could undermine state security. Egypt has seen a sharp rise in court cases for libel and blasphemy since the revolution in 2011.

headline: It’s Nice to Be Recognized, but Mortifying Too
text: I REMEMBER taking a flight to Disneyland when I was about 4. I was so excited. It was like I was flying to the moon. I got used to flying pretty quickly, traveling between Arizona, where I lived, to visit family in California. Then in the 1980s, I worked as a model in Japan and taught English. So again, more plane time.

headline: A Dispute Over Restrictions in a U.S. Auction of Airwaves
text: WASHINGTON — In the mobile high-speed Internet market, the Obama administration believes it may be necessary to limit competition in order to promote it.

headline: U.S. Adds to Its List of Sanctions Against Iran
text: The Obama administration escalated sanctions pressure against Iran on Monday for the third time in a week, taking actions that could further weaken the country’s already-devalued currency and seriously disrupt its automotive industry, a significant domestic employer and revenue generator for the Iranian government.

headline: Toner, Often Met With a Shrug, Is Having Its Moment
text: As temperatures climb, our thoughts turn to toner: that post-cleansing, pre-moisturizing, cooling concoction treasured in adolescence (Sea Breeze, Bonne Bell Ten O Six) for its ability to remove facial grime onto a cotton ball. Some insist that even in adulthood, their beauty routine would be incomplete without it. Others think it’s an unnecessary step, scoffing that toner, while often refreshing, doesn’t offer any real benefits to the complexion.

headline: Blacks Are Singled Out for Marijuana Arrests, Federal Data Suggests
text: WASHINGTON — Black Americans were nearly four times as likely as whites to be arrested on charges of marijuana possession in 2010, even though the two groups used the drug at similar rates, according to new federal data.

headline: Malware That Drains Your Bank Account Thriving on Facebook
text: In case you needed further evidence that the White Hats are losing the war on cybercrime, a six-year-old so-called Trojan horse program that drains bank accounts is alive and well on Facebook.

headline: Promising New Cancer Drugs Empower the Body’s Own Defense System
text: CHICAGO — The early success of a new class of cancer drugs, revealed in test results released here over the last several days, has raised hope among the world’s top cancer specialists that they may be on the verge of an important milestone in the fight against the disease.

headline: Chief of Staff at Rutgers Facing Discrimination Lawsuit
text: In early April, as the Rutgers president, Robert L. Barchi, was working to defuse a coaching abuse scandal, he named Gregory S. Jackson, a university administrator, to be his chief of staff.

headline: Connecticut Approves Labeling Genetically Modified Foods
text: Connecticut on Monday became the first state to pass a bill that would require food manufacturers to label products that contain genetically modified ingredients — but only after other conditions are met.

headline: How Christie Can Maximize the G.O.P.’s Chances in New Jersey
text: The death of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, creates a confusing electoral situation in the state. There are conflicting interpretations of exactly what New Jersey’s law requires — whether a special election should be held this November, when Gov. Chris Christie will be up for re-election, or in November 2014, when Mr. Lautenberg’s term was set to expire. In the interim, Mr. Christie, a Republican, has the option of appointing a senator, but he is not required to do so.

headline: Taking Account of Risk
text: Paul Tracy remembers it well. He had just arrived in Luanda, Angola, at 4 a.m. when an immigration officer approached him. “Your visa’s not right,” Mr. Tracy, a seasoned traveler, remembers being told. “The date’s wrong.” The officer then asked for several hundred dollars.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,213 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: As Turks Challenge Their Leader’s Power, He Tries to Expand It
text: ISTANBUL — After days of demonstrations that have presented Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan with his worst political crisis in more than a decade of power, the Turkish leader responded on Monday with a supremely confident flourish: he simply turned his back and left, boarding a plane to start a four-day good-will tour of Northern Africa.

headline: Add Tear Gas and Stir: Images of Police Brutality Fuel Anger in Turkey
text: Last Updated, Tuesday, 10:52 a.m. As Sebnem Arsu reports, protests continued for a fourth day in major Turkish cities on Monday, one day after Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan blamed the unrest on what he called “lies” circulating on Twitter and other social networks.

headline: Bringing a Cup to the City by the Bay
text: This year’s America’s Cup promises to transform San Francisco and its waterfront, though with a month before the start of the competition, some worry it won’t be successful.

headline: A Selfless Star of Rare Skills Says Goodbye
text: Point guard Jason Kidd, who announced his retirement Monday, two weeks after a disappointing end to his first season with the Knicks, was the most unusual of N.B.A. superstars. He was a basketball savant who could dominate a game without scoring, who preferred passing to shooting, who elevated his team with his intelligence alone.

headline: Why the Court Was Right to Allow Cheek Swabs
text: SOMETHING astonishing happened Monday: Antonin Scalia, the Supreme Court’s longest-serving member and one of its most conservative justices, joined three liberal justices in a sharply worded dissent arguing for the rights of criminal suspects.

headline: Don’t Trust the Pentagon to End Rape
text: LOS ANGELES — THE Senate Armed Services Committee will hold a hearing today on sexual assault in the military. This comes after months of revelations of rapes and other violent attacks at military bases and academies. At the hearing, the chiefs of staff of the military branches will likely admit that there is a serious problem and insist that the solution involves changing military culture. But the challenge goes far deeper.

headline: The Meanest Season
text: If my body is a buffet, summer is the server who rips the metal covers off the roast beef and the scalloped potatoes so that the hordes can start feeding. And feed they do, mosquitoes and ants and for all I know spiders. (I’m never sure which tiny glutton has made off with the most of me.)

headline: The Way to Produce a Person
text: Dylan Matthews had a fascinating piece about a young man named Jason Trigg in The Washington Post on Sunday. Trigg is a 25-year-old computer science graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who has hit upon what he thinks is the way he can do maximum good for the world. He goes to work each day at a high-frequency trading hedge fund. But, instead of spending his ample salary, he lives the life of a graduate student and gives a large chunk of his money away.

headline: Turkey’s Authoritarian Turn
text: THE huge demonstrations that engulfed Istanbul over the weekend were initially prompted by a small grievance: the government’s decision to build a shopping mall and a replica of Ottoman military barracks in an old, much beloved park where I played as a child. The impending destruction of Gezi Park and Taksim Square, an important civic space with beautiful water fountains and flower stands, has touched a nerve because it seems an effort to erase the face of the old, majestic Istanbul, which has largely disappeared in recent years in favor of shallow, gaudy, stupefied consumerism.

headline: Elite in China Molded in Part by Tiananmen
text: BEIJING — For four days, more than 400 of China’s brightest political minds gathered in smoke-clouded halls at a Beijing hotel, vigorously debating the nation’s future.

headline: U.S. Drops Plan on Screening of Statue Visitors
text: In the staredown at New York City Hall over the Statue of Liberty, the National Park Service blinked.

headline: DNA and Suspicionless Searches
text: Alonzo Jay King Jr. was arrested in Maryland on assault charges in 2009. When he was booked into jail, the police took a sample of his DNA by swabbing the inside of his cheek without a warrant to collect his DNA or probable cause to think it would link him to any crime. His DNA profile matched evidence from a rape in 2003, and he was convicted of that rape.

headline: A Smart Change in Iran Policy
text: The Obama administration has made a useful modification to its Iran policy by lifting sanctions on companies that want to sell cellphones, laptops, encryption software and other similar technology to ordinary Iranians. This should improve the ability of Iranians to circumvent their government’s unrelenting crackdown on dissenting opinion and communicate with each other and the outside world without reprisal.

headline: An Unnecessary Military Expense
text: At a time when the United States government is under pressure to cut spending, and every dollar counts, some members of Congress are pushing for a new missile defense site, possibly on the East Coast, that could eventually cost at least $3.6 billion. The proposal is premature at best and could actually harm America’s national security by denying resources to other more urgently needed and more effective defense programs.

headline: Teachers Ask About Mission They Lived By
text: There are few more pleasurable ways to pass an hour than to talk with veteran teachers who burn with a passion for their chosen work — lighting bonfires in the minds of children.

headline: Experiences as Students and Parents Shape Candidates’ Views on Schools
text: They say that standardized tests have turned students into robots. They speak in apocalyptic terms about the rise of China and the decline of American education. They promise to infuse classrooms with music courses, iPads and one-on-one instruction.

headline: What Are Fathers For?
text: In an age when more and more mothers are sole or primary breadwinners, do fathers bring anything unique to the table?

headline: Internet Hate Speech
text: To the Editor:

headline: Classical Music, Alive and Well
text: To the Editor:

headline: Why Health Care Costs Are So High
His Yiddish Is Good ...
text: To the Editor:

headline: Palestinian Authority’s New Premier Admired as ‘Conscience’
text: JERUSALEM — One of the first academic papers Rami Hamdallah published was about the myriad origins of Palestinian nicknames: he listed 12 categories, among them animals, food, instruments, occupations, natural phenomena and personal characteristics.

headline: Throat Cancer Link to Oral Sex Gains Notice
text: For many years, smoking and drinking were considered the dominant risk factors for cancers of the throat. But on Monday, The Guardian, a British newspaper, reported that the actor Michael Douglas believed that his throat cancer was caused by an infection acquired during oral sex, highlighting a trend that has alarmed many scientists.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 4, 2013
text: “The proud men who wrote the charter of our liberties would not have been so eager to open their mouths for royal inspection.”

headline: With Sentencing Near, Espada Seeks a New Trial
text: Pedro Espada Jr., the former New York state senator who was convicted last year of stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars from a nonprofit health care network he ran, accused the federal trial judge in his case of improperly pressuring the jury to reach its verdict, and filed a motion on Monday seeking a new trial.

headline: Corrections: June 4, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Critical Times of Attack
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Snakes. It had to be snakes.

headline: Swisher, Back in Bronx, Has No Hard Feelings, Bro
text: Professional baseball players sign up for a life filled with negatives. Nick Swisher just chooses to ignore them.

headline: Statements by Detained Terror Suspect Are Focus of Sentencing, and of Debate
text: He was known as “the Doctor,” an Egyptian terrorism suspect who was interviewed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a foreign country where he had been held since his arrest. From the start, he made utterly clear his hatred for the United States, describing how he had even recruited a Brooklyn man to conduct surveillance of the New York Stock Exchange for a possible attack.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 3, 2013

headline: When Billionaire Sets Rules, It’s an Exclusive Race
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Victory in the America’s Cup of 2010 gave Larry Ellison, the tech titan who had spent hundreds of millions of dollars trying to capture sailing’s ultimate prize, the right to set the rules for this year’s regatta.

headline: Young Victim Was Drawn by Street Fight, Jury Is Told
text: In the early morning hours of Sept. 11, 2011, the paths of two 18-year-old women crossed in front of a seafood store in Harlem. The young men in their lives were on opposing sides of a continuing street fight, and the young women were about to be drawn in.

headline: After Shootings, City Police Add Patrols
text: The New York Police Department announced on Monday that it was putting more officers in certain neighborhoods “to suppress further violence” after 26 people were shot and 7 were killed during a 72-hour period from Friday to Sunday.

headline: Connecticut Legislature Approves Budget
text: HARTFORD — Connecticut legislators on Monday passed a two-year, $37.6 billion budget that includes a large expansion of gambling and reflects the degree to which Connecticut faces continuing financial budget distress despite passing a record $1.5 billion tax increase in 2011.

headline: What to Watch on Day 10 at the French Open
text: The field shrinks further for this quarterfinal stage, from eight singles matches per day to four. But though the field is slimming, the schedule is not fan- or television-friendly; matches will remain stretched across two courts, largely to sell more tickets — meaning that the women’s quarterfinals and then the men’s quarterfinals will be simultaneous, making it impossible to watch all the action in its entirety. Play also starts three hours later, meaning that those who have been waking up on 5 a.m. on the East Coast for the start of play can wait all the way until 8 a.m.

headline: Steinbrenner Says Rodriguez Has Disappointed
text: Hal Steinbrenner was at Yankee Stadium on Monday, looking toward next autumn as he took part in the announcement of a new Pinstripe Bowl partnership between the Yankees and the Big Ten Conference.

headline: Polio Virus Discovered in Sewage From Israel
text: The Polio virus has been found in a sewage sample from Israel for the first time since 2002, the World Health Organization announced on Monday. But no children or adults newly paralyzed by polio have been identified in Israel or in Gaza or the West Bank.

headline: Computer-Assisted Vision
text: Liat Negrin, an employee at OrCam who has limited sight, demonstrates the Orcam device, which helps her cross streets, read menus and shop at the supermarket.

headline: Device From Israeli Start-Up Gives the Visually Impaired a Way to Read
text: JERUSALEM — Liat Negrin, an Israeli who has been visually impaired since childhood, walked into a grocery store here recently, picked up a can of vegetables and easily read its label using a simple and unobtrusive camera attached to her glasses.

headline: Hints of a Bigger Drama Awaiting Miami

headline: Some Republicans See I.R.S. Troubles as Means to a Big Goal: Tax Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — When Representative Dave Camp, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, calls conservative activists to the witness table on Tuesday to talk about their experiences in seeking a tax exemption from the Internal Revenue Service, his chief aim will not be to scar the Obama administration or to fuel the continuing Congressional inquiries.

headline: With Overbay in Right, Teixeira Powers Yankees
text: The old right fielder was back Monday night, cheered by the fans at Yankee Stadium once again, and the Yankees’ new right fielder arrived without even the proper glove. He had to borrow one from a relief pitcher.

headline: Yen Below 100 Per Dollar, Again, in Challenge for Abe
text: TOKYO — Less than a month after the yen breached 100 to the dollar, celebrated as a milestone for this export-loving economy, the yen is back on the wrong side of that symbolic threshold. Shares traded in Tokyo have lost 15 percent of their value since May 23, as a euphoric rally suddenly gave way to nerve-racking market swings.

headline: Earning Merit Badges and Learning Knots Under New Flags
text: For more than a century, the Boy Scouts of America has had something of a monopoly on neckerchiefs, knot-tying, merit badges and all manner of backcountry skills for boys, treating snakebite and frostbite alike.

headline: Viktor Kulikov Dies at 91; Led Warsaw Pact Forces

text: MIAMI — The beacon that drew LeBron James to South Beach on that fateful July day three years ago was not a glowing trophy or the bright, bright Florida sun. It was the promise of a partnership and the certain glory that would come with it.

text: As protesters and police continue to clash in Istanbul, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan has left Turkey on a tour of Northern Africa.

headline: For Lautenberg, a Long Career as a Fighter
text: The New Jersey senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who died on Monday, was known for battling the alcohol and tobacco lobbies during his five terms in office.

headline: Kings Arrive Home Fighting Malaise and Facing Deficit to Blackhawks
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — In preparation for a third playoff game in four days, Monday was a day of rest first and reflection second for the Los Angeles Kings, who trail the Chicago Blackhawks, 2-0, in the Western Conference finals.

text: The moment 7-year-old Patrick Cummings stumbled on a horse racing show from Philadelphia Park in 1988, his life changed forever. It was the first day that his parents had cable.

headline: Fashion Designers Awards Show Hits Its Stride
text: After years of trying, the Council of Fashion Designers of America finally has its annual awards show down pat. There were few surprises on Monday night at Lincoln Center, except maybe the number of designers who professed to be surprised that they had won.

headline: A Reluctant Prince (a Dashing Young Man in Uniform)
text: I was in New York recently, helping my 18-year-old daughter, Lilly, a student at the Fashion Institute of Technology, paint her new apartment. To pass the time I was telling her stories about my student days in New York, when I was a cadet at West Point and often visited the city on leave. She had just traveled up to West Point to attend the Yearling (sophomore) prom with a cadet from back home in Tennessee. With that in mind I asked her if she wanted to hear a romantic story about a night when I was a Yearling and went on a date to a prom. She did.

This two-hour Season 8 premiere features auditions in New York, Los Angeles and San Antonio, leading up to live shows at Radio City Music Hall. Nick Cannon, above, hosts.

headline: Yen Strengthens Again, in Challenge for Abe

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 4
text: NEWS The immersion of today’s leaders of China in the political experimentation that preceded the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989 raises the question of whether they will be open to new ideas and discussion. Andrew Jacobs reports from Beijing, and Chris Buckley from Hong Kong.

headline: States Strive for Balance Between Tiger Conservation and Tourism
text: MUMBAI— In July last year, the Indian Supreme Court banned tourism in the core areas of 41 tiger reserves in an attempt to protect the 1,700 tigers in the country. Three months later, the court reversed its decision but told the state-managed reserves to abide by new guidelines drafted by the National Tiger Conservation Authority.

headline: Pistorius Case Adjourned Until August
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — The Paralympic and Olympic track star Oscar Pistorius, accused of killing his girlfriend in a case that has drawn fascination across the globe, returned to court here on Tuesday for a procedural hearing, his first appearance since he was granted bail in February.

headline: Merkel Visits Flood-Stricken Regions of Germany
text: PIRNA, Germany — When Chancellor Angela Merkel arrived in this Baroque town on Tuesday to wade through ankle-deep floodwaters and dole out human sympathy, Toni Schacha laid down his caulking gun on a stack of sandbags and strained to catch a glimpse of her.
