headline: U.N. Panel Reports Increasing Brutality by Both Sides in Syria
text: GENEVA — Reporting “new levels of brutality” in Syria’s more than two-year-old conflict, United Nations investigators said on Tuesday that they believed that chemical weapons and more indiscriminate bombing had been used in recent weeks and urged world powers to cut off supplies of weapons that could only result in more civilian casualties.

headline: A Photographic Champion of Latinos
text: This is Puerto Rican Week in New York City, when flags cover cars, banners and bodies, accompanied by a two-three beat that sends spirits soaring. But in one newsroom, every week is Puerto Rican Week — and Colombian, Cuban, Dominican, Ecuadorean, Mexican and Salvadoran Week, too.

headline: How Much Is Michael Bolton Worth to You?
text: A few weeks ago, I met Barry Arakelian a minute after he got scammed at a Tom Petty concert. Arakelian had paid a scalper $375 for two tickets (face value: $135) outside the Beacon Theater in Manhattan. The tickets, however, turned out to be fakes, and Arakelian, who was getting the evil eye from his girlfriend, approached a nearby police officer for help. But the officer said that he couldn’t do anything unless Arakelian could locate the scalper in the crush of people. By that point the scalper was long gone; Arakelian was embarrassed. Naturally, a minute later, he turned and shouted to no one in particular, “Who’s got two tickets?”

headline: What’s on Your Summer Reading List?
text: Last weekend, The New York Times Book Review put out its annual Summer Reading edition. That, along with our own summer reading contest, inspired us to ask you what you’ll be reading this summer, and what great summer memories of reading you would like to share.

text: The federal government opened its antitrust case against Apple on Monday, saying the company and five book publishers worked together in the six weeks before Apple’s deadline of Jan. 21, 2010, to raise the average price of an e-book, Brian X. Chen reports in The New York Times.

headline: I.M.F. Tells France to Continue to Focus on Growth
text: PARIS — The shrinking French economy will resume growth in the second half of the year, the International Monetary Fund forecast on Tuesday, but it urged France to focus on removing impediments to growth and to stimulate domestic demand.

headline: A Company Flourishes by Selling Social Transformation
text: When Benjamin O’Keefe read the words of Abercrombie & Fitch’s chief executive, Mike Jeffries, suggesting that the retailer wanted its clothes worn only by thin, attractive “cool kids,” he wasn’t happy. Mr. O’Keefe, 18, struggled with weight issues in middle and high school and felt compelled to speak out. He created a petition on the Web site Change.org, encouraging Mr. Jeffries to sell clothes to people of all sizes. That was on May 8; the petition has now attracted more than 75,000 signatures.

headline: Judicial Picks Set the Stage for a Battle in the Senate
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s announcement of three nominees to an important federal appeals court on Tuesday is adding fuel to a larger fight on Capitol Hill over whether the minority party in the Senate has too much power to thwart a president’s agenda.

headline: Europe Imposes a Tariff on Chinese Solar Panels, for Less Than Expected
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s trade chief on Tuesday carried out his threat to impose tariffs on solar panels from China. But in a significant concession to Chinese lobbying and after opposition from some European leaders and industry executives, he significantly watered down the penalties.

headline: A Literary Mind, Under the Spell of Drugs and a MacBook
text: A few times a year I’ll buy a book or a CD because of its title alone. “Feels Like the Third Time,” the Freakwater disc, for example. It happens to be good.

headline: Cliffhanger at SAC
text: Wall Street was in suspense over what would become of SAC Capital Advisors, as the embattled hedge fund faced a regularly scheduled quarterly deadline for investors to ask for their money back. For most of Monday, a report about the investor exodus was the most-viewed article on Bloomberg data terminals. With SAC facing an intensifying insider trading investigation, a major reason for the concern on Wall Street is a commercial one.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Slathering on Sunscreen Can Prevent Aging Skin
text: Slathering on sunscreen daily can fight aging skin, big investor money fuels housing prices, Ford recalls 465,000 cars for possible fuel leaks and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Add Google’s Street View to Apple Maps
text: One of the major complaints about Apple Maps (aside from its odd inaccuracies) is that it lacks anything like Google’s Street View, which allows a user to see photographic images of the location being sought.

text: Salesforce.com agreed on Tuesday to buy ExactTarget, a provider of marketing software services, for about $2.5 billion, further bolstering its social marketing offerings.

headline: Check In | A Venetian Palace With a View
text: The 25-room Aman Canal Grande opens this month in Venice’s San Polo neighborhood. You would be hard pressed to beat its setting, perched on the Grand Canal in the 16th-century Palazzo Papadopoli, an example of Venetian neo-Renaissance and rococo architecture at its finest. The new hotel preserves much of the palazzo’s original artwork, including frescoes by the 18th-century Italian artist Giovanni Battista Tiepolo (now decorating the Aman’s Italian and Thai restaurants). San Polo itself is one of Venice’s less chaotic, residential districts, with the Rialto Market and the Scuola Grande di San Rocco a few minutes away by foot. Guest rooms have silk walls, twinkling chandeliers and views of private gardens. The hotel’s garden terrace faces onto the Grand Canal, and from the roof, when clear weather permits, you can see past Venice’s chimney pots and terra cotta rooftops all the way to the Swiss Alps.

headline: An Unusual Theater Revival in China: An American Play About Press Freedom
text: BEIJING — One night in December 2011 I found myself sitting in a freezing theater south of Tiananmen Square in the Chinese capital watching an American play about press freedoms and government control. The play, “Top Secret: Battle for the Pentagon Papers,” portrayed in fictional terms the legal fight by The Washington Post to publish the Pentagon Papers over the vigorous objections of the Nixon administration. It was written by Geoffrey Cowan — a former dean of the Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism at the University of Southern California and former director of Voice of America — and Leroy Aarons.

headline: M.L.S. Teams Learn Concacaf Opponents
text: Five teams from Major League Soccer, four based in the United States and one in Canada, learned their opponents for the 2013-14 Concacaf Champions League tournament in a draw held in Miami on Monday evening.

headline: American Tourist Gang-Raped in Manali, Police Say

headline: Reagan for Health Care Reform
text: With many right-wing politicians dead set against expanding Medicaid, the Republican governor of Ohio, John Kasich, needed cover for going along. Facts and figures and kindness surely weren’t enough, what with his colleagues comparing health care reform to a “hostage” situation. But in an op-ed for USA Today he settled on a great excuse: It’s what Ronald Reagan would have done.

headline: The Return of McMansions
text: Construction of new homes dropped off a cliff during the housing bust. But where there has been building of single-family homes in recent years, the homes have been getting bigger.

headline: Deacon Jones Dies at 74; Made Quarterback Sack Brutal and Enthralling
text: Deacon Jones, a prototype of the pass-rushing defensive end who became a master of the sack and one of the National Football League’s greatest defensive players with the Los Angeles Rams’ line known as the Fearsome Foursome, died on Monday in Anaheim Hills, Calif. He was 74.

headline: Former Hacker Testifies at Private’s Court-Martial
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — Adrian Lamo, the former computer hacker who reported Pfc. Bradley Manning to military authorities in May 2010 after Private Manning confided that he had provided vast archives of secret government documents to WikiLeaks, testified at the soldier’s court-martial on Tuesday that he saw parallels between his own youthful hacking offenses and those of the young Army intelligence analyst.

headline: Bill to Alter Bush-Era Education Law Gives States More Room
text: Renewing the effort to revise No Child Left Behind, the signature Bush-era federal education law, Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, introduced a new version on Tuesday that he said would “replace the failed tenets” of the law.

headline: Heat’s Big Three Rise Again
text: At some point Monday night in Game 7 of the N.B.A. Eastern Conference finals, Miami Heat fans must have decided their team is the sporting equivalent of a devilish 5-year-old, the little boy who runs around creating havoc and testing everyone’s last nerve only to turn up at your hip holding a cute picture he drew in art class and beaming up at you with a heart-melting smile. Game 7 against the Indiana Pacers was the Heat’s art-class creation and the smiles coming at the end said, “Aren’t we adorable?”

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates Whether G.M. Should Expand Air Bag Recall
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has begun investigating whether General Motors should have recalled about 400,000 vehicles, instead of only 6,900, for an air bag problem, according to a report the agency posted Tuesday on its Web site.

headline: How Storm Chasers Have Made Tornado Alley Safer
text: Here’s a “Your Dot” contribution exploring the surprising mix of factors — including data gathered by storm-chasing scientists — that have steadily made America’s tornado hot zone a safer place, despite the meteorological hazards that are a fact of life there.

text: I have a nephew graduating today, and am at the commencement (and, sad to say, with access to Princeton wifi); anyway, the high point so far was the Latin salutation, which was apparently — judging from the reactions of those who understood it — a spectacularly funny stand-up routine. Who knew?

headline: Poultry Plant in Deadly Fire Won Plaudits From Chinese
text: BEIJING — A local Communist Party official called it an “inspiring” factory three years ago. Local officials later gave it the “leading enterprise” label for its innovation in processing chickens. But the official homages to the Jilin Baoyuanfeng Poultry Plant, where at least 120 people died this week in a fast-moving fire, now serve as little more than stark reminders of the blind eyes turned to the dangerous conditions facing many workers in China.

headline: Banks Lag on Consumer-Friendly Checking Practices

headline: Tony Awards: In Performance With Billy Porter and Stark Sands
text: The second video in our special Tony Awards In Performance series is with two actors nominated for their roles in the British-set musical “Kinky Boots”: Billy Porter, who plays Lola, a drag performer, and Stark Sands, who portrays Charlie, the young shoe-factory owner who enlists Lola to help turn around his struggling business. In the number “Not My Father’s Son,” both men sing about not living up to a parent’s expectations. This cinematic interpretation was shot at T. O. Dey Shoes, the company that made the show’s signature boots.

headline: Afghans Say New Bodies Have Been Found Near a Former U.S. Base
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Soon after family members found what they believe are the bodies of the last three people still missing out of 17 Afghan men detained by an American Special Forces team in Wardak Province, another tragedy found them: they said one person was killed and another was critically wounded on Tuesday when Afghan Army troops opened fire on the family members at an unruly demonstration to protest the deaths of their relatives.

headline: President Names Court Nominees
text: President Obama announced his plans to nominate three candidates for the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

headline: Decoding Strawberry Jam
text: It happens every year in late spring. Seduced by a flat of strawberries, their scent wafting through the farmers’ market, first-time canners gather little glass jars and attempt preserves. But in some cruel twist of fate, strawberry turns out to be one of the more difficult jams to make. It’s often runny. Frustrated cooks toss up their hands and vow never to try again.

headline: Peak Performances Announces New Season
text: The Peak Performances Series at Montclair State University in New Jersey will feature 13 new works, including five commissioned world premieres, for the 2013-2014 season starting Sept. 19, the artistic director Jedediah Wheeler announced Tuesday. The season runs through June 15.

headline: The Plane That Did Not Crash, and Other News
text: After being away for much of the past week or so, I’m catching up with a few issues, along with some other items of interest.

headline: Pierre-Paul Has Surgery for a Herniated Disk
text: Jason Pierre-Paul, the nimble Giants defensive end who confounds opponents’ blocking with a mix of agility and strength, had surgery to repair a herniated disk in his lower back on Tuesday. The team said Pierre-Paul would be out three months, seriously jeopardizing his availability for the Giants’ season opener at Dallas on Sept. 8.

headline: Bear’s Visit Keeps Children Inside and a Town Buzzing
text: The warning sent by school officials on Tuesday morning seemed more suited for the Alaskan wild than the bustling suburb of Montclair, N.J.: All outdoor activities were suspended because a black bear was lurking about.

headline: Seeing the Trees and the Forest
text: ISTANBUL — We are still keeping toll — of injuries and arrests, of nightly standoffs between demonstrators and police, of the points lost on the Turkish stock market. Throughout the country, the streets in large cities are littered with tear-gas canisters, shop fronts are covered in spray paint, and police cars lie overturned. A confederation of public workers’ unions has called for a general strike. Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the iron fist of Turkish politics for over a decade, now looks like a man grasping at straws.

headline: A Spanish Shrimp Crisp With a Taste of the Sea
text: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tweaked for home cooks.

headline: Rev. Will D. Campbell, Maverick Minister in Civil Rights Era, Dies at 88
text: The Rev. Will D. Campbell, a renegade preacher and author who joined the civil rights struggle in the 1950s, quit organized religion and fought injustice with nonviolent protests and a storyteller’s arsenal of autobiographical tales and fictional histories, died on Monday night in Nashville. He was 88.

headline: How Rebecca Parker, Editor, Does It
text: Rebecca Hughes Parker is the editor in chief of The FCPA Report, a legal publication about anticorruption issues. Previously, she spent eight years as a litigator at a large law firm, a job she took while pregnant with her twin girls. She lives in Manhattan with her husband and three daughters, 8-year-old twins and a 2-year-old. Her husband is the primary caregiver for the children. They have never had a nanny or a housekeeper.

headline: Libertarian Populism and Its Limits
text: I recommend reading Peter Suderman’s entire post on the relationship between libertarianism and what I’ve been calling “reform conservatism,” but the ending, especially, is very perceptive about the state of play on the American right today:

headline: Tackling New York With Children
text: Next week, the Travel section will start a new series of articles on traveling with children in big cities. The series will include tips on everything from unexpected kid-friendly attractions to basics like where to eat and find a bathroom.

headline: Obama’s Appeals Court Nominees
text: President Obama is taking the step of nominating three people at once to the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, a key federal court, in a challenge to Republicans who have blocked earlier nominations.

headline: Townsend’s Whirlwind Day Includes a Fast Win, and an Award
text: PARIS — Taylor Townsend was in a hurry on the way to the quarterfinals of the French Open junior championships on Tuesday.

headline: Yoko Ono Receives Chapin Humanitarian Award
text: Yoko Ono Lennon was honored on Monday night with the ASCAP Harry Chapin Humanitarian Award at a gala dinner in Manhattan for her efforts to raise money for the world’s poor through the “Imagine There’s No Hunger” campaign. The award is given each year by WhyHunger, a charity founded in 1975 by the songwriter Harry Chapin that finances anti-poverty efforts throughout the world.

headline: Windows Phones Gain Some Traction on Verizon Wireless
text: There is hope yet for Windows Phone, the smartphone operating system that could.

headline: Belmont Starters Put Through Final Preparations
text: The field for Saturday’s Belmont Stakes is firming up, with a full field of 15 horses likely to draw into the race. Many of the contenders completed their final workouts last weekend, and others traveled from Kentucky to New York. Of the contenders, Freedom Child, Orb and Palace Malice have been most impressive in their training.

headline: The Gun Report: June 4, 2013
text: Guns at the public pool? If the N.R.A. has its way, Charleston, W. Va., may be facing a new reality this summer.

headline: After Looking Bored at Forum, Weiner Finds Energy to Tussle With Press
text: He slouched back deeply into his chair, played with his pen, stole glances at his Blackberry and stared off into space.

headline: I.R.S. Spent $4.1 Million on Conference, Audit Finds
text: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service spent $4.1 million on a single conference in Southern California in 2010, paying top dollar for hotel rooms, $27,500 for a keynote speaker and tens of thousands of dollars for gifts to the 2,600 people who attended, according to a newly released Treasury Department audit.

headline: France Dares to Dream as Tsonga Defeats Federer
text: PARIS — Jo-Wilfried Tsonga’s surprisingly straightforward 7-5, 6-3, 6-3 quarterfinal victory over Roger Federer on Tuesday at the French Open could be seen through two different lenses.

headline: Could Pretty Cars Be the Key to Attracting Younger Car Nuts?

headline: Wawrinka Proves Tireless in Stopping Gasquet in Fourth Round
text: Stanislas Wawrinka battled back from two sets down to defeat Richard Gasquet in fourth-round French Open match Monday that featured the two best one-handed backhands in the game. After Gasquet outplayed Wawrinka in the first two sets, Wawrinka settled in for the long haul, lengthening out points as he tried to break down his French rival. Wawrinka told reporters after the match, “When I was 2-0 down, I was thinking something really simple. I was thinking: point after point I was thinking to make him work, to make him work hard, because I know if he start to be a little bit tired, then he’s not doing so much with his racquet, he’s not pushing so much pressure.”

headline: Man Arrested in South Carolina Over Killing on Queens Bus
text: A man wanted in the shooting death of a 14-year-old girl aboard a Queens bus last month has been arrested in South Carolina, the authorities said on Tuesday.

headline: 7 Injured in Explosion at a College in Rockland County
text: An explosion at a college in Rockland County on Tuesday injured seven people, fire officials said.

headline: Avoiding the Easy Trap of Buying High
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: The Hurdles to Reviving an Investment Bank Partnership
text: Goldman Sachs’s initial public offering in 1999 seemed to hammer a nail in the coffin for the partnership model in investment banking. Now, the activist investment firm Knight Vinke is suggesting that UBS could adopt something like a partnership structure as part of its plan to split wealth management from investment banking. The breakup idea is overambitious today. Only with time, luck and possibly more capital could an employee-owned UBS investment bank be made to work.

headline: Bubbles With Bluefish, but Not Necessarily Champagne
text: Bubbles go beautifully with fried foods, but bubbly doesn’t always have to mean Champagne. With these savory flavors, which will be deeper and more assertive if you choose bluefish, I would skip the cavas, sekts and proseccos to seek out a good, dry sparkling Vouvray, from the chenin blanc grape, which has a slightly richer texture than most Champagnes. Chenin blanc has a flavor that suggests a combination of lemon and honeysuckle that you feel as much as you taste; texturally it will meld well with the crisp panko crust. For a surprise twist, and particularly if you use bluefish, you could try a sparkling red, like a savory Lambrusco.  Just make sure the label says secco, for dry, and not amabile, for slightly sweet.

headline: Davis Stands a Little Taller in the Batter’s Box
text: MIAMI – When the Mets pulled out of South Florida on Sunday, they did so clearly having lost all the momentum that came from a five-game winning streak and a four-game sweep of the Yankees.

headline: Fort Hood Suspect Says Rampage Was to Defend Afghan Taliban Leaders
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist accused of killing 13 people, told a judge on Tuesday that he believed he was defending the lives of the Taliban leadership in Afghanistan from American military personnel when he went on a shooting rampage at Fort Hood here in November 2009.

headline: Calculating Apple’s True U.S. Tax Rate
text: One lesson from the Senate hearing about Apple’s offshore tax planning is that figuring out what a multinational company actually pays in taxes is harder than it should be. At the risk of sounding Clintonesque, it depends on what the meaning of “pays” is.

headline: Christie Decides on October Vote for New Senator
text: TRENTON — Gov. Chris Christie announced on Tuesday a highly unusual special election that was immediately criticized for costing the state $24 million and setting up a schedule that was likely to confuse the voting public. Voters will go to the polls on a Wednesday in October to cast ballots for a new senator, then return just three weeks later for the regularly scheduled general election, in which Mr. Christie will stand for a second term.

headline: Link to Marathon Bombing Rattles City Known for Its Tolerance
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — On April 15, Peter Payack left this city, where he has lived for 40 years, and crossed the Charles River to watch his son run the Boston Marathon.

headline: If You Like Foreigner, Try Snow Patrol
text: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Scene City: Fashion Designers Take a Bow
text: The Council of Fashion Designers of America hosted its annual fashion awards at Alice Tully Hall.

headline: Floods Across Central Europe
text: Heavy rains swelled major rivers in Germany, the Czech Republic and Austria causing widespread destruction.

headline: U.S. to Lease Federal Waters for Commercial Offshore Wind Energy
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government will hold the first lease sale for commercial offshore wind energy projects at the end of July, the Interior Department announced on Tuesday.

headline: Suspect in Colorado Killings Enters Insanity Plea
text: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — James E. Holmes, the former neuroscience student charged with killing 12 people inside a Colorado movie theater last July, changed his plea on Tuesday to not guilty by reason of insanity.

headline: Chrysler Rejects Regulator’s Request to Recall Jeeps
text: DETROIT — In an escalating confrontation with regulators, Chrysler said on Tuesday that it would not recall 2.7 million Jeeps that the government contends are defective and prone to fires in the event of rear-impact collisions.

headline: Scene City: After the Fashion Awards
text: Vera Wang Celebrates the C.F.D.A. Awards with a dinner, with guests including Anna Wintour, Andy Cohen and Calvin Klein.

headline: A South Korean’s Soundless Journey Through Junior Tennis
text: PARIS — A 15-year-old from South Korea has emerged as one of the world’s top junior tennis players without ever hearing the sound of a ball being struck or a score being called. He is deaf.

text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: When Corton’s Chef Crossed the East River
text: This summer, Paul Liebrandt is opening a restaurant in Williamsburg.

headline: In Viacom Deal, Amazon Scoops Up Children’s Shows
text: If parents of preschoolers want to plop their children in front of the laptop or tablet to watch “Blue’s Clues” and “Dora the Explorer,” they may have to join Amazon’s subscription streaming service.

text: Hunched at a table at Bar Masa, four stories above Columbus Circle, Paul Liebrandt was nibbling and sipping his way toward an $800 bill and talking about art.

headline: Fluent in French, Colloquially
text: Hungry for rillettes or a blanquette? Why yearn for the Boulevard St.-Germain when the Bowery might do. Since last summer, more than a dozen French restaurants have opened in New York, most of them bistros.

headline: Can a Shaving Company Produce Another Viral Video?
text: We recently published a small-business conversation with Michael Dubin in which he talked about how he had introduced his company, Dollar Shave Club, with a funny video that went viral — and how he was trying to build on the success of that video to create a full-fledged lifestyle brand.

headline: Gallup Identifies Factors That Led to Its G.O.P. Skew in November
text: The Gallup Organization has identified a series of factors that contributed to its overestimation of support for Mitt Romney in the 2012 presidential election, including problems with its survey sample and methodology, according to an in-depth analysis of its procedures released Tuesday.

headline: Once Uncertain of Parker’s Toughness, Spurs Now Rely on It
text: SAN ANTONIO — When Gregg Popovich first set eyes on Tony Parker at a predraft camp in Chicago in 2001, he did not need long to reach an assessment.

headline: Whiskey Makers Court Jewish Market
text: For avid whiskey lovers, few events are more eagerly anticipated than WhiskyFest, an enormous tasting that touches down in several American cities throughout the year. But when sponsors of the New York festival suddenly moved it last year from Tuesday to Friday and Saturday, many regulars were unable to attend.

headline: The Little Land of Big Houses
text: When Kevin Liau gives directions to his house, an updated four-bedroom 1960 ranch at the northernmost end of Englewood Cliffs, he tells friends it is one of the smallest on his block. But Mr. Liau’s house holds another distinction: it happens to be one of the older models around — as residents of this affluent Bergen County community facing the Hudson seem to have a propensity for tearing down and rebuilding.

headline: Bike Sharing in New York: The Tourist’s Perspective
text: When New York’s transportation commissioner, Janette Sadik-Khan, announced plans for the city’s bike-sharing program at a 2011 press conference she called it “a fast, easy, affordable way to get around town.”

headline: A Casino Outing Spoiled by the Ace Up His Sleeve
text: Like a runner fast off the mark, “21” is energetic at its start. But races and plays can be long, and what was once full of vigor can wear itself out.

headline: Sebelius Asked Companies to Support Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, disclosed on Tuesday that she had made telephone calls to three companies regulated by her department and urged them to help a nonprofit group promote President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Erdogan Has Been Warned
text: ISTANBUL — “HISTORY shows that if nations cannot manage to win all together, they are destined to lose all together,” declared Turkey’s prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, on the first anniversary of his 2007 re-election. “We defend freedom, justice, democracy and welfare for everybody.”

headline: Close to Its Home, Walgreen Tests Energy-Saving Ideas
text: CHICAGO — As the Walgreen Company expands its sales items to fresh salads, Redbox DVD rentals and digital photo scanners, among other products, its consumption of power keeps inching up.

headline: Special Election Timing in New Jersey Points to a Weak G.O.P. Field
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has scheduled an Oct. 16 special election to replace Frank R. Lautenberg, the Democratic senator who died on Monday. Mr. Christie will appoint a replacement for Mr. Lautenberg in the interim, but he has yet to announce his pick. His choice of timing for the special election, however, may indicate that he expects the Republican candidates to be weak.

headline: In Moscow, Mayor’s Move Could Mean Snap Election
text: MOSCOW — The mayor of Moscow said on Tuesday that he would like to step down two years before the end of his term and hold snap elections on Sept. 8, radically accelerating the election cycle in an apparent attempt to minimize the risk of political change.

headline: NATO to Send Team to Libya to Assess Security Aid
text: BRUSSELS — NATO is sending a team of experts to Libya to assess how the alliance can provide security assistance, notably military training, to help the turbulent North African nation combat Islamist militants claiming allegiance to Al Qaeda and other threats.

headline: Promoting ‘Social Welfare’ by Defeating Gun Control
text: What with the ongoing scuffle over the Internal Revenue Service improperly targeting conservative organizations that applied for 501(c)(4) status, it can be hard to keep in mind what 501(c)(4)s are supposed to do — and not do.

headline: Carbone
text: Inside the fancy red-sauce joint where any hope of moderation is abandoned.

headline: A Red-Sauce Joint Steals the Show
text: At Carbone, they don’t ask if you’ve dined with them before. Even if you haven’t, the answer would still be yes. This is supposed to be the Italian restaurant where you celebrated your birthday before anyone told you that chicken scarpariello isn’t Italian.

headline: U.S. Trade Nominee Has $490,000 in Cayman Fund
text: WASHINGTON — Michael Froman, a longtime White House economic aide nominated to be President Obama’s trade representative, has nearly half a million dollars in a fund based in the Cayman Islands, according to financial documents provided to the Senate Finance Committee.

headline: Part D, Without Paying a Dime
text: Here’s a nonhypothetical question: If an older person without much money could receive prescription drug insurance — i.e. Medicare Part D — at no cost, why wouldn’t he apply?

headline: A Study Makes It Official: New York Is the Most Competitive City
text: Anyone who has tried to park a car on a Manhattan street may already have deemed New York the world’s most competitive city. A new study concluded that it is and will stay that way for at least another 12 years.

headline: Minneapolis Museum Gets Major Collection of Japanese Art
text: The Minneapolis Institute of Art’s collection of Japanese works has suddenly expanded thanks to a combined gift and purchase from the California businessman Willard “Bill” Clark and his wife Elizabeth.

headline: Breast Feeding Killed My Focus on Work. I Don’t Miss It.
text: Years ago, when I lived on the Upper West Side, I used to have coffee with a bunch of mothers from my daughter’s school — the Philosophy Day School, “opposite Mayor Bloomberg’s house,” as we used to tell the taxi drivers. We would drop our children off in the morning and walk around the corner to drink mediocre brew and forge connections at Nectar Cafe.

text: PARIS — The first of the quarterfinals may have been about to get under way on the Philippe Chatrier and Suzanne Lenglen courts, but for some fans and journalists, the most powerful draw was coming from another corner of the Roland Garros complex.

headline: U.S. Bans 37 Firms in Dispute With Iran

headline: At the C.F.D.A. Awards Ceremony, Not a Lot of Reflection (Besides the Mirrors)
text: Inside the fishbowl of a lobby at Alice Tully Hall, where walls of glass offered a floor-to-ceiling view of guests arriving for the Council of Fashion Designers of America awards on Monday evening, swam two women in almost scandalously revealing black gowns.

headline: F.B.I. Pick Could Offer Look Into World of Ray Dalio

And it’s not unusual that the financial institution where Mr. Comey, a former deputy attorney general, had worked was a hedge fund — you may recall that Lawrence H. Summers, the former Treasury secretary, had a short spell at D. E. Shaw, making millions.

headline: Kevin P. Maloney
text: Mr. Maloney, 54, is a founder and principal of the Property Markets Group, a real estate acquisition and development firm specializing in residential projects in New York, South Florida and Chicago. The company often works in partnership with other developers.

headline: Egypt Convicts Workers at Foreign Nonprofit Groups, Including 16 Americans
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian criminal court on Tuesday found more than three dozen employees of foreign nonprofit groups, including 16 Americans, guilty of receiving illegal funds from abroad and operating unlicensed organizations in what the United States has criticized as a politically motivated trial that mars Egypt’s transition to post-revolutionary democracy.

headline: Hepatitis Warning Leads to Recall of Frozen Berries
text: A berry and pineapple producer in Oregon announced late Monday night that it was voluntarily recalling a frozen blend of organic berries after the Centers for Disease Control linked it to a multistate outbreak of hepatitis A, a virus that affects the liver.

headline: Boxes of Art History, Free to a Good Home
text: The photographer D. James Dee is giving away his archive of about 250,000 unlabeled color transparencies and slides.

headline: On Anniversary of Arab-Israeli War, a Palestinian Plea
text: LATRUN, West Bank — On the second night of the war in June 1967, Israeli forces captured the fort at Latrun, a West Bank enclave that protrudes like a half-blown bubble into Israeli territory. Israel had tried to take in 1948 — and failed.

headline: Pelé Comes to Town as Cosmos Take Flight (Sort of)
text: It seemed like old times.

headline: He Captured Modern Art, and Now Is Letting It Go
text: Help yourself to D. James Dee’s luscious, sprawling photographic archive of the modern New York art scene. He has about 250,000 color transparencies and slides, ranging in size from 35 millimeter to 8 by 10 inches, documenting the work of almost every important artist of the last 40 years and installations at some of the most influential galleries. And, yes, he’s giving them away.

headline: With Bellows and Growls, a Band Gets Back to Work
text: Tomahawk sent up a distress flare as its first song at the Best Buy Theater on Sunday night, but with a typically mordant twist. The song was “Mayday,” and against both the coiled tension of its verses and the volcanic release of its chorus, Mike Patton bellowed or warbled or growled, with all the pique and derangement expected of him. He didn’t sound marooned so much as cynically above the fray.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Pinterest Formula and ‘Arrested Development’ Security
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: On Screen, No Scars or Scandals for Bolshoi
text: The Ballet in Cinema series has been enlightening many of us about troupes abroad, but no company is making more of the opportunity than the Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow. As if to show that all is running smoothly as usual, it transmitted a high-definition presentation of “Romeo and Juliet” on Sunday to movie theaters across North America.

headline: Q. & A. | Sharon Stone on Fashion and Philanthropy
text: On May 21, the stars of Cannes flocked to Hôtel du Cap-Eden-Roc to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the luxury jeweler de Grisogono. The soiree, “Seduction in Cannes,” was hosted by the de Grisogono founder Fawaz Gruosi, who seemed genuinely touched that the party had attracted so many revelers. “My first party was only 50 people,” Gruosi said during a rare quiet moment in the night’s proceedings, which included a fashion show, fireworks and a 500-person seated dinner. “It is an institution of the Cannes festival.”

headline: Metro, Rymdkapsel, Quell Memento and Tetris Blitz
text: METRO

headline: Young Star Raises Funds for Making Younger Stars
text: Most of what you need to know about the classical superstar Lang Lang is helpfully summed up by the biography on his official Twitter profile: “Pianist. Mentor. Lifelong Student. Traveler. I believe that classical music is for everyone!”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Germany and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Germany, Turkey, China and Spain.

headline: Attraction, Revulsion and Discussion
text: In “Berries and Bulls,” a premiere by the choreographer Tiffany Mills, one side of the stage features towers of stacked paper and books. The dancer Jeffrey Duval, with boyish concentration — though he is well into manhood — sits in front of them and exactingly folds a paper airplane, pressing his index finger down hard on the surface to make perfect creases. He reclines on his back and rests the airplane on his chest. It’s not the smoothest of takeoffs.

headline: In DNA Ruling, a Cruel Blow to Scriptwriters
text: Do Anthony M. Kennedy, Clarence Thomas, Stephen G. Breyer, Samuel A. Alito Jr. and John G. Roberts Jr. not own televisions?

headline: The Eiffel Tower’s Voice
text: Using drumsticks and mallets, composer Joseph Bertolozzi is turning Paris’ Eiffel Tower into a giant percussive instrument.

headline: That Instrument Known as the Eiffel Tower
text: PARIS — The composer Joseph Bertolozzi, bearing a meditative look, stood with his feet apart in front of a door frame inside the Eiffel Tower. Then, 187 feet above the Champ de Mars garden, he pulled a latex mallet from his tool bag and hit the frame hard, and then softer, with agility and rhythm.

headline: From Lottery to Oligopoly in Wireless Spectrum
text: For all its sleek iThing patina today, the origins of the wireless communications revolution had a decidedly Wild West feel.

headline: In Taksim Square
text: A view of Taksim Square in Istanbul on Tuesday, an area that has seen violent clashes between protesters and the police.

headline: Better Late Than Never on Deeming Nonbanks Too Big to Fail
text: New systemic-risk tags are better late than never. The American International Group, GE Capital and Prudential Financial are among the first nonbank firms to be deemed systemically important financial institutions by the Financial Stability Oversight Council. These are no-brainers for the moniker. The trouble is, five years on, watchdogs are still bogged down in the last crisis rather than looking out for the next one.

headline: Long Ago, a Pilot Landed on an Uptown Street. That’s Where the Bar Was.
text: Surprise airplane landings always make headlines. Who will forget Capt. Chesley Sullenberger steering a US Airways jetliner onto the Hudson River in 2009? Then there was a Long Island man who touched down on Rockaway Beach in 2011 and, more recently, a stunt pilot who coasted down safely onto a Suffolk County road.

headline: Alzheimer’s Drugs May Have Heart Benefits
text: A new observational study suggests that drugs commonly used to treat Alzheimer’s disease may have another benefit: preventing heart attacks and premature death.

headline: Learning the Uses of Disorder
text: Just as an evening of aimless movement is difficult to endure, too much order can kill a dance. In her new work, the task for the choreographer Joanna Kotze is to mess things up.

headline: Quirky Leader of Ohio State Is Set to Retire After Remarks
text: E. Gordon Gee, the colorful, highly paid president of Ohio State University who has been embroiled in a series of embarrassing gaffes, announced Tuesday that he would retire on July 1.

headline: New Exchange Is Formed for Trading Patent Rights
text: Patent rights, which are usually bought and sold in private transactions, are set to be publicly traded on a new exchange, which plans to announce its first offering on Wednesday.

headline: The Valuable Lesson of Grant Hill
text: With his retirement after 19 N.B.A. seasons, Grant Hill leaves behind a legacy far more important than on-court statistics, according to William C. Rhoden.

headline: Panel Advises N.H.L. to Mandate Visors for New Players

headline: N.F.L. Deal on Images Divides Retirees
text: Athletes have long complained that they have not been fairly paid for the use of their images. A century ago, Honus Wagner supposedly objected when a tobacco company issued baseball cards with his face on them not because he opposed smoking, but because he was not compensated.

headline: Chants Against Iran’s Supreme Leader Heard in Video of Dissident Cleric’s Funeral
text: Chants in support of jailed opposition leaders, and against Iran’s ruling cleric, rang out during a funeral procession for a dissident religious leader in the city of Isfahan on Tuesday, BBC News reported.

headline: Chinese President Makes Bridge-Building Trip to Mexico
text: SAN CRISTOBAL DE LAS CASAS, Mexico — President Xi Jinping of China arrived in Mexico City on Tuesday for a three-day visit intended to smooth over relations that have long been prickly.

headline: A Matchup of Strangers in a Familiar Land
text: MIAMI — Maybe Gregg Popovich knew something on that late November evening when he put his three best players on a Southwest Airlines flight and sent them back to Texas.

headline: Complaint Accuses U.S. Judge in Texas of Racial Bias
text: A group of civil rights organizations and legal ethicists filed a complaint of misconduct against a senior federal judge on Tuesday, alleging that recent remarks of hers showed bias against minority groups and an inappropriate religious belief in the death penalty.

headline: The Second-Most Important Court
text: President Obama announced plans on Tuesday to nominate three judges to fill the vacancies in the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

headline: In China, an Empire Built by Aping Apple
text: BEIJING — China is notorious for its knockoffs. But now comes a knockoff of one of the gods of American ingenuity: Steven P. Jobs.

headline: Arts and Sciences Academy Defends Leader’s Honesty
text: The American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the prestigious 233-year-old scholarly society in Cambridge, Mass., said on Tuesday that it is standing behind its president, Leslie Cohen Berlowitz, after accusations that she had falsely claimed on at least two grant proposals to have a doctorate.

headline: Report Says T.S.A. Screening Is Not Objective
text: The Transportation Security Administration has little evidence that an airport passenger screening program, which some employees believe is a magnet for racial profiling and has cost taxpayers nearly one billion dollars, screens passengers objectively, according to a report by the inspector general for the Homeland Security Department.

headline: S.E.C. to Vote on Proposal to Overhaul Money Funds
text: Regulators are preparing to take a crucial step toward overhauling some parts of the widely used money market fund industry.

headline: Syrian Rebels Meet Setbacks on a New Front
text: IBLIL, Syria — The airstrikes resumed at 7:30 a.m., beginning with a rolling series of explosions in the village of Zoghba. An extended roar shook the northern Hama Plain.

headline: College Fund Tinkers With Its Slogan to Stress Investing in Students
text: THE United Negro College Fund, now known as the U.N.C.F., is introducing a new public service advertising campaign this week that tweaks its well-known tagline to stress the importance of investing in university education for young African-Americans.

headline: A New Strategy on One Syrian Front
text: Syrian rebels have decided to fight less of a strictly guerrilla war on the Hama plain, and to try to battle the government forces on more conventional terms as a fully functional army.

headline: Welfare for the Wealthy
text: The critically important Farm Bill [1] is impenetrably arcane, yet as it worms its way through Congress, Americans who care about justice, health or the environment can parse enough of it to become outraged.

headline: Japanese Pilots Worry About Repaired Boeing 787 Jets
text: TOKYO — As Boeing’s 787 Dreamliner returns to the skies, Japanese pilots are nervous about whether they would receive enough warning about any hazards with the jetliner’s new battery system.

headline: Make Patent Trolls Pay in Court
text: FROM an early age we are taught the importance of fighting fairly. But as the vast number of frivolous patent lawsuits have shown, too many people are rewarded for doing just the opposite.

headline: Playing Politics With Student Debt
text: WASHINGTON — THIS summer, more than nine million undergraduates will take out an average of $6,700 each in federal loans to pay for college next year. They will borrow, on average, $24,803 to earn their degrees. While this continues to be one of the smartest investments they will ever make, Congress should take one step toward making it an even smarter one.

headline: Transportation Security Administration Report on Profiling
text: The inspector general of the Transportation Security Administration released a report on screening practices at airports.

headline: Syrian Rebels Drive South
text: In Syria, C.J. Chivers profiles Grandsons of the Prophet, a rebel unit, on its march south toward Homs.

headline: Jewish Identity, Spelled in Yiddish
text: LAST Thursday, a 13-year-old boy won the Scripps National Spelling Bee by spelling “knaidel,” Yiddish for matzo ball. But the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, which created the standard Yiddish transliteration now used in libraries around the world, holds that the correct spelling is “kneydl.”

headline: A County in Alabama Strikes a Bankruptcy Deal
text: Jefferson County, Ala., took a big step toward resolving its historic bankruptcy case on Tuesday, saying it had reached an agreement to refinance most of the debt at the heart of its financial breakdown.

headline: Filly Will Face the Boys, and Resemble Them
text: It is not done lightly or often, leading a filly into the paddock of a Triple Crown race and hoping she is tough and fast enough to hold her own against the boys. And for good reason. Only three fillies have won the Kentucky Derby, five the Preakness Stakes and three the Belmont Stakes.

headline: Gov. Christie’s Quick, Costly Decision
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey had a straightforward choice in filling the Senate vacancy left by the death of Senator Frank Lautenberg on Monday. He could have added the Senate race to the general election on Nov. 5, the day he is up for re-election in what is expected to be an easy glide into a second term. Instead, he called for a special election on Oct. 16, a Wednesday, with a primary on Aug. 13 — a schedule that might give him a small political advantage but at considerable and needless cost to state taxpayers.

headline: Advise and Consent
text: On Tuesday, when President Obama made the unusual gesture of personally introducing his three nominees for the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, he said that Americans would consider it a “judicial crisis” if the Supreme Court were similarly shortstaffed. The president did not come right out and say it, but he should have: The severe breakdown in the process for approving federal judges in the Senate has been especially hard on that critically important appeals court.

headline: Getting to Know You
text: This week’s summit meeting between President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China is an important opportunity for the leaders of the world’s two largest economies to chart a smoother path and avoid the destructive conflicts that have historically afflicted relations between rising and established powers.

headline: Israel Lives the Joseph Story
text: How would you like to be an Israeli strategist today? Now even Turkey is in turmoil as its people push back on their increasingly autocratic leader. I mean, there goes the neighborhood. The good news for Israel is that in the near term its near neighbors are too internally consumed to think about threatening it. In the long run, though, Israel faces two serious challenges that I’d dub the Stephen Hawking Story and the Joseph Story.

headline: Diabetes Is the Price Vietnam Pays for Progress
text: HO CHI MINH CITY — He survived the deprivation of the Vietnamese countryside and decades of war, but Pham Van Dang, 70, lay dazed in his hospital bed, the stump of his freshly amputated leg sewn up like the seams of a leather bag.

headline: Hand-Washing in Hospitals
text: To the Editor:

headline: How to Teach Reading
text: To the Editor:

headline: Another Year Older, Another Year Wiser?
text: Should there be an age limit for the House and Senate?

headline: In Praise of Donors
text: To the Editor:

headline: Notaries’ Role in Greece
text: To the Editor:

headline: Evidence Against William Masso
text: Undercover federal agents give William Masso, a police officer at the time, two bags containing firearms at warehouse in New Jersey in 2011.

headline: As Vandals Deface U.S. Parks, Some Point to Online Show-Offs
text: SAGUARO NATIONAL PARK, Ariz. — When Steve Bolyard checked out a report of black paint on some of the park’s majestic saguaros — cactuses whose towering bodies and upraised arms are as emblematic of the American West as red-rock buttes and skittering tumbleweeds — he did not expect to see ganglike calligraphy covering more of them than he could easily count.

headline: A Pariah After a ’98 Death, an Ex-Yale Lecturer Reclaims His Status as a Pillar
text: James R. Van de Velde graduated cum laude from Yale University, won fellowships at Stanford and Harvard, got a Ph.D. from Tufts and returned to Yale as a lecturer.

headline: Nunez Has Setback, Delaying Return
text: When Eduardo Nunez felt a twinge in his left side during a game against the Oakland Athletics on May 5, forcing him out of the lineup, the Yankees did not think the injury was serious. Nunez thought the pain was from indigestion.

headline: Discovered at 64, a Brooklyn Artist Takes His Place
text: Rafael Leonardo Black, hermit and artist in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, keeps all his tools in elbow’s reach in the studio where he lives. A coffee mug with nine No. 2 pencils, each razor-whetted to the sharpness of a spear. A single brand of tracing paper. Shelves of art books, surrealists mostly.

headline: Corrections: June 5, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Meth Addict With a Perfect Résumé
text: When people speak of the golden age of the small screen that we are currently living through, they are generally not referring to the kind of fare dissected in “Good Television,” a new play by Rod McLachlan that goes behind the scenes — and into the trailer park — with the creators and subjects of a reality show about addiction.

headline: ‘I’m Melting!’ Is No Stretch
text: “Am I repeating myself?” asks the addled woman in the hospital bed. Yes, she certainly is, but then Evelyn Armstrong, played with starchy verve by Kathleen Chalfant, can be forgiven for this and some other lapses, like those jokes she keeps making for the benefit of her caretaker’s unborn baby. Evelyn is on a morphine drip, and a painful death from cancer looms.

headline: It Just Can’t Be Predicted
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Mark Bickham has constructed crosswords for The Los Angeles Times, but this appears to be a debut in The New York Times, so let’s welcome him. Some constructors come in quietly and make their mark, but Mr. Bickham is bringing the noise: his grid ends with a BANG! Hopefully, Mr. Bickham is not aiming for the EMUS at 14 Across.

headline: Cut the Strings to George III
text: WASHINGTON — You see glistening mermaid sightings on Animal Planet more than you catch glimpses of vintage John McCain on Capitol Hill.

headline: The Roles That Faith Plays in Life
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Hunt for a Deadly Sniper From Two Perspectives
text: During the 2010 assault on Marja in Helmand Province, Afghanistan, Cpl. Thomas Gibbons-Neff was the leader of a Marine Corps scout sniper team that came under fire from a Taliban sniper. The sniper, like others in the area, had proved surprisingly effective, and Corporal Gibbons-Neff’s team was ordered to flush him out. Ben Anderson, a journalist and filmmaker, accompanied the team on the assault. The two became friends, and the following is their joint account of the weeklong hunt for one sniper, told from their different viewpoints on the battlefield.

headline: Critics of Health Care Law Outspending Its Supporters on Ads
text: WASHINGTON — Seven months before the core provisions of President Obama’s health care law are to take effect, most television advertising that mentions the law continues to come from its opponents.

headline: Apple Violates Samsung Patent, U.S. Trade Panel Says
text: Apple’s legal victory against Samsung Electronics over patents in the United States is not flawless. A trade commission on Tuesday determined that the company had violated one of Samsung’s patents, and it ordered a ban on some older Apple devices.

headline: Richie Phillips, Union Leader Who Helped and Hurt Umpires, Dies at 72
text: Richie Phillips, a boisterous, street-shrewd lawyer who quintupled the salaries of major league baseball umpires as their union representative, then caused many of them to lose their jobs by having them resign en masse, died Friday at his home in Cape May, N.J. He was 72.

headline: France Offers Evidence of ‘Multiple’ Uses of Nerve Gas in Syria
text: PARIS — France announced on Tuesday that French laboratory tests had confirmed that sarin gas had been used “multiple times” in Syria, but only “in a localized way.” The French foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, said that in one case, at least, “there is no doubt it was the regime and its accomplices” that used the gas.

headline: China’s First Lady Won’t See U.S. Counterpart on Visit
text: WASHINGTON — Whatever President Obama and China’s president, Xi Jinping, do this weekend to make their highly anticipated meeting in California as informal, even intimate, as both sides profess to want, there is one thing they will not do: double date.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 5, 2013
text: "It’s one thing to see a pioneer’s inscription on a wall. It’s another to see the signature of the 1,237,000th of 2 million visitors.”

headline: In the Majors, but Not in the Lineup
text: WASHINGTON — On Tuesday night, for the 24th time since his April 24 promotion to the major leagues, Juan Lagares was not penciled into the Mets’ lineup.

headline: Hidebound Chamber Lets Down Its Hair in Gay-Marriage Debate
text: LONDON — The House of Lords stands as one of the great bastions of tradition here, a baroque link to a distant, noble-centric past of pomp and pageantry. Its members serve for life. Their average age is 69. Once a year, they unearth fur-lined robes from their family vaults (or from the vaults of upmarket robe-rental shops) and process regally into Parliament as if it were still, say, 1599.

headline: Alarming Trend of Amputees in Vietnam
text: A spike in cases of Type 2 diabetes is reflected in the increasing number of leg amputations being performed at a hospital in Ho Chi Minh City.

headline: Park Defender Helped Set Off Turkey’s Crisis
text: ISTANBUL — It was just before midnight a week ago Monday when three friends saw the bulldozer approaching the edge of the park.

headline: Joint Chiefs’ Answers on Sex Crimes Dismay Senators
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Roy Blunt sat silently for nearly an hour as his colleagues on the Armed Services Committee questioned one military leader after another on Tuesday about what they were doing to address the problem of sexual assault in the military, and then assessed their responses: “Stunningly bad.”

headline: U.S.-China Meeting’s Aim: Personal Diplomacy
text: WASHINGTON — When Tom Donilon, President Obama’s national security adviser, met with President Xi Jinping in Beijing last week to discuss his coming visit to the United States, China’s newly minted leader told him he wanted a conversation with Mr. Obama that did not involve diplomatic talking points. As if to underscore the message, he ignored the notes sitting in front of him.

headline: His Body Healthy and His Swing Robust, Teixeira Carries Yanks Again
text: No injured Yankees player was more open in his eagerness to return to the lineup than Mark Teixeira. While Derek Jeter’s and Alex Rodriguez’s rehabilitations were shrouded in secrecy, and both rarely appeared in the clubhouse, Teixeira stood by his locker almost daily and told reporters excitedly about each step in his recovery from a right wrist injury, regardless of how minimal it seemed.

headline: Lopez Is Said to Be Fined Over Sexual Abuse
text: A legislative ethics panel will impose the largest fine in its history on former Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez for reportedly sexually harassing several of his former employees, people briefed on the decision said.

headline: Facing Years in Jail, Officer in Gun Scheme Has Regrets
text: Police Officer Ali Oklu said it began in 2010 with a phone call from a fellow officer: “Hey, you want a side job?”

headline: Baseball to Get Help in Doping Case
text: The head of a defunct South Florida anti-aging clinic suspected by Major League Baseball of providing a number of players with banned substances has agreed to cooperate with the sport’s investigators, potentially opening the way for player suspensions, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Is Barefoot-Style Running Best? New Studies Cast Doubt
text: Barefoot-running enthusiasts long have believed that running without shoes or in minimalist footwear makes running easier, speedier and less injurious. But a surprisingly large number of new studies examining just how the body actually responds when we run in our birthday shoes or skimpy footwear suggest that for many people, those expectations are not being met.

headline: Bloomberg Begins Fund to Invest in Start-Ups
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In the increasingly clubby world of Silicon Valley, some might say it was almost inevitable that Bloomberg L.P., the parent of Bloomberg News, would start its own venture capital firm to invest in start-ups, including some that its technology reporters write about.

headline: Andrew Greeley’s Insistence on Careful Measurement
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Word of the Day | turncoat
text: turncoat •\ˈtərn-ˌkot\• noun

headline: Leak Found in Steel Tank for Water at Fukushima
text: TOKYO — The operator of the stricken Fukushima nuclear plant said Wednesday that it had found a leak in one of the hundreds of steel tanks used to store radioactive water at the plant, raising renewed questions about the company’s ability to handle the plant’s cleanup.

headline: Deacon Jones’s Deep Impact on the N.F.L.
text: Deacon Jones was one of the first pro football players to put a sunny spin on what we know to be a very dark game.

headline: The First Lady Refuses to Let a Heckler Go Unscolded
text: WASHINGTON — Michelle Obama had a rare face-off with a heckler at a Democratic fund-raiser on Tuesday evening before the protesting woman, shouting for gay rights, was escorted out by party supporters.

headline: Italy’s Migrant Detention Centers Are Cruel, Rights Groups Say
text: ROME — The Identification and Expulsion Center, a detention complex on the outskirts of Rome where illegal immigrants can be held for months before deportation, is not a prison. But the difference seems mostly a question of semantics.

headline: As System in Italy Is Criticized, Detainees Wait
text: There are eleven detention centers in Italy that are used to hold people — some who have lived in Italy for years — who lack working or residence permits, or whose papers have expired.

headline: What to Watch on Day 11 at the French Open
text: The two women’s quarterfinals were the more competitive of the four matches Tuesday, with Serena Williams and Sara Errani eking out tight wins while David Ferrer and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga cruised. The women’s matches, despite being best-of-three, actually lasted 32 minutes longer than the best-of-five men’s matches, and that was even with Errani winning in straight sets.

headline: Police Shoot Chain-Wielding Man in East Harlem
text: A police officer shot and wounded a man who law enforcement authorities said had hit at least one person with a chain in East Harlem on Tuesday evening.

headline: New York Parks Rank No. 2 in a Survey of 50 U.S. Cities
text: New York City’s park system ranked second, behind Minneapolis’s, in a survey of the nation’s 50 largest cities by the Trust for Public Land.

headline: Judge Throws Out Verdict in Police Brutality Case
text: When Sean Thomas sued three New York City police officers in 2009, claiming they had used excessive force against him, he appeared to have a strong case. After his arrest the previous year during a dispute with his girlfriend at her home in the Bronx, he was handcuffed, wrapped in a restraint blanket, strapped to a stretcher and taken to the hospital where he was involuntarily sedated, according to court documents. He was never charged with any crime.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 4, 2013

headline: Kicked Off Their Flight, Students Turn to Internet
text: They started their senior trip joking about the 3 a.m. start and comparing seat assignments, a bubbly group of about 100 high school students from Brooklyn flying to Atlanta to bond and relax over white-water rafting and a day at Six Flags.

headline: China Aims at Europe’s Wines After Solar Panel Action
text: HONG KONG — China’s nouveaux riches millionaires, wealthy princelings and bribing business executives may soon find their wallets a little thinner: The price for French Champagnes and Burgundies, Italian Barolos and pinot grigios and other European wines may soon rise in mainland Chinese stores.

headline: R Tube to Be Shut More Than a Year for Storm Repairs
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to close a river tunnel that carries the R train for more than a year to make repairs stemming from Hurricane Sandy, an agency official said.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (MSG) FOUR COURSES WITH J B SMOOVE In the premiere of this talk show, filmed at the Tre Dici restaurant in Manhattan and part of MSG’s “Original Wednesdays” summer lineup, Mr. Smoove, the actor and comedian, right, sits down to dinner with the retired basketball players Larry Johnson and John Salley, the comedian Judah Friedlander and the musician Tariq Trotter, a k a Black Thought, to chat about the Knicks, food, entertainment and life in the city.

headline: Cuomo Women’s Rights Plan May Hinge on Abortion Proposal
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Tuesday unveiled his long-promised Women’s Equality Act, a 10-point plan whose controversial final element, which includes codifying federal abortion rights into state law, could determine the fate of various other antidiscrimination provisions included in the bill.

headline: A Call for Mandatory Visors
text: The N.H.L. competition committee recommended that visors be mandated for players entering the league next season. Under the plan, any player who has appeared in more than 26 N.H.L. games would be allowed to play without a visor. About 73 percent of players wore a visor this season, up from 23 percent in 2001-2, according to The Hockey News.

headline: News Quiz | June 5, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: In Hong Kong, a Rain-Soaked Celebration of Democracy
text: BEIJING — There aren’t many, if any, places in China where a group of people can shout “down with the Communist Party” in public and not be punished for it. But in Hong Kong, which since 1997 has been part of China but is largely self-governing, they can, and do.

headline: China Allows Return of U.S. Executive Before Xi’s Visit
text: An American engineer and entrepreneur whose inability to leave China for the last five years has been a low-grade irritant for United States-Chinese relations was allowed to return home to Los Angeles on Monday, according to his family.

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 5
text: NEWS The French foreign minister announced on Tuesday that laboratory tests confirmed that sarin gas had been used in Syria, and that there was “no doubt it was the regime and its accomplices” that had used it. Steven Erlanger reports from Paris, and Nick Cumming-Bruce from Geneva.

headline: Can Job Training Trump a Degree?
text: HONG KONG — China and India, Asian giants with a staggering 2.5 billion people between them, have a big problem with their youth.

headline: Death of Victim Focuses Attention on Acid Attacks
text: NEW DELHI —When Preeti Rathi got off the train at Bandra Terminus station in Mumbai on May 2, she was looking forward to a new life in the city, where a job as a nurse awaited her. But the life of the 23-year-old from Delhi changed dramatically in a matter of seconds when an unidentified man doused her face with acid.

headline: France and Britain Say Nerve Gas Likely Used in Syria
text: PARIS — A day after France announced that French laboratory tests had confirmed that sarin gas had been used “multiple times” in Syria “in a localized way,” Britain on Wednesday repeated an earlier assessment that “a growing body of limited but persuasive information” pointed to the use of the same toxin.

headline: Abe’s New Steps in Japan Draw Less Enthusiasm
text: TOKYO — The fervor is fading.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 5, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article “Who Will Crack the Code?”

headline: Protests Erupt Across Turkey
text: In the article “Turkish Official Apologizes for Force Used at Start of Riots,” Sebnem Arsu writes about the recent protests and riots that have erupted in Turkey.

headline: Police Continue Search for Suspects in American Tourist Gang-Rape
text: NEW DELHI —The Himachal Pradesh police said Wednesday that they were still looking for the three men who raped an American tourist after the victim was not able to identify any suspects in a lineup.

headline: In Syrian Victory, Hezbollah Risks Broader Fight
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In the final days the outgunned Syrian rebels, deprived of reinforcements, ammunition and sleep, were surviving on olives and canned beans. They were hiding in the concrete shells of destroyed houses and underground tunnels near the besieged rebel stronghold of Qusayr, unable to help their trapped colleagues and civilians dying of treatable wounds, as Syrian government forces and their Hezbollah allies from Lebanon assaulted the town by land and air.

headline: Why Did a Cheerios Ad Attract So Many Angry Comments Online?
text: Cheerios made the above advertisement featuring an interracial cast as a family. Why do you think the commercial attracted so many angry comments online?

headline: A Reconstruction of Memory
text: Johan Willner started out as a documentary photographer, trying to capture decisive moments that explained other people’s experiences. He later became a printer for Magnum in New York, painstakingly reproducing other people’s visions while studying the archived contact sheets of Josef Koudelka, Robert Capa and Henri Cartier-Bresson.

headline: Agreement Elusive on Syria Peace Talks in Geneva
text: GENEVA — Senior United States, Russian and United Nations officials failed on Wednesday to find enough common ground among themselves and antagonists in Syria’s civil war to convene an international peace conference this month, setting their sights on convening it instead in July.

headline: As Floods in Germany Continue, Officials Urge More Evacuations
text: Officials in eastern Germany’s river cities and towns on Wednesday urged citizens in vulnerable areas to evacuate their homes as the Elbe River and its tributaries swelled ever higher, amid some of the worst flooding that some regions have seen in centuries.

headline: Voters Think Silver Should Resign, Poll Finds
text: ALBANY — By more than two to one, New York State voters believe the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, should step down because of the way he handled sexual harassment allegations against Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, according to a new poll.
