text: Today’s Times

headline: The Rail Bookshelf: A Filly’s Growing Mystique
text: Horse racing fans typically fall into one of two camps. In the first are the hard-core gamblers, obsessed with speed figures and lineage and probability. In the second camp are the romantics, for whom horse racing is all about beauty and strength and the story behind the story.

headline: In London Theater, Repetition Is Not a Dirty Word
text: LONDON — How soon is too soon?

headline: Q&A: Streaming Videos From PC to Tablet
text: Q.

headline: Tips on Archiving Family History, Part 2
text: Readers sent dozens of questions about archiving and preserving family history and stories to Bertram Lyons, an archivist at the American Folklife Center of the Library of Congress in Washington. He was recently asked to be the editor of the International Association of Sound and Audiovisual Archives, an organization that aims to share best practices in the management of audiovisual materials internationally. He received his master’s degree in museum studies from the University of Kansas in 2009.

headline: Rice to Replace Donilon in the Top National Security Post
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced on Wednesday afternoon that Susan E. Rice, the American ambassador to the United Nations, would replace Tom Donilon, who is resigning, as national security adviser in a major shakeup of his foreign-policy inner circle.

headline: Trying to Take the Sting Out of a Price Increase
text: At the last She Owns It Business Group meeting, the owners talked about several pricing issues. Susan Parker, who owns Bari Jay, recently discovered that customers react not only to a price increase but also to the way it is presented. When she learned her factories were raising her prices, she thought she would pass along a 10-percent-per-dress increase to all of customers. But then she had another idea.

headline: Daily Report: Bloomberg Beta Will Invest in Technology Firms
text: The parent company of Bloomberg News will start its own venture capital firm to invest in start-ups, including some companies that its technology reporters write about, Nicole Perlroth reports in The New York Times.

headline: Pushy Parents Urged to Let Offspring Go It Alone
text: LONDON — Here’s a question for every parent. Is it right to use your connections to give your children a potentially unfair advantage in the labor market or should you make them stand on their own feet?

headline: Stealing Fame
text: Perhaps, by way of illustrating the deeply surreal, snake-eating-its-own-tail nature of Sofia Coppola’s new film, “The Bling Ring,” it’s best to start with a simple exchange between reporter and director.

headline: Latvia Steps Toward a Tarnished Prize, the Euro
text: FRANKFURT — The small Baltic nation of Latvia received official endorsement for membership in the euro currency union Wednesday, in a move that European leaders clearly hoped would demonstrate the endurance of the euro zone despite its dismal economic performance and damaged reputation.

headline: Top Murdoch Executive Denies Hacking Charges
text: LONDON — Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of Rupert Murdoch’s newspaper operations in Britain, appeared in court on Wednesday and denied charges relating to the country’s phone hacking scandal, which has sent shock waves through the press, the police and the political establishment.

headline: A Garden Hose With an Electronic Brain
text: The thing about an over-the-top item like, say, a Maserati, is that no one needs one, but plenty of people still want one. Maybe that’s the idea behind the RoboReel Water, which at $650, might qualify as the Maserati of hoses.

headline: On the Subway, Dioramas of Manhattan Life
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Pakistan’s New Premier Calls for Drone Strike Halt
text: LONDON — Nawaz Sharif took office as Pakistan’s prime minister for an unparalleled third time on Wednesday, vowing to tackle the country’s crippling electricity crisis and issuing an urgent call for the end of American drone strikes on Pakistani soil.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Bike Sharing in New York, for Tourists
text: Bike sharing in New York for tourists, studies cast doubt on barefoot-style running, frying food outdoors and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Jefferson County’s Bankruptcy Deal
text: Jefferson County, Ala., reached an agreement to refinance most of the debt at the heart of its financial breakdown, taking a big step toward resolving its bankruptcy, Mary Williams Walsh reports in DealBook. “The deal, according to the people briefed on the negotiations, covers about $2.4 billion of Jefferson County’s total $3.078 billion in sewer debt, which was issued to pay for significant repairs needed to bring the county into compliance with federal clean water laws.”

headline: Remembering Ada Louise Huxtable
text: A steady procession of mourners in dark suits on a summery afternoon all but traced the history of modern American architecture as they arrived on the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art: Richard Meier, followed by Kevin Roche, followed by David Childs, followed by Frank Gehry. And many more.

headline: Oh, Bring Back Frankie, Dion and Bobby and Songs of Love
text: I don’t normally tell people this, but it’s summertime, when restraint tends to fail, so here goes:

headline: Guilty Plea by Sergeant in Killing of Civilians
text: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash. — Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, the enigmatic figure at the center of the worst American war crime in recent memory, admitted for the first time on Wednesday deliberately killing 16 Afghan civilians last year, most of them women and children.

headline: Food Matters | A Sweet Take on Modern Art
text: Caitlin Freeman, the pastry chef for Blue Bottle Coffee, has a new cookbook out inspired by the collection at San Francisco’s Museum of Modern Art, where Blue Bottle has opened a cafe. Both the cafe and museum will be temporarily closed starting this month as part of a massive expansion project, but in the meantime you can enjoy the book’s 27 painterly confections, from a Warhol gelée to a Matisse parfait. To help guide less experienced bakers, Freeman includes names and definitions for the equipment (think microplanes, piping bags and thermocouples) involved in recreating her desserts, as well as the back story behind every creation. SFMOMA’s Janet Bishop provides the curator notes. There is, for example, the “Build Your Own Newman,” a construction of chocolate sables based on the Abstract Expressionist Barnett Newman’s sculpture “Zim Zum I.” For her part, Freeman was determined to photograph her cookie replica alongside the original art, in this case an eight-foot-tall steel structure in the museum’s sculpture garden. That necessitated perching a sheet pan over the roof of the museum and assembling the pastry in what Freeman describes as “hurricane-force winds while simultaneously holding lighting equipment.”

headline: It’s Not Just Nice to Share, It’s the Future
text: Some people in New York love the city’s new bike-sharing system. Some people really, really do not. One of the latter is Dorothy Rabinowitz, an editorial writer for The Wall Street Journal, who in a five-minute opinion video called “Death by Bicycle” — this is apparently not a parody — charges that bikes are the city’s “most important danger” and that Citi Bikes have “begrimed” the city’s best neighborhoods. She calls the bike lobby an “all-powerful enterprise” and denounces Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s “ideology-maddened traffic commissioner.”

headline: Dell’s Mathematical Argument Against Plan From Icahn and Southeastern
text: As Dell  prepares to defend its $24.4 billion sale to its founder, the computer company took a big swipe at two of its biggest investors, who oppose the leveraged buyout.

headline: Political Leaders Honor Lautenberg as a Senator Who Loved the Fight
text: When Senator Frank R. Lautenberg pushed to ban smoking on airplanes, a pitched battle ensued. When he moved to raise the drinking age to 21, there was an outcry. That there was a fight at all may now seem remarkable, but at Mr. Lautenberg’s funeral on Wednesday, his eulogists said it was the fight that drove him.

headline: Kerry Meets With Official of Venezuela to Set Talks
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — After months of tensions between the United States and Venezuela, Secretary of State John Kerry met on Wednesday with the Venezuelan foreign minister, Elías Jaua, in Antigua, Guatemala, and announced the start of talks aimed at improving relations between the two countries.

headline: Treasury Plans to Sell 30 Million G.M. Shares
text: The Treasury Department said on Wednesday that it planned to sell 30 million shares of General Motors in an offering tied to the company’s reinsertion into the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘The Hero of Paris’
text: This poem, one of 12 winners of our fourth annual Found Poem Student Contest, was written by Micah, 17, from Phoenix.

headline: Building Your Own Web Site, Free
text: Personal Web sites have been around a long time. Just ask anyone with an old Angelfire or GeoCities page. But now, Internet users have a dizzying array of free, feature-rich services to choose from — no coding skills required.

headline: Chen Xitong, Beijing Mayor During Tiananmen Protests, Dies at 82
text: HONG KONG — Chen Xitong, the mayor of Beijing during the Tiananmen Square protests of 1989, died on Sunday, two days before the 24th anniversary of the armed crackdown he had championed. He was 82.

headline: Vollis Simpson, Visionary Artist of the Junkyard, Dies at 94
text: Vollis Simpson, who made metal scraps into magnificent things that twirled and jangled and clattered when he set them out on his land, and who did so long before anyone started calling them whirligigs or him an artist, died on Friday at his home in Lucama, N.C. He was 94.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Observer: Gas heat, skirt steak and a good U.S.D.A. number: grilling tips and other carnivore lore from New York’s masters of meat: the Pat LaFriedas, Jr. and Sr. – Patrick Farrell

headline: Will Congress Do Anything About the Military’s Sexual Misconduct Crisis?
text: Tuesday’s Senate Armed Services Committee hearing on the sexual misconduct crisis in the military started off with testimony from a nearly all-male panel of a dozen Pentagon officials. Exactly one was female. And there were no assault victims. That imbalance conjured memories of the all-male panel of witnesses at the much-mocked 2012 House hearings on the so-called birth-control mandate — and set expectations suitably low.

headline: Three Noteworthy Apps for Kids
text: Three noteworthy apps for children this week let children freely explore early music and logic experiences.

headline: Fire in China Stirs Debate on Safety of Workers
text: BEIJING — The fire and ammonia gas leak at a poultry factory that killed at least 120 people and injured scores of others this week has stirred outrage and debate in China over workplace safety issues.

headline: The Right Rules for Keeping Ships from Hitting Right Whales
text: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has built a solid case for making permanent the rules the agency implemented five years ago to limit collisions between ships and endangered North Atlantic right whales along the East Coast.

headline: Accord Aims to Create Trove of Genetic Data
text: More than 70 medical, research and advocacy organizations active in 41 countries and including the National Institutes of Health announced Wednesday that they had agreed to create an organized way to share genetic and clinical information. Their aim is to put the vast and growing trove of data on genetic variations and health into databases — with the consent of the study subjects — that would be open to researchers and doctors all over the world, not just to those who created them.

headline: Obama Bets on Rice's Redemption
text: The Times's Mark Landler discusses the White House's decision to put Susan E. Rice back in the harsh spotlight as the national security adviser.

headline: Late Checkouts Let You Hit the Snooze
text: It’s hard to sleep in when an 11 a.m. hotel checkout looms. Now, a number of hotels are offering what many rushed travelers want: a few more hours, at least on low occupancy days.

headline: An Entrepreneur Chooses Potential Growth Over Proven Profits
text: Last week, we published a case study about a young entrepreneur in Seattle, Aseem Badshah, who has been deciding how to divide his time and attention between two ventures.

headline: All the King’s Men
text: RABAT, Morocco — Morocco is going through a slow-moving political crisis. Last month, Istiqlal, a secular party, voted to withdraw from the Islamist-led coalition government, criticizing it as ineffective. But after a phone call from King Mohammed VI, who was on vacation in Paris, Istiqlal’s leaders decided to stay put until the monarch’s return. Meanwhile, the embattled Justice and Development Party — the Islamist party that after years in opposition now leads the coalition government — has become isolated. Abdelilah Benkirane, its leader and the country’s prime minister, addressed a half-empty chamber of deputies last week; the opposition had boycotted the session.

headline: Obama to Speak at Brandenburg Gate During Berlin Visit
text: Apparently Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany does not find the idea “odd” any longer: At her invitation, President Obama will finally get his chance to speak at Berlin’s historic Brandenburg Gate this month.

headline: Losing It
text: If a picture is worth a thousand words, then a video ought to be worth at least ten thousand, right? So, with that bargain in mind, here’s a look at today’s sports news, in video.

headline: Olbermann to Return to TV, Anchoring Postseason Baseball
text: Keith Olbermann — the sports anchor, not the political news one — is returning to television.

headline: Toeing the Line
text: TIJUANA, Baja California — On most radio stations in this city you get a traffic report every 15 minutes. It’s not the typical kind. It doesn’t refer to what’s going on in the streets; it’s all about “la Línea,” the Line. Here, an average of 50,000 cars and 25,000 pedestrians move between the United States and Mexico every day.

headline: The Gun Report: June 5, 2013
text: A month after the Newtown shooting, President Obama issued 23 presidential actions regarding gun regulation, one of which was to restore government funding to research gun violence in the United States. (If you’ll recall, heavy N.R.A. lobbying caused research funding to dry up in 1996, and the Centers for Disease Control has reportedly cut firearms safety research by 96 percent since then.)

headline: Protest Group Gives Turkish Official a List of Demands
text: ISTANBUL — With a measure of calm returning to a city that for days has been a caldron of antigovernment passions, representatives of a group that helped incite protests that have been roiling Turkey opened dialogue on Wednesday with the government.

headline: Jack White Pays Detroit Concert Hall’s Back Taxes to Save It
text: Jack White has saved the historic Masonic Temple in Detroit, a well-known performance space for rock bands, paying $142,000 in the building’s back taxes to keep the structure from being auctioned. One of two theaters inside the 14-story building will be named after Mr. White, The Detroit Free Press reported on Tuesday.

headline: House Hunting in the Yucatán
text: A fully furnished four-bedroom house near the Caribbean beachfront and 45 minutes from the Cancún airport is on the market for $3.3 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Mexico
text: A FOUR-BEDROOM HOUSE WITH CARIBBEAN VIEWS IN EASTERN YUCATÁN

headline: Ode to Music
text: Not every parent wants to be a Tiger Mom, but many parents harbor the desire to raise a virtuoso cellist, or at the very least, children who can distinguish between their Vivaldi and their Verdi. Two new illustrated books, one complete with CD, aim to instruct children on how to listen to and appreciate classical music. Even if they don’t have a piano to practice on.

headline: Panel Says Better Data Is Needed on Gun Issues
text: WASHINGTON — A panel of experts convened in response to the school shooting last year in Newtown, Conn., gave the federal government an ambitious set of priorities on Wednesday for research on guns, ending what experts said has been a 17-year hiatus in the study of gun violence after Congress took away federal money for the topic in the 1990s.

headline: Baseball Union Says Judgment Should Wait in Clinic Case
text: Major League Baseball’s players union is cautioning against any prejudging of the sport’s current doping inquiry in light of the disclosure that Anthony Bosch, the head of a now-shuttered South Florida anti-aging clinic, has agreed to cooperate with baseball’s investigators.

headline: Surfing and Serenity on a Remote Philippine Island
text: We sat facing a weathered wood pagoda set in an emerald sea, the perfect swimming distance from a private beach lined with crooked coconut trees. Grilled mahi-mahi that arrived via a banca, a Filipino fishing boat, just an hour earlier was seasoned with calamansi (a citrus fruit native to the Philippines) and served with grilled eggplant and squash from the resort’s organic farm, accompanied by a bottle of crisp white wine. Steps from the restaurant pavilion was our villa with its huge bed swathed in a white mosquito net, an open shower surrounded by local shiny white pebbles, and swinging outdoor daybeds. The pummeling of an unforgettable surfing session hours before made the idea of crawling back to such luxurious digs even more appealing.

headline: Top Hotels Look to the Next Frontier
text: LIJIANG, China — Tourists from China’s crowded coasts have long considered this city of 1.2 million in the Himalayan foothills to be a scenic getaway.

headline: Image of the Day: June 5
text: A donkey marriage in Mumbai, Maharashtra, to usher in good rains.

headline: M.T.A. Details Shutdown Plans for R and G Trains
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Wednesday outlined shutdown plans for later this year on the R and G trains, a result of repairs to tunnels damaged during Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Ben Bernanke, Force of Nature
text: By any reasonable standard, the great failing of economic policy over the past 5 years — monetary and fiscal both — is that it has done too little. Output lies far below reasonable estimates of potential, meaning trillions of dollars of wasted resources; unemployment remains at levels that amount to personal, social, and possibly political catastrophe; inflation has been below target, and there are good reasons to believe that the targets are too low.

headline: Street Style: Venice Biennale
text: As one can imagine at an art industry event, the street style ranges from the latest trends to creative pieces.

headline: The Great Civil War Lie
text: Civil War buffs have long speculated about how different the war might have been if only the Confederacy had won formal recognition from Britain. But few recognize how close that came to happening — and how much pro-Southern sympathy in Britain was built on a lie.

headline: Homes for $1.3 Million
text: Tours of properties with views in Chicago, Portland, Ore., and Georgia.

headline: What You Get for ... $1.3 Million
text: CHICAGO

headline: Video and Images From Building Collapse in Philadelphia
text: 4:05 p.m. | Updated As my colleague, Jon Hurdle reports, at least 13 people were injured and rescue crews were still trying to reach one person trapped under a mountain of debris after a building collapsed onto a thrift store in the Center City section of Philadelphia on Wednesday.

headline: In Performance: Rob McClure
text: The New York Times invited Tony nominees to perform scenes on location in New York. Rob McClure sings a cinematic interpretation of “The Life That You Wished For” from “Chaplin.”

headline: Tony Awards: In Performance With Rob McClure
text: For the third cinematic interpretation in our special Tony Awards in Performance series, Rob McClure explores the strange aisles of Eclectic/Encore Props, a Chelsea warehouse filled with movie décor, as he sings “The Life That You Wished For” from the musical “Chaplin.”

headline: Heritage Shock
text: Link fixed

headline: La Scala Names New General Manager
text: The board of directors at the Teatro alla Scala, the celebrated opera house in Milan, has appointed Alexander Pereira, currently the artistic director of the Salzburg Festival, as the house’s new general manager. He will succeed Stéphane Lissner, who has held the post since 2005, when Mr. Lissner leaves to take over the Paris Opera in 2015.

headline: Food Fears Persist in Japan
text: Two years after the disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, people are still worried about contaminated food, and farmers are struggling.

headline: Orb Is Morning-Line Favorite for Belmont
text: The Kentucky Derby winner, Orb, drew Post 5 and was installed as the morning-live favorite for the 145th running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday at Belmont Park. The Preakness Stakes winner, Oxbow, will break from Post 7 and has odds of 5-1.

headline: Severe Flooding Cripples Germany
text: Officials in eastern Germany’s river cities urged citizens in vulnerable areas to evacuate as the Elbe River and its tributaries swelled ever higher.

headline: A Rooftop Garden at the Waldorf-Astoria
text: Last year, the Waldorf-Astoria installed six beehives on a 20th-floor setback; today, “Top of the Waldorf” honey is used in the hotel’s restaurants. Now the rooftop has been planted with fig and apple trees, hops, strawberries, lavender and other herbs that the executive chef, David Garcelon, can use in the kitchen, and that the mixologist, Frank Caiafa, adds to drinks.

headline: Samsung May Have Passed Apple in U.S. — for Now
text: Samsung Electronics may have surpassed Apple to become the top smartphone maker in the United States in May, according to an analyst’s report. Sales of Samsung’s new flagship phone, the Galaxy S4, combined with its bigger-screen Galaxy Note II and the older Galaxy S III, lifted Samsung’s sales above Apple’s last month, the report said.

headline: ‘It Opens Your Mind': A Student-Made Video About a Year of Reading The Times
text: A student-produced and directed video was made, according to teachers, “off the cuff, from the heart and without notes.”

headline: Help for Traveling Pets
text: Animals traveling through Chicago on United Airlines can now stay in 28 temperature-controlled enclosures at the carrier’s kennel at O’Hare International Airport. (Overnight stays are $100.) Staff members will walk and exercise pets, and groom and bathe them on request. The facility also has vans to transport pets to and from flights. The kennel is United’s third and is part of the airline’s PetSafe program for animals not eligible to travel in the cabin. The carrier operates similar facilities at airports in Houston and Newark.

headline: Compelling Series, but James Tilts Edge to Heat
text: The N.B.A. finals are saturated with story lines. A fifth title for the 37-year-old San Antonio star Tim Duncan would solidify his case for being his generation’s best player. A second straight title for LeBron James would cap one of the most dominant seasons in league history. The series pits the glitz and bombast of South Beach against the quiet diligence of the small-market Spurs.

headline: Philadelphia Building Collapses During Demolition, Killing at Least Six
text: PHILADELPHIA — A four-story building that was being demolished collapsed onto an adjacent thrift store in central Philadelphia on Wednesday morning, killing at least six people, city officials said.

headline: Two Liberal Voices for Intervention, but Not in Syrian War
text: WASHINGTON — In naming Susan E. Rice and Samantha Power to key national security posts, President Obama has turned to two prominent advocates of liberal interventionism, a foreign-policy credo that calls for the United States to act aggressively to defend human rights – by military means, if necessary.

headline: Another Senator Urges Caution on Smithfield’s Sale to Chinese Company
text: 5:44 p.m. | Updated

headline: Toyota to Recall 2010 Prius and Lexus Hybrids
text: Toyota has announced a recall in the United States of about 87,000 Prius and Lexus HS 250h hybrids from the 2010 model year to fix a brake problem, the second time since 2010 the cars have been recalled to fix the braking. According to the automaker’s release, dealers will replace brake boosters, which can develop leaks.

headline: S.E.C. Proposes Changes in Money Funds
text: A new effort to avert the problems that hit money market funds during the financial crisis is already attracting criticism for not going far enough while winning praise from advocates of the money fund industry.

headline: Palm-Size Fossil Resets Primates’ Clock, Scientists Say
text: A nearly complete skeleton of a tiny, ancient primate — one that weighed no more than an ounce, had a tail longer than its body and would fit in the palm of your hand — is the earliest well-preserved fossil primate ever found, dating back some 55 million years and dialing back the fossil record for primates by an impressive eight million years, a research team declared on Wednesday.

headline: A Building Collapse in Philadelphia
text: Reuters footage of a building collapse Wednesday in the Center City section.

headline: Rare Look at a Baby Kipunji – One of the World’s Most Endangered Monkeys
text: The photograph above, distributed today by the Wildlife Conservation Society, provides a rare look at a baby kipunji (Rungwecebus kipunji) on Mount Rungwe, Tanzania.

headline: A Campaign Trail Lined With Words Friendly to Each Audience
text: 3:31 p.m. | Updated The Democratic mayoral candidates gathered on Tuesday night in Midwood, Brooklyn, for a debate sponsored by the Flatbush Jewish Community Coalition, in which most remarks hewed to a single informal commandment: Say nothing that might conceivably discomfort your audience.

headline: Orb Draws No. 5 Post and Is Favored
text: Orb, the Kentucky Derby winner, is the lukewarm favorite; Oxbow, the Preakness Stakes victor, will try to beat him again; and the filly Unlimited Budget will try to upend them both Saturday in the 145th running of the Belmont Stakes.

headline: Wheelies: The Cheaper Used Cars Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A Magic Carpet Ride in a Venetian Palazzo
text: As if the Venice Biennale didn’t offer enough art already between the Arsenale, the Giardini and the various national pavilions found on the crumbling side streets, there are also numerous palazzos that have been repurposed for parallel exhibitions mounted by some of the world’s pre-eminent private collections. The Francois Pinault Foundation owns two such mansion-seums on the Grand Canal: the industrial Tadao Ando-designed Punta Della Dogana and the quintessentially Venetian Palazzo Grassi. In the latter, the New York-based Italian artist Rudolph Stingel has created what may be the most sumptuous aesthetic experience on the island this year.

headline: The First Lady’s Heckler
text: Let’s stipulate that heckling the First Lady at a private fundraiser in Washington, D.C., is not very polite—even if you paid admission, like the protester who confronted Michelle Obama at a party for Democratic donors on Tuesday night.

headline: Hirshhorn Museum Scraps Idea to Cover Courtyard With Bubble
text: The Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden on Wednesday finally abandoned its long-planned project to cover the museum’s interior courtyard in Washington D.C. with a distinctive, temporary inflatable bubble.

headline: Is This a Government Which I See Before Me?
text: Gail Collins: Happy June, David! How’s the weather where you are? Last weekend New York felt like August. August in the tropics. Now it feels like we’re getting ready for an Easter Egg Roll.

headline: A Noisy Semifinal Ahead as Sharapova and Azarenka Advance
text: PARIS — Maria Sharapova and Jelena Jankovic have been battling each other since they were girls, after they were plucked from their homes and settled at the Bollettieri Academy in Florida to be turned into champions. Their relationship can be diplomatically described as frosty, and Jankovic has long existed in the considerable shadow of the more successful Sharapova.

headline: A Ride Around Manhattan in the Taxi of Tomorrow
text: Assuming its legal holdups are resolved, the Nissan NV200 that was shown in front of the Hilton New York Fashion District hotel in Manhattan on Tuesday will become the city’s “Taxi of Tomorrow.” Mike Hobson, director of the Nissan commercial vehicle division in the United States, points out that tomorrow is coming soon.

headline: British Judge Urges Public Inquiry Into Litvinenko Death
text: LONDON — In an unusual attempt to circumvent official restrictions on evidence, a British judge urged the government on Wednesday to hold a public inquiry into the death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer poisoned in London in 2006 with radioactive polonium.

headline: Racing Ambassadors Are Spreading the News About the Belmont
text: The Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes have come and gone, and with this, racing fans have also seen their hopes of a Triple Crown winner in 2013 shattered almost before they could even tell what had happened. Every year fans hope that after the Derby, that year’s winner will continue on and become a Triple Crown winner — something fans believe our sport desperately needs. No one said it was easy, and that is why no horse has completed the feat since Affirmed in 1978.

headline: In Besieged Area of Syria, Bitterness of Sunnis Points to Rending of Sects
text: NEAR QUSAYR, Syria — In the final days of their stubborn but increasingly hopeless stand against an overwhelming assault, Syrian rebels hid among the concrete shells of destroyed houses in the village of Hamediyeh, subsisting on olives and canned beans. They tried to sleep, without much success, in tunnels dug for shelter from government shelling.

headline: Trial Date Set for Former SAC Trader in Insider Case
text: Mathew Martoma, the former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, is set to stand trial on Nov. 4, almost a year after federal authorities charged him in what they called the largest insider trading case ever brought.

headline: Start-Up to Connect Home Appliances
text: One of Silicon Valley’s favorite buzz phrases is “Internet of things,” a catchall for everyday stuff like home appliances and light bulbs that are connected to the Internet. Nest Labs, a company founded by a former Apple executive that makes a smart thermostat, has brought cachet to the category and gotten a lot of other manufacturers thinking about how they can bring the Internet to their otherwise humdrum products.

headline: Harlem Legislator Accused of D.W.I. in Albany Suburb
text: ALBANY — Robert J. Rodriguez, a state assemblyman from Harlem, has been charged with driving while intoxicated in a suburb of the capital, the police said on Wednesday.

headline: Final-Like Semifinal in Paris: Djokovic Will Meet Nadal
text: PARIS — It has been nearly two weeks since a murmur and a few groans went through the room in Paris after Rafael Nadal landed on the same side of the French Open draw as Novak Djokovic.

headline: Packing Lunches, and Packing Up the School Year
text: The school my children attend ends its lunch program nearly two weeks before school ends.

headline: ‘Waiting to Be Heard’
text: To the Editor:

headline: 60 Seconds With Pogue: Dashlane
text: David Pogue on the convenience and security of Dashlane, a free password manager.

headline: Video of Samantha Power’s 2002 Remarks on Imposing Peace on Israel Could Haunt Her, Israeli Paper Says
text: Last Updated, 5:12 p.m. Even before the official announcement by President Obama on Wednesday that he would nominate Samantha Power to be the next United States ambassador to the United Nations, various aspects of her record were being picked apart and debated, weighed against the potential for confirmation.

headline: The 2012 Fiction Pulitzer
text: To the Editor:

headline: What to Watch on Day 12 at the French Open
text: After spreading itself thin over two courts for the quarterfinals, the action for the semifinals will be condensed onto one court, with the men getting the day off and the women’s semifinals taking center stage. With the final four all ranked in the Top 5, it’s hard to ask for much more from Thursday’s slate. Here’s a look at the two penultimate women’s singles matches, plus a bonus glimpse at a doubles semifinal:

headline: Remember All Those Passwords? No Need
text: “If you want to avoid having your identity stolen, use long passwords that contain digits, punctuation and no recognizable words. Make up a different password for every Web site. And change all of your passwords every 30 days.”

headline: Dell’s Board Puts Investors in a Bind
text: Dell’s board special committee has neatly painted investors into a corner.

headline: Literature Down Under
text: To the Editor:

headline: Daft Punk Holds On at No.1
text: This week on Billboard’s music charts, Daft Punk’s new album holds at No. 1 and the rap duo Macklemore & Ryan Lewis extends its run with the top single.

headline: Cara Black, a Doubles Wizard, Shows She Is Back
text: PARIS — It was a French Open quarterfinal that felt like a final, fiercely fought by two teams of near equals.

headline: Bruins’ Domination of Penguins Has Been Very Penguin-Like
text: It is not unusual to see at team in Pittsburgh skating circles around its opponent for two straight games, especially this postseason. But usually the team skating the circles is the Penguins, who had outscored their playoff opponents 26-10 at home entering the Eastern Conference finals against Boston.

headline: Humanities Endowment to Investigate Grants Made to Scholarly Society
text: The National Endowment for the Humanities will conduct an investigation of three grants awarded to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the scholarly society in Cambridge, Mass., whose president, Leslie C. Berlowitz, has been accused of falsely claiming on various documents to hold a doctorate.

headline: If You Drive on the Beach, Reduce the Air in Your Tires
text: It’s beach season, and in some locales that means beach driving. The video above is a good depiction of why it’s a good idea to air down your tires before driving on sand. Aired-down tires have a wider footprint and float better over soft sand than hard, fully inflated tires. A good place to start is 15 pounds per square inch.

headline: The Gossip Just Won’t Stop
text: Around 10:30 p.m. last Wednesday, 12 days after his 29-year tenure as the gossip columnist for The Village Voice was abruptly ended by the newspaper’s owner, Michael Musto was in a TriBeCa production studio, dressed in a bedazzled tuxedo jacket, getting ready for his first post-Voice job.

headline: A. M. Homes Awarded Women’s Prize for Fiction
text: Hilary Mantel can’t win them all. A. M. Homes took home the Women’s Prize for Fiction on Wednesday night in London, for her novel “May We Be Forgiven.”

headline: Obama Presents New Security Team
text: President Obama introduced Susan E. Rice as the national security adviser and Samantha Power as the new American Ambassador to the United Nations.

headline: She Swims Again (Flies, Too)
text: MILLBURN, N.J. — Under the sea, things seem to have calmed down a bit.

headline: Bobby’s on the Lower East Side
text: Bobby’s, a new night spot on the Lower East Side, is hoping to capitalize on the Gatsby-inspired rage for all things ’20s. Just south of Delancey Street, a green light glows (à la East Egg) above the unmarked entrance to a formerly generic club that has been given a sleek Art Deco makeover in hopes of attracting dapper dudes and their latter-day flappers.

headline: The Argument Against Oil Drilling in Arctic Seas
text: The Natural Resources Defense Council has issued a statement concluding that recent events — most notably the grounding of a Shell Oil drilling rig in Alaska — show the oil industry is not ready to safely, cleanly drill offshore in the Arctic.

headline: Even Silence Is Steeped in Emotion
text: There are some good stories in “Tea for Three: Lady Bird, Pat & Betty.” But sometimes the silences tell the best tales.

headline: Sybrina’s Sorrow
text: Sybrina Fulton hasn’t been able to visit her son Trayvon Martin’s grave site since the Florida teenager was buried 15 months ago.

headline: Kirna Zabête to Move to Larger Store in SoHo
text: After 14 years in the same space with the same lavender-painted hardwood floors, Kirna Zabête, the SoHo emporium of daring design, is moving this month to a new home with twice the space. Just inside the entrance of the 10,000-square-foot store at 477 Broome Street (Wooster Street), will be a wall of quotations in neon lights, the origins of which might have been Coco Chanel. Or maybe Carrie Bradshaw.

headline: Sabathia, Now Crafty, Has Perfect Start in Complete Game
text: Nick Swisher was C. C. Sabathia’s teammate for four years with the Yankees, observing the big left-hander mostly from right field. On Wednesday, though, he acted surprised at what he saw while facing Sabathia for the first time with the Cleveland Indians.

headline: How Bad Is European Youth Unemployment?
text: My Sunday column returned to what’s become a recurring theme of mine: The remarkable political quiescence of Europeans in the face of the economic devastation wrought by their rolling disaster of a currency union. In this case, my jumping-off point was what the Atlantic’s Derek Thompson calls “the scariest graph in the world,” which shows youth unemployment — for under-25-year-olds, that is — breaking 40 percent in Italy, 50 percent in Spain and 60 percent in Greece. So it’s worth saying something about the (fairly widespread) rejoinder that these numbers aren’t actually as bad as they look, because most young people are in school or training rather than looking fruitlessly for work. For instance, here’s the Financial Times’ Kate Allen, downplaying the youth-unemployment crisis:

headline: Proenza Schouler Updates Its First Collection
text: Observing some of their colleagues wearing pieces from the early days of Proenza Schouler recently, Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough had a thought. If it still looks good after 10 years, why not make it again?

headline: Finding Country Truths in Nature and in People
text: When I was a boy growing up in rural New Hampshire there were a few old men who always wore overalls and who lived out in the woods. And those men — Chief, Pop, Jake — knew where to find the best wild dandelion greens, sensed when the sucker fish were running the mill race, and squinted at the sky as if it were a baseball box score printed in the tiniest type.

headline: Is This Senegal’s Answer to ‘The Daily Show’?
text: Even if you can’t decipher every word of the weekly YouTube show “Journal Rappé” — part music video, part news broadcast delivered entirely in French and Wolof by two Senegalese rappers — it’s worth checking out. Especially given that Senegal happens to be on Barack Obama’s itinerary when he makes his longest trip to Africa as president later this month. (Grist for the “Africa Rising” meme?)

headline: SAP’s Purchasing Power Play
text: SAP just did a big acquisition, along with a little head fake.

headline: Latest Resort Collections: Balenciaga, Altuzarra and Derek Lam
text: For Alexander Wang’s first resort collection for Balenciaga, presented Wednesday morning at the company’s new showroom on West 22nd Street, which was formerly a Balenciaga store, the designer took a trip to Getaria, in Spain, to visit the coastal city where Cristobal Balenciaga was born. Mr. Wang and members of the design studio toured the museum there to see some pieces that were not in the company’s own archives.

headline: Chefs on the Move
text: Robert Moorman, who was at North End Grill, is the new executive chef at Krescendo, in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, which opened last fall and is owned by Nancy Puglisi. The original chef, Elizabeth Falkner, has left.

headline: The Middle Class Strikes Back
text: WASHINGTON — SINCE 2002, Turkey’s sound economic policies have made it a member of the Group of 20 and turned it into a majority middle-class society for the first time in its history. Yet this week’s huge protests show that the ruling Justice and Development Party, known as the A.K.P., has become a victim of its own success.

headline: Development Won’t Ensure Democracy in Turkey
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — FOR the past few years, there has been a general optimism about Turkish democracy in Western capitals, especially in Washington, thanks to the economic strides made by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s Justice and Development Party, known as the A.K.P.

headline: Activists’ Stunt Livens Up a Routine Senate Session
text: ALBANY – There wasn’t much to see in the State Senate on Wednesday: the reciting of the Pledge of Allegiance, the honoring of a basketball player and a bunch of empty seats where elected representatives are paid to sit.

headline: Changes in Obama’s Foreign Policy Team
text: President Obama’s new foreign policy team is filled with some of his closest advisers and confidants, many of whom waited patiently for the top jobs during his first term.

headline: Therapy for Victims of Sexual Violence Shows Promise in Congo
text: A type of group therapy designed for trauma victims has proved extraordinarily helpful for survivors of sexual violence in Democratic Republic of Congo, enabling women to overcome the shame, nightmares and terrifying flashbacks that had left them unable to work or take care of their families or themselves, researchers report.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Turkey, Bangladesh and Germany.

headline: An Evening Dedicated to Charmers
text: Orchestras sometimes use gala concerts as an occasion to ditch the Bruckner and Beethoven and focus on other genres, as the New York Philharmonic did on Tuesday evening with a lineup of Broadway, Brazilian and classical songs at Avery Fisher Hall. The program, “An Enchanted Evening With Paulo Szot,” featured the charismatic baritone in a range of repertory conducted by Ted Sperling.

headline: Charge Your iPad in Luxury
text: Strut, a maker of grills and wheels for luxury cars, is seeking to add its touch of refinement to the iPad.

headline: Lessons for the Living, Courtesy of the Dead
text: If you’ve avoided vampire/zombie television until now because you think it’s either dumb sci-fi or drippy romance aimed at teenagers, “In the Flesh,” a three-part mini-series that begins Thursday on BBC America, gives you a chance to find out just how well written and layered some of these shows are.

headline: Jewish Folk Songs, Set to Fela’s Afrobeat
text: As Jon Madof worked at his computer one Friday in 2011, doing the graphic-design job that supported his life as a guitarist, he listened to the Afrobeat music of Fela Anikulapo-Kuti. Then, with the Sabbath sundown nearing, he shut down his home office and began humming one of the Jewish religious songs made famous by Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach.

headline: In Store | Hedi Slimane’s Sleek New Saint Laurent Flagship
text: For many, marble might conjure antiquity. But Hedi Slimane has put the majestic material to thoroughly contemporary use in the new Saint Laurent Paris flagship store in SoHo, which opened today. The brand’s first outpost downtown is part of Slimane’s revamp of the label, which until recently was known by the initials YSL. Black-and-white silk-marble panels flank the walls, lending an airiness and sophistication to the space, which also features 19th-century cast-iron columns and tin ceilings typical of the neighborhood.

headline: Countries Seek Entrepreneurs From Silicon Valley
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A bold new billboard looms over U.S. 101, the highway that runs through the heart of the global technology industry. “H-1b problems?” it reads. “Pivot to Canada.”

headline: Open Trial to Select U.S. Team for Bermuda Bowl
text: The Open Trial taking place in Orlando, Fla., will select the two United States teams for the Bermuda Bowl in September. The semifinal draw for the unbeaten teams is Martin Fleisher, Michael Kamil, Zia Mahmood, Chip Martel, Michael Rosenberg and Chris Willenken against Warren Spector, Michael Becker, Curtis Cheek, Joe Grue, Fred Gitelman and Brad Moss; and Nick Nickell, Ralph Katz, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell versus John Kranyak, Gavin Wolpert, Kevin Bathurst and Kevin Dwyer.

headline: A Rainbow of Fragility
text: A line from the Sting song “Fragile” — “Nothing comes from violence/And nothing ever could” — became much more than a sad reflection on human nature when sung by the Arab-Israeli singer and songwriter Mira Awad at the Metropolitan Room on Tuesday evening. Ms. Awad, 37, who sings in Arabic and English and occasionally in Hebrew, was born in Rameh in Galilee to a Palestinian father and Bulgarian mother. She stars in “Arab Labor,” a popular Israeli television comedy about Jewish and Arab coexistence.

headline: Byron’s Gloomy Pirate Tale, With Bikini Tutus Added
text: Next year brings the bicentennial of Byron’s heroic poem “The Corsair” — a literary sensation that sold some 10,000 copies on its first day of publication. In foreign translations it so flourished over the next few decades that it prompted multiple stage adaptations, including an opera by Verdi (1848) and a Parisian ballet choreographed by Joseph Mazilier to music by Adolphe Adam (1856). Yet by one of the more perverse tricks of artistic fate, the most popular version of it today is a Russian ballet that contains nothing of Mazilier’s choreography or much of Adam’s music and in which Byron’s original poem, heavy with tragic emotion, is distorted into an absurd romp.

headline: Share Ideas on Travel With Kids in N.Y.C.
text: Next week, the Travel section will start a new series of articles on traveling with children in big cities. The series will include tips on everything from unexpected kid-friendly attractions to basics like where to eat and find a bathroom.

headline: Taking the Rockabus to the Rockaways
text: What better time than Memorial Day to show support for one of the places hardest hit by Hurricane Sandy. Sun, sand and suds included.

headline: Sun, Sand and Suds
text: On the morning of Memorial Day, as the sun broke through the wet blanket of a weekend, more than a dozen 20- and 30-somethings in striped tank tops and straw hats boarded a yellow school bus idling in a bleak parking lot in Williamsburg.

headline: The New Guy (With a Gun) at a Dream Beach House
text: “Graceland,” is a confusing title for a series that isn’t about Elvis Presley or Paul Simon in his South African period.

headline: Container Store Said to Prepare for an I.P.O.
text: The Container Store has begun to hire advisers to prepare for a potential initial public offering, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday, nearly five years after selling itself to the private equity firm Leonard Green & Partners.

headline: Cleaning More Than Cobwebs
text: It turns out that Bhakti Sondra Shaye does windows. She also scours microwaves, refrigerators, dishwashers and closets.

headline: Fending Off the Bad Spirits
text: If you are a feng shui expert or, for that matter, a Jewish grandmother, you are likely to believe that a scrupulously clean and tidy home is the first defense against bad spirits. (No place to hide.) But even at the risk of cluttering, you may want to acquire a talisman or two. The following demon-repelling goods not only have the endorsements of ancient belief systems (in some cases, several), but they are also pleasing to the senses (in some cases, several).

headline: Bushwick Open Studios 2013
text: The arty denizens of the neighborhood throw open their doors for the annual spate of exhibitions.

headline: At Every Turn, Another Strange World
text: Bushwick is not, as you may have read (and read and read), the coolest place in the universe, though for three days every year it may be the coolest place in the five boroughs.

headline: A Homestead for House Stalkers
text: Listening to Jade-Snow Carroll and Ian Rasch talk about the 1,650-square-foot, two-bedroom passive-solar house they built two years ago amid rolling farmland here, one senses it is soon to become a memory rather than a place where memories will be made. If building a house is this much fun, they seemed to be saying, why not do it again?

headline: The Simple Modern Solution
text: A sun-warmed, plant-filled box for living.

headline: Accessories for Outdoor Entertaining
text: With the outdoor entertaining season finally under way, it’s time to take stock of the accessories. And like anything that has been in hibernation for the better part of the year, they can look a bit worse for wear.

headline: Shopping for Accessories for Outdoor Entertaining
text: Bronson van Wyck, an event planner, takes stock of new accessories with the outdoor entertaining season finally under way.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. Does it matter how I stock and organize my fridge and pantry before showings?

headline: Beyond the ‘Palace,’ an International Tour in One City
text: VENICE — Dark weather and high water were the backdrop to the start of the 55th Venice Biennale, an event that predictably combines enough cold cash and hot air to create a storm system of critical opinion. The main barometric indicator is always the big show that gives each Biennale its theme, and on this score, for the first time in years, there’s fairly smooth sailing.

headline: Their Annual Migration
text: An American couple make the trek every year to their house in the Andes.

headline: Rampant Blooms, but No Color
text: Amika: Hairdo Bar, a two-story, 700-square-foot hairstyling salon, will open June 11 in Hong Kong. “We’re demystifying hair styling, making things faster and easier,” said Vita Raykhman, 31, the creative director of Amika, a Brooklyn hair products company. The Hairdo Bar, Amika’s first salon, will allow a woman to change her image in less than 40 minutes “without the commitment of a cut or a color,” Ms. Raykhman said. Customers will be offered a choice of 12 hair styles, with prices ranging from $24 to $70. Guy Zucker of Z-A Studio in Manhattan designed the space on a budget of $90,000 using the company’s flower-shaped graphic identity as an architectural motif. On the first floor, the birch plywood walls are cut into floral silhouettes, and flowers are printed on the wallpaper in the rear. Upstairs, the flower shape is applied to the booths. Hairdo Bar is at 8 Elgin Street, Hong Kong, 011-852-2291-0070. Three additional shops will open in New York City next year.

headline: Up in the Clouds
text: CAÑAR, Ecuador — Most people aren’t willing to drive more than a few hours to get to a second home in the country.

headline: Darling of Cannes Now at Center of Storm
text: PARIS — Last month the film “Blue Is the Warmest Color” was the toast of Cannes. A drama about young lesbian love, it was so celebrated for its explicit sex scenes that it won the festival’s top prize. Since then it’s being castigated for those very same scenes.

headline: An Ultramodern Island Draws on Italian Styling
text: Minacciolo, the Italian interiors company, says its Mina kitchen is the ultimate accessory, but really it is an island unto itself — with cooktop, oven, dual dishwashing drawers, illuminated storage and refrigeration in a customizable package.

headline: Illustrator to City: It’s Personal
text: Peter Kuper, the cartoonist and illustrator, has tried to capture his three decades in New York, and the city itself, with “Drawn to New York” (PM Press; $29.95). “You can’t be comprehensive because it’s too big a piece of pie to swallow — or apple, rather,” Mr. Kuper said. Instead, he inks his own experiences, which seem informed by the twin responses shared by many New York transplants: anxiety and wonder. In one illustration, a lone man looks out from his darkened apartment and wonders how many people are having sex at that moment. Another panel tells the story of a long-ago night when Mr. Kuper and a friend scaled the suspension cables of the Brooklyn Bridge. The artistic styles change from page to page, mirroring the frenetic, unpredictable nature of the city. As Mr. Kuper said, “The thing I like about New York is the quality of feeling like you’re traveling at all times.”

headline: Contemporary Design Lands in Antiques Country
text: Hudson, N.Y., is an antiques-hunter’s haven, but it is becoming more of a source of contemporary design as well, with the opening of Fern Handcrafted Furniture.

headline: Garage Band Ceramics
text: Paula Greif’s whimsical, wiggly, home-brewed designs.

headline: Now What’s Her Line?
text: Paula Greif made some of the first music videos for MTV (on Super 8 film, no less) and designed album covers for Madonna, Debbie Harry and Paul Simon. Though she has been the art director of Mademoiselle and for Barneys New York, and worked with fashion photographers like Richard Avedon, Steven Meisel and Arthur Elgort, Ms. Greif was always a rocker at heart. When she was in the art department of Self magazine in the late ’70s, she spent her nights at CBGB and the Mudd Club, and slept under her desk at lunch. Now 60, she is making ceramics, animated porcelain and terra-cotta pieces that look like wiggly line drawings (you can find them occasionally on her Web site — be warned, she is frequently sold out — and at Beautiful Dreamers, a store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn). Ms. Greif calls her pottery “garage band ceramics” because of its handmade funkiness and because her new career has unfolded in a typically ad hoc, no-frills manner.

headline: New York’s Clueless Election Board Drags Out Ancient Machines
text: New York City voters should be prepared to cast their ballots once again this fall on voting machines invented in the 19th century. State legislators were apparently close to a deal on Wednesday afternoon to allow New York City’s clueless board of elections to use the old mechanical machines for the city’s September 10 primary.

headline: Greek Regrets
text: The IMF has released a fairly remarkable piece of self-criticism (pdf) over policy in Greece. On a first read, the report seems to suggest two main failings on the IMF’s part: it failed to acknowledge early on that Greece simply could not repay its debt in full, and it vastly underestimated the economic damage austerity would inflict.

headline: Sales at Hable Construction, the Future Perfect and Others
text: All in-stock pillows are 25 percent off at Hable Construction, through June 13 (a 14-by-18-inch Azul Waterfalls pillow, usually $65, is now about $49); the code SUMMER should be entered at check out, (817) 422-5313, hableconstruction.com.

headline: A Spiritual Center of Power Is a Required Stop on Iran’s Campaign Trail
text: QUM, Iran — Qum, home to some of Iran’s most influential clerics, is not just Iran’s holiest city, but one of its most powerful, a Shiite Vatican in the desert that can make or break any Iranian political career. So it is not surprising that it has become a destination recently for almost all of the candidates in next week’s presidential election, seeking to sip from the cocktail of money, politics and religion that the city represents.

headline: Rockaways Rising
text: What’s open and closed on the still-fashionable beach:

headline: The Tablet or Smartphone Becomes a Tutor for the Budding Artist
text: The smartphone revolution, among other things, has put a camera in everyone’s pocket. This has led to an explosion in the art of photography — if you can call an Instagram self-portrait art. But smartphones and tablets have another ability that is genuinely arty: they can help teach basic drawing and sketching.

headline: Civil Disobedience on a Turkish Game Show
text: While most of Turkey’s journalists were carefully avoiding mention of the tens of thousands of protesters who poured into the streets this week, in a show of deference to the government that enraged supporters of the demonstrations, the host of one Turkish game show found a way to raise the issue not once but 70 times during a broadcast on Monday night.

headline: Painting the Lily? He’s One Up on That
text: By the time Delano Brown showed up at his first New York gallery show, a model in a white dress had been waiting — silently, fiercely — more than an hour for his paint. She was doing such a good job of staring into the distance that the phenomenally well-appointed crowd filling the Smart Clothes Gallery on the Lower East Side stopped noticing her almost entirely.

headline: If You’re Not Going to Wear That …
text: “What girl isn’t interested in seeing what her friend has in her closet?” So reasoned Ambre Dahan, the design director of Joe’s Jeans and now the founder, with Amandine Rohmer, of Walk in My Closet, a virtual wardrobe manager and shopping site. Like many of us, she and Ms. Rohmer often shared new purchases and outfits via text. The new site (walkinmycloset.com) and app, available on iTunes this week, streamlines the whole process. How it works: You download the app and shoot the items in your closet like a pro (it silhouettes them on a white background) and essentially create a boutique of everything you own. From there, you can make packing lists, sell things you never wear — for a 25 percent commission — and buy from other users, who include founding members like Charlotte Ronson, Irene Neuwirth and Julia Restoin Roitfeld. If you ever find yourself saying, “I don’t have anything to wear,” think of this as your new best friend.

headline: Bally Offers Mountaineer Reindeer Boots
text: It is one of the 20th century’s most memorable photos: the one Edmund Hillary took of Tenzing Norgay on May 29, 1953, standing at the summit of Mount Everest, the highest point on earth. Now, 60 years later, there is an answer to the question everyone — or at least one or two people — has been asking ever since: where can I get those chic reindeer boots? The answer is Bally, the Swiss company that in the ’40s began custom-making boots for serious mountaineers, among them the pair that Tenzing wore for his storied ascent. In honor of the anniversary of that climb — and the fact that the old-fashioned mountaineer has become a style model in men’s fashion — Bally is issuing a new version of the boots. The sole is lighter in weight and they lace more easily. But like the originals, they are available only by order, and they are still made of reindeer fur. They may never help you get to the top of a mountain, but, at $2,495, they will definitely get you to the tiptop of your credit card limit. Bally, 628 Madison Avenue; (212) 751-9082.

headline: Monoprice Introduces an LED Monitor
text: Monoprice, the Web retailer best known for its low-priced cables, continues to expand its product line with a 27-inch high-resolution LED computer monitor it showed at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas last January. The price? $475, nearly a third less than many models with similar specifications.

headline: Sheer Garments Make a Tasteful Return
text: Despite the sheer number of sheer garments in recent runway collections, a public display of underwear still seems vaguely … well, amateur. But we’re getting past it. Bras, we’ve noticed, are now fully (and chicly) on display. There was Julia Restoin Roitfeld, who was out and about with an opaque bra under a beautiful sheer blouse; the model Hye Park, whose bra was visible under a sheer white shirt and tuxedo jacket; and the actress Stella Schnabel, who looked impeccable in all-white tailoring, including the underpinnings. What makes the looks winning is the juxtaposition of peek-a-boo sex appeal with sharp lines and volume. Instead of grungy, the effect is sophisticated and modern.

headline: Orlebar Brown Swim Trunks Use Paris Review Art
text: The British pop-meets-prep swimwear label Orlebar Brown, known for its well-cut swim trunks, does the collaboration thing well. Already it has done limited editions with Monocle magazine and Alan Aldridge, the illustrator famous for his work with the Beatles, among other imaginative collaborations. The latest (and most highbrow) is a venture with The Paris Review, in which it is reprinting select archival cover illustrations on the classic Orlebar Brown midlength swim shorts. Included are a Kim MacConnel beach scene, titled “Ten Items or Less,” from the summer ’80 cover; Donald Sultan’s orange flowers from summer ’96; and a Leanne Shapton figure drawing from the spring 2011 cover. Any dad with an appreciation of cool men’s fashion or graphic design or literature will gladly take a pair on Father’s Day.

headline: ‘Real Housewives’ of the World
text: Bravo’s “Real Housewives” franchise has a global reach, inspiring versions in countries like Canada, Israel and Greece.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Zynga Memories and Wi-Fi Agriculture
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Judge Orders All Restrictions Lifted on Some ‘Morning-After’ Pills
text: A federal appeals court in New York on Wednesday ordered that some types of emergency contraceptives be made available for now to women of all ages without a prescription, adding another layer of confusion to a complex and intensely political fight over the drug’s availability.

headline: Scouting Report
text: CFDA Winners

headline: When an Ally Treats Protests Harshly
text: How should the United States respond to the Turkish government's reaction to dissent?

headline: Komen Breast Cancer Charity Cancels Races in 7 Cities
text: The Susan G. Komen for the Cure foundation has canceled half of its “3-Day” fund-raising races around the country next year as it struggles to regain support nearly 18 months after its 2012 decision to withdraw funding for breast cancer screening at some Planned Parenthood affiliates.

headline: Keith Suspended for Game
text: The N.H.L. suspended Duncan Keith of the Chicago Blackhawks for one game for his one-handed high stick on Los Angeles Kings forward Jeff Carter in Tuesday’s Game 3. The stick struck Carter in the mouth and neck. Carter said he sustained damage to several of his teeth and required about 20 stitches because of various cuts. Keith said it was an accident.

headline: In Nigeria, ‘Killing People Without Asking Who They Are’
text: BOSSO, Niger — For the soldiers, the young men’s long, flowing robes — the traditional garb of Muslim West Africa — were enough to establish guilt, the refugees said.

headline: An Old Staple of Black Culture Now Adds to a New Restaurant’s Décor
text: It started with Miss Susie. Miss Susie owns a brownstone a few doors from Dennis Decker on West 119th Street in Harlem, where over the years she rented out rooms and tenant after tenant left scraps of their lives behind. Last summer, Mr. Decker helped his 84-year-old neighbor, known to everyone simply as Miss Susie, by organizing a cleaning, and in the sifting came across a handful of vintage Jet magazines.

headline: Meanwhile, Back at the Resort Collections…
text: The long, lean line of Francisco Costa’s resort clothes for Calvin Klein today seemed attuned to the moment, though we won’t be seeing these designs in stores for several months. Most of the skirt lengths were below the knee, and below the belly button, and Mr. Costa kept shifting attention from bare midriffs to sorcerer cover-ups with long sleeves.

headline: T.S.A. Drops an Effort to Allow Some Knives on Planes
text: Facing strong opposition from flight attendants and lawmakers, the Transportation Security Administration said Wednesday that it was abandoning a plan to allow passengers to carry small knives on board.

headline: City Reverts to Its Days of Hobbling
text: It was New York City’s clunky, unsophisticated emblem of 1980s law and order — part security tool, part public shaming device — fastened to the front wheels of offending vehicles like the mark of Cain.

headline: Chief of Boston Marathon Bombing Fund Stands Firm on Deadline
text: BOSTON — The fund to aid victims of the Boston Marathon blasts has grown quickly, with nearly $40 million raised since the bombings on April 15. But with just over a week to go before the June 15 deadline to apply for compensation, only a fraction of the anticipated beneficiaries have done so, raising questions among lawyers and health care professionals about whether ample time has been provided to ask for help.

headline: Fort Hood Suspect Given More Time to Prepare Defense, Most Likely Delaying Trial
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — The long-delayed court-martial of the Army psychiatrist accused in a shooting rampage at Fort Hood here will most likely be delayed again after a judge on Wednesday instructed prospective jurors from other posts to return home while the court clears up logistical and legal issues arising out of the defendant’s decision to represent himself.

headline: Publishers Tell of Disputes With Apple on E-Book Prices
text: In an e-mail to her boss, Leslie Moonves, Carolyn K. Reidy, the chief executive of Simon & Schuster, dismissed an Apple executive as a “minion.”

headline: Debt Deal in Alabama Will Cost JPMorgan
text: Under the deal to settle the bankruptcy of Jefferson County, Ala., firms that invested in its distressed debt will have the most to gain, JPMorgan Chase will face a big loss, and residents will be wondering whether there will be any relief for them.

headline: As Investors Bail Out, SAC Shows a Brave Face
text: SAC Capital Advisors, the besieged hedge fund owned by the billionaire stock picker Steven A. Cohen, has told its employees that it will survive a wave of investor withdrawals during the government’s intensifying investigation into possible insider trading at the firm.

headline: North Carolina Repeals Law Allowing Racial Bias Claim in Death Penalty Challenges
text: A law that allowed death-row inmates to challenge their sentences based on racial bias claims was repealed by the North Carolina legislature on Wednesday, paving the way for executions to resume in a state that has 152 people on death row.

headline: In Clash of Styles, Only Certainty Is Worthy Champ
text: MIAMI — On one side of the 2013 N.B.A finals is Tim Duncan, a quiet superstar who has stayed put for 16 years in south Texas. On the other is the world-renowned LeBron James, who left home in blue-collar northern Ohio for the glitterati of South Beach.

headline: Betty Ford Center and Hazelden Seek Business Partnership
text: With the Affordable Care Act poised to make addiction treatment available to millions of new patients, the Betty Ford Center and the Hazelden Foundation, two of the biggest names in substance abuse recovery, are pursuing a formal business alliance, the two groups said Tuesday. The boards of both institutions have approved the alliance in principle, though neither group will so far divulge specifics of the plan. Hazelden has a network of 10 treatment centers throughout the country.  Starting in 2014, Medicare and all insurance sold on Health Insurance Exchanges will be required to provide treatment for substance abuse under a provision of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Election Move Typifies Christie: Fast and With Politics in Mind
text: Even before Frank R. Lautenberg’s death, Gov. Chris Christie had a solution on how to fill the United States Senate seat he would vacate, a choice the governor knew was rich with political risk and reward.

headline: Fill a U.N.-Bound Double-Decker With Diplomats? Citing Risk, New York’s Police Say No
text: The classic red London double-decker crossed the Atlantic by ship this spring. On its early runs through the streets of New York City, Prime Minister David Cameron and Prince Harry were passengers. It ventured as far away as Boston in its promotional campaign for all things British.

headline: The Sizable Shadow That Won’t Leave the Yankees
text: When Mark Teixeira squeezed the final out of the Yankees’ last championship, in 2009, he bolted across the diamond from first base. Teixeira would say later he had no plan for the celebration; he just took off, a spontaneous expression of joy. He was not trying to run toward Alex Rodriguez.

headline: Can Pakistan Make Peace Next Door?
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — IN the spring of 1992, as the Communist government in Afghanistan started imploding after the collapse of the Soviet Union, seven Afghan mujahedeen leaders, pumped full of C.I.A. money, gathered in Peshawar, Pakistan, to discuss how to take over Afghanistan and share power peacefully.

headline: Don’t Treat Consumers Like Criminals
text: WASHINGTON — THE House Judiciary Committee will hold a much-needed hearing today on cellphone unlocking. At stake is whether wireless consumers can be prosecuted for what, not long ago, was considered a routine practice.

headline: Promoter Ignored Ill Singer, Jackson Family Lawyers Say
text: In the days before Michael Jackson died in June 2009, a flurry of e-mails passed among music executives about the singer’s missing rehearsals and sometimes appearing gaunt and weak as he prepared for a string of comeback concerts, according to evidence at Jackson’s wrongful death trial in Los Angeles.

headline: Escape From North Korea
text: A smuggler named Dragon attempts to guide North Korean defectors across China into safe asylum.

headline: The Way to Run College Sports
text: So, are you convinced yet? Do you need any more proof that college presidents are not qualified to run a major entertainment industry like college football and men’s basketball? That whatever their academic and fund-raising skills, they are in over their heads whenever they involve themselves in the $6 billion-and-counting business that big-time college sports has become? Besides, don’t they have other things to do?

headline: Watchdog Halts Action on Researchers
text: The federal Office for Human Research Protections announced on Wednesday that it would suspend action against the University of Alabama at Birmingham, which it said in March did not adequately inform parents about the risks to their premature infants of enrollment in a large research trial.

headline: After a Police Pursuit Ends Fatally, Doubts Arise Over the Decision to Give Chase
text: It was a situation nearly as old and familiar as the automobile: a police chase of a suspect fleeing in a vehicle.

headline: ‘Escape From North Korea’
text: In this Op-Doc video, I profile a smuggler named Dragon, who charges North Korean defectors for guiding them through China and Southeast Asia into eventual asylum and safety in South Korea. They provided me with remarkable access to their courageous journey. (I did my best to protect their identities.) As you’ll see, a North Korean’s pursuit of freedom comes at a price.

headline: Tennis’s Cloud of Dust
text: PARIS — For several months, Rafael Nadal has been vocal about his wish for fewer hardcourt tournaments and more on clay. The rationale is simple: the softer clay courts are much better for players’ knees.

headline: A Hint of ‘Mad Men’ in an Agency Merger
text: A MAJOR plotline this season on the AMC series “Mad Men” is about an unexpected merger of two independent agencies so they could get bigger to compete for and handle larger accounts. Now, in a life-imitates-art moment, two actual independent agencies are merging, for that same reason.

headline: Better Teachers for New York City
text: The new teacher evaluation system that the New York State education commissioner, John King Jr., has imposed on New York City represents an important and necessary step toward carrying out the rigorous new Common Core education reforms.

headline: Chinese Champ Back to Defend Her Title
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Shanshan Feng of China says she has always chased Yani Tseng of Taiwan, since the two were 13-year-olds competing in Asia. Tseng was always better when they were juniors, and that didn’t change years later when the two women found themselves half a world away competing on the L.P.G.A. Tour.

headline: The Split Between the States
text: Wisconsin and Minnesota are neighboring states with long traditions of caring for the least fortunate, but, at the moment, only one of them is concerned about the health of the poor and uninsured.

headline: Fighting ‘Patent Trolls’
text: Abusive patent litigation is a festering problem that costs the American economy billions of dollars. This week President Obama proposed promising reforms to rein in lawsuits filed by businesses that buy patents with the intent of suing individuals and businesses for using or selling products that they claim violate their patents.

headline: Power to the Preschoolers
text: “Spread the word about President Obama’s plan to provide high-quality preschool for every kid in America,” twittered the White House on Wednesday. We all know that nothing on the planet compares to the awesome power of social media. But it may require more than a hashtag to bring this one home.

headline: Paying Tribute to a Seeker of Justice, 50 Years After His Assassination
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — Myrlie Evers-Williams, the widow of the slain civil rights leader Medgar Evers, said her husband was a man who saw a job that needed to be done, and he answered the call, “not just for his people but for all people.”

headline: A Suspect Food Warning in Britain Spreads an Alarm
text: The case of the labels warning of genetically modified wheat found on Kraft Mac & Cheese boxes in Britain has been solved.

headline: John Dingell, the Longest-Serving Member of Congress
text: Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, served 29 consecutive terms before not running for re-election in 2014.

headline: Dingell Reflects on Nearly 60 Years in Politics
text: John D. Dingell Jr., a Michigan Democrat, became the longest-serving member of Congress in American history in 2013. That year, he sat down with The New York Times and discussed his years in U.S. politics.

headline: Financial Fears Gain Credence as Unrest Shakes Turkey
text: LONDON — It is not often that the rock-throwing street protester and the seasoned bond investor see eye to eye.

headline: Defenseman’s Rousing Play Enlivens the Kings
text: LOS ANGELES — Even after a victory, the Los Angeles Kings’ locker room can have all the color and festivity of a mortuary, with its stoic, black-and-white-clad competitors repeating remarks about team play, finding a way and immediately hitting the reset button for the next game.

headline: From ‘a Child of the House’ to Longest-Serving Member
text: WASHINGTON — In an institution where seniority has long been prized, Representative John D. Dingell Jr. of Michigan is about to set a new standard with 57 years, 5 months and 26 days of House service — a remarkable tenure that spans more than a quarter of the existence of Congress.

headline: I.M.F. Concedes Major Missteps in Bailout of Greece
text: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund released an internal report on Wednesday that sharply criticizes its first bailout program for Greece, the latest in a series of partial mea culpas as the fund reassesses the austerity that it has insisted on for ailing, debt-plagued economies.

headline: Top Arm, but Maybe Not No. 1 in Draft
text: Last season, Mark Appel, a Stanford right-hander, was considered by many to be the top prospect in his draft class. He did not attract the kind of attention once on Stephen Strasburg or Mark Prior, but as a polished starting pitcher who would probably need little time in the minors, he was thought to be a potential ace.

headline: Blackhawks’ Keith Suspended for Game 4
text: LOS ANGELES — The N.H.L. suspended the Chicago Blackhawks’ Duncan Keith for one game for his one-handed high stick on Los Angeles Kings forward Jeff Carter in Game 3 of the Western Conference finals Tuesday.

headline: Bulgaria Pulls Back on Blame for Hezbollah
text: Nearly a year after a bomb in a tour bus at the Burgas airport in Bulgaria killed five Israeli tourists and their Bulgarian driver, the country’s new government is trying to shift blame for the attack from Hezbollah, the militant Lebanese Shiite movement.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 6, 2013
text: "I gave dad about a week to get comfortable and then I went and ran. It turned out to be a great thing. I’ve loved the job.”

headline: Corrections: June 6, 2013

headline: Which Way to the Egress?
text: Administrivial Will Shortz Sighting Alert! Will Shortz will be in Alaska through Wednesday, June 12 and will be posting his table tennis adventures on the travel website Gadling. There are no posts yet at this writing, but click here to watch an introductory video and follow along.

headline: Social Networking Is Easier Than Life
text: How would you feel if you had almost invented Facebook, but didn’t quite get it off the ground? Probably a lot like the three friends and roommates fighting off disappointment and depression in “The Tutors,” a modest but keenly observed and compassionate new comedy-drama by Erica Lipez that opened on Wednesday at the McGinn/Cazale Theater in a spiffy production directed by Thomas Kail (“In the Heights”).

headline: On Newsstands, Allure of the Film Actress Fades
text: Pity the poor Hollywood film stars: they can’t open movies the way they used to and now they can’t sell magazines.

headline: Rent Board Trims Roster of Hearings on Increases
text: Even as many New Yorkers face substantial rent increases, they will have one less chance to complain about it.

headline: Genetically Altered Wheat in Oregon Comes as No Surprise
text: One week after the revelation that an Oregon farmer had found genetically engineered wheat growing in his fields, scientists remain mystified over how the strain — apparently the remains of a test crop shut down a dozen years ago — got there.

headline: The Other Side of the Murphy Bed
text: In 2006, I saw a listing for an apartment in the heart of Park Slope for $169,000.

headline: In Personnel Appointments, Obama Takes Assertive Tack
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s defiant selection of Susan E. Rice as his new national security adviser on Wednesday underscored the newly assertive approach he has taken to appointments ever since he abandoned a potential cabinet nominee named Susan E. Rice.

headline: Into the Woods With a Painter
text: The artist Ellen Altfest sits with her subject, outside, through four seasons.

headline: 2 Hosts of Self-Help Program Kill Themselves in Brooklyn
text: They were hosts of a self-help radio show, motivational speakers on happiness and life coaches from Park Slope, Brooklyn. They called their business Why Not Now, and featured inspirational quotations.

headline: Jury Convicts Harlem Man in Killing of a High School Basketball Star
text: A jury on Wednesday found a Harlem man guilty of murdering a high school basketball star who prosecutors said was the victim of a rivalry between the fighting young men of two neighboring housing projects in Harlem.

headline: Lottery Numbers
