headline: Mets Left-Hander Has Become an (Almost) Everyday Player
text: WASHINGTON — Scott Rice cupped his right hand over his left shoulder while speaking to a reporter inside the Mets’ clubhouse one recent afternoon.

headline: China Seen in Push to Gain Technology Insights
text: SHENZHEN, China — A government-financed research institute in the Pearl River Delta here boasts an impressive range of specialties, from robotics to nanomedicine to magnetic resonance imaging.

headline: Martin Arnold, Former Times Journalist, Dies at 84
text: Martin Arnold, a former reporter, editor and columnist for The New York Times whose assignments took him to the invasion of the Dominican Republic, the mountains of the Yukon, the capital of 1960s hippie culture and the corridors of the publishing world, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Helen Hanft, Master of Camp Way Off Broadway, Dies at 79
text: Helen Hanft, an actress whose mastery of camp humor, surreal scenarios and roles too risqué for mainstream comfort made her the acknowledged queen of the Off Off Broadway stage during a golden age for experimental theater in New York, died on May 30 in Manhattan. She was 79.

headline: Obama’s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama named Susan E. Rice and Samantha Power to major national security posts on Wednesday, promoting two outspoken voices for humanitarian intervention on a foreign policy team known for its deep caution in dealing with conflicts abroad.

headline: 2 Vying to Succeed Kerry in Senate Clash in Debate
text: BOSTON — From the opening bell to a dramatic closing clash, Representative Edward J. Markey and Gabriel Gomez squabbled for an hour Wednesday night in a tense debate that sharply contrasted their differences on issues like banning assault weapons, United States involvement in Syria and abortion rights.

headline: Is Virginia for Haters?
text: This year’s gubernatorial election in Virginia represents politics at its worst. So says Jonathan Chait, New York magazine columnist. He describes the race as the “most depressing election in America,” giving voters a choice between “Republican nutjob Ken Cuccinelli or soulless Democratic hack Terry McAuliffe.”

headline: Iraq: 14 Travelers Are Killed by Gunmen
text: Gunmen killed 14 people in Nukhaib, a police official said. A local government official in Karbala, where several of the dead were from, said that the assailants had stopped the travelers at a fake checkpoint. The City Council of the Shiite holy city of Karbala issued a statement accusing Sunni insurgents and the Baath Party of being behind the killings. Iraq has been shaken by an upswing in sectarian attacks. There were no immediate claims of responsibility for the attack, The Associated Press reported.

headline: U.S. Is Secretly Collecting Records of Verizon Calls
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is secretly carrying out a domestic surveillance program under which it is collecting business communications records involving Americans under a hotly debated section of the Patriot Act, according to a highly classified court order disclosed on Wednesday night.

headline: Nigerians Flee What They Call Indiscriminate Killings
text: Thousands of refugees have crossed into Niger, many saying their government’s fight against Islamists makes no distinction between militants and civilians.

headline: This Is Your Brain on Coffee
text: This column appears in the June 9 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

headline: Multinational Corporations’ Support for Big Banks Is Not Persuasive
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: G.O.P. Bill on Schools Would Set Fewer Rules
text: Signaling a preference for a much smaller role for the federal government in public schooling, Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, is introducing legislation on Thursday to revise No Child Left Behind, the Bush-era education law.

headline: Penguins Extend Game 3, but the End of the Series Appears Imminent
text: BOSTON — On a night when they could not afford to lose, the Pittsburgh Penguins played easily their best game of the Eastern Conference finals against Boston.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (TNT) THE HERO In this new competition series nine people, living together in a penthouse in Panama, try to prove that they have what it takes to be a hero in challenges that test their brains, their brawn and their morality. Dwayne Johnson, a k a the Rock, above, oversees the action, with viewers voting for the winner of $1 million and the title. In “72 Hours,” at 9, three teams of three strangers are dropped into the waters off the Yasawa Islands in Fiji, where they must find a briefcase filled with $100,000 in just 72 hours, supplied with only the clothes on their backs, a GPS device and a bottle of water. Brandon Johnson hosts.

headline: News Quiz | June 6, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Charges Against Chinese Rights Activist Said to Be Reduced
text: BEIJING — We’ve been tracking the situation of Liu Ping, the rights activist from Xinyu in Jiangxi Province, for more than a year – and last month we reported that the authorities had detained her and planned to charge her with subversion, according to her daughter and lawyers hired by her daughter.

headline: Focus in Philadelphia Building Collapse Turns to Demolition Contractor’s Expertise
text: PHILADELPHIA — Rescuers ended their search on Thursday for survivors and victims of a city-center building collapse that left 6 people dead and 13 injured, including a 61-year-old woman who was pulled from the rubble 12 hours after the collapse.

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 6
text: NEWS The Obama administration is secretly carrying out a domestic surveillance program to collect business communications records involving Americans under a hotly debated section of the Patriot Act, according to a highly classified court order disclosed Wednesday night. Charlie Savage and Edward Wyatt report from Washington.

headline: North and South Korea Agree to First Official Dialogue in Years
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North and South Korea agreed Thursday to hold their first government dialogue in years, an abrupt change after tensions over the North’s nuclear program this year escalated into one of the divided peninsula’s worst crises.

headline: Police Arrest 3 in Gang Rape of American
text: NEW DELHI— Three men were arrested Thursday in the gang rape of a 30-year-old American tourist in Manali, the Himachal Pradesh police said.

headline: Test Yourself | English, June 6, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “For Today’s PGA Pros, the 19th Hole Is a Fitness Trailer.”

headline: An Increase in Graffiti in National Parks
text: In the article “As Vandals Deface U.S. Parks, Some Point to Online Show-Offs,” Felicity Barringer writes about the recent spike in graffiti in national parks.

headline: Would You Want a Bike Share Program for Your Community?
text: New York City is in the second week of its bike share program, joining other major cities like Boston, London and Mexico City.

headline: The Woman in a Jim Crow Photo
text: When Joanne Wilson stepped out to enjoy a balmy summer afternoon with her niece in 1956, she stepped into history. The two stood in front of a movie theater in downtown Mobile, Ala., dressed in their Sunday best. But the neon sign that loomed overhead — “Colored Entrance” — cast a despairing shadow.

headline: Tip of the Week: Blog More Efficiently on Tumblr
text: Tumblr, the blogging platform that was recently purchased by Yahoo, has been around since 2007 and hosts more than 111 million blogs. Over the years, the site has made sharing photos and other content from the Web even easier.

headline: The Early Word: Contrast
text: In Today’s Times

headline: As Syrian Fighting Nears Border, Israel Considers Its Options
text: ELYAKIM, Israel — Syrian rebel groups briefly took control Thursday of the only crossing between Israel and Syria, bringing the intense violence of that nation’s civil war closer than ever to the Golan Heights, where farmers were told to stay out of their fields, tourists were turned away from cherry-picking and roads were closed.

headline: In London, Student Designers Take Their Bows
text: LONDON — A purse, a pearl necklace and a surface pattern pressed into silicone made a prizewinning group of molded dresses. They came from Hannah Williams of Epsom, England, during Graduate Fashion Week in London.

headline: Daily Report: Other Nations Offer Visas to Compete With Silicon Valley
text: In a bid to create their own versions of Silicon Valley, countries like Canada, Britain and Australia are dangling start-up visas before foreign entrepreneurs. Chile is even offering seed money to lure foreigners to Santiago and get their start-ups off the ground, Somini Sengupta reports in The New York Times.

headline: Jackie Chan Presses Case for Rhino Conservation
text: Jackie Chan, a global star for his mashups of Charlie Chaplin and Bruce Lee, is working with the conservation group WildAid to raise awareness of the environmental cost of high demand for rhinoceros horn in China and Vietnam (where rhino horn has become something of a club drug).

headline: Why the Tumblr Deal Is a Disaster for Entrepreneurs
text: I have never met a fast-growth entrepreneur that I did not like. Sure, some are weird and scary smart, but what I like about fast-growth entrepreneurs is that most have a riverboat gambling streak that makes them fun, free and a little different from most small-business and corporate types.

headline: Obama Promises to Have High-Speed Internet in Most Schools in 5 Years
text: MOORESVILLE, N.C. — President Obama visited an innovative middle school in central North Carolina on Thursday to demonstrate the Internet-based education programs that he is proposing to make available nationwide.

headline: Bank of England Keeps Interest Rate at Record Low
text: LONDON — The Bank of England decided on Thursday to keep its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low to help strengthen the British economy, which recently showed tentative signs of improvement.

headline: Nazi Islamic Bikes From Hell
text: Well, yesterday I was inconvenienced by the new Citi Bikes: a newly installed line of bike racks blocked the place where I usually cross John Street, forcing me to make a 20-foot detour. Impeach Michael Bloomberg!

headline: Former Cameron Aide Denies Hacking Charges
text: LONDON — Andy Coulson, formerly a close aide to Prime Minister David Cameron and senior editor in Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper outpost, pleaded not guilty on Thursday to charges relating to the phone hacking scandal that spread turmoil among journalists, politicians and police officers.

headline: Bad Faith and Civility, Health Care Edition
text: Austin Frakt and Aaron Carroll, who offer wonderfully helpful health policy analysis on their blog The Incidental Economist, wish that we could just debate the issues, without getting into the people presenting positions. I appreciate their preferences. But it can’t be done.

headline: Activists Hope Law Changes the Way Kashmir Treats Juveniles
text: NEW DELHI – In October 2011, a Kashmiri boy who was throwing stones in a protest against Indian security forces found out very quickly that what it was like to be treated as an adult by the local police.

headline: It’s a Small World of Real Housewives
text: It can be done. It turns out that the word for Botox is the same in just about every language, and there is a near-universal supply of rich, vain, well-groomed and ill-mannered women ready to preen, bicker and malign one another on camera.

headline: Dancing Happily Around All Topics
text: The 56-year-old dancer, choreographer and director Mark Morris is known for his innovative work in modern dance, ballet and opera. This month he becomes the first choreographer to serve as music director of the Ojai Music Festival, which is June 6 to 9 in Ojai, Calif. Mr. Morris called recently from his office at the Mark Morris Dance Center in Brooklyn to talk about weltschermz, mortality and the hokey pokey. A condensed and edited version of our conversation follows:

headline: Think Like a Doctor: A Cough That Won’t Quit
text: The Challenge: Can you figure out what is wrong with a previously healthy 75-year-old woman with a cough that just won’t quit?

headline: Protests in Turkey
text: Turkish protesters challenge the Erdogan vision.

headline: A Hushed Crowd After a Triple Crown Quest Is Denied by a Nostril
text: Some 80,162 roaring partisans, then the second-largest crowd to ever attend a Belmont Stakes, were there to witness that frenzied finish. It was not … real quiet.

headline: SAC Says It Will Survive
text: SAC Capital Advisors has told its employees that it will survive a wave of investor withdrawals amid the government’s insider trading investigation, DealBook’s Peter Lattman reports. Investors in the hedge fund, which is owned by Steven A. Cohen, have asked to withdraw a significant amount of money by a quarterly deadline on Monday, according to an internal e-mail sent by SAC’s president, Thomas J. Conheeney. The amount, though not disclosed, was said to be more than the $1.7 billion taken out earlier this year, meaning SAC would be left with a fraction of the $6 billion in outside capital with which it began the year, Mr. Lattman reports.

headline: Many Children Left Behind
text: KARACHI — Anum Fatima won’t be the first student from Pakistan to participate in an exchange program at Harvard Business School this summer, but she certainly will be the first from one of the country’s slums. The daughter of a maid and a chauffeur, Fatima grew up in the Ismail Goth settlement near Karachi’s steel mills. After going to a school run by The Citizens Foundation, a nonprofit charity, she is now attending one of the city’s prestigious business schools.

headline: Thursday Reading: Airport Help for Traveling Pets
text: Airport help for traveling pets, Dashlane helps you manage all those passwords, building your own Web site at no cost, and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Obama Circles the Wagons
text: Regarding “Obama’s covert trade deal” (Views, June 4): The administration is casting a shadow over democracy and transparency with its assaults on journalists and whistle-blowers as it circles the wagons against the public interest.

headline: European Central Bank Leaves Rate Unchanged
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank on Thursday debated ways to funnel more credit to suffering euro zone businesses, but decided not to act because it was not sure which way the economy was heading.

headline: The Sound and the Fury: Azarenka and Sharapova Meet Again
text: Women’s tennis is in need of rivalries, and Victoria Azarenka and Maria Sharapova have quite a competitive one. They have played 12 times, with Azarenka winning 7 of those matches. On Thursday in the semifinals of the French Open, they will meet for the third time in a Grand Slam tournament, following the final of the 2012 Australian Open and the semifinals of the United States Open, matches won by Azarenka. It figures to be a compelling match.

text: Dear Diary:

headline: Alcohol, Islam and Turkey’s Founding Fathers
text: LONDON — Abdullah Gul, the president of Turkey, was reported to be wavering over implementation of a controversial law restricting alcohol use, a measure seen by some as the kind of assault on personal freedom that has spurred a week of anti-government protests.

headline: Britain to Compensate Kenyan Victims of Colonial-Era Torture
text: LONDON — In a remarkable admission that imperial forces tortured Kenyans fighting against British rule in the 1950s, Foreign Secretary William Hague announced Thursday that the government would pay about $30 million in compensation to more than 5,000 victims of abuse in its former East African colony.

headline: I.R.S. Targeting of Conservatives Wrong, Most Say in Poll
text: Regardless of their party affiliation, Americans think the Internal Revenue Service was wrong to target conservative groups applying for tax-exempt status, and that it was done for political reasons and not because officials felt it was the right policy to pursue, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Showing It All, Revealing Nothing
text: Now that the awards-giving season in theater is nearly over, and we’ve exhausted such ponderous topics as the relative worth of various actors and dramas, can we get superficial for a moment? O.K., even more superficial. You see, I’ve been thinking about what the well-dressed stage has been wearing recently, which seems to be undressed men.

headline: Court Permits Hailing of Taxis Across the City
text: The state’s highest court on Thursday unanimously upheld the Bloomberg administration’s plan to radically expand street-hail taxi service beyond Manhattan, signaling a fundamental shift in New York City’s entrenched taxi culture.

headline: Who Does the Ethicist Think He Is?
text: Is it ethical for a student to submit the same paper in two college classes? That was the question posed to the Ethicist in last Sunday’s Times Magazine. His answer, in brief, was yes. It may be lazy, he concluded, but it’s not unethical.

headline: Jozy Altidore: ‘A Nice Step Forward’
text: KINGSTON, Jamaica — When it comes to wild weeks, the last seven days take the cake.

headline: Want Investors? Skip the Glossy Sales Pitches
text: This interview with Adi Tatarko, chief executive of Houzz, an architecture and interior design Web site, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: U.S. Confirms That It Gathers Online Data Overseas
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government has been secretly collecting information on foreigners overseas for nearly six years from the nation’s largest Internet companies like Google, Facebook and, most recently, Apple, in search of national security threats, the director of national intelligence confirmed Thursday night.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Eatocracy: How much do you tip your food delivery people? Do you kick in an extra couple of bucks when the weather is bad? James Oliver Cury does, and he’s right. — Melissa Clark

headline: Turks Angry Over Dearth of Protest Coverage by Established Media
text: The Turkish government blames Twitter. Many Turks point their fingers at a cowed news media.

headline: Is it ‘On Line’ or ‘In Line’?
text: Matthew J.X. Malady’s Riff in the magazine this past weekend about lines (a k a “queues,” or those things you stand in while you wait to get on Mr. Toad’s Wild Ride at Disneyland, say) inspired a lively discussion in the comments section. Lines are, Malady argues, “society’s great equalizer”; paying to skip to the front of them is a “horrendous” unfairness. (Though not all Times readers agree that line cutting is always wrong.)

headline: Khaled Hosseini: By the Book
text: The author of “And the Mountains Echoed” keeps a handy copy of “I’m a Lebowski, You’re a Lebowski: Life, ‘The Big Lebowski,’ and What Have You” on his bookshelf.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Architects’
text: This poem, one of 12 winners of our fourth annual Found Poem Student Contest, was written by Alison, 23, from Boston. The poem comes from the article “12-Year-Old Building at MoMA Is Doomed”.

headline: Down So Long, It Looks Like Up to the Euro Zone
text: FRANKFURT — This is what passes for good economic news in Europe: Spain just added 265 jobs.

headline: Fossil Fuel
text: With the N.B.A. finals set to start Thursday night, pitting a set of grizzled veterans against the best player in the world, those hoping the relics of a bygone era would finally be bygone have to hope they were not seeing an omen in the N.H.L. playoffs Wednesday night. Because deep in double overtime of the Bruins-Penguins series, the bygonest player of all struck one for the old school.

headline: Joss Whedon on ‘Much Ado About Nothing’
text: In this Anatomy of a Scene, the director Joss Whedon narrates a scene from his film version of Shakespeare’s “Much Ado About Nothing.”

headline: Life Across Borders: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie Talks About ‘Americanah’
text: “Americanah,” the third novel by the Nigerian writer Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, follows Ifemelu, a young Nigerian woman who moves to the United States and finds a certain amount of fame as a blogger writing candidly about issues of race and nationality. In her review in The Times, Janet Maslin called the book’s first half “tough-minded and clear,” but expressed disappointment in the “simple romance” of what followed. In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Adichie discussed the state of American fiction, the tropes she wanted to avoid in writing about race and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Former Senator Lieberman Joins Kasowitz Benson
text: Joseph I. Lieberman, a former senator from Connecticut and onetime vice presidential candidate, has joined the law firm Kasowitz Benson Torres & Friedman.

headline: Arguing Their Way Into Love
text: Joss Whedon’s adaptation of “Much Ado About Nothing” — perhaps the liveliest and most purely delightful movie I have seen so far this year — draws out the essential screwball nature of Shakespeare’s comedy. It may be the martini-toned black-and-white cinematography, the soigné Southern California setting, or the combative courtship of Amy Acker’s angular, sharp-tongued Beatrice and Alexis Denisof’s grouchy, hangdog Benedick, but from its very first scenes, Mr. Whedon’s film crackles with a busy, slightly wayward energy that recalls the classic romantic sparring of the studio era.

headline: Lunch With the Simpsons
text: Though “The Simpsons” has never revealed the exact location of Springfield, the family’s hometown, a replica of it can now be found in Florida. Universal Orlando Resort has added a street scene and an attraction to the area surrounding its Simpsons Ride, which opened in 2008. Visitors can stroll along Fast Food Boulevard and grab a sandwich at Krusty Burger, a slice at Luigi’s Pizza and, of course, a Duff Beer at Moe’s Tavern. Past the statue of Jebediah Springfield, the fictional town’s founder, visitors will find the new “intergalactic” spinning ride called Kang & Kodos’ Twirl ’n’ Hurl.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘The Gulf, 1987’
text: We mark the last Poetry Pairing of the school year with “The Gulf, 1987″ by Deborah Paredez and the article “New Summer for Shore Residents, but Not as Before” by Peter Applebome.

headline: Americans on I.R.S. Scrutiny of Conservative Groups
text: Americans think the Internal Revenue Service was wrong to target conservative groups applying for tax-exempt status, and that it was done for political reasons and not because officials felt it was the right policy to pursue

headline: A One-of-a-Kind Design Auction at Christie’s
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Musician Getting His Game Back Together
text: PARIS — The sun is beginning to set on another lazy day at Roland Garros, and a large crowd is gathering between Suzanne Lenglen and the media zone. But the autograph hunters are not clamoring for Novak Djokovic or Tommy Haas. Instead, the slightly clownish figure of Redfoo has caught their attention.

headline: A Globe-Trotting Barista Lands in New York
text: Stefanos Domatiotis is one of high-end coffee’s most recognizable figures, at least within the industry. The six-time winner of the Greek Barista Championship and three-time finalist of the World Barista Championship, he is on the cover of this month’s Barista Magazine. And until recently, he was the marquee draw at Taf Coffee in Athens.

headline: Finding Solitude at Monet’s Gardens
text: Early in the day, a breeze made the purple blossoms of wisteria, dangling from a steel gray vine draped over a stone wall, dance. The busy aural embroidery of bird song that had awakened us an hour earlier had yet to fade. As we approached a man with a pungent pipe walking his dog on the main street in Giverny, an hour west of Paris by car, he nodded at us knowingly. “Vous serez les premiers,” he said with a chuckle. “Bonne visite!”

headline: Dropping In on Monet
text: A visit to Giverny, where the artist spent decades.

headline: A Mid-Michigan Museum Draws a Crowd
text: Along the main drag north of the Michigan State University campus in East Lansing lies the usual dowdy mix of Gothic-inspired classroom buildings and rundown frat houses. Then, a canted, glass-and-stainless-steel building, in the shape of a parallelogram, radicalizes the streetscape.

headline: In Performance: Shalita Grant
text: The New York Times invited Tony nominees to perform on location. In a cinematic adaptation of a scene from “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” Shalita Grant plays a doom-predicting waitress.

headline: Ask Your Questions About Debt Collection
text: Do you have a question about debt collection? You’re invited to submit it to participants in a daylong discussion being held Thursday by the Federal Trade Commission and Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

headline: Warming to Painting in the Cold
text: Painters often work in self-imposed solitude, some versions more extreme than others. The minimalist Agnes Martin spent long stretches of winter in her rural New Mexico studio completely snowed in, seeing no one, living on jarred preserves. “The best things in life,” Martin once said, “happen to you when you’re alone.”

headline: Well-Chilled Drinks, Well-Read Bartender
text: Donatella Arpaia said that she had a simple set of requirements for DBar, the small, appealingly unassuming lounge that adjoins her Donatella restaurant in Chelsea.

headline: Chrysler to Recall 434,000 Jeeps Over Air Bag and Transmission Problems
text: In two actions, Chrysler will recall about 434,000 Jeeps in the United States to correct problems with the air bags or loss of transmission fluid, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: From Blankfein, a Horatio Alger Story for New Graduates
text: Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive and chairman of Goldman Sachs, tried out a new role on Thursday: inspirational speaker.

headline: Bruins Lose Campbell for Remainder of Playoffs
text: 1:42 p.m. | Updated

headline: Tony Awards: In Performance With Shalita Grant
text: For the fourth video in our special Tony Awards in Performance series, Shalita Grant plays a frazzled waitress who has visions that predict doom in a scene adapted from the Christopher Durang comedy “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike.” (In the play Ms. Grant plays a voodoo-enthusiast housekeeper who knows her away around classical Greek drama.) This cinematic interpretation was filmed at the theater district restaurant Bond 45.

headline: Bob Fletcher Dies at 101; Helped Japanese-Americans
text: Bob Fletcher, a former California agriculture inspector who, ignoring the resentment of neighbors, quit his job in the middle of World War II to manage the fruit farms of Japanese families forced to live in internment camps, died on May 23 in Sacramento. He was 101.

headline: Living With Cancer: Look Good, Feel Better
text: A friend in my cancer support group suggested a call to Look Good Feel Better when I arrived at lunch looking bad and feeling worse. The program had given her eyebrows. Eyebrows, I thought, would be good. Eyebrows seem like something it might be reasonable to want.

headline: The Sex Life of Birds, and Why It’s Important
text: For a strange sexual history, it’s hard to beat birds. In some lineages, bird penises have evolved to spectacular lengths. Ducks, for example, have corkscrew-shaped penises that can grow as long as their entire body. They use their baroque genitalia to deliver sperm to female reproductive tracts that are also corkscrew-shaped — but twisted in the opposite direction.

headline: Attorney General of New Jersey Named as Interim Senator
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Thursday appointed Jeffrey S. Chiesa, the state’s attorney general, to temporarily fill the Senate seat left vacant by the death of Frank R. Lautenberg.

headline: Sharapova and Williams Advance to Final
text: PARIS — It was only a coincidence that both French Open women’s semifinal matches ended with aces, because there was almost nothing else similar about the performances that got Maria Sharapova and Serena Williams to their moments of triumph and into Saturday’s final.

headline: Tip Sheet | A Family’s Lessons From the College Tour
text: I never went on a college tour when I was a teenager. My parents wanted me to attend the college where my father was employed; it would have been tuition-free for me, and so they weren’t eager to encourage other explorations.

headline: Making Windows 8 Better
text: Windows 8 has been something of a flop. It’s selling even worse than the much-loathed Windows Vista did, and the entire PC industry is feeling the pain.

text: RULES 1. Player has not seen the photo beforehand.

headline: Curtain’s Up on a Real Race
text: Will the crowd-pleasing American musicals “Kinky Boots” and “Pippin” deliver a one-two punch at Sunday’s Tony Awards to the British-made musical “Matilda,” the early front-runner in major categories? It’s starting to look that way, though “Matilda” partisans are hoping that its unsurpassable reviews from theater critics will trump the feel-good momentum of its two competitors.

headline: Q. and A. on the Domestic Surveillance Program
text: The Guardian disclosed Wednesday night that the Obama administration is secretly carrying out a domestic surveillance program, in which the National Security Agency is collecting communications records from a subsidiary of Verizon Communications. Some basic questions and answers about the issue follow:

headline: Report Criticizes U.S. Stewardship of Wild Horses
text: DENVER — A new report catalogs a range of problems with the way the federal government is managing thousands of wild horses and burros that roam the American West, supporting the position of animal rights advocates who have long argued that the program is ineffective and needlessly cruel.

headline: The Gun Report: June 6, 2013
text: As our colleague Charles Blow pointed out in his column yesterday, George Zimmerman is going on trial for the killing of Trayvon Martin—a killing, of course, that Zimmerman first got a pass on by invoking Florida’s Stand Your Ground law. What we’ve come to realize in compiling the Gun Report each day is that more and more people feel completely justified to use a gun to settle an argument, to shoot first and ask questions later—even when the person who is killed is a drunk 16-year-old who accidentally climbs through a neighbor’s window instead of his own—and to “defend” themselves even when no defense is required. Stand Your Gun laws—as well as concealed carry laws, and laws that allow people to brandish weapons in public—are laws that provoke gun violence rather than prevent it, and help return us to the ethos of the wild west, where guns were the court of first resort. I would be nice to think that Zimmerman’s trial might change that, just a little, but we’re not holding our breath.

headline: Protecting Yourself After a Data Breach
text: Half of identity fraud victims in 2012 had also received a data breach notification in the same year, a new report from Javelin Strategy & Research finds.

headline: Ghana Arrests Chinese in Gold Mines
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The authorities in Ghana have conducted sweeping arrests of Chinese citizens in the nation’s gold-mining regions, officials said Thursday, the latest sign of tensions between a sub-Saharan African nation and the global power that has become the continent’s largest trading partner.

headline: Mark Rylance to Lead Two Shakespeare Plays on Broadway This Fall
text: The two-time Tony Award winner Mark Rylance will return to Broadway this fall to lead all-male ensembles in a double bill of Shakespeare, playing the besotted noblewoman Olivia in “Twelfth Night” and the titular monstrous monarch in “Richard III,” the producers Sonia Friedman and Scott Landis said on Thursday. Mr. Rylance’s fellow British actor Stephen Fry (“Wilde,” “Blackadder”) will make his Broadway debut in the “Twelfth Night” production, playing the priggish manservant Malvolio.

headline: Goop on the Road
text: Ever since the actress Gwyneth Paltrow started her weekly lifestyle newsletter and Web site, Goop, in 2008, readers have been clicking on the “Go” tab for guides to cities like Paris, Hong Kong and New Orleans. Now they can take her advice on the road with them. Released in April, the Goop iPhone and iPad apps compile her recommendations for restaurants, shops and family-friendly sights in New York, London and Los Angeles. Ms. Paltrow narrates and appears in videos about how she likes to spend her day in each city.

headline: S.E.C. Freezes Assets of Thai Trader in Smithfield Inquiry
text: Another international deal appears to have an insider trading problem.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Obama on Surveillance in 2007
text: Via Andrew Kaczynski

headline: Uncertainty Is Hard for Doctors
text: My patient came to me for advice. His cardiologist was recommending that he get an I.C.D., a type of defibrillator, implanted in his heart. My patient hadn’t suffered any abnormal heart rhythms, but his heart was enlarged and he was at risk.

headline: Market Report | Freshening Up the New Bohemian Look With Florals and Fringe
text: The boho style that Kate Moss and Sienna Miller made famous on their annual excursions to the Glastonbury Music Festival has grown up. The floral headpieces and neon crop tops are gone, in favor of fluid, embroidered dresses that blossom beneath sand-colored fringe jackets. Accessories add a golden shine for extra polish.

headline: Concerns About Dashlane, and Answers
text: In my column in Thursday’s paper, I reviewed Dashlane, a very cool, free program that automatically enters your names, passwords, credit card information and other details on Web sites.

text: David Milarch wants to stop global warming by climbing and cloning the world’s largest trees.

headline: Esther Williams, Swimming Champion Who Became a Movie Star, Dies at 91
text: Esther Williams, a teenage swimming champion who became an enormous Hollywood star in a decade of watery MGM extravaganzas, died on Thursday in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 91.

headline: The Bob Benson of His Office: James Wolk on His ‘Mad Men’ Role
text: Every office has its Bob Benson, that one person whose hard work and good intentions are unfortunately canceled out by their overeagerness and  ingratiating ways. (Don’t worry, it’s not you.)

headline: Canadian Utility Finds a Use for Detroit’s Pile of Oil Sands Byproduct
text: OTTAWA — In something resembling a bottle return program, Detroit’s enormous petroleum coke pile, a byproduct of Canadian oil sands, is making its way back to Canada.

headline: What I Learned (Too Late) About Keeping Kids Safe Around Dogs
text: When my son Otto was 2 years old, he was bitten in the face by a dog. It was my fault; I knew the dog didn’t like children. A mutt I’d adopted in the Caribbean, Zeke was the friendliest dog you could hope to meet (that’s why I dragged such a scraggly creature home with me), until my first son, Zane, was born. After a few angry growls, Zeke went to live with my father.

headline: Another Summer Nears Without Chase Manhattan Plaza
text: It took “both imagination and a sense of citizenship to clear an open plaza on some of the city’s most valuable land and to throw it open to the light of the sun — and to the public.”

headline: Q. and A.: Geoffrey Fletcher on ‘Violet & Daisy’
text: In 2010, Geoffrey Fletcher made history as the first (and currently only) African American to win a screenwriting Oscar, taking home the adapted screenplay award for “Precious.”

headline: Former Interior Secretary Salazar Joins WilmerHale
text: Ken Salazar, who recently stepped down as interior secretary, is joining WilmerHale as a partner, the law firm announced on Thursday.

headline: Los Perros Locos
text: Inside this spot on the Lower East Side where the specialty is hot dogs in the ornate Colombian style.

headline: Handzus Helped Shape Blackhawks and the Kings
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Michal Handzus’s nickname, Zus, does not refer to the Greek god, but he has seemingly been omnipresent for both teams in the Western Conference finals.

headline: Turkish Leader Says Razing of Istanbul Park Will Proceed
text: ISTANBUL — Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan returned to his country early Friday morning and was met at the airport by tens of thousands of supporters who offered a boisterous counterpoint to the demonstrations that for nearly a week have occupied Taksim Square in central Istanbul and presented Mr. Erdogan with the gravest political crisis of his decade in power.

headline: A Classic Story of Man Bites Perro
text: Los Perros Locos can be an unsettling place to eat if you’re sober. The interior of this Lower East Side spot is half acid-washed concrete and corrugated metal, half spatter pattern in hot pink, mustard yellow and chlorine blue. On silk-screened wall panels, spindly palm trees stretch as high as the Empire State Building while the Fontainebleau hotel in Miami Beach hovers on the fringe of Bogotá’s Plaza de Bolívar.

headline: Mapping Appalachia
text: Long after the start of the Civil War, President Lincoln continued to believe that the Confederacy was home to a large population of Unionists, particularly in East Tennessee and western North Carolina. In the fall of 1861 he privately outlined a campaign to liberate these loyalists by seizing the Cumberland Gap, a passage through the Appalachian Mountains on the Tennessee-Kentucky border, and then moving south.

headline: Marianne Vitale: ‘Diamond Crossing’
text: Zach Feuer

headline: ‘Xstraction’
text: The Hole

headline: In Smaller Numbers, Britain’s Modified Enthusiasts Cruise On
text: PETERBOROUGH, England — When Sam McKee bought his used silver 2001 Vauxhaull Astra Coupe for £750 (about $1,140), it was “a bit battered from making school runs,” he said. He promptly “stripped it down, sorted all the dents out and painted it.” Since then, he’s added a body kit, 18-inch Cruize Alloy wheels and low-profile tires, spending around £3,000 (about $4,550), the majority of which, he said, went toward amps and speakers.

headline: ‘The Thrill of the Ideal: Richard Tuttle: The Reinhart Project’
text: Pocket Utopia

headline: Teachers, What Are Your Thoughts on the Common Core Standards?
text: The work of this blog is to suggest ideas for teaching and learning with The New York Times. We don’t do original reporting, and we don’t offer opinions on education issues. Instead, like teachers everywhere, we strive to facilitate discussion on issues of the day rather than imparting our own points of view.

headline: Paul Klee:  ‘Early and Late Years, 1894-1940’ and ‘The Bauhaus Years’
text: Moeller Fine Art

headline: Street Style Outside Delano Brown’s Gallery Show
text: The crowd at Delano Brown’s first New York gallery show at Smart Clothes Gallery on the Lower East Side was too big for the space and unrelentingly beautiful. That meant that for every guest watching Mr. Brown hand-paint flowers onto his model’s dress, there were plenty of others preening, hoping to be seen, in outfits drawing from a range of influences — hip-hop, K-pop, goth, prep and more.

headline: Stephanie J. Block and Will Chase to Star in ‘Little Miss Sunshine’ Musical
text: Stephanie J. Block and Will Chase, who will be up for Tony Awards pn Sunday for their performances in “The Mystery of Edwin Drood,” will star in Second Stage Theater’s production of the new musical “Little Miss Sunshine,” the Off Broadway theater said on Thursday.

headline: Mystery Mountains in the Illinois Governor’s Race
text: Illinois is a wonderful state, with many things to see, very few of them involving altitude. There is, of course, the Willis Tower (that’s the Sears Tower, for those of you who haven’t been to Chicago in a while), and the John Hancock Center. But once you leave the Windy City and head south, except for the grain silos and water towers, a general prairie flatness reigns.

headline: CW Network Completes Upfront Sales
text: CW has become the first of the large English-language broadcast networks to complete the bulk of its sales of commercial time ahead of the 2013-14 season in the so-called upfront market.

headline: Splish, Splash and Pedal Harder
text: I LOVE the cardio rush I get from spinning, but I find the workout rather torturous: the music blaring as a shrill instructor screams on a headset to “climb up a mountain” that doesn’t exist, as I frantically adjust the knob so the bike speed is “seven-tenths” of my total strength.

headline: She Does My ’Do
text: The Look pages this past weekend featured 28 portraits of hair stylists around New York City. You see this collection of interesting people and think, How might my life change if I had this person, or that person, cut my hair? Well, I know how one of them changed my life: Madoka Wakatsuki, who works out of Tim Dark Hair in the East Village.

headline: Figment NYC at Governors Island; ‘Native Games’
text: This weekend Governors Island presents its sprawling Figment NYC art project, now in its seventh iteration. Choosing among its many events and exhibitions, the Miser might recommend becoming a human letter on a “living letterpress” as part of “Smash Type”; or zipping yourself and a few friends into “Cocoon Playground,” a life-size swath of perspective-warping, stretchy fabric; or tracking down the “Jester of the Peace,” whose jurisdiction extends as far as your imagination and who will happily “marry” you to the person, place, object or idea of your choice.

headline: Cooper-Hewitt Museum Names New Director
text: Caroline Baumann, the acting director of Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in New York, has been officially given the chief job, the museum announced on Thursday.

headline: Tsonga Isn’t Noah, Despite French Hopes
text: PARIS — The French desire to compare Jo-Wilfried Tsonga and Yannick Noah is hardly new.

headline: Despite Tax Rules, Companies Stick With U.S.
text: The tactics that multinational companies like Apple, Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard use to avoid paying corporate income taxes might make one wonder why they incorporate in the United States in the first place. Why not Ireland?

text: By day, the jokes revered at Punderdome 3000 are more likely to earn a groan from the next cubicle than a standing ovation.

text: PITTSFORD, N.Y — The first round of the L.P.G.A. Championship never started Thursday after heavy rains pounded the Rochester area and saturated Locust Hill Country Club.

headline: Rarely Together, Putins Meet Up Only to Split Up
text: MOSCOW — For years Moscow has been captivated by speculation about the apparently moribund marriage of President Vladimir V. Putin. He was in love with an Olympic gymnast half his age, some said. His wife, Lyudmila, was not seen in public for months at a time, and when she did appear with the president they behaved like strangers.

headline: Fed Reports American Households Have Regained Ground Lost in the Recession
text: Buoyed by a healthier housing sector and a soaring stock market, American households continue to regain ground lost during the financial crisis and the severe recession that followed.

headline: Empathy Without Boundaries
text: Jean McFee Raichle, 94, is a remarkably cheerful woman. She lives in an assisted living center in Seattle staffed by aides who are warm and nurturing. She exists in the moment, mostly untroubled by her Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: Robbing a Gas Station: The Hacker Way
text: Thieves of the future will look back on today’s stick-up artists and have a good old belly laugh. Why would anyone ever rob a cashier with a gun, when all that is needed is a smartphone?

headline: A Look Back at the Films of Esther Williams
text: The swimmer-turned-movie-star Esther Williams, who died today at the age of 91, became famous for taking her swimming skills to the big screen in Technicolor spectacles from the 1940s and ’50s. Below are clips and trailers from some of her memorable films.

headline: President Obama’s Dragnet
text: Within hours of the disclosure that federal authorities routinely collect data on phone calls Americans make, regardless of whether they have any bearing on a counterterrorism investigation, the Obama administration issued the same platitude it has offered every time President Obama has been caught overreaching in the use of his powers: Terrorists are a real menace and you should just trust us to deal with them because we have internal mechanisms (that we are not going to tell you about) to make sure we do not violate your rights.

headline: A Fallen New Yorker Writer Signs With Simon & Schuster
text: Jonah Lehrer, the disgraced writer who resigned from The New Yorker after he was discovered plagiarizing and fabricating material, has sold a book to Simon & Schuster that uses his journalistic misconduct as a case study of the mysterious and redeeming power of love.

headline: Portent of Peril for Muni Bondholders
text: The bankruptcy of the most populous county in Alabama moved closer to resolution this week with an agreement providing that investors will lose 20 percent of the money they invested in bonds that were rated AAA. The big loser financially is JPMorgan Chase, which underwrote many of the securities — and paid bribes to get the business.

headline: Bryan Brothers Excited to Be in Another French Final
text: Fatherhood is going well for Bob Bryan: many new fathers would envy his claim that his 16-month-old daughter sleeps through the night. Things are going well on the tennis court, too.

headline: Former Bush Adviser Will Head His Foundation
text: With his presidential library now open, former President George W. Bush brought in new leadership for his foundation and public policy institute on Thursday, turning to one of his longest serving and most trusted advisers.

headline: Karl Is Out of a Job in Denver and Drawing Interest Elsewhere
text: MIAMI — The Denver Nuggets parted ways with George Karl on Thursday, adding an unexpected jolt to an unusually hyperactive N.B.A. coaching carousel.

headline: More Resort: Ralph Lauren, Nina Ricci
text: With more designers presenting their resort collections to the media than ever before, it was inevitable that the once-informal presentations would eventually begin to look like yet another full-on Fashion Week. But no one expected it to happen so quickly.

headline: A New Senator for New Jersey
text: Gov. Chris Christie announced the appointment of Jeffrey S. Chiesa, the state's attorney general, to the vacant Senate seat.

headline: Why Rate Shock Might Matter
text: There has been a lengthy, multi-sided debate in the last week or so, with much ad hominem and gnashing of teeth, over whether California’s insurance premiums are going up because of Obamacare, and if so what that might mean for the law’s success or failure. Avik Roy of Forbes is responsible for starting it, but at this point just about everyone who writes on health policy has weighed in, and if you read the most recent round of posts — see Jonathan Cohn, Tyler Cowen, Matt Yglesias, Megan McArdle and Peter Suderman, for a representative sample — you’ll find that liberals are mostly acknowledging that premiums are going up for the young and healthy (and especially the crucial “bro” demographic) but arguing that this was always part of the health care reform plan, while their critics are mostly countering that 1) Obamacare supporters were not always so forthright about this cost-shifting and 2) that if “rate shock” is severe enough, the whole mandate-regulate-subsidize framework could quickly fall apart.

headline: Eating a Little Crow Over Chips
text: I have a 14-year-old daughter. She is a little plump. I have been so careful not to say anything derogatory about her appearance or diet, which is usually quite healthy. But last week, I blew it. During a hot car ride, I told her she should lay off the potato chips that I saw her eating in the back seat. She asked me why, and I told her to take a look in the mirror. Now I feel awful and don’t know what to do about it. Please help.

headline: SAP Paying Top Dollar in a Buying Spree
text: If you can’t make it, buy it.

headline: Stravinsky Returns, and Prominently
text: New York City Ballet’s spring season ends on Sunday. Important ballets have continued to re-enter the crowded repertory. Over the weekend, George Balanchine’s “Stravinsky Violin Concerto” (1972) had its first performances of the year. Thanks to a guest conductor, David Levi, and the solo violinist, Arturo Delmoni, the score sounded marvelously bracing; and Sunday afternoon’s performance onstage was among the ballet’s finest in years.

headline: ‘Bridges of Madison County’ Musical Will Open on Broadway
text: “The Bridges of Madison County” is going to Broadway. Bartlett Sher (“South Pacific,” “The Light in the Piazza”) will direct a new musical based on the hit film and best-selling novel by Robert James Waller, the producers said on Thursday.

text: Images from the career of the actress, who died on Thursday in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 91.

headline: Why Does the F.D.R. Drive Look Like an Unmade Bed?
text: As you wake up tomorrow morning, take a look at your bed just after you’ve climbed out of it. Unless you’re some kind of zen monk who doesn’t move a muscle, your bed probably looks pretty roughed up at the tail end of a good night’s sleep. Most likely, it’ll be rumpled, the sheets will be twisted around and perhaps there will be a big pit in the pillow where your head was.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Germany and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Germany, Israel, New Jersey and France.

headline: Piano City
text: The Sing for Hope Pianos project has placed 88 keyboards in outdoor locations in all five boroughs. The project runs through June 16.

headline: Advocate in Myanmar Hopes to Seek Presidency
text: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — Yes, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi would like to be president of Myanmar.

headline: What’s Alikeness Got to Do With It?
text: I always thought love was love, no matter where you were in the world. I learned differently when I was based in New Delhi for two months in 2006.

headline: Excerpt: 'Dirty Wars'
text: The documentary by Jeremy Scahill and Richard Rowley investigates covert American military operations.

headline: His Target Is Assassinations
text: Jeremy Scahill, an investigative foreign correspondent whose first documentary, “Dirty Wars,” opens Friday, writes for The Nation and achieved his biggest success with “Blackwater,” a best-selling book critiquing security contractors hired by the George W. Bush administration. Neither of which keeps him from being labeled a right-wing stooge by detractors.

headline: Feverish Spin of the Globe
text: Jules Verne’s “Around the World in 80 Days” is a story about the kind of trip any frequent traveler has experienced: a mishmash of highs and lows, of peak experiences, vexing missed connections and other catastrophes. The stage version of the tale now at the New Theater at 45th Street brings its own layer of mishmashing to the telling. It’s an odd combination of slick steampunk and cheesy vaudeville, high-tech razzle and low-budget dazzle.

headline: Opening Credits: ‘20 Feet From Stardom’
text: A look at the credit sequence of the documentary.

headline: Who Made That?
text: An archive of the weekly Innovation column from The New York Times Magazine.

headline: When George and Martha Met Tony
text: When it comes to the Tonys, nothing succeeds like a spectacularly failed marriage.

headline: 88 Spots to Tickle Keys and Your Fancy
text: Henry Andrews, a little boy going about town with his mother, dismounted his miniscooter one day this week and, still wearing a helmet, began dancing to a jaunty Bach bourrée. He was in a small square on the edge of Lincoln Center, and the music came from a beat-up but attractively decorated silver piano played by a stranger: me.

headline: Noises Off: Surviving the Sounds of an Azarenka-Sharapova Match
text: As the French Open semifinal between Maria Sharapova and Victoria Azarenka thundered into a third set, an already ear-splitting chorus of shrieks grew even louder. Eurosport commentators labeled it the loudest match they had ever heard. Brad Gilbert of ESPN wondered how Sharapova was not losing her voice. Fans continents away pleaded for mercy.

headline: ‘Tummy Time’ May Not Be Needed
text: Putting infants to sleep on their backs, recommended since the early 1990s, has helped reduce the prevalence of sudden infant death syndrome. But because of concerns that the practice might cause delays in motor development — as measured by the age at which babies roll over — parents were encouraged to give their infants “tummy time” when awake to help build upper-body strength.

headline: Riding Waves of Thrills, Chills and Carats
text: “Welcome to Joyland,” says the archway leading into a vintage amusement park in Stephen King’s latest work of ultra-pulp fiction. This Joyland is not innocent, of course. Its retro thrills include an enticingly steamy cover, Hard Case Crime’s sensually tactile paperback format, and a cover line that asks, “Who Dares Enter the Funhouse of Fear?”

headline: Painting the Casbah: Orientalist Artworks
text: When 19th-century European and American painters traveled to Arab lands, many canceled their return trips. They settled into studios on medieval streets overlooking tiled fountains and palm trees and within earshot of mosques’ call to prayer.

headline: As Arms Sales Fade, Aerospace Contractors Chase Commercial Customers
text: The aerospace and military industries, faced with lackluster sales of military equipment as the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan wind down, are turning their attention to the soaring market for commercial jets.

headline: With Cameras Rolling, Egyptian Politicians Threaten Ethiopia Over Dam
text: Egypt’s president, Mohamed Morsi, had some important information to share with a room full of politicians who, believing they were in a secret meeting, had just laid out all the covert ways that their country could stop a Nile River dam project in nearby Ethiopia: they were on live television.

headline: One New York Poet Honors the New York Poems of Another
text: “You’re being very good,” Patti Smith told a sold-out audience at the Bowery Ballroom on Wednesday night. “I’m very proud of you.”

headline: Ami’s Alexandre Mattiussi Goes to Marrakesh
text: It’s only been two years since the French designer Alexandre Mattiussi started his men’s-wear label Ami, following successful stints working for Dior, Givenchy and Marc Jacobs. But he is fast becoming a household name for his playful, elegant, well-tailored sportswear. What does a rising star do to relax? In Matiussi’s case, the answer is to fly solo: “I like to travel by myself,” he said. “I always take few days off before the presentation of a new collection.” Last season, he headed to Marrakesh for a quick weekend jaunt — his second trip to Morocco — snapping lots of pictures as he went. Here, Mattiussi recounts his adventures.

headline: New York Post Faces Suit Over Boston Bomb Article
text: Two men have filed suit against The New York Post, accusing the paper of invading their privacy and inflicting emotional distress by publishing an article that made them look as if they were suspected in the Boston Marathon bombings case.

headline: Pork Chops With a Lusty Neapolitan Topping
text: The muscular sear and smoky, crisp burnish of grilled food has immense appeal. But achieving it requires time and attention to hot coals. The grill master might scoff, but I have increasingly come to rely on my oven, sealing the deal with a slow bake after a quick sizzle atop the stove. That’s how I made these pork chops, with their lusty Neapolitan topping to accompany a sturdy aglianico. The slow cooking gently brings the meat to tenderness, guarding its juices. It also grants the cook nearly an hour to assemble the rest of the dinner, and what does the grill master know about that? (You might consider moving the meat away from the fire and covering the grill, but the temperature will not be as consistent and will require monitoring.) Penne or other modest macaroni dressed with just olive oil and chile flakes is excellent alongside, to share the sauce with the meat.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,217 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Dark Places
text: Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus and Michelle Knight, the three women kidnapped and held captive for about a decade in Cleveland, have asked through their lawyer for “time, space and privacy,” and have said they will not give interviews until the criminal case against the man accused of imprisoning them is resolved. Surely their pleas to escape the frenzied attention and speculation of the media are justified. The flood of rumors and analysis is overwhelming, and the public appetite for details about the abduction of young women seems voyeuristic and prurient. We feel guilty being attracted to these stories, almost complicit in the exploitation of women.

headline: Aglianico Emerges From the Bottom of Italy’s Boot
text: The vast ocean of wine that is Italy is fed by many rivers. Sangiovese and nebbiolo, universally considered to be among the world’s great grapes, pour in to acclaim. They are joined by great floods of crowd-pleasers like pinot grigio and workhorses like montepulciano and trebbiano, which account for many serviceable but indistinct wines. Lesser-known varieties trickle in from all directions, adding wonderful flavors and nuances.

headline: From the Front Lines, if You Can See Them
text: The thesis of Richard Rowley’s pessimistic, grimly outraged and utterly riveting documentary “Dirty Wars” is that America’s largely clandestine war on terror is now globally entrenched. Far from ending, the film argues, the fight has spread and begun breeding an increasing hatred of the United States that would have delighted Osama bin Laden. Because it is a hidden war, there are few Congressional restraints on how it is conducted.

headline: More Than Just Housewares
text: As artistic revolutions go, the Vienna Secession of 1897 was a mild one. Unlike the Impressionists and Fauves, whose initial challenges to bourgeois taste were viewed with fear and loathing by mainstream viewers, the Secessionists’ rebellion against the provincial conservatism of Vienna was warmly embraced by critics, patrons and the general public. That’s because their innovations were the opposite of alienating. Taking their lead from the British Arts and Crafts movement and French Art Nouveau, they envisioned art reaching its apogee in the Gesamtkunstwerk, the total artwork in which architecture, painting, sculpture and decorative arts would be integrated into environments of supremely stylish and spiritually elevating equilibrium.

headline: The Green Roots of Turkey’s Urban Unrest
text: The street protests that spread from Istanbul to some 60 cities around Turkey in recent days have focused on a broad range of grievances, particularly what some see as the unresponsive nature of the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan. But the initial spark was a government pan to uproot hundreds of trees and turn a park abutting Istanbul’s Taksim Square (interactive panoramic view) into a shopping mall.

headline: Leader of Scholarly Society To Step Aside During Inquiry Into Her Credentials
text: 6:34 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Big Money
text: Danny Hartzell grew up near Pittsburgh, the son of an alcoholic father who left him largely unsupervised. His wife, Ronale, was also raised by parents who were alcoholics, and her mother drank rubbing alcohol when the other kind wasn’t available. Often they lived out of their car, and Ronale went to bed hungry when her mother was too drunk or unable to feed her.

headline: Comedy Listings for June 7-13
text: Comedy

headline: A Master, Between the Lines
text: There’s not much action in the art of Edward Hopper, who revealed the American soul by freezing and monumentalizing the American scene. His paintings give quiet moments of everyday life an Egyptian stillness; they are fixed in an eternal present, shorn of superfluous detail, rendered as if carved in stone. Their blocky immobility is part of their psychological weight.

headline: A Criminal to Root For
text: If you can squint your way through an early prison fight — and the sight of a guy’s face being sandpapered against a wall, capped by a red smear arcing across the surface — the French thriller “The Prey” will reward your squeamishness with one ridiculously diverting moment after another. A story of resilience (human and genre), it pivots on a prisoner turned running man, Franck (Albert Dupontel), who races through an obstacle course swarming with cruel inmates, corrupt guards, man-hunting cops and a woman-stalking serial killer. Short on words if rarely breath, Franck runs to save his family, his cash and an ever-more outrageous movie that shouldn’t work yet does.

headline: Movie Listings for June 7-13
text: Movies

headline: Plans for Subdivision May Threaten Bat Colony
text: SAN ANTONIO — As the sun sets every summer night at Bracken Cave in the Hill Country, a vortex of Mexican free-tailed bats rushes forth. For as long as four hours a night, a stream of bats leaves the cave to dart south, over the tree line, to hunt. The scene at the cave is repeated in reverse at dawn, when the bats return.

headline: Just Tap Here: Technology and Travel
text: Goodbye, plastic hotel room key. So long, wallet. Farewell, camera.

headline: Wood, Made to Bend to an Artist’s Whims
text: Wood is one of the oldest art materials, so it might seem that anything you can do to it has already been done. But rather than lay down their chisels, the clever artists and designers in “Against the Grain: Wood in Contemporary Art, Craft and Design,” at the Museum of Arts and Design, rise to the challenge.

headline: Laurel and Hardy in Google’s Toyland
text: When did Vince Vaughn drink the Google-aid? That’s one of the many imponderables raised by “The Internship,” his two-hour commercial for GoogleWorld masquerading as an aspirational buddy comedy that he headlines with Owen Wilson. According to Reuters, the movie’s director, Shawn Levy, said Mr. Vaughn hit on the story idea after watching a report on “60 Minutes” that anointed Google as one of the best places in the world to work. Thus inspired, maybe because he himself works in Hollywood, Mr. Vaughn reached out to the company, which cooperated with the production because executives were said to feel that they didn’t have much choice but to agree to hours of Google adoration.

headline: When It Comes to Redistricting, Nothing’s Easy
text: The Texas Legislature’s redistricting mission was supposed to be easy-peasy: zip in for a special session, ratify the court-drawn maps used as a stopgap in the 2012 elections, close the legislative books and go home.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for June 7-13
text: Pop

headline: The Other Sister
text: To experience this novel exactly as the author intended, a reader should avoid the flap copy and everything else written about it. Including this review. The last writers to be unscathed by spoilers were probably the Victorians, who pounded out the likes of “Great Expectations” in weekly, serialized installments. No reviewer could blow the surprise of a convict benefactor or Miss Havisham’s cobwebby cake when these were yet unwritten. But in modern times, literary fiction presents a conundrum: The more craftily constructed its suspense, the more it tempts its advocates — in the interest of airtime — to reach into a serious tale and pull out something resembling a tabloid headline. Such as: “Girl and Chimp Twinned at Birth in Psychological Experiment.” That’s the big reveal in Karen Joy Fowler’s “We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves,” a novel so readably juicy and surreptitiously smart, it deserves all the attention it can get.

headline: Art Imitates I.R.S., or Vice Versa
text: Yet another Internal Revenue Service training video has surfaced, this one a thinly veiled parody of the hit television show “Mad Men.”

headline: The University of Texas System Prepares for Its Newest Member
text: While residents of the Rio Grande Valley know that they are poised to get a new university, there are several details they do not know, like what its mascot or official colors will be. The university president has not been named.

headline: Navigating Surely (With a Steady Horn) Between Quartet and Orchestra
text: The saxophonist Joshua Redman put the least possible glint of salesmanship into his welcoming remarks at Town Hall on Tuesday, as if he were mildly embarrassed by his good fortune. He said it was a special night, and caught himself, confessing that he made that claim to audiences all the time, but really meant it here. He stammered. Noting that the program would be ballad-heavy, he said: “I guess you could set your alarm clocks now” and laughed ruefully, looking as if he wanted to take back the remark.

headline: Five Plague Years
text: Disease is always an intrusion, an indignity, an assault, a devastation. And if the new exhibition at the New-York Historical Society, “AIDS in New York: The First Five Years,” were about any other epidemic, that is what it might evoke. Here is how influenza or polio or the Ebola virus manifested itself. Here is how it was identified and fought. And here are the scars it left behind on the living.

text: Theater

headline: Keeping Score: Key Statistics Favor Heat
text: Carlton Chin, a portfolio strategist and fund manager, and Jay Granat, psychotherapist, are the authors of “Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological & Mathematical Method.” They have previously written about the Stanley Cup finals, N.C.A.A. men’s basketball final and the Super Bowl.

text: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: Emphasizing Inner Beauty, Pageant Says No to Bikinis
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — In a move sure to delight anyone who watches beauty pageants not for the swimsuit competition, but for the parts where contestants play instruments and talk about world hunger, the billionaire organizer of the Miss World pageant declared Thursday that there would be no bikinis this year.

headline: Jazz Listings for June 7-13
text: Jazz

headline: F.D.A. Vote Is Minor Victory for Troubled Diabetes Drug
text: SILVER SPRING, Md. — A panel of experts voted Thursday to loosen restrictions on a controversial diabetes drug, saying doctors should have more freedom to prescribe it to patients. But the decision was unlikely to improve prospects for the drug; sales have sagged since a highly publicized episode in 2007, when a doctor showed evidence that it increased the risk of heart problems.

text: Dance

text: Art

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Is Seen in Poll as an Issue for the States
text: A solid majority of Americans opposes a broad national right to same-sex marriage, saying the power to legalize gay unions should rest with the states — even as most support marriage equality for gay people, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Skepticism Over U.S. Involvement in Foreign Conflicts
text: WASHINGTON — Americans are increasingly skeptical about whether the United States should thrust itself into conflicts overseas, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, but that reluctance does not extend to preventing Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted May 31 through June 4 with 1,022 adults throughout the United States. Interviews were in English or Spanish.

headline: “More Fun Than Anyone”
text: From the album “Hey Hey it’s... The Jeffrey Lewis & Peter Stampfel Band.”
