text: There is no telling who will drop by for the Steve Nash Foundation’s sixth annual Showdown match in Manhattan.

headline: H.P. Explains Its Computing Shotgun
text: Hewlett-Packard is using its supply chain, the global network of parts and manufacturing companies it uses, to build more varied and just plain more products faster than ever.

headline: A Home for Us, a Street for the Car
text: After a few years of sharing apartments on the Upper East Side, Rebeccah Rumph received a job transfer to London, where she worked in the marketing field. There she met Andy Pocock, who is from Liverpool.

headline: All Over but the Lease
text: A strange thing can happen to young couples in New York City. Just when it seems everything is going according to plan, they move in together.

headline: The Spurs’ Quiet Class, in Splendid Harmony
text: MIAMI — Before a ball had been shot or a basket had been made in San Antonio’s 92-88 Game 1 victory Thursday night, David Stern anointed the Heat-Spurs series as “probably the most anticipated finals in, who knows, 30 years.”

headline: ‘Daily Show’ Takes On the Bike Share Program
text: On his last “Daily Show” episode Thursday before leaving for the summer to direct a film, Jon Stewart devoted the first nine minutes to New York City’s bold plan to import “Europe’s most boring idea.”

headline: 10 Things Day Camps Wish Parents Knew
text: It’s camp time. You’ve done your homework, and you’re ready to send your wee ones out the door for a fun time at summer day camp. If you’re lucky, you’ve got the right kid in the right camp with the right schedule at the right location. You’re ready to go — but as someone who’s run a few camps, and enjoyed many a happy hour with camp directors and counselors who are more than willing to dish on the parents of the children in their care, I’m here to offer up a few things camp professionals wish every parent knew before sending a child on her merry way.

headline: One Is Enough
text: A couple of years ago, the comedian Tina Fey, grappling with whether to have a second child, wrote in an essay that “the second-worst question” you can ask a woman is, “Are you going to have more kids?” Fey described her bouts of middle-of-the-night angst this way: “I’ll never regret it for a moment unless it ruins my life.” In short order, she gave birth to No. 2.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE VICTORY SEASON: The End of World War II and the Birth of Baseball’s Golden Age,  by Robert Weintraub. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) After the war came a joyous reacclimatization; this account looks at those who served and traces new developments.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE TEA PARTY AND THE REMAKING OF REPUBLICAN CONSERVATISM, by Theda Skocpol and Vanessa Williamson. (Oxford University, $18.95.) Rooted in anthropological fieldwork, this informative study examines the anti-­government passions and sources of discord among Tea Partiers at the grass-roots and national levels. WHEN THE TEA PARTY CAME TO TOWN, by Robert Draper. (Simon & Schuster, $16.) The showdown over the incendiary question of whether to raise the national debt limit is the focal point of Draper’s engaging chronicle of the year in the House of Representatives after the Tea Party-powered 2010 elections.

headline: Inside the List
text: CREATION THEORY: “My name is Odd Thomas. I have accepted my oddness. And I am no longer surprised that I am drawn to trouble as reliably as iron to a magnet.” Thus proceeds “Deeply Odd,” the latest entry in Dean Koontz’s popular series of goofy paranormal noir thrillers, which is new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 3. Koontz doesn’t take himself too seriously: the villain in “Deeply Odd” is a long-haul trucker who dresses like a rhinestone cowboy and carries a .45 Sig Sauer instead of a guitar, while Odd Thomas, an unemployed fry cook determined to stop the trucker from killing three unknown victims, is accompanied on his travels by the ghost of Alfred Hitchcock.

headline: Faith in the Unseen
text: Most works in philosophy enter the world quietly, but not Thomas Nagel’s recent “Mind and Cosmos.” With its chin-leading subtitle, “Why the Materialist Neo-Darwinian Conception of Nature Is Almost Certainly False,” the slim volume met with a firestorm of indignation from critics who thought Nagel had lost his mind or, worse, had thrown in with intelligent design theory. (Steven Pinker tweeted: “What has gotten into Thomas Nagel? . . . a once-great thinker.”) What incited the reaction was Nagel’s questioning whether advances in neuroscience are on the verge of resolving the mysteries of consciousness, and with it issues that have fueled philosophical speculation for centuries, from subjectivity to free will.

headline: Expo Takes Manhattan
text: As this issue goes to press, thousands of bookish types are descending on New York for BookExpo America, the annual publishing trade convention that has been housed at the Javits Center on the West Side of Manhattan since 2009.

headline: Tony Parker’s Wild Final Possession
text: In the dying moments of Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals Thursday night, as San Antonio point guard Tony Parker nearly dribbled himself a sinkhole to the Everglades only to right himself and sink a 2-point dagger, the Spurs confirmed all of the Miami Heat’s fears. They are not going away. Maybe they are never going away. Tim Duncan may be smartly positioning himself for rebounds when he’s 62. Manu Ginobili will lose what’s left of his hair and there will be no way to tell if he’s aging. Gregg Popovich already appears to have begun coaching in the Dark Ages.

headline: Difficult Terrain
text: What do Detroit, Mich., and a town in Zimbabwe called Paradise have in common? For Darling, the narrator of NoViolet Bulawayo’s striking first novel, “We Need New Names,” the answer is almost nothing — except they’re places she has lived.

headline: Into the Abyss
text: In 2006, the British political and war correspondent J. M. Ledgard published his first novel, “Giraffe,” a finalist for the Commonwealth Writers’ Prize. Closely based on the true story of 49 giraffes slaughtered at a zoo in Communist Czechoslovakia, it was a risky, bitter performance that balanced numerous narrative voices — including that of an erudite, lyrical giraffe — against stark reporting.

headline: Diary of a Russian Priest
text: Why do Russians consume alcohol the way they do? In many nations people drink to blot out their memories. But Russians, especially those stuck in withering villages, seem intent on drinking themselves into nonexistence, pouring spirits down their throats so systematically, and in such reliably lethal quantities, that their behavior provides a scientific definition of despair.

headline: Why Wall Street Likes Slow Job Growth
text: Job growth in May kept up with the year’s monthly average, with 175,000 new jobs added. Meanwhile, the unemployment rate increased slightly to 7.6 percent.

headline: Realities of Race
text: What’s the difference between an African-American and an American-African? From such a distinction springs a deep-seated discussion of race in Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie’s third novel, “Americanah.” Adichie, born in Nigeria but now living both in her homeland and in the United States, is an extraordinarily self-aware thinker and writer, possessing the ability to lambaste society without sneering or patronizing or polemicizing. For her, it seems no great feat to balance high-literary intentions with broad social critique. “Americanah” examines blackness in America, Nigeria and Britain, but it’s also a steady-handed dissection of the universal human experience — a platitude made fresh by the accuracy of Adichie’s observations.

headline: Amid Hunger Strike, Senators Lead Delegation to Prison at Guantánamo
text: Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, and the White House chief of staff, Denis McDonough, are flying to Cuba on Friday to examine what is happening at the prison at Guantánamo Bay.

headline: Who He Really Was
text: When Alysia Abbott was a child, she constructed a fairy tale of sorts from the shards of her family’s short life together. Barbara Binder, beautiful Smith College graduate and aspiring psychologist, and Steve Abbott, conscientious objector and budding writer, had been an ideal match. Drawn together by radical politics while master’s candidates at Emory University, they were married in Atlanta in 1969. Late the next year, Alysia-Rebeccah was born. “We lived happily,” she writes in her memoir, “Fairyland,” hewing to her childhood fantasy, “until, one night late in the summer of 1973, my mother was out driving when her car was rear-ended. She flew into the street, was hit by a car and was killed instantly.”

headline: Who She Really Was
text: Emma Brockes, a reporter for The Guardian, was the only child of a middle-class couple in a small town in England. Her mother, Paula, was born poor in South Africa, lost her mother to tuberculosis, helped care for her seven half siblings and emigrated alone at 28 to England, where she married and had Emma. The differences in their lives notwithstanding, Brockes writes in her new book, “it didn’t occur to me until an absurdly late stage that we might, in fact, be separate people.” Paula deflected questions about her previous life, which enabled Brockes to maintain that illusion. “If it struck me as odd that we never saw or heard from” her mother’s brothers and sisters, Brockes writes, “I didn’t dwell on it. Like most children, the life my parents led before I was born was a rumor I didn’t believe in.”

headline: Prisoners of the Caucasus
text: Anthony Marra’s extraordinary first novel, “A Constellation of Vital Phenomena,” opens with a disappearance typical of postmodern warfare, cobbled to an image completely alien to it: “On the morning after the Feds burned down her house and took her father, Havaa woke from dreams of sea anemones.” This fusion of the desperate with the whimsical sets the tone.

headline: Revolution Redux
text: Each year, on the anniversary of George Washington’s successful siege of British-occupied Boston, a procession glides through the Province House, the old governor’s mansion. The participants are the ghosts of colonial Massachusetts governors. Unable to accept that the British lost the American War for Independence, they are forever doomed to commemorate a moment when it might have gone the other way.

headline: Horseplay
text: The year is 1930 and the country has slid into the Great Depression. Fifteen-year-old Thea Atwell has been ejected from her family home in Florida for doing something very, very bad. Her punishment: to be remanded to the Yonahlossee Riding Camp for Girls in the Blue Ridge Mountains of North Carolina. A child of privilege, Thea has grown up in near isolation on a citrus plantation, with her twin brother, Sam, and 16-year-old cousin, Georgie, as her closest companions. Once deposited and uniformed, Thea comes to realize that Yonahlossee isn’t just an elite summer camp but a year-round school and — cue “Hotel California” — she’s not going anywhere for a long time.

headline: The Fortress of Solicitude
text: Have you ever bought a handmade trifle on Etsy? Browsed homegrown produce at a farmers’ market? Read one of the many recent memoirs in which the heroine ditches her adrenalized urban professional life to raise animals and plant vegetables in the country? Or perhaps watched an episode of “Portlandia” (artisanal knots, anyone?), a show that pokes gentle fun at such precious activities? If so, you are probably aware that a cultural change is afoot: people increasingly want experiences and artifacts that feel natural, simple and untainted by consumerism.

headline: Truly Great Companies Add More Than They Extract
text: Perhaps no business consultant enjoys higher esteem in the corporate world than Jim Collins. Over three decades, he has sold millions of copies of his books describing the characteristics of what he terms “great” companies.

headline: Lost Footing
text: Ben Greenman’s wry new novel, “The Slippage,” opens with the 42-year-old William Day hosting a party on his deck in an unnamed suburb. “He had always had an ability to put people at ease,” Greenman writes, “which was why he came on board quickly whenever Louisa proposed that they host a party. It was a chance to see himself in the best possible light, and there were fewer and fewer of those with each passing year.”

headline: Romantically Incorrect
text: If a ban is a sign of recognition in an authoritarian regime, then Victor Martinovich, a young Belarussian writer, is a winner. His novel “Paranoia” — half thriller and half dystopian fiction — was taken off the shelves in Belarus two days after it was published. As Anna Akhmatova said of Joseph Brodsky when he was persecuted by the K.G.B.: “What a biography they’re fashioning for our red-haired friend! It’s as if he’d hired them to do it on purpose.”

headline: The Genius of Getting It Wrong
text: In a letter to a fellow physicist in 1915, Albert Einstein described how a scientist gets things wrong:

headline: Rengan Rajaratnam Cuts Own Path in Plea Talks
text: Raj and Rengan Rajaratnam were both born in Sri Lanka. They both studied at the University of Pennsylvania and they both started hedge funds. But as Rengan, 42, faces insider trading charges, he appears to be taking a very different approach from his older brother, Raj.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: TIME ON MY HANDS  By Giorgio VastaTranslated by Jonathan Hunt  Faber & Faber, paper, $16.

headline: Suffer the Little Children
text: It’s hard to say anything original about the sexual abuse scandals that have rocked the Roman Catholic Church over the past 30 years. Hundreds of books and articles have dealt with the subject, which has also spurred an entire genre of daytime talk show — the secular confessional. By now, the basic outline of the story has become depressingly familiar: a needy, socially isolated boy (sometimes girl) falls victim to a charming, manipulative priest while church elders either turn a blind eye or quietly ship the offender to a different parish. Afterward, it’s business as usual.

headline: The House That Coco Built
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Archie Could Be Latest Comic Book Hero Headed for the Big Screen
text: Archie, who, at 72, may now be America’s oldest teenager, is headed to the big screen for the first time, at least if a new project at Warner Brothers proceeds as planned.

headline: A Timeless Epic Takes 4 Hours 37 Minutes
text: PARIS — It was a mere semifinal, and it was even relegated to the first slot on the Friday schedule, which meant that the French love affair with the leisurely lunch guaranteed there would be plenty of empty seats at the Philippe Chatrier court when Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic walked on the red clay to renew the best rivalry in tennis.

headline: Two Hippies on a Long Flight Together
text: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Image of the Day: June 7
text: Heavy rains in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: 911 Worker’s Error Delayed Response to Crash That Killed Girl, Officials Say
text: Emergency medical workers were delayed in responding to a car crash in Manhattan that left a 4-year-old girl dead because a 911 dispatcher failed to see an incoming report on his computer for several minutes, fire officials said on Friday.

headline: Are They Still Masters of Reality?
text: The concept of ear fatigue is widely understood, possibly too widely; in an ever-louder world, everyone’s an expert. But those who spend a lot of time in recording studios — engineers, producers, musicians — talk about it with the most knowledge, because ear fatigue prevents them from working. After hearing too much loud music, without enough dynamics, they can’t hear differences in tone and frequency and all sound becomes porridge. They’re tired, done for the day.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Anthony Marra and Lauren Sandler
text: This week, Anthony Marra discusses his novel, “A Constellation of Vital Phenomena”; Lauren Sandler talks about “One and Only: The Freedom of Having an Only Child, and the Joy of Being One”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Sabbath Resurgent Sabbath
text: Steve Smith, a classical music critic for The New York Times and prime Sabbathologist, talks to Ben Ratliff about the meaning of Black Sabbath and its new album, “13.”

headline: An Amazingly Simple Way to Add Air-Conditioning to Your Car
text: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NUhs_1puHk0

headline: The Gun Report: June 7, 2013
text: Yesterday, a Texas jury acquitted Ezekiel Gilbert, 30, of murdering Lenora Ivie Frago, a 23-year-old escort Gilbert met through an ad on Craigslist, after he learned sex wasn’t included in her $150 fee. When Frago tried to leave, taking the money with her, Gilbert shot and paralyzed her. She died seven months later.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra Tours China, 40 Years Later
text: BEIJING — If Ping-Pong diplomacy is what paved the way for President Richard M. Nixon’s visit to Beijing in 1972 to re-establish the United States’ official relationship with China, then one could say it was the visit by the Philadelphia Orchestra the following year that truly cemented it. Personally chosen by President Nixon himself, the Philadelphia Orchestra was one of the first cultural delegations to be sent to China that followed Nixon’s visit. The orchestra’s performance in 1973 in front of a packed audience at the Cultural Palace of Nationalities in the heart of Beijing was the first-ever given by an American orchestra in Communist-led China.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Anthony Marra and Lauren Sandler
text: This week, Anthony Marra, Lauren Sandler and best-seller news.

headline: In Its Biggest Appeal Ever, U.N. Requests $5 Billion in Humanitarian Aid for Syria
text: GENEVA — The United Nations issued the biggest financing appeal in its history on Friday, asking for more than $5 billion in humanitarian aid for Syria this year to help millions of people affected by the country’s civil war and ease the pressure building up in neighboring countries overwhelmed by Syrian refugees.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Pit masters and barbecue aficionados from around the country will come together for the Big Apple Barbecue Block Party on Saturday and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. at Madison Square Park, between 23rd and 26th Streets and Fifth and Madison Avenues. Besides the various vendors selling $9 plates of barbecue, there will be a tent open both days from 4 to 6 p.m. with seafood, seminars and live music.

headline: A Growth Spurt at Governors Ball
text: The Governors Ball Music Festival, which started on Friday, has grown since last year: from two days to three, from two stages to four, from theater-circuit headliners to arena acts like Kanye West on Sunday, Guns N’ Roses on Saturday and Kings of Leon on Friday. The event made its debut in 2011 on Governors Island, its namesake, but moved to Randalls Island in 2012.

headline: In Myanmar, Flirtations by Investors Turn Into Commitments
text: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — Foreign executives who flew into this dirt-poor country over the past year to tap into what is described as Asia’s last major frontier market often came away skeptical, befuddled or outright disappointed.

headline: British Employers See Value in Europe-Wide Labor Pool
text: LONDON — With several big construction projects under way in Britain, the multinational company CH2M Hill spent six months searching for a qualified tunneling engineer.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Italy and Oslo
text: Lucca Music Festival, Italy Every summer, thousands of revelers converge on the Piazza Napoleone in Lucca, a medieval Tuscan town, to hear music that’s decidedly modern. The rock festival, which will be held from July 6 to July 30 this year, will feature an eclectic lineup of international groups and musicians, including Sigur Ros, Leonard Cohen (above) and Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds.

headline: Q & A
text: Guests in a Co-op

headline: Book Review Podcast: Memory as Survival in Chechnya
text: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Madison Smartt Bell reviews Anthony Marra’s debut novel, “A Constellation of Vital Phenomena.” Mr. Bell writes:

headline: The Ammo Conspiracy
text: For over a year, survivalist bloggers have waxed apocalyptic about the Department of Homeland Security’s bulk ammunition purchases for its 100,000 peace officers in its 90-plus agencies — “buying up enough ammo to wage seven-year war against the American people,” as one hysteric put it. Others have charged that D.H.S. is deliberately creating a domestic bullet shortage for ordinary Americans intent on pursuing their Second Amendment rights. This concocted issue seemed like an occasion for light amusement until Wednesday evening. That’s when the House seriously voted to block funds for future D.H.S. ammunition needs — until the department submits to Congress a comprehensive report on the history of and justification for its bullet requirements.

headline: Canada Responds to Attacks on Management of Peace Bridge
text: Canada is providing Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo with a lesson in diplomacy.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Starlet Obsession
text: David Carr and A.O. Scott discuss the darker side of celebrity culture and America's fascination with witnessing an actress's demise.

headline: Living in the Clouds
text: Two residential towers are set to surpass the Empire State Building in height.

headline: Looking Down on the Empire State
text: Not since builders stuck a dirigible mooring mast to the top of the Empire State Building, eclipsing the Chrysler Building as the world’s tallest tower, have developers been engaged in the type of skyscraper war that New York City is now witnessing.

headline: A Swiveling Proxy That Will Even Wear a Tutu
text: SUMTER, S.C. — Lexie Kinder solves problems during math class, earns gold stars from her teacher and jokes with classmates at her elementary school.

headline: Robots Lead the Way to the Classroom
text: Some chronically ill children can attend school remotely, using a robot called a VGo that allows them to see, hear and interact through two-way video.

headline: Obama Defends Surveillance Programs
text: President Obama defends and explains a National Security Agency program that monitors domestic and international phone records.

headline: At Once Intimate and Grand
text: A beautifully proportioned apartment that commands nearly the entire 15th floor at the hyperexclusive 778 Park Avenue, an important pearl in the elegant prewar necklace of Upper East Side residences designed by Rosario Candela, is being offered for private sale by the family of its late owner, the ABC maestro Roone Arledge. The head of ABC Sports for 25 years, Mr. Arledge expanded his hands-on fief in 1977 to include the network’s news division. “Wide World of Sports,” “Nightline” and “20/20” were among his varied creations, as was Howard Cosell.

headline: Vince Vaughn and Owen Wilson Arrive in Silicon Valley
text: When Vince Vaughn and Owen Wilson arrived on Google‘s campus to film their new comedy, “The Internship,” which comes out Friday, they were in for a bit of culture shock.

headline: YouTube Founders Focus on New Video Tools
text: If imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, Twitter should consider itself very flattered.

headline: A Financial Backer When a Parent’s Wallet Isn’t an Option
text: SHEFALI KUMAR FRIESEN set out to create an app to allow people to send sound clips, like music or speeches or poems, as text messages. She wanted the app, called Emotitones, to have a vast digital library that would allow people to search for clips by name but also by sounds, like something to inspire or apologize.

headline: Popcast: Sabbath Resurgent Sabbath
text: This week, we look at “13,” the new album by Black Sabbath, the proto-doom metal band, makers of loud, post-blues stomps and drones about war, paranoia and godlessness, and one of the most persistently influential groups in rock history.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Starlet Obsession
text: In this week’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about the darker side of celebrity culture and America’s fascination with witnessing an actress’s demise.

headline: Quiet Campaigns Begin for Presidency of I.O.C.
text: In the last 60 years, there have been seven popes but only four presidents of the International Olympic Committee. There will soon be a fifth, although without the promise of a billow of white smoke.

headline: The End Comes for a Troubled California Nuclear Plant
text: The two reactors at California’s troubled San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station will be permanently shut down, the plant’s owners said Friday. The Los Angeles Times has the details in this piece: “Activists praise San Onofre closure, but 1,100 layoffs expected.”

headline: Wal-Mart Yearly Meeting Follows a Narrow Script
text: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. — There were two Wal-Marts on display at the company’s shareholder meeting on Friday: the one Wal-Mart presented, and the one some investors and activists were complaining about.

headline: In U.S., News of Surveillance Effort Is Met With Some Concern but Little Surprise
text: LOS ANGELES — The string of revelations over the past 48 hours about sweeping government surveillance of American telephone records and Internet activity by foreigners, including e-mail, stirred expressions of concern across the country on Friday — along with something of a collective national shrug.

headline: A Bond Market Plunge That Baffles the Experts
text: As if it wasn’t bad enough for the millions of Americans scraping by on paltry interest payments, now they face another threat: the loss of principal on their bonds and other fixed-income assets.

headline: Reimagined ‘Rite of Spring’ Is Canceled at Manchester International Festival
text: Igor Stravinsky might be turning over in his grave, but then again, he might be dancing. A radical reimagining of his 1913 ballet “The Rite of Spring” – without dancers but with powdered bone that is “choreographed”  – has been canceled by the Manchester International Festival. The scheduled July 14-19 run, staged by Romeo Castellucci, the innovative director, was felled by several technical problems, Nadja Coyne, a spokeswoman for the festival said Friday.

headline: Woman From Texas Is Charged in Ricin Case
text: A week ago Thursday, Shannon Guess Richardson traveled from her small town in Texas to meet with investigators in Louisiana and accuse her husband of a disturbing crime. Ms. Richardson, a pregnant mother of five, said she suspected that her husband, Nathaniel, had mailed three ricin-laced letters to President Obama, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and a gun-control lobbyist in Washington. She also offered hard evidence: a book of stamps that microscopic analysis revealed to be the source of the stamps on the three letters.

headline: The Lesson From the Coup at Timken
text: Big targets were all the rage this shareholder voting season in the United States. Uppity investors set their sights on industry heavyweights like JPMorgan Chase and Apple. Such headline-grabbing giants overshadowed activist investor Ralph Whitworth’s success at the far smaller Timken. He persuaded fellow shareholders to approve his ballot campaign to break up the steel and ball bearing manufacturer. It’s the result that boards should be most carefully watching.

headline: Bruins Likely to Replace Campbell with Daugavins
text: BOSTON – Kaspars Daugavins appears to be the likely candidate to replace the injured Gregory Campbell in the Boston Bruins’ lineup for Game 4 of their Eastern Conference Finals against Pittsburgh Friday night.

headline: Long-Term Jobless: Still a Bleak Picture
text: Long-term unemployment remains a very dark shadow in the May jobs report: 4.4 million workers have been out of a job for more than six months. In essence, the job market has normalized for the short-term unemployed. But the longer you have been out of a job, the bleaker the picture gets.

headline: Harvey Weinstein Finds a New Director for ‘Finding Neverland’
text: 3:58 p.m. | Updated

headline: Expansive Setting for Obama’s Meeting With Xi
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — It was Leonore Annenberg’s wish that the sumptuous winter home that she and her billionaire husband, Walter H. Annenberg, built in the Southern California desert would become, after their deaths, “Camp David West” for American presidents — a place both to relax and to parley with world leaders, preferably those from Pacific powers.

headline: Clip: 'Berberian Sound Studio'
text: A scene from the film, directed by Peter Strickland.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Digital Plans for Batman
text: It’s a slow week on our hardcover graphic books best-seller list, with little movement and few surprises.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: A Cough Solved
text: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to unravel the mystery of a 75-year-old woman with a cough that lasted for months. In addition, we asked you to tell us what kind of test you would order to clinch the diagnosis.

headline: Kevin Barry Wins Dublin Literary Award for Debut Novel
text: Kevin Barry, an Irish author, has won the International Impac Dublin Literary Award for “City of Bohane,'’ his debut novel. The award, issued since 1996 for novels written in or translated into English, is given with a prize of 100,000 Euros, or about $130,000. Previous winners of the award include Colm Toibin for “The Master” and Colum McCann for “Let the Great World Spin.”

headline: Putin Offers Russian Troops as Golan Peacekeepers
text: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia volunteered his country’s troops as replacements on Friday for the Austrian members of a United Nations peacekeeping force who are vacating the disputed Golan Heights area along the Israel-Syria border, where violence from the Syrian civil war has intensified.

headline: A Second Chance, but on His Own
text: It’s possibly no surprise that Vanity Fair’s John Galliano interview, by Ingrid Sischy, raises as many questions as it answers. Articles about addiction and atonement often strain for sympathy against the banality of the circumstances: a talented designer wrecks his career by behaving like an utter fool. At the time of Mr. Galliano’s dismissal from Dior, in 2011, for racist and anti-Semitic remarks, Michael Specter, who had once written an admiring profile of the designer in The New Yorker, offered one of the few sane views of his fall. He wrote: “His career, and his life, were built on twin pillars of excess and exhibitionism. He was a slave to addiction … But who could be shocked at his behavior? Who would have expected any other end?”

headline: Federal Protection of Gray Wolves May Be Lifted, Agency Says
text: Gray wolves, whose packs now prowl through the northern Rockies and the forests along the Great Lakes, no longer need endangered-species protection to prevent their extinction, the Obama administration said Friday.

headline: Obama’s Remarks on Health Care and Surveillance
text: The following is a transcript of President Obama’s remarks about the health care overhaul and response to a question about electronic surveillance in San Jose, Calif., as provided by the White House:

headline: In Cape Breton, a Rugged Golf Getaway
text: “Well, you can tell we’re not in Myrtle Beach,” said my brother Tom, peering into the darkness from the passenger seat of our rental car.

headline: In Rimini, Looking for Fellini’s World
text: Opening with the tiniest click, the door swung wide to reveal the furnishings of a classic Old World grand hotel suite. On the far wall, the late-afternoon light of the Italian coastline filtered through gauzy curtains, striking the worn velvet seat of an old Empire settee and filling the room with a funereal glow.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Much Ado About Nothing’
text: In this video, Joss Whedon narrates a moment from his adaptation of Shakespeare’s “Much Ado About Nothing,” shot in his home. It includes Blake Edwards-style slapstick humor, the deployment of a “blanky cam” and the creative use of a kitchen nook. Read A. O. Scott’s review.

headline: 36 Hours in Verona, Italy
text: Compact and easy to navigate, Verona remains one of Italy’s most underrated cities despite its picturesque center of cobblestone streets lined with medieval pink-hued buildings, well-preserved Roman sites and dozens of churches. A short hop from major hubs like Milan and Venice, the former Roman settlement never feels overrun by tourists, although visitors descend on the town for events like the summer opera festival, which runs June 14 until Sept. 8 and which celebrates its centennial and Verdi’s bicentenary this year, and Vinitaly in April, one of the wine world’s most important events. In between the landmarks and happenings that keep Verona so culturally vibrant, you’ll find time for lavish meals in inventive new restaurants, tastings at wine bars tucked away behind unassuming facades and shopping in small boutiques off the main arteries. Who are we to point out that Juliet’s much-visited balcony actually has no historical connection to Shakespeare’s star-crossed characters? After all, the city is just about as romantic as it gets.

headline: Views of Verona
text: Whether you’re interested in Roman history or gelato and wine, this Italian city can accommodate.

headline: Big Ticket | Park Perks for $15.27 Million
text: In a repeat of last week’s performance, the exacting renovation and restoration at the historic 18 Gramercy Park South by Zeckendorf Development and Robert A. M. Stern recorded its second closing — No. 5, another floor-through condominium, which sold for $15,273,750 — in a sale that was the most expensive of the week, according to city records.

headline: Hotel Review: Gale South Beach in Miami Beach
text: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Prairie Canary in Grinnell, Iowa
text: What does a small, eclectic college town do to attract a chef? Eager to fill an empty downtown storefront, Grinnell, Iowa, took an unusual approach: it held a national contest and offered a hefty prize.

headline: A Lonely Planet Founder Looks Back
text: In 1972, when Tony Wheeler, a co-founder of the Lonely Planet guidebooks, traveled from London to Sydney, Australia, overland from Europe to India and Nepal, along what was, tellingly, called the hippie trail, he had little to guide him.

headline: Obama’s Secret Habit
text: In our editorial on the news that the N.S.A. routinely, indiscriminately and secretly collects the communication records of millions of Americans, we noted other secrets that the Obama administration has kept from citizens and the press: “secret warrants to scoop up a news agency’s phone records” and “secret orders to kill an American suspected of terrorism.” The administration’s tendency to keep things quiet is especially galling because President Obama once “promised transparency and accountability.”

headline: Interactive Map: Your Biking Wisdom in 10 Words
text: An interactive map, “Your Biking Wisdom in 10 Words,” allows readers to annotate a map with their own inside knowledge and read what others have to say.

headline: Indie Rock Packed Densely
text: The Northside Festival, Thursday through June 20, is Brooklyn’s compressed answer to South by Southwest: a long weekend of digital entrepreneurship talks and music followed by a film festival. The music festival is New Yorkcentric and strong on indie rock and guitar squall. Its centerpieces are afternoon concerts at McCarren Park, at Bedford and North 12th Streets in Williamsburg, featuring the Walkmen and Phosphorescent on Saturday and Solange Knowles on Sunday; they require an $80 music-festival badge, which also provides admission to dozens of club shows.

headline: The Seasoning of Student Chefs
text: In the 21st-century economy, the path from a degree to a job is, for many fields of study, no longer as clear as it once was. But everybody has to eat, right? So the numerous people who think they can cook might think culinary school is the way to go educationally. Yet a serious cooking school is not all sugar and spice, as it were, as the students profiled in “The Freshman Class” find out.

headline: Progress Made on Laminitis, but Still Much Left to Do
text: Barbaro succumbed to laminitis, after a long and valiant fight. Other Kentucky Derby winners have also suffered from the disease; it ended the lives of Secretariat, Affirmed and Sunday Silence. It is a disease that affects all types of horses and their attending horse people. We have struggled with it since we first partnered with the horse, and we do not yet fully understand it. I wrote about the disease in my book, Greatness and Goodness: Barbaro and His Legacy. I was curious to get an update on the understanding of the disease.

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 7
text: This week’s photos include a scene in the South Bronx, a music hall in Hoboken, N.J., and a tribute to Senator Frank R. Lautenberg.

headline: Young Pianist, Younger Festival
text: Conrad Tao, a gifted composer-pianist who is in the Columbia University-Juilliard School joint degree program, will celebrate his 19th birthday on Tuesday by inaugurating the Unplay Festival. This three-day event that he is organizing at the Powerhouse Arena in Brooklyn will explore several themes, including the musician’s evolving role in contemporary culture and how and why particular works come to be considered standard repertory.

headline: Eager for Release on a Big Stage
text: Some choreographers might be daunted by 4,000 square feet of empty space. But in “Coming Together/Attica,” a United States premiere, the Brooklyn artist Rebecca Lazier plans to take full advantage of the sprawling third-floor loft at the Invisible Dog Art Center. Guided by Davison Scandrett’s lighting scheme, the performance migrates between the far ends of the room, a 50-minute exploration of isolation and breaking free.

headline: Classic Tensions, Set to Hip-Hop
text: In 2010, Time magazine declared “Venice” that year’s best musical, but it’s unlikely that many theatergoers are familiar with this Shakespeare-influenced, hip-hop- and rock-infused tale of a dystopian society on the brink of civil war. In New York, the Public Theater is now providing a chance to see “Venice,” a collaboration between the performer Matt Sax and the director Eric Rosen, who wrote the lyrics together.

headline: A Hearing to Remember
text: The annual Human Rights Watch Film Festival, Thursday to June 23 at the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the IFC Center, is as close as anything to being the social conscience of the film industry. Not that of Hollywood, mind you, but of more high-minded, noncommercial independent and world cinema.

headline: Movements Frozen Into Folk Tales
text: The self-taught Alabama artist Bill Traylor is known for his flat, simple shapes. But in chronicling memories and observations from African-American life, his work also had complexity and depth. The New York Times critic Roberta Smith has called Traylor “the American master of taut silhouettes,” yet some of his work is literally about movement, evoking dances of his era like the Lindy Hop and the Cakewalk, with women in hoop skirts and men in high hats.

headline: Hip-Hop’s Global Accent Finds Harlem
text: A storied New York institution imports a festival of hip-hop, that pride of the Bronx, from Britain. The notion, as Jonzi D, the founder, artistic director and host of the festival, joked in a recent Skype interview, sounds like “bringing ice to the Inuit.” But next weekend, for the first time, Breakin’ Convention will travel across the Atlantic to the Apollo Theater in Harlem.

headline: A Bond Forged Over Time on the Open Sea
text: A decade ago, as the first R Family Vacations cruise prepared to set sail, Kelli Carpenter envisioned a place where same-sex couples could take their parents, their siblings and their children, and commune with people just like them.

headline: Bond Market Turmoil
text: A sell-off in fixed-income securities began in May, on fears that the Federal Reserve might start tapering off its purchases of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities earlier than expected.

headline: Health Apps as Parenting Aids
text: Three new apps provide evidence-based healthy hints for raising children ages 1 to 5. For example: “Don’t forget it’s time for your child’s 1-year checkup! The doctor will talk to you about how your child is growing and what to expect this year.”

headline: Fashion Stylist Annabel Tollman Dies
text: Annabel Tollman, a British stylist known for her work with celebrities like Scarlett Johansson, Mariah Carey and Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, died in her sleep this week. She was 39. Born in Brussels, Ms. Tollman, who attended Central Saint Martins in London, was previously the fashion director of Interview magazine. She also worked with eBay and Calvin Klein and contributed to several fashion publications. Over the years, she became known for an Old Hollywood aesthetic. The cause of her death is not yet known. Police responded to a call at her West Village apartment yesterday between 4:00 and 5:00 p.m. A message signed “Annabel’s Family & Friends” was posted on her Facebook page today, which included: “At this time, there is not confirmation of what caused this tragedy.”

headline: Pedro Almodovar: ‘Bad Education’
text: Part 15: The director discusses his 2004 film “Bad Education” and recalls his own loss of faith.

headline: Pedro Almodovar: The Economic Crisis
text: Part 14: The director talks about how “I’m So Excited!” was influenced by the current political and economic situation in Spain.

headline: Pedro Almodovar: Spain vs. Hollywood
text: Part 13: The director explores the differences between American and Spanish cinema.

headline: Britten at 100: An Original’s Legacy
text: Learning to let go of infuriating experiences is a valuable life skill. Yet in this year of extensive international festivities for the centennial of the English composer Benjamin Britten, I have become annoyed all over again about a conversation I had with some fellow students and junior faculty at the Yale School of Music in the early 1970s, when I was shot down for arguing that Britten’s “Peter Grimes” is a great opera and that Britten was a major composer.

headline: Pedro Almodovar: Sex and Death
text: Part 12: The director discusses his 1986 film “Matador,” and reflects on the recurrent themes of sex, death and surrealism in his work.

headline: Objects | Camping Tents for the Style-Obsessed
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Heavy-Metal Jazz, and an Homage to Abbey Lincoln
text: Hedvig Mollestad Trio

headline: Former Joint Chiefs Chairman to Join Board of Sprint
text: Sprint announced Friday that Adm. Mike Mullen would join the company’s board after its proposed $20.1 billion sale to SoftBank of Japan closes.

headline: Q. and A.: Brian Baker, Sidelined Again, but Comeback Continues
text: Brian Baker was one of the top story lines of last year’s French Open, when he beat Xavier Malisse in the first round and lost in a fantastic five-set match to Gilles Simon in the second. This came as part of Baker’s remarkable comeback: a top junior player, Baker’s career was derailed for six years by injuries that required five separate surgeries. Unfortunately for Baker, a knee injury has again forced him off court for much of 2013. He answered questions via e-mail.

headline: Anguish for France; Joy for Spain
text: PARIS — In the first men’s semifinal at Roland Garros on Friday, the French fans got a dream match. In the second, the one the locals had anticipated even more than the epic between Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic, they got a nightmare.

headline: A Pitch to Add Ivory to the Agenda as Obama Meets His Chinese Counterpart
text: Needless to say, there’s pressure on President Obama to address a host of issues in his weekend summit in the California desert with President Xi Jinping of China. Think computer security, trade disputes, North Korea’s destabilizing behavior.

headline: Participate in a Recipe Lab Video Chat
text: Since March we’ve been asking Dining readers to participate in Recipe Lab, a monthly feature in which we publish a standout recipe from a new cookbook for home cooks to try. Then Julia Moskin, a Dining reporter for The Times, joins the book’s author and three readers in live video chat to discuss the recipe at hand and cooking techniques.

headline: What’s the Right Age to Appreciate ‘Star Wars’?
text: A quandary from my friend J.: When, he asks, should you introduce your children to “Star Wars”? As infants, so that they never know a world without Jedi? When they are old enough to appreciate the light sabers and R2-D2? Or when the shock will be full and genuine as Darth Vader intones, “I am your father”?

headline: Weighing Fed Policy from Sturgeon Bay, Wis.
text: Paul Kasriel spends his days learning the bass guitar for a band he joined after he retired last year as Northern Trust’s chief economist. Between practices, however, he works on an economic yardstick that many on Wall Street would find fascinating.

headline: Some Music Old and New in Morgan Library & Museum’s 2013-14 Season
text: The Morgan Library & Museum, which has presented an array of programs in the Gilder Lehrman Hall since 2006, will offer semi-staged performances of Marc-Antoine Charpentier’s seldom-performed operas “La Descent d’Orphée aux Enfers” and “La Couronne de Fleurs” in collaboration with the Boston Early Music Festival during the 2013-14 season.

headline: Apocalypse, Again and Again
text: What’s so funny about the end of the world? Filmmakers might answer that with their own question: what’s not to laugh at?

headline: Why Music Makes Our Brain Sing
text: MUSIC is not tangible. You can’t eat it, drink it or mate with it. It doesn’t protect against the rain, wind or cold. It doesn’t vanquish predators or mend broken bones. And yet humans have always prized music — or well beyond prized, loved it.

headline: Week in Review: Steven Cohen Keeps His Chin Up
text: As investors bail out, SAC shows a brave face. | Debt deal in Alabama will cost JPMorgan. | Wall St. buyers behind the rise in house prices. | A tale of Wall St. excess.

headline: The New Economics Behind the Oracle-Dell Partnership
text: This week, Dell and Oracle announced a partnership unique to both companies. Dell would offer Oracle software on its machines and would resell Oracle services. Much head-scratching ensued among industry analysts, largely over misunderstandings about where the industry was headed.

headline: Not Your Mother’s Bridesmaid Dresses
text: A collection of unique designs that one might actually wear again.

headline: Sound Men on Film
text: A look at some of the films that feature sound professionals as characters.

headline: After a Three-Story Fall, His Tennis Career Is at Stake
text: PARIS — When he was falling three stories into a French courtyard one night in November, Sergei Bubka Jr. said, he did not have any flashbacks and there was no time to fear death.

headline: What Dissonant Sound Looks Like
text: No people were harmed in the making of “Berberian Sound Studio,” but fruits and vegetables didn’t fare too well.

headline: Williams Evokes Unbeatable Graf in ’88
text: PARIS — When Maria Sharapova tries to find a bright spot in her rivalry with Serena Williams, she sifts through the wreckage of a career spent lunging after Williams’s powerful ground strokes and watching serves whiz by. Sharapova clings to one set — the first set in the final at Key Biscayne, Fla., in March.

headline: Soup Up Your Spinach
text: Farmers’ markets are loaded with spinach this time of year, and Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist, has found that soups can be a great way to draw out the flavor of this superfood. She writes:

headline: Driven on Sundays, but Never in the Heat of Competition
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Given its enormous size and shiny black paint, it would have been hard to miss the ’67 Lincoln Continental convertible parked in front of the W Hotel in Scottsdale, Ariz.

headline: Pedro Almodovar: ‘Women on the Verge’
text: Part 11: The director talks about the musical stage production of “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown.”

headline: Pedro Almodovar: Classic Musicals
text: Part 10: The director discusses his 1983 film “Dark Habits,” and reflects on the influence of Hollywood musicals in his work.

headline: Pedro Almodovar: Sex on Film
text: Part 9: The director talks about the multiple meanings of the English and Spanish titles of “I’m So Excited!” and speaks about the importance of sex and sexuality in his films.

headline: Fund Manager Settles Case in Dell Insider Trading Ring
text: In August 2008, in the midst of the financial crisis, a large bet that the shares of Dell would drop proved highly lucrative for a tight-knit group of traders. It has also proved to be bountiful for the government in its campaign to root out insider trading on Wall Street.

headline: Pedro Almodovar: Christians
text: Part 8: The director reflects on the role religion plays in his films.

headline: Pedro Almodovar: No Improv Allowed
text: Part 7: The director discusses the role of improvisation in his films, and explains how his films change during the shooting process.

headline: It’s Now a Party Dress, Not a Uniform
text: It used to be that being a bridesmaid was an honor requiring loyalty, friendship, patience and the willingness to wear a clownish taffeta dress that could have been a hit only at a 1980s prom.

headline: Pedro Almodovar: Making ‘I’m So Excited’
text: Part 6: The actors Carlos Areces and Miguel Angel Silvestre talk about the atmosphere on the set of “I’m So Excited!”

headline: Pedro Almodovar: Blanca Suarez
text: Part 5: The actress Blanca Suarez discusses her experiences working with Almodovar.

headline: Is Everyone Out to Steal My Umbrella?
text: A friend walked to a restaurant and left his umbrella in the front basket. The umbrella was taken by someone else. My friend took another umbrella from the basket that was “similar to his own.” He hoped it belonged to the person who took his (and assumed it had been taken by mistake). Of course, there’s no way of telling if the original theft was an honest mistake. So my question is not “What should an ethical person have done?” but rather “What should an ethical person presume?” Should one presume that most people want to do right and that these types of oversights can be ameliorated by a response like my friend’s? Or should one presume that most people are thieving heels? NAME WITHHELD, LOS ANGELES

headline: Pedro Almodovar: Favorite Actors
text: Part 4: The director reflects on why he tends to collaborate with the same actors over and over.

headline: My Grandfather Invented the Reuben Sandwich. Right?
text: Every family has a claim to fame. A friend’s great-grandfather (times 16) was king of Poland for a day in 1586, according to family lore. My neighbor claims he’s related to the man who punched Houdini in the stomach, which may have killed him. My grandfather invented the Reuben sandwich. I’ve had some doubts since seeing the movie “Quiz Show” in 1994, but it’s what I choose to believe.

headline: The 5.26.13 Issue
Jared Leto’s Worst-Kept Secret
text: I just saw a video for a single from your new 30 Seconds to Mars album, “Love Lust Faith + Dreams.” Why is it that when you are acting, you are Jared Leto, but when you direct music videos you go by Bartholomew Cubbins?

headline: Fine Print and Red Tape in Long-Term Care Policies
text: One of the big reasons people buy long-term care insurance is to avoid burdening a spouse or grown children when they can no longer care for themselves.

headline: Pedro Almodovar: Influences
text: Part 3: The director talks about the films that influenced “I’m So Excited!” and explains how he ended up making a comedy.

headline: Report Your Long-Term Care Insurance Claim Experience
text: This week’s Your Money column discusses the difficulty that some people have encountered when trying to file a long-term care insurance claim on a family member’s behalf.

headline: Pedro Almodovar: Writing a Comedy
text: Part 2: The director discusses his screenwriting process.

headline: The 2014 Toyota Corolla Is Bigger, Braver and Brighter
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — After a wild night filled with bungee cord-suspended gymnasts, women dancing sideways on a wall of aluminum foil and a floating clear-bottomed pool with Argentinian nymphs sliding and squishing inches over the heads of a puzzled, crowd, Toyota on Thursday unveiled its all-new 11th-generation Corolla, the latest iteration of its ubiquitous economical compact.

headline: Lamb Sausage Edges Out the Hamburger
text: I have nothing against hamburgers; a well-made one can be terrific, and often (or a couple of times a year, anyway) it’s just what I want. For the most part, though, I find sausages more interesting, and more fun to make at home.

headline: The 12-Tone Tale of a Prisoner’s One Chance
text: At the New York Philharmonic concert on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall, there was a five-minute ovation for a 12-tone opera.

headline: Shaping Taksim Square
text: The decision by Turkey’s prime minister to clean up Taksim Square has provoked outrage.

headline: Trading a Daughter for a Strong Wind
text: In his latest program Pascal Rioult appears to be invoking Martha Graham. On Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, Mr. Rioult, a French choreographer who has made New York his home since 1981 and who danced with Graham’s company, opened a particularly ponderous program of works exploring Greek mythology (“Iphigenia,” based on Euripides’ “Iphigenia in Aulis,” and “On Distant Shores,” a study of Helen of Troy); transformation (“Prelude to Night”); and forceful unison formation (“Bolero”).

headline: On the Market in Hilton Head, S.C.
text: Homes in gated communities with amenities that include pools, wine rooms, elevators, movie theaters, yachting and golf.

headline: Who and Where Is the Original ‘Who Made That?’ Maker?
text: If you’ve ever wondered who made that Who Made That? column in the front of the magazine, the answer is Hilary Greenbaum. It began March 7, 2011, in this very space when Greenbaum, a former designer at the magazine, published a blog post about some illustrations then appearing on Diet Coke cans. She followed up with investigations into the origins of subway tiles, the rainbow flag, album covers for the Decemberists and that “chung-chung” sound known to all watchers of “Law and Order.” The posts proved popular (Greenbaum’s theory: “Since everything has gone so digital, I think people are becoming more interested in physical objects”), which led to a weekly column (she recalls the one on snow globes, which involved an interview with the actor Corbin Bernsen, with particular fondness) and then to this weekend’s special “Who Made That?” Innovations Issue.

headline: Pedro Almodovar: Intro
text: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the filmmaker Pedro Almodovar and the cast of his film, “I’m So Excited!”

headline: In Istanbul’s Heart, Leader’s Obsession, Perhaps Achilles’ Heel
text: ISTANBUL — On a normal day, Taksim Square is a mess of buses and crowds, a tangle of plazas, streets, shops and taxi horns. Turkey’s prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is determined to clean it up and make it into a pedestrian zone, with a new mall, mosque and tunnels for traffic to move underground.

headline: Errani and Vinci Return to Women’s Doubles Final
text: Sara Errani endured a humiliating afternoon Thursday, but Friday’s women’s doubles semifinals gave her a chance at redemption. With Roberta Vinci, she enjoyed a 6-3, 5-7, 6-3 win over third-seeded Nadia Petrova and Katarina Srebotnik, putting the Italians in the French Open final for the second year running.

headline: Aiming for the Hybrid’s Sweet Spot
text: Berkeley, Calif. — Using electricity as an automotive fuel, to most Americans, seems as alien as powering a car by Higgs bosons. Electricity, they’d say, might be fine for fueling exotic sport machines made by California start-ups — or for tiny Japanese mobility pods — but not the family sedans of America’s highways.

headline: Making a Mountain Out of a Digital Molehill
text: ATLANTA — THE revelations this week that the federal government has been scooping up records of telephone calls inside the United States for seven years, and secretly collecting information from Internet companies on foreigners overseas for nearly six years, have elicited predictable outrage from liberals and civil libertarians.

headline: Great Range, but Doesn’t Travel Well
text: The Ford Fusion Energi and Honda Accord Plug-In Hybrid could have been satisfying to mainstream consumers. But their pipsqueak trunks kill the deal.

headline: Redefining ‘Under the Influence’ in Colorado
text: DENVER — With the recreational use of marijuana now legal in Colorado, officers who patrol the state’s roads face a new set of challenges. Though smoking or possessing small amounts of cannabis is no longer breaking the law, anyone who drives while impaired is still subject to arrest.

headline: Claramae Turner, 92, Singer and Heart of a Song
text: Renowned for her lustrous voice, Claramae Turner sang more than 100 times with the Metropolitan Opera. But she is best known — or, more precisely, best unknown — for having introduced “I Left My Heart in San Francisco,” the sentimental ballad indelibly associated with Tony Bennett.

headline: Where Rehab Meets Reality
text: Around dusk on Feb. 17, Dr. Drew Pinsky was sitting at the computer in his hillside home in Pasadena, Calif., when he received an e-mail from a friend with some troubling news. Mindy McCready, a 37-year-old country singer and a star of the third season of “Celebrity Rehab with Dr. Drew,” a television show that made its debut on VH1 in 2008, had shot herself at her house in Heber Springs, Ark.

headline: Gunman Kills 4 in California Before He Is Killed
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Four people were killed and five wounded on Friday morning as a gunman, dressed in black and carrying an assault rifle, strode across Santa Monica firing at people, cars, a public bus and buildings before being shot and killed by the police at the Santa Monica College Library, the authorities said.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Istanbul, Germany and Nepal.

headline: TimesTalks | Pedro Almodovar: Preview
text: The director discusses his comedy “I’m So Excited!,” and explores the use of music and sexuality in his films.

headline: Ex-Leader of Planned Mosque Near Ground Zero Settles Suit With Donor
text: The former leader of a proposed Muslim community center and mosque near ground zero in Lower Manhattan has settled a lawsuit in which a donor accused him of spending charitable contributions on himself, both sides confirmed on Friday.

headline: Staten Island Ferry, 1:15 P.M.
text: N.Y. See: A view of Lower Manhattan from the Staten Island Ferry during a steady rainfall.

headline: Russians Dreaming in French
text: After its early dominance of international film production was shattered by World War I, France never quite managed to sustain a studio system on the Hollywood industrial model. What the French achieved instead was an artisanal cinema built around independent producers, several of whom — like Adolphe Osso in the 1930s, André Paulvé in the ’50s and Anatole Dauman in the ’60s and ’70s — had tastes pronounced enough to establish identities for their firms. These maisons de production functioned more like book publishers than dream factories, attracting a certain kind of talent for individual productions rather than putting rosters of stars and filmmakers under contract for a steady stream of releases.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Hyperloop Theories and N.S.A. Surveillance
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: They’re Jumping Through Hoops, Dreamily
text: There are at least two kinds of lava in the world, and both move. One is the bubbling, molten rock expelled by a volcano; another is LAVA, Sarah East Johnson’s all-female, environmentally conscious company, which mixes dance and acrobatics.

headline: The Dancing Life, Condensed
text: Headlong Dance Theater, a Philadelphia company, has never existed under a set of choreographic rules. Formed 20 years ago by David Brick, Andrew Simonet and Amy Smith (though Mr. Simonet left last year), the group has staged works in hotel swimming pools, explored the cult of Britney Spears and constructed a performance journey for one audience member at a time led by a cellphone.

headline: Sooner Than Expected, CBS Largely Finishes Upfront Sales
text: A second big English-language broadcast television network, CBS, has just about wrapped up its sales of commercial time ahead of the 2013-14 season in what is known as the upfront market.

headline: The Tinkling of the Keys, the Slapping of the Thighs
text: Jazz musicians use their physical presence all the time in projecting an artistic persona, although it’s usually conveying muted concentration or communion, enveloping their instrument or listening to another’s with laser focus. Not too many jazz musicians in recent decades come close to physical comedy when they perform, as Fats Waller and Louis Armstrong did. There have been the Dutch players who poke fun at jazz convention with critical remove: Han Bennink and Misha Mengelberg and Willem Breuker. And then there’s Stefano Bollani, who isn’t much like any of them.

headline: Four Classical Composers, Caught in Love Affairs With Popular Music
text: The season-ending program of 20th-century music that the Riverside Symphony and its music director, George Rothman, presented at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night was well thought out, smart and illuminating. Snazzy, too.

headline: All Aboard for a Writer’s Views on His Adopted Homeland
text: MILAN — “That’s very strange,” Tim Parks, the polymath writer, said recently, waiting at the top of an escalator at the Porta Garibaldi train station in Milan. “Your train didn’t even appear on the board.”

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 7
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

headline: President Obama on The Daily Show
text: In an Oct. 18, 2012, interview on Comedy Central’s “The Daily Show,” President Obama talked about how his wiretapping policies differ from those from the Bush era.

headline: Putin Aide Denies Divorce Is Driven by a Relationship
text: MOSCOW — A spokesman for President Vladimir V. Putin took the unusual step on Friday of announcing publicly that Mr. Putin is not in a romantic relationship, trying to quiet speculation that he and his wife of 29 years are divorcing to allow him to remarry.

headline: The Trial to Select USA-1 Bermuda Team
text: The 120-board final of the open trial to select the USA-1 Bermuda Bowl team will finish on Saturday. The match is John Kranyak, Gavin Wolpert, Kevin Bathurst and Kevin Dwyer versus Martin Fleisher, Michael Kamil, Zia Mahmood, Chip Martel, Michael Rosenberg and Chris Willenken.

headline: Kendall Jenner, a Sister Who Does More Than Keep Up
text: Kendall Jenner seemed stilted, perhaps because she was being aggressively managed.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 7
text: More photographs.

headline: Pussy Riot Takes Manhattan, Quietly
text: If there is ignominy in being anonymous at the premiere of your own movie, the ladies of Pussy Riot didn’t show it. There they were, without their trademark bright balaclavas, sitting at the back of the Landmark Sunshine Cinema on the Lower East Side on Wednesday evening, awaiting the showing of an HBO documentary called “Pussy Riot: A Punk Prayer.”

headline: Movie Review: 'Wish You Were Here'
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Wish You Were Here."

headline: An Arab Cartoonist in Motion
text: Khalid Albaih’s cartoons have become a symbol for uprisings across the Arab world. Watch how he does them.

headline: Setting New Coordinates
text: Three years ago, Christopher J. Raxworthy, an associate curator of vertebrate biology at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, ventured to Madagascar in its rainy season to pursue his interest in chameleons. His account of that field expedition was the start of the Scientist at Work blog, and the first of many tales from the field told in words, photos and video by an array of adventurous and determined scientists.

headline: Foreclosure Is New Blow to Nashville Symphony
text: For a while, the Nashville Symphony Orchestra seemed to have everything going for it. After a triumphant Carnegie Hall debut in 2000, it began to make compact discs prolifically, winning a handful of Grammys and a reputation for its championship of contemporary American music along the way. And it opened a sumptuous new concert hall, the 1,844 seat, $123 million Schermerhorn Symphony Center, in 2006.

headline: President Obama on Surveillance
text: President Obama clip from June 7 discussing government surveillance.

headline: Cartoons Seen Across the Arab World
text: Khalid Albaih’s illustrations have captured the politics of his native Sudan as well as developments across the rest of the Arab world, where his work has inspired even more tumult.

headline: All in Harmony
text: As the New York Philharmonic’s orchestra personnel manager, Carl R. Schiebler keeps rehearsals running on time, tracks down substitutes and serves as fixer. Mr. Schiebler, 75, was the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra’s second hornist and later its personnel manager before coming to the Philharmonic in 1986. When he is not taking care of one of his 106 orchestra members, Mr. Schiebler splits his time between his apartment on the Upper West Side and Pleasantville, N.Y., where he lives with his wife, Noriko Whyte, a pianist and music teacher.

headline: A Look Nicer Than the Name
text: Welcome to the summer of the rash guard. If you don’t already own one of these surfer mainstays, you probably will soon. And (unlike in summers past) it will be cute.

headline: Cartoonist’s Pen Leaves Mark Across Arab World
text: DOHA, Qatar — THERE are many players in a protest — the sign makers, the rabble rousers, the logisticians. And then there are the political cartoonists, who sketch the events unfolding on the streets and, if they are like Khalid Albaih, inspire even more tumult.

headline: As Criticism Grows, Curtailing Surveillance Program Seems Unlikely
text: WASHINGTON — New revelations about the scope of government surveillance elicited some bipartisan criticism in Congress on Friday, but beyond the bluster, prospects for a legislative response to curtail monitoring of Internet and telephone communications appear remote.

headline: The ‘I Dos,’ Unplugged
text: The attendant was stationed at the front door of my friend Michael’s wedding. “The ceremony is in the chapel,” she said to the arriving guests. “The ragtime band will be playing in the courtyard. The mini-cheeseburgers and lobster rolls will be served under the tent.

headline: President Obama on Wiretapping in 2005
text: In 2005, President Obama, then a U.S. Senator, spoke about wiretapping.

headline: Movie Review: 'The Internship'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Internship."

headline: Student Social Climbing, but on an Indoor Bike
text: Like many college students, Madeleine Rosuck spent much of her first year at the University of Texas in pursuit of a good party. She road-tripped with 19 sorority sisters for a spring break beachside bacchanal, hit the weekend-long blur of fraternity parties known as Roundup — and panted through five classes a week at Cyc, an indoor cycling gym in Austin.

headline: Where Angry Children Stomp, and Pop Has a Strut
text: Bit by bit, to marvelous effect, the choreography of the Broadway musical “Matilda” becomes central to the whole production. Most of its characters are caricatures. Their movement takes that caricaturish quality and makes it vivid in terms of rhythm, gesture and formal dance steps.

headline: Worship, Austin Style
text: Sunday services at Vox Veniae, a Protestant church in Austin, Tex., feature a six-piece band and volunteer baristas. The 200-member congregation reflects the eclectic city.

headline: Need a Theater? Broadway Vacancies Are Up
text: In a weak Broadway season defined by unusually long vacancies, the St. James Theater looked as if it finally had a new booking this spring, as posters for a Raymond Carver play went up on the marquee.

headline: Standing Above the Cookie Crowd
text: The word from Venice, and the 55th go-round of the world’s oldest biennial of contemporary art, is that the hotshot young curator Massimiliano Gioni has a hit on his hands: “a quiet success,” the New York Times critic Holland Cotter wrote, that was largely achieved through a refreshing approach of mixing — desegregating, if you will — outsider and insider artists.

headline: Live Streaming: TimesTalks With Pedro Almodóvar
text: ArtsBeat streamed Friday night’s conversation with the Spanish director Pedro Almodóvar, whose latest film, “I’m So Excited,” opens June 28. The conversation, at TheTimesCenter in Manhattan, was moderated by Lorne Manly, a New York Times journalist.

headline: A Le Corbusier Rooftop Gets a New Life as an Arts Space
text: One of the greatest achievements of the pioneering architect and urbanist Le Corbusier is Cité Radieuse, an extensive apartment complex in Marseille, France, which he completed in the early 1950s. Often described as a “vertical village,” it has 337 apartments, a restaurant, a hotel, a bookstore and a nursery school. France classified it as a historical monument in the 1980s. When the building’s rooftop gym and solarium went up for sale in 2010, the French designer Ito Morabito, who goes by Ora-Ito professionally, purchased it as a collector might. “Like you buy a piece of art, but architecture,” he explained.

headline: Breaking the Evangelical Mold at a Church With Ethnic Roots
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Last Sunday at Vox Veniae, a 200-person church in working-class East Austin, the volunteer baristas showed up an hour before worship services to make locally sourced coffee in the vaunted Chemex system, beloved of connoisseurs. To enhance the java-snob appeal, no milk or sugar was provided. “It’s a purist thing,” one barista said.

headline: Promoter Is Charged in Radiohead Stage Collapse
text: The Ontario Ministry of Labor has brought charges against Live Nation Canada for safety violations in connection with the stage collapse at an outdoor Radiohead concert last year that killed the band’s drum technician, Scott Johnson, and injured three other workers, The Toronto Star reported on Friday.

headline: Friday Night Music: Zaz
text: We Americans, we are an insular people. A European suggested that I might like Isabelle Geffroy, and when I looked up her performances I discovered that she has a huge multinational following — but none of my usual music sources here had even heard of her.

headline: Comparing Two Secret Surveillance Programs
text: The targets and types of data collected by the two government programs recently revealed.

headline: Gaza Farmers Near Fence With Israel Remain Wary
text: WADI GAZA, Gaza Strip — About 185 yards from the fence that separates Gaza from Israel, 300 rows of green chili pepper plants are sprouting on farmland that lay barren for years.

headline: A Season’s Last Concert Restores a Work’s Lost Passages
text: For all the sturdy proclamations and occasional bluster in Mendelssohn’s “Reformation” Symphony, the real drama occurs at moments when intense dynamism yields to blessed simplicity. Thomas Crawford, the founder and music director of the period-instrument American Classical Orchestra, made the most of one of those crucial junctures on Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall in the last concert of the ensemble’s 28th season but, by his own choice, pretty much missed another.

headline: A Much-Anticipated Recital, Sans Shoes
text: The defining mission of Le Poisson Rouge, the popular Greenwich Village club and cabaret, is to present all kinds of contemporary music. On successive nights you can hear an indie rock band, a jazz singer or a string quartet playing Xenakis.

headline: Retirement Risks of Bonds
text: Conventional wisdom says people should hold more bonds as they age. But ultralow interest rates have left many would-be retirees with a big problem: the chance that they will exhaust their bond portfolios before they die. The outlook is worse for people who retire earlier and withdraw more. Adding stocks to a portfolio increases the risk of big losses, but it also reduces the risk that you’ll outlive your money.

headline: Obama on Drones
text: President Obama talks about drones.

headline: Waving My Tweak Flag High
text: In my years of writing and performing songs I’ve come to realize that small, even accidental, lyric changes can greatly improve (or screw up) a song. Sometimes I notice it in my own songs; an accident of vocal delivery on stage one night might turn a light bulb on and then remain an integral part of a song forever, leaving me to lament that my officially released album recording is weaker than the currently performed version.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 7
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a scene in the South Bronx, a music hall in Hoboken, N.J., and a tribute to Senator Frank R. Lautenberg.

headline: What to Watch on Day 14 of the French Open
text: And then there were two. The top two. For the fourth time this year, it will be No. 1 vs. No. 2, with all three previous meetings won by the No. 1. Will Saturday’s French Open women’s singles final break that trend on Saturday? Unlikely.

Developing New Antibiotics

headline: 57 Years in the House

text: To the Editor:
