text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Drone Strike Kills at Least 7 in Pakistan as New Prime Minister Announces Cabinet
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least seven people were killed late Friday when an American drone fired three missiles at a house in northwestern Pakistan, according to an intelligence official, hours after the country’s new prime minister announced his cabinet.

headline: Golfing in Cape Breton
text: The Times photographer Piotr Redlinski explores the rugged landscape of Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, in a series of images from local golf courses.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Tails, You Win
text: Short in front, long in back: some people call it indecision; others, the best of two worlds.

headline: Restaurant Chains Try to Woo a Younger Generation
text: From sun-dried tomato wraps to agave-sweetened smoothies, restaurant chains are working to court an exceptionally particular generation — the millennials.

headline: Martian Rock Another Clue to a Once Water-Rich Planet
text: The discovery of what appears to be a clay-rich rock on Mars adds to the portrait of the planet as one that once — in its youth, more than three and a half billion years ago — was a water-rich world with conditions amenable for life, NASA scientists said Friday.

headline: Safety Agency Shuts Down Discount Bus Line
text: Passengers who paid $15 to ride Lucky Star buses between Chinatown in Manhattan and Boston were apparently lucky that they or their luggage did not fall onto Interstate 95 at high speed.

headline: Pierre Mauroy, Socialist Who Led Changes in France, Dies at 84
text: PARIS — Pierre Mauroy, who as France’s first Socialist prime minister since the beginning of the Fifth Republic in 1958 pushed through some of the Socialist Party’s most important overhauls, died on Friday in a hospital near Paris. He was 84.

headline: David Simon, Creator of ‘The Wire,’ Debates N.S.A. Surveillance With Readers of His Blog
text: David Simon, the former reporter behind the television drama “The Wire,” which President Obama calls “one of the greatest shows of all time,” came to the defense of his embattled fan on Friday, suggesting in a long post on his blog that “the national eruption over the rather inevitable and understandable collection of all raw data involving telephonic and Internet traffic by Americans” was misguided.

headline: Get Ready to Watch Some Big Destruction
text: Here’s something fun to do Sunday morning. Get up early and watch a building be imploded in your pajamas. That is — watch it in your pajamas. The building is not in your pajamas. It is on Governors Island.

headline: Splits Appear in Policy ‘Troika’ Addressing Europe’s Financial Crisis
text: BRUSSELS — After a series of nightlong crisis meetings on Cyprus, the European Union’s economic policy chief, Olli Rehn, remarked that his wife had started complaining that he spent more time with Christine Lagarde, the head of the International Monetary Fund, than with her.

headline: She Rode Horses, Drove an S.U.V. and, the Authorities Say, Farmed Marijuana
text: There were many mornings, the authorities say, when a gray Mercedes GL4 S.U.V. pulled out from a driveway on a wooded street in Scarsdale, N.Y., and cruised through the Bronx before ending up inside an ugly, brick-face building in an industrial stretch of Queens.

headline: More Space, and a Bigger Menu, Too
text: Modern, New Rochelle’s beloved pizza joint, moved this past winter from cramped quarters to a lofty space that was first a car showroom and later a restaurant supply store. As recorded on various social media sites, loyal patrons were variously elated and scandalized. But no one can dispute that the new home of this Italian-American emporium — with its vaulted ceiling, giant arched windows and granite floor — is a knockout.

headline: Scam Suspects Become the Victims
text: The scam’s elaborate setup began Monday afternoon with a simple question on a Chinatown sidewalk, and built itself up in a series of seemingly chance encounters and grave predictions. Grave in tone, but also as in coming from a dead person below ground.

headline: Homey Ambience, and a Changing Menu
text: Picador, on Elm Street in New Canaan, may succeed where previous occupants of its tiny space have failed over the years. This new 31-seat restaurant, which opened around Thanksgiving, is minute, but charming, like dining in a private home, with copper tabletops, several framed wall mirrors, carriage lamps, and a banquette along the end wall piled with big puffy cushions. One wall is decorated with a display of colorful Spanish ceramic plates.

headline: Summer Shades of White and Rosé
text: GIVEN THE NUMBER OF TASTERS last month at Brooklyn Uncorked, where only Long Island wines are sampled, vintners on the Island might expect a flood of summer visitors.

headline: Choice for U.N. Post Gets Israeli Vote of Confidence
text: WASHINGTON — Samantha Power, President Obama’s choice to be the next ambassador to the United Nations, is encountering resistance from pro-Israel groups for remarks she once made about Israel and the Palestinians. But on Friday, she got an unexpected vote of confidence from Israel’s representative in the United States.

headline: Flavors of the Andes, Everywhere
text: Corn is not only a staple of the food at Cuzco Peru in Lynbrook, but it also finds its way into one of the soft drinks: chicha morada, made from purple corn here flavored with citrus juice, cinnamon and tiny cubes of apple.

headline: Joey Covington, Rock Drummer, Dies at 67
text: Joey Covington, a drummer for the psychedelic rock band Jefferson Airplane in the early 1970s and a founding member of their bluesy spinoff Hot Tuna, died on Tuesday. He was 67.

headline: Don’t Forsake the Gray Wolf
text: KETCHUM, Idaho — IT has been celebrated as one of the great victories of the Endangered Species Act of 1973. After several decades of federal protection, gray wolves — once nearly wiped out in the continental United States — have reached a population of roughly 6,100 across three Great Lakes states and seven Western states.

headline: Expansive Space, Portions and Flavors
text: To visit the sprawling Ria Mar Restaurant and Bar is to step into a holiday of plenty: a vast restaurant with two separate dining areas; a sea of tables; endless plastic pitchers of sangria; poster-size pictures; and a wave-shaped installation covering an entire wall in both rooms.

headline: With Little Time Before Election, Senate Race in New Jersey Begins to Take Shape
text: The candidates for United States Senate in New Jersey have not even all declared themselves, but with a deadline to file petitions looming on Monday, the shape of the race to succeed Frank R. Lautenberg is already coming into view.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: For a Street Festival, Hats On!
text: THE ORGANIZERS OF THE INAUGURAL Hat City Streets Festival, to be held June 15 in Orange, hope no one shows up to the free daylong event bareheaded.

headline: But for the Bloody Hands, a Fine Lad Indeed
text: WOMEN LOVE BAD BOYS, they say. But in J. M. Synge’s timeless comedy “The Playboy of the Western World,” a whole village falls in love with one — a young man who staggers through the pub door one evening and soon confesses that he has killed his father.

headline: Cicada Sex: All Together Now
text: As part of the World Science Festival, the Staten Island Museum celebrated its insect collection with a night of drinks, art, music and conversation inspired by the mating strategies of bugs.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: In Bosnia, a Protest Over IDs Traps Hundreds in Parliament
text: It was a decidedly Balkan revolt and a rare explosion of people power in one of Europe’s poorest and most ethnically divided countries.

headline: Christie, at G.O.P. Event, Finds Many Unburned Bridges
text: PARK CITY, Utah — Gov. Chris Christie addressed Mitt Romney’s financial inner circle on Friday, and the most telling moment may have been the question-and-answer session that followed: No one brought up the hug.

headline: Kentucky and New York Make Storied Rivals and Partners
text: Perhaps the lone uncontested aspect of the sport of thoroughbred racing in America is that its history and its future are rooted in the states of Kentucky and New York. Their longstanding competition that will gain a new chapter with Saturday’s Belmont Stakes.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: United States automakers kept up strong sales, Boeing’s 787s returned to the air in Japan, and Wal-Mart shareholders gathered under the cloud of a bribery scandal.

headline: An Invasion of 17-Year-Olds, Loud, Lusty and Six-Legged
text: There are a few acts of nature, such as the passage of Halley’s comet or the transit of Venus, that are so rare and so dramatic as to seem like metaphors for the virtues of patience itself. But of all of these, the arrival of the 17-year cicadas, the noisy insects that nestled under the earth for that length of time and recently awakened by the millions to spawn, may be the grossest.

headline: An Enchanted Evening Open to Possibilities
text: Even before the cute siblings sing their playful “Dites-Moi,” and before the American nurse and the French plantation owner tenderly embark on their romance, the production of “South Pacific” at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport exudes a sense of open-ended possibilities. The simple but elegant set designed by Josh Zangen does it, with four hanging, slatted panels evoking airy Pacific island architecture, and four rattan-like borders framing the stage, one behind the other.

headline: A South Korean Stays in the Fairway and in Front
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Continuing rain on Friday did not bother Chella Choi of South Korea, who took a one-shot lead at five-under 67 in the first round of the L.P.G.A. Championship.

headline: Richard Ramirez, the ‘Night Stalker’ Killer, Dies at 53
text: Richard Ramirez, who claimed to be inspired by Satan when he killed at least 14 people in the “Night Stalker” attacks that terrorized California in 1985, died on Friday in a hospital in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 53.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: The Plan to Change Taksim Square
text: In response to a plan by Turkey’s prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, for a pedestrian zone, the square has become a stage for clashing worldviews.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 7, 2013

headline: Dr. J’s Slam Dunk
text: Julius Erving, known as Dr. J, was a basketball legend in the A.B.A. and then the N.B.A. when the leagues merged in 1976. A new documentary about his life, called “The Doctor,” will air on NBA TV.

headline: Tech Companies Concede to Surveillance Program
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When government officials came to Silicon Valley to demand easier ways for the world’s largest Internet companies to turn over user data as part of a secret surveillance program, the companies bristled. In the end, though, many cooperated at least a bit.

headline: Fifes and Drums as Performance Art
text: Social practice is a relatively new term for art that puts less emphasis on objects made for individual contemplation and more energy into projects involving participation, activism or community organizing. Of course, plenty of artists were making art like this before critics and scholars christened it “social practice.” One such artist is Allison Smith, whose exhibition “Allison Smith: Rudiments of Fife and Drum” combines elements of craft, performance and participation and is currently on view at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn.

headline: In This Sport, Beware of Left Hooks, Jabs and Castling
text: The title highlights a contradiction, pairing an intellectual activity in which the combatants never touch and a combat sport in which opponents aim fists at each other’s chins. There is chess. There is boxing. And then there is chessboxing.

headline: Video and Images From Scene of Santa Monica Shooting Spree
text: The shooting spree in Santa Monica, Calif., on Friday, which left four people and the gunman dead, began on Yorkshire Avenue, where the Fire Department responded at 11:52 a.m. to a report of a structure fire, officials said.

headline: News of U.S. Surveillance Draws Anger of Activists and Militants Abroad
text: Mohamed al-Hadi, an antigovernment activist in Syria, had just received a Skype briefing from rebels about the Ming military airport near the northern city of Aleppo, a protracted battleground in the country’s civil war. Then he learned that the United States government had the ability to monitor that call, as well as a broad range of other information transmitted through the Internet.

headline: Weather Muddles Belmont Outlook
text: There will be no Triple Crown on the line for the 145th running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday and perhaps very little sunshine thanks to Tropical Storm Andrea. But there will be plenty on the line as the Kentucky Derby winner Orb has a chance to avenge his loss to Oxbow in the Preakness Stakes.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 8, 2013
text: “Nobody is listening to your telephone calls.”

headline: Administration Says Mining of Data Is Crucial to Fight Terror
text: WASHINGTON — In early September 2009, an e-mail passed through an Internet address in Peshawar, Pakistan, that was being monitored by the vast computers controlled by American intelligence analysts. It set off alarms. The address, linked to senior Qaeda operatives, had been dormant for months.

headline: The Senate vs. the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court
text: Four senators wrote a letter to the court asking it to provide summaries of its opinions on domestic spying, but the court resisted.  Here is the letter from the senators and the response from the court.

headline: Congress Can Stop Privacy Abuse
text: Over the last three years, several measures were introduced in Congress that would have helped reduce or eliminate the abuses of communications surveillance revealed this week. Every one of them was voted down.

headline: The I.M.F. Admits Mistakes. Will Europe?
text: The International Monetary Fund admitted this week that it made big errors in the first bailout of Greece three years ago, but it added that no matter what it did then the country would have suffered a deep recession. European Union officials, by contrast, still refuse to concede that their handling of the financial crisis has been deeply flawed.

headline: Many Rival Nations Surge Past the U.S. in Adding New Jobs
text: The American economy may be the world’s biggest, but when it comes to job creation since the recession hit at the end of 2007, it is far from a leader.

headline: What’s All the Fuss About Bikes?
text: New Yorkers will tolerate almost anything, including obvious inconveniences like overcrowded subways. Why, then, all the anxiety and hyperventilating over something that is indisputably a good thing: the short-term bicycle rentals that have become available in parts of the city?

headline: Happy Belmont Day
text: Saturday is not a particularly noteworthy day in my life; no birthdays or anniversaries to commemorate, no real attached significance at all.

headline: Racial Injustice in North Carolina
text: The North Carolina Legislature repealed the state’s Racial Justice Act this week, and the Republican governor, Pat McCrory, is expected to sign the bill. But the state cannot erase the detailed and irrefutable proof of ugly racial bias that led a state trial judge to resentence four death row inmates to life without parole because of this statute.

headline: Collegial Charcuterie
text: Swine, a pork-based place at 531 Hudson Street in the West Village, is one of those establishments that pack a full menu of gastronomic trends into a fashionably monosyllabic name. On the one hand, the owners of the year-old restaurant have described it as a neighborhood dive and, indeed, there is a pinball machine beside the bar and a vintage Ping-Pong table in the basement playfully reclaimed for communal dining. On the other hand, the fare tends toward artisanal charcuterie and small-production wines. The clientele is similarly varied, including, on a recent evening, some European tourists, a liquor distributor and his date, and a group of seven lawyers who had dropped by to visit one of the proprietors, Cris Criswell, who, until three months ago, was working at their firm.

headline: Corrections: June 8, 2013
text: SPORTS

headline: Trix Alternative
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I must be getting better at these things. I felt this was one of the easiest Saturday puzzles I’ve done in a while.

headline: Nuclear Power Plant in Limbo Decides to Close
text: The owners of the San Onofre nuclear power plant in Southern California, which has been shut since January 2012, said on Friday that they would close it permanently because of uncertainty over when it could be reopened.

headline: At Murder Trial, Jurors Hear of Turbulent Relationship
text: There were a few things about her younger boyfriend that Sylvie Cachay thought needed to change.

headline: Obama and Xi Tackle Cybersecurity as Talks Begin in California
text: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — President Obama, midway through much-anticipated weekend talks with President Xi Jinping of China, said Friday night that there was no parallel between the cyberattacks on American businesses and government interests that it blames on China and the United States government’s surveillance of phone and Internet traffic to foil terrorists.

headline: Spurs’ Stinginess With the Ball Draws Generous Attention Before Game 2
text: MIAMI — The first possession of the N.B.A. finals went exactly the way the Miami Heat had hoped, with Tim Duncan forced into a turnover that resulted in a fast-break dunk for Dwyane Wade.

headline: Intelligence for Dummies
text: Question for the day: Do you feel more secure or less secure, now that you know the government is keeping a gargantuan pile of information about everybody’s telephone calls in the name of national security?

headline: ‘A Giant Among Pygmies’
text: For 40 years, Joe Durso, 58, has been strutting and fretting upon the Seaside Courts next to the Boardwalk in Coney Island, the mecca of one-wall handball, and a place that claims Mr. Durso as perhaps its greatest and most frustrated player.

headline: How to Monetize Plagiarism
text: This is a column about Jonah Lehrer, the 31-year-old disgraced former New Yorker writer who recently — sigh — landed a contract for a book about love. (Yes, love.) But I want to start by recalling another disgraced former magazine writer: Stephen Glass.

headline: China: Arrests in Poultry Factory Fire
text: Officials in Jilin Province have made two arrests in the investigation of a poultry factory fire that killed at least 120 people and injured at least 77 others this week, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency. One of the men arrested was Jia Yushan, owner and president of Baoyuanfeng, the poultry processing company. The second man arrested was Zhang Yushen, the general manager. The company’s bank account and the assets of Mr. Jia have been frozen, and the factory’s license has been revoked, according to the Xinhua report, which was published Thursday. Survivors of the fire described encountering locked doors that prevented many people from escaping. The factory had been hailed in recent years as a model enterprise by local officials, but the deadly accident underscored the lack of rigorous safety inspections by officials.

headline: Of Slippery Slopes
text: Maybe I’m a bit pessimistic when it comes to governmental paternalism and the unrelenting erosion of civil liberties, but I’ve always assumed that someone or something — including the government — is tracking, or could track, everything I do in an increasing virtual reality.

headline: Mets Add Another Game to Their Growing To-Do List
text: Be it subfreezing temperatures, heavy snow or hammering rains, the Mets have faced Mother Nature’s worst this season.

headline: Peru: Ex-President Is Denied a Pardon
text: President Ollanta Humala said Friday that he had decided not to grant a pardon to former President Alberto Fujimori, who is serving a prison sentence for human rights violations and corruption. Mr. Fujimori, left, has tongue cancer and other health problems; his family had requested the pardon in October, saying it was justified for medical reasons. Mr. Humala, who ran against Mr. Fujimori’s eldest daughter, Keiko Fujimori, when he was elected in 2011, said that he reviewed material from doctors who examined Mr. Fujimori and took into account the nature of the former president’s crimes. A presidential commission had previously recommended against giving Mr. Fujimori a pardon. Mr. Fujimori was president from 1990 to 2000, when he led a successful fight against the Shining Path guerrilla group. In 2009 he was sentenced to 25 years in prison for overseeing death squads involved in two massacres that killed a total of 25 people.

headline: Bike Share’s One-Track App
text: Ah, to ride a bike through the streets of New York! The wind in your hair, a stench in your nose, the invigorating fear that your legs will give out, causing you to tumble backward down the steep slope of the Williamsburg Bridge.

headline: The Blackhawks’ Bickell Outperforms Star Teammates
text: LOS ANGELES — When the Chicago Blackhawks won the Stanley Cup in 2010, left wing Bryan Bickell did not meet N.H.L. requirements to have his name etched on the trophy. Should Chicago win the Cup in 2013, he might also see his name hammered onto the Conn Smythe Trophy, awarded to the player judged most valuable to his team during the playoffs.

headline: Ex-Councilman in Capital Is Charged With Bribery
text: WASHINGTON — A former city councilor was charged with bribery on Friday after being accused of accepting cash from federal agents posing as business owners, rekindling attention to a long-simmering corruption inquiry of the District of Columbia government.

headline: Biking to Work, and Around It
text: When Governors Island opened for the season last month, it meant a change of schedule for Leslie Koch: Until the island closes at the end of September, she works weekends, bicycling to the free ferry, then touring the island’s 172 acres on pedal power. Ms. Koch, 51, is the president of the Trust for Governors Island, a nonprofit organization created by the city in 2010. She never knows what she’ll find on her rounds. “If someone’s carrying something odd,” she said, “you just say it’s an art project, and usually you’re right.” She lives in a brownstone in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, with her husband, Douglas Grey, who produces entertainment for cruise ships, and an English golden retriever named Clara.

headline: Teixeira Is Making Life Easier for Cano at the Plate
text: SEATTLE — It wasn’t long after Robinson Cano slapped hands with Mark Teixeira at home plate after a three-run homer Thursday night that Teixeira turned his attention to the pitcher and followed with a blast of his own.

headline: Roll Tape, Curtain Up
text: The Theater on Film and Tape Archive tapes about 50 Broadway, Off Broadway and regional theater performances each year.

headline: After the Final Curtain, Act II
text: On a recent Thursday evening, a blue-and-white GMC motor home with tinted windows was parked in front of the Stephen Sondheim Theater on West 43rd Street. Cables ran from it, up over the theater marquee, through a window, and down into the theater, where they plugged into three cameras set up to record the evening’s performance of “The Trip to Bountiful,” which has four Tony nominations heading into Sunday night’s awards ceremony.

headline: Want to Play at a Different College? O.K., but Not There or There
text: When a quarterback decided last month to transfer to another football program after one season at Oklahoma State, he thanked the coach, who thanked him back. Here were two parties seemingly in mutual agreement, on good terms, headed for an amicable divorce.

headline: The Secrets of Nadal’s Success
text: In 2011, Novak Djokovic solved the riddle of Rafael Nadal on all three surfaces, besting Nadal on clay (Rome finals), grass (a decisive four-set victory in the Wimbledon final) and on hard courts (another solid four setter at Flushing Meadow). Nadal looked at once beleaguered and confused by Djokovic’s technical and tactical mastery, as if stymied by the puzzle of how to solve the Djokovic problem. One of Nadal’s favorite words at news conferences is “solutions,” but he seemed at a loss for words when he tried to explain how he was losing Grand Slam finals to someone other than Roger Federer.

headline: The Hazards of Hecklers
text: Mark Leibovich on prominent and recent cases of political heckling, and the risks that come from engaging hostile interlopers.

headline: Obama on Surveillance, Then and Now
text: As a senator, Barack Obama was a critic of the Bush administration,  saying it cast a “false choice” between liberty and security. As he engages in his own surveillance efforts, he has spoken of finding a balance.

headline: Less Than a Fair Share
text: If you found yourself harboring skepticism or vague negativity toward the city’s newly initiated bike-sharing program, it is possible that you were suddenly moved to defend it after witnessing The Wall Street Journal’s recent video interview with Dorothy Rabinowitz, an editorial board member who spent four minutes making crazy-lady assertions about cycling’s hold on New York.

headline: The New Arab Brooklyn
text: The Arab population in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is the latest in a series of Arab enclaves appearing in New York City.

headline: A Little Korea in Queens
text: People strolling for the first time on Northern Boulevard in Queens could be forgiven for thinking they had somehow been magically transported to Seoul.

headline: Harriet Tubman’s Great Raid
text: It is arguably the most beautiful scene ever recorded in war. Two Union gunboats, the Harriet A. Weed and the John Adams, converted ferryboats, churning up the Combahee River with their big side paddlewheels. Steam whistles signal, while in the bow of the Adams, a small, powerful woman is… singing. From all around, hundreds hear Harriett Tubman’s call and run for the boats, for freedom. At least 727 men, women and children escape, mothers carrying babies, including one pair of twins: the largest liberation of slaves in American history.

headline: Little Guyana in Queens
text: No place has acquired as intense a Guyanese flavor as Liberty Avenue, the lively commercial corridor that divides Richmond Hill and South Ozone Park.

headline: As Bruins Reach Finals, Empty Feeling for Penguins
text: BOSTON — The way the game was going, with goals at an absolute premium, the first one, whenever it came, seemed destined to be the only one. And so it was.

headline: What’s on Bernanke’s Mind?
text: The Federal Reserve is closely watching the employment picture, as it considers when to pull back on its stimulus measures.

headline: Take the A Train to Little Guyana
text: Sri Lankans have gathered on Staten Island, Arabs in Brooklyn, Ghanaians in the Bronx: A guide to the new immigrant enclaves of New York City.

headline: After Brief Stumble, a Step Closer to Brazil
text: KINGSTON, Jamaica — The National Stadium here is nicknamed the Office, a place where the United States took care of business in stunning fashion on Friday night as frustration whipped into elation.

headline: Player Ratings: Jamaica 1, U.S. 2
text: Three World Cup qualifiers without a defeat — two wins and a draw — with two home games to come. With a possible six points from those two (Panama and Honduras), the United States can probably book its reservations for Brazil. Seems like a long way from the angst and hand-wringing after the first game in the Hex, a loss at Honduras.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (Nickelodeon) SAM & CAT Jennette McCurdy, who portrayed Sam Puckett on “iCarly,” and Ariana Grande, who played Cat Valentine in “Victorious,” team up in this crossover spinoff comedy about girls who meet cute in the back of a garbage truck, become best friends and roommates, and then go entrepreneurial with Sam & Cat’s Super Rockin’ Fun-Time Baby-Sitting Service. Above, from left, Cameron Ocasio, Ms. McCurdy and Ms. Grande in a scene from the show.

headline: China’s Export Growth Slows Amid Concern of Slowdown
text: HONG KONG — Chinese exports showed only modest growth in May, rising just 1 percent from a year earlier, officials said Saturday, an increase that was much lower than analysts’ expectations.

headline: 100 Percent of the Game Is Half Mental
text: I thought of a wonderful little article by Allen Fox, the former Pepperdine men’s tennis coach who played at the highest levels of the game and has since become the eminence grise of sports psychologists, as I watched the immensely likeable and charismatic Frenchman, Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, play David Ferrer on Friday in a men’s semifinal at the French Open. Fox recounts the 2000 Wimbledon final between Patrick Rafter and Pete Sampras. Like all of Fox’s writings, the difficult and painful truths that tennis exposes are laid out like a cadaver awaiting a scalpel. Fox describes how each player allows the score — and their emotions relating to that score — to influence how they play and, even more importantly, their level of motivation as they compete in the match.

headline: A Rain-Soaked Kickoff to the Governors Ball
text: The direst words on a concert ticket are “rain or shine.” They certainly were on Friday, the first of three days of the Governors Ball Music Festival on Randalls Island.

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 8
text: Europe’s reaction Friday to news of a sweeping international digital surveillance program by the U.S. government ranged from the outrage of citizens and politicians to the muted envy of some law enforcement agencies on this side of the Atlantic. Privacy is an emotional issue in Europe, where memories of state-sponsored snooping by communist and fascist regimes still linger. And so the revelation Thursday that the U.S. National Security Agency had obtained routine access to e-mail, Web searches and other online data from many of the biggest U.S. Internet companies — whose users stretch far beyond U.S. shores — prompted hand-wringing about America’s moral authority. “If the U.S. complains about foreign governments spying and then it turns out it is doing the same thing — well, what are you complaining about?” said Yaman Akdeniz, a law professor at Istanbul Bilgi University in Turkey, where anger over restrictions on civil liberties has fueled anti-government protests. Eric Pfanner reports from Serraval, France and James Kanter reports from Brussels.

headline: Two Mariners Catch Fire as Kuroda Melts Down
text: SEATTLE — With a mere 26 runs batted in entering Friday, Jason Bay and Brendan Ryan of the Seattle Mariners had fewer R.B.I. combined than three Yankees — Robinson Cano, Travis Hafner and Lyle Overbay — had individually. They were tied with Brett Gardner.

headline: Mandela Is Hospitalized Again, Deepening Worries Over Frailty
text: JOHANNESBURG — Former President Nelson Mandela of South Africa was hospitalized early Saturday to be treated for a recurring lung infection, the South African government said. It was the fourth time in less than a year that the 94-year-old anti-apartheid leader has been hospitalized, deepening concern about his increasing frailty.

headline: The Weekend Word: Surveillance
text: Today’s Times

headline: Serving Up Our 2013 Belmont Picks
text: The Rail’s contributors welcome this year’s Belmont Stakes guest picker, the celebrity chef and horse owner Bobby Flay. Flay, the original guest picker on The Rail, was honored Thursday night with the Earle I. Mack Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation Champion Award, given to an individual for outstanding efforts and influence on thoroughbred racehorse welfare, safety and retirement. Flay, a newly appointed board member of the New York Racing Association, has raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for thoroughbred retirement and is an outspoken proponent of owner responsibility to their horses.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: An Indian soldier was killed Friday in an incident of unprovoked firing from across the cease-fire line with Pakistan near the Poonch sector, about 110 miles southwest of the summer capital, Srinagar, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Big Data Is Watching You
text: A few days before the story broke about the National Security Agency mining the data of citizens using Verizon, I walked by a newsstand and saw an issue of Foreign Affairs that had a feature on Big Data. I bought it. When I got onto Metro North, the man across the aisle was reading a book, its title: “Big Data.” We were both reading print media, I thought to myself: No trace. Unless we paid with our credit cards? I checked my e-mail before diving into the feature in Foreign Affairs: An e-mail from a friend, telling me she had a story idea for me. About Big Data. No doubt, all the outraged electronic references so many of us are suddenly making back and forth to each other about Big Data (on Facebook, Twitter, etc.) are being mined by various private and governmental institutions, revealing, via syntax, frequency and context, not only how we’ll probably vote in 2016 but also what brand of hair conditioner we prefer.

headline: Urban Trees as Triggers, From Istanbul to Oregon
text: As street protests spread across Turkey following an initial clash between police and demonstrators over the imperiled sycamore trees of Gezi Park (a rare green patch in the sprawl of central Istanbul), I was reminded of “If a Tree Falls,” the fine Oscar-nominated documentary on the roots of the Earth Liberation Front (Dot Earth coverage).

headline: 3 Americans and an Italian Killed in Afghan Attacks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two American soldiers and an American civilian working with them were killed in a so-called insider attack on Saturday in Afghanistan, officials said. In a second attack on international forces, an Italian soldier was killed when a grenade was thrown at him.

headline: Depressing Draghi
text: A correspondent directs me, despairingly, to the last part of Mario Draghi’s latest press conference — and the correspondent is right, it does give cause for despair. Draghi is, after all, as smart and flexible an ECB president as we’re likely to get for a long time; quite possibly ever, because the euro might not last. Yet what he has to say about inflation manages to be wrong on multiple levels, and this kind of thing has to be damaging to ECB policy.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Williams Wins French Open Title
text: Serena Williams captured her most elusive title, beating Maria Sharapova, 6-4, 6-4, to win her second French Open title and her 16th Grand Slam title over all. Williams, 31, won 11 years to the day after her first title at Roland Garros and is the oldest French Open champion in the open era.

headline: Following Up on Poverty Coverage in The Times
text: I heard from many readers after I wrote last Sunday about The Times’s coverage of poverty. I’ve rarely received more feedback on a column, and I appreciate the many thoughtful comments and e-mails.

headline: Syrian Opposition to Sit Out Any Talks Unless Arms Are Sent, General Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Syrian opposition will not attend the proposed Geneva conference on the crisis in Syria unless rebel fighters receive new supplies of arms and ammunition, the top rebel military commander said Friday.

headline: Turkey Turns to Taksim
text: Michael Kimmelman examines why Istanbul's Taksim Square evolved into the urban fissure that is growing in Turkish society.

headline: Crisis Withdrawal Syndrome
text: Dean Baker complains, as he often does (and correctly so), about “reporting” on the fiscal outlook that reads a lot like editorializing — indeed, like a sponsored ad from Pete Peterson. But maybe he should show a bit of human sympathy: these guys are basically addicts trying to get off the stuff, and maybe it’s too much to expect them to go cold turkey.

headline: Early Leader in Polls Usually Wins New York Mayoral Primary
text: The early Democratic front-runner in recent New York City mayoral races has a near perfect record in going on to win the party’s nomination, according to an analysis of public opinion surveys conducted since 1989. If that pattern holds true in this year’s race, Speaker Christine C. Quinn of the City Council will very likely win the Democratic nomination in September. She has led in every primary poll conducted in 2013.

headline: U.S. and China Move Closer on North Korea, but Not on Cyberespionage
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — Even as they pledged to build “a new model” of relations, President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China ended two days of informal meetings here on Saturday moving closer on pressuring a nuclear North Korea and addressing climate change, but remaining sharply divided over cyberespionage and other issues that have divided the countries for years.

headline: Chinese Link 47 Deaths in Bus Blast to a Suicide
text: BEIJING — An unemployed man intent on killing himself set off an explosion that engulfed a bus in flames and killed 47 people in the southeastern city of Xiamen on Friday, according to reports on Saturday by state-run news organizations.

headline: Williams Rejoices, in French, After Winning 16th Grand Slam
text: PARIS — Serena Williams has tried to master French, as she has finally mastered the French Open again. So after she had served five aces in her last seven service points to beat Maria Sharapova, 6-4, 6-4, in Saturday’s final, and had gone down on her knees and put her head to the clay in celebration, Williams kept up her recent habit of making her postmatch remarks to the crowd in the local language.

headline: Largely Forgotten Champion, No Longer Dispassionate, Will Return as Host
text: WHITEFISH, Mont. — In the cedar dining room of Iron Horse Golf Club, David Graham sat with a glass of red wine and reminisced about his career, which included victories at the P.G.A. Championship and the United States Open. His eyes welled with tears as he talked about the illness that caused him to retire and forced him to confront his mortality.

headline: The Titles He Won, the Things They Lost
text: MIAMI — On the day he was hired as the Boston Celtics’ coach in May 1997, Rick Pitino had thick black hair, a swagger in his step and a pocket full of Ping-Pong balls stamped with Tim Duncan’s name.

headline: Variety: A Tasty Diagramless
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — I do love a good fruit salad, and that appears to be what Fred Piscop has in store for us today, especially in the southeast, where the sliced PEAR gets incorporated into a GRAPE ARBOR.

headline: U.S. Helps Allies Trying to Battle Iranian Hackers
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has begun helping Middle Eastern allies build up their defenses against Iran’s growing arsenal of cyberweapons, and will be doing the same in Asia to contain computer-network attacks from North Korea, according to senior American officials.

headline: For Retirees, a Million-Dollar Illusion
text: A MILLION dollars isn’t what it used to be.

headline: Zimmerman Trial, Opening This Week, Will Raise Complex Questions
text: Was it murder when George Zimmerman shot and killed Trayvon Martin? Or was it self-defense?

headline: When Presidential Words Led to Swift Action
text: WASHINGTON — These days it is hard to imagine a single presidential speech changing history.

headline: A Search for Answers
text: Cullen Finnerty, who won three national football titles, did not return from a fishing trip. Searchers found his body, but many questions remain.

headline: Questions Linger About Death of Former Quarterback
text: BALDWIN, Mich. — The search started the night of May 26, a Sunday, when Cullen Finnerty went missing in the woods here, amid towering white pines and shrubby scrub oak trees and owls and white-tailed deer. By Monday morning, helicopters circled overhead as cadaver dogs combed through the brush below.

headline: Booker Formally Declares Candidacy for Senate Seat
text: NEWARK — Cory A. Booker, who has built national celebrity from his perch as mayor of this beleaguered city, brought another of the state’s most famous political figures here on Saturday as he officially declared his campaign for United States Senate.

headline: Pound Your Fist if You Must, but Make Me Listen
text: This interview with  Paulett Eberhart, president and chief executive of CDI, an engineering and technology professional services firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Dumped by Mets, Perez Revives His Career as Mariner
text: SEATTLE — At the worst moment of his career, Oliver Perez swallowed hard, blinked several times to prevent tears from forming and told reporters what all ballplayers say, even if sometimes it’s hard to believe. He claimed he still loved the game.

headline: In a Position to Cement a Role for the U.S. Team
text: KINGSTON, Jamaica — There was no clock at the National Stadium, so Brad Evans had no idea that Friday’s taut World Cup qualifying match had extended into added time.

headline: Some Baby Steps on Money Funds
text: WHEN the Securities and Exchange Commission tried last year to safeguard investors in money market mutual funds, Mary L. Schapiro, its chairwoman at the time, ran into a buzz saw of opposition from industry lobbyists. Last week, Ms. Schapiro’s successor, Mary Jo White, tried her hand at bringing change to this $2.9 trillion market.

headline: White House Plays Down Data Program
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration tried Saturday to marshal new evidence in defense of its collection of private Internet and telephone data, arguing that a secret program called Prism is simply an “internal government computer system” designed to sort through court-supervised collection of data, and that Congress has been briefed 13 times on the programs since 2009.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: A New School Schedule?
text: Readers react to a proposal for a longer school year and day.

headline: Seeing the World as Your Stage
text: IN days past, if you were born in the United States, you generally worked for an American company and an American boss in an American city. Everyone you interacted with — from your favorite clients to the company that manufactured your office supplies — was American.

headline: Fixing the Digital Economy
text: TWO big trends in the world appear to contradict each other.

headline: Loving the Midwest
text: AFTER we moved to St. Louis in 2007, my husband joked that we were self-hating Midwesterners. He grew up in Indiana, I grew up in Ohio, we met in Washington, D.C., and we landed in St. Louis — for my husband’s job — by way of Philadelphia. If our friends from the coasts disparaged the heartland, we were quick to defend it. Privately, however, we were critical.

headline: The Internship: Not the Movie
text: THE NEW YORKER last week carried a cartoon of a man delivering a commencement address to a graduating class, all in caps and gowns, and his advice was: “It’s an intern-eat-intern world out there!”

headline: Who’s Minding the Schools?
text: IN April, some 1.2 million New York students took their first Common Core State Standards tests, which are supposed to assess their knowledge and thinking on topics such as “The Adventures of Tom Sawyer” and a single matrix equation in a vector variable.

headline: Your Smartphone Is Watching You
text: ON Thursday, just after reports broke that the National Security Agency had been helping itself to data from just about every major American Internet company, an enterprising Twitter user set up an account called “Nothing to Hide,” which reproduced tweets from people expressing blithe unconcern about their government’s potential access to their e-mails, phone records, video chats, you name it.

headline: How Not to Be Alone
text: A COUPLE of weeks ago, I saw a stranger crying in public. I was in Brooklyn’s Fort Greene neighborhood, waiting to meet a friend for breakfast. I arrived at the restaurant a few minutes early and was sitting on the bench outside, scrolling through my contact list. A girl, maybe 15 years old, was sitting on the bench opposite me, crying into her phone. I heard her say, “I know, I know, I know” over and over.

headline: Progress At Work, But Mothers Still Pay a Price
text: HERE’S an old riddle: a boy and his father are in a car crash and the father is killed instantly. The boy is airlifted to the best hospital in the region and prepped for emergency surgery by one of the top surgeons in the country. The surgeon rushes in, sees the boy, and says “I can’t operate on this patient. He’s my son.” Who is the surgeon?

headline: That Entrepreneurial Itch
text: I’VE always been interested in gadgets and building things. When I was 12, I got my first camera and built a darkroom under a staircase in my family’s house in a Detroit suburb.

headline: No Learning Without Feeling
text: “IT’S sad,” the kid at the far table told me, “but it’s my favorite poem we worked on.” He was talking about “The Weary Blues,” by Langston Hughes, and although his emotional language was rudimentary, his response was authentic. “So we should read literature that makes us sad?” I asked. He laughed. “Well, sadness, Ms. Hollander, is something people pretty much feel every day.” He looked up at me and smiled incredulously. The connection was obvious to him.

headline: Peeping Barry
text: WASHINGTON — THE acid that corroded George W. Bush’s presidency was fear — spreading it and succumbing to it.

headline: A Feast of Golf History, and Dinner Near the First Tee
text: It’s the family estate of American golf. It treasures its revered champions. It displays the trophies of more than a century of national tournaments. It whispers its landmark status. And it looks the part.

headline: Shining Moments in Baseball Amid the Tarnish
text: To go by the ominous headlines and warnings of 100-game suspensions for 20 or more players, last week was sobering for Major League Baseball. There is no question about the seriousness of the scandal involving a defunct anti-aging clinic in Florida and the revelation that its owner, Anthony Bosch, will cooperate with baseball’s investigation.

headline: Meet the New Landlord
text: A lot of people were surprised by the upsurge in home sales and prices last year, especially in some of the nation’s most depressed markets. Nationwide sales prices rose 7.3 percent last year, according to one major index, while prices in hard-hit Phoenix surged 23 percent. Other trouble spots, including Las Vegas and Riverside County, Calif., have also had double-digit gains.

headline: Immigration Headwinds
text: The bipartisan immigration bill that passed the Senate Judiciary Committee last month is now being sent to meet its fate on the Senate floor. While its chances of passage there look promising, there remains much uncertainty about how much — and how badly — the bill will be changed in the coming three weeks of debate.

headline: The Weird World of Colonoscopy Costs
text: Colonoscopies are one of three standard ways to screen for colorectal cancer. So it is disturbing to learn that the cost of this routine procedure, performed on more than 10 million Americans each year, differs radically from state to state and even within the same metropolitan area.

headline: Europe’s Social Contract, Lying in Pieces
text: What began as a debt and currency crisis in the European Union risks becoming a crisis of liberal democracy itself. Four years of grinding austerity across much of the Continent has caused millions of middle- and working-class voters to lose faith in the ability of mainstream political parties to protect their basic interests. It would be a sad paradox if the European movement, conceived in the ruins of fascism and two world wars, and for decades democracy’s best advertisement to the Communist East, undermined its democratic achievements in pursuit of a perverse economic dogma.

headline: Want to Fix Social Security? Use the Right Wrench
text: SOCIAL SECURITY is expected to run out of reserves by 2033 — a mere 20 years from now. With the public apparently opposed both to tax increases and to benefit cuts, the main politically feasible way to avoid such a fate seems to involve some monkeying with obscure aspects of the definition of benefits.

headline: Hazy With a Chance of Apocalypse
Invasion of the Beetles, and a Rancher’s Revenge
text: FOUR years ago, the trees on Larry Lipson’s property in western Montana began to die. Not just one or two, but 10,000 of them. The culprit was the mountain pine beetle, which has ravaged 23 million acres of forests in the United States since 2000.

headline: Chief Bill John Baker
text: Chief Bill John Baker leads the Cherokee Nation, which has 300,000 members and business interests that range from aerospace to casinos. The local economic impact of the tribe, which is based in northeastern Oklahoma, is $1.5 billion annually.

headline: Bishop Joseph M. Sullivan, Advocate for the Poor, Dies at 83
text: Bishop Joseph M. Sullivan, whose work on behalf of the poor and downtrodden for Catholic Charities in Brooklyn and Queens earned him national recognition, died on Friday as a result of injuries from a car accident. He was 83.

headline: Nearly Sunk, Bruins Snap Into a Juggernaut
text: BOSTON — The game had ended, the handshakes and pleasantries had been exchanged, and the Bruins gathered in their black jerseys and white hats for a team picture surrounding the Prince of Wales Trophy, given to the winner of the Eastern Conference finals.

headline: An Oasis in a Desert of Customer Service
text: REMEMBER the recent column about DailyCandy, the e-mail service for discount deals, and the customer who sent e-mails for six maddening months, trying to get an $85 refund?

headline: Don’t Take Your Vitamins
text: PHILADELPHIA — LAST month, Katy Perry shared her secret to good health with her 37 million followers on Twitter. “I’m all about that supplement & vitamin LYFE!” the pop star wrote, posting a snapshot of herself holding up three large bags of pills. There is one disturbing fact about vitamins, however, that Katy didn’t mention.

headline: Horses Don’t Care if the Jockey’s a Woman
text: The question is starting to wear on Rosie Napravnik, the way it did — and still does — on Julie Krone: what is it like being a female jockey?

headline: Mr. Hot Stuff’s Career Switch Pays Off Handsomely
text: When Mr. Hot Stuff had placed in two graded stakes and was being pointed for classics, the habit was funny, cute, good to lighten any mood around the barn. When he’d lost 6, 7, 8, 10 races in a row, the trick was no longer cute.

headline: Makeover Possible For Penguins After a Sweep
text: For years, the idea of Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin on different N.H.L. teams was unimaginable. But now that Pittsburgh has been swept from the playoffs by the Boston Bruins, the unimaginable could be on the Penguins’ off-season agenda.

headline: Reliving Secretariat’s Magical Ride 40 Years Later
text: Forty years ago Sunday, Ron Turcotte unleashed Secretariat in the Belmont Stakes, prompting the track announcer Chic Anderson to exclaim as he thundered into the final turn, “He’s moving like a tremendous machine!” Secretariat went on to win by 31 lengths, setting a track and stakes record with a time of 2 minutes 24 seconds.

headline: The Syria the World Forgot
text: LAST month, while we waited at the Lebanese border for our papers to be processed so that we could return to Syria, a woman traveling in our shared taxi pointed at the clouds gathering in the sky and said, “The Orthodox will be happy.”

headline: Only Children: Lonely and Selfish?
text: CALL me a terrible mother. I have an only child. For now at least, I’m planning to keep it that way, for my happiness and for hers. But the notion that an only child might be a happy one contradicts strong cultural beliefs. According to these, children like mine will end up rotten with selfishness and beset by loneliness.

headline: A Golden Age for Intervention?
text: UNITED NATIONS

headline: Weiner Criticizes Police Stops, but Offers No Alternative
text: Appearing before an African-American audience in Harlem on Saturday, Anthony D. Weiner criticized the Police Department’s stop-and-frisk policy as excessive and promised that, if he became mayor, he would not use the tactic “as a racial tool.” He did not say, however, precisely how he would otherwise change the policy.

headline: No Tie-Ins. No Touch Screens. No Apps.
text: ESTHER BERNSTEIN, 6 years old with long blond hair, pulled on a pair of blue slippers with a gray tassel over the toe. She grinned.

headline: The Joke’s on All of Us
text: EVERY compulsive joker knows that joking leads to trouble. And so it has for my boss, E. Gordon Gee.

headline: Chronicling the Lives of Women
text: Abigail Heyman, who died on May 28 at 70, said her work as a photographer reflected “the conflicts inherent in growing up female.”

headline: Emirates Balk at Activism in Region Hit by Uprisings
text: RAS AL KHAYMAH, United Arab Emirates — The white mosque, soccer field and wedding hall are still there.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 9
text: Senators from both parties will take to the Sunday shows this week to address the newly disclosed government initiatives to mine phone call and Internet data from the public. Are the measures too invasive or are they justified for preventing terrorist attacks?

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, June 9
text: “The thing that scares me is the values going up so quickly.”

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Palace Malice Wins Belmont Stakes
text: Palace Malice cruised to the lead turning for home and beat both the Preakness winner Oxbow and the Derby winner Orb to capture the 145th running of the Belmont Stakes at Belmont Park on Saturday.

headline: Resilient Miami Rarely Entertains a Losing Streak
text: MIAMI – Past performance is no guarantee of future results, in investing or basketball, but if the past five months mean anything, the Miami Heat will win Game 2 of the N.B.A. finals on Sunday night.

headline: Fast One
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Elizabeth C. Gorski is the undisputed master of the “artistic” grid. Whether it’s drawing pictures with black squares or leaving us circled squares with which to play connect-the-dots, Ms. Gorski usually goes the extra length to give us some value-added in her puzzles. You’d be doing yourself a disservice if you race through this one.

headline: What to Watch on Day 15 of the French Open
text: Like the women’s final, the men’s final at Roland Garros features a prohibitive favorite. But the fans at the crowd at the Philippe Chatrier Court got more of a match than many expected. Will the crowd on Sunday be as lucky?

headline: Democrats Seek to End 20 Years of Texas Losses
text: Ambitious and sometimes wildly optimistic candidates for statewide offices are running all over the place, energized by the number of potential open seats on the 2014 ballots.

headline: Experts Urge Focus on Aquifers in Push for Water From Mexico
text: As Texas lawmakers say farmers in the Rio Grande Valley are hurting because Mexico is not honoring a treaty on surface water delivery, experts caution that greater attention should be paid to water deep below the surface.

headline: Attacker in Afghanistan Hid Bomb in His Body
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan’s spy chief, Asadullah Khalid, was taking no chances.

headline: Decades Later, Revisiting a Death in the Family
text: Near the end of his extraordinary new book, “Run, Brother, Run: A Memoir of a Murder in My Family,” about the killing of his older brother, Alan, outside Houston in 1968, David Berg writes about going to see Joel and Ethan Coen’s 2007 film “No Country for Old Men” — not knowing that the film featured the actor Woody Harrelson in a supporting role.

headline: Stephanopoulizing
text: My head will be talking tomorrow morning. I understand we’ll be talking about New Jersey. You got a problem with that?

headline: Abandoned Oil Wells Raise Fears of Pollution
text: LULING, Tex. — Amid the dry weeds on a 470-acre ranch here, a rusted head of steel pokes up, a vestige of an oil well abandoned decades ago. Across the field stand two huge, old wooden oil tanks, one of them tilting like a smokestack on the Titanic.

headline: Low-Key Player Thrives With Low-Key Spurs
text: MIAMI — Danny Green has enjoyed living in San Antonio just as much as he enjoyed living on Long Island when he was a teenager. Green said the weather in San Antonio reminded him of North Carolina, where he played in college for four years and where, in 2009, he was an all-everything starter on the team that won the national championship.

headline: Dropped Charges in Deadly Rape Provoke Fury in South Africa, and Pessimism
text: BREDASDORP, South Africa — As Anene Booysen lay dying, she whispered to her medics the name of the man who had assaulted her and left her lying in the dirt on a construction site, her bowels spilling from her abdomen.

headline: Rough Road to Victory at Grand Prix in Greece
text: Leinier Domínguez Perez needed a little help to overcome a bad start and go on to win the Grand Prix tournament in Thessaloniki, Greece.

headline: As Home Sales Heat Up Again, Buyers Must Resort to Cold Cash
text: LOS ANGELES — Bidding wars sound almost quaint. These days, the only way for would-be buyers to secure a home, it often seems, is to offer all cash and be ready to do so within hours, not days.

headline: Buying Homes With All Cash
text: An increase in all-cash purchases of single-family homes and condos in areas like Los Angeles and Boston are squeezing many people out of the market and making it nearly impossible for first-time buyers to even compete.

headline: Abigail Heyman, Feminist Photojournalist, Dies at 70
text: Abigail Heyman, a photographer whose stark portraits of women at work, at home and at weddings gave a visual concreteness to feminist doctrine of the 1970s about the oppressiveness of traditional female roles, died on May 28 at her home in Manhattan. She was 70.

headline: The Perennial Senate Guests and the No-Shows
text: Senators often make the rounds of the Sunday news shows, and Republicans are the most frequent guests.

headline: On the Sunday Morning Talk Shows, a Rather Familiar Cast of Characters
text: WASHINGTON — In mid-February, Senator John McCain went on the NBC program “Meet the Press” to explain his unhappiness with President Obama’s nominee for defense secretary. A week later, he took to “State of the Union” on CNN to chat about sequestration (bad) and the attack in Benghazi (worse).

headline: Police Call Santa Monica Gunman ‘Ready for Battle’
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — The gunman whose rampage across this city on Friday left four people dead before he was killed by the police at Santa Monica College carried a vast arsenal with him, including a semiautomatic rifle, a handgun, a tactical vest and 1,300 rounds of ammunition, the police said Saturday.

headline: Palace Malice, a Long Shot, Rewards a Promoter for His Patience
text: Before Todd Pletcher was a trainer with 200 horses in his stable, millions in his bank account, expensive suits and an exquisite haircut, he was a guy with eight horses who was in desperate need of clients. One of his first was Cot Campbell, a wily old Southerner with an affinity for plaid sports coats and porkpie hats who had pioneered the novel idea that horse ownership did not necessarily have to be exclusive to rich people.

headline: Protesters Are Killed in Libya in Fight With Militia
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — At least a dozen people were killed here Saturday and dozens wounded after members of a powerful militia fired on protesters surrounding the group’s headquarters in an outpouring of public anger at the armed bands that have been blamed for fueling political violence and undermining a fledgling state.

headline: Long Before the 20th Inning, Harvey’s Twinge Gives the Mets Shivers
text: In a game lasting 6 hours 25 minutes on Saturday, a worrying scene at Citi Field gradually turned into a maddening one.

headline: Protecting Your Privacy
text: The Times’s Nicole Perlroth outlines ways in which you can protect your privacy against the National Security Agency’s Prism program.

headline: How the U.S. Uses Technology to Mine More Data More Quickly
text: WASHINGTON — When American analysts hunting terrorists sought new ways to comb through the troves of phone records, e-mails and other data piling up as digital communications exploded over the past decade, they turned to Silicon Valley computer experts who had developed complex equations to thwart Russian mobsters intent on credit card fraud.

headline: Milestones for a Pair of Pettittes
text: SEATTLE — Andy Pettitte has enjoyed many special moments at the pinnacle of his profession. He has pitched 13 times in the World Series, been a 21-game winner, ridden on five parade floats and, best of all, celebrated the birth of four children who later rampaged around Yankees clubhouses for the better part of the last two decades.

headline: Construction Worker Tied to Philadelphia Building Collapse Turns Himself In
text: A construction worker sought in connection with the collapse of a building in Philadelphia that killed six people last week turned himself in to the police on Saturday.

headline: Vows: A Bridesmaid Democracy?
text: To make their bridesmaids feel more comfortable, brides are seeking out dress collections with flexibility in materials, cut and color.

headline: Moscow Trial Sends Warning to Rank-and-File Putin Foes
text: MOSCOW — Yaroslav G. Belousov, a political science student, found himself in the center of the mayhem last year when a rally against Vladimir V. Putin, then the prime minister, unexpectedly turned violent. As protesters grappled with riot police officers in helmets swinging truncheons, investigators say, Mr. Belousov “threw rocks and pieces of asphalt, broke through the cordon and attacked police officers.”

headline: Exhibit A for a Major Shift: Justices’ Gay Clerks
text: WASHINGTON — As Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. was struggling with how to cast the decisive vote in a 1986 Supreme Court case that would end up devastating the gay rights movement, he told his fellow justices that he had never met a homosexual.

headline: With CO2 Cuts Tough, U.S. and China Pledge a Push on Another Greenhouse Gas
text: As some environmental analysts had hoped, President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China found room to maneuver on global warming in their California desert retreat. They sidestepped the super wicked issues impeding restrictions of the greenhouse gas of greatest concern, carbon dioxide, and staff released a joint statement on plans to cut releases of hydrofluorocarbons, or HFCs, a potent group of heat-trapping gases.

headline: 36 Holes and No. 1 Foe Will Challenge Pressel
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Morgan Pressel will start Sunday’s marathon day of golf as the leader of the L.P.G.A. Championship. She takes a two-stroke lead in a tournament that has endured more than five inches of rain in 10 days, forcing the field to play 36 holes Sunday.

headline: Bryans Beat a French Team to Win at Roland Garros
text: PARIS — Bob and Mike Bryan of the United States held off a pair of battling French underdogs and won their 14th major international doubles title, defeating Nicolas Mahut and Michael Llodra of France, 6-4, 4-6, 7-6 (4), on Saturday at the French Open.

headline: A Review of Nadal’s Look, Mannerisms and Game
text: PARIS — Sunday’s all-Spanish duel between Rafael Nadal and David Ferrer was the eighth French Open final in nine years for Nadal.

headline: Tom Sharpe, Darkly Satirical British Novelist, Dies at 85
text: Tom Sharpe, a British novelist whose work was a riotous dark amalgam of Dickens, Waugh, Wodehouse, Rabelais and Benny Hill, died on Thursday at his home in Llafranc, in the Catalan region of Spain. He was 85 and had lived in Spain, in cheerful dyspepsia, for many years.

headline: Corrections: June 9, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: In China, More Signs of Slowing Economic Growth
text: HONG KONG — After weathering the global financial crisis better than any other large economy, China is now showing signs of slackening growth despite heavy lending from state-owned banks and extensive government investment programs.

headline: Yet Another Delay for Debut of Pineda
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — Michael Pineda had to wait 501 days for the chance to pitch in his first official game in the Yankees’ organization. Now he will have to wait at least one more.

headline: Officials From North and South Korea Meet to Arrange Talks
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Delegations from North and South Korea met on their heavily armed border on Sunday to try to arrange their first cabinet minister-level talks in six years following months of tensions marked by a North Korean nuclear test, international sanctions and threats of war.

headline: Catherine Fugazy, Sean Bave
text: Catherine Bridget Fugazy, a daughter of Catherine Donahue Fugazy and Roy D. Fugazy of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there Friday evening to Sean O’Keefe Bave, a son of Ann O’Keefe-Bave and John H. Bave of White Plains. Msgr. Walter F. Kenny performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Augustine, where he is the emeritus pastor.

Hudson Morgan, a friend of the couple who became an American Marriage Ministries minister for the occasion, officiated.

Drumm, a friend of the bride’s family who received permission from Massachusetts.

headline: Melody King and Winston Chou

headline: Indiana Jones and the Shoe Box of Fate
text: Abigail Righter Bristol and Jason Palmer Hafler were married Saturday at the summer home of the bride’s family in Tisbury, Mass., on Martha’s Vineyard. Muzammil Mansuri, a friend of the couple, received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

headline: Lauren Dresbach, Ross Newman
text: Lauren Michele Dresbach, a daughter of Karen Schneier Dresbach and Lee Dresbach, both of Aventura, Fla., is to be married Sunday afternoon in New York to Ross Jacob Newman, the son of Grace E. Newman and Craig A. Newman of Tampa, Fla. Rabbi Arthur Schneier, the bride’s maternal grandfather, is to perform the ceremony at Park East Synagogue, where he is the senior rabbi, with Rabbi Marc Schneier, the bride’s maternal uncle, participating.

text: Emily Rose Anderson and Andrew Louis Stein are to be married Sunday at the Liberty House Restaurant in Jersey City. Rabbi Robin Nafshi is to officiate.

text: Megan Lynn Gaffney and George Robert Painter IV were married Saturday evening at the Hall of Mirrors, an event space in Cincinnati. The Rev. Frieda N. Hughes, a minister of the Revelation Spiritual Church, officiated.

Villemaire of Moretown, Vt., is to be married Sunday evening to Eric David Helms, the son of Carolyn Helms and the Rev. Dr. David M. Helms of Southern Pines, N.C. The groom’s father, a Baptist minister, is to officiate at the Jekyll Island Club, a hotel on Jekyll Island, Ga.

text: Dr. Vietta Louise Johnson and David Wiley Campt were married Friday evening at the Millennium Center, an event space in Winston-Salem, N.C. The Rev. Touré C. Marshall, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

headline: Kristina Rodriguez and David Salaverry
text: Dr. Kristina Ana Rodriguez and David Alfred Salaverry were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Kevin V. Madigan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More, where he is pastor.

text: Maria Nicole Sinopoli, a daughter of Maria C. Sinopoli and Joseph M. Sinopoli, both of Manlius, N.Y., is to be married Sunday afternoon to Brian Michael Rosenberg, a son of Linda M. Rosenberg and Dr. Joel M. Rosenberg of Fayetteville, N.Y.

text: Melissa Christina Bellino and Tyler Ryan MacDonald were married Saturday at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Church in Shrub Oak, N.Y. The Rev. S. Kulandairajan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

text: Christine Elizabeth Sutherland Wight and Dr. York Chen were married Saturday in Skaneateles, N.Y. The Rev. Margaret K. Bates performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church, where she is the associate rector.

text: Suzanna Hallie Publicker, the daughter of Stephanie Perrine Publicker and Dr. Mark R. Publicker of Gorham, Me., is to be married Sunday evening to James Ponzini Mettham, a son of Suzanne M. Ponzini and Hugh J. Mettham of Port Washington, N.Y. The Rev. Eileen Grizer Feinman, an interfaith minister ordained by the Heart River Healing School in Manhattan, is to officiate at Brooklyn Bridge Park in Brooklyn.

Wisnia officiated at the Rockleigh, a banquet hall in Rockleigh, N.J..

headline: Vivian Healey, Wade Hindes
text: Vivian Olsiewski Healey, a daughter of Paula J. Olsiewski and Dr. John H. Healey of New York, was married Saturday to Wade Michael Hindes, a son of Kathleen Barthel Hindes and Michael R. Hindes of Atlanta. Msgr. Jacques Plante performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Mary on Broadway, in Providence, R.I.

text: Alisa Lea Ruvinsky and Josiah Orne Low IV were married Thursday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau in New York. Angel Lopez, a staff member of the New York City Clerk’s office, officiated.

text: Clea Elaine Bunch and Robert Martin Hupp were married Saturday at the home of Chip and Cindy Murphy, friends of the couple, in Little Rock, Ark. The Rev. Victor H. Nixon, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

text: Heather Jean Maher and Frantisek Brabec Jr. were married Saturday evening at the Historic Rosemont Manor in Berryville, Va. George J. Kempf, a civil officiant for the Commonwealth of Virginia, officiated.

text: Caitlin Anne Viole and Ross Nicholas Dodd were married Saturday at the Ridgewood Country Club in Paramus, N.J. Eric W. K. Young, a friend of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated.

text: Danielle Lindsay Flug, the daughter of Laura Gurwin Flug and Robert S. Flug, both of New York, was married Saturday evening to Reid Francis Capalino, a son of Dr. Carlin B. Vickery and James F. Capalino of New York. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts in New York.

text: Dr. Cynthia Melissa Gitler, a daughter of Dr. Ellen Spielman Gitler and Dr. Bernard Gitler of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married Saturday to Nicholas Paul Ciancio, a son of Susan Ciancio and Nick L. Ciancio of Downingtown, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister formerly associated with the United Methodist Church, officiated at the Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y.

text: Courtney Vaughan Ambrose, a daughter of Colleen and William V. Doyle, a friend of the couple.

Wailand and Barry A. Willner of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Lisa Rubin officiated at Wave Hill, the public garden and cultural center in Riverdale.

headline: Kwon Crumble, David Benowitz
text: Kwon Michelle Crumble and David Barry Benowitz were married Saturday at the Mayflower Renaissance Hotel in Washington. Rabbi Annie L. Bornstein officiated.
