text: To the Editor:

headline: Second Major Title of Year for No. 1 Player in the World
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Inbee Park of South Korea nearly gave it away Sunday, but she held on at the L.P.G.A. Championship to earn her fourth victory and second major title of the season.

headline: Billups Honored as a Top Teammate
text: MIAMI — Chauncey Billups, one of the most respected veterans in the N.B.A., was voted by his peers as the first winner of the Twyman/Stokes Teammate of the Year award. Billups, a point guard for the Los Angeles Clippers, has been a mentor to numerous players throughout his 16 years in the league.

headline: Band Reunites in Brooklyn, Opening for Nobody
text: At a small music venue in Gowanus, Brooklyn, four men well past their rock ’n’ roll prime gathered anxiously backstage, aware that their loyal following was waiting.

headline: Suzuki Slides Into Old Home With Winning Run
text: SEATTLE — There may be no patches of grass and red dirt in the world that Ichiro Suzuki knows better than right field and the home-plate area at Safeco Field, where he performed so brilliantly for 12 seasons as a Seattle Mariners right fielder and hitter.

headline: High Line Offers a Walk on the Wild Side
text: When the third and final section of the High Line opens next year, it will represent a sharp aesthetic departure from the first two sections: Instead of modernistic benches and showy perennials, there will be rusted tracks overgrown with Queen Anne’s lace and goldenrod.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 9, 2013

headline: Grouping Students by Ability Regains Favor in Classroom
text: It was once common for elementary-school teachers to arrange their classrooms by ability, placing the highest-achieving students in one cluster, the lowest in another. But ability grouping and its close cousin, tracking, in which children take different classes based on their proficiency levels, fell out of favor in the late 1980s and the 1990s as critics charged that they perpetuated inequality by trapping poor and minority students in low-level groups.

headline: Torrisi Group Switches From Sandwiches to Clams
text: Rich Torrisi, Mario Carbone and Jeff Zalaznick, who have taken Italian-American cuisine up a few notches at three restaurants in New York, have abandoned their plan to open Lobster Club, for sandwiches, three doors away from Carbone, their new spot in Greenwich Village.

headline: In Iran Race, All 8 Candidates Toe Hard Line on Nuclear Might
text: TEHRAN — A group of chador-wearing female supporters of Iran’s nuclear negotiator, Saeed Jalili, cheered wildly when he entered a packed conference hall during a campaign stop at Tehran University last week.

headline: U.S. Open’s Experiment: Today’s Golf Equipment vs. Tradition
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — After he won the 1971 United States Open at Merion Golf Club, Lee Trevino said, “I love Merion, and I don’t even know her last name.”

headline: Affirmative Reaction
text: In the coming days the Supreme Court is expected to rule on a case that could further restrict the use of race as a factor in college admissions. A white student denied a place at the University of Texas at Austin claims that although Texas uses race sparingly in its college admissions, the state is still cheating white students and violating the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment. The betting among court watchers is that the verdict will be another setback for racial affirmative action. As a supporter of diversity, I wonder: could that be a blessing in disguise?

headline: 2013 Tony Awards
text: Photos of some of the winning performers and shows.

headline: Criminal Defense Lawyer Closes Office to Join a Big Firm
text: In his celebrated career as a criminal defense lawyer, Gerald Shargel has represented Mafia bosses, corrupt politicians and celebrities in hot water, while trying more than 125 jury trials along the way.

headline: Secrecy and Freedom
text: Is government surveillance a threat to our democracy?

headline: Third Democrat to Seek Lautenberg’s Senate Seat
text: When Representative Frank Pallone Jr., a Democrat from the central New Jersey suburbs, officially announces his Senate candidacy on Monday, he will do so in a way that is intended to underscore his middle-class roots.

headline: Aiken: A Special Place Where the Horse Rules
text: When Dogwood Stable’s president and chief cheerleader, W. Cothran Campbell, who is known as Cot, expressed his delight at winning the Belmont Stakes with Palace Malice, he included in his winner’s circle remarks an acknowledgement of the small city of Aiken, S.C., the home base for his racing partnership operation.

headline: Near the Border, a Few Deputies Are Outnumbered by Drugs and Bodies
text: AJO, Ariz. — On a recent morning, Lt. Bill Clements, commander of a remote sheriff’s department substation here, sent his deputies into the sun-blasted Sonoran Desert to recover a body — the fifth in five days. Hours later, back at the station, a deputy unzipped a white body bag, revealing the corpse of a man who had died making the brutal crossing from Mexico, his lips shrunken, either with dehydration or from being partly eaten by wild animals, the deputies said.

headline: Japanese Suitor for Rodriguez Got No Response
text: At the end of last year, after Alex Rodriguez had been pinch-hit for and benched in the playoffs, speculation raged that he would be traded, cut or somehow removed from the Yankees’ roster. The only problem with any of those possibilities was that no team was willing to take his enormous contract, or so it was thought.

headline: Gunmen and Bombs Target Kabul Airport
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Gunmen and suicide bombers attacked the periphery of Kabul International Airport before dawn on Monday, Afghan officials said.

headline: Kidd Shows Interest in Nets’ Coaching Job
text: The Nets, in search of a coach to secure their future, are reaching into their past.

headline: Pineda Focuses on Control in First Step Toward Yanks
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — One day, it will be footnote. But for now, it is noteworthy.

headline: Mott Green, a Free-Spirited Chocolatier, Dies at 47
text: Mott Green, who emerged from a hermitlike existence in a bamboo hut in the jungle of Grenada to produce a coveted Caribbean delicacy — rich, dark chocolate bars that he exported around the world with the help of sailboats, bicycles and solar-powered refrigeration — died on June 1 in Grenada. He was 47.

headline: Charlie Coles, Who Led Underdog to a Stirring N.C.A.A. Run, Dies at 71
text: Charlie Coles, who coached Miami University in Ohio and its all-American forward Wally Szczerbiak to an improbable run in the 1999 N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament and became the most successful coach in the program’s history, died on Friday in Oxford, Ohio. He was 71.

headline: Legal Guns en Route to New York Are Cause for Arrest Before Flight Home
text: A subset of visitors to New York City looks, on the surface, just like the rest. Some are high profile, like the boxer this year, and the football player, and the Tea Party leader from California. They are joined by the anonymous: the military wife from Minnesota, and the hazardous waste expert. There was a minister, and a surgeon, and someone in pest control.

headline: In Soccer’s U.S. Open Cup, a Twisted Loan Deal
text: Dom Dwyer will not have the chance to play in one of the biggest games of his young soccer career.

headline: When Artworks Crash: Restorers Face Digital Test
text: Paintings fade; sculptures chip. Art restorers have long known how to repair those material flaws, so the experience of looking at a Vermeer or a Rodin remains basically unchanged over time. But when creativity is computerized, the art isn’t so easy to fix.

headline: Groups Propose to Simplify Accounting for Small Firms
text: Making accounting easier for small companies — and saving them the need to report some losses that big companies can face — has become a new preoccupation of the accounting profession.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 10
text: “In past years someone like Snowden may not have had access to briefings detailing these collection programs, but now with the push from a ‘need to know’ to a ‘need to share’ philosophy, it’s far more likely for an IT contractor like him to gain access to such documents.”

headline: Google Close to Acquiring Waze, a Rival in Maps
text: Google, which dominates the market for online maps, is close to a deal to acquire Waze, a largely Israeli company that has developed a social mapping service that is popular with drivers seeking to find the best route given actual traffic conditions.

headline: Heat Pummel Spurs to Tie Series
text: MIAMI — There are countless ways to dominate a game,  myriad  methods and attack points and angles, and LeBron James has mastered them all. The scheme and the scoring totals may vary, but it is the results that matter, a fact that James emphatically reminded anyone who had doubts Sunday night.

headline: Breaking It Down: Williams vs. Sharapova
text: There was a time not so long ago that clay-court tennis demanded patience and guile, and the accepted strategy was a war of attrition.

headline: Swimming and the Fear Factor
text: Annalyn Barbier’s daughter was 6 years old and a nonswimmer when she was invited to spend a week at a friend’s home, which had a pool. Ms. Barbier wanted her daughter to be able to save herself if she landed in the water. So Ms. Barbier, herself an avid swimmer, signed the child up for lessons at a high school near their Brooklyn home.

headline: The Once (but No Longer) Golden Age of Human Capital
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Corrections: June 10, 2013
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Word of the Day | conceit
text: conceit •\kən-ˈset\• noun

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’ Dances to the Top of the Tonys
text: The crowd-pleasing Broadway show “Kinky Boots” pulled off an upset victory as best musical at the Tony Awards on Sunday night, edging out the onetime front-runner, “Matilda the Musical,” while also scoring wins for Billy Porter’s lead performance and Cyndi Lauper’s music and lyrics in her Broadway debut as a composer.

headline: From the Start, a One-Man Show
text: It took Neil Patrick Harris only about three minutes to banish any worries that the fearsome Host Fatigue Syndrome would overtake him and the Tony Awards on Sunday night. Instead he set the bar so high with his introductory flourish that fears of another familiar Tony malady haunted the rest of the CBS broadcast: the dreaded How Do We Top the Opening Number Disease.

headline: Designated Drivers Often Drink
text: A new study suggests that many designated drivers do not themselves refrain from drinking, creating an obvious barrier to the campaign’s effectiveness.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 10:30 P.M. (Cooking) THE FRESHMAN CLASS Four aspiring chefs try to overcome personal and academic challenges to earn degrees from the Louisiana Culinary Institute in Baton Rouge in this new documentary series. Tiffany is a full-time mother trying to embark on a career despite her husband’s resistance. Jared is a Marine Corps veteran battling war injuries and post-traumatic stress disorder. Ben is a father of three anxious about how he’ll provide for his family as a student. And Jasmine is a single mother eager to stop working as an exotic dancer and fulfill her dream of opening a restaurant.

headline: Game 2: Heat vs. Spurs
text: The Miami Heat bounced back from a Game 1 loss with an emphatic victory over the San Antonio Spurs.

headline: Marching in the Streets
text: The National Puerto Rican Day Parade, which started in Midtown and ran north up Fifth Avenue to East 79th Street, was held on Sunday.

headline: A Week in Photos
text: A view of the week in sports, from the French Open to kiteboard racing.

headline: News Quiz | June 10, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: On Surveillance, Is America Becoming More Like China?
text: BEIJING — “The west is moving towards China in its quest for mass surveillance,” reads a headline in The Observer, a Sunday publication and the sister newspaper of The Guardian, which has published a string of articles about classified National Security Agency surveillance programs, transfixing readers around the world.

headline: A Dog’s Spring Break
text: Dear Diary:

headline: N.S.A. Whistle-Blower Revealed in Video
text: Last Updated, 12:42 p.m. In a 12-minute video interview recorded last week in Hong Kong and published on Sunday, Edward Snowden, a 29-year-old former C.I.A. computer technician who worked until several weeks ago as a private contractor at a National Security Agency facility in Hawaii, explained why he leaked classified information about the scope of America’s surveillance efforts to The Guardian and The Washington Post.

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 10
text: NEWS A 29-year-old former C.I.A. computer technician went public on Sunday as the source behind the daily drumbeat of disclosures about U.S. surveillance programs, saying he took the extraordinary step because “the public needs to decide whether these programs and policies are right or wrong.” Mark Mazzetti and Michael S. Schmidt report from Washington.

headline: Afghan Insurgency Attacks Kabul Airport and Building in Capital
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan insurgency sent 13 suicide bombers to assault two high-profile government targets on Monday, one in the capital and the other in a southern province, in a striking signal of its willingness to expend followers on missions that have relatively little military impact but command headlines.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 10, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article “Breakdown Imperils NASA’s Hunt for Other Earths”

headline: Broadway Stars Shine at the Tony Awards
text: In the article “‘Kinky Boots’ Dances to the Top of the Tonys,” Patrick Healy writes about the awards ceremony.

headline: How to Find Lens on Your Phone
text: Now you can have a world of photojournalism in the palm of your hand. More people are reading The Times on smartphones, and you can now experience Lens on the New York Times iPad/iPhone and Android apps. Here’s how:

headline: How Do You React to Strangers Having Private Conversations in Public?
text: Overhearing cell phone conversations and seeing someone’s screen as you walk by is a common experience.

headline: Bidders for British Utility Threaten to Walk Away from $8.2 Billion Offer
text: LONDON – The battle for control of the British water utility Severn Trent continued on Monday after the investment group that offered $8.2 billion to buy the company said it would walk away unless Severn Trent entered into discussions.

headline: Are Students Who Go Far Away to College More Likely to Study Abroad?
text: Katie Anne Scott was the only one of her friends to leave California for college. None of them understood her desire to leave, with so many terrific options for college in her home state. And yet to Ms. Scott, from San Diego, that was just the point. Staying in California meant she would not experience anything new.

headline: How Serena Williams’s Game Is Growing
text: Serena Williams may be the best women’s tennis player in history, and she’s improving before our very eyes.

headline: Danube Crests Near Record Level in Budapest
text: BUDAPEST — The Danube, which normally bisects Budapest as a gently rolling swath of silver, hovered at historic levels Monday, as the Hungarian capital struggled as record floods battered Central and Eastern Europe.

headline: Biosphere 2: An American Space Odyssey
text: Retro Report: With dreams of colonizing space, eight people sealed themselves in a glass biosphere in 1991. But some eventually “suffocated, starved and went mad.”

headline: A Second Act for Biosphere 2
text: In the fall of 1991, eight men and women marched into a glass and steel complex that covered three acres in the Arizona desert and was known as Biosphere 2. Their mission: to test whether they could be self-sustaining in this sealed-off environment, with hope that the model would someday be replicated to colonize outer space.

headline: Daily Report: Dismay in Silicon Valley at N.S.A.’s Prism Project
text: The dreamers, brains and cranks who built the Internet hoped it would be a tool of liberation and knowledge. Last week, an altogether bleaker vision emerged with new revelations of how the United States government is using it as a monitoring and tracking device, David Streitfeld and Quentin Hardy write in The New York Times.

headline: Indonesia Asks Saudis to Extend Deadline for Undocumented Workers
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesian officials called on Saudi Arabia to extend a deadline to register undocumented foreign workers on Monday, a day after a woman died from suspected heat exhaustion outside the Indonesian Consulate in Jeddah while waiting in line for new papers, and frustrated workers set fires and clashed with security forces.

headline: B.J.P. Patriarch Relinquishes Party Posts After Modi’s Promotion
text: NEW DELHI— One day after Narendra Modi, the chief minister of Gujarat state, was chosen to lead the Bharatiya Janata Party into the next general election, his main rival, L.K. Advani, resigned from his party leadership positions, a move that cracked open the deep fissures within India’s main opposition party.

headline: Group Takes On Arms Trade Corruption
text: A nonprofit group in London on Monday stepped up its campaign to reduce corruption in the military industry, a problem that has long been part of the seamy underside of international trade.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Cronuts!
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Q&A: Finding a Long-Lost Web Site
text: Q.

headline: AstraZeneca in Deal for Pearl Therapeutics Worth Up to $1.15 Billion
text: LONDON – The European drug maker AstraZeneca agreed on Monday to buy the American respiratory drug manufacturer Pearl Therapeutics for up to $1.15 billion.

headline: French Air Traffic Controllers Plan Strike Over Pan-European Plan
text: PARIS — Air traffic controllers in France have planned three days of strikes beginning Tuesday, to protest a proposal by the European Commission to accelerate the integration of air traffic management systems across the Continent. In addition, their counterparts in several other European countries were expected to take more limited labor action this week.

headline: Monday Reading: What Day Camps Wish Parents Knew
text: Ten things day camps wish parents knew, Universal Studios theme park debuts V.I.P. tickets, weddings go unplugged and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Weighing Alternatives to a Telecom Deal
text: Sprint Nextel’s path to recovery once seemed clear, involving a sale to SoftBank of Japan and a deal to buy full control of the wireless network operator Clearwire. But that plan has been complicated by Dish Network, which has bid for Sprint itself and Clearwire, leaving both Sprint and SoftBank to weigh backup plans, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports.

headline: Divorce and the Duma
text: MOSCOW — If you followed the news from Russia last week, you might be forgiven for thinking the country had lost its mind. Moscow’s mayor resigned from his post so he could declare an early election and run in it, and the largest political trial in half a century got underway. Yet all Russians seemed to talk about was marriage.

headline: What They Said: Indian Rupee Hits Record Low
text: The rupee fell to a new low against the dollar on Monday, hitting 58 rupees per dollar at one point. The previous low was recorded in June 2012 at 57.33 rupees for a dollar.

headline: The Rail’s Final Scoreboard, Year 6
text: Scoring points in each Triple Crown race this year, Jim Squires won the crown (using a 3-2-1 point breakdown for win-place-show) as The Rail’s 2013 handicapping champion, beating Joe Drape, who correctly picked Palace Malice to win the Belmont.

headline: Energy Agency Makes Case for Climate-Wise Energy Steps
text: The International Energy Agency today released a helpful report that charts four climate-wise (if fairly familiar) actions countries can pursue to make a difference in greenhouse-gas emissions by 2020. There’s a low bar to entry, the agency noted, saying these steps “can deliver significant emissions reductions by 2020, rely only on existing technologies and have already been adopted successfully in several countries.” Here are the four core points, followed by a slide show and related links:

headline: Exide, a Big Maker of Car Batteries, Files for Bankruptcy
text: Exide Technologies, a major manufacturer of car and truck batteries, filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday as it sought to repair its finances amid rising costs for materials and the shutdown of an important operation.

headline: Accused of Scheming With U.S., Britain Says It Follows the Law in Gathering Intelligence
text: LONDON — Stung by allegations that it colluded with American intelligence agencies to collect data on its citizens, Britain’s government insisted on Monday that its secret services operate within the law, but did not give details of what rules apply to some requests for information from foreign powers.

headline: Twitter’s Surveillance Resistance
text: There is much we don’t know about the data-collection activities of the intelligence world. For all the revelations made possible last week by Edward Snowden, the intelligence contractor who admitted forthrightly on Sunday that he was the source of the leaks, I still imagine a National Security Agency manager reading them all, shaking her head and thinking, you have no idea.

headline: A Crystal-Crusted Gown Made with a 3-D Printer
text: “Dita’s Gown,” a dress designed for Dita Von Teese using 3-D printing technology — which is most often used to create objects and architectural models — caused a stir when it was first shown at a symposium on 3-D design in New York last March. On June 12, it will be the West Coast’s turn to marvel, when one of its masterminds, the costume and jewelry designer Michael Schmidt, discusses the dress at an event at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

headline: Abenomics and Interest Rates: A Finger Exercise (Wonkish)
text: Japan has announced a long-term turn to easier money and a higher inflation target. Stocks are up (if bouncing around a lot), the yen is down, but long-term interest rates are somewhat higher (although still very low). Is this a puzzle or a problem?

headline: North Korea’s Defiance Looms Over Talks
text: SEOUL, South Korea — When North and South Korean officials meet in Seoul on Wednesday and Thursday for their first high-level dialogue in six years, the South will face a government with a nuclear policy that has become more recalcitrant than ever under its young new leader, Kim Jong-un.

headline: Fashion Makes Noise for Women’s Rights
text: LONDON — Can fanciful fashion become a force for good?

headline: Man in Handcuffs Shoots Officer in His Foot
text: An emotionally disturbed man being escorted in handcuffs by the police on Monday ripped a gun from the holster of an officer outside Harlem Hospital Center and shot a second officer in his left foot, the authorities said.

headline: Hong Kong Seen as Likely to Extradite Leaker if U.S. Asks
text: HONG KONG — In choosing Hong Kong as an initial place to take refuge from the United States government, the National Security Agency contractor who has acknowledged leaking documents has selected a jurisdiction where it may be possible to delay extradition but not avoid it, legal and law enforcement experts here said.

headline: Deloitte Buys Assets of a Boutique Bank
text: Deloitte announced on Monday that it had acquired most of the assets of McColl Partners, a boutique investment bank founded by Hugh L. McColl Jr., who had built Bank of America into a colossus. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: Greece Seeks an Edge as Troika Returns to Athens
text: ATHENS — The international lenders overseeing Greece’s bailout were back in Athens on Monday for their latest audit, with Greek officials hoping that dissent in the lending group might allow them new negotiating room.

headline: An iPad 5 Case Hints at Design Changes
text: Shortly before the iPhone 5 was announced, the first case for that phone arrived at my desk. It was made by Gumdrop.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap: A Knee-Jerk Reaction
text: Every Monday morning, Sloane Crosley and Logan Hill will offer their post-“Mad Men” analysis here.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: June 7-9, 2013
text: Here we are again.

headline: Nomura Adds 6 Bankers to Its Americas Arm
text: Nomura of Japan said on Monday that it had hired several senior bankers to take various posts at its investment bank as the firm continued to expand its presence in the Americas.

headline: Airlines Push for Global Measures to Control Carbon Emissions
text: Despite the unpopularity of a European aviation carbon emission tax, the world’s airlines are ready to discuss global measures.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Discover: Can mushrooms save the world? One man believes the fascinating fungi can help clean up oil spills and radioactive waste, and potentially provide a treatment for ailments like diabetes and dementia. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Ups, Downs and Redirected Dunks in the N.B.A. Finals
text: Now that the Miami Heat and the San Antonio Spurs have traded victories, each team slipping alternately into the role of heroic victor and pathetic also-ran as if it were trying on bathing suits for the summer, the N.B.A. finals have formally started. Everyone has now had a chance to hail the venerable, ageless champions, who then got old, and catapult LeBron James from the insufficient superstar foothill back to the top of Mount Basketball. It took two games to accomplish one big psychological warm-up.

headline: Former Dutch Leader Steps Into U.S. Nukes Debate
text: LONDON — In a report that caused some consternation in the Netherlands on Monday, a former prime minister was said to have confirmed for the first time that American Cold War-era nuclear bombs are being stored on Dutch soil.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘I Cannot Tell’
text: This poem, one of 12 winners of our fourth annual Found Poem Student Contest, was written by Cristobal, 14, from Naples, Fla. The poem comes from the Learning Network post “Poetry Pairing | ‘Once Upon a Midnight Dreary’”.

headline: Reaction to the N.S.A. Leak
text: The Times’s Mark Mazzetti on how a low-level contractor was able to leak vast amounts of classified information, and the reaction it caused in Washington.

headline: Air Bag Problems May Affect 320,000 Honda Minivans
text: Citing complaints about air bags deploying when there has not been an impact, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether 320,000 2003-4 Honda Odyssey minivans should be recalled.

headline: Worry Grows as Mandela Is Unchanged in Hospital
text: JOHANNESBURG — Former President Nelson Mandela of South Africa was in intensive care on Monday, the third day of his latest hospitalization for a recurring lung infection, South African officials said.

headline: Happy Father’s Day (and Lose Those Love Handles)
text: If plastic surgeons have their way, liposuction and Botox injections may replace ties and socks as the go-to gifts for Father’s Day.

headline: In the Soul’s Dark Night, a Digital Solace
text: Though the birth classes my wife and I took last summer while we were expecting our daughter were almost painfully thorough, they did not answer a few pressing questions: What is one to do if the imminent arrival of his first child engenders nothing but fear and dread? If the creation of new life turns his morbid mind to the inexorability of death? If the mere notion of bringing an innocent creature into this malevolently entropic world fills him with an anxiety that is like a persistent, unreachable itch?

headline: ‘The Woman Who Can Bring Don Draper to His Knees': Linda Cardellini on Her ‘Mad Men’ Role
text: To think there was a time when a television character played by Linda Cardellini was regarded as a freak simply because she dropped out of her high school Mathletes club. But that was a different decade, on a different period drama, and when Ms. Cardellini showed up on “Mad Men,” she brought a whole new calculus to that AMC series and to the life of Don Draper.

headline: Cited by a Justice, but Feeling Less Than Honored
text: WASHINGTON — Authors usually like it when the Supreme Court cites their work. But a reference to a book in an opinion last week is drawing mixed reviews.

headline: Year-End Roundup 2012-13 | Social Studies, History, Geography and Civics
text: Updated June 13, with links to all our 2012-13 collections.

headline: Aiming to Simplify the Landlord-Tenant Relationship
text: A new Web service called Cozy aims to simplify the relationship between those who own apartments and homes for rent, and those who pay rent to live in them.

headline: A Newsy Morning for Fashion Designers
text: It’s a newsy Monday morning for fashion designers. Emma Hill, the longtime creative director of the British label Mulberry, announced her intention to leave the company, and Jason Wu has added a role to his repertory, becoming the artistic designer of Boss women’s wear at Hugo Boss.

headline: Kidd as Nets’ Next Coach? Not So Fast
text: MIAMI — In the interests of understanding Jason Kidd’s iconoclastic mind-set, Chauncey Billups was a suitable stand-in after news circulated Sunday night that Kidd was pursuing the Nets’ head coaching vacancy. And what veteran point guard worth his handle wouldn’t think himself capable of making the transition from player to coach in seven seconds or less?

headline: Notable Night for the Tonys
text: Cyndi Lauper, Cicely Tyson, Patina Miller and Billy Porter highlighted the diverse talent being recognized and awarded on Broadway.

headline: Tenacious D Unveils Its Festival Supreme, With Sarah Silverman, Adam Sandler and More
text: When a rock group describes itself, as Tenacious D does, as “the greatest band in the world,” then when its members, Jack Black and Kyle Gass, decide to set aside self-interest and organize their own live festival, you expect them to enter into the enterprise with that same spirit of modesty and altruism.

headline: Unemployment Benefits and Actual Unemployment: An Analogy
text: A reader writes in, having just heard somebody or other claim that the current unemployment rate would be much lower if unemployment benefits were even less generous, and asks whether this can be true. And the answer is no. People who say things like this are fundamentally confused about what the economic research actually means.

headline: Rethinking the Twice-Yearly Dentist Visit
text: For decades, dentists have urged all adults to schedule preventive visits every six months. But a new study finds that annual cleanings may be adequate for adults without certain risk factors for periodontal disease while people with a high risk may need to go more often.

headline: A Loan Program for Veterans Comes Wrapped in Red Tape
text: Joe Vollono and his wife, Monica Raquel Ortiz, are ready to buy an apartment. Actually, they were ready to buy in November, when they found a one-bedroom they loved in Brooklyn Heights and came to an agreement with the developer on the price. They were ready in January when they signed a contract, and they have been ready ever since.

headline: Booz Allen’s Role in N.S.A. Case Puts Spotlight on Carlyle
text: For years, the Carlyle Group has tried to shed its former reputation as a second home for government officials and a specialist in buying defense companies.

headline: Want to Commit Insider Trading? Here’s How Not to Do It
text: Traders who act on confidential insider information usually try their best to keep their actions hidden from view. But other times, insider trading just leaps off the page, as if someone decides to directly flout securities law.

headline: War on Women Continues
text: Republican leaders eager to reject criticism that they are waging a “war on women” should read the legislation that their members endorsed last week.

headline: The Steps Puzzle
text: This week’s puzzle was suggested by University of Pennsylvania student Eric Utay, who said he came across the puzzle while preparing for quantitative job interviews.

headline: Really? The Claim: Fibromyalgia Is Affected by Weather
text: THE FACTS

headline: Disillusioned Nation
text: From Dick Cheney to Edward Snowden

headline: Highlights From Apple’s Conference Keynote
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As expected, Apple shared details of the next version of its iOS mobile operating system during the opening keynote address at its annual developer conference.

headline: JBS of Brazil in $2.7 Billion Deal
text: Brazil’s food sector took a move toward consolidation on Monday, as Marfrig announced the sale of its subsidiaries Seara Brasil and Zenda to its rival JBS.

headline: Walkabout – 6/10: Perks at Theme Parks; Compensation for Flight Delay
text: V.I.P. Roller Coasters As stratification becomes more pronounced in all corners of America, theme parks, including Universal Studios in Los Angeles, above, have been adopting a similarly tiered model, with special access and perks for those willing to pay. (New York Times)

headline: Discontent With Chief Is Seen in Votes by Wal-Mart Shareholders
text: A breakdown of the Wal-Mart shareholders’ vote tallies showed sustained opposition among some outside shareholders to the company’s chief executive, Michael T. Duke, and highlighted support for several proposals regarding broader disclosure and changes to the board.

headline: More Groups and More Tests in Shifting Classrooms
text: Grouping students by ability level in the classroom is back. “Ability grouping and its close cousin, tracking, in which children take different classes based on their proficiency levels, fell out of favor in the late 1980s and the 1990s as critics charged that they perpetuated inequality by trapping poor and minority students in low-level groups,” Vivian Yee wrote in The Times’s Education section. But the practice of separating children into groups according to strengths, weaknesses and achievement has undergone a stealth return:

headline: Image of the Day: June 10
text: A protest in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: A Wily Banker Reaches the Top
text: ATHENS — Not long ago, Michalis G. Sallas, the chairman of Piraeus Bank in Greece, had a dream: to make his bank too big to fail.

headline: Defense Minister May Become a Liability for Merkel
text: BERLIN — This is not going to be an easy week for Chancellor Angela Merkel. Her trusted and long-time friend, Defense Minister Thomas de Maizière is fighting for his political survival because of a deepening scandal over Germany’s development of surveillance drones.

headline: Sienna Miller Was Rosy in Resort at the Tony Awards
text: The Girl: The actress supporting her fiancé, Tom Sturridge (in Burberry), who was nominated for his role in the play “Orphans.”

headline: Monday Motorsports: Vettel, Johnson, Castroneves Score Weekend Racing Wins
text: Sebastian Vettel made easy work of the competition to win Sunday’s Formula One race in Montreal. Vettel’s victory extended his lead in the championship points standings over Kimi Raikkonen, who finished ninth after a trouble-plagued race. Fernando Alonso finished second and also moved ahead of Raikkonen in points. Lewis Hamilton was third.

headline: Expansion at the National Archives Means More Focus on Human Rights
text: The National Archives in Washington, D.C., a vast repository of documents related to the country’s history, will significantly expand in November with a new permanent exhibition called “Records of Rights,” depicting the struggles of women, African-Americans and immigrants for human rights.

headline: The Envelope, Please: Bryan Stromer
text: In his final post, Bryan Stromer, a senior at the New York City Lab School for Collaborative Studies, reflects on his college admissions process and prepares for life at Vanderbilt University.

headline: An Exclusive for Britain’s Guardian
text: The Times’s Christine Haughney on how the eavesdropping news has affected The Guardian, the newspaper that broke the story.

headline: The Small Picture: Painting the Town
text: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

headline: Innovation Bout: Beijing vs. Zurich
text: What do bike-sharing, bottle service, dog parks, pop-up stores, turnstiles and the wave (the stadium phenomenon) have in common? For starters, they are among the many things that get the “Who Made That” treatment in this year’s Innovations Issue, which came out this past weekend. But they are also features of city life, the sorts of adaptations that you would expect to evolve to take advantage of — and possibly release the pressures of — urban density.

headline: A Glamorous Killer Returns
text: The great migration began perhaps 40 years ago. From strongholds in the Rocky Mountains and Texas, young males headed east, seeking female companionship and new places to settle.

headline: Pettitte’s Uncertain Case for the Hall
text: For Andy Pettitte, the near constant in an ever-changing Yankees starting rotation, his chances of one day making the Hall of Fame will most likely come down to how much the voters value victories, and how much they continue to punish players for connections, however limited, to performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: 120,000 Years of Tumors
text: A Neanderthal who lived more than 120,000 years ago had a tumor in a bone, the earliest of its kind in the human fossil record, a new study reports. The tumor, which was discovered in the rib of a Neanderthal specimen found in present-day Croatia, is described in the journal PLoS One.

headline: Golf Books for All Sorts of Fathers
text: Father’s Day, which falls on the last day of this year’s United States Open, is a prime opportunity for buying golf books. And there is plenty of time left this week to get Dad something to read in the early afternoon Sunday as he waits for the action to heat up at Merion Golf Club.

headline: Justices Decline Case on Graphic Abortion Images
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday let stand a court order barring abortion protesters from displaying images of aborted fetuses in places where they might disturb children. As is their custom, the justices gave no reasons for declining to hear the case.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Rich States, Poor States
text: 1.8: it’s the ratio of average personal income in the richest state to that in the poorest state in 2012.

headline: ‘A Christmas Story, the Musical’ to Return to New York
text: “A Christmas Story, the Musical” is coming back to New York, but not to Broadway. The Tony Award-nominated show, with music and lyrics by Benj Pasek and Justin Paul, will return for a limited run from Dec. 11-29 at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, the show’s producers announced on Monday. The original Broadway director, John Rando, and choreographer, Warren Carlyle, will be part of the creative team. Casting is to be announced.

headline: Unraveling the ‘Game of Thrones’ Finale
text: For “Game of Thrones” it was the calm both before and after the storm. In its Season 3 finale on Sunday night, HBO’s popular fantasy series gave its fans a breather after the graphic slaughter that punctuated the previous week’s episode and inspired countless reaction videos. Oh, there was violence (spoilers ahead): the pint-size warrior Arya Stark claimed her first kill, the Wildling raider Ygritte put some non-lethal arrows into her former boyfriend Jon Snow, and there was some real unpleasantness involving Theon Greyjoy’s anatomy. But by “Game of Thrones” standards it was a tea party.

headline: One-Third of Americans Now Own Tablet Computers
text: Over the last three years, the number of adults owning a tablet computer has jumped sharply. Now, for the first time, a third of American adults own tablet computers, according to a new report released today by the Pew Research Center.

headline: Devaluing Human Capital
text: Nancy Folbre suggests that the golden age of human capital – roughly speaking, the era in which the economy strongly demanded the kinds of skills we teach in liberal-arts colleges and universities – is already behind us. She may well be right: after a long stretch when both technology and trade seemed to be undermining only manual labor, it does look as if many skilled occupations are now under threat by Big Data, Bangalore, or both.

headline: A Royal Wedding (No, Not That One)
text: The wedding last Saturday of Princess Madeleine of Sweden and the New York banker Christopher O’Neill did not have the global audience of Kate Middleton’s marriage to Britain’s Prince William, but it was noteworthy nonetheless to followers of royal fashion.

headline: The Stickers on Edward Snowden’s Laptop
text: For online activists around the world, one thing stood out in a photograph published on Sunday by The Guardian: Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who leaked information about the scope of United States government surveillance, adorned his laptop with stickers showing support for the Electronic Frontier Foundation and the Tor Project.

headline: ‘How’ Now, Time Warner Cable Media?
text: A cable television giant that helps sell other people’s brands every day will promote one of its own in a new way.

headline: Canada’s ‘Last Car Standing’ Gets Another Season of Beater Car Destruction
text: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GJICy8XYNTQ&feature=share&list=UUCHPcAPFxs_g7UY5GFphJqg

headline: New Massachusetts Senate Poll Suggests Support for Markey Is Slipping
text: BOSTON — Representative Edward J. Markey’s lead over Gabriel Gomez, a Republican businessman and former member of the Navy SEALs, in the special Senate election in Massachusetts has slipped by 10 percentage points since May, according to a new poll, which suggests that Mr. Markey has lost support among women and independents.

headline: From Apple, an Overhaul for Mobile and the Mac
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple wants to prove that it has not lost the ability to innovate in a post-Steve Jobs world.

headline: Tiny Patients, Major Goals
text: BOSTON — Here at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, a black mouse lies on a miniature exam table, his tail dangling off the end. A plastic tube carries anesthetic to his nose and mouth. He is asleep.

headline: Turn Off or Leave Running?
text: Q. Is it safe to leave a house or apartment while appliances like dishwashers or washing machines are running, or to run them overnight?

headline: ‘Vanya and Sonia’ Will Get a New Masha When Broadway Run Extends
text: The day after their show won the Tony Award for best play, the producers of “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike” announced that its Broadway run would continue at the Golden Theater through Aug. 25. The play, a bittersweet comedy by Christopher Durang, had been slated to close on June 30, then July 28.

headline: Bird Night at the Disco
text: Remember this when your feet start tapping to a catchy tune: Singing and dancing are so deeply intertwined that even birds feel the beat as they sing along.

headline: Eating Frogs in France
text: The journey from commercial frog farm to restaurant table.

headline: More Than a Great Pair of Legs
text: LES ÉCHETS, France — There was a time when frogs’ legs drowned in butter and garlic were standard fare at just about every bistro in France. Then two things happened.

headline: Rapid Malaria Test Uses the Power of Magnets
text: A student-professor team at Case Western Reserve University has invented a hand-held malaria detector that works on an unusual principle: Malaria parasites are stuffed with iron, so their innards can be magnetized.

headline: Mouse Hospitals, Cougars on the Prowl, Michael Douglas and HPV
text: Inside an operating room for tiny patients; one big cat makes a comeback; an actor blames oral sex for his throat cancer.

headline: Hold Off on the Alpha Centauri Trip
text: Cosmic hearts started beating a little faster last fall when a team of European astronomers announced that they had found a planet with a mass comparable to Earth’s orbiting Alpha Centauri B, part of a triple star that is the Sun’s nearest neighbor, only 4.4 light years from here.

headline: Philotimo: a Horse Rescue Success Story
text: There are horses who can uplift, cause a chuckle, spur a memory. Philotimo is a 6-year-old off-the-track chestnut thoroughbred gelding. He’s transitioning to life as a riding horse. When he’s ready, he’ll compete in classes for retired racehorses as well as in open-company horse trials and events. Summer Brennan, his trainer, has big plans for him. His path to Brennan has been fraught.

headline: Science Bookshelf
text: 1 QUIET by Susan Cain. Crown. Introverts — one-third of the population — are undervalued in American society. (Last month’s ranking: 3.)

headline: Turkish Leader Agrees to Meet Protest Organizers
text: ISTANBUL — In an apparent change of tactics, Turkey’s prime minister agreed on Monday to meet with leaders of the protest movement whose opposition to the razing of a park in Istanbul’s Taksim Square was a catalyst for violent nationwide antigovernment demonstrations that began more than a week ago and escalated into a political crisis.

headline: In New Role, James Picks Apart the Spurs’ Defense
text: After two games in the N.B.A. finals, the San Antonio Spurs and the Miami Heat have established their blueprints for victory. The Spurs’ offense hummed with productivity in Game 1, and point guard Tony Parker was nearly flawless in his command of his team’s pick-and-roll attack. But the Heat adjusted, and in Game 2 they disrupted the Spurs with their thieving hands and dazzling athleticism.

headline: Exploding Bourbon Bottles and Strange Encounters
text: I’VE been in the bourbon business for the last 17 years. Every bottle that I sold at the start of my career, I sold personally. I was going all over the country. If hotels were too costly, I would sleep in friends’ apartments in various cities. I was just trying to make it in the business, and flying was just something that I had to do. It still is.

headline: Harsher Sentencing Guidelines Can’t Be Used for Old Offenses, Justices Say
text: WASHINGTON — In a 5-to-4 decision that broke along ideological lines, the Supreme Court on Monday ruled that courts violate the Constitution when they rely on current federal sentencing guidelines if those guidelines call for harsher punishment than the ones in place at the time of the offense.

headline: Eating In, Maybe With Carryout
text: Room service has long been part of the convenience and lore of staying at a hotel — Julia Roberts’s and Richard Gere’s characters put it to good use in “Pretty Woman.”

headline: New Executive Producer Named for ‘American Idol’
text: One of the makers of “American Idol,” FremantleMedia North America, announced a new executive producer on Monday after reports that two longtime producers of the singing competition had been dismissed.

headline: Asymmetrical Bodies
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Blue-Collar Friendship Down at the Shipyard
text: The actor Dan Gordon is an ideal stage ambassador for Northern Ireland. Burly, affable and self-deprecating, he puts a warm face on a region too well known for sectarian violence. His one-man show “A Night in November” (written by Marie Jones) depicted a Belfast Protestant who cheers for the Irish soccer team at the 1994 World Cup in the United States. “The Boat Factory,” which he wrote and performs with Michael Condron as part of the Brits Off Broadway series, celebrates the sprawling Harland & Wolff shipyard, a once world-renowned institution, perhaps most famous as the birthplace of the Titanic. In multiple roles, Mr. Gordon and Mr. Condron vividly provide a collective portrait of labor in postwar Belfast.

headline: Brick and Mortar and Cold Steel
text: THE NEW BEST MADE CO. store was empty when I walked in, because of course it was. The shop was a couple of weeks old, it was early in the day, and the temperature was somewhere in the mid-80s with humidity even higher, which is appropriate weather for ax shopping approximately nowhere.

headline: Back on the Prowl
text: Mountain lion, puma, cougar, catamount, painter, panther — no matter what you call it, the big cat is making a comeback.

headline: A New Kind of Leaker for an Internet Age
text: What does a leaker look like? Sometimes, people who reveal secrets remain in the shadows, and the public is left to guess at their motivations, agendas and states of mind.

headline: The Pain of Constipation
text: Many years ago, when I was a much younger pediatrician with much younger children, I called their doctor to say that one of them was experiencing bad intermittent abdominal pain. As one pediatrician calling another, I was well prepared with a list of diagnoses, ranging from incipient inflammatory bowel disease to a walled-off abdominal abscess.

headline: Peer-to-Peer Car Sharing at the Airport
text: Most Internet sources that dedicate content to such things agree that Hertz opened its first airport car rental center at Chicago’s Midway International Airport in 1932. Hertz says it was the first of its kind anywhere. But regardless of who started it, airport car rentals changed the way people traveled.

headline: Don’t Do Something; Just Sit There
text: Educational opportunities abound in medicine. But it turns out there is exactly nowhere to learn the single hardest skill of all.

headline: The Drama at Jen’s Place
text: Don’t have enough Facebook friends? Need another blog to follow? If so, I’ve got some people to introduce you to. So what if they’re fictional.

headline: Oral Cancer Sneaks Up
text: The actor Michael Douglas has done for throat cancer what Rock Hudson did for AIDS and Angelina Jolie did for prophylactic mastectomy. By asserting last week that his cancer was caused by a virus transmitted during oral sex, Mr. Douglas pushed the disease onto the front pages and made millions of Americans worry about it for the first time.

headline: Struggling Up a Mountain, Led by a Trumpet Blast
text: The concept of questing is fundamental to “The Seven Storey Mountain,” a sequence of related compositions by the trumpeter, improviser and composer Nate Wooley. He borrowed the title from the 1948 autobiography of Thomas Merton, who gave up a life of scholarship and leisure to pursue spiritual matters as a Trappist monk.

headline: Looks at the Governors Ball
text: Concert-goers at the soggy three-day music festival wore bright colors to ward off the rain.

headline: Production Note
text: An article was posted on this page inadvertently, before it was ready for publication.

headline: A Cherished Amenity Is Likely to Stay at High-End Hotels
text: I’D spent the whole day and a good part of the night flying across the continent in airline custody. I was famished. On Devil’s Island, the regimen for prisoners used to be bread and water, but in a coach seat on an airline these days you’re lucky to get the bread.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: The New York premiere of “Beer Hunter: The Movie” on Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. at Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue in the East Village, will feature the documentary about Michael Jackson, the beer and whiskey journalist. A panel discussion follows the screening, and food and beer will be served. Tickets are $10 online or $12 at the door.

headline: What to Make of a Warming Plateau
text: As unlikely as this may sound, we have lucked out in recent years when it comes to global warming.

headline: Inside a Mouse Hospital
text: At a unit inside the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston, scientists use highly specialized methods to study cancer in mice.

headline: The $1 Million Nest Egg
text: My Strategies column on Sunday, “For Retirees, a Million-Dollar Illusion,” was intended to be provocative. It evidently succeeded.

headline: Antiheroes and Shoe-Sucking Mud
text: The Governors Ball Music Festival took place on Randalls Island last weekend, with Kanye West, Guns N’ Roses and more than 60 other acts performing.

headline: Re-election Challenge Could Complicate McConnell’s Balancing Act
text: WASHINGTON — In any season, Washington bristles with barriers to accomplishment: permanent partisan warfare, vast ideological differences, a system built for stalemate.

headline: N.S.A. Monitoring and Partisan Hypocrisy
text: According to a new survey from the Pew Research Center, a majority of Americans are O.K. with the National Security Agency’s surveillance program—i.e. secret tracking of phone records. Fifty-six percent think it’s “acceptable” while 41 percent think it’s “not acceptable.” That’s a slight change from seven years ago, when 51 percent said it was acceptable and 47 percent said it was not.

headline: New Ring For Legend Of Boxing: Opera Stage
text: WASHINGTON — Anna Nicole Smith, Richard M. Nixon and Harvey Milk are among the prominent figures chosen as protagonists by opera composers in the late-20th and 21st centuries. Joining them, in “Approaching Ali,” which had its premiere on Saturday at the Kennedy Center Terrace Theater here, is Muhammad Ali.

text: THUNDERCAT

headline: Watched by the Web: Surveillance Is Reborn
text: Google does it. Amazon does it. Walmart does it. And, as news reports last week made clear, the United States government does it.

headline: Killing Becomes a Habit, With Madness and Method
text: You may think that television is currently supplying more than enough serial killers and serial-killer pursuers to meet our entertainment needs. But at Netflix the reigning view is apparently that too much is never enough: the service is now offering its subscribers a British serial-killer series, “The Fall,” from BBC2, starring Gillian Anderson of “X Files” fame.

headline: Dropped Last Year, ‘Community’ Creator Returns
text: Usually in Hollywood when a studio and the creator of a television series part ways under a cloud of angry recriminations they never work together again.

headline: Balanchine Revealed in a Dance Inside a Play
text: “Nikolai and the Others,” Richard Nelson’s new play at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, recreates one very particular milieu of Russophone exiles in America just after World War II. The characters include Nikolai — better known to posterity as the composer Nicolas Nabokov — the painter Sergei Sudeikin; Sudeikin’s ex-wife, Vera; and her second husband, Igor Stravinsky. They swirl around the choreographer George Balanchine (Michael Cerveris), who is at work with Stravinsky in preparing the ballet “Orpheus.” Though the play has its problems, I would want it to be seen by anyone interested in Balanchine and his choreography.

headline: A Rise in Requests From Brokers to Wipe the Slate Clean
text: If an investor checked the securities industry’s official regulatory database of complaints against brokers for the name of Michele Kief, a Wells Fargo broker in Naples, Fla., it would reveal nine client disputes — enough red flags to give a customer pause.

headline: Throat Cancer and H.P.V.
text: After remarks from the actor Michael Douglas attributing his throat cancer to a sexually transmitted virus, men are concerned that they, too, might be at risk.

headline: Pop Heroes Made and Remade
text: Notoriety was the key to headlining the Governors Ball Music Festival last weekend on Randalls Island. It used to be the making of a pop hero, and sometimes it still is.

headline: A Landmark Tony Awards Season for Black Actors
text: When Cicely Tyson was asked to star in “The Trip to Bountiful” on Broadway this spring, she knew some people might regard it as a marketing ploy. Her role was originally conceived as a white character, after all, with Geraldine Page winning an Academy Award in the 1985 film version.

headline: An Old Torah, Older Sunken Boats and a Seriously Old Primate
text: “I hate paying taxes, but wouldn’t mind paying more if the money went to fund science and research like this,” wrote a reader from Connecticut, commenting on an article about the discovery of a pocket-size early primate that lived 55 million years ago in what is now China.

Fraud Against Older
Consumers
text: The pitch arrived, as so many do, with a friendly cold call.

headline: In Performance: ‘Caucasian Chalk Circle’
text: Elizabeth A. Davis sings “Shoes of Gold,” with the composer Duncan Sheik on guitar, in an excerpt from the Classic Stage production of Brecht’s “Caucasian Chalk Circle.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Afghanistan, India, Germany and Yemen.

headline: Highlights From Apple’s WWDC
text: At its annual worldwide developers conference, Apple unveiled its newest products and features, including the Mac Pro computer and iTunes Radio.

headline: A Chef in the Field | Asparagus
text: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Live From St. Petersburg (With Popcorn)
text: You’ll hunt in vain for a good production of the full-length “Swan Lake” among America’s leading ballet companies. Although this work’s whole spirit belongs in the medieval age of chivalry, all too often it’s set in the Tudor or Victorian eras. And large swaths have been badly rechoreographed, notably the final act. So it’s restorative to see a live broadcast of one of the world’s finest productions, that of the Mariinsky Ballet in St. Petersburg. Broadcast in cinemas in 55 countries on Thursday night, this should have been more restorative than it proved. But its virtues are considerable.

headline: Chicago Killings at 1960s Level
text: Chicago murders have dropped to levels not seen since the 1960s.

headline: Triple Play: Week 10 Results
text: The Mets’ Ike Davis, the only player in Question No. 1 now playing at Class AAA, struck out the fewest number of times last week. The rest of the pack was pretty tight, and Boston’s Mike Napoli needed a golden sombrero on Sunday to tie Houston’s Chris Carter with nine for the week.

headline: Grand Jury to Convene on Building Collapse in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — A grand jury will investigate the building collapse that killed six people in central Philadelphia last week, and may recommend criminal charges, the city’s district attorney, R. Seth Williams, said on Monday.

headline: What Xbox One and Politics Have in Common
text: Video game consoles have become a bit like political candidates — both need to excite their bases to win.

headline: The Money-Go-Round
text: How internet merchants may use banks to gain access to people’s money.

headline: Colorado State Lab Accused of Mishandling Evidence
text: DENVER — Every day, vials of human blood arrive at the state toxicology lab here to be tested for alcohol and drugs. The results can offer a crucial piece of evidence in criminal cases like charges involving drunken driving and vehicular homicide.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Proof via Bitcoin, and Images From Sounds and Sand
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Senate Passes Farm Bill; House Vote Is Less Sure
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate approved a sweeping new farm bill on Monday that will cost nearly $955 billion over the next 10 years, the first step in a renewed attempt at passing legislation that will set the country’s food and agriculture programs and policy.

headline:
U.S. Drops Bid
to Limit Sales
of Morning-After Pill
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has decided to stop trying to block over-the-counter availability of the best-known morning-after contraceptive pill for all women and girls, a move fraught with political repercussions for President Obama.

headline: Iran: Candidate Drops Out of Presidential Campaign
text: A conservative former Parliament speaker ended his presidential campaign on Monday, narrowing the field of contestants to seven in a move that appeared aimed at strengthening the candidacies of fellow conservatives and reducing any chance that a moderate could win. The departure of the former speaker, Gholam Ali Haddad Adel, left four other conservatives on the ballot, with four days left the election. Mr. Haddad Adel, who is related by marriage to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, exhorted followers to vote for one of the other conservative candidates to avoid a possible runoff. The presumed front-runner is Saeed Jalili, Iran’s nuclear negotiator and a prominent disciple of the ayatollah, who has warned against showing any sign of weakness in Iran’s nuclear dispute with the West.

headline: Quick Reversal for Plan to Rename Canadian Broadcaster
text: OTTAWA — After several days of widespread public ridicule and political criticism, the government-owned Radio-Canada on Monday partly backed away from a plan to rename most of its television, radio and online service “ICI,” the French word for “here.”

headline: Big Data Sleuthing, 1960s Style
text: America’s intelligence agencies have long prodded the frontiers of computing and data analysis as the most demanding of customers, willing to pay whatever it takes for advanced surveillance technology.

headline: Obama Names Longtime Aide as His Chief Economic Adviser
text: WASHINGTON — The Council of Economic Advisers will have a prominent voice in White House discussions after President Obama named his longtime adviser Jason Furman as chairman of the panel on Monday.

headline: Greece: Ex-Official’s Relatives Fined for Bank Deposits
text: Greece’s financial crimes squad has traced more than six million euros, or nearly $8 million, in undeclared assets in the bank accounts of four relatives of a former finance minister, George Papaconstantinou, who is being investigated for his handling of a list of some 2,000 wealthy Greeks with Swiss bank accounts, a source of much-needed potential tax revenue untapped by the authorities. The four people face fines of about $13 million, said an official of the crimes squad. The development appeared to strengthen the case against Mr. Papaconstantinou, who became the focus of a parliamentary investigation in January after prosecutors revealed that the names of four of his relatives had been removed from the original list of depositors. Last week, Greek lawmakers voted to widen the investigation of Mr. Papaconstantinou.

headline: Progress for Jeter
text: Derek Jeter was back on the field Monday doing baseball activities in Tampa, Fla.,  another step in a long rehabilitation that the Yankees hope will lead him back to the team sometime after the All-Star break.

headline: Plant Faces New Hurdle on Horse Meat
text: New Mexico’s attorney general ruled on Monday that veterinary drugs commonly administered to horses would render their meat adulterated under state law, meaning it would not be fit for human consumption.

headline: How the National Anthem Turned Into a Blackhawks Rallying Cry
text: CHICAGO — Before Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals Wednesday night at United Center, the visiting Boston Bruins will be treated to one of the loudest and most venerable traditions in hockey: the cheers during the national anthem before a Blackhawks game.

headline: New Climate Data Depict a City More at Risk
text: The Bloomberg administration on Monday issued new warnings about New York City’s vulnerability to climate change, offering updated data to encourage businesses, residents and perhaps even future mayors to better prepare against hotter weather, fiercer storms and increased rainfall.

headline: India Scrambles to Reassure Tourists Shaken by Recent Attacks on Women
text: MUMBAI, India — Dheeraj Dixit used to make $2 a day snapping photographs of the tourists milling around the Gateway of India, the imposing monument at the southern tip of Mumbai. But a recent series of well-publicized attacks on women in India, and the international outcry over them, have Mr. Dixit worried.

headline: Chasing a Golden Dream, Chinese Miners Are on the Run in Ghana
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The lucky ones have hidden out on cocoa farms and in Chinese-owned companies, surviving on yams and water, moving about constantly and trembling at the prospect of being discovered by Ghana’s security forces. The unlucky ones have been beaten, robbed and swept up by soldiers.

headline: Little-Known Guide Helps Police Navigate a Diverse City
text: Arab immigrants often speak loudly, even by New York standards, so what sounds like an argument could be just a family discussion. Chinese immigrants are uncomfortable asking strangers for help. And immigrants from rural Mexico generally avoid making eye contact with authority figures.

headline: Kidd Meets With Nets About Coaching Job
text: Jason Kidd was regarded as a coach on the floor during his 19 seasons as an N.B.A. point guard, a reputation he is now trying to parlay into a head coaching job with the Nets, despite his lack of formal experience.

headline: German Court to Weigh Bond Buying by E.C.B.
text: Two longtime friends will appear before Germany’s highest court on Tuesday to argue opposite sides of a fateful question: What if the promise that holds the euro zone together is unconstitutional?

headline: Using a Would-Be Subway Bomber to Justify Sweeping Surveillance

headline: Libya Doesn’t Need More Militias
text: TWO years after the Libyan revolution, the police and army remain weak and hollow. Neglected by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in favor of more loyal units commanded by his sons, they are ill-equipped, understaffed, bloated at the senior ranks and tainted by their association with the old regime. Into their place have stepped the country’s 300 revolutionary militias — the groups that fought in the 2011 revolution that overthrew Colonel Qaddafi or arose in its aftermath.

headline: Kennedy’s Finest Moment
text: MEDFORD, Mass. — JUNE 11, 1963, may not be a widely recognized date these days, but it might have been the single most important day in civil rights history.

headline: The Solitary Leaker
text: From what we know so far, Edward Snowden appears to be the ultimate unmediated man. Though obviously terrifically bright, he could not successfully work his way through the institution of high school. Then he failed to navigate his way through community college.

headline: Tech Companies Tread Lightly in Statements on U.S. Spying
text: Someone’s not telling the whole truth.

headline: Immigration Legislation Draws Many Amendments as It Heads to Floor
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate Judiciary Committee considered more than 300 amendments to immigration legislation last month before sending it to the full Senate, which is expected to begin debate on the bill on Tuesday.

headline: Tebow Finds a New Home in New England
text: The Jets released Tim Tebow six weeks ago, and the longer he went unsigned, the dimmer his N.F.L. prospects seemed. Arena football beckoned. So did Canada, if he wanted to go, which he did not. Only the N.F.L. would suffice, and now that Tebow is poised to return, it is with the benefit of hindsight that perhaps there was only one plausible destination for him all along.

headline: Sexism’s Puzzling Stamina
text: This month the Supreme Court will issue raptly awaited decisions about affirmative action and gay marriage. But what’s been foremost in my thoughts isn’t race, sexual orientation or our country’s deeply flawed handling of both.

headline: Syrian Teenager’s Public Death Reveals Growing Anger as Civil War Continues
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The teenager’s name was Muhammad al-Qatta, and he was 14 years old when witnesses said radical Islamists in the northern Syrian city of Aleppo pulled him from his coffee kiosk on Sunday and later executed him in a public square.

headline: Writing and Fear
text: It’s 9 p.m. on a Wednesday night, and I’ve just gotten my three boys to bed. I sit down at my desk with a cup of tea and open the draft of my new novel. There’s a hazy moon in the sky and the wind is howling outside my office window. I can hear the branches of the old maple tree creaking in the wind, thrashing against the house — the perfect dark and stormy night.

headline: The Sentencing Guidelines and the Constitution
text: Marvin Peugh was convicted in 2010 on five counts of bank fraud connected to loans to farming businesses he ran with his cousin.

headline: Fresh Start for a Critical Relationship
text: There was never any guarantee that President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China would end their informal talks over the weekend with a deeper and more productive relationship. On too many issues, their national interests diverge. Even so, their meeting seems to have laid a reasonable basis for cooperation and for managing the inevitable competition between rising and established powers.

headline: A Real Debate on Surveillance
text: For years, as the federal surveillance state grew into every corner of American society, the highest officials worked to pretend that it didn’t exist. Now that Americans are learning what really takes place behind locked doors, many officials claim they are eager to talk about it. “That’s a conversation that I welcome having,” President Obama said on Saturday. Senator Dianne Feinstein, chairwoman of the Intelligence Committee, said on Sunday that she was open to holding a public hearing on the subject now, a hearing next month, a hearing every month.

headline: Still More Questions Than Answers on Nerve Gas in Syria
text: ANTAKYA, Turkey — A Syrian doctor said that one day in March, in the city of Aleppo, he was on duty in a hospital when it suddenly filled up with patients, some vomiting, choking or sensitive to light. A few responded to a treatment for nerve gas, he said, but at least two dozen others died.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 11, 2013
text: “Banks are in business to make a profit. Unfortunately, this is a moneymaking operation at consumers’ expense.”

headline: Rebels’ Losses in Syria Complicate Options for U.S. Aid
text: WASHINGTON — President Bashar al-Assad’s gains on the battlefield have called the United States’ strategy on Syria into question, prompting the Obama administration to again consider military options, including arming the rebels and conducting airstrikes to protect civilians and the Syrian opposition, administration officials said on Monday.

headline: An Era of Greatness, but No Grand Slams
text: PARIS — Impressive numbers have become the hallmark of these tennis times, and the French Open, which ended in the rain on Sunday, generated more math to remember.

headline: Maps That Live and Breathe With Data
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Maybe real estate agents should start selling mobile phones on the side. Why? Because with phones, as with homes, location is everything.

headline: Jury Selection in the Trayvon Martin Case Gets Off to a Slow Start
text: SANFORD, Fla. — The first round of jury selection in the murder trial of George Zimmerman began Monday, as lawyers from both sides sought to gauge prospective jurors’ exposure to the widespread coverage of the case and their sensitivity to the racial furor it unleashed.

headline: Ethnicity, Class and Suicide Lead a Hamptons School to Reach Out
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — As he walked the East Hampton High School campus on the last day of classes last week, Adam S. Fine seemed to be one satisfied principal. Graduating seniors were moving on to colleges including Brown and Cornell Universities; class-cutting was down; and Newsweek had ranked the school among the 2,000 best public schools in the nation, all to be expected in a ZIP code synonymous with success.

headline: Cuomo’s Office Won’t Release 2012 Video Satirizing His Secrecy
text: ALBANY — For the Capitol press corps’ annual gala last year, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and his aides put together a video poking fun at their reputation for secrecy. It was a self-deprecating moment for a hard-charging administration, drawing laughter from a hotel ballroom filled with lawmakers, lobbyists and other Albany power brokers.

headline: Readers Capture Istanbul’s Shifting Identity
text: Readers of The New York Times responded to a request to send in photographs that spoke to the kinds of change that sparked protests around Turkey.

headline: Corrections: June 11, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Assortments
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Thank goodness for reveals. I very nearly missed the theme of Pete Muller’s Tuesday offering, but thanks to the hint at 62 Across, I now understand that we have MIXED BAGS buried inside the list theme.

headline: New Jersey Assembly Speaker Enters Senate Race
text: The race to fill New Jersey’s vacant seat in the United States Senate is officially on, and it will not only be faster than usual, but also more complicated than expected.

headline: South Sudan Says Oil Will Flow Despite Sudan’s Threats
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — South Sudan will continue to pump oil for export through Sudan despite a threat by Sudan’s president to shut down the pipeline, a South Sudanese official said Monday.

headline: Vote Allows Children Under 12 Seeking Lung Transplant to Have Case Reviewed
text: WASHINGTON — Officials with the national Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network voted in an emergency meeting on Monday to create a new avenue for children seeking lung transplants after two families filed lawsuits challenging the rules.

headline: Answers Elusive 6 Months After a Fatal Shooting in Manhattan
text: Surveillance footage captured the killer pacing by a getaway car on a street in Midtown Manhattan, the victim with his eyes glued to the screen of his cellphone and the deadly moment in December when the gun went off.

headline: U.S. Requests Shorter Term for Mob Boss Sentenced to Life
text: Joseph C. Massino, who was sentenced to life in prison in 2005 after becoming the first official boss of one New York’s five mob families to testify for the government, could be released early if a judge honors a rare request from prosecutors to reduce his sentence.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Northern Ireland Town Eager for Reinvention Freshens Up for Group of 8
text: ENNISKILLEN, Northern Ireland — The smell of fresh paint hangs in the air as this small town completes an extensive makeover ahead of the meeting of the Group of 8 industrialized nations here next Monday and Tuesday. Workers are putting up new signs, repairing sidewalks and painting and plastering fake storefronts on closed-down businesses to make them resemble working shops.

headline: At U.S. Open Course, Weather Could Be Game Changer
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — After a downpour suspended practice rounds Monday morning at Merion Golf Club, more saturating rain arrived in the early afternoon. Umbrellas sprouted like mushrooms.

headline: U.S. Preparing Charges Against Leaker of Data
text: WASHINGTON — As Justice Department officials began the process Monday to charge Edward J. Snowden, a 29-year-old former C.I.A. computer technician, with disclosing classified information, he checked out of a hotel in Hong Kong where he had been holed up for several weeks, according to two American officials. It was not clear where he went.

headline: Signs Point to Wheeler’s Debut in Atlanta
text: LAS VEGAS — The Mets have made it clear that their series next week in Atlanta against the Braves would be a logical time for them to promote Zack Wheeler, their top pitching prospect.

headline: Edward Hotaling, 75, TV Reporter Who Shed Light on Black History, Is Dead
text: Edward Hotaling, a television reporter whose question about racial progress ended the career of the CBS sports commentator Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder in 1988, but who may have made a more lasting mark by documenting the use of slave labor in building the nation’s Capitol, died on June 3 on Staten Island. He was 75.

headline: Cryptic Overtures and a Clandestine Meeting Gave Birth to a Blockbuster Story
text: WASHINGTON — The source had instructed his media contacts to come to Hong Kong, visit a particular out-of-the-way corner of a certain hotel, and ask — loudly — for directions to another part of the hotel. If all seemed well, the source would walk past holding a Rubik’s Cube.

headline: Water Levels Fall in Great Lakes, Taking a Toll on Shipping
text: Aboard the Dorothy Ann, in Lake Erie near Fairport Harbor, Ohio — As Capt. Jeremy R. Mock steered this 711-foot combination of tug and barge toward a harbor berth, a screen of red numbers indicated the decreasing depth of water under the vessel: 6 feet, 3.6 feet, 2 feet.

headline: Shootings by Agents Increase Border Tensions
text: NOGALES, Ariz. — As rocks hurled from Mexico rained down on United States Border Patrol agents one night last October, at least one of the agents drew his gun and fired across the border, striking a teenager 11 times, 7 times in the back. The boy, José Antonio Elena Rodriguez, 16, collapsed and died on a cracked sidewalk blocks from his home, under a sign that read “emergencias médicas.” The police in Nogales, Mexico, reported that he had been carrying only a cellphone.

headline: Arnold Eidus, 90, Adman With Stradivarius, Dies
text: Arnold Eidus, a retired advertising executive who began his career as an internationally acclaimed concert violinist, died on June 3 in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 90.

headline: A Continuing Divide on Priorities

headline: Yoram Kaniuk, Maverick Israeli Novelist, Dies at 83
text: JERUSALEM — Yoram Kaniuk, a prominent author and journalist from Israel’s founding generation who often expressed bleak views about what the country had become, died on Saturday in Tel Aviv. He was 83.

headline: Wicker Baskets, Not Flags, Adorn Merion Golf Course
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — There is no more recognizable golf course feature than the flag that adorns a green. It is a signature symbol and a beacon, golf’s version of a lighthouse — sometimes barely visible from the tee box but ever more noticeable as the golfer draws closer.

headline: Debate on Secret Data Looks Unlikely, Partly Because of Secrecy
text: WASHINGTON — Edward J. Snowden said he had leaked secret documents about National Security Agency surveillance to spark a public debate about civil liberties. President Obama, while deploring the leak, endorsed the same goal of a vigorous public discussion of the “trade-offs” between national security and personal privacy. “I think it’s healthy for our democracy, “ he said on Friday of the prospect of re-examining surveillance policy.
