headline: Sabathia Does Something Special for His Cousin
text: VALLEJO, Calif. — When C.C. Sabathia was a boy living in this East Bay town nestled in the hills north of Berkeley and Oakland, the words “Demi is playing” meant only one thing. Get up to the courts at the North Vallejo Community Center, because Sabathia’s older cousin Demetrius Davis was playing basketball.

headline: Guardian Makes Waves, and Is Ready for More
text: When Janine Gibson, the editor in chief of The Guardian’s Web site in the United States, realized that one of her columnists had a scoop about secret National Security Agency surveillance — potentially one of the biggest leaks in American intelligence history — she presented it to The Guardian’s top editor in London with classic British understatement.

headline: Search for His Swing Takes Davis to Las Vegas
text: LAS VEGAS — Midday temperatures on Monday climbed to 100 degrees around Las Vegas, the faraway outpost for the Mets’ organization, the place where first baseman Ike Davis will attempt to thaw his long and vexing cold spell.

headline: A New York Perfumer Finds an Unlikely Source of Inspiration
text: This Saturday, a little over a year after introducing its namesake signature fragrance — a combination of rhubarb and Madagascar vetiver — the Greenwich Village boutique-turned-perfumer Aedes de Venustas will release its much-anticipated follow-up. Teaming up this time with the German perfumer Ralf Schwieger, whose clients include the likes of Frédéric Malle and Hermès, the brand’s co-owners Karl Bradl and Robert Gerstner attempted to capture the essence of a rare flower to create the unisex aroma Iris Nazarena. “The inspiration was an iris that grows only in the mountains of Nazareth,” said Bradl, who discovered the species through art on a postcard. “It is a protected wildflower, so we could not harvest or remove the flower.” What’s more, iris flowers don’t actually have a scent — typically, only their roots do — so the team had to get creative. The fragrance they created, according to Bradl, is inspired by the “color, texture and pattern of the blossom.” The result is decidedly not floral. Instead, the eau de parfum has a powdery quality, with musky hints of clove and star anise, evoking burning incense — a signature note in the olfactory repertory of Aedes de Venustas, whose house line includes a scented room spray and candles. The effect is like a visit to an officers’ club from a bygone era, all smoky wood, aged leather and classic men’s cologne.

headline: Chicago Tactics Put Major Dent in Killing Trend

Killings this year have dipped to a level not seen since the early 1960s.

headline: A Conversation With: U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara
text: As the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, Preet Bharara has prosecuted high-profile political corruption and terrorism cases. But he’s best known for going after some of the world’s biggest hedge funds in his pursuit of corporate criminals.Among those Mr. Bharara, 44, has prosecuted are two prominent South Asians: Raj Rajaratnam, head of the Galleon Group, who is serving a 11-year sentence for receiving insider information from Rajat K. Gupta, a former Goldman Sachs director, who received a two-year sentence. (Mr. Gupta has appealed for a new trial.)

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 1 P.M. (Sundance) L’AMOUR FOU (2011) The French couturier Yves Saint Laurent, below, may have been surrounded by intense beauty, both in the atelier and at home, yet he was said to be joyful only twice a year: on the days a new collection was shown, usually to boisterous acclaim. But within 24 hours, the euphoria had evaporated. Pierre Bergé narrates this documentary about Saint Laurent, his partner in business and in life for a half-century until the designer’s death in 2008. The “crazy love” of the title refers not so much to their relationship but to Saint Laurent’s obsessions with objects, from the artworks — including Picassos, Matisses, Braques and a treasured Brancusi that were sold at a 2009 Christie’s auction — to the perfect houses, which he collected passionately. (All of the rooms in one were named after characters from Proust.) “Much of this stately, rather detached biography,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times of this documentary from Pierre Thoretton, “is pornography for the eye (not the body).” Of Saint Laurent’s depression, he added, “To realize that you may have the world while still feeling as if you have nothing is to experience a closer encounter with the void than most of us are likely to have.”

headline: A Gay Man Finds a Sixth Sense Declining With Age
text: My eyesight isn’t what it used to be. (I buy reading glasses online, for $2 a pair, and stash them all over the house.) And my hearing isn’t as sharp as it once was. (True story: When I asked my doctor if hearing loss at the upper frequencies was a serious problem, he said — with the comic timing of a man who has used the line before — “Only if you want to hear women.”)

headline: The Sippy Cup 1%

At the 2013 Brooklyn Baby Expo, though, I was shocked by the number of companies hawking natural products, organic foods and biodynamic skin creams. (Is biodynamic a subset of organic, or something else?) There was even a guy selling teething rings made out of plant-derived plastic resin who could have been played by Fred Armisen.

headline: SoftBank Raises Bid for Sprint
text: SoftBank of Japan has raised its takeover bid for Sprint Nextel to $21.6 billion, seeking to block a rival bid from Dish Network, Michael J. de la Merced reports in DealBook. Under the revised terms, SoftBank is shifting about $1.5 billion originally intended for Sprint itself to the company’s shareholders; investors can now sell shares at $7.65 each, an increase of nearly 5 percent from the original offer. The revised offer is valued at about $7.48 a share, up nearly 19 percent from the earlier bid, Mr. de la Merced reports. SoftBank would own about 78 percent of Sprint if the deal is approved.

headline: Domestic Surveillance Could Create a Divide in the 2016 Primaries
text: A poll released on Monday by the Pew Research Center and The Washington Post found a partisan shift in the way Americans view the National Security Agency’s domestic surveillance programs. In the survey, slightly more Democrats than Republicans said they found it acceptable for the N.S.A. to track Americans’ phone records and e-mails if the goal is to prevent terrorism. By comparison, when Pew Research asked a similar question in 2006, Republicans were about twice as likely as Democrats to support the N.S.A.’s activities.

headline: The Healer Behind the Belmont Winner of 1963
text: On June 8, 1963, Chateaugay, owned by Darby Dan Farm, trained by J. P. Conway and ridden by Braulio Baeza, won the Belmont Stakes at Aqueduct. With wind down the backstretch, he finished the one-and-one-half-mile race in 2:30.20 seconds, establishing a track record for that distance. Before this race, there was no track record at Aqueduct for this distance. Chateaugay went off the second choice at 9-2, beating the favorite Candy Spots, who went off at 1-2. While many in the crowd were disgruntled by Chateaugay’s win, probably few were surprised because he was the second favorite. And probably only a very few were actually amazed by Chateaugay’s accomplishment.

headline: North Korea’s Dialogue With the South Collapses

headline: Invisible Men
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — The prison library here is housed in a prefabricated building behind chain-link fencing and razor wire inside Camp Delta, an older, largely disused wing of the complex. Inside, the place has the feel of a branch library, with several rooms of books divided by language and genre — but its patrons may not browse the stacks. Instead, the chief librarian, a civilian who asks to be identified as “Milton” for security reasons, or an aide fills plastic bins with about 50 books and takes them to each cellblock once a week. If they obey prison rules, the 166 detainees may peer at the spines through the slots in their doors and check out two titles at a time, or make specific requests.

headline: Guantánamo’s Eclectic Prison Library

headline: The Sacking of Darien
text: Near sunrise on June 11, 1863, Confederate outposts noticed a flotilla of ships rounding Doboy Sound and steaming up the Altamaha River toward Darien, Ga. Settled on a picturesque bluff above the river in 1736, Georgians had once known Darien as a thriving port and financial center. During the early 19th century, however, Savannah absorbed most of Darien’s economic activity; by the time of the Civil War, a visitor to Darien could still see slaves loading timber and cotton at the wharves, but he or she would more likely notice the town’s quaint colonial charm.

headline: But for the Grace of Social Security
text: Back in the 1980s and 1990s, when it was still possible to believe that steady investments in 401(k) plans would lead to a comfortable retirement, the notion took hold that the best way to pay for old age was to leave your tax-deferred plan untouched for as long as possible, allowing it to grow into a formidable nest egg.

headline: The Great (Gay) Novelist You’ve Never Heard Of
text: Great war novels inevitably follow great wars, and in literary circles following World War II, everyone was wondering what would be the successors to “A Farewell to Arms” and “All Quiet on the Western Front” — and who would write them. But when John Horne Burns, age 29, in his small dormitory suite at the Loomis School in Windsor, Conn., on the night of April 23, 1946 (Shakespeare’s birthday, at that), finished “The Gallery” — “I fell across my Underwood and wept my heart out,” he later recalled — he was convinced he had done just that, and more. “ ‘The Gallery,’ I fear, is one of the masterpieces of the 20th century,” he wrote a friend.

headline: Jury Selection Continues in Trayvon Martin Case
text: SANFORD, Fla. — The first round of jury selection resumed Tuesday morning in the second day of the murder trial of George Zimmerman, with lawyers trying to discern prospective jurors’ exposure to the sensationalized case and any leanings they may harbor.

headline: U.S. Proposes Wildlife Protection for Captive Chimps
text: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service proposed Tuesday to bring captive chimpanzees under the protection of the Endangered Species Act, a move that would create one more major barrier to conducting invasive medical research on the animals for human diseases.

headline: Cell Phone Population Spike Catching up With Humans
text: The International Telecommunication Union, a United Nations agency tracking issues and trends in information and communication technologies, recently released an update on the high-speed buildout of the planet’s mobile phone network that I summarized on Twitter this way:

headline: French Prosecutors Seek to Drop Charges Against Strauss-Kahn
text: PARIS — Prosecutors in the northern French city of Lille are seeking to drop charges filed against Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former chief of the International Monetary Fund, in connection with a ring that recruited prostitutes for sex parties from Paris to Washington, according to a statement released on Tuesday by the prosecutors’ office.

headline: Hong Kong’s Old Airport Reopens as Cruise Ship Terminal
text: HONG KONG — It was perhaps the most spectacular flight approach in the world: amid mountains, seas and frequently tempestuous winds, aircraft nearing Kai Tak Airport in Hong Kong would stage a stomach-churning right turn, glide over the densely populated Kowloon Peninsula and land on a runway that jutted straight out into the sea.

headline: Weiner Story Appears Briefly, Then Disappears, From The Times’s Web Site
text: The Times has a strong policy against what it calls “unpublishing” articles. But there are occasional exceptions.

headline: Shareholders Approve Plan to Split News Corp.
text: News Corporation inched closer toward separating itself into two publicly traded companies on Tuesday, as shareholders approved a plan to sever the company’s publishing assets from its more lucrative entertainment divisions.

headline: Gamification Done Right
text: Developers tend to cringe at the term “gamification,” regarding it with a level of contempt they reserve for words favored by business types. Other examples include “the link economy,” “monetization” and “synergy.”

headline: Year-End Roundup 2012-13 | Science, Health, Technology and Math
text: http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=lxRNQbEGwm4#!

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Law and the Real World
A Big Bet on Nuclear Energy
text: Builders of a new nuclear plant project in Georgia hope to come through with a faster, better and cheaper system that will lead the way for a new generation of reactors.

headline: Bloomberg Outlines $20 Billion Storm Protection Plan
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg outlined a far-reaching plan on Tuesday to protect New York City from the threat of rising sea levels and powerful storm surges by building an extensive network of flood walls, levees and bulkheads along its 520 miles of coast.

headline: Whoa, the Apocalypse. We’re Still Buds, Right?
text: “This Is the End” — in more ways than one. The premise of Seth Rogen and Evan Goldberg’s new movie — a foul-mouthed, good-natured “Funny or Die” sketch stretched to feature length and garnished with special effects — is that the apocalypse is here. As a bunch of funny guys gather at a party in Los Angeles, events foretold in the Book of Revelation come to pass. The righteous are raptured up to heaven, while the rest (or at least most of the famous people in Hollywood) are swallowed up in fiery pits that open up in the ground, or pursued by scaly, oily, horned demons with enormous genitals.

headline: Hong Kong, a Strange Place to Seek Freedom
text: HONG KONG — Edward J. Snowden, the 29-year-old government contractor who blew the whistle on the American government’s vast data-collection efforts, was last seen checking out of a boutique hotel here on Monday. The previous day, he released a video defending his decision to leak sensitive secrets and explaining that he’d sought refuge in Hong Kong because it “has a strong tradition of free speech” and “a long tradition of protesting in the streets.”

headline: Greece Shuts Broadcaster in Bid to Show Resolve
text: ATHENS — Under pressure from its creditors to cut public employment, the Greek government said Tuesday that it was closing down its state-run television and radio broadcaster, idling 2,900 people — less than 1 percent of the public work force — and outraging the country’s powerful labor unions.

headline: The Bloomberg Administration’s $20 Billion Plan
text: The following slides are from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s presentation on storm preparations.

headline: Sprint’s Increased Bid Is No Knockout Blow
text: SoftBank’s raised bid for Sprint Nextel is no knockout blow.

headline: A Philadelphian Restaurateur Flourishes in New York
text: Stephen Starr unseated Glorious Food last week as the caterer of the New York Botanical Garden Conservatory Ball. It was no small feat for a restaurateur who used to be considered an out-of-towner.

headline: 3 Tech Giants Want to Reveal Data Requests
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google, Facebook and Microsoft on Tuesday asked the government for permission to reveal details about the classified requests they receive for the personal information of foreign users.

headline: S.E.C. Fines Options Exchange for Lax Oversight
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission fined the Chicago Board Options Exchange and an affiliate $6 million on Tuesday for what it called breakdowns in regulatory oversight, including a failure to enforce rules to prevent abusive short-selling.

headline: Tony Win Gives Box Office Boost to ‘Kinky Boots’
text: Fresh off winning the best musical Tony Award on Sunday night, the Broadway show “Kinky Boots” had its single-best day of ticket sales on Monday, taking in $1.25 million, a spokesman for the producers said. The show’s advanced ticket sales are “growing wildly,” the spokesman added, declining to provide specific figures, as “Kinky Boots” now attempts to catch up to the box office popularity of its chief competition at the Tonys, “Matilda the Musical.”

headline: Cuban Blogger Who Reveres Castro Pushes for Reform
text: Elaine Díaz may be the most important Cuban dissident you’ve never heard of. But that is perhaps because she doesn’t even call herself a dissident.

headline: Statues Long Held by the Metropolitan Museum Return to Cambodia
text: Two Cambodian statues that stood for a millennium in a remote Khmer Empire temple before spending two decades at the Metropolitan Museum of Art arrived back in their homeland Tuesday to the plaudits of Cambodian officials, who plan to display them in Phnom Phen starting Saturday.

headline: At Festivals: Melody, Lyrics, Menus
text: Chefs really are the new rock stars, at least according to their shared billing at a string of music festivals around the country.

headline: Stealing the Burglar Look From Pussy Riot
text: It’s easy to strike a sinister note when you take to the stage in a balaclava. Conventionally known as a ski mask, this menacing insignia of cat burglars, insurgents and thugs of every stripe took to the pulpit last year when the punk band Pussy Riot stormed a cathedral in Moscow, its members dancing and punching the air, their features concealed by violently colorful masks.

headline: Power and Privacy on the Internet
text: As my Sunday column hopefully made clear, I’m both disturbed by the expansion of surveillance power in America and pessimistic that the internet era could really turn out any other way. To explore that pessimism a little more, allow me to pivot off an interesting recent passage from a writer named Jacob Bacharach, who’s writing in defense of the Millennial generation’s willingness to put it all online:

headline: Mumford & Sons Bassist Is Hospitalized
text: The bassist for the folk-rock band Mumford & Sons has been hospitalized with a blood clot in his brain that will require surgery, the band announced on its Web site on Tuesday.

headline: I Got Pregnant at 14. Ask Me About Plan B.
text: When I was 14, I started having sex. At 15, I became a mother.

headline: The Patriots' Wicked Signing
text: The Patriots must be giddy thinking about ways to torture the rival Jets with Tim Tebow, according to William C. Rhoden.

headline: Formula One Exhibition to Be Held in Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM — Although grand prix racing started in Europe, it has recently expanded to Singapore, South Korea, India, the United States and is scheduled to spread to Russia next year. And this week, Formula One cars will run through the streets of this city.

headline: Intersection: Detail-Driven in Spanish Harlem
text: In Spanish Harlem we met residents who have diverse detail-oriented looks, including Melenee Suarez Burns in 1950 saddle shoes.

headline: Three’s a Trend | The Cropped Sweater With the Ladylike Skirt
text: This resort season, designers have been creating unfussy yet sensual holiday ensembles by pairing a midriff-baring knit top with a relaxed, below-the-knee skirt. Calvin Klein and Marc Jacobs presented monochromatic looks, offsetting the sexiness of their models’ toned abs with weighty crisscross sandals. Jason Wu, meanwhile, offered a study in neutrals, adding a heel for more of an evening look.

headline: Making Alberto Gonzales Look Good
text: Government officials employ various tactics to avoid actually saying anything at intelligence hearings, mostly by fogging up the room with references to national security and with vague generalities. It’s part of a dance, which the public and the media may grumble about but which we also expect.

headline: The Patriots’ Wicked Signing
text: The Jets never found a role that worked for quarterback Tim Tebow, and now Tebow has signed with rival New England. Patriots Coach Bill Belichick has made stars of other teams’ castoffs in the past, and he must be relishing the chance to torment the Jets.

headline: Investor Group Ends Bid for British Water Utility
text: An effort by an investment consortium to buy the British water utility Severn Trent fell apart on Tuesday as the two sides failed to enter into talks before a deadline.

headline: A Children’s Book by Ringo Sprouts From ‘Octopus’s Garden’
text: Ringo Starr may have been the last member of the Beatles anyone would have pegged as a potential paperback writer, but suddenly he seems interested in expanding his bibliography. Though a decade has elapsed since his first book, “Postcards From the Boys,” Mr. Starr has just announced his second book in two weeks.

headline: Staten Island Community Gets Back Its Library, Much Improved
text: Finally, post-Hurricane Sandy, Staten Islanders have something to cheer about: Local civic leaders and elected officials joined executives of the New York Public Library on Tuesday in opening the newly renovated Stapleton branch, which, at 12,000 square feet, is now more than double its original size.

headline: The War’s Not Over: Home Is a Battleground
text: The events in Jen Silverman’s “Phoebe in Winter” happen in a time out of joint, when the world is in “a state of aftermath.” A war has ended, fought in a jungle somewhere far-off. Or maybe it hasn’t ended, and the field of battle is distressingly near — an explosion rumbles through the theater as the action begins.

headline: Walgreen to Pay $80 Million Fine in D.E.A. Inquiry
text: The Walgreen Company, the nation’s biggest pharmacy operator, agreed on Tuesday to pay $80 million to resolve federal charges that it failed to properly control the sales of narcotic painkillers at some of its outlets.

headline: A.C.L.U. Files Lawsuit Seeking to Stop the Collection of Domestic Phone Logs
text: WASHINGTON — The American Civil Liberties Union sued the Obama administration on Tuesday over its “dragnet” collection of logs of domestic phone calls, contending that the once-secret program — whose existence was exposed last week by a former National Security Agency contractor — is illegal and asking a judge to stop it and order the records purged.

headline: A Doubles Windfall: Federer and Haas Hit the Grass Together
text: HALLE WESTFALEN, Germany — Because singles players will often enter a doubles field after the tennis tour shifts to a new surface just for the extra practice, the Gerry Weber Open found itself with an unusually talented doubles field this week.

headline: A Family on the Run From Population Enforcers
text: In the Chinese countryside, where, the saying goes, heaven is high, and the emperor is far away, the phrase “family planning” has taken on a sinister connotation.

headline: Essay: Medication Continues to Stifle America’s Triple Crown Hopes
text: It is no coincidence that there has not been a Triple Crown winner since the administration of raceday Lasix became the standard for Kentucky Derby runners some 35 or so years ago. An understanding and appreciation of the veterinary science of equine behavior are necessary to elucidate how raceday Lasix impoverishes the medical welfare of racehorses, and why permissive raceday and day-before medication should be banned in American horseracing to protect the heath and welfare of the racehorses and the sport.

headline: Few Wash Hands Properly, Study Finds
text: Did you wash your hands properly after you used the toilet? Probably not, a new study suggests.

headline: 2013 Fantasy Football: Top 10 Quarterbacks
text: Cam Newton should at least duplicate his 2012 performance as the fourth best quarterback in fantasy football.

headline: Teff Pancakes With Chia, Millet and Blueberries
text: If you’re trying to work more grains and seeds into your diet, a pancake can be a good home for them. These are hearty pancakes – 3 make a good breakfast – with nice texture.

headline: Sprint and SoftBank Shore Up Defenses Against a Dish Counterbid
text: In raising its bid for Sprint Nextel, SoftBank of Japan is doing its best to make sure Dish Network will have a harder time fighting back.

headline: Montmartre
text: Inside the restaurant infusing French cuisine with Asian flavor.

headline: A Clearer Long-Distance Connection
text: And the award for the most improved restaurant of the year so far goes to ...

headline: Police Clash With Protesters in Istanbul
text: An operation by the Turkish authorities to disperse demonstrators from Taksim Square began a day after the prime minister agreed to meet with protesters.

headline: Making a Case for Belgian Frites
text: “Other countries have frites, but they’re not the same.”

headline: In Brussels, Frites Are More Than Just Fries
text: Meeting a doctor at a frites stand in Brussels was fortuitous, in an enabling-poor-behavior sort of way. “It’s obvious that French fries are not very healthy, but that doesn’t mean that you should not have them at least once a week,” said Philippe Wuyts, a psychiatrist I found in line at Frit Flagey, one of the more famed spots for fries in the Belgian capital. “Even as a doctor I would recommend for everybody to have at least one portion.”

headline: Great Sound, and Easy on the Wallet
text: Expanding its stable of audio products, Sol Republic recently introduced a line of low-priced in-ear headphones called Jax.

headline: New Plans for Casinos in the Catskills
text: Casino fever has hit the Catskills, again.

headline: Restaurant Report: Lolla in Singapore
text: Just a five-minute walk from the din of Singapore’s Chinatown, the once-vibrant Club Street-Ann Siang Road dining enclave is enjoying a revival. A raft of restaurants and clubs is riding the upswing, and one of the hardest tables to book is Lolla, a new kid on the block that made Zagat’s 2013 “10 hottest restaurants in the world” list. What you wouldn’t necessarily know on arrival: Lolla is the permanent shopfront incarnation of Lolla’s Secret Supper, a guerrilla-style underground supper club founded in 2008 by Pang Hian Tee.

headline: G.M. and BMW Adopt D.C. Electric Car Charging
text: General Motors and BMW say they are moving ahead with technology that can give electric cars an 80 percent charge in 20 minutes. Charging time is a major problem in a car that can travel only 100 miles or less between charges.

headline: As Senate Begins Debate, Organized Labor Makes Immigration Push
text: As the Senate opens debate on an overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws, organized labor is picking up the pace of its advocacy for the bill.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Headliner

headline: An Invitation to a House on a Greek Island
text: Dozens of books arrive at The New York Times Magazine every day. Books that whimper for attention: See me. Read me. Love me. Most of them end up on a counter in the 6th-floor mailroom, forlorn as puppies in an animal shelter. I rescued one book in prepublication form last week: “The Greek House: The Story of a Painter’s Love Affair With the Island of Sifnos,” a memoir by the Swiss artist Christian Brechneff (with Tim Lovejoy).

headline: Broadway Mainstays Will Be Part of Encores! Off-Broadway Series
text: City Center’s Encores! series may be exploring Off Broadway this summer, but Broadway talent is coming along for the ride. Tony winner Anika Noni Rose and nominees Raul Esparza, Judy Kuhn, Danny Burstein and Da’Vine Joy Randolph are among those starring in “The Cradle Will Rock,” the inaugural show in the new Encores! Off-Center series. The production, directed by Sam Gold, will run July 10 to 13.

headline: Front Burner
text: To Savor: For a Party, a Sushi Treat

headline: Health Care’s Overlooked Cost Factor
text: When the Evanston Northwestern Healthcare Corporation merged its two hospitals with the neighboring Highland Park Hospital just north of Chicago 13 years ago, the deal was presented as an opportunity to increase efficiency and improve the quality of patient care.

headline: Why Surveillance Draws Little Outcry
text: Daniel J. Solove, a privacy expert and professor of law at George Washington University, discusses the public response — or lack thereof — to recent disclosures about government eavesdropping.

headline: Romantic, Quirky or Funky
text: WASHINGTON — Because each program of the “Ballet Across America III” season at the Kennedy Center here features three American companies, every performance is attended by partisan supporters keen to signal their delight in the offering by their team. On Sunday afternoon I caught Program C, the final segment of last week’s three-part event. Ovations were lusty for North Carolina Dance Theater, Ballet Austin and Dance Theater of Harlem.

headline: Letting Go Is Hard to Do When It’s the Old Manse
text: Removing an aged parent or grandparent from a home that’s no longer safe or convenient is never easy.

headline: Playing Dead, With Aplomb
text: In any production of “Romeo and Juliet” there is a lot of playing dead. At the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday, when American Ballet Theater performed its first “Romeo” of the season, one of the unmoving corpses near Juliet in the crypt was played by a guest star: Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a New York Democrat. She was perfect. That doesn’t quite count as news, but it was noteworthy in a performance of predictable excellence. Kenneth MacMillan’s 1965 “Romeo” is a reliable construction, and Monday’s cast looked comfortable in roles played many times before.

headline: How to Fill a Melting Pot
text: New York has immigrants from 148 countries, at least by the city’s count, and it seems a number of the more successful ones eventually make their way to Allerton, whose diversity stands out even in an extremely multicultural field.

headline: Living in Allerton, the Bronx
text: The neighborhood is especially diverse, made up of hard working immigrants, proud of their homes.

headline: Brothers Who Make Electronica by Hand
text: Boards of Canada thrive on making themselves scarce. A duo of brothers from rural Scotland, Mike Sandison and Marcus Eoin, the group has been releasing electronic music since the mid-1990s — music that eludes most standard pop notions of electronica and has built a fiercely dedicated following among fellow musicians and producers.

headline: A Year Later, the Missed Opportunity of the JOBS Act
text: More than a year ago, Congress passed legislation that its supporters said would help revive new company offerings. Now, the market for initial public offerings is starting to heati up, but the law, the Jump-Start Our Business Startups Act, or the JOBS Act, has had little to do with it.

headline: A Nearly Instant Picnic
text: You can take advantage of picnic weather even if you don’t have a wicker basket and cold fried chicken on hand.

headline: A Ballet Master Full of Light and Shadows
text: The 2012-13 season of New York City Ballet that ended at the David H. Koch Theater was a milestone in several ways. At age 66, Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief, has weathered 30 years at its helm. He may well end up lasting longer than the 35 years enjoyed by the company’s founding ballet master, George Balanchine. In the past year Mr. Martins has also presented three world premieres by a new choreographer, Justin Peck. All of them — “In Creases,” “Year of the Rabbit” and “Paz de la Jolla” — are at least good; and “Rabbit” really does seem to be the most exciting new ballet since Alexei Ratmansky’s “Concerto DSCH.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Web Page No. 1 and Amazon in China
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Pan Bagnat, the Perfect Picnic Sandwich
text: When it comes to picnics, we can do better than a loaf of bread and a wedge of cheese. Melissa Clark shows why the pan bagnat is the ideal sandwich for outdoor summer dining.

headline: Undervalued Coal Leases Seen as Costing Taxpayers
text: WASHINGTON — The Interior Department is failing to collect tens of millions of dollars in lease payments for coal mining on federal lands, according to an agency inspector general’s report released Tuesday.

headline: The Ants Will Love You
text: There’s nothing wrong with a tuna fish sandwich eaten in an air-conditioned kitchen on a summer afternoon. But there’s something special about that same sandwich nibbled on a picnic blanket in the park.

headline: Academy’s Troubles Shadow Key Report
text: When a much-anticipated report defending the beleaguered liberal arts is released on Capitol Hill next week, it will come amid bad news beyond the usual lamentations about declining enrollments, slashed budgets and the perceived unemployability of English majors.

headline: U.S. Blacklists Fund-Raisers for Hezbollah
text: Retribution against Hezbollah for helping the Syrian government fight rebels intensified on Tuesday, as the United States blacklisted four fund-raising operatives and warned of further steps to choke the group’s financing.

headline: Hauling Your Feast to the Picnic
text: This week’s column focuses on the joys of picnics, and features recipes for three dishes that are easy to make, but not too fussy to haul to the park and eat on a blanket. One of the recipes is for a pan bagnat sandwich, which I show you how to make in this video.

headline: Three’s a Trend | The Desert Deco Aesthetic Takes Over Resort
text: Numerous resort shows — including Derek Lam, Bottega Veneta and Michael Kors — made use of bold, 1920s-inspired color blocking in unexpected earth tones on easy day-wear pieces. The result was sporty elegance, with a hint of urban safari.

headline: Asking Environmentalists Not to Fear the Reactor
text: Early in “Pandora’s Promise,” Mark Lynas, a British environmental activist, walks around the ghostly environs of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in Japan, near the second-worst nuclear disaster in history. There, amid spookily forsaken homes and cars, he talks about the 2011 earthquake and tsunami, as well as the meltdowns, and says he understands why people are afraid of nuclear power. Wearing a white Tyvek suit and knotting his forehead, he occasionally pauses to take a radiation reading with a meter no bigger than a cellphone. “So, are you still pro-nuclear?” asks a man off camera, presumably the director Robert Stone. Mr. Lynas squints at his interlocutor and asks, “Are you still pro-nuclear?”

headline: In Fields and Hives, Zooming In on What Ails Bees
text: If bees were to disappear from the globe, mankind would have four years left to live. That assertion, attributed to Albert Einstein but perhaps apocryphal, is voiced in “More Than Honey,” a fascinating but rambling documentary about the decimation of the world’s bee population through the phenomenon known as colony collapse disorder.

headline: Branch Falls on Tourist as She Walks Through Central Park
text: A 59-year-old tourist from Indiana was seriously injured on Tuesday afternoon when she was struck by a falling tree branch in Central Park, the authorities reported.

headline: Poll Finds Disapproval of Record Collection, but Little Personal Concern
text: In the wake of the exposure of two classified surveillance operations, most Americans expressed disapproval about the United States government’s collecting phone records of “ordinary” Americans. Yet, most showed little concern about their own Internet activities or phone calls’ being monitored.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Turkey, Russia, Afghanistan and England.

headline: Expensive Medicine
text: Rising prices — not waste — are the main force behind rising health care spending.

headline: N.S.A. Denies Phone Surveillance
text: During a hearing in March 2013, James Clapper, the director of national intelligence, denied widespread surveillance of American phone services.

headline: Thrilling New Chance to Get Queasy Is Planned for Coney Island
text: It won’t exactly be THE Thunderbolt, but it will definitely be the Thunderbolt: The city announced on Tuesday that a new roller coaster would open on Coney Island next year on the site of the old Thunderbolt, the roller coaster that once rivaled the Cyclone and makes a famous appearance in “Annie Hall.”

headline: Behind Kanye’s Mask
text: Malibu, Calif. — From Shangri-la Studio here you can see the Pacific Ocean just over the fence lapping calmly at Zuma Beach. And this compound is just as Zen, with recording equipment set up in various locations, including an old bus and a spotless white house with all the mirrors removed.

headline: Blackhawks Replace Stalberg With Bollig in Game 1
text: CHICAGO — Viktor Stalberg wore a white jersey at practice Tuesday afternoon and a scowl afterward. For the second time this postseason, Stalberg, the speedy Blackhawks winger, appeared to have caught the ire of Coach Joel Quenneville and is headed for the bench, the latest instance coming ahead of Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals against Boston Wednesday.

headline: A Sexual-Assault Measure to Be Cut From Military Bill
text: WASHINGTON — In a striking showdown between Senator Carl Levin, the chairman of the Armed Services Committee, and a member of his own party, Mr. Levin said on Tuesday that he would remove a measure aimed at curbing sexual assault in the military from a defense spending bill.

headline: City Argues to Overturn Ruling That Prevented Limits on Sugary Drinks
text: One justice asked if the city might limit scoops of ice cream. Another posed repeated questions about the nutritional content of an average milkshake. A lawyer, possibly hungered by the proceedings, raised the issue of steak size at Peter Luger.

headline: Top Three Will Tee Off in Rare Unit
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — Rory McIlroy, who recently moved to South Florida from Northern Ireland, has become an avid Miami Heat fan. Like most of his neighbors, he admires LeBron James, who happens to be a friend; he respects Dwyane Wade; and he wonders half the time what Chris Bosh is thinking.

headline: Tomic Loses While His Father Watches
text: LONDON – Bernard Tomic said he didn’t know his controversial father, John, was watching his match on a grey Tuesday at the Aegon Championships in west London.

headline: Ethics Panel Fines Lopez $330,000 in Harassment Case
text: ALBANY — Accusations of sexual misconduct have already cost Vito J. Lopez his job as a state assemblyman and his reputation. Now that misconduct will reach into his campaign coffers as well.

headline: Canadian Conflict Grows Out of Quebec Soccer Federation’s Ban on Turbans
text: The newest intersection of soccer and cultural controversy has an unusual address — Canada.

headline: Arturo Vega, Shepherd for the Ramones, Dies at 65
text: Arturo Vega, who was often called the fifth Ramone for serving as spokesman, logo designer, T-shirt salesman, lighting director and omnipresent shepherd for the Ramones, the speed-strumming punk quartet that helped rejuvenate rock in the mid-1970s, died on June 8 in Manhattan. He was 65.

headline: Earlier Denials Put Intelligence Chief in Awkward Position
text: WASHINGTON — For years, intelligence officials have tried to debunk what they called a popular myth about the National Security Agency: that its electronic net routinely sweeps up information about millions of Americans. In speeches and Congressional testimony, they have suggested that the agency’s immense power is focused exclusively on terrorists and other foreign targets, and that it does not invade Americans’ privacy.

headline: In a Town of Tough Crowds, García Is Taking a Conciliatory Approach
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — After shaking hands with Tiger Woods on Monday, Sergio García again displayed gracious behavior on Tuesday at Merion Golf Club, signing autographs at the driving range, making small talk, trying hard to win friends and influence people.

headline: Damien Hirst’s Spot Prices
text: A chart of the individual spot paintings sold and their price ranges, by year.

headline: Insurers Inflating Books, New York Regulator Says
text: New York State regulators are calling for a nationwide moratorium on transactions that life insurers are using to alter their books by billions of dollars, saying that the deals put policyholders at risk and could lead to another taxpayer bailout.

headline: If Patriots Have Plan for Tebow, It’s a Secret
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Bill Belichick smirked when he observed the unusually large news media contingent gathered for the start of the New England Patriots’ three-day minicamp.

headline: In a Shift, Interest Rates Are Rising
text: It has been a reliable fact of life for investors, corporations and ordinary borrowers: interest rates, for the most part, keep heading lower.

headline: Immigrants Reach Beyond a Legal Barrier for a Reunion
text: NOGALES, Ariz. — Three young immigrants had a jubilant and painful reunion here on Tuesday with parents who had been deported from the United States, sharing hugs through the steel bars of the border fence that separates this American town from its Mexican twin.

headline: Healing the Overwhelmed Physician
text: BOSTON — DURING an 1817 visit to Florence, the French author Marie-Henri Beyle, known by the pen name Stendhal, was seized by palpitations, dizziness and a feeling of being overwhelmed by the abundance of great art surrounding him; an Italian psychiatrist later coined the term Stendhal syndrome to describe this phenomenon.

headline: The Price of the Panopticon
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — THE revelation that the federal government has been secretly gathering records on the phone calls and online activities of millions of Americans and foreigners seems not to have alarmed most Americans. A poll conducted by the Pew Research Center over the four days immediately after the news first broke found that just 41 percent of Americans deemed it unacceptable that the National Security Agency “has been getting secret court orders to track telephone calls of millions of Americans to investigate terrorism.”

headline: Russia Passes Bill Targeting Some Discussions of Homosexuality
text: MOSCOW — The Russian Parliament passed a bill on Tuesday that imposes a fine for what it calls propagandizing “nontraditional” sexual relationships among minors, in the latest in a wave of socially conservative new rules here.

headline: Giving up Tuna? Breathing Is Next
text: If you’re like most people (including me, up until a month or two ago), you know that tuna and other top-of-the-food-chain fish contain unsafe levels of mercury and that childbirth-age women and nursing mothers, especially, are warned off these fish. What you don’t know, probably (I didn’t), is the mercury’s source, or how it gets in these fish.

headline: Hirst Counts the Dots, or at Least the Paintings
text: Damien Hirst’s spot paintings — some with dots about the size of pinholes, others 60 inches across — have long been celebrated, and disdained, for a certain anonymous, machinelike industrial uniformity.

headline: Blowing a Whistle
text: I’m glad I live in a country with people who are vigilant in defending civil liberties. But as I listen to the debate about the disclosure of two government programs designed to track suspected phone and e-mail contacts of terrorists, I do wonder if some of those who unequivocally defend this disclosure are behaving as if 9/11 never happened — that the only thing we have to fear is government intrusion in our lives, not the intrusion of those who gather in secret cells in Yemen, Afghanistan and Pakistan and plot how to topple our tallest buildings or bring down U.S. airliners with bombs planted inside underwear, tennis shoes or computer printers.

headline: When Patients and Suspects Just Don’t Fit
text: One morning a woman was wheeled into a cardiac unit in a hospital, and a team of doctors, nurses and technicians began the incredible voyage of threading a tiny camera through a blood vessel to her heart. All seemed to be going well. Then someone wandered into her hospital room and was startled to find the bed empty. A few minutes later, everyone realized she had been mistakenly taken to the cardiac lab, where the team quickly took out the camera.

headline: James K. Moyle
text: Mr. Moyle, 35, is the chief executive of RealtyTrac, an online marketplace for foreclosed residential properties and real estate data, based in Irvine, Calif. Mr. Moyle, who goes by the name Jamie, joined RealtyTrac in April 2012 as president and chief operating officer after RealtyTrac acquired the online company he founded, Homefacts. Before Homefacts, Mr. Moyle developed SkiWest, which was sold to Overstock.com in 2005.

headline: An Important Victory on Morning-After Pills
text: Reluctantly yielding to a federal-court decision, the Obama administration announced on Monday that it will take steps to allow a version of the so-called morning-after pill, known as Plan B One-Step, to be sold over the counter to girls and women of all ages. They will not need a prescription, nor will they be required to show any identification to obtain the emergency contraceptive. There will be no restrictions on where the drug can be sold; it will be up to the manufacturer to propose appropriate venues.

headline: Kidd Impresses Nets, Boosting Chances to Become Coach
text: Jason Kidd’s bid to become the next coach of the Nets appears to be gathering momentum, although no offer has been made yet and team officials are continuing their interview process.

headline: Lawyers Torn Over Suspect in Rampage at Fort Hood
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — The claim by Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan that he carried out a shooting rampage at Fort Hood in 2009 to protect Taliban leaders has outraged soldiers and military law experts. But another, more crucial group appeared to have a problem with it: his legal defense team.

headline: Patriots Reclamation Projects
text: Tim Tebow is the latest player whose career was at a crossroads before Bill Belichick stepped in.

headline: Expanding the Market for Audiobooks Beyond Commuters
text: READING the latest Dan Brown novel, “Inferno,” while driving a car or mowing the lawn would be perilous, but probably not for audiobook listeners.

headline: In Kosovo, Bridging an Ethnic Divide
text: Five years after Kosovo was carved from Serbia, the minority Serbs who live here doggedly reject Kosovo’s sovereignty, pretending that the new country does not exist.

headline: A Little Birdie Told Me
text: WASHINGTON — In her first two days on Twitter, Hillary Clinton did not bother to follow the man she wants to follow.

headline: Protests in North Carolina Challenge Conservative Shift in State Politics
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — By now, the sixth week that the police and protesters have faced off in a series of political rallies called Moral Mondays, everyone knew what to do.

headline: Judge Rules That Movie Studio Should Have Been Paying Interns
text: A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan ruled on Tuesday that Fox Searchlight Pictures had violated federal and New York minimum wage laws by not paying production interns, a case that could upend the long-held practice of the film industry and other businesses that rely heavily on unpaid internships.

headline: Discrimination in Housing Against Nonwhites Persists Quietly, U.S. Study Finds
text: Discrimination against blacks, Hispanics and Asians looking for housing persists in subtle forms, according to a new national study commissioned by the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. Though less likely to face overt obstacles, like being refused an appointment to see a home, minority customers were shown fewer available units than whites with similar qualifications, the study found.

headline: Lifting Restrictions of ‘Morning After’ Pill Has Little Impact for Drug Maker
text: Sometime in the months ahead, women who want to buy the emergency birth-control pill known as Plan B One-Step are likely to be spared the embarrassing ritual of asking for it at the pharmacy counter. Anyone will be able to grab it off the shelf in the women’s health aisle.

headline: A Speech in Spanish Is a First for the Senate
text: WASHINGTON — When Senator Tim Kaine, Democrat of Virginia, took the Senate floor on Tuesday to deliver a speech in support of an immigration overhaul bill, he did it in a way no senator had done before: entirely in Spanish.

headline: When Home Is a Memory
text: Maybe the name was part of the problem: Elzbieta Czyzewska. (Don’t try to spell it at home, please.)

headline: Same Couples, Reshuffled by a Mellowing Playwright
text: You don’t always know how much you’ve missed certain people until they show up in your life again. When Steph started bawling out Greg the other night, and rushing him as if he were a tackling dummy, I felt an oddly comforting warmth. “Oh, you two,” I said to myself, grinning. “You haven’t grown up at all.”

headline: Triple Scoop
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I will let you in on a little secret: I love ice cream cones, but if I am getting more than one flavor, I ask for the treat in a cup and plunk the cone on top. This way, I don’t have to worry about the cone toppling over or dripping down my hands, but I can still enjoy the cone part. No need to thank me. I’m dedicated to making this world a better place through strategic food consumption.

headline: Davis’s First Night in Vegas:  0 for 3, 2 Strikeouts
text: LAS VEGAS — The mission to mend the swing and the psyche of Ike Davis over the coming weeks will look much as it did at Cashman Field on Tuesday afternoon: a handful of men on a sun-scorched field, quietly trading thoughts and questions and encouragement.

headline: In Kosovo, Ethnic Barriers Linger as a New Accord Is Taking Effect
text: MITROVICA, Kosovo — A high barrier of sticks and stones blocks the main bridge over the Ibar River — put there by ethnic Serbs as a bulwark against their ethnic Albanian neighbors who live just a short walk away on the other side and, in theory at least, share the same territory, Kosovo.

headline: Robert W. Fogel, Nobel-Winning Economist, Dies at 86
text: Robert W. Fogel, a Nobel-winning economist whose number-crunching empiricism upended established thinking, most provocatively about the economics of slavery, died on Tuesday in Oak Lawn, Ill. He was 86.

headline: Unlike Jets, Patriots May Get Lift From Tebow
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Rex Ryan is going to need all the help he can get to survive beyond next season as the coach of the Jets. Bill Belichick, he suggested, might wish to contribute to the divisional cause by playing Tim Tebow.

headline: Murphy’s Error at First Proves Costly
text: Daniel Murphy no longer owns a first baseman’s mitt. He gave his old one to a college player at Jacksonville University, his alma mater, with the belief that his job as the Mets’ second baseman was permanent. After all, he appeared in 138 games at second last season and had been something of a fixture there this season.

headline: Behind Cry for Help From China Labor Camp
text: MASANJIA, China — The cry for help, a neatly folded letter stuffed inside a package of Halloween decorations sold at Kmart, traveled 5,000 miles from China into the hands of a mother of two in Oregon.

headline: In Blackhawks and Bruins, Unfamiliar, but Similar, Rivals
text: CHICAGO — The Boston Bruins and the Chicago Blackhawks are practically strangers, having last met on Oct. 15, 2011. Blackhawks Coach Joel Quenneville, though, believes that does not pose a tactical problem when the teams open the Stanley Cup finals on Wednesday night.

headline: Report Outlines Accusations of Misconduct by Diplomats
text: WASHINGTON — A former ambassador who oversaw an audit of the State Department’s Bureau of Diplomatic Security has outlined several cases of alleged misconduct by American diplomats and security agents as part of an inquiry into whether senior officials interfered with politically delicate investigations.

headline: Surveillance: A Threat to Democracy
text: A new Washington Post-Pew Research Center poll found that a majority of Americans are untroubled by revelations about the National Security Agency’s dragnet collection of the phone records of millions of citizens, without any individual suspicion and regardless of any connection to a counterterrorism investigation.

headline: Surveillance: Snowden Doesn’t Rise to Traitor
text: For several top lawmakers in Washington, Edward Snowden committed the ultimate political crime when he revealed to the world just how broadly and easily the government is collecting phone and Internet records. “He’s a traitor,” said John Boehner, the House speaker. “It’s an act of treason,” said Senator Dianne Feinstein, the chairwoman of the Intelligence Committee.

headline: Bloomberg’s Plan to Protect the Coast Focuses on Key Areas
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has proposed several major projects to protect the city and its economy from future flooding.

headline: In the Crash of Bull Horns, Echoes of a Desert Land of Old
text: AL FUJAYRAH, United Arab Emirates — When the fight the audience had been waiting for arrived, a hulking black bull named Rocket, whose horns had been filed to sharp points, strutted into the dirt lot used for this city’s bullfights.

headline: Cruising Through Town He Put on the Map
text: MODESTO, Calif. — George Lucas stepped out of a 1946 apricot-colored Mercury convertible and signed a few final autographs, mostly posters and photographs from “Star Wars.” Fans yelled, “We love you, George!” and “Welcome back home, George!” though Mr. Lucas was saying goodbye to his sisters and getting ready to leave. A black limousine took him away, making a sharp left before this city’s arch and its century-old slogan, faintly discernible in the twilight, “Water Wealth Contentment Health.”

headline: Lucas Revisits His ‘American Graffiti’ Roots
text: The American Graffiti Car Show festival drew the filmmaker George Lucas back to Modesto, Calif., for his first public role in his hometown in decades.

headline: Nicks Returns, but Cruz Doesn’t
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Hakeem Nicks arrived at Giants minicamp on Tuesday without an explanation for his surprising absence from the recent voluntary organized team activities.

headline: Obama Waves White Flag in Contraceptive Battle
text: WASHINGTON — After eight years of contentious legal battles about access to the morning-after pill, the federal government finally surrendered this week to a hostile district court judge and an appeals court that seemed to offer little hope of restricting access to the drug.

text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, embracing a top priority of government reformers and liberal groups, asked the Legislature on Tuesday to enact a system of public financing for state elections, modeled after one used in New York City.

headline: The New Subsidy for Layoffs
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Civil Rights Complaint Filed in Texas Truancy Cases
text: Advocacy groups have filed a civil rights complaint with the Justice Department on behalf of seven students in Texas. The move was to protest policies under which students are referred to truancy court.

headline: How Accurate Are Fitness Trackers?
text: Nate Meckes recognized that he needed to study the accuracy of activity monitors after wearing one. A shipment of the devices, known technically as accelerometers and designed to measure a person’s movement and energy expenditure, had arrived at Arizona State University, where Dr. Meckes was a researcher. To ensure they were operational, he slipped one over his hip and wore it throughout the day, including to an interminable meeting where he stood up and paced. “I’m not good at sitting still,” he says.

headline: The Nonstars Come Out

The N.B.A. finals cater to celebrity more than quiet workmanship, and these finals are thick with celebrities of every brand, stripe and vintage.

headline: China Celebrates First Dragon Boat Festival in Space
text: BEIJING — 2:37 p.m. | Updated Whenever Chinese astronauts blast off into space, there’s interest here on earth in China about what they will eat. As the saying goes: “for the people, food is heaven.”

headline: Alabama: Suit Is Filed to Block Abortion Clinic Law
text: Planned Parenthood and the American Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit in federal court Tuesday to block a new Alabama law that would force three of the state’s five abortion clinics to shut down. The law, like measures passed in Mississippi and North Dakota that are under challenge, would require doctors performing abortions to have admitting privileges at local hospitals. Proponents say it will protect patients in emergencies, but the clinics and prominent medical groups call it medically unnecessary and an unconstitutional effort to force the closing of the clinics in Birmingham, Mobile and Montgomery, which rely on visiting doctors.

headline: Using Humor to Get a Little Respect for Faster Play

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (Spike TV) SPIKE GUYS CHOICE 2013 This awards ceremony, taped on Saturday at Sony Picture Studios in Culver City, Calif., honors the things men like the most, as voted by viewers of Spike. Categories include the original dude, most dangerous man, our new girlfriend, best Lincoln, hottest Allison (or Alison) and outstanding literary achievement. Henry Cavill, Amy Adams, Russell Crowe and the director Zack Snyder receive the Most Manticipated Movie of the Year award for the new Superman film, “Man of Steel,” which opens on Friday. Ben Affleck is the Guy of the Year. And Burt Reynolds, above, receives the evening’s biggest tribute, the Alpha Male award.

headline: Spain Puts Its Depth on Display at Yankee Stadium
text: As Spain’s national team walked off the field at Yankee Stadium, unbeaten for the 22nd straight time, Frank Sinatra was, per stadium custom, singing about being “king of the hill.” With Spain having won three consecutive major tournaments, with a possible fourth on the horizon, the moment fittingly crossed sporting cultures.

headline: Leakers: Saints or Villains?
text: Daniel Ellsberg and Edward J. Snowden maintain that they performed a public service even as others label them traitors. Villains or saints, leakers often cast their actions as a kind of moral crusade.

text: TEL AVIV – As Indian municipal officials and water engineers search for ways to provide cleaner water to their nation’s 1.2 billion people, they are increasingly turning to Israel, which has solved many of the same problems that India is now experiencing.

text: NAHA, Japan — A Japanese man who was the world’s oldest living person, and the longest-lived man in recorded history, died Wednesday at the age of 116 at a hospital near the city of Kyoto.

headline: What Happens to Women Who Are Denied Abortions?
text: S. arrived alone at a Planned Parenthood in Richmond, Calif., four days before Christmas. As she filled out her paperwork, she looked at the women around her. Nearly all had someone with them; S. wondered if they also felt terrible about themselves or if having someone along made things easier. She began to cry quietly. She kept reminding herself that she felt secure in her decision. “I knew that that was going to be the right-wrong thing to do,” she told me later. “I was ready for it.”

headline: What Are the Most Important Innovations of the Last 50 Years?
text: The New York Times Magazine this weekend was a special “innovations” edition about modern inventions, from ant farms and A.T.M.’s to Web pages and zip lines.

headline: South African Leader Cites ‘Progress’ in Mandela’s Condition
text: JOHANNESBURG — After four days in the hospital battling a lung infection, former President Nelson Mandela of South Africa “is responding better to treatment,” President Jacob Zuma told Parliament in Cape Town on Wednesday.

headline: Behind Failure of Korean Talks, a Long History of Squabbling
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Plans for what would have been the highest government dialogue between North and South Korea in years — and hopes for a rapprochement on the divided Korean Peninsula — collapsed over what appeared to be a minor technical issue: who should lead their delegations to the planned talks.

headline: Tip of the Week: Force Yourself to Stop Wasting Time
text: If you find yourself wasting too much time puttering around on the Web instead of getting actual work done, products like RescueTime and FB Limiter temporarily lock you out of the sites you procrastinate on the most. Browser add-ons are another quick way to keep focused. For example, LeechBlock for Mozilla Firefox and Productivity Owl for Google Chrome let you add the Web addresses of the sites where you waste the most time, and will deny you access to those places when you try to sneak a peek instead of working. Both add-ons are free, but their creators gladly accept donations.

headline: Voice-Activated Technology Is Called Safety Risk for Drivers
text: As concerns have intensified about driver distraction from electronic gadgets, automakers have increasingly introduced voice-activated systems that allow drivers to keep their hands on the wheel and eyes on the road. But a new study says that the most advanced of these systems actually create a different, and worse, safety risk, by taking a driver’s mind, if not eyes, off the road.

headline: Money in a Bottle

headline: Vodafone Pursues a German Deal
text: The British wireless giant Vodafone has approached Kabel Deutschland of Germany over a potential takeover that could be worth more than $10 billion, DealBook’s Mark Scott reports. An acquisition would allow Vodafone, which owns 45 percent of Verizon Wireless, to expand its cellphone operations in Germany and offset increasing competition.

headline: Tips on Archiving Family History, Part 3
text: Readers sent dozens of questions about archiving and preserving family history and stories to Bertram Lyons, an archivist at the American Folklife Center of the Library of Congress in Washington. He was recently asked to be the editor of the International Association of Sound and Audiovisual Archives, an organization that aims to share best practices in the management of audiovisual materials internationally. He received his master’s degree in museum studies from the University of Kansas in 2009.

headline: Chart | An Irreverent Guide to Japanese Men’s Magazines

headline: Is Forced Fatherhood Fair?
text: This weekend millions of Americans will happily celebrate the role that fathers play in their families. For some families, though — specifically those in which dad’s role was not freely assumed, but legally mandated — Father’s Day can be an emotionally complicated occasion. And that somewhat messy reality raises a question that is worth examining today as the very definition of parents and families continues to undergo legal and social transformation.

headline: A Homing Beacon for Your Key Chain
text: In the ranks of nagging annoyances, the search for misplaced keys (especially when you are late) is pretty high.

headline: The Gun Report: June 12, 2013
text: Here’s something you don’t see every day: the wounds left by bullets after a shooting. Debra Fine, who was shot four times in Friday’s shooting rampage on the streets of Santa Monica, showed hers on Piers Morgan Live Monday night. Sitting next to her husband, she calmly pointed out the hole in her left shoulder. She held up her bloody shirt – what was left of it – and the yellow bruises all over her arms were clearly visible. Her right ear was bandaged, having been grazed by a bullet that whizzed uncomfortably close to her head.

headline: British Regulator Looking Into Currency Rates Trades
text: LONDON – Britain’s financial regulator said on Wednesday that it was examining claims that traders at large banks manipulated some foreign exchange benchmark rates and that it might start an official investigation.

headline: Caution, Not Panic, Over Spread of Middle East Virus

headline: The Risk of Doing Too Much in Syria
text: Richard N. Haass, president of the Council on Foreign Relations, cautions against doing too little or too much in Syria.

headline: Found Objects
text: What child hasn’t experienced the thrill of spotting the gleam of sudden treasure — a coin, a toy, a bauble of one sort or the other — lying on the sidewalk or hidden in the grass? Most young children are well versed in the politics of possession, and are acutely aware of what belongs to them and what belongs to someone else. But what about the found item? Two new picture books explore the mysterious world of chanced-upon objects and the questions they pose: Who lost this? Is it mine now? Should I try to return it?

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Washington Post: As any Amtrak regular knows, you skip the microwaved sandwiches and soggy Amburgers and buy your meal at the station before you board. But the rail line’s Culinary Advisory Team – which includes Sara Jenkins, the chef of Porsena and Porchetta — is cooking up potential dishes like a braised pork chop with persillade on a bed of white beans and roasted vegetables. — Patrick Farrell

headline: News Finds New Ways to Flow as Greek State Broadcaster Is Shut
text: ATHENS — Private television channels here suspended their news coverage as of 6 a.m. Wednesday in solidarity with employees of the state broadcaster, ERT, which was shut down by the government on Tuesday, while newspaper headlines conveyed the shock felt by many Greeks at the closing of a 75-year-old institution that had employed 2,900 people.

headline: Are We Still at War?

Bush the authority to invade Afghanistan, to tackle the Taliban and Al Qaeda and others “who planned, authorized, committed or aided” the 9/11 terrorist attacks. Only one lawmaker voted against the bill in either chamber.
