text: The final winner in our fourth annual Found Poetry Student Contest is Katie, 14, from Herndon, Va. Her poem is taken from the article “Tantalizing New Clues Into the Mysteries of Dark Matter.”

headline: Hey, Hey, Hey: Bill Cosby on ‘Fat Albert,’ Yesterday and Today
text: For audiences of a certain generation, their introduction to Bill Cosby was not through his kinetic stand-up comedy and not as the wisecracking household head Dr. Cliff Huxtable on “The Cosby Show.” To these viewers who grew up glued to their TV sets on Saturday mornings, Mr. Cosby was first and foremost an overweight neighborhood kid with a rallying cry of “Hey, hey, hey!”; as well as a bucktoothed adolescent with an unusual speech impediment; and, somehow, a more youthful version of himself.

headline: A Small Company’s Reality Is Altered by ABC’s ‘Shark Tank’
text: It has been about a month since ABC showed the season finale of “Shark Tank,” the reality show that gives entrepreneurs in search of financing a chance to plead their cases before five tough-talking investors, or “sharks.” At VerbalizeIt, a technology start-up that was part of this season’s final segment, the effects of the show’s appearance can already be quantified.

headline: Regulatory Nominee Vows to Speed Up Energy Reviews
text: WASHINGTON — The White House has blocked several Department of Energy regulations that would require appliances, lighting and buildings to use less energy and create less global-warming pollution, as part of a broader slowdown of new antipollution rules issued by the Obama administration.

headline: Relighting the Lamp
text: The Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island, badly damaged by Hurricane Sandy, are scheduled to reopen on July 4, in time for Independence Day fireworks. As before the storm, visitors will be screened in Lower Manhattan, a reversal of the National Park Service’s plan to begin letting visitors board boats and be checked later on Ellis Island. That plan came under attack after Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York warned it could leave the statue vulnerable to a terrorist attack.

headline: Protecting American High-End Research as China Rises
text: BEIJING — If the authors of a new book, “Chinese Industrial Espionage,” are right, and China is carrying out one of the greatest intellectual heists of history in its systematic transfer of the advanced research and development of other nations — including the West, Japan and elsewhere — to China, what can the world do to protect its intellectual property?

headline: Is It Worth a Piece of Your Company to Appear on ‘Shark Tank’?
text: VerbalizeIt Shark Tank Episode.

headline: IFC Orders Two More Seasons of ‘Portlandia’
text: The dream of the ’90s will continue until at least 2015: the IFC cable channel said on Wednesday that it had picked up two further seasons of “Portlandia,” its popular sketch comedy series with Fred Armisen and Carrie Brownstein about life in a city that is similar but not identical to Portland, Ore., where alternative culture still thrives and where, as one character put it, “young people go to retire.”

headline: Given a Shot, Spurs’ Neal Makes It Count
text: SAN ANTONIO — The message on the scoreboard exhorted the Spurs’ fans at AT&T Center to yell during the third-quarter timeout, so they did, but not nearly as loudly — or with as much authenticity of feeling — as when play resumed. That is when Gary Neal faked, then dribbled around the Miami Heat’s Mike Miller, and past LeBron James, before unspooling a running, off-balance teardrop from the edge of the paint.

headline: Gardening Advice for Aging Bodies and Minds
text: This week’s Ask an Expert features Patty Cassidy, who will answer questions on how to use outdoor spaces and gardens to improve health and well-being, and what to do when the physical challenges of aging or mental challenges such as dementia and Alzheimer’s come into play.

headline: ‘The Greek House’ by Christian Brechneff
text: After reading “The Greek House” by the painter Christian Brechneff (written with Tim Lovejoy; Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27), I wanted to drop everything and go to Sifnos, the rocky island in the Aegean Sea lovingly portrayed in his memoir But that would require time-travel, to visit the Sifnos Mr. Brechneff first saw as a 21-year-old aspiring artist in the summer of 1972, a place that had goat trails for roads and lacked even a ferry dock, let alone the yachts that clog the modern-day harbor.

headline: Image of the Day: June 12
text: Sikhs commemorate the martyrdom of one of their gurus in New Delhi.

headline: Pope Is Quoted Referring to a Vatican ‘Gay Lobby’
text: ROME — For years, perhaps even centuries, it has been an open secret in Rome: That some prelates in the Vatican hierarchy are gay. But the whispers were amplified this week when Pope Francis himself, in a private audience, appears to have acknowledged what he called a “gay lobby” operating inside the Vatican, vying for power and influence.

headline: The Risks of America Doing Too Much in Syria
text: NEW YORK — Richard N. Haass, president of the Council on Foreign Relations, the American foreign policy think tank, sat down with Rendezvous’s editor Marcus Mabry to talk Syria. Mr. Haass gave a long laundry list of what issues are more important to the United States than the bloodbath in Syria, even as he detailed the risks of that widening conflict.

headline: The Children of Taksim
text: ISTANBUL — Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan had warned that his patience was running thin. On Tuesday morning it finally ran out: Police used water cannons and tear gas to shoo away the protesters who have been occupying Taksim Square for more than a week to save the neighboring Gezi Park from redevelopment. The crackdown turned this major thoroughfare into what a Hollywood agent would pitch as Woodstock meets Mad Max 4.

headline: Overhaul Efforts in Washington Reflect Few Lessons of Housing Crisis
text: Nearly five years after the government took over the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, Congress is slouching toward remaking how Americans buy homes.

headline:
Dozens of Shiites
Reported Killed in
Raid by Syria Rebels
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — At least 30 Shiite Muslim villagers in eastern Syria were killed in a reprisal raid by rebels, the government and opposition fighters and activists said Wednesday, the latest in a string of massacres underscoring the increasingly sectarian nature of the Syrian conflict.

headline: Year-End Round Up, 2012-13 | Language Arts, Journalism and the Arts
text: Anatomy of a Scene: Baz Luhrmann’s “Great Gatsby”

headline: Morgenthau to Step Down as Chairman of Museum of Jewish Heritage
text: The developer Bruce C. Ratner will succeed Robert M. Morgenthau, the former Manhattan district attorney, as chairman of the Museum of Jewish Heritage — A Living Memorial to the Holocaust, the museum announced Wednesday.

headline: Journalist Held in Beijing, Friends Say
text: BEIJING — A Chinese journalist who recently released a documentary about a forced-labor camp and has worked as a freelance photographer for The New York Times has been detained by police officers in Beijing, his friends and family members said this week.

headline: Standoff Ends After Police Discover Suspect Was Not There
text: A standoff outside an apartment in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday ended peacefully after the police determined that the man they were looking for, a suspect wanted in connection with a 2010 killing of a Pace University student, was not there.

headline: If It’s June, the Blackhawks’ Hossa Must Be in the Stanley Cup Finals
text: CHICAGO — Marian Hossa has been here before; he knows the drill. He has faced the cameras, answered the questions and endured the dog and pony show of Stanley Cup media day.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. 2, Panama 0
text: The Hexagonal reached its halfway point, and after a convincing 2-0 win over Panama on Tuesday night in Seattle, the United States national soccer team now sits safely in first place.

headline: Burberry’s Kiss and Sell
text: Burberry’s latest online foray is a virtual kissing booth. The company, working with Google, introduced a promotion on Wednesday called Burberry Kisses, in which you can capture an image of yourself puckering up and then send it to someone. While this may sound a little cutesy or silly, everyone in the industry pays close attention to whatever Burberry, which has been ahead of most brands in embracing digital innovation, does online.

headline: Actors Make Videos in Push for Campaign Finance Reform
text: ALBANY — It may not have the political sex appeal of fighting climate change, ending the war on drugs or thwarting hydrofracking, but the issue of campaign finance reform is getting a little celebrity spin this week, compliments of a series of Web videos being released on Wednesday.

headline: Bringing an Ancient Art Form to the Edge of Modern Manhattan
text: Kevin Sudeith, 47, climbed up a wooded area in northern Manhattan recently and stood in front of a rock outcropping that looked as if it had been visited by a group of industrious cave men – albeit ones with art degrees and a working knowledge of modern aircraft.

headline: 36 Hours in Oslo
text: Has Oslo priced even itself out of the city? These days, the most appealing areas in the famously expensive Norwegian capital lie on the periphery of the city center, in its newly trendy neighborhoods — hip Grunerlokka to the northeast, glamorous Tjuvholmen to the southwest — and beyond, in the glorious landscapes of the Oslo Fjord and the sprawling northern forests. Granted, downtown still harbors a version of “The Scream,” by Norway’s best-known painter, Edvard Munch, whose birth 150 years ago is being celebrated here all year. But more buzz now surrounds the dazzling architectural landmarks — the sinuous art museum that opened last year and the angular opera house — anchoring the city’s renewed waterfront. Today, to properly explore Oslo’s finest attractions, expect to wander widely.

headline: Scenes From Oslo
text: Coffee and cocktails, beers and beaches are all part of 36 Hours in Norway’s capital city.

headline: R.B.S. Chief to Step Down
text: 4:07 p.m. | Updated

headline: Winfrey Gives $12 Million to New Smithsonian Museum of Black History and Culture
text: Oprah Winfrey is giving $12 million to help build the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington, the museum announced on Tuesday.

headline: Red Square Bike Share
text: Moscow has a new public bike-share program. Thirty-two mobile solar-powered docking stations opened earlier this month with about 220 bikes. More docking stations are planned by the end of the year. The program was developed by the city with the Bank of Moscow. Other recent bike-friendly amenities include bike racks on public transportation, parking structures and new cycle paths. Cyclists can register by the day, week, month or season, starting at 100 rubles (about $3) a day, and are then charged 60 rubles (about $1.85) every hour. The first 30 minutes are free. Registration is available at the program’s Web site (velobike.ru); an English-language version is planned.

headline: In Nepal, Exiled Each Month
text: In far western Nepal, many believe that women who are menstruating are impure and bring bad luck. And so they are exiled each month, leaving them vulnerable to rape and other horrors.

headline: A Cheetah’s Turn
text: They are the fastest animal on land, but new research shows that much of their predatory success is based not on sprinting, but on stopping and starting with extraordinary agility.

headline: Cheetahs’ Secret Weapon: A Tight Turning Radius
text: Anyone who has watched a cheetah run down an antelope knows that these cats are impressively fast. But it turns out that speed is not the secret to their prodigious hunting skills: a novel study of how cheetahs chase prey in the wild shows that it is their agility — their skill at leaping sideways, changing directions abruptly and slowing down quickly — that gives those antelope such bad odds.

headline: $50,000 Book Prize for Military History Established
text: The spoils of war, or at least the spoils of writing about war, have just gotten richer, thanks to a new $50,000 prize for the best book in military history, to be awarded annually starting in February 2014.

headline: Wall Street Titans Celebrate UJA-Federation
text: When the hedge fund manager Daniel S. Och called Bruce J. Richards, chief executive of Marathon Asset Management, it was not to discuss the latest gossip around their building, 15 Central Park West, which is home to several Wall Street heavyweights.

headline: Wheelies: The Fabled Ferrari Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: An Agile Hunter
text: Cheetahs hunting prey depend more on agility and rapid acceleration than on speed.

headline: Bulger Is Many Unsavory Things, Lawyer Says, but No Informant
text: BOSTON — On the opening day of his much-anticipated trial here on Wednesday, James (Whitey) Bulger was reputed to be many things, even by his own lawyer — among them, a bookmaker, drug dealer and loan shark who made “millions and millions” of dollars from his underworld dealings.

headline: Data, Data, What Do You See?
text: David Brooks: Gail, my general view of politics is that at their core people want government to provide order.

headline: When Hearing Aids Won’t Do
text: Most older adults choose not to use hearing aids. Many find them too expensive, difficult to manipulate, embarrassing — or just too poignant a reminder of advancing age.

headline: Fish Nets Found to Kill Large Numbers of Birds
text: Fishing vessels that deploy gill nets snare and drown at least 400,000 seabirds every year, and the actual figure could be considerably higher, according to research published in the June edition of an academic journal devoted to conservation.

headline: The Management Buyout Path of Less Resistance
text: David H. Murdock’s effort to take the Dole Food Company private shows how a recent Delaware case has made these types of management buyouts easier, perhaps too easy.

headline: Centerview Hires 2 Senior Media Bankers From Morgan Stanley
text: Centerview Partners said on Wednesday that it had poached two senior media bankers from Morgan Stanley in the latest hiring by the boutique investment bank.

headline: ‘Ann’ to Close on Broadway
text: “Ann,” Holland Taylor’s solo show about the former Texas governor Ann Richards, will close on June 30 at Lincoln Center’s Vivian Beaumont Theater, two months before its scheduled closing date of Sept. 1, the show’s producers announced on Wednesday. Directed by Benjamin Endsley Klein, “Ann” opened on Broadway in March to mostly positive reviews and was extended once. But weekly grosses never surpassed $400,000, and in recent weeks it has never played to more than 50 percent of its capacity at the Beaumont.

headline: Boehner Endorses House Farm Bill
text: The House farm bill received a major endorsement on Wednesday when Speaker John A. Boehner announced that he would support the agriculture and nutrition legislation that the chamber is to begin work on this month.

headline: N.S.A. Leaker Says He Will Fight Extradition in Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG — Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency computer technician who has acknowledged leaking highly classified documents about the United States government’s monitoring of Internet and telephone communications, told a Hong Kong newspaper on Wednesday that he planned to stay in the city and fight extradition.

headline: Facebook Adds Hashtags to Organize Public Conversations
text: 4:42 p.m. | Updated Added more explanation of how hashtag searching works.

headline: Michelle Dockery of ‘Downton Abbey’ Is Regal in Purple
text: The Girl: The actress at a panel for the show in North Hollywood, Calif.

headline: Lincoln Answers His Critics
text: Today we widely understand that Abraham Lincoln’s use of presidential war powers was indispensible to his success. But one of his biggest problems at the time was convincing the Northern public that suspending habeas corpus and other restraints on civil liberties were both temporary and constitutional, and that their enforcement was necessary to win the war.

headline: A Glimpse of Where Chicago Hockey Was in 1934
text: CHICAGO — Here is a bit more Original Six lore as we await Wednesday night’s opener of the Chicago-Boston Stanley Cup finals. We turn to the University of Chicago Library and its online copy of the Oct. 1, 1934, issue of The Chicagoan, a magazine of the period that was meant to be the Second City’s version of The New Yorker, and the article “Falconer McLaughlin: The Boss of the World’s Champion Black Hawks.”

headline: Paul Westerberg on How to Write an Ending
text: That quirky, lovable riff on songwriting that Paul Westerberg wrote for The Times recently got me thinking of a tip that I picked up from him many years ago. Not personally. It was from an article in Musician, a long-gone magazine that I was addicted to as a teenager. I remember Westerberg talking about how he often wrote a brand-new part at the end of his songs because when he was a kid listening to the radio, it bugged him when the tunes just repeated and faded out. So lazy! Why stop being creative before the song was over? Throw something new in there, man, give people a reason to listen to the end.

headline: Tip Sheet: Determining College Fit and Value
text: Gloria Cordes Larson is the president of Bentley University, a private institution in Waltham, Mass.

headline: Annabel Tollman: The Calm Amid Fashion’s Storm
text: The core code of conduct governing fashion can sometimes be characterized as jungle law. According to the unspoken rules of the business, the person you had dinner with last night might, if it is expedient, cut you dead at a fashion show the following morning. Somehow this ugly reality is found usual and acceptable.

headline: The Great Assimilation Debate
text: Now that the immigration bill is actually moving through the Senate, it seems worth returning to the debate over recent patterns in immigrant assimilation that I discussed in a column back in April. That piece made the point that while today’s second-generation immigrants still seem to be making real gains compared to their parents, there’s a fair amount of evidence showing a subsequent stall-out in advancement — both educational and economic, and particularly noticeable among the descendants of immigrants from Latin America — that leaves later generations stuck well short of full integration into the American middle class. If true, this would lend credence to the worry, common among immigration reform skeptics but apparently rarer among United States senators, that the accelerated pace of low-skilled immigration contemplated by the current legislation might be a recipe for ever-greater socioeconomic stratification.

headline: Love and Hate for Apple’s New Mobile Software
text: Apple this week unveiled a major redesign for iOS, the mobile software system running on iPhones and iPads. The software, called iOS 7, adopts a “flat” design principle that simplifies the look, while introducing thin typography and a vibrant color palette.

headline: Queens of the Stone Age Earns Its First No. 1
text: It was a good week for the rock and country genres, as five of the Top 10 albums on the Billboard 200 came from rock bands of various flavors and three belonged to country singers.

headline: Lincoln MKZ Hybrid Is Aimed at Progressive Luxury Buyers Who Also Like Quiet
text: Coffee creamer matters. That was one of the lessons offered by Kimberly Cape, marketing manager for Lincoln, at a ride and drive event for the 2013 MKZ Hybrid in Manhattan on Tuesday.

headline: House Panel Advances Bill to Restrict Abortions
text: WASHINGTON — Legislation that would outlaw nearly all abortions after the 22nd week of pregnancy was put on a fast track to the House floor on Wednesday after being approved in committee on a party-line vote.

headline: Rape and Abortion, Again
text: Did G.O.P. Rep. Trent Franks pull a Todd Akin?

headline: Malone May Play Role of Spoiler in Cable Deal
text: Vodafone’s ambitions in Germany could be undone by the king of cable.

headline: Texas Comes North to Poach Business
text: New York radio listeners, give it up for Gov. Rick Perry of Texas.

headline: A Tablet That Doubles as a Desktop, or Vice Versa
text: The big breakthrough was the iPad: a flat, thin, beautiful, nearly buttonless computer, all touch screen. But that was three years ago.

headline: Hearing Loss Takes a Health Toll
text: Hearing loss in older adults increases the risk for hospitalization and poor health, a new study has found, even taking into account other risk factors.

headline: After Setbacks, Del Potro Looks to Return to Form
text: LONDON – Juan Martín del Potro of Argentina did not overexert himself in practice Monday.

headline: Scene City: Blue Skies for Shakespeare
text: Shakespeare in the Park holds its annual gala in Central Park.

headline: Three’s a Trend | The Moody Blues Return (to Women’s Wear)
text: The predominant hue to emerge from resort collections this season is an intensely rich shade of indigo. The deep inky blue added intrigue to simple monochromatic ensembles like the floor-length sheath and coat from The Row, Dior‘s classic bar suit and Calvin Klein‘s relaxed, slouchy trousers paired with a suede boat-neck top.

headline: Miller Barber, 82, Golf Champion With Odd Swing, Dies
text: Miller Barber, who wielded an unorthodox swing in becoming a leading player on the PGA Tour in the 1960s and a dominant one in the early years of senior play, died on Tuesday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 82.

headline: Q&A: Making New Playlists on the iPod Classic
text: Q.

headline: The Stars Come Out for Shakespeare in the Park
text: The rain was so intense Monday that Shakespeare in the Park had to cancel its annual gala in Central Park, which included a $1,500 dinner for 950 on the untented lawn.

headline: 2 Scaffold Workers Rescued From Outside 45th Floor
text: Two scaffold maintenance workers who were stranded 500 feet above the streets of Midtown Manhattan for nearly two hours after their work platform snapped were rescued on Wednesday by New York City firefighters.

headline: Spurs Expose the Risks of Heat’s Scrambling Defense
text: The dominant Miami Heat team that dismantled the San Antonio Spurs’ offense in the second half of Game 2, was, in a nominal sense, the same group that took the court in Game 3 Tuesday night. The results could not have been more different. The Spurs blistered the Heat from deep and left them ragged and gasping for breath on the way to a comprehensive 113-77 victory.

headline: Shopping Events, Sales and Openings for the Week of June 13
text: Father’s Day

headline: ‘Steve Harvey’ Talk Show Gains an Extension
text: Steve Harvey’s daytime talk show, which had its debut last September, will remain on television through at least 2016 thanks to a series of deals announced Wednesday by its distributor, NBCUniversal.

headline: Study Shows Pill Prevents H.I.V. Among Drug Addicts
text: Drug-injecting addicts who took a daily antiretroviral pill were half as likely to become infected with H.I.V. as those who did not, a major new study has found, providing the final piece of evidence that such treatments can prevent AIDS in every group at risk. Earlier clinical trials showed that the therapy can sharply reduce the risk of H.I.V. transmission from mother to child, and in gay and bisexual men and heterosexuals.

headline: Obama Speaks at Rally for Massachusetts Democrat
text: BOSTON — President Obama drew a crowd of thousands to a campaign rally for Representative Edward J. Markey on Wednesday, an event that seemed intended to generate a push of energy two weeks before the end of a relatively sleepy campaign.

headline: Northside Festival Saves Brooklyn Bands the Airfare to Austin
text: The Northside Festival grew out of a simple question posed by its organizers, the brothers Scott and Daniel Stedman, about five years ago. The Stedmans, who founded The L Magazine a decade ago to record the goings on around Williamsburg, realized that every year, many of the musicians, managers and record labels in Brooklyn’s indie rock scene were trekking en masse to Austin, Tex., for the South by Southwest music festival, which had become the country’s most important forum for new bands.

headline: A Workout for Your Brain, on Your Smartphone
text: I often say I have a bad memory. In fact, it is perfectly possible for me to lose track of what I’m writing in the middle of a ... um ... never mind. To improve my memory and enhance my other brain skills, I love doing mental math, logic and word puzzles. Nowadays, my smartphone hosts a whole range of tools to help with this.

headline: Monfils, Soaring on the Grass, Will Miss Wimbledon
text: HALLE WESTFALEN, Germany — Keeping the ball inside the white lines is normally the most immediate concern to a tennis player. But for Gaël Monfils, awareness of the outermost dimensions of the court’s barriers is equally crucial, for reasons of personal safety.

headline: Pixels Floating on the Art World’s Margins
text: LOS ANGELES — The annual E3 convention here is known for the glitzy premiere of video games with huge budgets, and for its boisterous hustle and bustle. But tucked between the two rowdy convention halls is a quieter area resembling a Chelsea art gallery.

headline: An Only Child, Happy With a Big Family
text: Taking Sides

headline: An Only Child, Happy With an Only Child
text: Taking Sides

headline: The Fake News Has a Fake Host for Three Months
text: It’s still “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart,” only now it’s without Jon Stewart.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Turkey, Pakistan, Greece and Gaza Strip.

headline: Bloomberg Storm Plan Praised, but Faces Obstacles
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s $20 billion program to armor New York City against climate change over the next decade includes extensive details, right down to the size of the concrete bulkheads proposed for the coast of Queens.

headline: The Full Spectrum of One-Acts, Antic to Squeamish to Dark
text: Series C of Ensemble Studio Theater’s Marathon of One-Act Plays pulls audience members through all sorts of emotions, including discomfort, but it sends them out laughing, and not in a genteel way.

headline: Real Estate for $899,000
text: Represented this week: Late 19th-Century homes in Ohio, Denver and Florida.

headline: What You Get for ... $899,000
text: TITUSVILLE, FLA.

headline: A Show About Nothing but Comedy
text: Jerry Seinfeld’s Web series, “Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee,” consists of little more than Mr. Seinfeld driving around and chatting about work and life with other comedians in 10- to 20-minute episodes shot on sunny days in and around New York or Los Angeles. Among its most frequent topics are his wealth and copious free time — “Coffee, liquor, money, is that your life now?” his “Seinfeld” cast mate Michael Richards asks — and these seem to be reflected in the show’s indolent, contented rhythms and (for short-format online video) high production values.

headline: Shows to Catch at the Northside Festival in Brooklyn
text: Here are a few shows of note during the Northside Festival in Brooklyn, starting on Thursday. (A full schedule is online at northsidefestival.com/music/)

headline: Keeping Score: Which Statistics Show Path to the Cup?
text: Carlton Chin, a portfolio strategist and fund manager, and Jay Granat, psychotherapist, are the authors of “Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method.”  They have previously written on the N.B.A. finals, N.C.A.A. men’s basketball final and last year’s Stanley Cup finals.

headline: A Start for a ‘Neighborhood of Art’ in Houston
text: The landscape architect Michael Van Valkenburgh has been appointed to enhance and expand the Menil Collection’s 30-acre campus in Houston, the museum is scheduled to announce on Thursday.

headline: A Town House on the Côte Basque
text: A 1920s-era property in Biarritz with city views and elaborate floor medallions is on the market for  $2.29 million.

headline: House Hunting on ... the Côte Basque
text: A RENOVATED TOWN HOUSE IN BIARRITZ

headline: Times Co.’s Thompson to Testify in Parliament on BBC
text: Mark Thompson, president and chief executive of The New York Times Company, is being recalled by the British Parliament to answer questions about testimony he gave in 2011 on a program called the Digital Media Initiative, which he oversaw when he was director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation.

headline: Cheerfully Soldiering on as the End Draws Near
text: If you were on a sinking ship, the title character of J. B. Priestley’s “Cornelius” would be just the man you’d like as your captain, at least as embodied by Alan Cox in the wonderful production at 59E59 Theaters, part of the Brits Off Broadway festival. It’s not that Cornelius is so resourceful that he would save you from drowning.

headline: Manly Manicures End in Color
text: A couple of weekends a month, Tom McMahon, 44, a federal government budget analyst who lives in Scottsdale, Ariz., joins his wife for a special indulgence, squeezed in around brunch and his regular Sunday touch rugby games: simultaneous pedicures, complete with nail polish as the finishing touch. Mr. McMahon, who is 6-foot-4 and weighs 270 pounds, typically chooses a decidedly bold color for his toes, often either China Glaze’s Gaga for Green, a hue that brings Kermit the Frog to mind, or Gargantuan Green Grape, a pastel by OPI that suggests pistachio ice cream.

headline: Unproductive Finance
text: More than half a century ago, in his classic paper on the economics of speculation, Paul Samuelson noted the perverse rewards to knowing stuff just slightly before everyone else. He asked readers to imagine someone who, somehow, consistently received crucial information one second before everyone else. As he pointed out, the social value of that extra second would be minimal; but the private rewards could be huge.

headline: Father’s Day Grooming Gift Ideas
text: Trying to buy the perfect gift for Father’s Day (it’s this Sunday) can stump even the most creative minds. Grooming products are usually a safe bet. Hundreds of lotions and colognes flood the market this time of year; here are three worthy options.

headline: A Mother’s Bond Stretches to a Far Side of the World
text: Lea Carpenter’s “Eleven Days” is an utter paradox. It is at once a deeply affecting story about a mother and a son that attests to the debut of an extraordinarily gifted writer and a conceptually flawed novel about a fictional Navy SEAL raid that just happens to take place on May 2, 2011, the same night as the one that killed Osama bin Laden.

headline: Melissa McCarthy, Pushing Boundaries
text: Images from the career of the actress.

headline: Five Underground Dance Clubs
text: Bossa Nova, Marquee, TBA, Verboten and Outpost are five examples of the ’90s dance club revival.

headline: In Japan, a Growth Strategy With Echoes of the Past
text: TOKYO — DIGITAL medical records. Special economic zones. Structural reforms.

headline: Insurance Tyranny
text: Many of us wish that Obamacare were a simpler system, one that directly provided health insurance. Political reality, unfortunately, ensured that many people will receive coverage from private insurers, selling policies — often with subsidies — on the “exchanges”. And naturally enough, the Obama administration is teaming up with the insurers and other parts of the health industry to help inform Americans of the benefits to which they will be legally entitled, starting Jan. 1.

headline: Messi Is Being Investigated for Tax Evasion
text: MADRID — Lionel Messi, the F.C. Barcelona star, and his father face a tax evasion investigation, after a prosecutor accused them Wednesday of defrauding the state of about 4 million euros.

headline: The Night Comes Back to Life: The Return of the ’90s Dance Club
text: Looking like engine parts from an alien spacecraft, the looming speakers thundered with enough bass to make one’s esophagus flutter. Red LCDs pulsed above. On the dance floor, a sea of guys in dress shirts nodded under the rhythmic necromancy of DVS1, a D.J. from Minneapolis.

headline: Kids Dance at Ballet Tech
text: The troupe will perform at the Joyce Theater Thursday through Sunday.

headline: As Putin Tries to Charm World Expo Voters, Protesters March Again in Moscow
text: As the Kremlin continued its campaign “to show as many people as possible that Russia is a normal country” by winning the right to host yet another international event, thousands of distinctly off-message protesters marched through Moscow on Wednesday, calling for the release of political prisoners and a “Russia without Putin.”

headline: A School for Young Dancers Grows Up
text: One recent afternoon at the dance school Ballet Tech, the choreographer Eliot Feld watched as Joyce Ha, an angelic young student, rehearsed a solo from his exuberant and charming “Meshugana Dance.” Over its raucous klezmer music, he shouted: “I can’t count your teeth! How many are there?”

headline: Lauded, but Not Resting on His Laurels
text: During the first 19 years of his life the pianist, violinist and composer Conrad Tao has achieved more than many artists do in twice as many years. Still a student in a Columbia University-Juilliard School joint-degree program, Mr. Tao has earned an Avery Fisher Career Grant, a Gilmore Young Artist Award and eight consecutive Ascap Morton Gould Young Composer Awards, to name only a few of his accolades.

headline: Google Offers Some Detail About How It Transfers Data to the Government
text: Google has offered a few more details about how it shares user data with the government, including in response to national security requests.

headline: The Many Looks of Kylie Minogue
text: Ms. Minogue is trying, one more time in a two-decade-plus career, to break into the American market, in part by reframing herself as a fashion icon.

headline: Shopping With Kylie Minogue
text: The Australian singer Kylie Minogue reflects on her experiences working with renowned international designers and reveals her personal style.

headline: Tip of the Week: Go Offline With Google Maps for Android
text: The Google Maps app for Android includes an “offline” feature that lets you store a map on your phone for those times when your data signal is weak or nonexistent.

headline: E-Cigarettes Are in Vogue and at a Crossroads
text: PARIS — On a recent day in the shadow of the Arc de Triomphe, a line of 20 people spilled onto the sidewalk of a trendy new boutique, eager to get a taste of its latest gourmet offerings.

headline: Kylie Minogue: Pop Star, Fashion Darling ... Who?
text: Kylie Minogue, the Australian pop star known in the United States for long-ago dance hits like “The Loco-Motion” and “Can’t Get You Out of My Head,” was having tea in the Astor Court of the St. Regis hotel on a recent spring Sunday, unrecognized in a nude-colored Moschino dress (which would have been a long-sleeved T-shirt on most) with a winking face illustrated on the front.

headline: José Parlá, Barclays Center Muralist
text: José Parlá stood inside the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, staring proudly at the giant mural he had painted, partly at the urging of Jay-Z.

headline: In Florida, the USA-2 Bermuda Bowl Bridge Team Is Born
text: The USA-2 Bermuda Bowl team is Martin Fleisher, Michael Kamil, Zia Mahmood, Chip Martel, Michael Rosenberg and Chris Willenken. On the last day of the open trial, in Orlando, Fla., in a 90-board match, they defeated Nick Nickell, Ralph Katz, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell by 194 international match points to 146.

headline: Greeks React to Shutting of Broadcaster
text: Hellenic Broadcasting Corporation employees, union workers and citizens staged protests after the Greek government’s closing of the state-run television and radio outlet.

headline: Day-Night Doubleheader Dresses
text: Putting together a summertime day-to-night outfit, work appropriate and breezy, can be a bit of a wardrobe challenge: how to feel confident and fabulous at the office, then chic (and fabulous, of course) in the evening without carrying a change of clothes.

headline: Beat Publication Celebrates Rock’s Cast of Characters
text: It’s hard to believe that Beat, a free print publication with top fashion photographers shooting its covers, actually exists, let alone exists under the radar. The twice-yearly newspaper out of East London can be spotted just behind the counter at Bookmarc and Opening Ceremony. Founded by the D.J. and writer Hanna Hanra, Beat makes you feel like a fan again. “I was tired of how boring and beard-strokey music magazines were,” Ms. Hanra said. “And tired of how style magazines would only feature a band if they thought they were cool or looked cool. What I wanted was a stylish music magazine.” What she created is a celebration of music and its intriguing cast of characters. (The cool factor is way high.) The latest issue, below, includes interviews with Zachary Cole Smith of the band DIIV, shot by Ryan McGinley, and another with the cover girl Sky Ferreira, shown above, shot by Letty Schmiterlow. Order back issues on thebeatjuice.com (you want the whole collection), and look for its official debut in the United States in September.

headline: Band of Outsiders Introduces Map-Print Shirt
text: For his fall collection for Band of Outsiders, Scott Sternberg took inspiration from a childhood fantasy of building a city from scratch. Maps became a key graphic reference, leading him to the multimedia artist Sam Durant, whose work explores social and political themes and who had a 2011 show that drew on cartography. Mr. Durant offered access to some of his imagery, which made its way onto this boyish slim-fit oxford-cloth shirt. Dad might not buy this one for himself, so you should give it to him for his special party shirt.

headline: Nektar De Stagni Creates Playful Bracelets
text: The way Nektar De Stagni, a jewelry designer in Miami, sees it, “design is about the playful balance of contrasting materials and ideas.” That means this bracelet with freshwater pearls and smiley-face emoticon beads, $114; others with tiny gold and glass beads, $80; and a gold ring with a peacock pearl inset with a smiley in black pavé diamonds, $644. They’re not your grandmother’s pearls, but believe your granddaughters will appreciate them one day.

headline: Google Says It Has Uncovered Iranian Spy Campaign
text: Google said on Wednesday that it had uncovered a vast Iranian spy campaign that had been targeting tens of thousands of Iranian citizens over the last three weeks.

headline: Cesar Chavez Film to Avoid Immigration Debate
text: LOS ANGELES — For Participant Media, a nine-year-old Hollywood company with a fondness for films about social issues, the political minefield is comfortable terrain. In the recent past, the company plunged “Lincoln” into the fracas over partisanship, used “The Help” to highlight the plight of domestic workers and made “Promised Land” as a call for environmental action.

headline: Torst Bar in Greenpoint, Brooklyn
text: Bars for beer geeks tend toward sober pedantry. But Torst, an ambitious bar that opened in March, doesn’t let its serious beer menu get in the way of the Brooklyn scene.

headline: Conflicting Goals Complicate an Effort to Forge a Trans-Atlantic Trade Deal
text: PARIS — The leaders of the European Union, mired in recession and battered by increasing opposition from voters, are desperate for political success to promote economic growth. They are pushing for a rapid negotiation of a trade agreement with the United States aimed at expanding commerce and creating jobs.

headline: Fire When Ready, but Spare My Hat
text: What would Philip Treacy or Eugenia Kim make of the Vintage Merryweather or the Gentleman’s Gatsby, two of the virtual hats coveted by fans of the first-person shooter video game Team Fortress 2?

headline: Mike D in Brooklyn
text: A hardcore Manhattanite and his family renovate a 160-year-old town house in Cobble Hill.

headline: Licensed to Grill: Mike D’s Brooklyn Town House
text: Michael Diamond was sitting in his Cobble Hill town house, marveling at the virtues of a backyard. “When I was growing up in New York, we were the anomaly,” said Mr. Diamond, better known as Mike D of the Beastie Boys. “Our family stayed, but back then families didn’t stay. Once you had a second kid, you immediately left, so the kids could run around outside.”

headline: Looking Inside Himself for a Breakthrough
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — Given a one-night break from parenting duties last year, Brandt Snedeker and his wife, Mandy, decided to watch “Moneyball” in their Nashville hotel room. Before it was half over, Snedeker’s wife was asleep and he had awakened the possibilities for taking his golf career to another level.

headline: Mommy Blog or a Glossy Fashion Magazine?
text: The first wave of mommy blogs (pre-Facebook) were simple family updates, like year-round Christmas letters. The second wave were confessional soap boxes for mothers with dirty laundry to air (like dooce.com), attracting devoted readerships, advertising dollars and eventually public mimicry.

headline: Go Watch the Movie, Then Ponder the Message
text: “Don’t change your culture. Understand your culture.”

headline: France Resists U.S. Trade Talks Over TV and Film Concerns
text: BRUSSELS — France’s insistence on protecting its state-sponsored film and television industry could create snags in the European Union’s preparations for trade talks with the United States, according to trade officials here.

headline: Native New Yorkers Without the Attitude
text: The Brooklyn Botanic Garden expands its display of local flora.

headline: Native Flora Garden Opens at Brooklyn Botanic Garden
text: It’s hard to imagine a wild Long Island with 40,000 acres of grasslands waving in Hempstead Plains, now covered with houses. Or thousands of wild orchids blooming in the bogs that were paved over to build Kennedy Airport. Or carpets of pyxie moss flourishing in the Pine Barrens of New Jersey.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. What can I do to make my low ceilings look higher?

headline: The Booty That Lies Beneath
text: Many of us wonder who was here before us and what they left behind. Some people are so curious, they start digging.

headline: Resort Collections are a Walk on the Whimsical Side
text: The resort shows, which won’t end until Christmas, are a complete distraction. Nobody can really decide if resort should be a nice reworking of a designer’s latest runway line or its own thing. Should it be relaxed and beachy? Or (why miss the boat?) is there an opportunity to create a fresh interpretation of resort, as Raf Simons demonstrated in May with his first Dior resort show?

headline: Furnishings That Never Grow Up
text: When  Lora Appleton was  shopping for bedroom furniture for her 4-year-old son, Willem, she had trouble finding pieces that weren’t mini-replicas of modern classics or poorly designed mass-market alternatives. She enlisted her interior designer, Bachman Clem, to work with her selling vintage children’s designs, and Kinder Modern was born.

headline: ‘Michigan Modern’ Opens at the Cranbrook Art Museum
text: The state that was the center of both the automotive and furniture industry for most of the 20th century has never been given due regard for its design influence. That’s the premise of “Michigan Modern: Design that Shaped America,” which opens on June 14 at the Cranbrook Art Museum in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Curated by Gregory Saldaña and Monica Ponce de Leon, the exhibition features well-known innovators like Eliel and Eero Saarinen, Florence Knoll and Henry Ford. But dozens of less-known figures also get to shine, including the textile designer Marianne Strengell, whose aluminum rug for Alcoa will be on view, and the architect William Muschenheim, whose 1954 home in Ann Arbor is shown here. A map room highlights every Michigan city that has made a design contribution, from Grosse Pointe to Kalamazoo. Through Oct. 13: (248) 645-3320 or cranbrook.edu.

headline: Classical Furnishings
text: Objects that borrow their forms and proportions from ancient Greece or Rome have staying power for a reason. “The shapes have been worked out over generations,” said Thomas Jayne, an interior designer whose work incorporates more than a few of those objects. “They’re preapproved, if you will, and they’re reliable.”

headline: Sales at John Derian, ABC Carpet & Home and Others
text: Thursday to Saturday, John Derian will discount some decoupage pieces up to 60 percent, and some tabletop items and bed linens up to 50 percent (a John Derian five-inch round decoupage plate, shown, usually $48, will be $22); 8 East Second Street (Bowery), (212) 677-3917.

headline: ‘Make It Fabulous: The Architecture and Design of William T. Georgis’
text: The architect William T. Georgis makes glamorous and naughty environments for “merchant princes,” as he describes his clients: art-world and real-estate heavies like Aby Rosen, for whom he renovated the interiors of Lever House in Manhattan. Sixteen of Mr. Georgis’s projects are collected in “Make It Fabulous: The Architecture and Design of William T. Georgis.” The monograph, published last month by the Monacelli Press, manages to turn the polite conventions of design books upside down.

headline: Shopping for Classical Furnishings
text: Thomas Jayne, interior designer, shops for the Greek and Roman forms that characterize his work.

headline: A New Web Site Offers Designs From Around the World
text: Ambra Medda, the wunderkind former director of the Design Miami/Basel fair, is embarking on her next chapter: a Web site, to be inaugurated June 19, that will give visitors easy access to international design. Speaking from Switzerland, where she was attending Art Basel in a downpour, Ms. Medda, 32, said L’ArcoBaleno (Italian for “rainbow”) will bring diverse design talents to light. They may be basket makers in Botswana or a British furniture designer like Peter Marigold, whose pieces are collected by moguls. (His Palindrome table, shown, will be available for $16,240.)

headline: Coty Raises About $1 Billion in Its Public Debut
text: After trying once before, the cosmetics maker Coty is set to finally become a public company.

headline: At Barclays Center Events, Fewer Cars Than Expected
text: Devotees of folk rock tend to take the train, while Disney on Ice attracts the car set.

headline: World Bank Forecasts Slower but Smoother Growth
text: WASHINGTON — The world economy will face slower but less volatile growth in the coming months and years, the World Bank forecast on Wednesday, as dire risks from the financial crisis in Europe fade and emerging economies confront new challenges adapting to softer commodity prices and the prospect of rising interest rates.

headline: Names of the American War Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,219 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Safeway to Sell Its Operations in Canada
text: OTTAWA — The Canadian retailer Sobeys said on Wednesday that it would pay $5.8 billion in cash for the Canadian operations of Safeway, a move that would make it a leading grocery chain in western Canada.

headline: U.S.G.A. Is Bracing for More Rain at Merion
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — United States Golf Association officials lavished praise on that grande dame Merion Golf Club at a news conference on the eve of the United States Open, describing the host course as “a classic beauty” worth celebrating. But in the end, Mother Nature entered the picture, as she has done all year on the PGA Tour.

headline: U.N. Leader Urgently Seeks More Golan Peacekeepers
text: The United Nations secretary general said Wednesday that he was urgently seeking hundreds of new troops for the peacekeeping force in the disputed Golan Heights, where clashes from Syria’s civil war, cease-fire violations by both Israel and Syria, and an abrupt withdrawal of the force’s Austrian contingent are threatening four decades of relative calm.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Bitcoin Sell-Off and an Apple Star
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Iain Banks, Novelist of Crime and Science Fiction, Dies at 59
text: Iain Banks, a best-selling Scottish novelist whose books ranged from violent crime dramas to interstellar conflicts, died on Sunday in Kirkcaldy, Scotland. He was 59.

headline: Clearwire Endorses Dish’s Sweetened Bid
text: Clearwire on Wednesday switched its allegiance to Dish Network, recommending that shareholders accept its bid of $4.40 a share over a rival offer from Sprint Nextel.

headline: Colorado Localities Make Own Rules Before Final Decision on Marijuana Sales
text: AURORA, Colo. — As Colorado moves closer to issuing temporary regulations on the sale of marijuana, now legal in small quantities here, some cities and towns are not waiting for the new rules to take effect.

headline: What’s Your Hurry?
text: Every Supreme Court decision day that goes by without a ruling in the University of Texas affirmative action case provokes a generalized wringing of hands from those eager (or afraid) to learn the constitutional future of university admissions. “Where’s the case? What’s taking so long?”

headline: In Short Season, N.H.L. Ad Celebrates the Emotional
text: THE National Hockey League on Wednesday introduced a television commercial to celebrate the start of the Stanley Cup finals and perhaps polish its image at the end of a truncated season.

headline: In Battle Over Malibu Beaches, an App Unlocks Access
text: MALIBU, Calif. — The battle between Malibu beachfront homeowners and a less privileged public that wants to share the stunning coastline has been fought with padlocks, gates, menacing signs, security guards, lawsuits and bulldozers. There seems little question who is winning: 20 of the 27 miles of Malibu coastline are inaccessible to the public.

headline: Gatekeepers of Cable TV Try to Stop Intel
text: WASHINGTON — As Intel tries something audacious — the creation of a virtual cable service that would sell a bundle of television channels to subscribers over the Internet — it is running up against a multibillion-dollar barricade.

headline: Brooklyn Prosecutor to Testify in Suit Against Him Amid Re-election Bid
text: The Brooklyn district attorney must testify about allegations of misconduct in his office, just weeks before the Democratic primary, in which he is running for re-election, a federal magistrate judge ruled on Wednesday.

headline: In Iran, Tiptoeing to Avoid Stirring Turmoil
text: TEHRAN — The eight men hoping to become the next president of Iran sat at a long table last week and were shown pictures of things like container ships and traffic jams and asked for their reactions.

headline: Atoning for the Sins of Empire
text: WARWICK, England — THE British do not torture. At least, that is what we in Britain have always liked to think. But not anymore. In a historic decision last week, the British government agreed to compensate 5,228 Kenyans who were tortured and abused while detained during the Mau Mau rebellion of the 1950s. Each claimant will receive around £2,670 (about $4,000).

headline: Will Congress Bring My Husband Back?
text: “THAT person doesn’t live here,” I told the Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials when they knocked on my door in Queens early on April 17, 2012, looking for someone I’d never heard of. I was afraid, because my husband and I did not have papers. But I let them come in anyway.

headline: Across-the-Board Growth in College Degrees
text: After decades of slow growth, the number of Americans graduating from college has surged in the wake of the recession.

headline: The Worst of Both Worlds
text: Congress’s approval rating is abysmal. No news there. But it’s important to understand why.

headline:
Data Reveal a
Rise in College
Degrees Among
Americans
text: WASHINGTON — The number of Americans graduating from college has surged in recent years, sending the share with a college degree to a new high, federal data shows.

headline: The Revenge of Magic Mike
text: Right now you’re probably asking yourself: What would I do if I had $27 billion to toss around?

headline: Booker, in Senate Race, Will Try to Match His Reputation
text: MAPLEWOOD, N.J. — With the announcement that Cory A. Booker would speak in five minutes, a crowd flooded the largely empty lawn at the gay pride celebration here over the weekend. It took him twice that amount of time to reach the stage, for all the people mobbing him for photos and autographs.

headline: Status of Spurs’ Parker Uncertain for Game 4 vs. Heat
text: SAN ANTONIO — The injured point guard and his coach spoke 10 minutes apart on Wednesday, but they still managed to issue the same vague answers about the most scrutinized hamstring in South Texas.

headline: Civil Rights for Transgender People
text: New York stood for equality by approving same-sex marriage two years ago. It is time now for state lawmakers to extend basic civil rights protections to transgender people. The 2002 state statute that bars discrimination based on sexual orientation in employment, housing, education, credit and public accommodations does not explicitly cover transgender people.

headline: A Failure on Military Sexual Assaults
text: The spate of alarming incidents in recent months underscoring the depth of the military’s sexual assault problem did not dissuade Senator Carl Levin, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, from killing the most promising corrective on the table.

headline: Lung Transplant Rules for Children
text: The cases of two desperately ill children in need of lung transplants raised questions about the criteria used to determine eligibility for such transplants. One case involves a 10-year-old girl with cystic fibrosis, who received a transplant from an adult donor on Wednesday. The other case involves a boy, 11, also with cystic fibrosis.

headline: The Storm, Next Time
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s ambitious proposal to protect New York’s 520 miles of shoreline and fortify the city against storms that could be worse than Hurricane Sandy will require intense planning, engineering, community input and all sorts of adjustments. But Mr. Bloomberg has done the city a great service by pushing for the necessary short-term repairs and mapping out a broader strategy that takes into account many of the worst consequences of climate change.

headline: After the Shooting
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Fifteen years ago, on April 20, 1998, Jan Reid and three of his friends got into a cab in Mexico City. The four men were all affiliated with Texas Monthly, a magazine I’d worked for early in my career, which is how I knew Jan. They were in Mexico to attend a prize fight.

headline: Weiner's Congressional Highlights
text: Clips of former Representative Anthony D. Weiner on a series of issues that he focused on during his time in Washington, including health care, environmental pollution and aid for Sept. 11 responders.

headline: Diabetes and Blindness
text: To the Editor:

headline: Women Healing in Congo
text: To the Editor:

headline: Georgians in Afghanistan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Streaming the Small Screen
text: With streaming services competing with Hollywood and media networks, how will the concept of “television” evolve — if at all?

headline: Chemical Plant Safety
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Dearth of Latinos on Sunday Morning TV
text: To the Editor:

headline: Privacy, Trust and the Eyes on Our Data
Arizona Pitcher Criticized After Brawl
text: LOS ANGELES — Major League Baseball announced Wednesday that the Arizona Diamondbacks and the Los Angeles Dodgers would open next season with a series in Sydney, Australia. Baseball might wonder if the two baseball ambassadors have the potential to create an international incident.

headline: After a Taxing Campaign, Orb Enjoys a Relaxing Retreat
text: If you’re a clover plant in northeastern Maryland, be very afraid. The Kentucky Derby winner Orb checked into the Fair Hill Equine Therapy Center on Sunday afternoon and, if Wednesday’s visit was any indication, he’s not in town for the views. He’s here for the grass.

headline: N.S.A. Chief Says Phone Logs Halted Terror Threats
text: WASHINGTON — The director of the National Security Agency told Congress on Wednesday that “dozens” of terrorism threats had been halted by the agency’s huge database of the logs of nearly every domestic phone call made by Americans, while a senator briefed on the program disclosed that the telephone records are destroyed after five years.

headline: Divergent Paths for Mets and Cardinals
text: There was a cheeky little sequence on “Mad Men” last week in which a friend tells Don Draper that he has been meaning to ask him to a baseball game. The friend says he gets a lot of tickets, mostly for the Mets, and Don sniffs, “Well, I’m glad you didn’t.”

headline: C.I.A. to Get First Woman in No. 2 Job
text: The C.I.A.’s deputy director, Michael J. Morell, is retiring after 33 years at the agency and will be replaced by Avril D. Haines, the top lawyer at the National Security Council, the C.I.A.’s director, John O. Brennan, announced Wednesday.

headline: Dark Money Politics
text: In the world of nonprofit “dark money” groups, nothing is as it seems: political committees, through the magic of the internal revenue code, become tax-exempt “social welfare” organizations; a partisan campaign ad becomes principled “issue advocacy”; and federal election law that requires public disclosure of donors is rendered toothless by regulatory loopholes.

headline: Mother to Sue New York City in Crash That Killed 4-Year-Old Girl
text: The mother of a 4-year-old girl who was struck and killed by a car in Manhattan last week said on Wednesday that she intends to file a lawsuit against the city, claiming that her daughter’s death could have been avoided had emergency vehicles not been delayed in their response.

headline: Syria’s Improvised Arsenals
text: Across northern Syria, a clandestine network of primitive arms-making plants churn out makeshift weapons. The Times’s C.J. Chivers reports on a signature element of a materially lopsided war.

headline: James Takes the Blame for Miami’s Struggles
text: SAN ANTONIO — The questions and the criticism were coming just as assuredly and relentlessly as the San Antonio Spurs had come at him the night before. LeBron James surveyed the room, tapped his fingers on the table and embraced the burden.

headline: Weiner’s Record in House: Intensity, Publicity and Limited Results
text: When President Obama needed every Democrat in Congress to back his health care plan in 2009, Representative Anthony D. Weiner threatened behind the scenes to torpedo the package in favor of a more sweeping measure. He backed off after he was promised a bigger share of the spotlight during the highly watched debate.

headline: Immigration Amendments Reflect Concern About Border Security
text: WASHINGTON — As debate started on Wednesday on amendments to the Senate immigration bill, border security emerged as a focal point, with supporters and doubters agreeing that those provisions would have to be strengthened to attract more votes, especially from Republicans.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Starved for Arms, Syria Rebels Make Their Own
text: SARAQIB, Syria — The workers arrive by darkness, taking their stations at the vise and the lathe. Soon metal filings and sparks fly, and the stack of their creations grows at their feet: makeshift mortar shells to be fired through barrels salvaged from disabled Syrian Army tanks.

headline: Executive Covets Goldman Seat Where a Friend Snugly Sits
text: Inside Goldman Sachs, Gary D. Cohn is the man who is waiting — and waiting — to be king.

headline: Bushes Were Found There
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s time for another episode of True Stories, in which I eat up your bandwidth by telling potentially embarrassing stories about my life based on an entry in the puzzle.

headline: Syrian Forces Seen Stepping Up Air Attacks on Rebels
text: WASHINGTON — The forces of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria have substantially stepped up their air attacks, exploiting a crucial offensive advantage against Syrian rebels, according to American intelligence reports.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 13, 2013
text: “Basically I was just barely getting by, and I didn’t like my job, and I wanted to do something that wasn’t living dollar to dollar.”

headline: Bettman Discusses Olympics and Future of Coyotes
text: CHICAGO — Less than eight months before the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, the N.H.L. has not reached agreement with Olympic officials to allow its players to participate in the Games, Commissioner Gary Bettman said Wednesday.

headline: Mets and Cardinals Since the Called Third Strike
text: How the Mets and the Cardinals have fared since the Mets’ loss to St. Louis in Game 7 of the N.L.C.S. in 2006.

headline: Open Rookie Reconnects and Rebuilds His Game
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — Growing up in New Hampshire, Jesse Smith was a baseball player, and if he was anything else, he was a hockey player.

headline: Peace Bridge Authority Given Deadline by Legislature
text: ALBANY — Escalating an increasingly bitter conflict between New York and Canada, the State Legislature on Wednesday approved a measure that could lead to the dissolution of a binational agency that runs a bridge linking Buffalo and Fort Erie, Ontario.

headline: Nets Reach Into Past and Make Kidd Coach
text: For the second time in his storied N.B.A. career, Jason Kidd has been asked to play savior for the Nets, a franchise that has been moved and transformed but is forever seeking credibility.

headline: ‘I Was There’ Confessions
text: Three confessions with similar language given to Louis Scarcella.

headline: Several Murder Confessions Taken by Brooklyn Detective Have Similar Language
text: As the Brooklyn homicide detective Louis Scarcella told it, the suspect in a ruthless home invasion that left one man dead and two more people in a coma started talking after just a few minutes of questioning.

headline: White House Makes Moves to Bolster Gun Safety
text: WASHINGTON — Six months after the mass shooting in Newtown, Conn., and with no major gun legislation on the horizon in Congress, the White House is quietly moving forward on an executive package of gun safety measures.

headline: Corrections: June 13, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Facing Young Star, Mets’ Bats Come Alive
text: The Mets seem to be underdogs each time they step on the field, but on Wednesday night they got timely hitting and rode a strong start by Dillon Gee to beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 5-1, at Citi Field.

headline: Colorado Residents Flee Wildfires Spreading Across Rockies
text: BLACK FOREST, Colo. — Wildfire season erupted in Colorado this week as a series of fast-moving fires spread across the Rockies, forcing thousands of people to flee and burning at least 92 homes to the ground.

headline: As Anchors Struggle, Yankees Feel the Pull
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The formula that has propelled the Yankees this season is rather simple. Good pitching has been their strongest attribute in the absence of several injured stars. There have been timely hits, to be sure, and solid defense. But pitching has been the cornerstone.

headline: Federal Plan for ‘Morning After’ Pill’s Sale Is Approved
text: The long-running lawsuit over emergency contraception finally ended Wednesday evening when a federal judge granted the Obama administration’s proposal to make the best-known morning-after pill available to all ages without a prescription.

headline: A First Pitch a Bit Longer Than 60 Feet 6 Inches
text: OAKLAND — There was an unusual and touching first pitch before the Athletics-Yankees game here on Wednesday that originated with a 13-year-old boy 1,800 miles away in Kansas City.

headline: Goldman Sachs to Finance Early Education Program
text: Goldman Sachs is making its second foray into an experimental method of financing social services, lending up to $4.6 million for a childhood education program in Salt Lake City.

headline: Obama Urges Massachusetts Democrats to Turn Out for Markey’s Senate Bid
text: BOSTON — With less than two weeks before Massachusetts voters go to the polls to elect a new senator, President Obama campaigned here on Wednesday to try to stir up enthusiasm for Representative Edward J. Markey.

headline: Tennis Channel Executive Rants After Losing a Court Ruling
text: Ken Solomon, the chief executive of Tennis Channel, thought until late last month that he was on his way to winning a big and lengthy legal battle — one that would greatly enhance the channel’s business. He believed that Comcast would soon make Tennis Channel as widely available on its cable systems as Golf Channel and NBC Sports Network, which it owns.

headline: Election Looming, Excitement Missing in Iran
text: Each step of the presidential election has involved intervention by state institutions to steer it, creating cynicism in some voters and candidates.

headline: Tibetan Nun Survives Self-Immolation
text: A Tibetan nun who self-immolated on Tuesday in Sichuan Province in China during a religious ceremony is still alive and in a hospital, according to reports from Tibetan advocacy groups and Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the United States government. The nun set fire to herself near Nyatso monastery in Tawu County. Free Tibet said about 3,000 monks from 60 monasteries had gathered to take part in a debate festival.

headline: New Party Picks Putin as Leader
text: The All-Russian People’s Front, a political group, chose President Vladimir V. Putin as its leader on Thursday at its founding convention. The group, created two years ago in preparation for national parliamentary and presidential elections, is seen as a potential replacement for United Russia, the party that controls Parliament but is increasingly unpopular with the public. Mr. Putin, speaking at the event in downtown Moscow, said the All-Russian People’s Front would operate above politics. The anticorruption blogger Aleksei A. Navalny branded United Russia as “the party of swindlers and thieves” — a moniker that has stuck.

headline: Venezuela Review Confirms Vote
text: A government review of electronic voting results from Venezuela’s recent election has been completed and confirmed the victory of President Nicolás Maduro, the head of the National Electoral Council announced this week. Mr. Maduro, the handpicked successor of former president Hugo Chávez, who died in March, won by just 1.5 percentage points. Tibisay Lucena, the electoral council president, announced the completion of the audit on Tuesday. The review was begun at the request of the losing candidate in the April 14 election, Henrique Capriles Radonski. But Mr. Capriles refused to take part in the review, calling it a sham.

headline: Egypt’s Ex-Security Chief Is Acquitted
text: An Egyptian criminal court acquitted the former chief of a Mubarak-era security service and 40 other officers on Wednesday of charges that they destroyed documents that could have implicated members of their feared apparatus in crimes. Protesters who stormed the State Security headquarters in Cairo and Alexandria after the revolution in 2011 found piles of shredded and burned documents. The armed forces, which ran the country after President Hosni Mubarak stepped down, took control of the facilities and later dissolved State Security, replacing it with a new internal security service.

headline: Record Corn and Soybean Yields Are Predicted
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The government is predicting record corn and soybean yields this year despite intense spring showers that have delayed planting, damaged crops already in the ground and prevented farmers from sowing all of their seeds. But the projections are based on estimates made before the heavy rains came about how many acres of crops will be planted.

headline: Chief Executive Linked to I.M.F. Official Faces Inquiry
text: French prosecutors said Wednesday that Stéphane Richard, the chief executive of France Télécom, would be formally investigated for his role in a politically charged case that has already shined an uncomfortable spotlight on his former boss, Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund. Mr. Richard has denied wrongdoing. He is being investigated on suspicion of organized fraud, according to the Paris prosecutor’s office. Investigators are examining a 2008 arbitration case in which Bernard Tapie, a businessman, was awarded $535 million to settle a dispute with Crédit Lyonnais, a state-owned bank. Mr. Tapie had been a career Socialist, but he switched his allegiance in 2007 to the center-right party led by the president at the time, Nicolas Sarkozy. Acting on a complaint from Socialist deputies, prosecutors began an investigation to learn if Mr. Tapie might have received special treatment in the case, which Mr. Tapie denied. They are also trying to understand why government officials did not challenge the outcome despite indications of possible anomalies in the procedure. At the time of the arbitration, Mr. Richard was chief of staff to Ms. Lagarde, who was Mr. Sarkozy’s finance minister from 2007 to 2011. Ms. Lagarde has herself come under suspicion for allowing the arbitration.

headline: Police Agencies Are Assembling Records of DNA
text: Slowly, and largely under the radar, a growing number of local law enforcement agencies across the country have moved into what had previously been the domain of the F.B.I. and state crime labs — amassing their own DNA databases of potential suspects, some collected with the donors’ knowledge, and some without it.

headline: Japanese Stocks Descend Into Bear Market
text: HONG KONG — The battered Japanese stock market lurched into bear-market territory Thursday, after a tumble of 6.4 percent took the combined decline in the Nikkei 225 index since a peak on May 23 to more than 21 percent.

headline: Barbara Vucanovich, 91, Dies; Served Nevada in Congress
text: Barbara Vucanovich, who traveled from New York to Reno, Nev., in 1949 to get a quick divorce and ended up staying and becoming the first woman to be sent to Congress from Nevada, serving seven terms in the House as a conservative Republican, died on Monday at an assisted-living facility in Reno. She was 91.

headline: Band of Heavy Weather Ravages Midwest
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — An enormous string of thunderstorms whipped through the Upper Midwest on Wednesday and barreled toward the Atlantic Coast overnight and into Thursday, blanketing a vast swath of the country with high winds, large hail and rain. More than a dozen tornadoes were reported throughout the Midwest on Wednesday, from Iowa to Indiana.

headline: How the World Bank Makes Doing Business Easier
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Census Benchmark for White Americans: More Deaths Than Births
text: Deaths exceeded births among non-Hispanic white Americans for the first time in at least a century, according to new census data, a benchmark that heralds profound demographic change.

headline: Former Obama Advisers Start Communications Company
text: Two former advisers to President Obama, Robert Gibbs and Ben LaBolt, are forming a strategic communications firm aimed at leveraging their political experience in Washington for corporate and nonprofit clients.

headline: Bike Sharing Can Mean Safer Biking
text: It took only a few days for reports of the first cycling accident involving New York’s new bike-sharing program to begin circulating. But experts and growing experience from bike-sharing programs in other cities make clear that bicycling can be a safe mode of transportation, and the presence of a bike-sharing program is a boon to the safety of all bicyclists.

headline: Word of the Day | monotony
text: monotony •\mə-ˈnä-tə-ne, -ˈnät-ne\• noun

headline: Central Park Dreams Trigger a Battle in Mumbai
text: MUMBAI— Few places in congested Mumbai are as unexpected and uplifting as its racecourse, a 225-acre expanse located near a sweep of coastline in the island city. Built on the swampy flats of Mahalaxmi in 1883, the racecourse hosts a 2,400-meter (2,600-yard) track for the annual races, as well as tony restaurants and South Mumbai’s only helipad. But it’s the oval of green – and the inner walking track – that brings people here every day for a dose of open sky and earth.

headline: Mets Plan to Let Davis Work Through Issues in Games
text: LAS VEGAS — Heated competition may not seem like the best environment for a struggling, mixed-up ballplayer to reconstruct his swing and rebuild his confidence. Pressures exist, no matter the level.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 7 P.M. (Showtime) ROCK ’N’ ROLL EXPOSED: THE PHOTOGRAPHY OF BOB GRUEN (2012) Led Zeppelin, the Rolling Stones, Elvis, Madonna, Bob Dylan, Bob Marley, John Lennon, Johnny Rotten — for half a century, Mr. Gruen has captured them and others through his camera’s lens. In this documentary from Don Letts, Mr. Gruen opens his archive (including photos of the Clash, above) and shares memories of wild times with music legends. His friends Yoko Ono, Iggy Pop, Alice Cooper, Tommy Ramone and Debbie Harry tell their own tales.

headline: U.S. Offers Conditional Support for Police Monitor in Stop-and-Frisk Case
text: The Justice Department on Wednesday waded into a federal trial over the New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk practices, strongly endorsing a monitor to oversee changes if a judge were to find the practices to be unconstitutional.

headline: Blackhawks Outlast Bruins, Winning Opener in Third Overtime
text: CHICAGO — As the sound of thunder echoed outside United Center, the Blackhawks and the Bruins, with a combined 175 years of history, faced off for the first time in the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: News Quiz | June 13, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Yankees, in Homer Drought, Are Overpowered by A’s
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Yankees dominated the sub-.500 Cleveland Indians and the Seattle Mariners, winning six of seven games against them before arriving in the East Bay, where they have quickly learned that the Oakland Athletics are not a team they can push around so easily.

headline: Can N.S.A. Surveillance Be Likened to Chinese Spying?
text: BEIJING —“Snowden: American Government Invaded Chinese Computers,” ran a headline Thursday on CCTV, China’s state-run television channel.

headline: Greek Workers Strike to Protest Shutdown of State Broadcaster
text: ATHENS — Thousands of Greeks walked off the job on Thursday in the third general strike of the year, this time called by labor unions to protest a surprise decision by the conservative-led government to close the state broadcaster and put about 2,900 employees out of work.

headline: Test Yourself | English, June 13, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “His Skills Diminished, a Star Finally Reaches a Pinnacle.”

headline: A Cry for Help From a Chinese Labor Camp
text: In the article “Behind Cry for Help From China Labor Camp,” Andrew Jacobs writes about an inmate at a Chinese labor camp who slipped letters into product packages likely destined for the West while toiling under brutal conditions.

headline: Examining Identity, Gender Image by Gender Image
text: I am the girl. He is the boy.

headline: Have You Ever Stumbled Upon a Cool Public Performance?
text: Sometimes we stumble upon the coolest performances where we least expect them, like in the park, at the beach or on the subway.

headline: Cities of God
text: MEXICO CITY — Saturday was a beautiful day in Monterrey, northeastern Mexico, and in the Plaza Zaragoza, just a few meters from City Hall, it was a cheerful one, too. Standing at a clear plexiglass podium, a woman of about 40 is making a speech. Human participation alone, she says, “does not have the ability to reverse the darkness”; only the light from faith in God can. “Which is why we are gathered here today, and I, Alicia Margarita Arellanes Cervantes, give Monterrey, Nuevo León, to our Lord Jesus Christ, so that his kingdom of peace and blessings may be established.”

headline: Charges Urged in Filipino Raid on Taiwanese Boat
text: MANILA — Investigators in the Philippines are recommending that criminal charges be filed against the crew of a Philippine Coast Guard vessel that opened fire on a Taiwanese boat, killing one fisherman.

headline: Immigration Cost to Countries Is Overstated, Study Finds
text: PARIS — Public debate about immigration is being distorted by unfounded concerns over the financial burden that new arrivals put on governments, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a report on Thursday.

headline: DeltaWing Will Race at Lime Rock Park
text: If you live in the Northeast and have had a hankering to see the crazy-looking DeltaWing racecar at the track, your opportunity is coming this summer at Lime Rock Park in Connecticut. The Wing is the closest thing there is to a living incarnation of Tim Burton’s Batmobile, and it has been making its way around various tracks in American Le Mans races.

text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Chinese State Media Suggest That N.S.A. Disclosures Will Hurt U.S. Ties
text: HONG KONG — After several days of relative silence on the issue, Chinese state news media Thursday highlighted revelations that the United States government was engaged in widespread monitoring of Internet and telephone communications, carrying reports suggesting the disclosures could damage relations between the two countries.

headline: The Future of Goldman Sachs
text: The Times’s Susanne Craig on the investment firm’s longtime chief executive Lloyd C. Blankfein, who is showing few signs of stepping down soon.
