text: When President Rafael Correa of Ecuador won re-election this year, and for the first time captured a majority in the National Assembly, he vowed to push forward with major proposals that had been stalled in his earlier terms. On Friday he gained a victory that he had long coveted when the Legislature passed a law regulating the news media, which he says will force news organizations to act fairly and which opponents say will quash freedom of expression.

headline: Player in Leaks Case, Out From Behind Camera
text: The filmmaker Alex Gibney recalled bumping into his fellow documentarian Laura Poitras at the airport last year, when they both happened to be taking the New York-to-London flight.

headline: The Meaning of Daring
text: The choreographer Patricia Noworol, who grew up in Poland and moved to Germany as a teenager, is fond of emotional and physical extremes. In the United States premiere of “?Culture,” performed at Danspace Project on Thursday, she is the queen bee. She perches on a high ladder wearing a hot pink robe while shrieking into a microphone, dances topless under strobe lights and lectures the audience about arts financing.

headline: How Flexible Is Your Employer?
text: This week’s Your Money column looks at how workers are perceived if they use a more flexible work arrangement — say, working early and quitting early, or cutting back on hours when caring for an elderly parent.

headline: Unwelcome Innovation Earns Gamers’ Jeers
text: LOS ANGELES — Even though new video game systems depend on technological innovation, players are a conservative lot, suspicious of change. That partly explains why they gave a sustained ovation for old-fashioned games on disc during a Sony presentation this week here at the industry’s trade show, E3.

headline: Laurie Anderson’s Wall-to-Wall Summer
text: Laurie Anderson has a disarming way of making intense levels of activity seem matter-of-fact, even laid-back. In a spacious room on the upper floor of her TriBeCa duplex, with a glorious view of the Hudson River, she briefly looked over the shoulder of an assistant who was editing a video recording of the Chinese dissident artist (and, lately, musician) Ai Weiwei, with whom Ms. Anderson will perform, via Skype, at the Luminato Festival in Toronto on Sunday. She then padded down a spiral staircase to her studio, where, one afternoon this week, her stage equipment — a small keyboard, an iPad, a MacBook and her trademark electric violin — was powered up and ready for rehearsal or experimentation.

headline: No False Advertising Here
text: The name says it all. But even if you didn’t know what Farm to Table Bistro was called, you could see immediately that this Fishkill restaurant fits right into the movement for locally sourced eating.

headline: BMW Announces Details and Prices for the 2014 4 Series Coupe
text: BMW released details — and photos — of its 4 Series Coupe on Friday, just in time for the weekend. So here they are, the 428i and 435i models, available in three different trim levels: Luxury, Sport and M Sport. Predictably, the Luxury trim caters to fancy gadgets, while the Sport and M Sport are tailored to the speed freaks amongst BMW’s customers.

headline: U.S. Agencies to Develop Standards for Bed Rails
text: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration and the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced on Friday that they have called for a committee to update voluntary standards for adult portable bed rails, which have been linked to the deaths of hundreds of elderly patients.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 14
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a building implosion on Governors Island, pedestrians in the rain in Manhattan and an invasion of cicadas on Staten Island.

headline: Song for My Father
text: I have been writing and singing songs for over half my life. And as I get older I’ve noticed that the things I write about have changed. I’m 46 now and I find myself writing a lot about middle age. I don’t take life for granted as I once did. When I see my hometown Ohio area code light up on my phone, I sometimes worry it might be “that call.” My mom is an older lady now. She had a knee replacement and her hair is turning white and she’s having a harder time getting around. My dad is 80 and he’s one of two siblings left out of nine.

headline: A Vineyard With a View (and Food, Too)
text: At some restaurants, being there is the real feast. So it is with the restaurant at Sharpe Hill Vineyard, which Steven and Catherine Vollweiler opened two decades ago in a quiet corner of Connecticut’s Quiet Corner, the northeastern part of the state.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Darned If They Do
text: Men answer the question: wear socks or expose your ankles?

headline: Keeping Up With Medical Knowledge
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Next Storm: New York Prepares, but the Rest?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dosas, Big and Bigger
text: It’s a puzzle to a chicken tandoori and lamb biryani gal like myself that the typical dosa joint has 6,000 items on the menu. Four thousand of these items are made of rice and lentils, sometimes with spices and sometimes with “special” spices. And the star among these items is the pancake. I was tempted to say “the humble pancake,” but there is nothing humble about a dosa. Bragging rights go to the dosa that can overhang its plate by the most inches. Or feet. This is not an exaggeration. Not much of one, anyway.

headline: Helping Syria’s Rebels
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Gay Lobby’ in the Vatican
text: To the Editor:

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:  Cyberwarlord for the U.S., and Power Strips on the Road
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: After $98,000 Crime at Tiffany, Security Tips From a Pawnshop
text: Tiffany & Company has been selling jewelry in New York City since 1837, but it would seem the famous name could learn a thing or two from an uptown clerk named Mattie Simon in East Harlem, and, in particular, what happens when she calls out for a cup of black coffee.

headline: Greedy Gardeners
text: ROOFTOP vegetable gardens were one thing, but the urban agricultural movement has gone a step too far. A new brand of activists want to incorporate fruit trees into the fabric of city life by turning our limited green space into woody groves filled with apples, cherries and plums. One group, the Guerrilla Grafters, has gone so far as to graft the branches of fruit trees onto street-side ornamental trees in San Francisco.

headline: Wheeler, Mets Pitching Prospect, to Face Braves on Tuesday
text: The Mets will have plenty of decisions concerning their rotation once the prized prospect Zack Wheeler joins the staff next week. But the first of those decisions was officially made Friday when Mets Manager Terry Collins confirmed that Wheeler would be pitching the second game of Tuesday’s split doubleheader in Atlanta. The Mets ace Matt Harvey will pitch the opener.

headline: Nuclear Plants, Old and Uncompetitive, Are Closing Earlier Than Expected
text: Washington — When does a nuclear plant become too old?

headline: Judge Rejects Fort Hood Shooting Suspect’s Defense Strategy
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — Days after the Army major charged in the Fort Hood shooting rampage here in 2009 argued that he had carried out the attack to protect Taliban leaders from American soldiers, a military judge effectively tossed out his defense, ruling on Friday that the claim had no legal merit.

headline: With Treetop Trail, Philadelphia Zoo Opens Grounds to Prowlers
text: PHILADELPHIA — Near the entrance to the Philadelphia Zoo, a new, long tubular cage hangs about 20 feet above the ground, twisting through trees and around buildings as it leads into the zoo’s densely packed campus.

headline: A Peaceful Piano Protest
text: With his piano parked at Taksim Square in Istanbul, the pianist Davide Martello led protesters in a rendition of The Beatles’ ”Let It Be.”

headline: Close to Nature, and Perfection
text: Never mind that a restaurant named Agricola, the Latin word for farmer, has a distinctly manufactured feel.  (A design firm and a branding firm were hired to create the rustic American effect.) The restaurant is a beautiful place in which to dine, and many of the dishes are, or are on their way to becoming, excellent.

headline: Judge at War Crimes Tribunal Faults Acquittals of Serb and Croat Commanders
text: PARIS — A judge at the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague has exposed a deep rift at the highest levels of the court in a blistering letter suggesting that the court’s president, an American, pressured other judges into approving the recent acquittals of top Serb and Croat commanders.

headline: A Chinese Push for Urbanization
text: China is contemplating a drastic plan to move 250 million rural residents into towns and cities over the next dozen years.

headline: Bad Idea, Mr. President
text: AMMAN, Jordan — ACCORDING to Bill Clinton, Barack Obama risks looking like a “fool” if he decides not to intervene militarily in Syria’s continuing civil war. Likening the situation to his decision to intervene in Kosovo in 1999, Mr. Clinton said Tuesday that if he hadn’t used force to stop Serbia’s campaign of ethnic cleansing, critics might have said: “You could have stopped this by dropping a few bombs. Why didn’t you do it?” Mr. Clinton believes that Mr. Obama could end up looking like a “total wuss” if he doesn’t intervene. And it seems he’s going to act.

headline: New Bridge Over Danube Helps Dissolve Old Enmities
text: VIDIN, Bulgaria — The European Union hardly basks in popular favor these days. But in this isolated corner of the bloc’s poorest periphery, leaders and locals on Friday celebrated a tangible benefit of membership — a $340 million bridge spanning the Danube that should help strengthen trade and ties between two impoverished members, Romania and Bulgaria.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: In Colorado, Nature Takes a Fiery Toll Despite a Community’s Efforts to Prepare
text: DENVER — For years, families in Black Forest, Colo., did what they could to keep the flames at bay. They scooped up pine needles and trimmed low-hanging branches around their homes. They chopped down saplings and hauled dead trees to the community mulcher.

headline: A Search for Sexual Freedom Gone Awry
text: There is a rumor going around that in the 1960s any reasonable adult in search of casual sex could find it in a New York minute. But Neil Simon’s “Last of the Red Hot Lovers,” which first opened on Broadway in 1969, proves there were exceptions. And the Schoolhouse Theater’s lighthearted new production of that comedy, in the theater’s newly renovated space, brings back those days with a clear eye and a warm heart.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Clinton and Christie, 2 Politicians Sharing Wonk-Speak
text: CHICAGO — They first bonded over basketball and sparred in the rough and tumble of a political campaign, admiring each other as master politicians.

headline: And With a Roof, They’d Cost Even More
text: BOSTON — If you thought housing prices were spiraling up again, consider the lowly parking space.

headline: The Other Side of the Story
text: The deck is always stacked when we debate keeping the nation safe.

headline: Getting to the Frank Talk About Sex
text: Did you know that Dr. Ruth Westheimer’s parents “had to get married,” as people used to say? Do you want to know when Dr. Ruth, as she is known in her professional life as a sex therapist, first had sex? Mark St. Germain’s “Becoming Dr. Ruth,” now at TheaterWorks Hartford, will tell you.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Trying to Sell Wall Street on the Value of Marijuana
text: Kalvin Savanh grew up in Portland, Ore., and, during high school, he said, he grew marijuana. About 15 years later, Mr. Savanh, 33, still helps grow it — but now it is legal.

headline: Disbelief, Merrily Suspended
text: ROLAND RUSINEK AND NOAH PLOMGREN, the actors who portray opera singers in Ken Ludwig’s “Lend Me a Tenor,” do not look a bit similar. Nevertheless, their characters are mistaken for each other throughout most of Act II in Mr. Ludwig’s clever farce, which has been revived frequently since its 1989 Broadway debut.

headline: A Chance to Do Better on Greece
text: The International Monetary Fund now has a chance to show what it has learned from past policy mistakes on Greece, mistakes it acknowledged last week. This week a delegation from the fund, the European Central Bank and the European Commission was in Athens to review Greek compliance with the terms of the latest bailout agreement, a condition for releasing this month’s $4 billion installment. Greek officials said they hoped the European examiners would show new flexibility on changing the agreement’s more counterproductive requirements.

headline: Hel-LO! You’re … Who Again?
text: It takes a certain amount of guts to go to your class reunions.

headline:
Heavy Pressure
Led to Decision
by Obama on
Syrian Arms
text: WASHINGTON — For two years, President Obama has resisted being drawn deeper into the civil war in Syria. It was a miserable problem, he told aides, and not one he thought he could solve. At most, it could be managed. And besides, he wanted to be remembered for getting out of Middle East wars, not embarking on new ones.

headline: The E.P.A. Backs Off on Factory Farms
text: The Environmental Protection Agency is obliged under the Clean Water Act to monitor America’s waterways and shield them from the toxic runoff from factory farms. But the growth of that industry, and its courtroom tenacity, has far outstripped the E.P.A.’s efforts to restrict runoff from manure lagoons and feedlots.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: Apple releases hardware and mobile software upgrades, a new study warns of peril in voice-activated car technology and Airbus flies its new A350.

headline: Used to Leading, Vonn Is Content to Follow for Now
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — Lindsey Vonn sat on a stone wall 20 yards from the first tee at the Merion Golf Club on Friday afternoon. Her boyfriend, Tiger Woods, had just teed off, striding down the fairway with thousands of fans in his wake.

headline: Locust Moon
text: I saw the first fireflies of June the other night. They looked a little aqueous, as if they were phosphorescing in a liquid darkness. I watched them with pleasure, wishing I were bioluminescent myself. It wasn’t the darkness of the night that bothered me. It was the way it had become dark. Usually, even on cloudy evenings, I can feel the light rising skyward from the pastures, retreating with the sun. But that night it seemed as though the farm was gradually sinking deeper and deeper in a tide of shadows.

headline: In Gospel Songs of Yore, Clues to the Speeches of Martin Luther King Jr.
text: When Jonathan Rieder was growing up in Philadelphia during the 1950s, infatuated with rockabilly and rhythm and blues, he sometimes rose early enough to inadvertently tune in to the Sunday-morning gospel show on WHAT. Those worship songs sounded different from his favorites, which aimed more at the hips than the spirit. For the Rieder family, fervently unobservant even in its own Jewish faith, Christianity stood at an alien distance.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Push for Speed Cameras Turns to School Zones
text: A leader of the State Senate is adopting a new strategy focused on young New Yorkers to try to build support for a bill to install speed-tracking cameras that has languished in the Legislature for years.

headline: Two Public Schools in New York Are Spared the Tear-Down of Development
text: After being considered as sites for new high-rise apartment buildings, two public schools near Lincoln Center have been saved from the wrecker’s ball, city education officials said on Friday.

headline: A Briton’s Bitter Farewell to China Echoes Loudly
text: MOGANSHAN, China — MARK KITTO is still here. But he is leaving soon, he swears. It will happen sometime this summer, he said, after a final road trip with his family to the outer reaches of the Chinese empire, where two decades ago as a British soldier he joined a 59-day expedition to cross the Taklamakan Desert.

headline: Minnesota Man, 94, Is Investigated for Nazi Ties
text: WASHINGTON — After more than three decades in existence, the Justice Department’s Nazi-hunting team is facing what could end up being its last investigation after reports emerged Tuesday that a 94-year-old Ukrainian immigrant in Minnesota had led a Nazi SS unit accused of burning villages during World War II.

headline: An Idol, Aging but Still in the Spotlight
text: There is one and only one center of attention in the Two River Theater Company’s fabulous production of Noël Coward’s “Present Laughter.” He is Garry Essendine, played here by the remarkable Michael Cumpsty. Mr. Cumpsty — whose appearance on Broadway last year as Judy Garland’s supportive accompanist in “End of the Rainbow” brought him a Tony Award nomination — is an Englishman with square-jawed looks that would have been at home on a soccer field. But he slides into the silk pajamas, luxurious dressing gowns and witty repartee of a 1930s Coward leading man with championship ease.

headline: Notes From the Underground
text: When “East End or Busk,” a new musical series at the Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill, begins its summerlong run on June 22, five acts that visitors may, or may not, recognize from New York City’s subways will descend on the premises.

headline: Medicare Panel Urges Cuts to Hospital Payments for Services Doctors Offer for Less
text: WASHINGTON — A federal advisory panel said Friday that Congress should move immediately to cut payments to hospitals for many services that can be provided at much lower cost in doctors’ offices.

headline: Behind Scolding of the F.D.A., a Complex and Gentle Judge
text: The judge whose vehement ruling ordered the Obama administration to surrender and make the morning-after pill available to all ages without a prescription is strikingly soft-spoken, so much so that to hear him in chambers, a visitor must sometimes lean forward from the raspberry-and-chartreuse striped sofa that is a legacy from his parents’ 1940s Brooklyn living room.

headline: Only Two Players in U.S. Open Enter Weekend Under Par
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — Merion is an old-fashioned beauty, with shapely fairways and greens and a lineage that can be traced to Bobby Jones and Ben Hogan, peerless names in golf’s Social Register. She reached maturity in a more genteel time, when decorum prevented any gentleman from insinuating that she was an easy conquest.

headline: Unexpected Décor
text: The ebony spleenwort (Asplenium platyneuron) is a fern with a strange name and a preference for growing where few other plants will. In New York City’s five boroughs, it is most frequently found squeezing its roots into the mortar of abandoned forts, railroad trestles, bridges and the foundations of old buildings.

headline: Seafood Smugglers to Pay $22.5 Million
text: Three men convicted in 2004 of smuggling sea bass and rock lobster from South Africa were ordered on Friday by a federal court to pay that nation $22.5 million in restitution, the largest amount ever awarded for such a crime.

headline: U.S. Open’s Latest Fashion: Boots
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — After Tiger Woods completed his delayed first round of the United States Open on Friday, his white golf shoes were muddied, and his gray pants were spattered.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 15, 2013
text: “To hell with you if you do not believe in our election.”

headline: Before Cabby Was Killed, His Dream Came True
text: After moving to New York from Nigeria about a decade ago, Uro Ama Orji worked long hours as a cabdriver with one goal in mind, his family said: to bring his five children to the United States.

headline: Unearthing Memories of the Vietnam War
text: The war in Vietnam ended four decades ago, but it still weighs on the men and women who served there, and even on those who, for one reason or another, did not. Philip F. Napoli, an assistant history professor at Brooklyn College, movingly delivers a belated salute to the former group in “Bringing It All Back Home: An Oral History of New York City’s Vietnam Veterans” (Hill and Wang, $27).

headline: Mets Favor Wright, but All-Star Voting Does Not
text: David Wright, by his own admission, has gotten tired of seeing his “ugly mug” on the video screen at Mets games. Yet there he is, looming over center field, as a voice-over urges fans at Citi Field to punch their ballots for Wright. A huge Twitter hashtag in white chalk spells out “#VOTEMETS” behind home plate.

headline: Some Protesters in Turkey Disavow Agreement With Premier to End Park Sit-In
text: ISTANBUL — Taksim Square is mostly back to normal: the taxicabs line up in front of fancy hotels, whose doormen no longer clutch gas masks, and outdoor cafes are bustling again.

headline: Home Away From Home
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Boy, this one really hung me up, and on a Saturday, one would expect nothing else, but boy, did I mention that this one really hung me up?

headline: Spurs Defend 11-Year-Old Anthem Singer
text: SAN ANTONIO — The national debate over immigration touched down in an unusual spot this week: the N.B.A. finals.

headline: The Sculptor Backstage
text: Working as the stage doorman of the Longacre Theater on West 48th Street in the theater district, Regan Kimmel sits in a small room inside the alleyway entrance and buzzes in the cast and crew.

headline: This Isn’t How to Stop Hacking
text: WUHAN, China — When we landed in China early this week, we hadn’t realized that a long holiday, the Dragon Boat Festival, was about to begin. It took us a little while to figure out why traffic was so light in Beijing, and why the offices where we were meeting officials were so deserted.

headline: These Children Are Our Future
text: Now that high school graduation season is winding down, it’s worth taking a moment to remember that in the sea of flowing gowns lurk some unsettling statistical realities. On many measures of childhood well-being, the last decade in the United States has been one of stagnation. We remain an outlier in many ways among developed countries.

headline: Corrections: June 15, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Court in Venezuela Orders Release of a Judge Once Scorned and Jailed by Chávez
text: During the three and a half years that she was held in prison or under house arrest, Judge Lourdes Afiuni became a symbol of political persecution for many in Venezuela under President Hugo Chávez. On Friday, a court in Caracas, acting at the government’s request, ordered Ms. Afiuni to be set free in the latest sign of a shifting political landscape in post-Chávez Venezuela.

headline: Yankees May Need Rodriguez After All
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Speculation has swirled over whether Alex Rodriguez would be healthy enough to return this season from off-season hip surgery, and whether the Yankees even wanted him back.

headline: The Blackhawks’ Biggest Fan, or the Biggest One in Congress, at Least
text: CHICAGO — As the Blackhawks and the Bruins skated into overtime Wednesday night, then another and yet another, Representative Mike Quigley was watching 700 miles away in Washington as he always does when he cannot be at United Center: alone.

headline: Million-Anecdote Baby
text: A friend of mine has an adult child with cancer, a young man just old enough to be beyond the age of coverage under his parents’ health care plan. After nearly killing him, the dreaded Hodgkin’s lymphoma is in remission. But he’s still a pariah in the eyes of the insurance industry, which means they can deny him a policy that might save his life.

headline: Prison Sentence for 2 Musicians Who Released Album of Protest Songs
text: Two Tibetan musicians detained about a year ago by Chinese security officers have each been given a two-year prison sentence, according to Free Tibet, an advocacy group based in London. The two musicians, Pema Trinlay, 22, and Chakdor, 32, from Ngaba in Sichuan Province, produced an album called “The Pain of an Unhealed Wound.” The album has 12 songs, among them ones that praised the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of the Tibetans, and the scores of Tibetans who have set themselves on fire since 2009 to protest Chinese rule. The singers were sentenced in February, but news of the punishments has only now begun to emerge, Free Tibet said in its news release on Thursday. About 120 ethnic Tibetans in Chinese-ruled regions have self-immolated. Many of the monks who set themselves on fire came from the Kirti Monastery in Sichuan Province on the eastern edge of the Tibetan plateau. The monastery has been in conflict with the Chinese authorities since 2008, during a widespread Tibetan uprising.

headline: Millions Spent to Deport Militant Cleric in Britain, but He Still Hasn’t Left
text: The British government said Friday that it had spent the equivalent of $2.7 million to date on legal expenses related to its efforts over the last decade to deport the militant Islamic cleric known as Abu Qatada, including more than $1 million in legal aid for the cleric’s lawyers. The Jordanian cleric, whose real name is Omar Mahmoud Mohammed Othman, arrived in Britain on a false passport in 1993.

headline: Yankees May Need Rodriguez After All
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Speculation has swirled over whether Alex Rodriguez would be healthy enough to return this season from off-season hip surgery, and whether the Yankees even wanted him back.

headline: Facebook Discloses Basic Data on Law-Enforcement Requests
text: 12:10 a.m. Saturday, June 15, 2013 | Updated Added Microsoft’s release of more data on Friday night.

headline: Local Stop: Brooklyn Navy Yard
text: The Brooklyn Navy Yard dates to 1801, and at its peak in World War II, 70,000 people worked there. But it closed in 1966, and today it is a model of eco-friendly adaptive reuse.

headline: A Birthplace of Ships, Transformed
text: The Brooklyn Navy Yard dates to 1801, when an entrepreneurial shipbuilder named John Jackson sold his land on Wallabout Bay, in the East River, to the federal government. At the yard’s peak in World War II, 70,000 men and women worked there. But it never recovered from a severe postwar decline, and the government closed it in 1966. The city turned the site into an industrial park, and today it seems to be a model of eco-friendly adaptive reuse. Only Building 92, which houses an interactive museum and job center, is regularly open to the public, but tours by bus and bicycle allow visitors to see the campus. To get there, take a bus to Flushing Avenue, the F train to York Street or ride a bike — if you don’t have one, there are Citi Bike stations nearby.

headline: Louisiana: One Killed and Five Hurt In Second Chemical Plant Blast
text: One person was killed and five people were injured in a chemical plant explosion in Donaldsonville, La., on Friday night, the state police said, a day after another fatal explosion at a chemical plant in the neighboring town of Geismar. The two explosions did not appear to be related. Friday’s was caused by a truck offloading material at the C. F. Industries plant, which produces nitrogen, among other chemicals, for fertilizers, said Lt. John Cannon of the Louisiana State Police.  The Thursday explosion, at a plant owned by Williams Companies Inc., based in Tulsa, Okla., killed two people and injured dozens. The Labor Department’s Occupational Safety and Health Administration is investigating the blast at the plant, which makes ethylene and propylene, highly flammable gases.

headline: A Myanmar in Transition Says Little of Past Abuses
text: YANGON, Myanmar — The former head of military intelligence, once feared and loathed for the torture his agents inflicted, now runs an art gallery. Myanmar’s former dictator, U Than Shwe, is reportedly enjoying a peaceful retirement in a secluded compound, while family members who grew rich during his military rule live luxurious lifestyles that contrast with the crippling poverty that afflicts most of the country. And a former top general in what was one of the world’s most repressive governments, U Thein Sein, is president, hailed both inside the country and abroad as a great reformer. He has been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize.

headline: Jerome Karle, Nobelist for Crystallography, Dies at 94
text: Jerome Karle, who shared the 1985 Nobel Prize in Chemistry with a former college classmate for creating what is now an essential tool in the development of new drugs, died on June 6 at a hospice in Annandale, Va. He was 94.

headline: Redesign for Living
text: Vishaan Chakrabarti, 47, has been a force in New York real estate for decades, working as director of the Manhattan office for the Department of City Planning and later as a senior executive at the Related Companies. Now he is the Marc Holliday associate professor of real estate development and the director of CURE, the Center for Urban Real Estate, at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation. He is also a partner at SHoP Architects, and recently published his first book, “A Country of Cities: A Manifesto for an Urban America.” Despite his many hats, Mr. Chakrabarti finds time on Sundays to work with his wife, Maria Alataris, also an architect, on renovations for their home near Union Square and to relax with their 5-year-old daughter, Avia, and 11-year-old son, Evan. The family lives on the top floor of a co-op on West 17th Street and was recently joined by a Havanese puppy, Hero.

headline: A Building Famous for Its Parties (Not to Mention Art)
text: From the outside, 404 East 14th Street, a former warehouse near First Avenue that runs through the block to East 13th Street, is unremarkable at best. The 13th Street facade is dominated by its fire escape; the focal point on the more commercial 14th Street side is a McDonald’s with a 24-hour express window.

headline: N.H.L. Trophies Awarded
text: After helping the Blackhawks to a narrow victory over the Bruins in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals, the Chicago captain Jonathan Toews logged a second narrow victory over Boston on Friday when he edged the Bruins’ Patrice Bergeron for the Frank J. Selke Trophy as the N.H.L.’s best defensive forward of 2013. Toews received 1,260 points from voters to Bergeron’s 1,250.

headline: Philadelphia Zoo Plans to Give Animals a Way to Roam
text: While other zoos have adopted trail systems in limited areas, the Philadelphia Zoo is the world’s first with a plan to rotate animals throughout its grounds.

headline: Marcum Slips in Bid to Stay in Rotation With Loss to Cubs
text: For the next two weeks, the Mets will be holding auditions for the right to remain in the pitching rotation. With the call-up of the top prospect Zack Wheeler to start in Tuesday’s doubleheader against the Atlanta Braves, the Mets will have three pitchers fighting for two spots.

headline: Joseph A. Unanue, Former Chief Executive of Goya Foods, Dies at 88
text: Joseph A. Unanue, who as chief executive helped Goya Foods become the largest family-owned Hispanic food company in the United States, died on Wednesday at his home in Alpine, N.J. He was 88.

headline: Voting in Iran
text: Iranians said that they saw an election as a way to send a message about their displeasure with the direction of the country.

headline: Reinvestigating the Friedmans
text: GREAT NECK, N.Y. — The letter to the Nassau County district attorney’s office was succinct and unambiguous.

headline: Christie Speaks With Bill Clinton
text: Gov. Chris Christie speaks to former President Bill Clinton about disaster preparedness in New Jersey and lessons other governors can take away from Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Bruins’ Depth Meets Its Match in Blackhawks
text: CHICAGO — The Boston Bruins are no longer a team that plays four lines. The team that used 12 forwards and whose fourth line destroyed the Rangers in the second round has changed. It is now a team led by star forwards.

headline: In Queens, a Casino Bet Gone Bad
text: On a recent Saturday afternoon I set out to explore South Ozone Park in Queens, in particular a stretch whose racial composition — according to recent census data, about a quarter white, a quarter Asian, 10 percent black and 11 percent biracial, with 30 percent of residents belonging to the statistical category of “other” — makes it one of the three most diverse patches of the city. Ethnically, too, it contains multitudes: Dominicans and Puerto Ricans live alongside Ecuadoreans, Indians, Pakistanis, Chinese and people who look as though they might be cast in the production of anything succumbing to Italian-American caricature.

headline: Ask a Transportation Officer
text: Next up in Metropolitan’s Q. and A. series is Pamela Elsey, 59, who as assistant chief transportation officer for New York City Transit plans whether and when your subway line will be repaired or improved.

headline: Messier Interviewed for Rangers Coaching Job
text: Mark Messier confirmed to NHL.com that he was interviewed for the Rangers’ vacant coaching position. “Obviously the Rangers would be a dream come true for a lot of coaches,” Messier said. The former Vancouver coach Alain Vigneault has already interviewed for the job, and the former Buffalo coach Lindy Ruff is also a candidate. The Los Angeles Times reported that the Kings assistant coach John Stevens, a former Flyers head coach, was in the mix as well.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE DARK KNIGHT RISES (2012) In this final installment in the director Christopher Nolan’s trilogy, Christian Bale stars as Batman, who has now retreated into the shadows — and his playboy alter ego, Bruce Wayne, who has gone into seclusion at Wayne Manor — years after the death of his foe Harvey Dent and the woman both men loved. Now Bane (Tom Hardy, above left, with Mr. Bales), an overmuscled brute who wears a mask that supplies him with a pain-relieving gas, is intent on destroying Gotham City. Bruce must also contend with Selina Kyle (Anne Hathaway), a cat burglar in search of a clean slate. Gary Oldman is back as Commissioner Gordon, and Michael Caine as Alfred, the Wayne family butler. “After repeatedly sending Batman down Gotham’s mean streets, Mr. Nolan ends by taking him somewhere new,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, choosing the film as a critic’s pick. “That’s precisely the point of a late sequence in which he shifts between a multitude of characters and as many locations without losing you, his narrative thread or momentum.” Like the scenes-within-scenes from his last movie, “Inception,” she said, “the controlled fragmentation works on a pleasurable, purely cinematic level.” But, Ms. Dargis added, “it also serves Mr. Nolan’s larger meaning in ‘The Dark Knight Rises’ and becomes his final say on superheroes and their uses because, as Gotham rages and all seems lost, the action shifts from a lone figure to a group, and hope springs not from one but many.”

headline: Simmons Upset With ‘SportsCenter’ for Editing His Joke
text: Bill Simmons is one of the most powerful voices at ESPN. He writes an influential column, runs the Grantland Web site and is a key part of the “30 for 30” documentary series. This past season, he got another job that appealed to his love of basketball, as part of the revamped N.B.A. studio show on ESPN and ABC Sports.

headline: Offense Still Absent as Yankees Lose Fourth Straight
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Weary, battered and undermanned is no way for a Yankees team to arrive in Orange County, home to many agonizing defeats for them over the years. They had lost 25 of their last 37 games at Angels Stadium since 2005, and that poor record was accomplished with players like Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and Jorge Posada.

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 15
text: NEWS As a group of rebels gathered in an apartment in Aleppo, Syria’s largest city, debating the value of the United States’ decision to provide them with weapons, government forces nearby began pounding an opposition-held neighborhood. The opposing events led the group to focus on a question asked on Friday by many in Syria’s beleaguered opposition: Would the promised aid come in time, or would be it be too little, too late? An older rebel who leads a few dozen fighters on one of the front lines in Aleppo was skeptical. “I’ll believe that America is helping us when I see American arms in my group’s hands, not statements and food baskets,” said the 40-year-old fighter, who calls himself Abu Zaki. Ben Hubbard reports from Cairo.

headline: Iran Moderate Wins Presidency by a Large Margin
text: TEHRAN — In a striking repudiation of the ultraconservatives who wield power in Iran, voters here overwhelmingly elected a mild-mannered cleric who advocates greater personal freedoms and a more conciliatory approach to the world.

headline: Google Calls U.S. Data Request Disclosures a Step Backward for Users
text: Even as tech companies were given permission to publish some data on national security requests for users’ data, Google said the authorization did not go far enough.

headline: Experiments With Democracy in Bhutan
text: Bhutan does things differently in South Asia, and nothing illustrates this so as much as the way it has conducted its transition to democracy.

headline: McCartney Plays to a Reverent Crowd at Bonnaroo
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — I can’t remember seeing a show — of music or really anything else — with so much privileged space and veneration around it as Paul McCartney’s two-and-a-half-hour concert here on the second night of the Bonnaroo festival.

headline: Police Storm Park in Istanbul, Setting Off a Night of Chaos
text: ISTANBUL — After 18 days of antigovernment demonstrations that presented a broad rebuke to the country’s leadership, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan ordered the riot police to storm the center of the protest movement in Gezi Park on Saturday evening, setting off a night of chaos in downtown Istanbul.

headline: The Early Word: Reinforcements
text: Today’s Times

headline: Rangers Said to Choose Vigneault as New Coach
text: CHICAGO — Alain Vigneault has agreed in principle to become the next coach of the Rangers, a person with knowledge of the situation indicated Saturday. The Rangers officially declined to comment on the reports, but an announcement of Vigneault’s hiring could come as soon as Sunday, an off day between Games 2 and 3 of the Stanley Cup finals between the Chicago Blackhawks and the Boston Bruins, if final details between Vigneault and the Rangers are worked out quickly.

headline: Worthwhile Canadian Comparison
text: I’m in Toronto, where I just received an honorary degree from the University of Toronto; and my thoughts have naturally turned, as they don’t do often enough, to matters Canadian. For it seems to me that Canada offers a useful test case for theories about what lies behind the Great Recession and the Not-So-Great Recovery.

headline: Hong Kong Demonstrators Show Support for Snowden in N.S.A. Leak Case
text: HONG KONG — Chanting slogans like “Shame, U.S. government,” demonstrators marched from a downtown park to the United States Consulate on Saturday to urge that Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor accused of leaking documents about American surveillance programs, be allowed to remain in Hong Kong.

headline: Attacks Test New Pakistan Government
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Islamic militants blew up a bus carrying female university students in Baluchistan Province in southwestern Pakistan on Saturday and then attacked a hospital complex where the wounded had been taken and local officials had gathered to comfort them, leaving at least 23 people dead.

headline: A Father’s Day Quandary: Go See the Mets or Not
text: The prospect of attending a major league baseball game for free with my two sons and my Dad on Father’s Day would normally be as good as it can get.

headline: Suddenly, Retiree Nest Eggs Look More Fragile
text: MANY Americans don’t have enough money to carry them through retirement — and many of them know it.

headline: Mandela’s Grandson Says Ex-Leader Is Recovering
text: QUNU, South Africa — A week after he was hospitalized with a serious lung infection, former President Nelson Mandela of South Africa has started to recover, his grandson said Saturday.

headline: For Snowden, a Life of Ambition, Despite the Drifting
text: WASHINGTON — In 2006, when Edward J. Snowden joined the thousands of computer virtuosos going to work for America’s spy agencies, there were no recent examples of insiders going public as dissidents. But as his doubts about his work for the Central Intelligence Agency and then for the National Security Agency grew, the Obama administration’s campaign against leaks served up one case after another of disillusioned employees refashioning themselves as heroic whistle-blowers.

headline: Pope Fills Key Job at Troubled Vatican Bank
text: ROME — Three months into his papacy, Pope Francis took his first significant step on Saturday toward making changes at the troubled Vatican Bank, naming a trusted prelate to fill a key vacancy in an indication that the pope intends to keep a close watch on the institution.

headline: Caste Is Not Past
text: BANGALORE, India — CASTE is not a word that modernizing India likes to use. It has receded to the unfashionable background. Newspapers reserve their headlines for the newer metrics of social hierarchy: wealth and politics, and those powerful influencers of popular culture, actors and cricket stars.

headline: 13 Major Winners Miss the U.S. Open Cut
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — Merion Golf Club has a history of crowning notable champions. But in the 2013 United States Open, 13 major winners did not make the cut when the rain-delayed second round was completed Saturday morning. The excluded group included Ángel Cabrera, a former winner of the event and the runner-up at the Masters in April, and Graeme McDowell, another former Open champion who was second last year and considered a favorite heading into this event.

headline: Variety: A Parental Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — The quote that makes up today’s acrostic is only a small part of a live performance that BILL COSBY gave in 1983, although I know most of it by heart. So do my kids as well as my parents, because the points Mr. Cosby made are universal when it comes to parenting and family-raising.

headline: China Sets New Rules Aimed at Curbing Air Pollution
text: HONG KONG — China’s cabinet has adopted 10 measures to improve air quality in the latest move aimed at responding to the dense smog that has repeatedly enveloped Beijing and other major Chinese cities in recent years.

headline: Can School Reform Hurt Communities?
text: NEW ORLEANS — BEFORE Hurricane Katrina, about 74 percent of this city’s schools were considered “failing,” based mainly on their standardized test scores. By 2012, that figure had dropped to 42 percent, even as the bar for passing was raised. Average ACT scores for the city’s public school students have inched up. In 2011, black students in New Orleans outperformed their peers in the rest of Louisiana for the first time since the state test scores have been tracked.

headline: U.S. to Keep Warplanes in Jordan, Pressing Syria
text: WASHINGTON — Ratcheting up the pressure on President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, the United States will keep American warplanes and antimissile batteries in Jordan, officials said Saturday.

headline: Spurs and the Heat Show the Rewards of Continuity
text: SAN ANTONIO — Springtime drama in the N.B.A. unfolds on parallel tracks, one lined with elation and triumph, the other with futility and despair, not all of it confined to 94 feet of hardwood.

headline: Why Colorado’s Fire Losses, Even with Global Warming, Need Not Be the ‘New Normal’
text: 11:53 a.m. | Updated below |As Coloradans grappled with the impact of the state’s latest wildfire disaster, some writers were quick to call this “the new normal” due to greenhouse-driven climate change.

headline: In Countrywide Case, Watchdogs Without Any Bark
text: FOR the last two weeks, a justice in New York State Supreme Court has heard testimony in one of the most pivotal cases of the financial crisis. The hearings will tell whether Bank of America can extinguish legal liability for more than a million Countrywide Financial loans by paying $8.5 billion in cash and agreeing to loan servicing improvements in a settlement struck with 22 investors in 2011.

headline: In California, Bolts May Hold Up a Bridge in More Ways Than One
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The plan was to finish construction on the new eastern stretch of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge and open it on Labor Day. Then the existing bridge, which partly collapsed in 1989 during the last major earthquake here, would be demolished.

headline: No Country for Slow Broadband
text: WASHINGTON — THERE is a popular story going around about the state of America’s broadband networks: service is pitifully slow, hugely overpriced and limited to the richest neighborhoods — whereas in Europe, service is cheap, fast and widespread because regulators force big companies to make room for smaller service providers.

headline: For a Horse of the World, a Finale in a Regal Race
text: There is no denying that Animal Kingdom is a citizen of the world. His father was Brazilian and his mother German. He has won the most famous race in the United States, the Kentucky Derby, and the globe’s richest, the Dubai World Cup. His talent has united an international cast of horsemen: an English-born trainer, an Australian breeder, an Arab sheik and 20 American partners.

headline: Solving a Structural Issue
text: Bolts on the new Bay Bridge have failed, possibly delaying the bridge opening.

headline: Bill McDermott of SAP, on Knowing What You Want
text: This interview with  Bill McDermott, co-chief executive of SAP, the software company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: I Know What You Think of Me
text: Recently I received an e-mail that wasn’t meant for me, but was about me. I’d been cc’d by accident. This is one of the darker hazards of electronic communication, Reason No. 697 Why the Internet Is Bad — the dreadful consequence of hitting “reply all” instead of “reply” or “forward.” The context is that I had rented a herd of goats for reasons that aren’t relevant here and had sent out a mass e-mail with photographs of the goats attached to illustrate that a) I had goats, and b) it was good. Most of the responses I received expressed appropriate admiration and envy of my goats, but the message in question was intended not as a response to me but as an aside to some of the recipient’s co-workers, sighing over the kinds of expenditures on which I was frittering away my uncomfortable income. The word “oof” was used.

headline: A Wearable Alert to Head Injuries in Sports
text: HARD knocks to the head are a constant concern in contact sports — and not just in football or boxing, where recent attention has focused. Millions of girls and boys play hockey, soccer, lacrosse and other sports where blows to the head from collisions and falls are part of the game, even in youth leagues and on high school teams.

headline: Ralph Graves, Who Strove to Keep Life Magazine Afloat, Dies at 88
text: Ralph Graves, a former writer, editor and executive at Time Inc. who as the last managing editor of the weekly Life magazine strove to keep an American institution afloat in its turbulent final years, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Smith Impresses Jets, but Role Is Unclear
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Geno Smith has made clear that he intends to be an upright, in-the-pocket, strong-armed quarterback in the N.F.L., and when training camp opens next month, he is squarely in the running to start that way with the Jets.

headline: The Next Iranian President
text: Hassan Rowhani, a moderate, has been elected the next president of Iran.

headline: Patience Yields Dividends for Brewers and Gomez
text: Before batting practice last week, by his locker in the Milwaukee Brewers’ clubhouse, center fielder Carlos Gomez wore a T-shirt with the logo of the Boras Corporation. Gomez is a proud client, and Scott Boras secured him a three-year, $24 million contract before this season, even though his career on-base percentage, to that point, was .294.

headline: What Sweden Can Tell Us About Obamacare
text: LAST month, for the 37th time, the House of Representatives voted to repeal Obamacare, with many Republicans saying that its call for greater government involvement in the health care system spells doom. Yet most other industrial countries have health care systems with far more government involvement than we are ever likely to see under Obamacare. What does their experience tell us about Republican fears?

headline: Messages Galore, but No Time to Think
text: I’M old enough to remember a simpler time in the office, when talking — whether in person or on the phone — was the main way to communicate. I once had a job where I filled out those pink “While You Were Out” slips for employees who had stepped away from their desks.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: How the Court Decides
text: Should the justices take the effects on society into account?

headline: What Periwinkle Looked Like
text: MONTEMURLO, Italy

headline: TimesTalks Luminato Festival Video: Willem Dafoe and Robert Wilson
text: The film and stage actor Willem Dafoe and the avant-garde director Robert Wilson, whose staging of “The Life and Death of Marina Abramovic” will have its North American premiere at the Luminato Festival, talk with the New York Times contributing culture writer and author John Rockwell.

headline: Charles Bengochea of HoneyBaked Ham, Carving a Career
text: I WAS born in Havana, but in 1959 my family left Cuba as the political regime was changing. I later became a naturalized American citizen.

headline: Fears of National ID With Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Driver’s license photographs and biographic information of most Americans would be accessible through an expanded Department of Homeland Security nationwide computer network if the immigration legislation pending before the Senate becomes law.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, June 16
text: “I never put online anything about where I live, my family, my pets. I’m even careful about what I ‘like.’ ”

headline: My Father, the Stranger
text: The photographer Diana Markosian travels around the globe to see the father she never knew.

headline: My Father, the Stranger
text: I KNOCKED on the door of a stranger.

headline: Dodgers and Yankees: A Gathering Made for Autumn
text: When the Dodgers played in Yankee Stadium, it was always the World Series back in the day. Back in the decades, actually, from 1941 to 1981.

headline: Mattingly Proudly Wears Dodger Blue, but Pinstripes Still Befit Him
text: LOS ANGELES — When Don Mattingly, at heart still the plain-spoken, small-town boy from Evansville, Ind., flies into New York and takes in the sweeping views of Manhattan, he cannot help feeling at home.

headline: Sources With Secrets Find New Outlets for Sharing
text: AT the end of the 1975 thriller “Three Days of the Condor,” a C.I.A. researcher played by Robert Redford, with the code name Condor, stands in front of The New York Times building. His life in danger, he is trying to save himself by taking his tale of government malfeasance to The Times.

headline: The Not-So-Good Old Days
text: MY column last month about the dangers of nostalgia inspired many readers to write to me about their family memories of the 1950s and ’60s. Some shared poignant stories about the discrimination they encountered as blacks, women, gay men or lesbians. Others described how much easier it was for their working-class fathers to support a family back then.

headline: Facebook Made Me Do It
text: A FEW weeks ago I was skimming through my Instagram feed when my mouth dropped open. Sandwiched between images of sunny afternoon outings and boozy brunches was a photo of my friend in a hotel room, wearing lime green thong underwear and very little else. It was scandalous, arguably over the top for a photo posted in public where, in theory, anyone who wanted would be able to see it. But people loved it. It had dozens of likes as well as some encouraging comments.

headline: A Daughter’s Search for an Invisible Presence
text: We recommend viewing this slide show in full-screen mode.

headline: Bill Schools Barry on Syria
text: WASHINGTON — NOT only is President Obama leading from behind, now he’s leading from behind Bill Clinton.

headline: Middle-Aged Music Man
text: ON a recent Sunday, I found myself in a small performance space in Brooklyn, wearing a jacket, which I rarely do, surrounded by 9-year-olds, and feeling more than a little anxious. I was 48 years old, and I was performing in my first piano recital.

headline: Stephen Hillenburg
text: Stephen Hillenburg is a former marine biology teacher and the creator of “SpongeBob SquarePants,” the most-watched animated series on television for the past 12 years. A worldwide cultural phenomenon, SpongeBob has had a tulip named after him in the Netherlands, and his bright yellow image is printed on hijabs in Egypt.

headline: The Pope’s Gay Panic
text: I HAVE many questions for and about the “gay lobby” in the Vatican, but I’ll start with this: How can you be so spectacularly ineffective?

headline: N.H.L. Players Watch as a Young Prospect Grows Before Their Eyes
text: TORONTO — Michael Peca met a newborn Justin Bailey in the summer of 1995.

headline: A Five-Time Runner-Up, Mickelson Leads the Open After Three Rounds
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — It took five and a half hours for Phil Mickelson to secure the pole position for Sunday’s United States Open finish, which was nothing compared with how long he has pined for a victory in this national championship.

headline: Coaches Play Down the Power Play in the Stanley Cup Finals
text: An N.H.L. coach has finally talked sense about the importance of the power play to winning hockey — to wit, not as important as most people think. That coach is Claude Julien of the Boston Bruins, the Stanley Cup champions in 2011 and finalists again this year.

headline: Egypt’s Perilous Drift
text: MARSA ALAM, Egypt — ON Tuesday, I visited a bakery in Cairo’s dirt-poor Imbaba neighborhood, where I watched a scrum of men, women and children jostling to get bread. You have to get there early, because the baker makes only so many subsidized pita loaves; he sells the rest of his government-subsidized flour on the black market to private bakers who charge five times the official price. He has no choice, he says, because his fuel costs are spiking. You can watch the subsidized-flour bags being carried on shoulders out the side door. “This is the hardest job in Egypt,” the bakery owner told me. Everyone is always mad at him, especially those who line up early and still leave with no bread.

headline: A Song for the Exonerated
text: Having lost 16 years in prison on a wrongful conviction for rape and murder, Jeffrey Deskovic opted for the simple exuberance of karaoke to celebrate the master’s degree he earned late last month from John Jay College of Criminal Justice. “I enjoyed singing ‘Live to Tell,’ ” he says of his graduation visit to a loud and friendly bar.

headline: A Judicial Travesty in Egypt
text: Human rights in Egypt have remained under attack even after the 2011 revolution that ousted President Hosni Mubarak. Still, it was a shock when the Cairo Criminal Court convicted 43 employees of foreign nonprofit groups, including 16 Americans, on criminal charges and gave them prison sentences of one to five years.

headline: Racially Biased Arrests for Pot
text: Researchers have long known that African-Americans are more likely to be arrested for marijuana possession than whites, even though studies have repeatedly shown that the two groups use the drug at similar rates.

headline: Don’t Blame the Work Force
text: There is a durable belief that much of today’s unemployment is rooted in a skills gap, in which good jobs go unfilled for lack of qualified applicants. This is mostly a corporate fiction, based in part on self-interest and a misreading of government data.

headline: Can’t Hide in the Cloud
text: Most Internet users were disabused of the notion that their online activities could be kept entirely secret long before the recent revelations that the National Security Agency has been tracking the phone calls and online communications of millions of people. And to a great degree, consumers have traded privacy for convenience — like having Web retailers store your credit card number to save you some typing on your next order.

headline: In Utah, a Local Hero Accused
text: THE morning after a catastrophic earthquake leveled buildings and killed thousands of people in Haiti in 2010, an Internet marketing millionaire from St. George, Utah, named Jeremy Johnson decided to cancel all his business meetings and arrange his own ad hoc aid mission.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 16
text: With the Obama administration planning to provide small arms and ammunition to rebel forces in the Syrian civil war, the Sunday shows will focus on the debate over whether this is the best response to the revelations that President Bashar al-Assad used chemical weapons against the rebels.

headline: Father Shares, and Looks Up to, Son’s Love of Hockey
text: I had wanted to play hockey since I was 14 and saw Guy Lafleur score a hat trick at the Forum while I was visiting relatives in Montreal. But I lived in Florida. The best I could do was fool around with a hockey stick and a tennis ball as I roller-skated up and down our suburban cul-de-sac near St. Petersburg, with a taped rectangle against the garage door as my net.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Highlights From Five Commencement Speeches
text: Amid an uncertain economic landscape, commencement speakers encouraged the graduates of 2013 to be bold and take risks.

headline: In Looser Tone, Speakers Urge Graduates to Take Risks and Be Engaged
text: A long, unpopular war had ended, but conflict brewed in the Middle East and the role of the United States in world affairs was in question. Months after his re-election, the president seemed to be in trouble amid revelations of government surveillance and secrecy.

headline: After Long Night of Counting, Post-Election Celebrations in Iran
text: The Lede followed developments in Iran on Saturday, where Hassan Rowhani, a moderate cleric supported by the country’s reformist movement, was declared the winner of Friday’s presidential election.

headline: Paul Soros, Shipping Innovator, Dies at 87
text: When Paul Soros, as a young engineer, observed that large cargo ships could not get to shallow-water piers to load and unload, he came up with a radical solution: take the piers to the ships.

headline: A Pre-Wimbledon Party in Germany
text: HALLE, Germany — An isolated town of about 21,000 in the state of North Rhine-Westphalia, Halle is an odd setting for a warm-up to the world’s most prestigious tennis tournament, Wimbledon.

headline: China’s Great Uprooting: Moving 250 Million Into Cities
text: BEIJING — China is pushing ahead with a sweeping plan to move 250 million rural residents into newly constructed towns and cities over the next dozen years — a transformative event that could set off a new wave of growth or saddle the country with problems for generations to come.

headline: Heat’s Return to Smaller Lineup Alters the Finals
text: N.B.A. teams that win 66 games, as the Miami Heat did this season, rarely find themselves making radical adjustments in the playoffs. It is also uncommon for teams that enjoy so much success to lose track of what took them to the edge of a second straight title.

headline: Walt Arfons, a Pioneer With Cars Using Jet Engines, Dies at 96
text: Walt Arfons and his half brother, Art, were the ultimate tinkerers. Working in garages adjoining their family’s feed mill and hardware store in Akron, Ohio, after World War II, they scooped up discarded automobile and truck parts along with old aircraft engines and patched them together to fuel their obsession with speed.

headline: Against Stupidity, The IMF Itself Contends In Vain
text: Yesterday the IMF chided the United States for spending too little and cutting its budget deficit too fast — and most people, if they heard about it, just shrugged. To be honest, that was my initial reaction too: we’ve come to accept the sheer stupidity of our current economic policies, and the fact that apparently nothing can be done about it, as part of the “new normal”.

headline: Alderson Expresses Optimism, but Mets Lose Again to Cubs
text: One fan asked Matt Harvey if he would ever consider joining the Yankees, and the fan was mercilessly booed until he apologized. Another suggested it was time for Gary Carter’s number to be retired, and he was cheered boisterously.

headline: TimesTalks Luminato Festival Video: Liz Diller
text: The architect Liz Diller, of Diller Scofidio & Renfro, the award-winning architecture firm whose many projects include re-envisioning New York’s Lincoln Center and transforming the High Line into an urban oasis, talks with the Times culture reporter Robin Pogrebin.

headline: Question Box
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Above all, don’t panic. And remember, there is no crying in crossword solving. Or crossword puzzle Web production, for that matter.

headline: Overshadowing Bad Behavior With Politics
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Tea for 2? Kentucky Senators in a Marriage of Convenience
text: WASHINGTON — Their relationship got off on an awful footing. In a Republican primary in his home state of Kentucky, Senator Mitch McConnell backed the establishment candidate in 2010, blinkered to the historic Tea Party wave that swept in the political newcomer Rand Paul.

headline: Regulator Charts His Political Future, With Eyes to the Right
text: Amid great fanfare two years ago, Barry Smitherman, then the Public Utility Commission chairman, bought a hybrid electric Chevrolet Volt. Now the chairman of the Railroad Commission of Texas, Mr. Smitherman drives a Chevy Suburban.

headline: Thomas Penfield Jackson, Outspoken Judge, Dies at 76
text: Thomas Penfield Jackson, a federal judge who ruled in 2000 that Microsoft was a predatory monopoly and must be split in half, only to see an appeals court reverse his order because he had improperly discussed it with journalists, died at his home in Compton, Md., on Saturday. He was 76.

headline: Echoes of Folly at Early Music Fringe Events
text: BOSTON – The theme of the Boston Early Music Festival this year is “Youth: Genius and Folly,” so it seemed a good idea to catch up with some young, rising stars in the field. A convenient opportunity presented itself on Friday afternoon with short concerts by Mylène Bélanger, a harpsichordist, and by the Sebastians, an instrumental group.

headline: Borghese v. Borghese: Battle for a Royal Name
text: Not just anyone can lay claim to the name Borghese, carried by the Italian noble family that has included rulers, philosophers and even a pope. Perhaps not even the Borgheses themselves.

headline:
Even Pessimists Feel
Optimistic About the
American Economy
text: For more than a decade, the economy has failed to grow the way it once did. Unemployment has not stayed this high, this long, since the 1930s.

headline: Afghan Forces, Taking Lead, Hold Steady in Violent District
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — First, the British marines tried to pacify it, and lost more soldiers there than anywhere else in Afghanistan. Then the American Marines moved in, and suffered severe casualties, before finally subduing it after a large troop increase. Now the foreigners are mostly gone from Sangin district in the southern Taliban heartland, and its fate is up to the Afghans.

headline: After Profits, Defense Contractor Faces the Pitfalls of Cybersecurity
text: WASHINGTON — When the United Arab Emirates wanted to create its own version of the National Security Agency, it turned to Booz Allen Hamilton to replicate the world’s largest and most powerful spy agency in the sands of Abu Dhabi.

headline: Belgian Diamond Theft, Filled With Cinematic Thrills, Also Has a Blooper Reel
text: GENEVA — When squads of fake police officers arrived in a whirl of blue lights, they struck with clockwork precision, plundering closely guarded packets of diamonds from the cargo hold of a parked plane and fleeing without troubling the passengers.

headline: Changing Perspectives Propel Chimp Protections
text: More than 50 years ago, Jane Goodall, then a young researcher at what would become the Gombe National Park in Tanzania, began introducing the public to the “fantastic beings” she had studied and lived with. In her book “In the Shadow of Man” and in later works, she showed the world complex animals with intricate social lives and helped change the way the world looked at the great apes.

headline: Where Grand Spanish Horses Learn to Be Medieval
text: Victor De Lara awoke early one morning not long ago to the sight of 40 white horses staring through his bedroom window. It was surreal, even for a man who has made a living with a company whose specialty is spectacle.

headline: Soldiers Killed During Overnight Attacks in Benghazi
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — Six soldiers were killed early Saturday in attacks believed to be retaliation for the expulsion of a major militia from the city last weekend, raising fears of an imminent showdown between the formal army units and rival militia brigades over control of eastern Libya.

headline: A Freed Man, an Ex-Wife and a Lawsuit
text: The spring of 1982 seemed full of promise for Steven and Traci Phillips, who had just started a roofing business in Dallas and were expecting their first child.

headline: Girl Wounded by Stray Bullet in Bronx
text: A 9-year-old girl was wounded on Friday after being shot in the stomach by a stray bullet in the Bronx, the police said.

headline: The Majors Seem to Sap the Energy From Woods
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — Tiger Woods looks tired. Not physically tired, not fatigued — he looks tired of falling apart at major championships.

headline: At Gezi Park, Tear Gas and Water Cannons
text: Violent clashes ensued between protesters and the police in Gezi Park just hours after the Turkish prime minister said it would be cleared.

headline: Parker’s Hamstring a Key for Spurs
text: SAN ANTONIO — The San Antonio Spurs’ title hopes might depend on the health of Tony Parker’s right hamstring, which apparently might last through the end of the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Rodriguez Runs at Three-Quarters Speed but Has Yet to Outrun Uncertainty
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Each day the progress reports on Alex Rodriguez travel from Tampa, Fla., to wherever the Yankees are, and are transmitted to Manager Joe Girardi. For weeks the progress was so minimal it almost seemed comical to address it.

headline: Spurs Need Production From Ginobili, and He Knows It Better Than Anyone Else
text: SAN ANTONIO — In a number of different ways and different languages, Manu Ginobili was asked Saturday why he had struggled in the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Top Seven in the World Skip Two Tournaments
text: Grandmasters from Azerbaijan and Vietnam won two fast-play world championships last weekend that were notable because none of the top seven players bothered to show up.

headline: U.S. Open Photo Replay: Third Round
text: Phil Mickelson, a five-time runner-up at the U.S. Open, moved into position yet again for his first victory in the tournament.

headline: Ovechkin and Crosby Split N.H.L.’s Top Honors
text: CHICAGO — Alexander Ovechkin and Sidney Crosby, the N.H.L.’s two highest-profile stars, split its two trophies for most valuable player, the league announced Saturday night. Ovechkin won the Hart Trophy, voted on by the Professional Hockey Writers Association. Crosby earned the Ted Lindsay Award, which is chosen by players.

headline: Thomas Roberts, Who Led Fight to Save Fire Island Lighthouse, Dies at 75
text: Thomas Roberts, a banker whose efforts to save the black-and-white-striped Fire Island Lighthouse in the early 1980s became a model for scores of lighthouse preservation campaigns around the country and yielded a popular tourist destination, died on Monday at his home in Bay Shore, N.Y. He was 75.

headline: Protesters Find Refuge in Hotel
text: The luxury Divan Hotel became a refuge for protesters after riot police raided Gezi Park in Istanbul and began firing tear gas, water cannons and, according to many demonstrators, rubber bullets.

headline: North Korea Proposes High-Level Talks With U.S.
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Sunday proposed high-level talks with the United States, saying that it was ready to discuss easing tensions and eventually denuclearizing the Korean Peninsula.

headline: 2013 Fantasy Football: Top 15 Running Backs
text: Arian Foster has had three consecutive seasons over 1,200 yards with double-digit touchdowns, but he’s not the top fantasy back.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 16
text: “For old people like us, there’s nothing to do anymore. Up in the mountains we worked all the time. We had pigs and chickens. Here we just sit around and people play mah-jongg.”

headline: Teixeira Aggravates Wrist Injury as Yankees Drop Fifth Straight Game
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Even after he returned, seemingly as healthy and as strong as ever, there was an element of concern with every swing that Mark Teixeira took. Would this one reinjure his wrist? Would the next one send him back to the disabled list?

headline: A Different Kind of Fatherhood
text: I came out long before gay men yearned for weddings, much less baby showers. In 1979, when I was 22, New York offered young men like me many freedoms, including the freedom to not have to propagate. Like many other gay men — and like many straight men — I had not been close to my own father. I could not imagine wiping runny noses, attending parent-teacher conferences or playing Candy Land.
