headline: Iran President-Elect Wants to Ease Strains With U.S., but Sees No Direct Talks
text: TEHRAN — President-elect Hassan Rowhani of Iran, speaking Monday for the first time since his election victory, said he wanted to reduce tensions with the United States but ruled out direct talks between the two estranged nations.

headline: In Performance: ‘Somewhere Fun’
text: Kate Mulgrew, left, and Kathleen Chalfant play two old friends who run into each other on a Manhattan street in “Somewhere Fun,” a surreal new play by Jenny Schwartz at the Vineyard Theater.

headline: Collectors’ Items
text: Student photographers rove their campuses for The New York Times. This issue, what students are collecting at San Jose State, Cornell and the University of Virginia.

headline: Yacht Builders Hit Rough Water
text: New Jersey boat makers hope to turn the tide as the recession leads to substantial declines in production.

headline: Hopes for Change in Iran
text: Will the election of a moderate cleric lead to real reform, or will powerful forces protect the status quo?

headline: Medical Helicopters Face Cuts
text: A proposed Connecticut budget may reduce emergency medical transportation.

headline: No More Yellow Ribbons
text: New Jersey families prepare for the return of National Guard members serving in Iraq.

headline: Wheels
text: Student photographers roved their campuses for The New York Times, capturing life at Harvey Mudd, the University of Arkansas and the Minneapolis College of Art and Design.

headline: Pride and Achievement
text: College students submitted visual expressions of their drive, passion and spirit.

headline: Abstract Expressions
text: Students submitted photos with an artsy eye on the higher-ed experience.

headline: What’s in Your Locker?
text: What students stash in their cubbyholes at college, high school and below. Text by Amanda M. Fairbanks

headline: College Life
text: In images of parties, people and activities, students made a statement about their college years.

headline: A Sense of Place
text: Students expressed their higher-ed experience through images of where they have been, and where they are. The common theme: broadening horizons.

headline: Simpler Substances
text: Student photographers roam their campuses for The New York Times. This issue: the marvels of making beer and sauerkraut. Text by Amanda M. Fairbanks.

headline: Where Rubber Meets Road
text: Q. With the millions of cars being driven billions of miles on American roads each year, why don’t I see residue from their worn rubber tires along the roadside? What happens to all that rubber?

headline: What Do You See?
text: Conceptual images as the basis for admissions essays.

headline: Public University Snapshots
text: Cutbacks and growth at eight top flagships. Text by Paul Fain.

headline: High-Speed Connections
text: Rutgers alumni advise job-seekers at a speed-networking seminar.

headline: Alternative Living
text: Student photographers rove their campuses for The Times. This issue: students striving to live off the grid (in a dome, teepee or mini-house). Text by Amanda M. Fairbanks

headline: Is Democratic Criticism on N.S.A. Hurting Obama’s Approval Rating?
text: A series of recent polls show President Obama’s approval rating at about 46 percent on average. This is somewhat lower than it was in late May, when it averaged 48 percent or 49 percent.

headline: G.O.P. Pushes New Abortion Limits to Appease Vocal Base
text: WASHINGTON — After Republicans lost the presidential election and seats in both the House and the Senate last year, many in the party offered a stern admonishment: If we want to broaden our appeal, steer clear of divisive social and cultural issues.

headline: Walkabout – 6/17: From Pittsburgh to D.C. by Bike, and Germany to England by Train
text: Biking Connection After 30 years, the final segment of the Great Allegheny Passage, above, from Homestead, Pa., to Pittsburgh, opened on Saturday. It links with the C&O Canal Towpath in Cumberland, Md., which continues to Washington. (USA Today)

headline: At Paris Show, Some Signs of Renewed Demand for Big Jets
text: LE BOURGET, France — After several years of intense demand for smaller, single-aisle workhorses, the European plane maker Airbus on Monday secured a customer for its twin-deck A380 superjumbo jet, in a deal the company hoped would signal a revival in interest in larger passenger jets.

headline: With New Lineup, Spurs Find One-on-One Success Against the Heat
text: The San Antonio Spurs’ reputation as exemplars of team basketball is well founded: no team is better at using passing and movement to derive a greater whole from five players. But in a 114-104 Game 5 victory over the Miami Heat on Sunday night, it was the individual ability of guards Tony Parker and Manu Ginobili that proved decisive as the Spurs routinely forewent their motion-based offense in favor of solo drives.

headline: AT&T Ready for a Deal, but Nowhere to Go
text: AT&T is all dressed up with nowhere to go.

headline: Nowadays, Fewer Tears at Her AIDS Concerts
text: Mimi Stern-Wolfe organized her first AIDS concert in 1990, after the death of a friend, and with a few exceptions she has made it an annual event – a kind of musical counterpoint to the changing shape of the epidemic. At the first concert, at Middle Collegiate Church in the East Village, the audience was dotted with men emaciated by the then-untreatable virus; listeners wept during the performance or left in tears.

headline: Surgical Skyscraper Demolition, Bill Nye the Science Warrior, Deconstructing the Doctor-Patient Relationship
text: In Japan, taking down 40 stories, a floor at a time; the science guy goes from teaching children to jousting on cable news; a doctor talks about better communication at the hospital bedside.

headline: A Warrior for Science
text: The Times’s John Schwartz takes a look at the career of Bill Nye and his quest to change the world through science literacy.

headline: Change We Can Believe In?
text: President Obama just had an enthusiastic reception in Belfast following an inspiring speech to the youth of Northern Ireland. But perhaps the president should worry more about his standing with a similar constituency back home—the young Americans whose energy and votes helped bring him back to office last fall.

headline: Czech Governing Party Moves to Form New Government
text: PARIS — The Czech Republic’s governing party began jockeying to form a new government on Monday after the prime minister, Petr Necas, resigned over an espionage and bribery scandal that has plunged the country into political instability.

headline: A Giant Bibimbap at a Korean Food Festival
text: There are 24 Korean restaurants concentrated near the intersection of 149th Street and 41st Avenue in Flushing, Queens, and locals refer to the area as Muk Ja Gol Mok, or restaurant street. So merchants and civic leaders decided to organize a festival by that name on Saturday, and they hope to make it an annual event, said Kim Young Hwan, president of the Muk Ja Gol Mok association.

headline: Neil Patrick Harris Set to Star in ‘Hedwig’ on Broadway
text: Neil Patrick Harris has made no secret that he wants to return to Broadway after his long run as the womanizing Barney Stinson on TV’s “How I Met Your Mother” wraps up. Now he’s making good on the promise, aiming to star in a Broadway production of the musical “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” in the spring of 2014, the producers of the show announced on Monday.

headline: Enjoy Venice; Please Don’t Swim in the Canals
text: In case you were considering a dip in one of Venice’s canals, don’t or expect to pay fines up to 500 euro. The city of Venice recently released a list of 10 no-nos aimed at tourists in a new campaign entitled “Venezia è anche tua, rispettala!” (Venice is yours too, respect it!).

headline: H.I.V. Tests Urged for 800 Million in India
text: Despite India’s enormous population, it would be cost-effective to fight its growing AIDS epidemic by testing all 800 million sexually active adults in the country every five years and treating all those infected, a new statistical study has concluded.

headline: The Leisure Pack Is Back
text: It was after midnight, and Leilanie Ramos just wanted clean clothes.

headline: Global Warming and Our Inconvenient Minds
text: I spent the first 20 years of my climate reporting focused on the buildup of human-generated greenhouse gases as a biogeophysical problem. Fuels and forests burn. Gases rise. Heat flows. Ocean chemistry changes. You get the idea.

headline: The Doctor-Patient Relationship
text: Danielle Ofri, a physician and author, talks about her new book, “What Doctors Feel.”

headline: Doctor Feelbad
text: In her new book, “What Doctors Feel,” Dr. Danielle Ofri tells the unforgettable story of a pediatrician she interviewed, a woman she calls Eva.

headline: Saying Less and Doing More
text: When I received a diagnosis of breast cancer in 2009, my friend Caitlin was one of the first people I called. And when she came to see me, she said the perfect thing: nothing. Instead, she burst into tears, gave me a hug — and then took me shopping for wigs.

headline: More Google Maps for Bikes
text: As short-term bicycle rentals like Paris’ Velib bikes expand in cities worldwide, navigating by bike has proposed a new set of challenges, including what’s the least trafficked route between X and Y? Google Maps, which began providing bike directions in the United States and Canada in 2010 and in nine European countries in 2012, just expanded its bike route directions to seven additional countries in Europe, including Germany, France, Poland, Ireland, Luxembourg and Liechtenstein.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: Margaret Howell Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the London fashion week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

headline: N.S.A. Leaker Denies Giving Secrets to China
text: WASHINGTON — Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who has confessed to disclosing troves of highly classified documents detailing American surveillance at home and abroad, said Monday that he had not given any classified materials to the government of China.

headline: For Olivari Olive Oil, a Campaign About ‘Little Things’
text: Olivari Olive Oil, a brand of one of the world’s largest olive oil producers, has embarked on an ambitious social media campaign to stake a claim in the United States market.

headline: Nervous Flier? He’ll Hold Your Hand
text: I’VE been traveling for business fairly consistently for about 20 years. For one thing, my office is in Irvine, Calif., but the corporate headquarters for Insperity  are in Houston. So there’s a ton of back-and-forth travel.

headline: User Satisfaction With Online Brokerages Declines
text: Scottrade moved to the top of the rankings in an annual study of customer satisfaction with online brokerages, but satisfaction with the self-serve tools over all fell from last year.

headline: The Heart Perils of Pain Relievers
text: Common pain relievers like ibuprofen and naproxen — called nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or Nsaids — are the go-to drugs for headaches and pulled muscles, arthritis and menstrual cramps. Their labels have long warned that overuse may increase the risk of heart attack and stroke, but we rely on them as we do on few other medications. And for good reason: They work.

headline: Triple Play: Week 11 Results
text: Robinson Cano and Prince Fielder, who have made pretty big names on their own, each collected eight hits last week to be the answers to our Father’s Day question.

headline: Snowden’s Questionable New Turn
text: When Edward Snowden first began leaking documents he purloined from the National Security Agency, he seemed to have a clear sense of purpose. He wanted to let Americans know that their government was secretly spying on the phone records of millions of innocent citizens, infringing on their civil liberties, and that it was demanding information on some of the Internet traffic flowing through American computer systems.

headline: The Trial of Whitey Bulger
text: Reporters who covered the Boston crime boss James (Whitey) Bulger describe how he became one of the most notorious gangsters in American history.

headline: How Do You Make a Building Disappear?
text: The Times’s Henry Fountain describes two unconventional demolition methods pioneered by the Japanese.

headline: Ludo’s Next Bite
text: For years, Ludo Lefebvre was a chef without a permanent address as his pop-up restaurant moved around Los Angeles. Now he’s settled at Trois Mec, cooking classic French dishes with a twist.

headline: Depicting the Colors of Space
text: The Cat’s Eye Nebula — a dying star in the constellation Draco — may appear in images in psychedelic shades of pink and green or in soothing tones of beige and aquamarine. But scientists apply more than artistic license when it comes to assigning colors to distant cosmic bodies that are telescopically photographed.

headline: Tricky Ways to Pull Down a Skyscraper
text: TOKYO — There are many ways to demolish a building, and some of them are spectacular: blowing it up from the inside so it collapses on itself, or smashing it to bits with a two-ton wrecking ball.

headline: Apple Executive Defends Pricing in Case on E-Books
text: Just days after Apple introduced the iPad and opened an e-bookstore, the biggest player in the e-book market, Amazon, changed the way it sold digital titles. Steven P. Jobs shot off an e-mail to the Apple executive who had negotiated deals with the publishers.

headline: Opposition to House Farm Bill Spans Political Spectrum
text: As the House prepares to vote this week on a new five-year farm bill, advocacy groups from across the political spectrum are lining up to oppose it, threatening to derail legislation that died last year when leaders refused to bring it to the floor.

headline: Role Player Has the Hot Hand, and the Spurs Find Him
text: SAN ANTONIO — Danny Green never hesitated, not with the ball in his hands and his feet behind the 3-point arc. Green, a role player for the San Antonio Spurs, kept launching the ball, and more times than not the ball swished through the hoop and the Miami Heat players continued to shake their heads.

headline: Iran’s Future Under Hassan Rowhani
text: Iranians react to the victory of Hassan Rowhani, a moderate who had previously proposed better relations with the West.

headline: With Trois Mec, Ludo Lefebvre Has a Place to Call His Own
text: LOS ANGELES — Ludo Lefebvre was always the chef without a restaurant, though it did not seem to have hurt him any. For six years, he commandeered empty spaces across Los Angeles as stages for the pop-up restaurants he called LudoBites, quick runs that lasted a few weeks or months. He built a base of intensely loyal fans who stormed the reservation line at the first whisper of the next LudoBites incarnation.

headline: A Marathon Meant for the Ears, Not the Feet
text: Stroller-pushing parents, tourists and harried traders in search of coffee were not to be seen at this year’s Bang on a Can marathon. Construction in the World Financial Center’s Winter Garden forced this annual new-music extravaganza to decamp on Sunday to the Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University, where there was none of the random walk-through business that has added touches of surrealism to the proceedings at the Winter Garden.

headline: Prom Memories at Halston Heritage
text: SENIOR PROM, the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria, 1990. The song of the night is Madonna’s “Vogue”; chicken paillard with capers is congealing on the plates; and the alpha girls of the class have chosen black Betsey Johnson dresses that barely cover their crotches.

headline: A Barrel of Trouble
text: At the start of Carl Hiaasen’s latest comedic marvel, a visitor fishing near Key West hooks a severed human arm. There is no time for this to register as grisly. A page later the captain of the fishing boat tells the freaked-out tourist reassuringly, “Well, son, we’re in the memory-making business.” You can’t argue with that.

headline: Till Death (or Duets) Do Them Part
text: In 2008 the dancers Chris Yon and Taryn Griggs moved from New York to Minneapolis. On Friday night they returned to New York to perform Mr. Yon’s piece “The Very Unlikeliness (I’m going to KILL you)” at the Club at La MaMa for the La MaMa Moves! festival. It was good to have these droll comedians back.

headline: Dwarf Galaxy May Be Answer to Predictions
text: A dim, lightweight galaxy on the outskirts of the Milky Way may be the smallest in the known universe, astronomers say.

headline: After Hours | A Performance Artist’s Heartfelt New Persona
text: Over his 30-year career, the performer John Kelly has used his lean frame and remarkable falsetto-to-baritone voice to conjure a panoply of classical and pop personas, including the Mona Lisa, Caravaggio, Egon Schiele and, most famously, Joni Mitchell. He has often done so through highly theatrical shows with costumes, choreography and elaborate visuals. But last night, Kelly unveiled a new cycle of covers, “Rebel Songs,” in the straightforward dinner-cabaret setting of the NoHo performance venue Joe’s Pub. (He’ll be back June 30, July 7 and July 14.) Save a few flourishes like glittery blue eye shadow, a bespoke black leather kilt and shiny foil hats for his musicians, Kelly took advantage of the format to remind the audience that his knack for setting a mood has more to do with a stray hand gesture, an odd stance or an unexpected modulation in vocal color than with any arty production wizardry.

headline: Outside Review of Clinical Data Finds a Spinal Treatment’s Benefit Overstated
text: Researchers have long argued that a heralded spinal treatment sold by the nation’s largest device maker, Medtronic, was no better than an older one and possibly more risky. Now with the company’s help, they have the proof.

headline: Five Coastal Drives for Summer
text: Winter and spring were tumultuous, weather-wise. Across much of the country, many have been battling blizzards, twisters, hurricanes and the occasional flash flood.

headline: Travel Security Companies Watch a Volatile World
text: NO place is without international travelers, so the routine at global travel security and emergency response companies that keep an eye on the world is never actually routine.

headline: Rickets Plagued Children of the Medicis
text: The rich are different from you and me, F. Scott Fitzgerald once wrote. But according to a new study in The International Journal of Osteoarchaeology, children of the Medicis, one of history’s wealthiest families, may have had rickets, a disease typically associated with the inferior diet and cramped living conditions of the poor. What’s more, the family’s wealth may have been to blame.

headline: Streisand Lends Her Support to Israeli Women
text: Barbra Streisand spoke out against the treatment of women in Israel by ultra-Orthodox Jews during a speech on Monday as she accepted an honorary degree from Hebrew University in Jerusalem, The Associated Press reported.

headline: ‘An Atlas of Modern Landscapes’
text: Images from the Corbusier show at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: ‘Back To Sleep’ Dividends (1 Letter)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photos from India, Syria, Turkey and Bangladesh.

headline: Factors for Dental Checkups (1 Letter)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Animals Are Patients Too
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Holographic Employees and Laser Archaeology
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Iran’s President-Elect Confronted With Plea for Detained Opposition Leader’s Freedom
text: At the end of his first news conference since winning Iran’s presidential election, the moderate cleric Hassan Rowhani was confronted, live on state television, with the raised expectations his election has stirred.

headline: In Bullies’ Hands, Nuts or Milk May Be a Weapon
text: Any difference can set schoolchildren apart from their peers and potentially make them a target for bullying. But a severe food allergy is a unique vulnerability: It takes only one lunch or cupcake birthday party for other children to know which classmates cannot eat nuts, eggs, milk or even a trace of wheat. It can take longer for them to grasp how frightening it is to live with a life-threatening allergy.

headline: New Albums by 3OH!3 and Falling in Reverse
text: 3OH!3

headline: Gathering Many Identities on the Road, Hip-Hop Returns to Its Roots
text: New York may be the birthplace of hip-hop, but London has now become one of hip-hop’s proudest homes. Sadler’s Wells Theater in London has been running an international hip-hop celebration called “Breakin’ Convention” since 2004, and for the first time, from Thursday through Sunday, this festival came to the Apollo Theater in Harlem as a co-production. The pun in the title is delicious. As the enthusiastic British D.J. Jonzi D explained on Saturday evening to the audience, this festival, like the art form itself, breaks conventions simply by presenting hip-hop from behind a proscenium arch. The history of Harlem and the Apollo, so central to the history of many black musical and dance styles, makes the wordplay all the more resonant.

headline: Undoing a Skyscraper
text: Japanese companies have developed cleaner and quieter techniques to take down high-rises.

headline: A 5-4 Ruling, One of Three, Limits Silence’s Protection
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court issued three 5-to-4 decisions on Monday. One limited a criminal suspect’s right to remain silent before being taken into custody. Another granted additional discretion to judges in sentencing. The third allowed a lawsuit against trial lawyers who had solicited clients using information from motor vehicle departments to move forward. The justices also agreed to hear a case on fair-housing laws.

headline: Q. and A.: Is Congress Broken?
text: On Sept. 18, 2008, with the nation on the precipice of a financial crisis, Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson told House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to gather a bipartisan group of lawmakers that very day. Congress quickly passed the bailout, but it was not until July 2010 that President Obama signed a sweeping overhaul of the financial system meant to prevent another Great Recession.

headline: Yankees’ Teixeira Is Likely to Return to Disabled List
text: Brian Cashman, the Yankees’ general manager, did not have much to be cheerful about when he spoke to reporters on a conference call Monday afternoon. His team is in a rut, losing 6 of 10 games on their recent West Coast trip, and medical issues continue to hound his team.

headline: Proven in Britain, Two Comics Try to Take New York
text: Dylan Moran likes to start with a pang.

headline: Kabel Deutschland Discloses Takeover Approach by Liberty Global
text: Kabel Deutschland said on Monday that it had received a preliminary takeover bid by John C. Malone’s Liberty Global, setting up a potential bidding war for the German cable operator.

headline: How Cyberwarfare and Drones Have Revolutionized Warfare
text: Since World War II there have been many advances in military weaponry, communications and technology. In early May 1942, naval forces from Imperial Japan and the allied forces of Australia and the United States fought in the Battle of the Coral Sea. That engagement was the first battle in which naval ships did not shoot upon or even see the opposing force. Aircraft carriers directly engaged one another using aircraft, with their long-distance reach, as their sole offensive weaponry. This new type of warfare, the carrier versus carrier, was an inevitable escalation of the air, radio and radar technology of the day. It was viewed as a revolution in military affairs.

headline: The Home-Cooked Challenge: Addicted to Snack Food, Trying to Change
text: On Saturday, I pulled the junk-food bin, took the Pop-Tarts out of the bread drawer and cleared off the cracker and cookie shelf, and our week without prepared foods began.

headline: City to Settle Pension Suit for Workers Called to Arms
text: New York City has agreed to settle a federal lawsuit that accused it of improperly withholding some pension benefits from police officers who were called to active military service after Sept. 11, 2001, newly filed court papers show.

headline: Celebrating a Poet of 3 Dimensions
text: “Le Corbusier: An Atlas of Modern Landscapes,” newly installed at the Museum of Modern Art, is really two exhibitions. It’s on the one hand a sprawling introduction to the life and work of this Swiss-born giant, on a scale that MoMA, hard though it may be to believe, has never previously organized. A little pruning might have helped. Hypnotic videos sometimes get noisy, distractingly so. But as an omnibus, long overdue, the show is riveting, fun, a landmark.

headline: Once Tallest Standing, Then the Tallest to Come Down
text: When it was opened to the public in 1908, the Singer Building at 149 Broadway held the record, however briefly, as the tallest skyscraper in the world. Sixty years later, it had the honor of setting a more enduring record – as the world’s largest skyscraper ever to be peacefully demolished.

headline: Yoga, Tents, Pulled Pork and Music That Lingers
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — My Bonnaroo this year probably wasn’t like anybody else’s. It couldn’t have been: it sprawled without a clear stylistic center. There were 121 shows of many stripes in four days, not counting the sets on the lesser stages, which would add up to about the same number. Vinyasa sessions, local pulled pork, neurotic comedians talking death and colonics. Films and videos, singalongs, dance-alongs. A campground world with solar-powered solo-electric guitar jams, food trucks, illicit this and that. A workshop called “Build a hula hoop! Appalachian Flow Arts.” A 530-acre principality of all-over-the-place-ness.

headline: Bright-Eyed and Bushy-Tailed, With a Serious Streak, on CNN
text: There is already way too much happy talk on morning television. So it’s a little worrisome that on the Monday premiere of CNN’s revamped morning show, “New Day,” Chris Cuomo responded to a report on the Supreme Court by his co-anchor, Kate Bolduan, by saying: “My mom says my tie is not on straight. How does it look? Look all right? Is it better now? All right, Mom, better?”

headline: Q. and A. With Clint Dempsey
text: It has been a long, long soccer season for Clint Dempsey, the captain of the United States national team who plays professionally in England’s Premier League for Tottenham Hotspur.

headline: An Invisibility Cloak, a Melting Continent and Angry Legos
text: Who wouldn’t click on the headline “Animal Invisibility Cloak Makes Cat and Fish Vanish”? Those of us who did were rewarded with one of the cooler science videos in recent memory, in which aforementioned animals did indeed vanish when they ducked behind aforementioned cloak, which was actually made of a special glass invention. Read on for details.

headline: Five New Musicals Top $1 Million at Box Office After Tony Awards
text: In its first week of performances after winning the Tony Award for best musical, “Kinky Boots” had its best run yet at the box office, grossing $1,474,349 through last weekend. Two other Tony winners, “Matilda the Musical” and “Pippin,” also had their strongest weeks so far, as did the audience favorite “Motown: The Musical,” which came up empty-handed at the Tonys ceremony on June 9.

headline: AT&T to Introduce Solar-Powered Charging Stations
text: As keeping the mobile life going becomes ever more important — both to wireless customers and the providers who serve them — AT&T says it has a new way to keep New Yorkers connected free.

headline: Can the Rich and Powerful Redefine Life for All of Us?
text: My Saturday Shortcuts column on a movement to redefine what a successful life means drew some enthusiastic responses from readers, and a few that were angry.

headline: Photo Replay: June 10-16
text: A roundup of the week’s best images in sports.

headline: Americans Are Reluctant to Aid Syrian Rebels, Polls Show
text: Americans oppose supplying military aid to Syrian rebels, but they are not paying much attention to the situation in Syria, according to new national polls.

headline: O.J. Simpson’s White Bronco Police Chase Happened 19 Years Ago Today
text: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HcyyCi2b2AY

headline: Large Truck Bomb Reported to Kill 60 Syrian Troops
text: Seeking to regain lost momentum, Syrian rebels mounted what appeared to be one of the deadliest strikes against government forces to date on Monday, sending a suicide bomber to detonate what they said was six tons of explosives in a truck. The bombing near the city of Aleppo in northern Syria was said to have killed as many as 60 soldiers.

headline: Hunting for an E.T. Castoff in a Most Terrestrial Place
text: ALAMOGORDO, N.M. — You are the world’s greatest video game maker, but suddenly you find yourself stuck with millions of cartridges of a game nobody wants. What do you do?

headline: True or Faked, Dirt on Chinese Fuels Blackmail
text: SHUANGFENG, China — The photograph usually arrives as an e-mail attachment or the old-fashioned way, in an envelope with no return address.

headline: Former Chairman of the F.T.C. Is Set to Join Davis Polk
text: Davis Polk & Wardwell has hired Jon Leibowitz, the former chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, a coup for the law firm as it bolsters its increasing presence in Washington.

headline: Britain’s Top Fraud Office Aims to Add Bite to Its Bark
text: David Green, the director of Britain’s Serious Fraud Office, is in a combative mood.

headline: Nurse Climbing to the Top in Hockey After Selecting a Different Path
text: BOSTON — Darnell Nurse is a big, tough 18-year-old defenseman and a top prospect in the coming N.H.L. draft, but his family gravitated to other sports. His father was a professional football player, and his uncle is Donovan McNabb. Nurse’s mother, older sister and aunt played college basketball, and his younger sister is on a Canadian national basketball team.

headline: 60 Years Later, Germany Recalls Its Anti-Soviet Revolt
text: BERLIN — The German president recalls it as an electrifying moment. One of Berlin’s most resplendent avenues is named simply the “Street of June 17” in remembrance. But the heady, short-lived uprising by hundreds of thousands of East Germans 60 years ago on Monday has never lived in history as the more famous anti-Communist revolts that followed — in Hungary and Poland in 1956, in Prague in 1968 and in Poland again in 1980-81.

headline: For Its Latest Beer, a Craft Brewer Chooses an Unlikely Pairing: Archaeology
text: CLEVELAND — The beer was full of bacteria, warm and slightly sour.

headline: Longing to Stay Wanted, MTV Turns Its Attention to Younger Viewers
text: TRYING to win over a fickle teenager isn’t easy. Trying to win over millions of them every night is — as the kids say — cray cray.

headline: Round by Round, Rose Comes Full Circle
text: ARDMORE, Pa. — There was not much Merion Golf Club could do to rattle Justin Rose, who was kicked by a chorus line of courses in his late teens. So complete was his failure during his first two years as a professional, the caddies on the European Tour snidely referred to him as “Justin Vite,” a nod to his dependence on the kindness of sponsors to get into tournaments.

headline: Maryland: Rape Inquiry at Naval Academy Advances
text: As many as three football players at the United States Naval Academy, in Annapolis, may soon face criminal charges in the case of the alleged serial sexual assault of a female midshipman in 2012. Vice Adm. Michael Miller, the superintendent of the academy, has decided to send the case to Article 32 proceedings, the military equivalent of a grand jury. The decision followed an investigation by the Naval Criminal Investigative Service, the academy said in a statement Monday. The exact number of football players who will face the proceedings has not yet been released, but officials previously said three players were under investigation. The investigation was dropped last year before it was reopened early in 2013.

headline: Maryland: Manning Trial Looks at Address Disclosures
text: Prosecutors laid the groundwork on Monday for trying to prove that Pfc. Bradley Manning gave WikiLeaks the e-mail addresses of more than 70,000 troops deployed in Iraq, a charge to which he has pleaded not guilty. As Private Manning’s trial at Fort Meade entered its third week, witnesses described how an individual could gain access to the internal directory of contact information for military personnel and how enemies could use that list against the United States. Defense lawyers countered that downloading the e-mail addresses of fellow military personnel was not against the rules. Evidence indicating that Private Manning released the e-mail addresses could damage his image as a good-intentioned whistle-blower who carefully selected which documents to release.

headline: After Gunfire, Politicians in Afghanistan Trade Accusations
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Even by the standards of an Afghan warlord turned politician, it was a memorable spat, involving wild accusations, dueling news conferences, a Twitter feed and — this being Afghanistan — actual gunplay.

headline: Top Senator on Panel Blocks Aid to Afghans
text: WASHINGTON — President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan may still be getting his monthly cash deliveries from the C.I.A. But now, until the Obama administration explains the rationale behind the payments, the Afghan government will have to go without $75 million in American aid.

headline: Put the Spies Back Under One Roof
text: WASHINGTON — THE revelation that Edward J. Snowden, a contractor at Booz Allen Hamilton, was responsible for the biggest leak in the history of the National Security Agency has sparked a furious response in Congress.

headline: Fraud Used to Frame Farm Bill Debate
text: WASHINGTON — Jimmy Thomas Sasser stood in silence in February as a federal judge sentenced him to four years in prison. For more than a decade, prosecutors said, Mr. Sasser, an insurance adjuster from Wilson, N.C., participated in a plot involving dozens of farmers, warehouse workers and insurance agents who conspired to defraud the federal crop insurance program of nearly $100 million by claiming fake losses on crops.

headline: To Get a Truce, Be Ready to Escalate
text: FOLLOWING the Obama administration’s conclusion last week that President Bashar al-Assad’s forces have used chemical weapons, the talk in Washington is all about military assistance to Syria’s rebels. That aid is necessary, but observers have overlooked a crucial point: the American decision to give rebels lethal aid, though it might eventually contribute to the overthrow of Mr. Assad, opens an opportunity for concerted diplomacy to end the bloodshed.

headline: More Data on Privacy, but Picture Is No Clearer
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Technology companies, the custodians of reams of personal data from hundreds of millions of people around the world, have been under fire after recent revelations that they secretly handed over customer information, including e-mails, in response to requests by the federal government made in the name of national security.

headline: Moving On: Part Two
text: The outpouring of comments on my column reporting the selling of my books and my musings on retirement comes close to matching the high-water mark set previously by columns on Hillary-hating and on phrases that set your teeth on edge (“Can I put you on hold?”). The difference is that the responses this time, rather than being combative or angry, are reflective, generous, kind, eloquent and, more than occasionally, wise.

headline: Writing Fiction and Nonfiction
text: When I wrote my second novel, I biked in New York City’s Riverside Park and plopped myself down where my character died in order to take in what she saw as her life ebbed. When I wrote my first nonfiction book, in one of more than 200 interviews, I grilled a woman about why she quit a sought-after job in Washington to live in Paris.

headline: The Mets’ Best Doubleheader, From 1969
text: The Mets, in an understandable effort to change the subject, have arranged to have Zack Wheeler and Matt Harvey team up as the starting pitchers in Tuesday’s doubleheader in Atlanta against the Braves.

headline: Beyond the Brain
text: It’s a pattern as old as time. Somebody makes an important scientific breakthrough, which explains a piece of the world. But then people get caught up in the excitement of this breakthrough and try to use it to explain everything.

headline: Headhunter for the Rich Turns on Them
text: Wall Street’s masters of the universe have a new enemy: Adrian Barrie Smith.

headline: After Sexual Abuse Case, a Hasidic Accuser Is Shunned, Then Indicted
text: Sam Kellner is a man twice shunned and living in a deepening shadow.

headline: Thousands Gather for Protests in Brazil’s Largest Cities
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Protesters showed up by the thousands in Brazil’s largest cities on Monday night in a remarkable display of strength for an agitation that had begun with small protests against bus-fare increases, then evolved into a broader movement by groups and individuals irate over a range of issues including the country’s high cost of living and lavish new stadium projects.

headline: Lesser Lights, Big City
text: Anthony Weiner’s quixotic mayoral candidacy is clearly a bid for redemption, and just as clearly a way to sate his epic, boundless need to be noticed.

headline: A Promising Moment in Iran
text: The election of Hassan Rowhani as Iran’s next president creates an opportunity to move forward on a negotiated agreement to stop Iran’s nuclear weapons program and to begin to repair three decades of hostility with the United States. The question is whether Mr. Rowhani and President Obama have the political skill and courage to make it happen.

headline: The U.S.D.A. Inspects Its Inspectors
text: In the United States, there are some 8,600 federal meat inspectors working in 6,300 packing and processing plants. Their task is daunting: visual and manual inspection of every carcass in plants that process thousands, and in some cases tens of thousands, of animals a day. How good a job does the United States Department of Agriculture’s Food Safety and Inspection Service really do? A new report from the U.S.D.A.’s inspector general is not encouraging.

headline: A Barrage of Data Requests
text: Technology companies received thousands of requests in the first six months of the year from American government agencies seeking information about their users.

headline: It Could Be Worse for Yankees (See: Dodgers)
text: The Los Angeles Dodgers have not played in the Bronx since they clinched the 1981 World Series at the old Yankee Stadium. It was so long ago that Brian Cashman, who has spent his entire adult life working for the Yankees, was actively rooting against his future employer.

headline: The Court: Right and Wrong on Criminal Justice
text: The Supreme Court handed down two significant criminal justice rulings on Monday that were mixed in how they will affect fairness and Americans’ basic rights.

headline: The Court: Congress Regulates Federal Elections
text: The Supreme Court, in a 7-to-2 ruling on Monday, strongly affirmed the power of Congress to regulate Congressional elections. The court held that Arizona cannot impose a requirement on voters to prove their citizenship when the federal law, the National Voter Registration Act of 1993, does not require any such thing.

headline: Loeb’s Third Point Raises Stake in Sony and Presses Split-Off Plan
text: The activist hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb has raised his bet on Sony as he continues his campaign to persuade the embattled Japanese giant into spinning off part of its entertainment arm.

headline: Unpredictable N.B.A. Series, Driven by Little Things
text: SAN ANTONIO — The hour was late, the mood was grim and LeBron James was doing that weird thing with his mouth again, scrunching and gritting and swiveling the entire lower half of his face, his discomfort on full display.

headline: A More Secular Europe, Divided by the Cross
text: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — Stanislav Zvolensky, the Roman Catholic archbishop of the Slovak capital here, was thrilled when he was invited to Brussels three years ago to discuss the fight against poverty with the insistently secular bureaucracy of the European Union.

headline: N.Y.U. Gives Its Stars Loans for Summer Homes
text: Follow one of Fire Island’s quaint footpaths away from the ferry dock, past modest cottages and better-appointed vacation homes, to an elegant modern beach house that extends across three lots. A composition in bold, unadorned planes, it has a perimeter of green and two separate entrances, each outfitted with the long ramps that are the local custom.

headline: Excerpts From N.Y.U. Mortgage Documents
text: The following are page excerpts from the mortgage documents of second homes of John Sexton, president of New York University, and Richard L. Revesz, a former dean of the law school.

text: “From their 7-Eleven stores the defendants dispensed wire fraud and identity theft, along with Slurpees and hot dogs.”

headline: In Embattled Detroit, No Talk of Sharing Pain
text: When New York City threatened to declare bankruptcy in 1975, the idea so terrified everyone that it forced the city, its workers and its recalcitrant bankers to sit down and find ways to share the pain.

Elite Units in U.S. Military to Admit Women
text: WASHINGTON — Women will be permitted to serve in the most intense and physically hazardous combat positions in the military, including the Navy SEALs, the Army Rangers and the Marine infantry, senior defense officials said Monday.

headline: At Trial, Hit Man Says ‘It Broke My Heart’ to Learn Bulger Was an F.B.I. Informer
text: BOSTON — Rare is the witness who takes the stand and immediately tells the court that he committed eight murders for which he has never been charged.

headline: Turkish Official Says Army May Have to End Protests
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s deputy prime minister on Monday raised the possibility that the army could be called in to help quell the continuing civil unrest, the latest sign of the government’s impatience and officials’ hardening stance against a nearly three-week-old protest movement.

headline: Quinn’s History of Mastering the Insiders’ Game
text: There was always a bit of scrappiness to the can-do activism of the New York City Anti-Violence Project, an advocacy group that promoted gay rights out of a neighborhood storefront in the West Village.

headline: A Boy’s Love of Cinderella
text: “We’ll get through this,” the older woman says to the younger, in a tone oozing sympathy and understanding, clearly intended to buck up faltering spirits. Ripped from its context, the line and its earnest reading might suggest that the troubles being faced are of a life-threatening or life-altering kind: a cancer diagnosis, the death of a close relative, a psychological breakdown.

headline: Abortion Restrictions in States
text: Forty-one states have enacted abortion restrictions at different stages of pregnancy. The chart below shows at which point after a woman’s last menstrual period that state laws ban abortion.

headline: Incorrect Date of Koch’s Birth on Tombstone
text: Four years before his death in February, Edward I. Koch commissioned a tombstone to serve as a monument to his achievements as New York City’s 105th mayor. He laid out precise instructions for the design and the inscriptions, and even inspected it himself when it was completed in 2009.

headline: Report on Metro-North Foreman’s Death Cites Actions of Student
text: A student rail traffic controller opened a section of Metro-North Railroad track in Connecticut without proper authorization last month shortly before a track foreman was killed by a train, according to an “urgent safety recommendation” that the National Transportation Safety Board issued on Monday.

headline: Solar-Powered Plane Faces the Human Factor
text: CHANTILLY, Va. — Nearing the end of a cross-continent flight powered by solar electricity, the designers of the Solar Impulse airplane are looking at the challenge of flying around the globe but focusing on the weak spot in their cutting-edge technological effort: human frailty.

headline: Justice Dept. Releases Recommended Fates for Guantánamo Detainees
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Monday opened a window on how the government views the 166 remaining inmates at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, releasing a list showing who has been recommended for transfer, prosecution or continued detention without trial.

headline: New Face Arrives to Brighten a Mets Season Many Fear Is Already Lost
text: ATLANTA — It has been an ongoing force, the hype surrounding Zack Wheeler, shadowing the struggling Mets this season from far away, from wherever the organization’s Class AAA team was playing.

headline: Senator Tries to Run Out the Clock on Immigration
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Jeff Sessions, an elfin Alabamian with a mischievous smile and a relentless approach to legislative battle, has a theory about the sweeping immigration bill pending in the Senate: It’s as good as dead.

headline: Proposed Celtics Trade Could Send Rivers to the Clippers
text: BOSTON — They once traded franchises. They took months to formalize what should have been a simple deal for Bill Walton. Now, the Boston Celtics and the Los Angeles Clippers are discussing a trade involving a coach.

headline: New York City Graduation Rate Remains Steady
text: The graduation rate for students in New York City public high schools held relatively steady last year despite more rigorous requirements, according to city and state statistics released Monday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Albany May Tighten Rein on Banking Consultants
text: New York State’s top financial regulator is preparing to crack down on the consulting firms that banks hire to navigate legal problems like money laundering and wrongful foreclosures, according to people briefed on the plans.

headline: Bernard Sahlins, Patriarch of Sketch Comedy, Dies at 90
text: Bernard Sahlins, a founder and former owner of the Second City, the Chicago nightclub that helped establish improvisational sketch comedy as a rudiment of American entertainment and created a resident troupe that propelled the careers of myriad funnymen and women, died on Sunday at his home in Chicago. He was 90.

headline: Where Corn Is King, a New Regard for Grass-Fed Beef
text: BASSETT, Neb. — Isolation comes with the territory in the Sandhills of Nebraska, where grassy dunes laced with wet meadows undulate above the Ogallala Aquifer, and the thinning towns are few and far between.

headline: Boy Praised for Saving His Mother in an Attack
text: As the Father’s Day barbecues wound down amid the fall of night on Sunday, an 11-year-old boy burst from a two-story white home in South Jamaica, Queens, screaming frantically for help.

headline: With Grass-Fed Beef, Midwest Ranchers Take Their Time
text: In rural grasslands, some breeders opt to raise cows that take longer to mature but are free of chemicals, hormones and grain.

headline: Two Views of the Night 27 Shots Were Fired
text: In Thomas Dunikowski’s telling, the evening of July 11, 2011, sounded like a scene out of “Lord of the Flies.”

headline: As Prison Term Nears, Lawyers for Astor’s Son Fight On
text: With a scheduled day of surrender to serve a prison sentence bearing down, lawyers for Anthony D. Marshall, the son of the society doyenne Brooke Astor, have unleashed a flurry of legal efforts to keep their aging client out of prison at least a little longer.

headline: Maxine Stuart, 94, Dies; Acted on Stage, Film and TV
text: Maxine Stuart’s stage, film and television career spanned more than six decades, including a recurring role on the soap opera “The Edge of Night” and a guest spot on a memorable episode of “The Twilight Zone.”

headline: Obama Defends Authorization of Surveillance Programs
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama defended his authorization of recently revealed domestic and international surveillance programs in comments broadcast Monday night but rejected the suggestion that his policies were basically a warmed-over version of those of the last White House.

headline: Cuomo Says Abortion and Anticorruption Bills Aren’t Likely to Pass Legislature
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo acknowledged on Monday that two of his priorities — enshrining abortion rights more firmly into state law and enacting new anticorruption laws — were not likely to be taken up by the Legislature this year.

headline: Derailment of L.I.R.R. Train Blocks East River Tunnel
text: An eastbound Long Island Rail Road train carrying about a thousand passengers derailed on Monday shortly after leaving Pennsylvania Station, blocking an East River tunnel and causing delays during the evening rush, officials said.

headline: The Latest to Disclose Government Requests, Yahoo Reveals the Least
text: Following in the footsteps of Facebook, Microsoft and Apple, Yahoo disclosed late Monday some broad data about the number of requests that American law enforcement authorities had made for data about its users.

headline: Bob Meistrell, Who Revolutionized Wet Suits, Dies at 84
text: Bob Meistrell, who began making wet suits for surfers and scuba divers in the early 1950s and with his twin brother, Bill, founded Body Glove, one of the world’s largest wet-suit companies, died on Sunday in Catalina, Calif. He was 84 and lived in Redondo Beach.

headline: Top Democrats in Senate Urge Faster Action
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democratic leaders sought on Monday to spur their colleagues to pick up the pace as the immigration debate entered its second week.

headline: Director of Enforcement Agency Resigns to Work for Bank
text: John T. Morton, the director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, the Department of Homeland Security agency in charge of controlling illegal immigration, announced Monday that he was stepping down after four years to work for a private bank.

headline: Dealt Early Blow, Blackhawks Are Punchless vs. Bruins
text: BOSTON — The Bruins on Monday played like the relentless team that swept the Penguins from the playoffs. And they did not need overtime to prove it.

headline: How the Revival of Postwar Germany Began
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

text: ceremonious •\ˌser-ə-ˈmo-ne-əs\• adjective

headline: Afghan Forces Struggle as U.S. Weans Them Off Support
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — When the American-led NATO coalition officially transferred security responsibility for all of Afghanistan to government forces in a ceremony on Tuesday, it was in part a formality. Already this year, Afghan forces have been in the lead in fighting the Taliban in more than three-quarters of the country — and they have been killed and wounded at a record pace, accordingly.

headline: Trying to Revive Mideast Peace Talks, Kerry Finds a Conflicted Israel
text: JERUSALEM — The intractable Israeli-Palestinian conflict can be seen as a trio of conflicts.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 6 P.M. (Cinemax) SAFE HOUSE (2012) Tobin Frost (Denzel Washington, above), a rogue superspy formerly with the Central Intelligence Agency and called “the black Dorian Gray,” is held for debriefing in a Cape Town safe house by an untested rookie, Matt Weston (Ryan Reynolds), after dodging a gun-toting gang and slipping into the American Embassy in this thriller about the very bad things that operatives sometimes do in the name of country and company. Despite cutting among as many as four action scenes at a time, the director, Daniel Espinosa, “maintains a visually coherent, narratively rational sense of time and space, no matter how fast the story shifts about, which it does with increasing speed when that same heavily armed horde that had been chasing Frost breaches the safe house, slaughtering most of the American operatives and sending Frost and Weston running,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “ ‘Safe House’ is essentially and very effectively a rollicking smash-and-crash chase movie that happens to be surprisingly well acted.”

headline: News Quiz | June 18, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: After Long Delay, Mets Lose to Braves on a Homer in the Ninth
text: ATLANTA — The game here on Monday between the Mets and the Atlanta Braves began 3 hours 43 minutes after its scheduled start time, amid a lingering drizzle. Once under way, it was finished quickly, the teams looking eager to get a decent night’s sleep before a scheduled day-night doubleheader Tuesday.

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 18
text: NEWS European Union leaders and President Obama announced on Monday the start of negotiations for a far-reaching trans-Atlantic trade deal, but French indignation over recent remarks by a high-ranking Brussels official created a sideshow here at the Group of 8 meeting. Stephen Castle and Jackie Calmes report from Enniskillen, Northern Ireland.

headline: From Nepal, a Push to End Human Trafficking
text: BEIJING — Human trafficking is one of the world’s fastest-growing crimes, the United Nations says, with nearly 21 million people falling victim each year. More than half of the victims of forced labor are from the Asia-Pacific region, the International Labor Organization estimates. It’s a major policy challenge and in Asia, Nepal is leading the way in terms of legislation, according to the San Francisco-based Asia Foundation.

headline: Blast Apparently Aimed at an Afghan Politician Kills 3 in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An explosion heard across Kabul on Tuesday morning appeared aimed at killing a prominent ethnic Hazara politician as he was traveling in his armored convoy. The politician survived, but at least three civilians were killed, according to the Kabul police.

headline: Protests Expand in Brazil, Fueled by Video of Police Brutality
text: Last Updated, 6:57 p.m. As my colleague Simon Romero reports from São Paulo, more than 200,000 Brazilians filled the streets in cities across the country on Monday to protest the high cost of living and lavish spending on soccer stadiums ahead of next year’s World Cup, in demonstrations that have intensified as images of police brutality against peaceful protesters spread on social networks.

headline: Test Yourself | English, June 18, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Behind Kanye’s Mask.”

headline: Bill Nye, Champion for Science
text: In the article “Firebrand for Science, and Big Man on Campus,” John Schwartz writes about the television personality Bill Nye and his efforts to promote science.

headline: What Paintbrush Makers Know About How to Beat China
text: As I toured Israel Kirschner’s Bronx paintbrush factory earlier this month, I couldn’t stop feeling amazed that it was still in business. Many days, Kirschner feels the same way. The charming, energetic 69-year-old joked about his ancient equipment (“That could be 100 years old,” he said of a bristle-cleaning machine); his two least-committed employees, his son and daughter (“They come late, they leave early”); and how his business has been increasingly undercut by Chinese manufacturers. After introducing me to his star brush maker, Fermin Gil, a Mexican immigrant who “can just see” when a brush isn’t right, Kirschner handed me a one-inch boar-bristle brush with a wooden handle. A Chinese manufacturer sells it for 30 cents. If he made it himself, he told me, it would cost significantly more.

headline: Exotic Explorers Venture From the Archive
text: “Slowly, rope length by rope length, we progressed. The declining sun flamed and died around us, a vivid furnace with bars of scarlet spread behind Mount Everest, and the tropic night dashed upon us.” So began an article on the front page of The New York Times in 1930, datelined Jonsong Base Camp. And if time and technology have made the Himalayas more accessible geographically, much else about this dispatch — the breathless prose, the heraldic portraiture — seems more distant and mysterious with each passing year.

headline: West African Piracy Exceeds Somali Attacks, Report Says
text: LONDON — In a marked shift in patterns of maritime piracy, three leading organizations reported Tuesday that in 2012, for the first time, the number of ships and sailors attacked off West Africa exceeded those assaulted by pirates based in Somalia, on Africa’s east coast.

headline: A Small Subwoofer With Case-Busting Bass
text: The normal formula of high fidelity says bigger speakers equal more bass, but Sunfire has turned that calculus on its head with the Atmos subwoofer. Designed by the physicist and audio rule-breaker Bob Carver, the Atmos is about the size of five or so stacked hardback books.

headline: The Graduates
text: TEL AVIV — Like other 16-year-olds, my son tends to say “O.K.” to express anything between “pretty bad” and “very good.” Three weeks ago, when he came home from taking the math section of his “Bagrut” exam, the Israeli high-school matriculation test, he said it had gone “O.K.” We, the parents, later discovered that most students had in fact found it extremely difficult — so much so that the supervisor for math studies at the Education Ministry received threats over the phone because of it.

headline: In Europe, Sales of Cars Hit Their Lowest Level in 20 Years
text: PARIS — European car sales tumbled again in May, reaching their lowest level in 20 years, manufacturers’ data showed Tuesday, but analysts and industry officials said the market might have finally begun to bottom out.

headline: Turkey Arrests Dozens in Crackdown on Protests

headline: Fraud Charges for Former UBS Trader

headline: In Performance: Kate Mulgrew and Kathleen Chalfant of ‘Somewhere Fun’

headline: Maggie Gyllenhaal to Star in ‘The Village Bike’ for MCC Theater
text: After featured roles in recent Off Broadway productions of Chekhov’s “Uncle Vanya” and “Three Sisters,” Maggie Gyllenhaal will switch things up and star in a new play, the sexually charged British drama “The Village Bike,” at MCC Theater next year, the company announced on Tuesday. Its 2013-14 season will also include “Hand to God,” a black comedy about a teenager battling his demonic sock puppet, which was a critical and audience favorite during an Off Off Broadway run in 2011.

headline: Patient, Heal Thyself
text: “Do no harm by doing nothing at all” (June 12) reminds me of the time my husband’s medications were withdrawn. In the hospital, he had written on a board, “Treatment: Benign Neglect!”

headline: University of Michigan Students Ready Solar Car for Australian Race
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. – The University of Michigan solar car team’s newest creation features four wheels instead of three, incorporates an asymmetric driving position in the name of increased efficiency and maximizes its Detroit connections as it heads for the biennial World Solar Challenge this October in Australia.

headline: A Tiny Amp for Power-Hungry Headphones
text: NuForce, a maker of audio electronics, has come up with a mini-headphone amplifier, the MMP, which stands for Mobile Music Pump. Using it to increase the power of your music player may improve the sound quality.

headline: At 52, Not Too Old for a Debut Novel
text: Among the many things I wasn’t prepared for after publishing my first novel at the age of 52 was the question I’m asked most often. I’ve heard it at book tour events in England, Germany, and here in the United States. The wording and language vary, but the gist of the question is the same: “Aren’t you too old for this?”

headline: Provocative Show Runner, Rehired at ‘Community,’ Apologizes for New Provocative Remarks
text: Hardly a week after he was reinstated as the show runner of “Community,” Dan Harmon, the beloved but unpredictable creator of that NBC comedy, offered his employers an unpleasant reminder of the loose-cannon qualities that got him fired in the first place by making remarks on a podcast that drew outrage and for which he apologized.

headline: Twilight of India’s Telegram Operators
text: On Saturday afternoon, Vikrant Deshpande, a 32-year-old Indian Air Force pilot, drove with his wife to the Central Telegram Office in New Delhi. The newly married couple gazed at a sign in the Telegram Office lobby that read, “Standard Phrases for Greeting Telegrams.”

headline: In China, a Controversial Law Is Seen to Excuse Sex With Minors
text: BEIJING — When Yan Yinhong, having removed a pair of pants from under her long dress, did a handstand and exposed her leotard-covered crotch onto which she had painted the face of a Chinese policeman, she intended to shock.
