text: Immaculate Infatuation: The best outdoor dining this summer in New York City, with the pictures to prove it. Gardens, patios and porches only — no sidewalk cafes need apply. (Click the link to get free PDF at Scribd.) — Julia Moskin

headline: Johnny Smith, Venerable Jazz Guitarist, Dies at 90
text: Johnny Smith, a jazz guitarist who was considered one of the emerging greats of his generation when he left the limelight in 1958 to move to Colorado, open a record store and become a full-time parent, died on June 11 at his home in Colorado Springs. He was 90.

headline: Let Us Start Composting Vegetables
text: Faced with a deadline of December 31, his last day as mayor of New York City, Michael Bloomberg has moved into overdrive. Last week he announced a new plan for combating hurricanes, along with an elaborate proposal for new building codes. It’s still early in this week, but already his administration has announced plans for the biggest expansion in recycling in more than 20 years: Mr. Bloomberg wants New Yorkers to start composting their food scraps. That means saving things like pizza crusts, bits of noodle in the Chinese takeout container, chicken bones and uneaten salad to go into a recycling bin.

headline: Royalty Pharma Drops Bid for Elan
text: LONDON – Royalty Pharma withdrew its takeover offer for the Irish drug company Elan on Tuesday, ending a fierce four-month acquisition battle.

headline: Fatal Floods Hit North India
text: NEW DELHI—Flash floods in northern India, which have killed at least 70 people over the past four days, have stranded 30,000 tourists and pilgrims in the Himalayan states of Uttarakhand and Himachal Pradesh, government officials said Tuesday.

headline: Globalization and Macroeconomics
text: My dialogue with Monti, to the extent that it was a “debate”, focused on the whole issue of structural reform; not on whether it’s a good thing (of course it depends on what’s being reformed, but surely every economy has structural problems that need work), but on whether it deserves the kind of star billing it gets in discussions of crisis response. More on that in another post, I think.

headline: Taliban Step Toward Afghan Peace Talks Is Hailed by U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — The Taliban signaled a breakthrough in efforts to start Afghan peace negotiations on Tuesday, announcing the opening of a political office in Qatar and a new readiness to talk with American and Afghan officials, who said in turn that they would travel to meet insurgent negotiators there within days.

headline: How the I.R.S. Encourages Oil and Gas Spinoffs
text: The grand bargain of the landmark tax legislation of 1986 was a deal for higher corporate taxes and higher capital gains taxes in exchange for lower rates on ordinary income. For the bargain to work, the boundaries of the corporate tax base had to be reinforced.

headline: The Gun Report: June 18, 2013
text: We often write about gun buybacks in this space, but here’s something new: a toy gun buyback.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: Alexander McQueen Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Structural Excuses
text: I promised in an earlier post to say something about why these days I tend to get annoyed when I hear the phrase “structural reform”, especially in Europe.

headline: Vandals Hit Mixed Suburb of Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM — The tires of 28 cars were slashed and anti-Arab graffiti was sprayed early Tuesday in Abu Ghosh, a quiet Arab-Israeli suburb of Jerusalem whose famous hummus makes it a popular destination for Jews and tourists.

headline: Tribune Faces Potentially Big Tax Bill for Newsday and Cubs Deals
text: The Tribune Company faces a potential tax bill of more than $500 million over the sales of the Chicago Cubs and Newsday despite efforts to minimize the tax consequences of both deals, the company disclosed on Monday.

headline: More on the Plane That Didn’t Crash, and ‘Truthiness’
text: A few weeks ago, I wrote about the plane that didn’t crash – that is, about a Lives piece in The Times Magazine that has drawn significant criticism from aviation experts including Patrick (“Ask the Pilot”) Smith and from James Fallows, a well-known journalist who writes for The Atlantic.

headline: Obama Raises Possibility of Change at the Fed
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama suggested that he was likely to nominate a new Federal Reserve chairman later this year, saying in a television interview aired late Monday that the current chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, had “already stayed a lot longer than he wanted or he was supposed to.”

headline: Zapping Bugs With the Wave of a Racket
text: Zapping mosquitoes with an electrified tennis racket might seem to be a surefire entrant into the World’s Dumbest Ideas Hall of Fame.

headline: Gee Almost Reproduces a Magical Mets Performance
text: In anticipation of Tuesday’s Matt Harvey-Zack Wheeler doubleheader against the Atlanta Braves, The New York Times published a brief article recalling the doubleheader of all doubleheaders for the Mets — when Jerry Koosman and Don Cardwell helped produce back-to-back 1-0 shutouts against the Pittsburgh Pirates and drove in the only run in each game, to boot.

headline: 2008 Bomber of Times Sq. Military Station May Have Had Lookouts, F.B.I. Says
text: In the early morning hours of March 6, 2008, a solitary bomber rode up to the military recruiting station in Times Square on a blue bicycle, knelt down and lighted the fuse of an explosive device. Then he took off, his identity unknown.

headline: Reduced Shakespeare Workout
text: The quick-witted Reduced Shakespeare Company highlights the athletic achievements in Shakespeare’s works.

headline: The ‘4-Minute Workout’ Playlist
text: Christopher McDougall reads from his book “Born to Run.”

headline: Burberry
text: The Burberry collection at London men’s fashion week, included colorful outerwear and bold accessories.

headline: If You Like Hall & Oates, Try Fitz and the Tantrums
text: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Burberry Prorsum: Spring 2014 Menswear
text: London

headline: Variations On an Article: Jeremy Denk Gets a Book Contract
text: Soon after The New Yorker published the pianist Jeremy Denk’s “Every Good Boy Does Fine” in its April 8 issue, Mr. Denk took to his blog Think Denk, and offered a bit of editorial second-guessing about his illuminating memoir of his studies.

headline: Regulators Are Divided Regarding Consultants
text: 8:33 p.m. | Updated

headline: Image of the Day: June 18
text: Jackie Chan at the Chinese Film Festival in New Delhi.

headline: A Pro-Clinton PAC Receives the Support of a Key Obama Backer
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Claire McCaskill, a Missouri Democrat and one of Barack Obama’s first backers in the Senate in his bitter presidential primary fight against Hillary Rodham Clinton, threw her support on Tuesday to the political action committee pressing Mrs. Clinton to run for president.

headline: Father’s Day Postscript: The Best Rally We Never Saw
text: The Glickson family — minus stubborn Grandpa Larry — did indeed attend the Mets game at Citi Field on Father’s Day. Unfortunately, we did not see Kirk Nieuwenhuis’s game-ending three-run homer, which beat the Chicago Cubs, 4-3. Nor did we see Marlon Byrd’s solo shot to start the inning, Lucas Duda’s walk, John Buck’s single and Omar Quintanilla’s sacrifice bunt.

headline: Protests Widen as Brazilians Chide Leaders
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Shaken by the biggest challenge to their authority in years, Brazil’s leaders made conciliatory gestures on Tuesday to try to defuse the protests engulfing the nation’s cities. But the demonstrators remained defiant, pouring into the streets by the thousands and venting their anger over political corruption, the high cost of living and huge public spending for the World Cup and the Olympics.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Week: Shaun Samson Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Kids With Food Allergies May Be Targets for Bullies
text: “In a recent survey of 251 sets of parents and children with food allergies, published in Pediatrics in January, roughly a third of the children reported being bullied for their allergies. … Surprisingly, classmates may prey on their vulnerability, plotting to switch a child’s lunch to see if she gets sick, for example, or spitting milk at a child’s face and causing a swift anaphylactic reaction. … Parents knew about the threatening behavior only half the time.”

headline: A Reality Check on a Plan for a Swift Post-Fossil Path for New York
text: Energy Policy, the journal that recently published a paper laying out an ambitious plan to end fossil fuel use in New York State within a few decades, has now published a short critique by four researchers in the Department of Engineering and Public Policy at Carnegie Mellon University.

headline: A Deal Spares a Brooklyn Library, for Now
text: The 109-year-old Beaux-Arts library near the Barclays Center has been given a reprieve.

headline: N.S.A. Chief Says Surveillance Has Stopped Dozens of Plots
text: WASHINGTON — Top national security officials on Tuesday promoted two newly declassified examples of what they portrayed as “potential terrorist events” disrupted by government surveillance. The cases were made public as Congress and the Obama administration stepped up a campaign to explain and defend programs unveiled by recent leaks from a former intelligence contractor.

headline: Advice to Visit Turkey Cautiously
text: The recent anti-government protests in Turkey over the future of an Istanbul park may have given some travelers pause about going to the country this summer.

headline: Sights and Sounds of Wimbledon Qualifying, Day 1
text: ROEHAMPTON, England — Qualifying for Wimbledon, the world’s most prestigious tennis tournament, began Monday — but not at Wimbledon.

headline: Immigration Law Changes Seen Cutting Billions From Deficit
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional budget analysts, providing a positive economic assessment of proposed immigration law changes, said Tuesday that legislation to overhaul the nation’s immigration system would cut close to $1 trillion from the federal deficit over the next two decades and lead to more than 10 million new legal residents in the country.

headline: Attack at Funeral in Pakistan Kills 28
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A suicide bomber struck a funeral on Tuesday in the city of Mardan in northern Pakistan, killing 28 mourners, including a provincial legislator, and injuring more than 60, a senior police officer said.

headline: At ZZ’s Clam Bar, Seafood Shares the Stage With Cocktails
text: Starter, an occasional column, takes a look at newly opened restaurants.

headline: N.S.A. Chief Testfies on Surveillance
text: At a House Intelligence Committee hearing on Tuesday, Gen. Keith B. Alexander described how American surveillance programs helped thwart dozens of terror plots.

headline: Muslim Woman Suffers Miscarriage After Attack in France
text: PARIS — A pregnant Muslim woman who was attacked for wearing a facial veil on Thursday in the Paris suburb of Argenteuil suffered a miscarriage and lost her baby, her lawyer said on Tuesday. Two men attacked the 21-year-old woman, trying to remove her head scarf and later cutting off her hair, and reportedly shouted anti-Islamic taunts at her.

headline: What Does Limbaugh Think the Pro-Choice Are Choosing?
text: The right-wing corner of the Internet is buzzing with delight following Rush Limbaugh’s latest pronouncement on abortion.

headline: Icahn Increases Stake in Dell and Calls for Stock Buyback
text: 4:24 p.m. | Updated

headline: Suicide Bombers Kill 37 at Shiite Mosque in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — Suicide bombers killed 37 people at a Shiite mosque in the Iraqi capital on Tuesday, in the third consecutive day of sectarian attacks this week.

headline: A Day at Royal Ascot
text: Opening day at Royal Ascot, a highlight on the horse racing calendar, was made even more interesting this year by the final race in Animal Kingdom’s storied career.

headline: An Interview with Ksenia Yudaeva
text: Ksenia Yudaeva, Mr. Putin’s liaison to the Group of 20 and a top economic adviser to the president, discusses Russia’s budget.

headline: Animal Kingdom Falls Flat at Ascot
text: ASCOT, England — Queen Elizabeth II had made it look so easy. Sharing her carriage with Prince Charles and his wife, Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, she led the royal procession uphill on the mile-long racecourse straightaway as if they were on an escalator. Britain’s monarch had no sign of tremor in her wave and Prince Charles smiled as if he were resting in the back of a Rolls-Royce.

headline: Hungarian Charged With War Crimes for Actions in World War II
text: BERLIN — A prosecutor in Budapest filed war-crimes charges against a Hungarian man, now 98, who is accused of regularly beating Jewish men, women and children under his supervision and helping to send almost 12,000 Hungarian Jews to Nazi death camps during World War II.

headline: Now Playing: Wall Street, Villains and Money
text: Seemingly every convention of late-19th-century theater is used in “The Henrietta”: Stock market fortunes are won and lost in minutes. Telegrams and letters arrive and are read aloud. Exposition-heavy asides are delivered directly to the audience.

headline: Wheelies: The ‘Car 54, Where Are You?’ Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Milk’s Crowning Moment
text: The artist Matthew Booth’s new video (below), “Milk Drop Coronet,” is a 3-D view of Harold Edgerton’s famous 1936 photograph of the same name; it captures the moment when a drop of milk splashes into the shape of a crown.

headline: Reds Pair Well With Middle Eastern Lentils
text: I love lentils, particularly Middle Eastern and South Asian, with their mellow flavors and gentle spicing. Many wines would go with this mujadara dish described in this week’s A Good Appetite column, but I would probably lean toward reds. A good cru Beaujolais or a mourvèdre, like a nicely aged Bandol, or one of the new-wave mourvèdres from California come to mind. But plenty of others suggest themselves: one of the lighter-weight blaufränkisches from Austria, a barbera from the Piedmont region of Italy or, if you like ethnic symbiosis, maybe a Lebanese red?

headline: 18 Orchestras Receive ASCAP Awards for New Music
text: ASCAP, the performing rights organization that collects royalties for nearly half a million composers, songwriters and publishers, will present its annual Adventurous Programming awards to 18 American orchestras and one new-music festival on Tuesday. The prizes, which ASCAP (the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers) established in 1947, are meant to encourage the programming of contemporary works. They will be awarded during the League of American Orchestras 68th National Conference, in St. Louis.

headline: Vodafone the Best Bet to Buy German Cable Giant
text: Vodafone remains the best bet to buy Kabel Deutschland. The mobile giant has stronger finances than Liberty Global, the U.S. challenger. It would wring bigger savings from the German cable outfit, and may also irk regulators less. But the outcome depends on questions of strategy and financial discipline.

headline: City Adds 600,000 People to Storm Evacuation Zones
text: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg ordered residents to leave coastal neighborhoods of New York City before Hurricane Sandy made landfall, officials found that they did not have much leeway. The evacuation map that they used was divided into just three zones, containing a total of more than two million people.

headline: G-8 Meeting Ends With Cordial Stalemate on Syria
text: ENNISKILLEN, Northern Ireland — The United States and leaders of other major industrialized nations on Tuesday papered over differences on Syria and the global economy in statements that summarized their two-day annual summit meeting at a secluded lakeside resort here.

headline: As Coney Island Stirs, One Man’s Vision Is Unbuilt
text: For over 30 years, Horace Bullard’s visions for Coney Island amounted to little more than a boardwalk of broken dreams.

headline: An Unfinished Vision in Coney Island
text: Horace Bullard had ambitious plans for Coney Island, but his vision was not realized before his death.

headline: More States Permit Digital Car-Insurance Cards
text: Earlier this year, I wrote about my wish for a digital insurance card that could be displayed on my smart phone, similar to the electronic boarding passes now available with airline apps.

headline: Jacob Lew’s Signature, Squiggle-Free
text: 7:50 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Words We Heard as Horrors Sank In
text: Kenneth Goldsmith is a conceptual poet, a literary trickster whose books are found art of a sort. He mines the mundane.

headline: Syrian Tensions Spill Into a City in Southern Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Violent sectarian spillover from the Syrian conflict reached across southern Lebanon on Tuesday, with armed clashes by rival groups of Sunni and Shiite militia members in the Mediterranean port of Sidon that left at least two people dead and forced the Lebanese Army to seal off the area.

headline: Recipe Lab: Making Pesto Pizza With Kids
text: Julia Moskin cooks simple pesto pizza from “The Batali Brothers Cookbook” with her children.

headline: Making Pizza With Mario Batali and Sons
text: Recipe Lab, a monthly feature, invites you to cook with the Dining section. We’ll publish a recipe from a new cookbook for you to try; the following week, the book’s author will join Julia Moskin and readers in a live video chat. This month we’re making a pesto pizza by Mario Batali’s sons; you can watch the video chat with Mario, Benno and Leo Batali here on Diner’s Journal on Wednesday, June 26, at 7 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: Living in New Milford, Conn.
text: Residents and weekenders enjoy Candlewood Lake, pastoral expanses and a lively town center.

headline: New Milford, Conn.: One Town, Many Neighborhoods
text: The largest of Connecticut municipalities, New Milford is several towns in one. The familiar tentacles of suburbia spread outward from the busy village center. Farther north, the subdivisions eventually give way to farmland, storied estates and dazzling vistas — New York weekender territory. The lower western edge of town, on the other hand, is oriented toward Candlewood Lake, an 11-mile man-made creation that spills across five towns.

headline: F.C.C. Nominee Favors Competition Over Regulation
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s nominee to head the Federal Communications Commission told a Senate committee on Tuesday that his top priorities, if he is confirmed, would be consumer protection, increasing competition and providing sufficient predictability so companies know what rulings to expect.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: A Doctor Shortage
Labor Seeks Influence in New York’s Mayoral Race
text: After more than a decade of sitting out the fiercest race in town, leaders of the United Federation of Teachers are plotting a comeback.

headline: In Overhaul, ‘Today’ Show Director Gets a New Title
text: NBC News is replacing the longtime director of “Today” in the latest sign of a top-to-bottom overhaul at the morning show, which is trying to climb out of a second-place ratings pit after a painful year there.

headline: A Health Maven’s Sweet Secret
text: “She doesn’t bring dessert,” a friend’s teenage son complained when he heard I was coming to dinner. “She brings fruit.”

headline: Education Chief Lets States Delay Use of Tests in Decisions About Teachers’ Jobs
text: Acknowledging that the nation’s educators face large challenges in preparing students for more rigorous academic standards and tests, Arne Duncan, the secretary of education, told state education officials on Tuesday that they could postpone making career decisions about teachers based on performance evaluations tied to new tests.

headline: A British Immersion, With Britten as the Focus
text: If you look past the sillier aspects of the Chelsea Music Festival — its house perfumes created just for the event, “culinary artist in residence” and such — it offers searching chamber music programming and passionate playing.

headline: Paille Goes from Role Player to Difference Maker for Bruins
text: Daniel Paille may play fourth-line minutes, but he is not your average checking-line forward, and the Chicago Blackhawks are finding that out in the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: Smoked Bread to Make at Home
text: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tweaked for home cooks.

headline: From Captivity to Liberty, Punctuated by Violence
text: Thanks largely to live music, but also to excellent dancers and a memorable use of space and lighting, Rebecca Lazier’s new 50-minute “Coming Together/Attica” has an exciting immediacy. Its structure gives it drama. So does its action, which comes extremely close to the audience.

headline: Beside an Enchanted Lake, a Lonely Prince Meets a Magical Flock
text: What is an American Ballet Theater season at the Metropolitan Opera House without swans? On Monday the company presented its first “Swan Lake” of the season, albeit a version that hasn’t exactly stood the test of time. The ballet, staged by the company’s artistic director, Kevin McKenzie, in 2000, drags along like a bird with an injured wing. This is a dance about enchantment: an evil sorcerer turns a princess into a swan, and her only escape is love.

headline: Chiasson and Newman to Remain Free During Appeal, Court Rules
text: Two former hedge fund managers may remain free on bail while they challenge their insider trading convictions, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday.

headline: The Scene | London Men’s Fashion Week: James Long
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Biden Touts White House Progress on Guns
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. resumed the White House’s campaign for gun control on Tuesday by reporting on executive action taken unilaterally by the Obama administration and pressing Congress to take up the legislation again.

headline: Rebels in North Mali Sign Peace Deal Allowing In Government Troops
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Nomadic rebels whose revolt in northern Mali last year split the West African nation signed a peace deal Tuesday with the government, resolving a stumbling block to the country’s reconstruction.

headline: Manhattan’s Biggest Apartment Complex Agrees to Drop Some Rent Increases
text: The notices of a sudden rent increase came like a phantom in the night, slipped under the doors of 1,100 tenants on May 14 at the largest apartment complex in Manhattan, Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village.

headline: Finding Gems on the Tuscan Coast
text: At dusk I jogged along a sandy road in a secluded nature reserve outside Bolgheri in western Tuscany. A family of bristly boars came charging out of the underbrush with their tails upright and momentarily froze with a wary glare before rambling away. I saw a couple of deer grazing behind dappled trees alongside an estuary dotted with herons. A fat hare sat partly hidden nearby in a tree trunk.

headline: In Milan, a Surge of Burger Spots
text: On a crisp Sunday afternoon a few weeks ago, a steady stream of patrons milled about a space with red brick walls, waiting to pick up orders of towering burgers before nabbing wooden stools at the restaurant’s perimeter. It was a scene that could have taken place in Brooklyn or Boise, especially given the huge American flag that hung near the doorway. But the restaurant, 202 Hamburger & Delicious, was on the Corso di Porta Ticinese, a shopping street in Milan.

headline: A Flagship Restaurant for Empire City Casino
text: Headliner

headline: Sign Up For New York Mayoral Election Updates
text:
This election season, The Times is introducing Trailside to Go, an
occasional e-mail that will keep you up to date as major developments occur on the mayoral campaign trail in New York City.

headline: Consumers Help Slow Growth in Health Spending
text: Growth in health care spending is expected to slow next year, in part because of a shift in consumer behavior, a report from PricewaterhouseCoopers’s Health Research Institute predicts.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Brazil and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Brazil, Syria, Afghanistan and India.

headline: A Royal-Style Room Has a Crib (but No Crown)
text: Britain’s Duchess of Cambridge – a k a Kate Middleton — is expected to deliver her first child in July, an event that has inspired the installation of a nursery fit for royalty – but available to untitled travelers with children — at Grosvenor House, a JW Marriott Hotel in London.

headline: Google’s Effort to Skirt Regulation May Invite More Scrutiny
text: Google’s motto is “don’t be evil.” But its recent acquisition of Waze, reportedly for $1 billion in cash, shows that just because you’re not evil, it doesn’t mean you can’t be aggressive in pushing the boundaries of the law.

headline: A Blackhawks Reserve Who Sits and Waits Gets a Chance to Play at Last
text: BOSTON — Marguerita Smith had almost reached her house in Avon, Conn., Monday evening when the cellphone rang in her car. Her husband was on the line with the startling news that their son, Ben, was going to play in Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: A Deadline Missed
text: Legions of home health aides continue to toil for less than minimum wage, the only American workers not covered by the Fair Labor Standards Act. More than a month has passed since May 14, when President Obama could have ended this exclusion and, with the stroke of a pen, forced a new regulation into effect. All legal deadlines and extensions in this sclerotic regulatory process have been exhausted.

headline: His Headlining Days Behind Him, Blake Still Enjoys the Tennis
text: EASTBOURNE — James Blake’s tournament may have ended with a 6-2, 6-4 first round defeat to Spanish clay-courter Albert Ramos at Eastbourne on Monday, but these days, Blake is simply happy to still be competing, saying he has finally found an inner peace after 14 years on tour.

headline: Six Men Sentenced for Attacking Sufi Shrine in Tunisia
text: CAIRO — A Tunisian court sentenced six men to five years in prison on Tuesday for attacking visitors to a famous Sufi Muslim shrine in Tunis, the capital, and for setting the shrine on fire.

headline: Live Blogging the Bris? This Might Hurt a Bit
text: Rick Moranis already had one of the odder résumés in show business. This week he made it more so with a new album of songs about, among other things, a brisket and a bris.

headline: Kajitsu
text: Inside the Japanese vegan restaurant in Murray Hill.

headline: A Formidable Undertaking for Any Orchestra
text: Making new music is hard work, both for the composer confronted with a blank page (or screen) and for the performer, who is usually faced with limited time to hone an unfamiliar piece before offering it to the public. The challenge is especially acute for an orchestra, for which expenses are high and time is in short supply.

headline: A Museum Named Cash
text: Nashville might be home to members of the Kings of Leon and Jack White, but the  country music scene dominates tourist attractions here, newly expanded with the Johnny Cash Museum.Keeping the memory and music of the Man in Black alive, the 6,500-square-foot downtown museum houses artifacts ranging from his boyhood marbles and high school yearbooks to his custom Gibson J200 guitar, costumes and a reassembled stone wall from his Hendersonville, Tenn., home.

headline: Greeting the Seasons, in Due Time
text: When I eat at Kajitsu, a restaurant that practices an animal-free cooking tradition called shojin ryori, I am never shocked to find that I don’t miss meat or fish. When the Japanese have been working on an idea for hundreds of years, they tend to figure out a few things. To express wonder that Kajitsu’s chef, Ryota Ueshima, can fashion a delicious multicourse meal out of nothing but plants and mushrooms is like being astonished when a French baker makes dessert from flour, butter, sugar and eggs.

headline: Even Pan Chimes In at Early Music Festival
text: BOSTON — What most struck a visitor to the biennial Boston Early Music Festival last week, after many years away, was the strength of the home team. It used to be that most star attractions came from abroad, and many still do, this year including Hespèrion XXI, led by that brightest of stars, Jordi Savall.

headline: Gunman Boasted of Killing Man He Taunted With Antigay Slurs, the Police Say
text: As he lay sprawled on a Greenwich Village street, held down by several police officers who believed that he had just fatally shot a man blocks away, Elliot Morales boasted of the killing, according to the police.

headline: Restaurant Report: Rustic Canyon in Santa Monica
text: At 9:30 on a Wednesday night, it was three deep at the bar at Rustic Canyon, a wine bar and restaurant in Santa Monica. The dining room was buzzing; outside, bundled diners braved the chilly late-winter air. In spite of his status as a cult figure among chefs and epicures, Jeremy Fox, who took over the kitchen in January, claims no credit for the crowds. “The place is really busy and was long before I got here,” he said.

headline: One-Two Punch Looks Dominant as the Mets Sweep
text: ATLANTA — It feels as if their names have been entwined for ages — by coaches and team officials, by columnists and television hosts, by fans and former players — but not until Tuesday did Matt Harvey and Zack Wheeler come together on the same pitching staff.

headline: Three’s a Trend | The Sailor Look Floods Resort
text: Gone are the days of referring to the pre-spring collections as “cruise.” Yet several resort collections this season seemed high-seas-ready. Interpretations of the United States Navy uniform were both indirect (a very casual denim ensemble at Valentino) and literal (a boxy tunic with jumper flaps at Marc Jacobs, a nautical sweater at Chloé).

headline: Obama and Putin on the Stage
text: Footage from President Obama’s meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday evening.

headline: Obama and Putin Signal a More Businesslike Path
text: MOSCOW — At times during their 12-minute joint appearance on Monday evening, Barack Obama and Vladimir V. Putin seemed locked in a frowning contest, their fingers laced tensely in their laps, eyes narrowed, lips pressed tightly together — especially when they noted their continuing disagreement about Syria.

headline: Money and Morals Sharing the Stage With Shakespeare
text: The connection between Shakespeare and nuclear waste might seem tenuous, but Michael J. Sandel, the political philosopher, did his utmost to unite the two at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park on Monday night, assisted by readings given by the likes of Alan Alda, Vanessa Redgrave, Christine Baranski and Matt Damon.

headline: Debut of ‘New Day’ Fails to Increase CNN’s Morning Audience
text: CNN introduced its new morning program, “New Day,” with a bit of fanfare Monday, and won mostly positive reviews for the revamping of the format and the new cast of anchors.

headline: Brazil Cement Giant Is Said to Cancel Planned I.P.O.
text: Brazil’s largest cement producer, Votorantim Cimentos, canceled its multibillion-dollar initial public offering on Tuesday amid worsening market conditions, a person closely involved with the operation said.

headline: Front Burner
text: To Indulge: Just Enough of a Good Thing

headline: Making the Case for a Rise in Inflation
text: I was in Brazil in the early 1990s, when annual inflation topped 2,000 percent and Brazilians spent their entire paychecks as soon as they got them, buying a month’s worth of food and other supplies before their money lost most of its value. When I moved there a few years later, inflation had been “tamed” to some 16 percent. But you couldn’t buy oranges at the supermarket in packages of less than 20 pounds.

headline: Dispute Ends as Chrysler Agrees to Fix Older Jeeps
text: DETROIT — A tense standoff between Chrysler and federal regulators over the safety of millions of Jeep sport utility vehicles was resolved in one last high-level phone call.

headline: A Famed Playwright as Seducer and Thief
text: Brecht the exploiter: That’s the topic of Sara Farrington’s “Requiem for Black Marie,” an Incubator Arts Project production that considers the playwright as manipulative oaf and the women who love him.

headline: I.B.M. Inflates Its Cloud
text: For all the money it has spent, you don’t hear about I.B.M. as a powerhouse of cloud computing-based services. Cloud computing is still a tiny fraction of the company’s $106 billion in annual revenue. Still, I.B.M. has spent more than $4 billion acquiring cloud computing-based services in the last few years, and recently bought a big public cloud.

headline: One Last Pass Through the 31st Century (for Now)
text: Can a show that’s hung around for 14 years — during which it’s been nominated for the animated-program Emmy seven times and won twice — be underappreciated? Did you know that “Futurama” is starting its last batch of episodes on Wednesday night? Case closed.

headline: Humanities Committee Sounds an Alarm
text: A new national corps of “master teachers” trained in the humanities and social sciences and increased support for research in “endangered” liberal arts subjects are among the recommendations of a major report to be delivered on Capitol Hill on Wednesday.

headline: Christie’s London Auction Brings Modest Art and Modest Sales
text: LONDON – A colorful canvas painted by Wassily Kandinsky in 1909 brought $21.1 million at Christie’s here on Tuesday night. In 2008 the same painting brought $16.8 million at a New York auction.

headline: A.M.A. Recognizes Obesity as a Disease
text: The American Medical Association has officially recognized obesity as a disease, a move that could induce physicians to pay more attention to the condition and spur more insurers to pay for treatments.

headline: Russian Space Center in Kazakhstan Counts Down Its Days of Glory
text: BAIKONUR, Kazakhstan — On a sultry desert evening, as bats fluttered about this town’s riverfront park, a man emerged from a reedy marsh carrying a bundle of grass tied with twine.

headline: A Kazakh Spaceport Slowly Declines
text: Baikonur, in remote southwestern Kazakhstan, was once the pride of the Soviet Union. Today, nomadic herders from the nearby steppe are moving into abandoned buildings.

headline: Google Asks Secret Court for Permission to Publish National Security Request Data
text: Google on Tuesday filed a motion with the secret Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, asking permission to publish data on national security requests that were made to it and authorized by the court.

text: WIMBLEDON, England — The Wimbledon Championships this year will be without one of its fixtures of the past 16: Venus Williams.

headline: Dish Network Backs Off Bid to Buy Sprint
text: Dish Network said on Tuesday that it would not submit a new takeover bid for Sprint Nextel ahead of a deadline imposed by the company and would instead focus on its bid for a stake in Clearwire, a smaller wireless operator. That appeared to leave Sprint free to complete the sale of a majority stake to SoftBank of Japan for $21.6 billion.

headline: Tech Moves to the Background as Design Becomes Foremost
text: In the last few decades, the computing industry has passed through several different eras. In the ’90s, the big tech companies were in a race for faster and more powerful computers. Then in the 2000s, the industry moved to mobile in a quest for slimmer phones with brighter screens.

text: Accessories highlights from the spring 2014 runways in London.

headline: British Commission Calls for New Laws to Prosecute Bankers for Fraud
text: LONDON – British lawmakers are calling for criminal prosecutions of senior bankers who cause the collapse of financial institutions, as Parliament is set to undertake a major overhaul of the country’s banking sector.

headline: It’s General Sherman’s Time to Shine, but Not Too Much
text: General Sherman, still marching through Georgia these many years later, has completely lost his luster.

headline: I.M.F. Courses Offered Online
text: The International Monetary Fund and edX, a nonprofit online venture started by Harvard and M.I.T., have announced a collaboration to offer the fund’s training courses in macroeconomics and finance on the edX platform. Until now, edX has worked only with universities. The first two online courses will be offered to small groups of government officials in the coming months, and then will be opened to the public in 2014. The I.M.F. offers policy-oriented courses to central bank, finance and other officials from its 188 member countries, but will use edX to expand its reach.

headline: In Partisan Vote, House Approves Ban on Abortions After 22 Weeks
text: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives on Tuesday approved the most restrictive ban on abortion considered by Congress in a decade, a largely symbolic vote that laid bare the deep ideological differences between Democrats and Republicans.

headline: Irv Gordon has Driven Nearly 3 Million Miles in his 1966 Volvo 1800S
text: Irv Gordon’s 1966 Volvo 1800S has already made the Guinness Book of World Records twice; once for eclipsing all other cars on the road when it hit 1.69 million miles in 1998, and again in 2002, when the the car’s odometer rolled past 2 million miles. Mr. Gordon, a retired science teacher from Patchogue, N.Y., reached 2.9 million miles in the car this month, and is now about 30,000 miles shy of 3 million miles, and a third nod from Guinness.

headline: Ex-Senator Feingold Chosen as Special Envoy to African Region
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry on Tuesday selected a former Senate colleague, Russ Feingold, to serve as a special envoy to the Great Lakes region of Africa, promising to raise the profile of a region torn by conflict and yet largely overshadowed in American foreign policy by other global crises.

headline: Labels Don’t Fit Duncan, but Championship Rings Do
text: MIAMI — It is not an issue that should keep him, or anyone, up much later than an N.B.A. finals game ends, but someday Tim Duncan is going to be remembered as the greatest power forward in league history — or one of its most distinguished centers.

headline: De Blasio Offers Ideas in Policy Book for Election
text: Bill de Blasio wants to ensure that all students are reading at grade level by the third grade, and to develop at least 100 community schools modeled after the Harlem Children’s Zone.

headline: Irish Lawmakers Expected to Approve Limited Abortion
text: DUBLIN — The Irish Parliament is expected to legalize limited abortion before its summer break after the publication of final government proposals that would allow terminations in cases when there is a real and substantial risk to the life of the mother, including the threat of suicide.

headline: The Home-Cooked Challenge: Taking Time Now to Save Time Later

headline: Reception for Obama Is More Sober Than in 2008
text: BERLIN — The last time President Obama paid a visit here, as a candidate in 2008, he was cheered on by 200,000 Germans eager to see the back of George W. Bush and, as one member of that crowd recalled Tuesday, “full of wholly unrealistic expectations of what kind of miracles Obama could work.”

headline: New Effort to Quantify ‘Social Cost’ of Pollution

text: BOSTON — If the Boston Bruins win the Stanley Cup, Gregory Campbell’s gallant shift on a broken leg may be a defining moment.

headline: A Place to Be Seen (and Heard) in Upper Manhattan
text: With the lights of the George Washington Bridge painting the Hudson River and a half-moon hanging over the Palisades, La Marina felt like the place to be last Saturday night. At the year-old restaurant in Fort Washington Park, at the end of Dyckman Street in Upper Manhattan, two D.J.’s, working opposite ends of the property, cranked up the volume. Patrons ordered bottles of liquor, starting at $130 for rum and rising to $12,000 for a methuselah of Champagne, equal to five bottles, to secure a table on the terrace. Dancers let loose on the “beach,” a sand-covered strip flanked with four-poster beds draped in flowing white fabric.

headline: Less ‘Rambo’ Seen in New U.S. Military Culture
text: WASHINGTON — “The days of Rambo are over,” the two-star general in charge of personnel policy for Special Operations Command said on Tuesday in explaining the changes in military culture that led to opening front-line combat positions to women.

headline: Remember, Mattingly Played for the Boss
text: Don Mattingly learned about the weight of expectations while playing for George Steinbrenner during the bad years. The Yankees won a lot of games in the 1980s, but not a single division title with Mattingly. Yet because of the way he played, he was beloved, more than many others in Monument Park.

headline: Islamists Press Blasphemy Cases in a New Egypt
text: DEIR EL GABRAWI, Egypt — Egypt’s prosecutors have been flooded with blasphemy complaints since 2011 as Islamists exercising their new societal clout have pushed for prosecutions and courts have handed down steep fines and prison terms for insulting religion.

headline: Surviving the Next Gulf Oil Spill
text: FAIRHOPE, Ala. — DOWN here on the Gulf of Mexico, the air is heavy with expectation as we await the arrival of billions of dollars in fines from companies involved in the BP oil-well blowout, which spewed millions of gallons of oil into the gulf over three months in 2010.

headline: Fred T. Shen
text: Mr. Shen, 71, is a founder and the chairman of Shen Milsom & Wilke, a consulting and design firm. The company, which has 13 offices worldwide, specializes in the design of multimedia systems, information technology, medical equipment, building security and acoustics. Its current projects include the World Trade Center transportation hub.

headline: Lawmakers in Albany Should Stay Put
text: After another run of indictments and arrests of public officials, New York’s lawmakers are planning to leave Albany this week without doing anything about the scandals around them. The list of unattended priorities left for next year is long and shameful. And at the top is campaign finance reform — specifically a system of public financing that would encourage more candidates to run for office and give voters wider choices. It is hard to throw rascals out if there is nobody else on the ballot.

headline: Our Genes, Their Secrets
text: WASHINGTON — THE Supreme Court’s unanimous ruling last Thursday, barring patents on human genes, was a wise and balanced decision that clears away a major barrier to innovation in the areas of biotechnology, drug development and medical diagnostics. But the decision is just a first step toward finding the right balance between protecting legitimate intellectual property and securing an open future for personalized medicine.

headline: How to End the Stalemate With Iran
text: THE stunning election of a pragmatic former Iranian nuclear negotiator, Hassan Rowhani, has offered the Obama administration a once-in-a-lifetime chance to end the atomic stalemate with Iran.

headline: Clues in the Search for a Sunken Ship, Lost in the 1600s
text: OFF POVERTY ISLAND, Mich. — Ever since the Griffin, a 40-foot-long ship built by the French explorer René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle, in his quest to find the mouth of the Mississippi River, disappeared somewhere on the Great Lakes 333 years ago, people have been searching for its resting place.

headline: The Taliban Agree to Talk
text: Update: The Afghan government on Wednesday rejected starting talks with the Taliban, saying it would not meet with the insurgents unless they lowered the profile of the Taliban’s political office in Doha, Qatar, which opened on Tuesday.  President Hamid Karzai also suspended talks on a bilateral security agreement with the United States that would allow American troops to stay after 2014, pointing to American influence in the opening of the Taliban office.

headline: Details on Spying, Not More Assurances
text: Battered by weeks of criticism about surveillance abuses, President Obama has embarked on a reassurance offensive. The spy programs have been used narrowly, he said on PBS’s “Charlie Rose” program on Monday, and have been effective in stopping several terror plots.

headline: Proper Scrutiny for Drug Settlements
text: The Federal Trade Commission has been battling for years to end a devious tactic used by some drug companies to pay competitors to delay putting cheaper generic versions of their brand-name drugs on the market. The tactic, known as pay-for-delay or reverse payments, results in higher costs for consumers.

headline: Postcard From Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — Having witnessed the Egyptian uprising in Tahrir Square in Cairo in 2011, I was eager to compare it with the protests by Turkish youths here in Taksim Square in 2013. They are very different. The Egyptians wanted to oust President Hosni Mubarak. Theirs was an act of “revolution.” The Turks are engaged in an act of “revulsion.” They aren’t (yet) trying to throw out their democratically elected Islamist prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. What they’re doing is calling him out. Their message is simple: “Get out of our faces, stop choking our democracy and stop acting like such a pompous, overbearing, modern-day Sultan.”

headline: Three Expected to Plead Guilty in Scheme Involving City’s Payroll Project
text: Three defendants accused of helping to conceal kickbacks generated in a massive fraud scheme that involved CityTime, a troubled automated payroll project in New York City, are expected to plead guilty in Manhattan on Wednesday, federal prosecutors said in a new court filing.

headline: NASA’s New Class of Astronauts Gives Parity to Men and Women
text: One flies a fighter jet for the Marines. Another is an assistant professor of anesthesiology at Harvard Medical School. A third is a helicopter pilot for the Army. And the fourth leads the station in American Samoa of the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration.

headline: After Sexual Abuse Conviction, New Scrutiny on Youth Athletics
text: McKINNEY, Tex. — Kelley Currin, a divorced mother of four, started a romantic relationship in January with a middle-aged teacher in a supervisory position at the middle school that employed them. The district rules are clear on relationships between consenting adults when one has decision-making power over the other: they are not allowed. So in the fall, Currin, who teaches seventh-grade science, will transfer to a nearby school.

headline: Audit Finds Sexual Abuse Was Topic Decades Ago
text: A regional province of the Capuchin religious order that had fought allegations of sexual abuse for decades decided last year to open its files dating to the 19th century to three independent auditors, in what the order claimed to be a first in the long-running Roman Catholic Church abuse scandal in the United States.

headline: Larger Evacuation Areas in New York City
text: New York City has officially released a map of expanded hurricane evacuation zones, which had been under consideration since before Hurricane Sandy hit in October.

headline: Obama Has Plans to Cut U.S. Nuclear Arsenal, if Russia Reciprocates
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to use a speech in Berlin on Wednesday to outline plans for further reductions in the American nuclear arsenal if Russia agrees to pare back its weapons at the same time, administration officials said Tuesday.

headline: Officials Covered Up Italian Olympian’s Doping, Investigators Say
text: Investigators in Italy say officials for track and field’s world governing body had evidence that an Olympic gold medalist used performance-enhancing drugs but made no effort to prevent him from competing in last summer’s Olympic Games in London.

text: AKIAK, Alaska — The humble pollock, great cash fish of the north, conquered the world through the flaky bland hegemony of a fish stick. At more than $1 billion a year, there is no bigger fishery for human consumption on the planet.

headline: Uncertainty at Fed Over Its Stimulus Plans and Its Leadership
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, faces the increasingly difficult challenge of shaping investor expectations about the future course of Fed policy amid growing signs that the Bernanke era at the central bank is drawing to a close.

text: Brazilians have seen the cost of many components of urban life rise at rates that surpass inflation generally.

text: The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the immigration bill currently being debated in the Senate would increase revenues more than it increases spending, cutting budget deficits through 2033 by nearly $1 trillion.

text: One year ago, the Walt Disney Company unveiled a strict new set of nutritional standards and said it would ban ads for noncompliant foods from its child-focused cable channels by 2015. Advocacy groups fighting childhood obesity cheered.

headline: Mets’ Harvey, in Bids for a No-Hitter, Gets No Support
text: For Matt Harvey, it is becoming a question of when he will throw his first no-hitter rather than if he will throw one. In a season in which he has already taken a no-hitter into the seventh inning three times, Harvey seems to be a threat to no-hit any team at any time.

headline: Spires at St. Patrick’s Cathedral, Cleaned Up, Come Back in View
text: The stone faces of the spires above Fifth Avenue have been scrubbed. The copper crosses that crown them have been cleaned and their finish restored. The little windows — “T windows,” to those in the know — were caulked last Saturday.

headline: Shakespeare at Large in Runyonland
text: By the time the gun-toting nuns make an appearance, you may find that you’re out of belly laughs. Rally those abs, if possible, because there is more fun to come in the brisk (90 minutes!) and buoyant production of “The Comedy of Errors” at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, with the sterling team of Hamish Linklater and Jesse Tyler Ferguson doubling down as Shakespeare’s two sets of long-lost twins.

headline: Extending a Hand, Obama Finds a Cold Shoulder Abroad
text: WASHINGTON — Over porterhouse steak and cherry pie at a desert estate in California earlier this month, President Obama delivered a stern lecture to President Xi Jinping about China’s disputes with its neighbors. If it is going to be a rising power, he scolded, it needs to behave like one.

headline: In Bulger’s Underworld, a ‘Judas Was the Worst’
text: BOSTON — “Family and friends come first,” John Martorano, an aging gangster known as the Executioner, declared from the witness stand here on Tuesday. “My father always taught me that. The priests and the nuns I grew up with taught me that. They taught me that Judas — Judas was the worst person in the world.”

headline: Evidence in Long Island Houses of 7-Eleven ‘Plantation’
text: They were known as the “7-Eleven Houses,” the two shabby homes in Islip Terrace on Long Island, and not simply because of their proximity to the 7-Eleven on Carleton Avenue — one across the street and one tucked behind it. It was because, morning and night, the men, more than half a dozen just from one house, some neighbors said, would file from the peeling doorways to work at the convenience store in shifts so long that it sometimes seemed as if they lived not in the tattered houses, but at the shop.

headline: A Political Stalemate Ends in Washington, With Food Truck Rules
text: WASHINGTON — A protracted legislative battle that has consumed this city — one that has pitted established businesses against start-ups, energized politicians on both sides of the aisle and prompted a grass-roots online campaign — has finally come to an end.

headline: Derailment Near Penn Station Snarls Train Travel
text: In a train tunnel just east of Pennsylvania Station, the two middle cars in a 10-car Long Island Rail Road train slid off the rails.

text: BOSTON — The Boston School Committee is set to vote Wednesday night on a new health policy that would make condoms available in the district’s high schools, bringing this city in line with New York and Los Angeles.

headline: A-List Celebration Traces Leader’s Trajectory, and Israel’s
text: JERUSALEM — Barbra Streisand did not, as many here had been hoping or openly joking about, don a white fur coat and purr, “Happy birthday, Mr. President.” Instead, Ms. Streisand offered a pleading rendition of “Avinu Malkeinu,” a hymn from the Yom Kippur liturgy requested by the president in question, Shimon Peres, who said he cannot hear her sing it without crying.

headline: Weak Bond Trading at Jefferies Prompts Wider Concern
text: The recent turbulence in the markets has already taken its toll on one Wall Street firm.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Sullivan Town Court Judge Resigns Over Tirade at Teenager
text: On several occasions during the summer of 2011, someone stole money from a farm stand that James P. Roman operated on his property in Madison County, N.Y. Convinced he had found the culprit that August, Mr. Roman, a justice of the nearby Sullivan Town Court, decided to take action, according to a complaint filed last year by the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct.

headline: The F.B.I. Deemed Agents Faultless in 150 Shootings
text: WASHINGTON — After contradictory stories emerged about an F.B.I. agent’s killing last month of a Chechen man in Orlando, Fla., who was being questioned over ties to the Boston Marathon bombing suspects, the bureau reassured the public that it would clear up the murky episode.

headline: Queens Worker Pulled From Mud After Fall Into Trench
text: A construction worker fell 25 feet into a trench at a construction site in Queens on Tuesday, and was trapped waist-deep in mud for over three hours before rescuers could pull him out, fire officials said.

headline: Man Arrested in Stabbing of Cabdriver in Brooklyn
text: A 28-year-old man has been arrested on charges of fatally stabbing a livery-cab driver with an umbrella after what investigators said was an argument over the fare, the authorities said on Tuesday.

headline: Small Businesses, With Group, Seek Greater Say in New York City’s Policies
text: Concerned about fines, taxes and regulation in New York, a new coalition of small-business owners is organizing to try to influence legislation and city policy.

headline: Younger Espada, Like His Father, Is Sentenced for Theft From Bronx Center
text: Pedro Gautier Espada, the former lawmaker who was charged with his father, Pedro Espada Jr., in a scheme to steal from a nonprofit health network, was sentenced on Tuesday to six months in prison and six months of home confinement.

headline: Montreal Mayor Resigns After Bribery Arrest
text: A day after his arrest on bribery charges, the mayor of Montreal, Michael Applebaum, resigned Tuesday. In a brief statement to reporters, he denied that he was guilty of any of the 14 charges he now faces. But he said it would not be possible to act as mayor while defending himself. For much of his political career, Mr. Applebaum was seen as a reformer and known as “Mr. Clean.” He became mayor last November when Gérald Tremblay quit, after testimony at a public inquiry showed that some of his close associates were corrupt. The City Council will pick the new mayor. Several members said that a crucial job requirement would be the lack of any connection, even distant, to police investigations.

headline: Soccer Stars Are at Center of Paris Prostitution Case
text: PARIS — President François Hollande may have been at the Group of 8 summit meeting in Northern Ireland on Tuesday discussing the future of the world economy, but much of France was transfixed by the far more salacious proceedings at home concerning two star athletes and an underage prostitute.

headline: 2 Qaddafi Children May Have Violated U.N. Travel Ban
text: Two children of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the longtime Libyan leader felled in the 2011 revolution, appear to have violated a travel ban imposed by the United Nations by moving to Oman from Algeria earlier this year, the chairman of a Security Council sanctions committee said on Tuesday.

headline: Sherwood Ross, President of Ross Bicycles, Dies at 92
text: Sherwood B. Ross, who turned his father’s Brooklyn galvanizing company into Ross Bicycles, for many years America’s third-largest bicycle manufacturer, died on June 4 in Pembroke Pines, Fla. He was 92.

headline: Mattingly Reflects on Time With Yankees
text: Don Mattingly, who returned to Yankee Stadium as the manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, talked about returning to New York and his time with the Yankees.

headline: High Level of Radioactive Strontium Found in Groundwater Near Fukushima Plant
text: Tokyo Electric Power, the operator of the stricken nuclear power plant at Fukushima, said Wednesday that it had detected high levels of radioactive strontium in groundwater at the plant, raising concerns that its storage tanks are leaking contaminated water, possibly into the ocean. The operator said it had found strontium-90 at 30 times Japan’s safety limit in groundwater near its No. 2 reactor, which suffered a fuel meltdown in 2011. The company has struggled to store growing amounts of contaminated runoff at the plant, but had previously denied that the site’s groundwater was highly toxic. If ingested, strontium-90 can linger in bones, emitting radiation inside the body that can lead, in time, to cancer.

headline: 4 Coalition Soldiers Killed in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Four coalition soldiers were killed in an attack Tuesday night, the American military said in a statement.

headline: U.N. Reports Increased Number of Displaced People
text: WASHINGTON — The United Nations refugee agency said Tuesday that an estimated 7.6 million people around the globe were displaced because of conflict or persecution in 2012, including 1.1 million refugees and 6.5 million people who were displaced within their own countries.

headline: Riding Latest Goal by Altidore, U.S. Holds Off Honduras
text: SANDY, Utah — It has been a long season for the European-based players on the United States national team, a marathon that included lengthy league schedules, a slew of international friendlies and the pressures of World Cup qualifying matches. Clint Dempsey, the captain of the American team, did not hesitate when asked earlier this week for his upcoming vacation plans: Relax. See his family. Go fishing with his father.

headline: Testy Debate in Mass. Senate Race Over Term Limits

headline: Heart-Stopping Survival as Heat Force Game 7
text: MIAMI — The rope was being laid along the baselines, a braided border signaling finality, a familiar indicator of the revelry to come. Security guards crouched along it. Somewhere, just out of sight, the Larry O’Brien trophy awaited its reunion with Tim Duncan and Tony Parker, Manu Ginobili and Gregg Popovich.

headline: Game 6: Heat 103, Spurs 100 (OT)
text: Back on their court after falling behind, 3-2, in the series, LeBron James and the Heat forced Game 7 against the Spurs with an overtime victory.

headline: What’s on Wednesday

(Fuse) THE HUSTLE Kutta (Y’lan Noel, above right) and D (London Brown, left), a rap duo known as Brooklyn’s Finest, try to keep their friendship intact while ascending to stardom with a record deal in this new scripted series, the network’s first. Esteban Serrano hosts “The Hustle After Party,” at 11:30, featuring interviews and performances with hip-hop stars, discussions with industry experts and appearances by the show’s cast.

headline: Sending a Signal, Philippines to Destroy Ivory Stock

Matthew Rosenberg reports from Washington and Alissa Rubin from Kabul.

headline: On Assam’s River Islands, Family Planning Clashes Against Religious Tradition
text: MAZERCHAR CHALAKURA, Assam — On the banks of the Brahmaputra River, off the coast of Dhubri town in the northeastern state of Assam, lie a few hundred villages that seem stuck in time, difficult to reach from the mainland and undeveloped for decades.

headline: U.S. Scrambles to Save Taliban Talks After Afghan Backlash
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a bid to regain control of a peace process with the Taliban that had suddenly spun out of control, President Hamid Karzai on Wednesday slammed the brakes on two strategic lines of American negotiation, again exercising his power in a strained alliance and getting results.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 19, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the City Room blog post “Commuters Nearly Double Manhattan’s Daytime Population, Census Says.”

headline: How Are These Times Different?
text: Ah, Paris! You walk for miles and miles — it’s still, after all these years, a spectacularly beautiful city. Then you have as traditional a meal as possible at an old-fashioned bistro, washed down with lots of wine.

headline: Iran Elects a New Leader
text: In the article “Iran President-Elect Wants to Ease Strains With U.S., but Sees No Direct Talks,” Thomas Erdbrink writes about Iran’s newly elected president.

headline: West Africa, as Seen From Its Barbershops
text: It takes a certain amount of trust to allow a man to put a straight razor to your neck or run scissors around your head.

headline: Dissent Festers in States That Obama Seems to Have Forgotten
text: WASHINGTON — You might call North Dakota the antithesis of President Obama’s political base.

headline: The Price of Loyalty in Syria
text: The Damascus neighborhood known as Mezze 86 is a dense, dilapidated warren of narrow hillside streets adorned with posters bearing the face of Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad. The presidential palace is nearby, and the area is crawling with well-armed guards and soldiers. It is next to impossible to enter unless you are accompanied by government officials or well-known locals, almost all of them members of Assad’s Alawite sect. I drove there on a quiet Friday morning in May, and we were stopped several times at checkpoints by young soldiers who examined our documents carefully before waving us on. When we arrived at our destination, in a small parking lot hemmed in by cinder-block towers, I emerged from the car to the suspicious glares of several middle-aged men in fatigues. “They are not expecting foreigners here,” one of the men who accompanied me said. “The rebels are trying constantly to hit this place, because they know who lives here.” He pointed to a damaged roof not far away. “A mortar struck very close the other day. A lady was killed just above us, and another just below.”

headline: Terra Firma Real Estate Unit to Raise $1.5 Billion in I.P.O.
text: LONDON – Terra Firma, the private equity firm run by Guy Hands, plans to raise around 1.1 billion euros ($1.5 billion) through the initial public offering of the German real estate company Deutsche Annington.

headline: BC Partners to Buy Academic Publisher for $4.4 Billion
text: LONDON – The European private equity firm BC Partners agreed on Wednesday to buy the academic publishing company Springer Science & Business Media for 3.3. billion euros ($4.4 billion).

headline: Health Spending: Watching for a Rebound
text: Every new report about the American health care economy seems to confirm the same pattern: spending is rising at the slowest pace in decades.

headline: Sirius XM Joins the In-Car Streaming Music Battle
text: In a sign of how the sands beneath the broadcast and music businesses continue to shift, satellite radio is joining the streaming music market in the car. Sirius XM will now offer in-dash access to its Internet Radio App in Ford vehicles with the Sync AppLink.

headline: The Early Word: Frenemies
text: Today’s Times

headline: Reception for Obama Is More Sober Than in 2008
text: BERLIN — The last time President Obama paid a visit here, as a candidate in 2008, he was cheered on by 200,000 Germans eager to see the back of George W. Bush and, as one member of that crowd recalled Tuesday, “full of wholly unrealistic expectations of what kind of miracles Obama could work.”

headline: Alcatel-Lucent Unveils Plan to Cut Costs
text: BERLIN — Shares of Alcatel-Lucent, the troubled French-American maker of telecommunications equipment, rose more than 5 percent in Paris on Wednesday after its chief executive presented a package of cost cuts, planned job reductions and asset sales designed to raise at least 2 billion euros, or $2.7 billion, by the end of 2015.

headline: Q&A: Reliving Your Twitter History
text: Q.

headline: Gardening Advice for Aging Bodies, Part 1
text: Readers sent dozens of questions about aging and gardening to Patty Cassidy, the author of “The Illustrated Practical Guide to Gardening for Seniors: How to Maintain Your Outside Space with Ease Into Retirement and Beyond” (2011, Anness). Ms. Cassidy is a registered horticultural therapist, a master gardener certified through Oregon State University, and a former counselor with a master’s degree from Lewis and Clark College in Portland, Ore. She currently oversees therapeutic gardening programs for seniors at Providence ElderPlace, a nonprofit health care agency in Portland.

headline: Meet the Sales Consultant
text: Editor’s note: Paul Downs is writing this week about his decision to hire a sales consultant. The series started with this post.

headline: An Investment Strategy in the Human Interest
text: You are a health official in Uganda, and you’re watching a crisis unfold. Your people have long suffered from epidemics of sleeping sickness, one of Africa’s biggest killers. There is no vaccine and the only treatment is protracted and painful. Sleeping sickness, transmitted by the tsetse fly, is carried by cattle and also kills cattle, destroying the livelihoods of families who keep them.

headline: Slaughterhouse-Live
text: CASABLANCA, Morocco — On a recent evening, at sunset, in a suburb of Casablanca, seagulls circled above a vast, dilapidated construction. At first glance, Casablanca’s old slaughterhouse — a surprisingly attractive and grand complex of 1920s neo-Mauresque buildings — appears abandoned. It’s not.

headline: Daily Report: Google Acquisition of Waze May Draw More U.S. Attention
text: Google’s motto is “don’t be evil.” But its recent acquisition of Waze, reportedly for $1 billion in cash, shows that just because you’re not evil, it doesn’t mean you can’t be aggressive in pushing the boundaries of the law, Steven M. Davidoff writes in a Deal Professor column in The New York Times.

headline: Bioblitzing in Mozambique
text: The sacred Mount Gorongosa, where mighty, impressive creepy-crawlies are everywhere.

headline: Japanese Nuclear Regulator Announces an Overhaul of Safety Guidelines
text: TOKYO — Japan’s nuclear regulator announced an overhaul of the country’s nuclear safety guidelines Wednesday, the first since a giant tsunami swept over a nuclear power plant in northeastern Japan two years ago and set off the world’s worst nuclear accident since Chernobyl, even as signs of new trouble at the stricken plant underscored the hazardousness of the site’s cleanup.

headline: Dish Backs Away From Sprint
text: Dish Network said on Tuesday that it would not submit a new takeover bid for Sprint Nextel ahead of the 11:59 p.m. deadline and would instead focus on its bid for a stake in Clearwire. That apparently leaves Sprint free to complete the sale of a majority stake to SoftBank of Japan for $21.6 billion, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes.

headline: Skates, Squids and Dollies That Make Striking Video
text: The products from Cinetics might not be the first accessories a budding videographer should buy, but if you want to create some advanced dolly effects on a budget, they are worth a look.

headline: Europe Fines Drug Companies for Delaying Generics
text: BRUSSELS — Europe’s top antitrust enforcer continued a crackdown on drug company efforts to keep low-cost generic versions of their medicines off the market, a campaign that is taking place on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Rising Spaniard Keeps Busy at Lower-Level Events
text: Even the tennis cognoscenti, or at least those outside Spain, would have known little about Pablo Carreno Busta before this year. But he has improved his ranking more than 500 places since January and is now 143rd. His recent performances caught the eye of Roger Federer, who dispatched Carreno Busta in straight sets last month at the French Open, Carreno Busta’s Grand Slam debut.

headline: Goodbye Across the Subway Tracks
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Monitor Finds Mortgage Lenders Still Falling Short of Settlement’s Terms
text: The nation’s five biggest mortgage lenders have largely satisfied their financial obligations under last year’s $25 billion settlement over mortgage abuses, helping hundreds of thousands of families keep their homes. But four of the five have yet to meet their commitment to end the maze of frustrations that borrowers must navigate to modify their loans, according to a report on Wednesday by the settlement’s independent monitor.

headline: Astrodome, Vineyard Lighthouse on List of Most Endangered Places
text: Houston’s Astrodome and the Gay Head lighthouse on Martha’s Vineyard are 2 of 11 endangered places to be cited Wednesday by the National Trust for Historic Preservation on its annual list of sites at risk of damage or destruction.

headline: New Group’s New Season Includes Beth Henley, Thomas Bradshaw Plays
text: The New Group on Wednesday announced two new productions as part of its 2013-14 Off Broadway season at the Acorn Theater. Beginning in October the company will present “The Jacksonian,” a dark comedy by the Pulitzer Prize winner Beth Henley (“Crimes of the Heart”), set in 1964 in her hometown, Jackson, Miss. Directed by Robert Falls, the production will feature Ed Harris, Glenne Headly, Amy Madigan and Bill Pullman, who will reprise their roles from the play’s premiere last year at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles. Additional casting is to be announced.

headline: Brazil’s Leftist Ruling Party, Born of Protests, Is Perplexed by Revolt
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The protests were heating up on the streets of Brazil’s largest city last week, but the mayor was not in his office. He was not even in the city. He had left for Paris to try to land the 2020 World’s Fair — exactly the kind of expensive, international mega-event that demonstrators nationwide have scorned.

headline: For Many Filipinos, Jobs and the Good Life Are Still Scarce
text: MANILA — At his vegetable stand on a busy street in the Philippine capital, Lamberto Tagarro is surrounded by gleaming, modern skyscrapers, between which a river of luxury vehicles flows.

headline: Pandemonium After Car Jumps Curb Outside Deli
text: Just before the morning rush on Wednesday, workers went about their usual routines outside the popular East Village Farm and Grocery in Manhattan. They set up the daily outdoor flower display, stocked the refrigerator, filled coffee pots and watched their neighbors make their way in the early morning sun.

headline: Where Did You Go for Your Bra, Mrs. Robinson?
text: The guy who is now the official boyfriend told me he’d like to take me shopping for lingerie last weekend. I declined, which was a probably a mistake, because the next thing you know, driving back home to Tennessee, he is sending me a picture of the fishing rod he has just bought for me and speaking enthusiastically about trout fishing. I have never in my life fished and I do not relish either slamming a fish’s head against a rock or releasing it after tearing up its mouth, which I figure is also no great pleasure for the fish.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Floral Prints Team Up With Solid Stripes
text: Opposites attract at Jonathan Saunders, Emanuel Ungaro and Gucci resort. Lively prints seemed more dynamic when paired with contrasting, color-blocked separates in similar color tones.

headline: Beyond Sweatshops
text: KARACHI — Hamid Omar is ready for Syntech Fibres to keep growing. Almost 30 years ago, along with his brother, he founded this textile company with a single polyester extrusion machine, one of the first in Pakistan. Now, the firm exports fabric and filter cartridges all over the world.

headline: Wednesday Reading: The Benefits of a Four-Minute Workout
text: The benefits of a four-minute workout, gardening suggestions for aging bodies, advice on visiting Turkey these days and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: And the Weatherman Says There’s More to Come
text: LONDON — If you’re planning a summer break in Europe anytime in the next 10 years, bring an umbrella.

headline: Ryanair Will Fight for Its Stake in Aer Lingus
text: LE BOURGET, France — Ryanair’s chief is not going to gently let go of his company’s stake in the Irish flag carrier Aer Lingus.

headline: Another Wide-Ranging White Light Festival From Lincoln Center
text: Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival seemed more of a catch-all marketing construct than an actual festival when it was introduced in 2010. And it still has its amorphous qualities, but by celebrating them, instead of trying to don a thematic straitjacket, this multidisciplinary exploration of spirituality, in its many guises, has become an important part of the fall season.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Bon Appétit: The many pitfalls when lighting a grill, and how to avoid them without resorting to lighter fluid. — Melissa Clark

headline: 3-D Printers to Make Things You Need or Like
text: You may have seen some odd-shaped plastic trinkets on someone’s desk or heard about the first shots fired a few weeks ago from a 3-D printed gun. With every new 3-D printed object, the world seems to be getting closer to a future where we can “print out” objects like furniture, clothing, human tissue and even buildings. NASA even recently invested in technology to print food. The possibilites are staggering.

headline: President Obama’s Remarks in Germany
text: The president delivered remarks at Brandenburg Gate in Berlin on Wednesday.

headline: Obama Says Surveillance Helped in Case in Germany
text: BERLIN — Pressed personally by Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany about the United States’ surveillance of foreigners’ phone and e-mail traffic, President Obama said Wednesday that terrorist threats in her country were among those foiled by such intelligence operations worldwide — a contention that Ms. Merkel seemed to confirm.

headline: Judge’s Remarks on Premarital Sex Raise Questions in India
text: On Monday, the Madras High Court weighed in on a spousal support case and inadvertently provoked a debate over what exactly defines a relationship between a man and a woman.

headline: Boehner’s Latest Blow to Immigration
text: House Speaker John Boehner threw an incendiary device into the immigration-reform debate yesterday. But it could just have been a smoke bomb.

headline: Self-Finance or Raise Money? A Quandary for Start-Ups
text: Roman Stanek and Robert J. Moore had the same dream. The two entrepreneurs saw businesses collecting lots of data about their customers’ Web transactions and decided there could be a huge market in helping those businesses analyze the data to determine who their customers were and how best to reach them.

headline: The Privilege of the Unpaid Intern
text: Like 30 percent of undergraduates in the United States, my daughter, Emma, has an unpaid internship this summer. She is one of the lucky ones. She is following her passion: her internship at a food Web site is in her field of study; the work she’s doing there is providing her, at age 20, with valuable skills, experience and connections.

headline: A Quantum Computing Problem Solved
text: Researchers at the University of Sydney and Dartmouth College said they have found a new way to design quantum memory, a key element in making quantum computing a reality. The method, they say, reduces the number of errors typically expected in quantum computing without sacrificing high-speed performance.

headline: Multilingual Allergy Messages
text: SelectWisely.com, the Web site that sells cards bearing a food-allergy message translated into several languages, has added categories for travelers with diabetes, gluten and other dietary restrictions. To its list of 58 languages, the company added several from South Asia, like Urdu, Kannada and Punjabi. There are three ways to receive the cards: laminated, by mail; in PDF format, by e-mail, for printing at home; or in JPG format, by e-mail, for smartphones.

headline: Heat’s Allen Knows All About Hitting Big 3-Pointers
text: MIAMI — He ended the bromance of one so-called Big Three and might have saved the future for another. There was symmetry to Ray Allen’s fateful and figurative moment in the South Florida sun, coming on a day when his former Celtics teammates and their popular coach produced the biggest off-finals N.B.A. news.

headline: Tesla Issues Recall of Model S for Faulty Rear Seat Latch
text: Tesla will recall 1,228 of its 2013 Model S electric cars because a folding rear seat may not stay upright in a crash, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in a report posted on the safety agency’s Web site. The affected vehicles were assembled between May 10 and June 8 this year.

headline: Men’s Wear Displays Some Bold Plumage
text: LONDON — “London is so peacock — the most peacock place in the world,” said Tom Ford, as he showed his collection of tailored pastel jackets, rich-hued pants and streamlined tailoring in ‘'pretty'’ colors, as though the 1970s were being redecorated via Instagram.

headline: Check In | A First Look at the New Ace Hotel in Shoreditch, London
text: The hotelier Alex Calderwood is all about creative restoration. He has transformed a halfway house in Seattle, a Howard Johnson in Palm Springs, Calif., and a turn-of-the-century S.R.O. in Manhattan into destination inns. But all of those properties had nostalgia working in their favor. Calderwood’s next move — and his entree into Europe — presented a different design challenge. How do you give a 10-year-old Crowne Plaza — a bland business hotel with track lighting and countless shades of beige — a hipster makeover?

headline: Heat Draw a Line in the Sand
text: Game 7? Of course, there’s a Game 7.

headline: Is $75 Million in Venture Capital an Advantage?
text: Steve Blank retired from serial entrepreneurship after working with eight start-ups, including E.piphany, a software company that he helped found and sold in 2005 for $329 million. Today he’s an associate professor in management science and engineering at Stanford University and co-author of “The Startup Owner’s Manual.” Mr. Blank is credited with helping to create the lean start-up movement, which holds that start-ups can be successful without large amounts of cash.
