As we considered the example posed in our just-published article contrasting the financing experiences of two data companies that went after roughly the same market at roughly the same time, GoodData (venture-backed) and RJMetrics (mostly self-financed), we asked Mr. Blank for his views on an age-old question.

headline: Marriage, the Job
text: Ben Affleck caught some flak earlier this year when, in the course of his Oscar-night thank-yous, in front of a billion of his closest friends, he referred to his marriage to Jennifer Garner as “work.” Matrimony, at least among the famous, is not supposed to be that way. It is either a magical storybook dream, breathlessly chronicled in supermarket magazines, or else, in those same pages a few years later, a train wreck of betrayal and heartbreak. Hollywood marriage, like so much else in modern celebrity culture, is both aspirational and cautionary.

headline: Latest Footage of Protests in Brazil
text: Dramatic moments from the protests in Rio De Janeiro, São Paulo and Brasilia this week.

headline: What You Get for ... $538,000
text: Ranch houses in Houston and Nashville and an old farmhouse in New Hampshire

headline: What You Get for ... $538,000
text: DOVER, N.H.

headline: Unisex Styling Is Back in London
text: Suzy Menkes speaks to designer Jonathan Anderson during the spring/summer 2014 men’s shows in London.

headline: Real Estate in the Czech Republic
text: The market in Prague has recovered fairly well from the financial crisis, but there is still a dearth of luxury properties.

headline: House Hunting in ... the Czech Republic
text: A TWO-BEDROOM ONE-BATH ATTIC APARTMENT IN PRAGUE’S OLD TOWN

headline: Chasing Waves South of Tokyo
text: From the portside window of the 19-seat passenger plane, the island of Niijima, 100 miles southeast of Tokyo, looked like any other tropical paradise. There were volcanic mountaintops wreathed in white clouds, valleys of verdant green jungle, and beaches filled with sand so bright and white the whole coastline looked as if it had been sketched out in chalk.

headline: Hotel Review: Acme Hotel Company in Chicago
text: RATES

headline: Altidore’s Scoring Spree Energizes U.S. Team
text: SANDY, Utah — There was a moment in the second half Tuesday night when Jozy Altidore, the enigmatic striker for the United States national soccer team, watched a defender for Honduras send a pass back toward his goalkeeper. It was a steamy night at Rio Tinto Stadium and Altidore had been running for much of the game; he could have easily stayed put and watched the goalkeeper, Noel Valladares, take the ball and boot it downfield.

headline: BT Group Chief Resigns to Join British Government
text: LONDON — BT Group, the British telecommunications giant, said Wednesday that Ian Livingston was resigning as chief executive to become the British minister for trade and investment.

headline: A Historic Home Restored
text: Wave Hill House, a Hudson River mansion in the Bronx, is reopening this summer after a $9.8 million, two-year renovation.

headline: Historic Wave Hill House, Restored to Former Glory
text: Even at 24,055 square feet, the stately fieldstone mansion in the Bronx has long been overshadowed by the more celebrated public gardens and Hudson River views just outside its door.

headline: Wesley Clark, Retired General, Joins Blackstone as an Adviser
text: Wesley K. Clark, a retired Army general and onetime supreme allied commander in Europe for NATO, has joined the Blackstone Group as a deal adviser in the energy sector.

headline: ‘Slaves of the Marriage Union’
text: On June 18, 1863, a woman named Elizabeth Packard rode out of a state insane asylum in Jacksonville, Ill., perched on the interwoven arms of two men. Three years earlier, she had been confined under a state law that allowed husbands and fathers to commit their wives or children to the asylum, with little legal process. All they needed was the permission of the asylum superintendent.

headline: Alaska’s Murkowski Becomes Third G.O.P. Senator to Support Gay Marriage
text: Senator Lisa Murkowski, the Alaska Republican who has emerged as one of her party’s more moderate members in the Senate, said Wednesday that she supports same-sex marriage.

headline: General Electric Adds to Its ‘Industrial Internet’
text: One of the most influential companies in high technology right now may be a 135-year-old industrial stalwart.

headline: Rethinking Makeup’s Sun Protection
text: The Food and Drug Administration’s new labeling rules for sunscreen have been closely parsed by the health community. But how will they affect your beauty routine?

headline: Runway Best Sellers
text: Qantas has something new for its most valued customers: a boxed set of 10 paperbacks customized for the length of the airline’s flights. The Australian airline commissioned the advertising agency Droga5 Sydney to create “Stories for Every Journey” in collaboration with the Hachette Australia publishing house as a gift for its Platinum One frequent fliers. The collection includes thriller, satire, nonfiction, history and romance titles designed to be read from start to finish during routes that last from one and a half to close to 24 hours. Book lengths were based on average reading patterns, factoring in time for takeoffs and landings and, in the words of the ad agency, “the odd glass of shiraz.”

headline: Porsche and GMC Rank Highest in New Version of J.D. Power Initial Quality Study
text: J.D. Power released the results of a new version of its Initial Quality Study on Wednesday at a news conference with the Automotive Press Association in Detroit. The 2013 study was redesigned to measure better the quality of new technology that is becoming common in vehicles – including features like voice-recognition, blind-spot-monitoring, lane-departure-warning and self-parking systems.

headline: Warm Notes in Berlin for Obama and Merkel
text: BERLIN — Twice, President Obama called her “Angela" — and he pronounced it the German way, with a hard G. When it came time to answer a German journalist’s question about Mr. Obama's failure to close the American prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, Chancellor Angela Merkel deftly told the president, “Du, glaube ich” — “You’re on, I think” — using the familiar form of the pronoun in German.

headline: Obama Readying Emissions Limits on Power Plants
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is preparing regulations limiting carbon dioxide emissions from existing power plants, senior officials said Wednesday. The move would be the most consequential climate policy step he could take and one likely to provoke legal challenges from Republicans and some industries.

headline: Father and Son Acquitted of Sex Trafficking Charges
text: A novel attempt to use New York State’s sex trafficking law against a father and son from Pennsylvania ended with mixed results on Wednesday, as the men were convicted in Manhattan of promoting prostitution and of money laundering, but were acquitted of the more serious charges of sex trafficking.

headline: HPV Vaccine Is Credited in Fall of Teenagers’ Infection Rate
text: The prevalence of dangerous strains of the human papillomavirus — the most common sexually transmitted infection in the United States and a principal cause of cervical cancer — has dropped by half among teenage girls in recent years, a striking measure of success for a vaccine against the virus that was introduced only in 2006, federal health officials said on Wednesday.

headline: The Success of the HPV Vaccine
text: The Times’s Pam Belluck on how the HPV vaccine has helped drastically reduce the number of human papillomavirus cases among teenage girls.

headline: Google’s Shareholder Bulwark for the Future
text: Google shareholders are getting some modest future-proofing.

headline: Border Raids
text: Gail Collins: David, you travel so much that I’m never sure where you are when I’m conversing with you. Do you happen to currently be in any of the places where the governor of Texas, Rick Perry, is trying to steal jobs?

headline: Executive at Monsanto Wins Global Food Honor
text: When it comes to agriculture, the World Food Prize is the equivalent of the Oscars.

headline: An All-American Roadside Attraction in West Texas
text: Over the next few months, motorists speeding through the West Texas desert on Highway 90, just outside the arts town of Marfa, will encounter an unexpected roadside attraction: a white neon Playboy logo hovering above a matte-black 1972 Dodge Charger perched at an 18-degree angle atop a concrete plinth. Playboy Marfa, as it’s being called, is the first in a series of art projects commissioned by Playboy’s new creative team of Neville Wakefield and Landis Smithers meant to reintroduce the brand for a younger generation. It’s the work of Richard Phillips — the artist best known for his hyper-realistic portraits of women, often in the mode of the old-school magazine pictorial — who was a natural fit for the brand, Smithers said. “I loved his idea of this glowing symbol in the middle of nowhere as we — Playboy — are emerging from this period of darkness.”

headline: A Homely Rodent May Hold Cancer-Fighting Clues
text: The laboratory of Vera Gorbunova and Andrei Seluanov, a husband-and-wife team of biologists at the University of Rochester, has the feel of a petting zoo. They maintain colonies of several species of rodents — some familiar, like mice and guinea pigs, and some much more exotic, like blind mole rats from Israel and naked mole rats from East Africa.

headline: Spurs Stick to the Plan, With Devastating Results
text: For half of Game 6 of the N.B.A. finals Tuesday night, Tim Duncan of the San Antonio Spurs dominated more thoroughly than he had in any of his 27 previous finals games. Miami Heat defenders were powerless to dislodge him from his place on the low block and, once there, Duncan bullied and beguiled his opponents with quick turns and authoritative jump hooks. Duncan punctuated his 25-point, 8-rebound first half with a one-handed sledgehammer dunk off a no-look pass from Boris Diaw.

headline: Buyers Are Scarce for Quinn’s Memoir
text: New Yorkers are not buying Christine C. Quinn’s story — at bookstores, anyway.

headline: From Jungle to Jungle Gym
text: Wiggling, giggling, running and jumping, a classroom of excited kindergartners gather in a circle at the feet of their teacher. It’s the last day of school; seen through a doorway, parents adjust their camera lenses and find their seats for the graduation ceremony. But as Mrs. Appleby, the children’s teacher, tells her students, “We still have time for one last guessing game.”

headline: Image of the Day: June 19
text: Devotees gather at the Kamakhya temple in Guwahati, Assam, for the Ambubachi festival which begins on Saturday.

headline: Militants Attack U.N. Compound in Somalia’s Capital
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Militants staged a deadly assault on a United Nations compound here on Wednesday, the latest in a series of attacks that have chipped away at the security gains the Somali capital has experienced in recent years.

headline: Day 2: Sights and Sounds of Wimbledon Qualifying
text: ROEHAMPTON, England — After the field of 128 men in the qualifying draw was halved on Monday in Day 1 of Wimbledon qualifying, the women’s field of 96 began play on Day 2 Tuesday on the lawns of the Bank of England Club, with the men to follow.

headline: The Gun Report: June 19, 2013
text: Over the weekend, a horrible gun incident took place in Des Moines, Iowa. Scott Hazelbaker, 51, accidentally shot and killed his 18-year-old daughter Emily. We included Emily’s death in our Weekend Gun Report, but there’s more. Laura Nichols, a reporter with KCCI in Des Moines, landed an interview with Hazelbaker, who described his daughter as his best friend. “She was just an angel here on earth,” he said. “I miss her so much.” During the interview, Hazelbaker “sat with his head down and tears in his eyes,” according to Nichols.

headline: Updates on the Fed Announcement
text: The Federal Reserve’s policy statement and news conference were awaited with unusual anticipation by economists and investors looking for clues about when the central bank might curtail its stimulus programs. The markets have been in turmoil since the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said at a May 22 hearing that a change could come “in the next few meetings” of the Fed’s policy making board. Here is an account of how the statement and Mr. Bernanke’s appearance unfolded.

headline: Obesity in Teenagers Is Tied to Hearing Loss
text: Obesity in adolescents is associated with a range of cardiovascular and other health risks. Now a new study adds one more: hearing loss.

headline: Self-Publishing Star Amanda Hocking Sells Next Series to St. Martin’s
text: Amanda Hocking, who sold more than one million copies of her self-published novels before turning to a traditional publisher, has sold another series to St. Martin’s Press.

headline: Michael Hastings, 33, Winner of Polk Award, Dies
text: Michael Hastings, the award-winning freelance reporter who died on Tuesday at 33, was known for an intrepid journalism that took him to war zones in Afghanistan and Iraq and, most famously, brought down a United States Army general.

headline: F.B.I. Director Warns Against Dismantling Surveillance Program
text: WASHINGTON — Robert S. Mueller III, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, warned Wednesday that dismantling the National Security Agency’s once-secret program that is keeping records of billions of domestic phone calls by Americans would slow down investigators as they seek to stop terrorist attacks.

headline: Optimistic Fed Outlines an End to Its Stimulus
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve, increasingly confident in the durability of economic growth, expects to start pulling back later this year from its efforts to stimulate the economy, the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Wednesday.

headline: Microsoft Adds Office for iPhone. Yawn.
text: Anticlimax (noun) 1. An event or conclusion that is far less important, powerful or striking than expected. 2. The release of Microsoft Office for the iPhone.

headline: 60 Seconds With Pogue: Office for iPhone
text: The Times’s David Pogue on whether Office for iPhone was worth the wait.

headline: The British Men’s Collections Stand Out
text: Spring 2014 collections like Burberry and Alexander McQueen made bold use of color.

headline: Krawcheck Guides 85 Broads Into Investments
text: Sallie L. Krawcheck, a former big bank executive, has emerged as a prominent advocate for Wall Street women in recent weeks, after buying the women’s network 85 Broads in May. But it remained unclear what Ms. Krawcheck was planning to do with the organization.

headline: Private Equity Firm Tied to New York Pension Scandal Raises $7.7 Billion From Investors
text: Four years ago this month, the private equity firm Riverstone Holdings agreed to pay $30 million to resolve its role in a “pay-to-play” pension fund investigation by Andrew M. Cuomo, the New York attorney general at the time. Several months later, Riverstone’s founder, David M. Leuschen, paid an additional $20 million to settle his role in the case.

headline: Making the Best of a Brief Turn
text: IT’S USELESS TO SAY that London men’s wear makers are true to form this season. What else would you expect from a bunch of brand-savvy designers? With their 15 minutes in the spotlight, before it shifts to Milan and Paris, they had better make an impression.

headline: The Ultimate Judges on Doping
text: Until fans stop spinning turnstiles and otherwise spending their money, baseball will not have incentive to push for true reform on performance enhancing drugs, according to William C. Rhoden.

headline: A Stop on a Michigan ‘Garage Crawl’ Reveals a Trove of Corvettes, Exotics and Other Classics
text: BRIGHTON, Mich. – “As a kid I’d hop the fence at local dealerships to see the new cars before they were revealed to the public,” said Ken Lingenfelter during a Saturday a tour of his private collection. Mr. Lingenfelter, the son of a General Motors executive, grew up immersed in all things automotive, so when he gained the means, he started buying cars, lots of cars. Many of them were built by the company for which his father had worked.

headline: Sunscreen No Longer Just for Sun
text: Sunscreen is no longer just for sea and ski. But which “city” formulations are most comfortable? Below, a few are reviewed.

headline: Video: The Ultimate Judges on Doping in Baseball
text: Until fans stop spinning turnstiles and otherwise spending their money, baseball will not have incentive to push for true reform on performance enhancing drugs.

headline: Casino Referendum Planned by New York Leaders
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders have agreed to ask voters in November to amend the State Constitution to allow a significant expansion of casino gambling.

headline: Nadal Made a Dangerous Fifth Seed at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The seedings for Wimbledon were announced Wednesday, and there were no surprises: the top five seeds mirrored the top five players in the ATP rankings and were unchanged by the formula tournament organizers use to account for prowess on grass courts.

headline: Decoding the Fed’s Statement
text: Comparing the May and June statements issued by the Federal Open Market Committee.

headline: Will Parents Still Turn Down an ‘Anti-Cancer Vaccine’?
text: New research strongly suggests that the HPV vaccine works.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Dress Whites Come to Resort
text: Crisp, cotton dresses in soft white poplin were timeless and simple standouts at the resort collections of The Row, Philosophy and Valentino (shown with a sheer lace skirt over the top).

headline: Tobias Lindholm on ‘A Hijacking’
text: The director Tobias Lindholm discusses his film.

headline: A Credit Card That Helps Pay Down Your Mortgage
text: There are credit cards that offer cash-back rewards for goals as diverse as travel and saving for college. Now, as the housing market rebounds, Wells Fargo is stepping up its promotion of a card that can help borrowers pay down their home loan faster.

headline: Scene City: Madonna Onscreen and in Person
text: “Madonna: The MDNA Tour” premieres at Paris theater.

headline: Her Madgesty Arrives Fashionably Late
text: At 8:50 p.m. Tuesday, Martha Stewart walked out of the Paris Theater, which was showing a premiere of “Madonna: The MDNA Tour,” a concert film to be shown on Epix.

headline: Sales and Events for the Week of June 20
text: Staycation

headline: A Symphony at Sea
text: In one of the most offbeat orchestras ever assembled, three brass bands, one lighthouse and more than 50 horn-blowing ships will perform the Foghorn Requiem on Saturday. Stationed off the northern England port of South Shields, the ships along with the shore-based bands and the Souter Lighthouse will sound a lament across the North Sea for the loss of foghorns in the age of satellite navigation.

headline: Four American Men Advance to Main Draw Through Wimbledon Qualifying
text: ROEHAMPTON, England — Four American men — Denis Kudla, Alex Kuznetsov, Wayne Odesnik, and Bobby Reynolds — qualified for the Wimbledon main draw Wednesday, winning the best-of-five final qualifying-round matches unique to this tournament.

headline: Hitchcock, Finding His Voice in Silents
text: Alfred Hitchcock may be the most famous film director who ever lived — a favorite of both the pleasure-loving public and theory-addled academics; the subject at once of bizarre biographical fantasies (now available in both book and movie form) as well as of some of the most significant critical thinking of the last 50 or 60 years.

headline: Baking His Own Tart
text: Outtakes is an occasional feature on the story behind the photographs in the Dining section.

headline: The Calorie-Packed Perk
text: Within my first week of working at a start-up, I acquired a gut. The reason was obvious: there was free food everywhere, it was delicious and I was nervous. Within five days I was heaving my stomach around like a kettle bell and crossly preparing, and then ignoring, cups of green tea.

headline: Smartphone Tools Have Their Place in the Wild
text: I have some vacation time coming up shortly and I’m planning to make the most of the summery weather by camping and walking in the wild. Unlike the makeshift camping trips of my youth, this outing will be planned carefully, and I’m taking my smartphone, loaded with apps that I think will be useful in the field.

headline: Footage of Aftermath of Attack on U.N.
text: Scenes from the United Nations compound in Mogadishu, Somalia after Islamist militants staged a deadly assault on Wednesday.

headline: Bank of America Names New Co-Heads of Technology and Media Banking
text: Bank of America Merrill Lynch named new co-heads of its technology, media and telecommunications investment banking group on Wednesday. It poached one from JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Wheelies: The Eco-Truck Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: An Entrepreneur Retreats Into a Swedish Forest
text: Thomas Backlund, 33, is a programmer from Stockholm who is trying to start a business, Blockie.io. As mentioned in this week’s Dashboard roundup of small-business news, Mr. Backlund has quit his job and left his apartment and moved to a Swedish forest in order to save expenses while creating his new venture. We contacted Mr. Backlund by e-mail for a conversation that has been edited and condensed.

headline: Apple and Netflix Dominate Online Video
text: Now that the video rental store is all but dead (see: Blockbuster), many people are turning to Internet services to get TV shows and movies. By some measures, Apple is No. 1 in online video, but by others, Netflix is leading.

headline: Here’s Snow White. Don’t Bring the Kids.
text: In the five years since it converted itself into a contemporary art hall, with one of the largest open exhibition floors in the world, the Park Avenue Armory has helped realize several gargantuan and difficult projects. The Brazilian artist Ernesto Neto remade the space into a science-fiction spider web, swathing it with thousands of feet of Lycra. Ann Hamilton installed swings from the trusses, turning visitors into participants in an ethereal moving sculpture.

headline: The Spirits of Brazil, Weaving Through Jazz Sounds
text: With her bright, alluring sliver of a voice — a darting musical tongue of flame — Stacey Kent has few of the traits commonly associated with jazz singing. Yet with her lightly swinging delivery, curt phrasing and attraction to Brazilian bossa nova, she is a jazz singer in the iconoclastic mode of the much-missed Blossom Dearie, whom some critics wrongly dismissed as more cabaret than jazz.

headline: The Impulse at Its Purest, Racing Anew
text: The world of the Israeli kibbutz and the broader Middle East comes to us in Zvi Gotheiner’s “Dabke.” Mr. Gotheiner has lived, danced and choreographed in New York since 1988, but he began life in a kibbutz. New last year, “Dabke” strikes me as the most enchanting piece I’ve seen in a long while — a little too long for its own good at 48 minutes, and yet continually surprising, even revelatory, throughout.

headline: Bike-Sharing Comes to Aspen
text: Never one to fall behind trends, Aspen, Colo., proclaims itself the first mountain town with a bike-share program. Its new We-cycle fleet includes 100 bikes parked at 13 stations around town.

headline: Britain Prepares to Sell Its Stake in Lloyds and Weighs a Breakup of R.B.S.
text: LONDON — The British government is preparing to sell part of its holding in the Lloyds Banking Group and is weighing a breakup of the Royal Bank of Scotland, the chancellor of the Exchequer said on Wednesday.

headline: In Harlem, Gershwin’s Brief, Brash, Early Opera
text: Familiar sights and sounds greeted visitors to the Cotton Club in Harlem on Tuesday night. Stepping into the modern-day incarnation of that storied Prohibition-era nightclub, you heard swing standards brightly played by the Cotton Club All-Stars: “In a Mellow Tone,” “Take the ‘A’ Train,” “In the Mood” and so on. Out on the dance floor, nattily garbed dancers cut a figurative rug.

headline: Tapping to Shostakovich, and Other Adventures
text: Within the first minutes of “STePz,” the playful new Savion Glover show that opened a three-week run at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, all but one of its essential elements are established. As usual for this virtuoso tap dancer, there’s an amplified platform. Unusually, there’s recorded music. Mr. Glover, at his most relaxed and appealing, is joined by Marshall Davis Jr. and three accomplished female hoofers: Ayodele Casel, Sarah Savelli and Robyn Watson. They’re all having a ball.

headline: The Glory and Brutality of a Purebred Texan Clan
text: The words of Edward Gibbon bookend Philipp Meyer’s novel “The Son,” a luxuriantly big book that tells a very Texan story of decline and fall. Mr. Meyer opens with Gibbon’s words about how the vicissitudes of fortune defeat the most magisterial human achievements. That the same quotation can be purchased on mouse pads and coffee cups does nothing if not affirm Gibbon’s wisdom.

headline: Investigation Follows Trail of a Virus in Hospitals
text: A man in a Saudi hospital has pneumonia. The patient in the room next door gets sick, and before anyone realizes what is happening he infects seven others, each of whom infects at least one more. An outbreak is born.

headline: Young Dodger Shows Full Day’s Worth of Skill
text: Yasiel Puig introduced himself to the Yankees early in Game 1 of Wednesday’s doubleheader, singling up the middle in the first inning, barrelling around first base and dashing full speed toward second — a 245-pound blur kicking up chunks of dirt in his wake.

headline: Pressed for Time and Looking for Love
text: PITTSFIELD, Mass. — The mating season has arrived at the Barrington Stage Company. This theatrical outpost in the Berkshires has recreated the habitat of creatures whose ruling imperative is to find sexual partners fast. You will be happy to know that, nature being generous by and large, most of them get — how shall we put it? — lucky. You, in turn, will surely feel lucky to be in their company for a couple of hours.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Brazil and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Brazil, Somalia, Afghanistan and France.

headline: Finding Deals With Paid Upgrades
text: With all the complaints about escalating fees that travelers have to pay, another pricing trend is on the rise that some customers may actually like: paid upgrades.

headline: Isner Hopes for Improvement at Wimbledon
text: STOKE PARK, England -– Events don’t get more quintessentially British than the Boodles Challenge, the pre-Wimbledon exhibition tournament tucked away in a well-heeled corner of the English countryside. This is tennis’ version of Royal Ascot, a week in which the spectator experience is as much about the clinking of champagne glasses as feasting on the sight of Richard Gasquet’s backhand.

headline: Now Screening | The Goofy, Cultish World of Master Sommeliers
text: How to make a wine documentary that doesn’t put audiences to sleep? The first-time director Jason Wise opted to focus less on wine itself and more on the characters who uncork, decant, sample and sell it: the sommeliers. His film “Somm” follows a quartet of hotshot American oenophiles as they prepare for a three-part, three-day test on every imaginable nuance of wine that is administered by the prestigious (and exclusive) British organization the Court of Master Sommeliers. Over nearly half a century, this international body has only “knighted” 197 candidates as Masters — about 10 percent of test takers. Dustin Wilson, the wine director of the triple-Michelin-starred Manhattan restaurant Eleven Madison Park and one of the film’s stars, passed just one of three parts — service — the first time he took it in 2010. “Only 16 people have ever passed it their first time,” he said.

headline: Kingdom for Horse? No, but $64 for Parking
text: For the last 17 summers it has been one of New York’s more offbeat free diversions: Shakespeare in the Parking Lot, wherein a troupe of actors on a shoestring budget perform “Hamlet,” “Macbeth” and other classics in a municipal lot on the Lower East Side.

headline: Readers Debate Brazil’s Protests
text: The nationwide protests in Brazil, which began over an increase in bus fares, have expanded this week into a wide-ranging popular indictment of the nation’s ruling class. As the unrest has intensified, Brazilian readers of The New York Times have attempted to explain the protests to a curious audience in comments posted on this site in English and Portuguese.

headline: Sotheby’s Considers Putting Its Headquarters Up for Sale
text: Sotheby’s, the auction house that has for centuries put other people’s treasures up for sale, is in the early days of exploring whether it should place one of its own on the block: its glittering glass-and-granite-fronted worldwide headquarters on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Remembering Seymon Deutsch
text: One of the true gentlemen of bridge, Seymon Deutsch, died in San Antonio on June 12. He was 78.

headline: Seattle Opera Names a General Director
text: Speight Jenkins has been the general director of the Seattle Opera for 30 of the company’s 50 seasons, and given his accomplishments — which include renovating the Seattle Opera House, staging productions of the complete Wagner canon and making the company’s “Ring” cycle an international attraction — it seemed as if he would lead the company indefinitely. But Mr. Jenkins, 76, told the board in 2011 that he would like to step down, and that set in motion a two-year search that ended on Wednesday. The company announced that the British stage director Aidan Lang, currently the general director of the New Zealand Opera, would succeed Mr. Jenkins in 2014. Mr. Lang, 57, has held his position in New Zealand since 2006. He was also artistic director of the Buxton Festival in Britain from 1999 to 2006 and Opera Zuid in the Netherlands from 1990 to 1998. Mr. Lang will join the company as director designate next March and work with Mr. Jenkins, who will remain general director through August 2014. They will work together on the 2015-16 season; Mr. Lang’s first season solo will be 2016-17.

headline: Musical Relics From Paganini and Mozart, Still Sending Blessings
text: The trade in religious relics has ebbed substantially since the Middle Ages, when wealthy collectors and ambitious clerics vied for possession of a saint’s femur or a splinter of the Holy Cross. But on feast days, relics are still paraded through towns across Europe.

headline: Black Sabbath Earns Its First No.1
text: It took four decades, but Black Sabbath, the British rock band that arguably spawned the entire heavy metal genre, finally earned a No. 1 album on the Billboard 200 chart this week with it’s latest release, “13,” which sold 155,000 copies, Billboard reported on Wednesday. Released on Vertigo, “13” is the group’s first set of new songs with most of its original lineup — the singer Ozzy Osbourne, the guitarist Tony Iommi and the bassist Geezer Butler — since the 1978 album “Never Say Die!” (The original drummer, Bill Ward, is not involved because of contract disputes.) The group’s only other Top 10 album was 1971’s “Master of Reality,” which rose to No. 8.

headline: Teachers’ Union Is Backing Thompson’s Bid for Mayor
text: The United Federation of Teachers, one of the largest union locals in the country, on Wednesday rallied its vast network of members behind William C. Thompson Jr. in the race for mayor of New York.

headline: Larger Rival to Acquire 3-D Printing Start-Up MakerBot
text: MakerBot, the Brooklyn-based start-up that makes 3-D printers, has agreed to sell itself to its larger rival Stratasys, the companies announced on Wednesday.

headline: W.T.O. Head Urges European Leaders to Lead
text: While Europe drowns in its problems, its leaders exacerbate them. In Britain, Prime Minister David Cameron has been promising a destabilizing referendum on the country’s membership in the European Union. Francois Hollande of France has been trying to undermine the E.U.’s negotiations with the United States on an important trade and investment agreement. And the administration of Germany’s chancellor, Angela Merkel, has been trying to delay a much needed banking union for the euro zone.

headline: Deal on Bank Secrecy Stalls in Swiss Parliament
text: Switzerland’s Parliament on Wednesday scuttled an information-sharing agreement with the United States that the Swiss government had hailed just weeks ago as a breakthrough in a dispute over banking secrecy, but left open the possibility for another solution.

headline: Statue Unveiled, Douglass Is Hailed for Equality Fight
text: WASHINGTON — Frederick Douglass, the slave turned abolitionist, believed in freedom and equality for “all of us, regardless of our race, gender, religion or sexual orientation,” his great-great-granddaughter said Wednesday at the unveiling of a statue of Douglass in the Capitol.

headline: Don’t Know This Face? Just Wait
text: In a corridor outside a sixth-floor conference room in Manhattan’s garment center, five exceptionally handsome young men slouched against the walls, looking like gods of Olympus come temporarily to rest. It was midafternoon, and the men had been summoned for a secret meeting, several flown specially from Houston or other corners of the country to meet with those who would decide their fate.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: NEW YORK WITH CHILDREN

headline: Relative Unknown Chosen to Direct ‘Fifty Shades’
text: It was coveted by a range of big-time filmmakers, but a woman from the cinematic minor leagues won the job: Sam Taylor-Johnson will direct the film adaptation of the best-selling erotic novel “Fifty Shades of Grey,” Universal Pictures and its arthouse division, Focus Features, announced on Wednesday.

headline: Anxiety in Detroit Over a Prized Car Trove
text: DETROIT — As this debt-ridden city lurches toward a possible bankruptcy filing, residents and workers have been locked in a grim faceoff with creditors over how to preserve what remains of their services and benefits.

headline: Seattle Opera Finds Replacement for Longtime General Director
text: Speight Jenkins has been the general director of the Seattle Opera for 30 of the company’s 50 seasons, and given his accomplishments – which include renovating the Seattle Opera House, staging productions of the complete Wagner canon and making the company’s “Ring” cycle an international attraction – it seemed as if he would lead the company indefinitely. But Mr. Jenkins, 76, told the board in 2011 that he would like to step down, setting in motion a two-year search that ended on Wednesday,

headline: Three Naval Academy Midshipmen Accused of  Sexual Assault
text: Three midshipmen at the United States Naval Academy were charged Wednesday in connection with the serial sexual assault of a female midshipman last year, the academy said.

headline: Clips from Bernanke's Press Conference
text: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, spoke at a press conference on Wednesday.

headline: DOMA and the Supreme Court
text: If the Supreme Court strikes down the Defense of Marriage Act, many federal benefits enjoyed by straight couples will be extended to same-sex couples. But there are other things that will not change.

headline: A Legacy of Detroit
text: The Detroit Historical Society manages 62 classic cars that could be placed on the block if Detroit winds up in bankruptcy court. The cars are pieces of Detroit — and automotive — history.

headline: Remembering Slim Whitman
text: Country musician Slim Whitman died Wednesday at age 90.

headline: The Test of a True Sommelier
text: A trailer by the director Jason Wise follows American oenophiles as they prepare for a three-day test on every imaginable nuance of wine.

headline: Not for the Birds
text: Nests big enough for people.

headline: Twigitecture: Building Human Nests
text: BIG SUR — Last week, I spent a night in a nest. Woven from eucalyptus branches, it bloomed high on the side of a cliff overlooking the Pacific Coast Highway, a great whorl of sticks atop four gnarly pillars. The north wind hissed through the gaps in the branches and the fog settled on my face and sleeping bag, but I could see the stars through the nest’s oculus entry and hear the elephant seals miles below honking and braying in a lullaby like no other.

headline: Solar Power to the People
text: At 9 o’clock Friday morning, some 20,000 people will start arriving at a vast field in Custer, Wis., to talk about wind power. No joke. Get this: Thousands of souls have been coming here every summer for 23 years to talk — really talk — about wind power.

headline: The Collections | The Top Five Men’s Wear Shows in London
text: London Collections: Men, in only its third season of menswear shown separately from womenswear, just wrapped. Next stop, Milan — and then on to Paris. Here, my five favorite looks from the Spring/Summer 2014 runways so far.

headline: I’ll Take It
text: In the Navajo Nation, the gift of a home.

headline: Shopping for Home Fragrance
text: Edward Yedid and Thomas Hickey, two partners in a design firm, scan scents and their packaging.

headline: Home Fragrance
text: As partners in a design firm called Grade, Edward Yedid and Thomas Hickey are unlikely authorities on home fragrance. Nevertheless, “scent is, surprisingly, one part of the different things we do,” said Mr. Hickey, 44, the architect who founded the firm in 2001.

headline: Italian Praised for Saving Jews Is Now Seen as Nazi Collaborator
text: He has been called the Italian Schindler, credited with helping to save 5,000 Jews during the Holocaust. Giovanni Palatucci, a wartime police official, has been honored in Israel, in New York and in Italy, where squares and promenades have been named in his honor, and in the Vatican, where Pope John Paul II declared him a martyr, a step toward potential sainthood.

headline: Rest in Pieces
text: Household objects rendered in clay for the modern day tomb.

headline: Her Hallowed Ground in the Navajo Nation
text: When a nonprofit group approached Lorraine Nakai in 2011 and offered to build her a house, she was taken by surprise. Although her community activism had improved living conditions for other Navajos on the reservation, it had never occurred to her to seek anything for herself.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. My home office is in my living room. How can I make it look more appealing to prospective buyers?

headline: Ceramics That Make the Afterlife More Fun
text: “Hereafter,” a show opening Thursday at Salon 94 Freemans in New York, features the sculpture of Matthias Merkel Hess, who makes ceramic copies of (mostly) household objects. Among the roughly 250 pieces are a Bose Wave radio, a Mr. Coffee brewer, a Black & Decker DustBuster and every single spoon in his home — items the Los Angeles artist considered appropriate for a modern-day tomb, for use in the afterlife.

headline: No Shrinking Violets Here
text: In May, the artist Peter Dayton created a Warholian room, covering walls, tables and screens in riotous bouquets. Mr. Dayton, a former rock musician, is known for his floral collages, which he creates from photocopies of pictures cut from seed catalogs. For this environment, which was commissioned by the Brooklyn gallery Grey Area and displayed at the Collective .1 design fair in New York, begonias were his chosen bloom. “They’re a bit ambiguous and hard to identify,” he said. The name Grey Area refers to “the undefined space between art and design,” in the words of the gallery’s founders, Kyle DeWoody and Manish Vora, who teamed up with Cavern Wallpaper of Los Angeles to make the wallpaper available commercially. Called Wallflowers, it is sold in color or black-and-white for $338 a roll. A resin-coated wood screen and table with the pattern are also available. Information: (347) 799-1155 or greyarea.co.

headline: Philip Johnson’s Glass House Gets a Store to Match
text: “It’s not a good design store, but the ultimate Glass House design store,” said Murray Moss about a shop that opens Friday at the Philip Johnson house in New Canaan, Conn. Mr. Moss, the former SoHo retailer who now heads Moss Bureau, a design advisory service, organized and selected merchandise for the space and installed oversize Corian benches. A map of the 49-acre estate, on which Mr. Johnson lived from 1949 until his death in 2005, hangs prominently on one wall. In Mr. Moss’s view, all of the items for sale dignify that modernist masterwork and its architect, be they an Alvar Aalto vase, brass bar tools by Carl Auböck of Vienna or Angelo Mangiarotti’s 1956 Maritime table clock (shown, $285). “These are souvenirs, but they should be of the level of intelligence of the visitors,” he said, adding, “There will be no finger puppets.” Information: (203) 594-9884, designstore.philipjohnsonglasshouse.org.

headline: ‘Shiro Kuramata’ by Deyan Sudjic
text: The Japanese designer Shiro Kuramata died in 1991, when he was just 56, and virtually all of his renowned interiors, for clients like Issey Miyake and Esprit, have vanished. Among his groundbreaking household objects, including an acrylic chair embedded with artificial roses and an armchair made of glued glass pieces, many are confined to museums and private collections.

headline: Nature’s Little Baubles
text: Succulents, the popular plants that seem to thrive on air and abuse, are jewels in the hands of Andreea Avram Rusu, a Brooklyn architect and designer. Made of porcelain, they adorn her new Gia collection of glass lamps. Why succulents? “It’s incredible, the shapes that you find,” Ms. Avram Rusu said, adding that she cast her ornaments from live specimens and needed plants that were sturdy: “Things with delicate leaves don’t work so well,” she said. The handblown glass globes shade from solid to transparent in an ombré effect. Three shapes are available in a variety of colors, in pendant and table versions. Prices range from $1,800 to $2,400, and custom colors and finishes are available. Information: (718) 389-0350 or avramrusu.com.

headline: Sales at Knoll, Blik and Others
text: During Knoll’s warehouse sale Thursday to Saturday, midcentury modern designs for the home are up to 75 percent off (a Harry Bertoia side chair with polished chrome frame and vinyl seat pad, originally $1,027, is $514; an Eero Saarinen Womb Chair in classic bouclé upholstery, originally $5,069, is $2,535); 55 West 17th Street, (212) 343-4000.

headline: Dumping the Face, and Founder, of Men’s Wearhouse
text: It seems that George A. Zimmer is no longer suited for Men’s Wearhouse.

headline: Flooding Damages Lourdes, French Holy Site
text: PARIS — The waters of the Christian holy site of Lourdes, reputed for their powers of healing, have been cruel this week.

headline: Shoe Battles: Going Toe-to-Toe in Stilettos
text: Stores and designers jump in with both feet to take part in the frenzy.

headline: Shoe Battles: Going Toe-to-Toe in Stilettos
text: The shoe department of Bergdorf Goodman, on the morning of May 29, looked like “an insane asylum of very well-dressed women,” said Sasha Charnin Morrison, the fashion director of Us Weekly, who was reporting from the front lines of what has become an annual rite of spring in Manhattan: the first day of the designer shoe sale.

headline: Nahmad Family’s Monet Brings $30.8 Million at Sotheby’s in London
text: LONDON — Bidders from 33 countries, including a record number from Asia — the broadest participation Sotheby’s had seen here in more than a decade, officials said — drove up prices for the best works at its two-hour sale of Impressionist and modern art on Wednesday night.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Tweet Mapping and Royal Tidings
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Ron Arad’s Metallic Vision
text: The Israeli-British architect and designer Ron Arad has always been fascinated by metal. He made an international name for himself designing furniture like the sheet-steel Well Tempered Chair for Vitra, and he designed an entire building with a ribbonlike Cor-Ten steel exterior — the Design Museum Holon in Holon, Israel, which opened in 2010.

headline: U.S. Accuses 3 Countries of Abetting Human Trafficking
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department on Wednesday accused Russia, China and Uzbekistan of continuing to abet human trafficking and forced labor, raising the possibility that they could face sanctions at a time when President Obama has tried to maintain relations with each on strategic issues.

headline: Domi Fought, but His Son Scores
text: TORONTO — When Max Domi was 12, doctors told him he had Type 1 diabetes.

headline: In Head-Hunting, Big Data May Not Be Such a Big Deal
text: This interview with Laszlo Bock, senior vice president of people operations at Google, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: James Gandolfini Is Dead at 51; a Complex Mob Boss in ‘The Sopranos’
text: James Gandolfini, the Emmy Award-winning actor who shot to fame on the HBO drama “The Sopranos” as Tony Soprano, a tough-talking, hard-living crime boss with a stolid exterior but a rich interior life, died on Wednesday. He was 51.

headline: WikiLeaks Says It Is Working to Negotiate Asylum in Iceland for Snowden
text: WASHINGTON — WikiLeaks activists in Iceland are discussing with government officials there the possibility of asylum for Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who disclosed hundreds of classified documents on N.S.A. surveillance, Julian Assange, the founder of the antisecrecy group, said Wednesday.

headline: Michelle Obama Promotes Healthy Eating With a Grass-Roots Campaign
text: WASHINGTON — The tables, which stretched the length of a full city block, were covered with pork lettuce wraps, catfish, spring rolls, all manner of vegetable soup and something called lunchtime waffles. Sam Kass, Michelle Obama’s senior policy adviser on nutrition, leaned over a pork dish, stabbed it with a fork, then delivered his approbation. “Fantastic.”

headline: Muffling of a Voice Provokes an Outcry in Greece
text: ATHENS — The poignant image made its way around the world: A blond violinist, tears streaming down her face as she played Elgar in a studio orchestra of Greece’s state broadcaster to protest Prime Minister Antonis Samaras’s unilateral decision last week to shut the broadcaster down and fire its 2,600 employees.

headline: Tear Gas Fired Outside Stadium in Brazil, but Protest Still Spreads Inside
text: Tear gas once again filled the air outside a gleaming stadium in Brazil as the police in the northeastern city of Fortaleza blocked an estimated 35,000 protesters from approaching the venue where the national team, known as the Seleção, met Mexico on Wednesday afternoon in a tune-up for next year’s World Cup.

headline: Turkish Liberals Turn Their Backs on Erdogan
text: ISTANBUL — For Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the antigovernment protests that have shaken Turkey have come with a jarring paradox: some of the protesters voted for him, most prospered from his economic policies, and some of the liberal intellectuals and columnists now calling him a dictator helped him win three successive elections with their writings.

headline: Time Lapse of 3-D Printing
text: Using 3-D printing technology, Ryan McMaster created components for a dolly system to use with his D.S.L.R. camera.

headline: Commotion Over the Sale of John Denver’s Sanctuary
text: SNOWMASS, Colo. — John Denver was a troubadour of Colorado, singing of clear skies and country roads, sunshine on his shoulder and Rocky Mountain highs.

headline: Obama Asks Russia to Join in Reducing Nuclear Arms
text: BERLIN — Fifty years after John F. Kennedy famously assured Europeans that the United States would protect them against a nuclear-armed Soviet Union, President Obama on Wednesday marked the changed times by calling on Russia to join him in cutting the world’s two largest nuclear arsenals to well below the level of the Kennedy era.

headline: “Cover”
text: A collaboration by Wesley Stace and Paul Muldoon.

headline: Gauging the Natural, and Digital, Rhythms of Life
text: Walking, sleeping, talking: it’s the stuff of everyday life. Add sensors that track all of it, and suddenly everyday life becomes an opportunity for knowledge.

headline: Why India Trails China
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — MODERN India is, in many ways, a success. Its claim to be the world’s largest democracy is not hollow. Its media is vibrant and free; Indians buy more newspapers every day than any other nation. Since independence in 1947, life expectancy at birth has more than doubled, to 66 years from 32, and per-capita income (adjusted for inflation) has grown fivefold. In recent decades, reforms pushed up the country’s once sluggish growth rate to around 8 percent per year, before it fell back a couple of percentage points over the last two years. For years, India’s economic growth rate ranked second among the world’s large economies, after China, which it has consistently trailed by at least one percentage point.

headline: Lebanon, Overrun by Syrian Refugees
text: ZAHLÉ, Lebanon — MY eyes kept being drawn to the shoes. The tiny pink running shoes with Velcro straps, on the feet of the 2-year-old girl sitting quietly on her mother’s lap. She fidgeted only a bit — jostling occasionally with her 7-year-old twin sisters while her father told a United Nations worker what had driven his young family 20 miles from Syria to this small town in Lebanon. They did not merely leave; they fled. And not once, but three times.

headline: Superstitious James Says His Headband Will Reappear
text: MIAMI — The first question for LeBron James before the Miami Heat’s practice Wednesday was not about Game 7 of the N.B.A. finals, his ever-developing legacy or his triple-double performance in Tuesday’s 103-100 overtime victory. It was not even about the Spurs. James was asked about his headband or, rather, the absence of it.

headline: “The Better Man”
text: A song by Charmaine Lee and Emma Zorensky

headline: Stocks Slide on Fears of Cuts to Fed’s Bond-Buying Program
text: Ben S. Bernanke’s confidence in the United States economy did not kill the worm of doubt that has been gnawing at markets.

headline: While Claiming Battle Gains Against Rebels, Syria’s Assad Is Facing Currency Crisis
text: Even as President Bashar al-Assad of Syria is proclaiming battlefield momentum against the insurgency with the help of his Hezbollah ally, he appears to be facing a new threat: a rapidly weakening currency that has unnerved many Syrians.

headline: A Public Art Project That Will Travel by Train
text: Chartered train trips tend to conjure images of flag bunting, stump speeches and glad-handing politicians.

headline: West Virginia, Still Home
text: Residents of McDowell County, W.Va., share memories and hopes for their rural community — in jeopardy because of high unemployment and an exodus of young people.

headline: ‘West Virginia, Still Home’
text: In this Op-Doc video, and a related online interactive documentary, “Hollow,” I share the experiences and memories of hard-working people who live amid the coal fields of McDowell County, W.Va. They are struggling to save their rural community — in jeopardy because of high unemployment and an exodus of young people (since 1950, the county has lost 80 percent of its population).

headline: Preparing for the Pope
text: In April, in the sunlit city of Natal, Brazil, two men knocked on Sandra Abdalla’s door to apply for a painting job. Their pitch, as she described it in an e-mail: they were evangelical Christians and therefore more reliable than the competition. They didn’t drink, raise hell or steal, as a Catholic might. In a country that boasts the largest Roman Catholic population in the world — and a quickly rising tide of evangelicals — those are fighting words. Not least to Pope Francis, an Argentine who will visit Brazil next month, in the first trip of his papacy.

headline: Andy Warhol and the Persistence of Modernism
text: The June 20th issue of The New York Review of Books contains a devastating portrayal, by the art critic Richard Dorment, of the activities of The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts and its (now dissolved) sister institution, the Andy Warhol Art Authentication Board. The foundation was established, according to Warhol’s will, to provide for the “advancement of the visual arts,” and was to be funded by the sale of a large number of works the artist left to his estate. The board was assembled for the purpose of deciding whether a given work was an original Warhol. As I’ll explain, that task is hardly straightforward.

headline: Injured Making an Arrest, Bear the Police Dog Becomes a Celebrity
text: He waited by an elevator on the 13th floor of Police Headquarters, the final stop Wednesday in a whirlwind of television appearances and newspaper interviews since his line-of-duty injury the previous day: broken teeth, swollen snout.

headline: An Online Meter Reader
text: Jonathan Harris is a digital artist and designer. His projects combine elements of computer science, anthropology, visual art and storytelling, seeking to “reimagine how humans relate to technology and to each other,” Mr. Harris says on his Web site.

headline: High-Stakes Games: Critical Step for Suit Seeking Payment for College Athletes
text: In 2008, as big money poured into the coffers of college athletics, the N.C.A.A. faced a growing chorus of criticism that student-athletes were being exploited.

headline: G.A.O. Says Airline Merger Will Reduce Competition
text: The planned merger between American Airlines and US Airways will reduce competition in a far larger number of airports than earlier airline mergers, including the one that created the nation’s current leader, United-Continental, according to a report released Wednesday by the Government Accountability Office.

headline: Kidd Adds Throwing Out First Pitch to Busy Schedule
text: Jason Kidd’s first six days as coach of the Nets have been a whirlwind of interviews and appearances, learning and organizing, settling in and reaching out to whomever might be willing to help him wade into his new career.

headline: A Nation Divided Against Itself
text: Along with — and because of — dramatic social and demographic changes, America is quickly dividing itself into two separate nations, regional enclaves of rigid politics, as the idea of common national priorities fades further into a distant past.

headline: Lawsuit Named for O’Bannon Has Other Critical Participants
text: For Sonny Vaccaro, the Ed O’Bannon lawsuit against the N.C.A.A. is an important part of a personal crusade. He wants to see the organization, his nemesis, in court, its inner workings exposed. He prays he will be called to testify. He is not shy about the stakes, with the latest hearing in the case scheduled for Thursday.

headline: G.E. Makes the Machine, and Then Uses Sensors to Listen to It
text: Thomas Edison invented tomorrow here.

headline: British Court Rules Against Sanctions on Iranian Bank
text: Britain’s Supreme Court ruled that sanctions imposed on a commercial Iranian bank were invalid because the British Treasury had sought them improperly through a secret court proceeding in a misuse of Britain’s antiterrorism laws. The decision raised new questions about the country’s secret courts and was a vindication for the Iranian bank, Bank Mellat, which had spent four years fighting the sanctions designation that had banned it from operating in Britain. In Washington, the Treasury Department sharply criticized the British ruling and warned that Bank Mellat, which has been accused of financing Iranian nuclear and ballistic missile activities, remained under sanction by both the European Union and the United States. A Treasury Department statement said Bank Mellat “has no place in the international financial system.”

headline: One-Sided Bill on Asbestos Injuries
text: Republicans rammed a bill through the House Judiciary Committee last month that would make it harder for plaintiffs injured by asbestos to get fair compensation. The bill is supposedly designed to root out fraud and abuse, but there is no persuasive evidence of any significant fraud or abuse. Before plunging ahead with this misguided attempt to protect asbestos companies from lawsuits, Congress ought to commission an objective study of whether there is even a problem that needs fixing.

headline: Turkey in Turmoil
text: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan had many opportunities over the last three weeks to resolve the political crisis in Turkey peacefully and quickly. However, with almost every statement and directive he has made the situation worse, increasing concerns at home and abroad over his authoritarian tendencies and Turkey’s future as a democratic model in the Muslim world.

headline: Prying Private Eyes
text: Whatever one thinks about Edward Snowden and his revelations about government snooping, the case has been a useful reminder of the extent to which the government has outsourced intelligence work to the private sector and the risks in doing so.

headline: Despite Their Guilty Pleas, Relatives of Payroll-Scheme Defendant Stay Loyal to Him
text: Family members are often seen in New York City courtrooms, observing legal proceedings that involve a loved one. But on Wednesday afternoon, there was a family gathering of a different sort in Manhattan’s federal court.

headline: A Second Chance for Ex-Offenders
text: The federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission took on an important issue last year when it reaffirmed and updated a ruling that barred employers from automatically denying people jobs based on arrest or conviction records. The guidance made clear that an arrest alone was not proof of illegal conduct or grounds for exclusion. It also explained that, when considering an applicant with a criminal conviction, the employer must take into account the seriousness of the offense, the time lapsed since the offense and the relevance of the crime to the specific job being sought.

headline: Will the Protests Change Brazil?
text: How is it possible for Brazil, which is often cited as a model for developing countries, to lag in providing basic services for its citizens?

headline: Digitizing Sports to Slake a Thirst for Stats
text: When Joe Inzerillo started taping baseball games for the Chicago White Sox a quarter-century ago, about all he needed was a video camera, some blank tapes and a bunch of VCRs. He would edit the tapes and send copies to the video staff members for the opposing team — job done.

headline: How to Tweet in Mandarin
text: BEIJING — Lunch had run late, and by the time we got back to our hotel, Hung Huang was already in the lobby waiting for us. Blunt, opinionated and wickedly funny, Huang is one of the country’s top fashion editors. But she is better known for her acerbic posts on Weibo, a microblog, where she has 7.5 million followers. As we introduced ourselves — four journalists on a three-city tour of China — she passed around a picture that someone had texted her.

headline: In Brooklyn, Long Island College Hospital Staff Gets Reprieve
text: A state judge has ordered Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn to keep up its level of staffing after complaints by hospital workers that the State University of New York was allowing it to wither away even as officials publicly claimed they were doing everything possible to keep it open.

headline: After a Crusher, Spurs Regroup and Refocus
text: MIAMI — The first order of business, after the most soul-crushing defeat in San Antonio Spurs history, was dinner.

headline: State Expected to Drastically Reduce Role of L.I. Power Authority
text: The Long Island Power Authority would cede most of its control over the electric grid on Long Island and freeze rates for two years under a proposal that state lawmakers are expected to approve on Thursday.

headline: Data-Driven Aesthetics
text: Looking out from a small control room, I scan the suspended grid of more than 200 iPhone-size computer screens for any sign of life. One flickers awake, flips through a sequence of messages, too fast to be legible, and then holds on the sentence “I’m really not meant for him.“ After a short pause, a screen three columns over lights up, runs through more messages and finds “I’m scared I’ll lose my smile …“

headline: Slim Whitman, Yodeling Country Singer With a Regular-Guy Image, Dies at 90
text: In the 1996 movie comedy “Mars Attacks!” Slim Whitman’s yodeling, high-octave rendition of “Indian Love Call” causes the heads of the invading Martians to explode, saving Planet Earth.

headline: Surveillance, in a Search for Safety
Time Warner Faces Suit After Taking Over Los Angeles Sports Market
text: Time Warner Cable’s spending spree for the rights to carry the Los Angeles Lakers and the Los Angeles Dodgers has altered the Southern California sports market. The Lakers have already left one of Fox Sports’ regional sports networks. The Dodgers will leave a different one after the season. The result: new regional channels featuring the teams that will add to the bills of local cable, satellite and telephone subscribers.

headline: New Ways Marketers Are Manipulating Data to Influence You
text: By now many people are used to the way advertisements follow them around the Web — how the shoes they clicked on here keep popping up there.

headline: Source of Friction in Albany? A New Color for Bus Lights
text: In 2011, there was the struggle over same-sex marriage. Last year, lawmakers grappled with retirement benefits for future public employees.

headline: 62 Vintage Cars in Collection at Risk
text: The Detroit Historical Society manages a collection of classic cars that could be placed on the block if Detroit winds up in bankruptcy court.

headline: Dave Jennings, All-Pro Punter for Giants, Dies at 61
text: Dave Jennings, who as a punter for the Giants was twice named an All-Pro and was more often the best player on a woeful team, died on Wednesday at his home in Upper Saddle River, N.J. He was 61.

headline: Rangers Set to Introduce New Coach
text: The Rangers are expected to introduce Alain Vigneault as their new coach at a news conference on Friday at Radio City Music Hall.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 20, 2013
text: "These are striking results. They should be a wake-up call that we need to increase vaccination rates. The bottom line is this: It is possible to protect the next generation from cancer, and we need to do it.”

headline: Bronx Teacher Is Charged in Rape of Girl, 10
text: A Bronx elementary schoolteacher told a 10-year-old girl he was taking her to an awards ceremony, where she was to be honored, then raped her in his car, the police said on Wednesday.

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: In New Tools to Combat Epidemics, the Key Is Context
text: Not long ago, Google Flu seemed like magic — a smart, cheap way to sift digital data for the public good.

headline: Climb the Ladder
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — When he wasn’t busy writing “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” or teaching mathematics at Oxford, Lewis Carroll had enough time on his hands to indulge in his hobby of inventing new word games. For that reason he can lay claim to inventing the word ladder, the parlor game featured prominently in today’s crossword puzzle.

headline: Our Broken Social Contract
text: Many Americans think that their country has lost its way. But when they try to make sense of what’s happening, they disagree about whether the problem is essentially economic or whether it stems from cultural and moral decay.

headline: Stephen Porter, Theater Director, Dies at 87
text: Stephen Porter, a director who dusted off classic plays by the likes of Molière and Shaw and honed them as “the realism of another time,” as he put it, on Broadway and other stages, died on June 11 at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Using Data to Stage-Manage Paths to the Prescription Counter
text: Every day, five million people walk into a CVS.

headline: F.T.C. Is Said to Plan Inquiry of Frivolous Patent Lawsuits
text: WASHINGTON — The chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission is expected on Thursday to recommend a sweeping investigation of “patent trolls,” companies that buy large portfolios of technology patents and use them to sue software designers and makers of products like smartphones and tablet computers, people briefed on the inquiry said.

headline: Steal This Idea, a Campaign Urges
text: USUALLY, the people who sponsor or create advertising campaigns are loath to see anyone borrow, lift or otherwise copy their ideas. A new effort, however, is intended to encourage such inspirational appropriation.

headline: For the Mets, an Afterglow, Then Reality’s Harsh Light
text: ATLANTA — From the sublime emotional high provided by Matt Harvey and Zack Wheeler, the Mets’ young, hard-throwing right-handers, the team on Wednesday descended back to the realities of its everyday existence.

headline: Strategist Out of Closet and Into Fray, This Time for Gay Marriage
text: As the Supreme Court considers overturning California’s ban on same-sex marriage, gay people await a ruling that could change their lives. But the case has already transformed one gay man: Ken Mehlman, the once-closeted Republican operative who orchestrated President George W. Bush’s 2004 re-election on a platform that included opposition to same-sex marriage.

headline: Executive With Eye on Bloomberg’s Mantle
text: It has a familiar ring: A civic-minded technology executive, flush with cash and connections from his corporate exploits, concludes that he is uniquely qualified to run City Hall.

text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Eddy Etaeta has learned the art of how to lose gracefully.

headline: Ways to Make Your Online Tracks Harder to Follow
text: There are few secrets in our digital worlds.

headline: James Gandolfini, Actor, Dies
text: The Emmy Award-winning actor, who shot to fame on the HBO drama “The Sopranos” as Tony Soprano, died on Wednesday.

headline: Mapping a Disease Outbreak
text: Investigators tracked a string of coronavirus infections through four Saudi hospitals earlier this year.

headline: 2 Men Charged in Bid to Make Deadly X-Ray Weapon
text: In April 2012, the authorities said, an industrial mechanic walked into a synagogue in Albany and announced his intention to build a weapon that could help Israel kill its enemies while they slept. He wanted to know if anybody would provide financial backing. Turned away, prosecutors said, he sought money from another source: a leader in the Ku Klux Klan in North Carolina.

headline: Handicapping the Half-Life of ‘Big Data’
text: The technologies that now fly under the banner of Big Data are undeniably advancing across the economy, well beyond their early stronghold in consumer Internet companies like Google, Amazon and Facebook. Exploring that evolution is the main theme of the articles in a special section of The New York Times on Thursday.

headline: Bill Would Allow the Sale of Air Rights to Raise Money for Pier 40 Repairs
text: Hudson River Park, the five-mile green space and bicycle path on the West Side of Manhattan that has struggled financially in recent years, may have a new source of money as a result of a deal reached in Albany.

headline: In Hot Pursuit of Numbers to Ward Off Crime
text: At the Seattle Police Department, the morning roll call begins with Google Maps and computer algorithms.

headline: These Soldiers Take Aim at Money Issues
text: For his going-away party last month, Second Lt. Travis Doyle’s young nieces and nephews wrote out some messages for him:

headline: From Campaign War Room to Big-Data Broom
text: At the Obama 2012 campaign headquarters in Chicago, inside a room nicknamed “the Cave,” a team of data analytics experts helped President Obama build the most technologically advanced campaign in American history. And in their own centers of power, even before those votes were cast, Republican leaders and strategists vowed to hone their high-tech skills for future Election Days.
