headline: At His Former Home in TriBeCa, Fond Memories of James Gandolfini
text: In recent years, James Gandolfini spent much of his time in Hollywood, but about a week ago, he was back on the quiet street in TriBeCa where he once lived, not to stay — his place was rented out — but just to say hello to his friends, the doormen.

headline: Online Classes Fuel a Campus Debate
text: The announcement last month that Coursera, which offers free college classes online, had signed agreements with state universities enrolling more than a million students made it plain that such courses, virtually unheard-of two years ago, are now part of the higher education mainstream.

headline: Sizing Up Big Data, Broadening Beyond the Internet
text: In his young career, Jeffrey Hammerbacher has been a scout on the frontiers of the data economy.

headline: Web’s Reach Binds N.S.A. and Silicon Valley Leaders
text: WASHINGTON — When Max Kelly, the chief security officer for Facebook, left the social media company in 2010, he did not go to Google, Twitter or a similar Silicon Valley concern. Instead the man who was responsible for protecting the personal information of Facebook’s more than one billion users from outside attacks went to work for another giant institution that manages and analyzes large pools of data: the National Security Agency.

headline: Jury Selection Reaches Final Stages in Trayvon Martin Murder Case
text: SANFORD, Fla. — The mother whose 18-year-old “lives in a hoodie” was in. So was the young man who said he paid little attention to the story of the shooting but remembers first hearing about it while doing a one-arm pull-up at the gym.

headline: Oregon State Stays Alive
text: Oregon State beat Indiana, 1-0, in the losers’ bracket of the College World Series, staying alive and eliminating the Hoosiers. It was the first 1-0 game at the series since 1985. Matt Boyd threw a complete game four-hitter for the Beavers.

headline: Two G.O.P. Senators Are Close to a Deal on Border Security
text: WASHINGTON — Two Senate Republicans closed in on a deal regarding stronger border security on Wednesday evening with the bipartisan group of eight senators that drafted an overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws, hoping to find a resolution to an issue that for two weeks has dominated — and at times bedeviled — the immigration debate on the Senate floor.

headline: Sony Rebuffs New Call to Sell Entertainment Unit
text: TOKYO – Sony’s chief executive, Kazuo Hirai, reiterated on Thursday that the company’s music and movie businesses were not for sale, striking a cautious tone on a renewed push by the American activist investor Daniel S. Loeb to break up Sony’s sprawling empire. He added that the company’s board would continue to study the matter.

headline: Condoms Approved for Schools in Massachusetts
text: The Boston School Committee on Wednesday approved making condoms available in the district’s high schools. The new policy allows students to obtain condoms, and counseling, from school health centers or trained staff members, unless parents opt them out, and makes sexual education a required part of school health curricula. The district first made condoms available through health centers in some of its schools in the mid-1990s; in the past few years, a coalition of students and community leaders campaigned to broaden access to condoms and sexual health education in the district.

headline: How Immigration Reform Would Help the Economy
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Word of the Day | fictitious
text: fictitious •\fik-ˈti-shəs\• adjective

headline: With Goalies Shaky, Momentum Sways to Blackhawks
text: BOSTON — Losing their balance in the Stanley Cup finals, the Chicago Blackhawks righted themselves Wednesday night with a 6-5 overtime victory in a wild Game 4 that they almost frittered away.

headline: Credit Tightens in China as Central Bank Takes a Hard Line
text: HONG KONG — China’s financial system is in the throes of a cash squeeze as the government tries to restructure the economy and punish speculators, with interbank lending rates spiking on Thursday and bank-to-bank borrowing nearly stalled.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 10 P.M. (NBC) HANNIBAL The season ends as Hannibal (Mads Mikkelsen) turns on Will (Hugh Dancy, above right, with Mr. Mikkelsen) after Will arrives home without Abigail (Kacey Rohl). Jack (Laurence Fishburne) and the team find evidence that Will murdered her — and may actually be the Copy Cat Killer. Things get uglier as Will plots his escape and takes Hannibal back to Minnesota to clear his name.

headline: 27 Million People Said to Live in ‘Modern Slavery’
text: BEIJING — 7:37 p.m. | Updated On Monday, we wrote about human trafficking and forced labor — or modern slavery, as it’s often called — and said the United Nations defines it as a fast-growing problem.

headline: News Quiz | June 20, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Potentially Tragic Taper
text: I will be traveling today, so limited blogging (and yes, I’m still in Yurp, so “today” is Thursday). But I did want to weigh in briefly on the Fed’s latest, in which Bernanke confirmed that the Fed is getting significantly more hawkish — based on relatively optimistic forecasts.

headline: After 37 Years of Trying to Change People’s Sexual Orientation, Group Is to Disband
text: IRVINE, Calif. — For 37 years, Exodus International was the leading beacon of the “ex gay” movement, which maintained that gay men and lesbians could change their sexual orientation through prayer and psychotherapy.

headline: Deaths of Chinese Officials Under Detention in Corruption Cases Raise Concern
text: BEIJING — The reported cause of death was respiratory failure, but the images circulating over Chinese social media on Thursday — showing a man staring blankly from a hospital bed, his gaunt body covered with bruises and scabs — told a different story.

headline: Test Yourself | English, June 20, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “In London, All Hail the Suit.”

headline: Politicos and Whizzes: Where Are They Now?
text: The latest careers for strategists from Barack Obama’s 2012 campaign.

headline: Henri Cartier-Bresson: Living and Looking
text: The journalist and filmmaker Sheila Turner-Seed interviewed Henri Cartier-Bresson in his Paris studio in 1971 for a film-strip series on photographers that she produced for Scholastic. After her death in 1979 at the age of 42, that interview, along with interviews that Ms. Turner-Seed had conducted with Bruce Davidson, Cornell Capa, Lisette Model, W. Eugene Smith, Don McCullin and others, sat like a time capsule in the archives of the International Center of Photography in New York.

headline: Data You Can Believe In
text: Earlier this year, senior members of President Barack Obama’s campaign team took a trip to Las Vegas. Nevada holds a special place in Obama-wonk lore as the place where his monthslong strategy of defeating Hillary Clinton by slowly and surely amassing delegates emerged. But the operatives were not there in March for any political reason. They were there to make money — specifically to land what they hoped would be the first corporate client for their new advertising business, Analytics Media Group (A.M.G.). Its bland name obscures its relatively grand promise: to deliver to commercial advertisers some of the Obama campaign’s secret, technologically advanced formulas for reaching voters.

headline: The Risks of Inadequate Sleep
text: In the article “Cheating Ourselves of Sleep,” Jane Brody writes about the effects of inadequate sleep.

headline: British Banks to Raise an Extra $21 Billion in Capital
text: 5:35 a.m. | Updated

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 20
text: NEWS Pressed personally by Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany about the United States’ surveillance of foreigners’ phone and e-mail traffic, President Obama said Wednesday that terrorist threats in her country were among those foiled by such intelligence operations worldwide — a contention that Ms. Merkel seemed to confirm. Jackie Calmes reports from Berlin.

headline: On Nuclear Cuts, a Split Over Whether Senate Backing Is Needed
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry called Senator Bob Corker on Tuesday to discuss President Obama’s renewed drive for arms control. On that much, at least, the two agree. Exactly what was said, however, has quickly become a point of contention.

headline: Pollution in Singapore Hits Record Level
text: HONG KONG — As pollution in Singapore soared to record levels on Thursday, local officials pressed Indonesia to curtail the widespread burning of forests, which they say is causing the stubborn haze enveloping the city-state.

headline: The Early Word: Climactic
text: In Today’s Times:President Obama’s decision to sidestep Congress on climate change in the coming weeks by announcing new limits on carbon dioxide emissions for existing power plants will probably ignite a legal battle with Republicans and some industries, even though the plants are the “largest single source of global warming pollution in the country,” John M. Broder writes.

headline: The House That Jinnah Built
text: LONDON — Last year some friends and I visited Flagstaff House, the residence in Karachi of Pakistan’s founder, Muhammad Ali Jinnah, who championed progressive secular democracy. We made our way through the high-ceilinged rooms past dust-covered furniture, photographs and personal items like shoes. We were almost alone. We couldn’t sign the guest book, which was mostly blank, because the ink in the pen provided had dried up.

headline: J.W. Anderson’s Shared Wardrobe
text: LONDON — Whether the J.W. Anderson collection was about genderbending for this new millennium or not, the designer sent out a collection that seemed fresh. The initiative came not so much from the pants — big Oxford bags, pleated at the waist and puddling over the feet. The effect was rather in the tunic tops, cut on sparse, geometric lines, maybe sliced at an angle, baring shoulders or with flourishes at the neckline. There were no men in frills this season but a defiantly female halter top with a girlie floral pattern.

headline: The Brutal Truth: My Score as a Sales Manager
text: Editor’s note: Paul Downs is writing this week about his decision to hire a sales consultant. The series started with this post.

headline: Former Trader Appears in London Court on Libor Fraud Charges
text: LONDON – Tom A.W. Hayes, a former trader at UBS and Citigroup who has been charged with fraud tied to the manipulation of global benchmark interest rates, made his first appearance in a London court on Thursday.

headline: Daily Report: Deepening Ties Between N.S.A. and Silicon Valley
text: Increasingly deep connections between Silicon Valley and the National Security Agency reflect the degree to which they are now in the same business. Both hunt for ways to collect, analyze and exploit large pools of data about millions of Americans. The only difference is that the N.S.A. does it for intelligence, and Silicon Valley does it to make money, James Risen and Nick Wingfield report in The New York Times.

headline: Amartya Sen on Why India Trails China
text: The growth models of India and China are an important subject of contemporary debate. Will India catch up with China? Will its messy, multiparty, multiethnic democracy hobble its economic rise? Are sections of Indian population being tempted by authoritarian China’s faster economic growth? These are some of the most argued questions of our times.

headline: G.M. Releases 2014 Corvette Stingray Performance Numbers
text: General Motors has released performance specs for the 2014 Corvette Stingray, which it is calling “the most capable standard Corvette ever.” Now, we have some official numbers.

headline: Aspiring to Be Like Walt Whitman
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Markets Slump Over Fed Exit Plan and China Credit Squeeze
text: PARIS — Global markets tumbled on Thursday over concern about a credit crunch in China and uncertainty about the United States central bank’s plans for withdrawing the monetary stimulus upon which the American economy has become dependent.

headline: Wall Street Jitters
text: The Federal Reserve expects to start pulling back later this year from its economic stimulus efforts, the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Wednesday. Increasingly confident in the durability of economic growth, the central bank plans to gradually scale down its monthly purchases of Treasury securities and mortgage-backed bonds beginning later this year and ending when the unemployment rate reaches 7 percent, which may happen by the middle of next year, Mr. Bernanke said, Binyamin Appelbaum reports in The New York Times. After that, the central bank would take several more years to unwind the rest of its stimulus campaign.

headline: Protests in Brazil
text: Brazil struggles with a wave of popular unrest.

headline: Explaining The Times’s Coverage of Key Supreme Court Decisions
text: The Supreme Court will issue rulings sometime after 10 a.m. Eastern on Thursday on a few of the 14 remaining cases on its 2012-13 schedule. The court may — or may not — release decisions on one or more of its four most-watched decisions remaining, concerning affirmative action, the Voting Rights Act and same-sex marriage (the subject of two cases). We want to give readers an overview of The Times’s coverage if one of the major rulings does come down on Thursday.

headline: Thursday Reading: Smartphone Apps for the Connected Camper
text: Smartphone apps for the connected camper, bike-sharing comes to Aspen, making your online tracks harder to follow and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Times Apps Pay Model to Change
text: The New York Times Company said Thursday it would begin a new metered pay model for its mobile apps and charge readers for articles, as it does on its Web site.

headline: Are Blogs Outdated? The Times Eliminates Several, and Explains Why
text: As The Times continues to change – becoming more digital, becoming more global, looking for new ways to make money as print advertising declines – it frequently adds new features or puts more emphasis on established ones, like video.

headline: Regulator in New York Sets Tough Bank Fine
text: It took just $8.6 million for Japan’s largest bank to settle with federal regulators in Washington who accused it of routing tainted money through the United States.

headline: Stones Unturned
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Walking through the hills around Ramallah, where I have lived for many years, I often come upon archeological ruins and remnants: Byzantine tombs, Ottoman olive presses, pottery shards. They lie there, scattered among stone walls and olive trees, unmarked and unstudied.

headline: Chancellor Merkel Discovers the Internet
text: LONDON — Germany has been all atwitter since Chancellor Angela Merkel referred on Wednesday to the existence of a new and uncharted country — Neuland.

headline: Consumer Group Calls Chrysler’s Jeep Fix Inadequate
text: The group responsible for the investigation that led to Chrysler’s recall of about 2.5 million Jeeps for a fire hazard involving fuel tanks says the company’s remedy – adding a factory-built trailer hitch – won’t properly protect consumers.

headline: Ending Poverty by Giving the Poor Money
text: Can you alleviate poverty by just giving money to the poor?

headline: N.B.A. Gets Another Memorable Game 7
text: MIAMI — On the eve of the N.B.A. finals, the last of his 30-year tenure as commissioner, David Stern went full-bore Barnum, proclaiming the matchup between Miami and San Antonio as probably the most eagerly awaited championship clash he had presided over.

headline: David Wall, a Prince Among Dancers, Is Dead at 67
text: David Wall, who became the youngest principal dancer in the history of the Royal Ballet (as of 1966) and was ranked beside Rudolf Nureyev and Anthony Dowell in leading male roles of the 1960s and ’70s, died on Tuesday at his home in London. He was 67.

headline: When Fear Is a Barrier to Good Care
text: “Good luck; I told him you were on your way in,” one of the nurses said to me, not a little ruefully, before I walked into the young man’s hospital room. I had heard the stories and steadied myself before entering.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Men’s Journal: The cheese steak gets all the buzz in the City of Brotherly Love, but it’s the ubiquitous roast-pork sandwich (slow-cooked, with garlic-drenched spinach and provolone) that truly vies for the souls of Philadelphians. – Glenn Collins

headline: Sweeping Protests in Brazil Pull In an Array of Grievances
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Just a few weeks ago, Mayara Vivian felt pretty good when a few hundred people showed up for a protest she helped organize to deride the government over a proposed bus fare increase. She had been trying to prod Brazilians into the streets since 2005, when she was only 15, and by now she thought she knew what to expect.

headline: Dan Brown: By the Book
text: The author of “The Da Vinci Code” and, most recently, “Inferno” made “the mistake” of reading “The Exorcist” at age 15: “It was the first and last horror book I’ve ever opened.”

headline: The Night the Hockey Nets Opened
text: It was, as NBC’s voice-of-hockey Mike Emrick likes to call it, “fire wagon hockey.” If you saw the score of Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals and thought it was a typo, you were not alone. Yes, there were 11 goals. There were 90 shots on goal. And yes, it was the kind of freewheeling, back-and-forth play that was banned from the N.H.L. in the mid-90s when it was decreed that all games, particularly in the playoffs, must resemble the battle scene from “Braveheart.” The Boston Bruins and the Chicago Blackhawks pitched all that in the Charles River and decided this game would be a race to six goals. The Blackhawks won. In overtime. Naturally.

headline: New Ways to Get Around Salt Lake City
text: A handful of new transportation options make it easier to get around the Utah capital without a car. This spring Salt Lake City opened the TRAX Green Line, a light rail route linking the airport and downtown. The six-mile ride costs $2.50 one way and, with the exception of overnight hours, runs every 15 minutes on weekdays and 20 minutes on weekends.

headline: Grids and Gardens
text: A look at the work of Jennifer Bartlett, who is having her first American museum retrospective.

headline: Disney Shows in Development
text: In addition to “The Jungle Book,” Disney Theatrical Group has several other titles in development — some just ideas and concepts, some with scripts and scores under way. Only one, the new musical “Aladdin,” has been confirmed for Broadway, set to open next spring at the New Amsterdam Theater after a tryout run in Toronto. A spokesman for Disney declined to comment on the projects, but a rundown was compiled from theater artists and executives with knowledge of the plans, who all spoke on condition of anonymity because the projects — other than “Aladdin” and “The Jungle Book” — are considered confidential.

headline: ‘Jungle Book’ Goes Onstage
text: A look at rehearsals for the new stage adaptation of the 1967 animated film.

headline: Organizing an Organizer’s Life
text: Jennifer Bartlett likes to pose questions, then follow them to logical — or occasionally illogical — conclusions.

headline: Cutting Through a Cultural Thicket
text: CHICAGO — The conductor sat cross-legged on the floor, but this was not a rehearsal break. Instead, Doug Peck, the music director and orchestrator for the Goodman Theater production of “The Jungle Book,” was leading an 11-piece band through a sinuous show tune while pumping a harmonium from the center of a large Persian rug.

headline: Thousands Are Stranded in Northern India Flooding
text: NEW DELHI— The death toll from flash floods in northern India rose to more than 150 on Thursday, with 50,000 Hindu pilgrims still stranded across the mountainous state of Uttarakhand.

headline: Justices Say U.S. Cannot Impose Antiprostitution Condition on AIDS Grants
text: WASHINGTON — Groups receiving federal financing to combat AIDS abroad may not be required to adopt policies opposing prostitution, the Supreme Court ruled on Thursday.

headline: Border Deal by 2 in G.O.P. Lifts Chances of Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The prospects for Senate approval of a broad overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws improved on Thursday after two Senate Republicans worked out a deal on a plan to strengthen border security with the bipartisan group of eight senators that drafted the original bill, raising hopes that the new agreement could build Republican support for the immigration legislation.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Leather Shines at Resort
text: Rochas, Jason Wu and Suno mixed summery prints, in silk and cotton fabrics, with glossy patent leather pieces — a delightfully unpredictable pairing.

headline: 36 Hours in Vancouver, British Columbia
text: Between the jaw-dropping confluence of mountains and sea, some of the best ethnic food in North America and public transit bliss courtesy of the Canada Line and SkyTrain, Vancouver is much more than an erstwhile Olympic site, or a place to stop over on your way to some other destination. Where else can you find an international brand of exoticism that rivals Hong Kong, Nordic-style order and a limitless array of shops, restaurants and top-notch accommodations? An abundance of outdoor options — whether it is hiking or biking in Stanley Park, kayaking in False Creek or skiing on nearby Grouse Mountain — only adds to the appeal. The city doesn’t take its natural gifts for granted; in recent years it has become so eco-friendly that some stores don’t even offer plastic bags. With its multitude of immigrant communities and northwest Canadian culture of extreme friendliness, Vancouver feels just different enough to be intriguingly foreign but familiar enough to be easily conquered in a weekend.

headline: Vancouver Views
text: From brunch to boats, seafood to cycling, spend 36 Hours in the Canadian city.

headline: At the Taliban Office, Waiting for Progress on Talks
text: DOHA, Qatar — The start of peace talks between the United States and the Taliban was delayed on Thursday, with no clear picture of when — or even if — they will restart.

headline: Home-Cooked Challenge: What’s for Breakfast?
text: First off, let me just say that a wiser person than I would not have paired the “Home-Cooked Challege” with the first week of what I should have dubbed the “free-range summer challenge,” the one in which my four children, on the weeks they don’t have camp, roam the house, trails and fields while I’m working for three days a week, playing with one another, the animals and the neighbors. It’s not that this isn’t going well. It’s that a) I also added the “I Don’t Have an Office Anymore” challenge, in which we remodel the part of the house with the office in it and I work in the kitchen and b) my visible presence serves as a constant reminder that if only I would, I could drive them to the end of the driveway with all their stuff for their lemonade sale, read the words one is struggling with in the book she’s reading (every other one) and c) when three children coated head to toe with mud appear in your doorway with the plan of heading upstairs to clean up, I challenge you not to take a minute to get them towels and redirect them to the hose — and so on.

headline: A Technical Dictionary That Fits the Definition of User-Friendly
text: Everybody talks about how Amazon has killed the American bookstore, how Facebook is isolating our children, how tiny changes in Google’s search algorithms can destroy small businesses. But Wikipedia has left some damage in its wake, too.

headline: Extremism Rises Among Myanmar Buddhists
text: TAUNGGYI, Myanmar — After a ritual prayer atoning for past sins, Ashin Wirathu, a Buddhist monk with a rock-star following in Myanmar, sat before an overflowing crowd of thousands of devotees and launched into a rant against what he called “the enemy” — the country’s Muslim minority.

headline: Home Depot Outflips Private Equity
text: Home Depot has outflipped and outstripped private equity. A buyout consortium led by the Carlyle Group acquired Home Depot’s wholesale arm for $8.5 billion just before the real estate bubble popped. On paper, the firms should recoup their HD Supply investment and then some in an upcoming initial public offering. But Home Depot fared even better.

headline: A Lifeline for Minorities, Catholic Schools Retrench
text: Sonia Sotomayor lives in Washington, but she has never forgotten her roots in the Bronx. On a drizzly March afternoon, she returned to Blessed Sacrament School, where she began her celebrated, if improbable, journey from her South Bronx childhood to the Supreme Court. But instead of a joyous reunion, it was more of a valedictory for her and the children — the school is closing for good.

headline: A Search for Harmony
text: Can choral singing really help people age well? Maintain their health and their crucial social connections? Perhaps find their way through grief and loss?

headline: The Lunchtime Lounge
text: Listen to a sample of Coffitivity’s ambient noise.

headline: Justices Support Corporate Arbitration
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday reinforced the ability of corporations to write their own rules for resolving disputes with customers, finding that a group of merchants were bound by an arbitration agreement with American Express even if the terms made it prohibitively expensive to pursue some types of claims against the company.

headline: Frank Langella to Play ‘King Lear’ at Brooklyn Academy
text: Frank Langella will follow in the trans-Atlantic footsteps of Ian McKellen and Derek Jacobi, playing the title role in “King Lear” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in a production imported from Britain.

headline: Market Jitters Explained
text: Long-term interest rates are going up in the United States and China, setting off fears that the global economic recovery could be put in jeopardy.

text: Long-term interest rates are going up in the United States and China, setting off fears that the global economic recovery could be put in jeopardy.

headline: Jon Oringer of Shutterstock, on the Power of the Hackathon
text: This interview with Jon Oringer, chief executive of Shutterstock, a stock photography company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: The Gun Report: June 20, 2013
text: Look at our first item today. It is nearly unfathomable: two people having a domestic dispute fire a gun and kill their 6-month-old daughter. I know I sound like a broken record, but this is the kind of gun violence that we could—and should—be working hardest to prevent. It does not require new legislation—although legislation that called for gun owners to keep their guns locked in their homes would certainly be welcome. It does not require we spend large sums of money. What it requires is a cultural change, in which gun owners take their responsibility more seriously. Why is this so hard?

headline: Image of the Day: June 20
text: The Indian rupee fell to a record low of 59.93 against the U.S. dollar on Thursday.

headline: Linking Loyalty Programs
text: Major hotel chains like Marriott offer frequent guest club members a large number of hotels where they can spend their loyalty points. Now two smaller hotel groups are linking their loyalty programs, offering consumers more places to use their virtual currency. Hyatt Hotels Corporation, which operates 450 hotels worldwide (Park Hyatt in the Maldives, below), and MGM Resorts International, which has 12 hotels in Las Vegas, will link loyalty programs starting this month. The Hyatt Gold Passport and M Life programs can join.

text: The common wisdom is that the Mets’ decline began when Carlos Beltran took that called third strike to conclude the 2006 National League Championship Series.

headline: A $1.6 Million Grant for the American Folk Art Museum
text: The American Folk Art Museum has received a $1.6 million grant from the Henry Luce Foundation for a national traveling exhibition of masterworks from its collection, the museum announced Thursday.

headline: Icahn, Outspoken Investor, Takes to Twitter
text: Carl C. Icahn, an outspoken investor in the old-school Wall Street style, has a new, and decidedly high-tech, megaphone.

headline: CNN Media Critic Going to Fox
text: Fox News said on Thursday that it had hired Howard Kurtz, the reporter who for 15 years has hosted the Sunday morning media criticism program “Reliable Sources” on a rival network, CNN.

headline: Fermi Laboratory Names New Director
text: The Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, the flagship of American particle physics, named a new director on Thursday: He is Nigel Lockyer, 60, currently the director of Canada’s national laboratory for particle and nuclear physics, or Triumf, and a professor at the University of British Columbia, in Vancouver. Dr. Lockyer, who was born in Scotland and raised in Canada, worked as a particle physicist working at Fermilab studying quarks. Dr. Lockyer will take office on Sept. 3. He is replacing Pier Oddone, who has held the post since 2005 and is retiring on July 1. Jack Anderson, Fermilab’s chief operating officer, will serve as interim director until Dr. Lockyer arrives.

headline: At Bar ‘21,’ Rubbing Elbows With History
text: One of the most prominent accounts of goings-on at the “21” Club bar in H. Peter Kriendler’s book about that storied restaurant involves the novelist John O’Hara, who, he writes, “was bad at handling his liquor.”

text: What began last year on the fringes of Burmese society has grown into a nationwide fundamentalist movement.

headline: Surf Car Beauty Is in the Eye of the Board Holder
text: Surfing is a simple pastime. All you need (aside from the far-off storms that send good waves to whichever shore you happen to be standing vigil upon) is a surfboard, trunks or a wetsuit and at the very least a beat-up car to get you from one surf spot to another as the conditions change.

headline: Perelman Company Reaches Another Settlement

headline: ‘Pandora’s Promise’ Director and Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., Debate Nuclear Options
text: I promised to alert folks when video was available of the heated discussion I moderated recently between Robert Stone, the director of “Pandora’s Promise,” the new film in which five former foes of nuclear energy defend this power source, and Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., the Pace University law professor and environmental firebrand. Here it is*, courtesy of the Jacob Burns Film Center, which hosted the debate after a screening.

text: In a new ad, Senator Joe Manchin III, a West Virginia Democrat who has been supportive of gun rights, challenges the National Rifle Association's opposition to background checks.

headline: For Almodóvar, Comedy Needs Color
text: In the latest film from the Spanish director Pedro Almodóvar, “I’m So Excited!,” crisis equals opportunity. The problem that kick-starts the narrative — a serious technical failure on a commercial flight to Mexico City — lets him build comic moments out of chaos and revisit some of the outrageous humor he used in 1980s comedies like “Labyrinth of Passion” and “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown.” It also gives him the chance to use his signature vibrant, colorful sets to complement his broad comedy.

headline: For Restaurants, Composting Is a Welcome but Complex Task
text: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s administration revealed this week that he was rolling out a plan to make New York City residents separate their food scraps for composting, chefs and restaurateurs with an interest in sustainability welcomed the news. Composting can help the city manage its huge trash output, and a growing number of restaurants already separate their scraps for organic-waste pickup.

headline: The Dangers and Benefits of Taking a Partner
text: I’ve worked with both sole-owner companies and partnerships. There are a lot of obvious advantages to having one person in charge, one person who makes the big decisions. And of course there are many advantages to sharing the burdens of ownership with a partner. But partnership is a lot like marriage: It can go very wrong.

headline: 3-D Map of Human Brain Gives Unprecedented Detail
text: Researchers in Germany and Canada have produced a new map of the human brain — not the sort that shows every brain cell and its every connection or the kind that shows broad patterns of activity in brain regions, but a work of classic anatomy, done with high technology, that shows a three-dimensional reconstruction of a human brain in unprecedented detail.

headline: Director of Ashmolean Museum at Oxford to Step Down
text: LONDON — Christopher Brown, director of the Ashmolean Museum of Art and Archaeology at the University of Oxford for the last 16 years, announced his retirement on Wednesday. He plans to leave the museum at the end of September 2014, take a year off, then become a research professor at Oxford for three years where he will focus on the study of van Dyck and Rembrandt. In 2016, the Ashmolean will present a Rembrandt exhibition organized by him.

headline: In the Navy: Rape
text: The Navy announced on Wednesday that it had finally charged three football players at the Naval Academy with rape, sexual assault and lying to investigators after they allegedly gang-raped a female midshipman while she was passed out from drinking. The three midshipmen will face court martial proceedings and, if they are tried and convicted, could be sent to prison for 20 years or more. We’ll see how that goes.

headline: Group Keeps Long-Distance Watch on Iran and Possible Sanction Violations
text: Inside a nondescript Midtown Manhattan office, a couple of computer analysts spend their days peering intently at large screens of satellite mapping surveillance data, watching dozens of little blips moving like snails. Each one, they said, represents a ship controlled by Iran or its trading partners.

headline: Astor’s Son Remains Free at Least Another Day

headline: Something for Every Taste in Next Glimmerglass Season
text: As it often does, the feisty and inventive Glimmerglass Opera, in Cooperstown, N.Y., will offer a broad range of styles within a compact program during its 2014 season next summer. Its schedule, which the company announced Thursday, includes four works including a staging of “Carousel,” the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical theater classic, which is part of the program of bringing musicals into the opera repertory that Francesca Zambello undertook when she became the company’s artistic and general director in 2010.

headline: New York City Ballet Announces Fashion-Focused Fall Gala
text: New York City Ballet will hold its annual fall gala celebrating dance and fashion on Sept. 19, featuring three world premieres, the company announced Thursday. Participants this year include the choreographers Benjamin Millepied, working with the Dutch designer Iris van Herpen; Justin Peck, whose new ballet will showcase costumes by Prabal Gurung; and Angelin Preljocaj, working with Olivier Theyskens.

text: WASHINGTON — The surprise defeat of the farm bill in the House on Thursday underscored the ideological divide between the more conservative, antispending Republican lawmakers and their leadership, who failed to garner sufficient votes from their caucus as well as from Democrats.

headline: Living With Cancer: Seeking Intimacy
text: A week or so after a procedure, I found a sticker on my body. Not a Disney sticker or a Dora the Explorer sticker, put there maybe by a godchild or nephew, but a 1 1/4-by-1-inch white rectangle with a steel nipple at the center.

headline: More Young People Ditching Credit Cards
A College Where the Exams Are Terrifying
text: What are little boy monsters made of? In Pixar’s “Monsters University,” they aren’t made of slugs, snails and puppy dog tails — they’re monstrous versions of those ingredients, only cuter, fuzzier, brighter, wilder and woollier. A stomping, creeping menagerie, they embody a Popsicle-hued rainbow of seeming diversity, from their googly eyes to their hydra heads and sticky tentacles. In this passable prequel to Pixar’s magical 2001 film “Monsters, Inc.,” anything and every being seems possible. Or so believes the young Mike Wazowski (voiced by Noah Johnson and Billy Crystal), who thinks that if he studies hard enough, he too can become one of his world’s Scarers.

headline: Climbing Everest — On Your Phone
text: Though the numbers of those attempting to summit Mount Everest have reached levels alarming to some, the vast majority of us have had to make do with second-hand accounts. Now there’s a high-tech virtual option: the new Mount Everest 3D app offers tours of the world’s highest peak from any angle.

headline: Brooklyn Pub Surrenders to Human Rights Commission
text: The Welsh pub in Brooklyn that got in trouble for a want ad offering British applicants a leg up has given up its fight against the New York City Human Rights Commission.

headline: In-Laws and Outlaws
text: My husband and I are in our late 50s and recently wed. We met long after our separations from our previous spouses. My family loves him, and his likes me — except for a sister-in-law (who is married to his brother). She refuses to acknowledge my presence or speak to me. It can’t be about me because she doesn’t really know me. I try to make the best of it at family functions, but it’s still weird and hurtful. Recently, she came to our home for dinner. She brushed past me when she came in and ignored my greeting. Any advice?

headline: Rethinking the Highway
text: Upgrades to the corridor between Denver and Boulder, Colo., will make it the first in the nation to offer a full array of options to encourage less driving.

headline: Jean-Louis Scherrer, French Fashion Designer of the ’60s, Dies at 78
text: Jean-Louis Scherrer, the couturier whose luxurious dresses and rich embellishments were symbolic of a fruitful period of French fashion in the 1960s, when designers like Yves Saint Laurent and André Courrèges were establishing their own houses, died on Wednesday at his home in Paris. He was 78.

headline: Brazil’s Protesters, in Their Own Words
text: As my colleague Simon Romero reports, Brazil is braced for another round of protests on Thursday, with demonstrations planned for dozens of cities, even after the authorities retreated from plans to raise bus fares across the country in the face of massive street protests.

headline: Highway Expansion Encourages More Than Just Driving
text: DENVER — Driving to Boulder from here offers a spectacular mountain panorama, but the nearer view is anything but impressive. U.S. 36, the unlovely highway that connects the cities, is crowded and often painfully slow, dotted with malls, fast-food restaurants and other commercial flotsam.

headline: Celebrating Scandinavian Culture
text: If you’re like the Miser, you tend to associate Scandinavia with fording frigid fjords and skiing over snowy white expanses, not cavorting in warm breezes on sun-splashed summer days. This weekend, however, several free events presented by Scandinavian expats are set to upset those expectations.

headline: Berdych Hopes to Rekindle His Wimbledon Magic
text: STOKE PARK, England — Tomas Berdych of the Czech Republic may be among the select few to have experienced the thrill of walking onto Centre Court for a Wimbledon final, but he is taking nothing for granted after crashing out in the first round in straight sets last year to Ernests Gulbis.

headline: The Workout Unplugged
text: Vintage exercise machines have recently become the padded shoulders of the workout world: swept aside for a fresher look. The so-called functional-fitness trend, with workouts devised to help people perform daily activities like lifting, bending and climbing stairs, are relegating machines like leg presses and biceps curlers to second-class status on the gym floor.

headline: How Cynthia Rowley Packs for Trips
text: The designer Cynthia Rowley travels so often with her husband and two young daughters that she has packing — particularly the quick, all-in-one-bag kind — down pat. “I have a checklist I keep at home,” she said. It’s inside her medicine closet along with toiletries, her family’s passports and a wad of cash. “It’s like I’m on the lam.”

headline: The Lubitsch Touch, in Song
text: Released in October 1934, “The Merry Widow” brought to an end the spirited series of musicals — operettas, really — that Ernst Lubitsch had begun with his first sound film, “The Love Parade,” in 1929, and continued through “Monte Carlo” (1930), “The Smiling Lieutenant” (1931) and “One Hour With You” (1932). (All four of those films are available in an essential box set from Criterion’s Eclipse line, “Lubitsch Musicals.”)

text: To the Editor:

headline: Another Croissant Incarnation
text: Scorn might be overstating it a bit. But that’s a hint of what Nathalie Dessyn was feeling when she was unable to buy one of Dominique Ansel’s iconic Cronuts even though she had gotten to the SoHo bakery as early as she could.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Explorers Club'
text: From left, David Furr, Carson Elrod and Jennifer Westfeldt in a scene from Nell Benjamin’s play at City Center.

headline: Rules to Ban Menthol and Slim Cigarettes Divide Europeans
text: LONDON — New rules to be discussed by European Union ministers on Friday would ban menthol and slim cigarettes, a move intended to improve the health of Europeans but one that has divided it broadly along cold war lines.

headline: I Believe in Family Dinner. We Just Don’t Achieve It Very Often.
text: I’ve just published a book about family food, but in my house, regular family dinner doesn’t exist. In fact, our family dinner has never looked the way it’s supposed to.

headline: Nogales Is Not Falluja
text: The Times is reporting that a deal has been struck to keep comprehensive immigration reform moving forward in the Senate, by addressing Republican objections that the bill is too weak on border enforcement.

headline: Supporters of Immigration Bill Offer Amendment Focused on Women
text: Saying the immigration overhaul bill now before the Senate would discriminate against future immigrants who are women, 13 female senators have introduced an amendment that would make it easier for foreign women to come to the United States under a new merit system in the legislation.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The Mesmerized Stare, and Google’s Weird Questions
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Taking a Seat at Soccer’s Table, but Cautiously
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Two months ago, in a ballroom at the Westin Playa Bonita in Panama City, Sunil Gulati became one of the 25 most powerful people in world soccer. So as he sat in a hotel restaurant here Tuesday morning, why was it hard to know whether to offer congratulations or condolences?

headline: Accidents and Accountability
text: One miscalculation leads to another in “Three Worlds,” Catherine Corsini’s severe, anxiety-producing French drama about the chain of consequences after a hit-and-run accident. The 16th feature by Ms. Corsini, the film is a rigorous moral inquiry that puts its characters — but especially its ambitious young protagonist, Al (Raphaël Personnaz) — through the wringer.

headline: Blazing a Path Out of the Shadows
text: The beef is nearly black and as chewy as toffee. It looks practically torn by hand, hunks of it scattered among the shriveled yellow-white skins of once-green chile peppers that have been blanched and sun-dried until leached of color. They still burn.

headline: Hunan Manor
text: Inside the Chinese restaurant just south of Grand Central Terminal.

headline: Cross Over
text: Colum McCann’s new novel, “TransAtlantic,” lifts off with a roar. The year is 1919, just after the end of the First World War: “It was that time of the century when the idea of a gentleman had almost become myth.” The war, McCann writes, had “concussed the world.” And yet here are two gentlemen, Jack Alcock and Arthur Brown, ready to set off in a modified bomber, a Vickers Vimy — “It looked as if it had borrowed its design from a form of dragonfly” — to fly the Atlantic, from St. John’s in Newfoundland all the way to Ireland. If they succeed, they’ll make history. They will make a brand-new world.

headline: Show Some Spine
text: A plague of women’s backs is upon us in the book cover world. We’ve recently seen “Finding Casey,” by Jo-Ann Mapson; “The Unruly Passion of Eugénie R.,” by Carole DeSanti; and “The Headmaster’s Wager,” by Vincent Lam, all showcasing a nape-and-shoulder combo on the jacket. “The Pretty One,” by Lucinda Rosenfeld, features three women with their backs turned; “The Smart One,” by Jennifer Close, has its heroine turned away, undoing her wrap dress; and a bride stands facing a beach on “Beautiful Day,” by Elin Hilderbrand.

headline: New York City’s Unemployment Rate Dips Slightly
text: New York City’s unemployment rate dipped to 8.3 percent in May, its lowest level in more than four years, despite a sharp drop in the pace of hiring, the State Labor Department reported on Thursday.

headline: Thrilled to Death
text: The usual portal for wickedness and darkness in modern American horror fiction is youthful sexuality. Surging hormones summon demons. That’s why big-breasted baby sitters, once they’ve tucked the kids in and phoned their boyfriends to tell them to sneak over, had best keep an eye out for slashers on the stairs. That’s why campgrounds full of teenagers in shorts so often lure scar-faced intruders from the woods. Who are these monsters? The thwarted and the spurned, their psyches warped by repression and rejection. They feed for a while on others’ erotic vitality but are ultimately defeated by these same energies in the form of some brave lass or lad who drives a stake or fires a lucky shot, restoring health and order to the world.

headline: Tribune Falls Afoul of Its Own Tax Strategy
text: It was perhaps the cleverest corporate tax strategy ever devised: no matter how much money the company made, neither it nor its shareholders would ever owe a penny in federal income taxes.

headline: Facebook Is Betting Longer Videos Are Better
text: What’s the perfect length for video shot and shared via a mobile phone — 15 seconds or six?

headline: Why Bernanke’s Remarks Set off Global, Contagious Market Fears
text: NEW YORK — It was a one-two punch. On Wednesday, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, testified that the Fed could foresee the day it would stop buying up U.S. bonds to goose the economy. The next day saw reports that Chinese banks had become reluctant to lend to one another, causing interest rates in the interbank market to spike to punishingly high levels.

headline: Ross Stores Fined in Sales of Defective Clothing
text: WASHINGTON — The Consumer Product Safety Commission said on Thursday that a leading discount department store had agreed to pay a $3.9 million fine for failing to report that it continued to sell defective children’s clothing after the agency warned that the clothes could cause injuries or deaths.

headline: Solid in the Playoffs, Boston’s Rask Shows a Sudden Vulnerability
text: BOSTON — Minutes after scoring the overtime goal that won Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals, Chicago defenseman Brent Seabrook uttered nine words that might be greeted with skull-imploding bewilderment in New York and Pittsburgh.

headline: Three Venerable Names From the Art World: Chuck Close, James Turrell and Polaroid Film
text: A behind-the-scenes look at Chuck Close’s use of almost-extinct Polaroid film to photograph James Turrell for our cover.

headline: Obama to Pick Bush-Era Justice Dept. Official to Lead F.B.I.
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday plans to announce the nomination of James B. Comey, a senior Justice Department official under President George W. Bush, to become the next director of the F.B.I., according to White House officials.

headline: Palestinian Premier Submits Resignation After Just Two Weeks in Office
text: JERUSALEM — The newly appointed prime minister of the Palestinian Authority, Rami Hamdallah, submitted his resignation on Thursday after only two weeks in office, a signal of continuing internal political disarray amid the already complicated American efforts to restart the peace process with Israel.

headline: National Parks Raise Guard Against Virus
text: DENVER — David Breskin was in line for the breakfast buffet at the Old Faithful Inn at Yellowstone National Park this week when he noticed something unusual: hotel employees in gloves were handing out plates and serving eggs and French toast.

headline: A Director Whose World Is the Stage
text: “Jack be nimble, Jack be quick, Jack jump over the candlestick.” So runs the nursery rhyme whose opening Jack O’Brien has made the title of his exuberant theatrical memoir, and it’s even apter than he may realize. It’s not just that a director as successful as he has had to be nimble and quick-witted to thrive in a precarious profession.

headline: Albanese Takes Mayoral Bid Underground
text: “Hi,” Sal Albanese said the other day, greeting a commuter on the Seventh Avenue line. “I’m Sal Albanese.”

headline: High-Mileage Alterations
text: Walking through his gutted Brooklyn brownstone row house, Arthur Michel points out the stacks of original woodwork that he has set aside and plans to reuse — fireplace mantels, pocket doors and shutters. The 1887 house is in the Park Slope Historic District. Yet the New York Landmarks Preservation Commission was not concerned with goings-on inside, only with what Mr. Michel planned to do with the front windows and exterior ironwork.

headline: Bloomberg Charity to Underwrite Mobile Guides for Museums
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s company, Bloomberg LP, has long provided financial support to museums to help underwrite audio guides.

headline: Devoted To Choir, In Life And Death
text: To gag or to weep, that is the question. You may do both while watching “Unfinished Song,” a shamelessly sentimental, manipulative comic tear-jerker about a British chorus, the OAPz (for Old-Age Pensioners); a grumpy old man; and his saintly wife.

headline: A Sugar Baron’s Scattered Art Collection
text: The 19th-century sugar tycoon William Hood Stewart ran a plantation in Cuba with thousands of acres and hundreds of slaves. Stewart invested the profits partly in European paintings.

headline: Loan Modifications, Proactively
text: Homeowners who have fallen behind on their mortgage payments should check their mail carefully in coming weeks. Lenders will be offering loan modifications without even being asked.

headline: Oracle to Leave Nasdaq for the Big Board
text: Oracle, one of the most prominent technology companies listed on the Nasdaq, is defecting to a rival exchange.

headline: Fourth Grader Disappears; Exotic Quest Ensues
text: “Bureau of Missing Persons,” a new play by Lila Rose Kaplan, is sprinkled with bits of absurdity and magical realism and other charms. But the whimsical frills ultimately do not make up for the underwritten characters, who remain disconnected from one another and ultimately from the audience too.

headline: James Gandolfini: Famous for TV, Marvelous in Movies
text: Updated, Sept. 13, 2013

headline: Disabilities and Drama in an Irreverent Mix
text: In a waiting room full of actors, a handsome guy recognizes an attractive woman. In Neil LaBute’s mini-drama “Call Back,” Brad (Jonathan Todd Ross) knows he has met Denise (Mary Theresa Archbold) before, but can’t remember where — or her name. It turns out that they shared a lot more than a casual conversation.

headline: ‘The ABC of It’
text: An exhibit exploring the world of children’s literature opens Friday at the New York Public Library.

headline: After French Loss, Djokovic Turns Focus to Wimbledon
text: STOKE PARK, England – Novak Djokovic is hoping to move on from his difficult loss to Rafael Nadal in the French Open semifinals two weeks ago.

headline: Questions of Identity, Images of Crisis
text: “I, YOU, WE,” the Whitney’s latest collection show and the last one for the Breuer building before the museum decamps to the meatpacking district, makes a useful prequel to the New Museum’s recent exhibition “NYC 1993: Experimental Jet Set, Trash and No Star.” Everything here dates from the 1980s and early ’90s, otherwise known as the era of identity politics. And this show is unusually, almost unfashionably, forthright about those politics, foregrounding them with a string of pronouns.

headline: The Woman at Jesus’ Side, and in His Bed
text: SAN FRANCISCO — At the end of the central scene in the first act of the composer Mark Adamo’s ambitious new opera “The Gospel of Mary Magdalene,” which had its premiere here on Wednesday night at the San Francisco Opera, Mary takes Jesus, called Yeshua in this work, to bed.

headline: Finding Meaning in the Mundane
text: LONDON — Gary Hume’s paintings don’t give much away. When he depicts a person, it is often little more than an outline; a plant is only a shape rendered in rich colors and varied textures. It’s as if he wants viewers to create their own narrative. Yet walking through the galleries at Tate Britain, where a midcareer survey of his paintings recently opened, Mr. Hume, 51, isn’t nearly as mysterious as his work suggests.

headline: Bedtime With Puritans and Wild Things
text: The great green room and the purple crayon are here; so are the wild things and the poky puppy, Charlotte’s web and Alice’s wonderland, the very hungry caterpillar and the stinky cheese man. It is a reunion of creatures, characters and creations, gathered from memories of childhood and parenthood, and celebrated in “The ABC of It: Why Children’s Books Matter,” a remarkably rich new exhibition at the New York Public Library.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Pakistan, Singapore, Iraq and Russia.

headline: Charlotte Moorman Performs the Cello
text: The French conceptual artist Jean Dupuy captures the cellist in performance at 405 East 13 Street. Moorman is wearing a mask of Pablo Casals.

headline: Alice Munro Says She Is Retiring
text: Alice Munro, right, the short story writer, is retiring from the writing life, she told an interviewer in Canada. Ms. Munro, 81, had just accepted the Trillium Book Award for her latest collection, “Dear Life,” when she told Mark Medley, an editor from The National Post: “I’m probably not going to write anymore. And, so, it’s nice to go out with a bang.” Asked if “you really think this is it for you,” she responded, “Oh yes.” Told that her fans would be disappointed, she said: “Well, tell them to go read the old ones over again. There’s lots of them.” Ms. Munro, an Ontario native who is considered a master of the short story, won the Man Booker International Prize in 2009. In her review of “Dear Life” in The New York Times in December, Michiko Kakutani wrote that Ms. Munro “creates tales that have the scope and amplitude of novels: whole lives are condensed into a handful of pages, the progress of love is charted over the years as passion gives way to restlessness or deeper commitment or something more ambiguous.”

headline: A Brief History of a Legendary New York Art Building
text: It didn’t look like much, but the blocklong building at 404 East 14th Street in New York’s East Village was one of the most vibrant artistic hubs in the city during the 1960s. A former button factory, it offered enormous lofts (and $300 rent) that energized its residents to experiment on a larger scale — and host giddy bacchanalias as well. A new exhibit at Tibor de Nagy Gallery brings together the paintings, sculpture, photographs, films, correspondence and poetry of its famous inhabitants, from Claes Oldenburg to Allen Ginsberg. Here, a few of their memories about the building’s glory days.

headline: When My Music Was Your Music
text: The sound of dial-up connections may be quaint in Alex Winter’s “Downloaded,” but not the issues in the film, the latest in VH1’s enlightening series of Rock Docs. In tracing the rapid rise and gradual emasculation of Napster, the peer-to-peer file-sharing service that flourished in the 1990s, “Downloaded” tells a fascinating story about how college students harnessed the Internet to enable people to trade favorite songs, and how a blindsided music industry, ignorant of the Web’s potential, effectively shut them down.

headline: Always Growing, and Open to Change
text: About 20 men and women assembled in a ballet studio in Chinatown on a recent Monday evening to rehearse a sequence of austere and meticulously choreographed movements in silence. Peering over a piece of paper covered in tiny handwriting, Jamie Benson, a choreographer leading this rehearsal of the Shakedown Dance Collective, called out instructions while the group flowed through a series of arm movements, hand gestures, dips and bends.

headline: Iron Supplements May Reduce Pregnancy Risks
text: A large review of studies concludes that taking iron supplements during pregnancy reduces the risk for maternal anemia and for having a baby with low birth weight.

headline: The Timid Guy With the Slasher Knife
text: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Comedy Listings for June 21-27
text: Comedy

headline: First a Bombing, Then a Truth That’s Elusive
text: “The Attack” opens with the image of a man and woman embracing, the world blurred behind them. Her face to the camera, the woman cries as they hold each other, but it’s unclear whether he can see her tears. Her unexplained weeping and the ill-defined backdrop make an apt start for this intelligent, involving movie that’s by turns a murder mystery and a politically charged argument about contemporary Palestinian identity. That it’s also about a troubled marriage becomes evident when the man, a successful Palestinian surgeon living and working in Tel Aviv, is awoken one night and discovers that both his wife and his safe, cosseted world have disappeared after a suicide bombing.

headline: A Young Couple Take a Bite of Southern Noir
text: Opens on Friday nationwide.

headline: Movie Listings for June 21-27
text: Movies

headline: It’s Definitely Not ‘Sesame Street’
text: Anna Chlumsky, who is doing great work in the sly HBO series “Veep,” is in the cast of “Bert and Arnie’s Guide to Friendship,” but that doesn’t make this utterly humor-free comedy remotely watchable.

headline: How Injustice Infects Democracy
text: Opens on Friday in Brooklyn.

headline: Rosneft to Send $60 Billion Worth of Oil to China
text: The Russian state oil company, Rosneft, intends to sign a major contract to supply China with more than $60 billion of crude oil, a deal that could signal a small shift away from Western Europe toward Asia.

headline: Follow the Leader; He’s Deep in the Pack
text: Leadership in jazz isn’t always as clear-cut as it seems. An ensemble discipline, it often involves hierarchies as a matter of course, but the business of directing energy or driving a narrative can be anybody’s game. That’s worth keeping in mind whenever the conversation turns to the saxophonist Mark Turner, who has been one of the most productive and vital artists of the last dozen years, without releasing his own album in that span.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for June 21-27
text: Pop

headline: Jazz Listings for June 21-27
text: Jazz

headline: An Okinawa Prose Poem
text: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for June 21-27
text: Classical

headline: Sipping and Studying, When the Subject Is Bottled
text: “Somm,” Jason Wise’s documentary about preparing for the master sommelier exam, is less about wine fetishism than about the fetishism of mastery.

headline: This Week’s Movies: June 21, 2013
text: The New York Times movie critics on “World War Z,” “Monsters University” and “A Hijacking.”

headline: Dance Listings for June 21-27
text: Dance

headline: For Headquarters and Pirates, a Test of Wills and Wits
text: In “A Hijacking,” his assured, intense second feature, the Danish director Tobias Lindholm turns tedium and frustration into agonizing suspense. Unfolding over a span of weary, stressful months, its action mainly confined to the below-deck parts of a cargo ship and a suite of sterile corporate offices in Denmark, the film is at once a probing psychological case study and a ripped-from-the-headlines exploration of modern sea piracy.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for June 21-27
text: Art

headline: Theater Listings for June 21-27
text: Theater

headline: Panel Adopts New Rules for Taxi of Tomorrow
text: One month after a judge blocked the Bloomberg administration’s initial plans for a near-uniform fleet of yellow cabs, the Taxi and Limousine Commission on Thursday approved an adjusted set of rules in a bid to introduce its Taxi of Tomorrow as scheduled this fall.

headline: These Dead Don’t Walk. They Run.
text: I know what some of you are thinking. Zombie apocalypse? Really? Again? But if you start complaining about the lack of originality in summer movies, honestly, when will you stop? (The answer in my case is Labor Day or cocktail hour.) And in many ways, when compared with “Man of Steel,” “Iron Man 3” and “Star Trek: OMG Ricardo Montalbán!,” “World War Z” is pretty refreshing.

headline: Lawmakers Approve Use of Lever Voting Machines for Fall’s Mayoral Voting
text: ALBANY — Acknowledging that New York City election officials say they cannot count votes cast on electronic machines fast enough to smoothly administer this year’s mayoral election, the State Legislature on Thursday night voted to allow the city to redeploy its old lever voting machines.

headline: Spare Times for June 21-27
text: Midsummer Night Swing (Tuesday through July 13) Dancing feet will fill Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center for the season opener of this alfresco series, which is celebrating its 25th anniversary. The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra with Wynton Marsalis, which has its own silver anniversary this year, will provide the big-band music for the evening.

headline: Spare Times for Children for June 21-27
text: ‘Geppetto’

headline: New Light Fixture for a Famous Rotunda
text: James Turrell’s exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum will probably be the bliss-out environmental art hit of the summer. This is primarily because of the ravishing “Aten Reign,” an immense, elliptical, nearly hallucinatory play of light and color that makes brilliant use of the museum’s famed rotunda and ocular skylight. The latest site-specific effort from Mr. Turrell, “Aten Reign” is close to oxymoronic: a meditative spectacle.

headline: For American Heroes, a Poke in the Eye
text: “Where Did I Go Wrong?” asks the title of a 1991 painted and collaged work by Llyn Foulkes. It’s what Clark Kent is wondering in the work, as with furrowed brow he reads a newspaper with a banner headline blaring “War!” over news of the outbreak of the Persian Gulf war. Rendered as a cartoon cutout, Clark sits on a bulbous rock formation in a desolate Western landscape, his shirt open to reveal his Superman costume.

headline: A Complicated Actor Who Made a Complicated Mob Boss Indelible
text: “I feel like I came in at the end of something great,” Tony Soprano told his therapist in the first episode of “The Sopranos,” the series that turned a little-known actor named James Gandolfini into the definitive postmodern mob boss.

headline: Mourning the Loss of a Star as He Was Preparing to Return to HBO
text: It might have been one of the most talked about television events in recent years: James Gandolfini was coming home to HBO in a new series, his first since his indelible portrayal of the mob boss Tony Soprano on “The Sopranos.”

headline: The East Coast of California
text: OVER six months in 2011 and 2012, dozens of art institutions in Southern California joined forces in a festival of exhibitions, “Pacific Standard Time,” celebrating the history of contemporary art in Los Angeles. The project was a big success and continues to generate energy. A jolt of it hits New York City this week in an unheard-of convergence here of major California shows.

headline: From Tony Soprano to Chris Christie
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — THE first time I saw James Gandolfini on the screen, as the comically pathetic heavy called “Bear” in the film “Get Shorty,” I felt a flash of recognition. There was something familiar about the weakness and vulnerability he carried with him beneath his bullying, macho airs. The hurt in his eyes hurt me to look at it. I later learned that we had grown up at the same time not far from each other in suburban Bergen County, N.J. On summer afternoons in the 1960s, my mother used to drop a friend and me off at the movie theater in Westwood, Mr. Gandolfini’s birthplace.

headline: Shopping for Ideas in a Star’s Basement
text: “Have you heard from Barbra?”

headline: Xbox Reversal Won’t Stop the Inevitable
text: It seemed like a spectacular flip-flop: Microsoft on Wednesday reversed a couple of controversial policies about how its new Xbox One game console will operate, both of which would probably have slammed the brakes on the used games business.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Pilotage Fun and Hobby
text: A shop amid the towers of Manhattan sells remote-control airplanes and boats, and a range of other toys that appeal to both young and old.

headline: Tightening the Border
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: The Dutch Prize Their Pedal Power, but a Sea of Bikes Swamps Their Capital
text: AMSTERDAM — About 6:30 weekday mornings, throngs of bicycles, with a smattering of motor scooters and pedestrians, pour off the ferries that carry bikers and other passengers free of charge across the IJ (pronounced “eye”) harbor, clogging the streets and causing traffic jams down behind Amsterdam’s main train station.

headline: New York’s California Moment
text: A look at new exhibitions of works by the California artists Llyn Foulkes, Ken Price and James Turrell.

headline: Flying, With Both Feet on the Ground
text: New York needs more helicopters, planes, yachts and cars?

headline: Jagr’s Cup Pursuit Keeps Fans in Prague Awake
text: PRAGUE — In the waning hours of a warm and muggy night, sports fans here indulged in two favorite pastimes: watching hockey and consuming some of the world’s finest beer.

headline: When a Founder Is the Face of a Brand
text: Companies can fire a founder.  But they can’t fire his brand.

headline: The New Economic Risk: Complacency
text: With each month of steady employment growth — in May, 175,000 jobs were created — the feeling of lassitude around the issues facing the American economy takes hold a little bit more.

headline: In Dallas, 3-Year High School Diploma Would Expand Preschool
text: The senior year of high school, a time when students sometimes seem more focused on social pursuits than academics, may soon be a thing of the past for some Texas students.

headline: Czech Premier Candidate Seen as Honest but Inexperienced
text: PRAGUE — Miroslava Nemcova, the governing party’s candidate to become the next prime minister of the Czech Republic, is a former bookshop owner who has never held a ministerial position, but has a reputation for moral rectitude and can restore confidence in the scandal-hit nation, analysts said Thursday.

headline: A Top Pitcher’s Workload Comes Under Scrutiny
text: OMAHA — A healthy breeze rustled the trees at Boys Town — yes, that Boys Town — as North Carolina pitcher Kent Emanuel signed autographs for young fans near the team bus. Coach Mike Fox likes to practice at Boys Town when the Tar Heels play in the College World Series so players see and learn about the famed home for at-risk youth founded almost a century ago.

headline: Mercurial Mortgage Rates to Stabilize Soon, Analysts Say
text: It looks like the great American mortgage sale is finally coming to an end.

headline: Clothing Line? Perfume? No. For Sharapova, It’s Candy.
text: LONDON — There was no way to cram all the publicist’s proposed talking points — Maria Sharapova’s stratospheric income, her stellar tennis record, her lucrative sponsorship deals, her popularity on Twitter, her charity projects — into the 10-minute interview slot. So the tough questions had to be asked upfront.

headline: The Cost of Credit
text: The recent jump in long-term bond rates has quickly filtered down to the mortgage market.

headline: U.S. Approves a Label for Meat From Animals Fed a Diet Free of Gene-Modified Products
text: The Agriculture Department has approved a label for meat and liquid egg products that includes a claim about the absence of genetically engineered products.

headline: F.T.C. Head Seeks End to Misuse of Patents
text: WASHINGTON — A Federal Trade Commission investigation into the practices of “patent trolls” is necessary because there is little real evidence about the costs and benefits of a rising tide of patent litigation, Edith Ramirez, the F.T.C. chairwoman, said on Thursday.

headline: Stern Skeptical of Proposal to Send Rivers to Clippers
text: A proposed deal that would allow Doc Rivers to leave the Boston Celtics for the Los Angeles Clippers — with players and draft picks changing teams as part of the transaction — violates N.B.A. rules, Commissioner David Stern said in a radio interview Thursday.

headline: Nearing One Year In, Egypt’s Leader Is Besieged by Critics
text: CAIRO — Across Egypt, angry crowds have barred President Mohamed Morsi’s appointees from their offices, millions have signed petitions calling for his ouster and work crews have fortified the headquarters of the Muslim Brotherhood that propelled him to power to prevent attacks the police have failed to stop.

headline: Collision Over the House Farm Bill
text: The House’s rejection of the farm bill by a 195 to 234 vote on Thursday was a stunning defeat for Speaker John Boehner, who supported the legislation and brought it to the House floor for a vote. Mr. Boehner was unable to win support from 62 Republicans on the party’s conservative fringe, who cast no votes because they believed the $20.5 billion cut in the food stamps program did not go deep enough. Nearly all Democrats also voted no because that draconian cut would have eliminated food assistance for nearly two million people.

headline: Checking Out
text: In my younger and more vulnerable years I labored for a time in the lard-steamed back room of a Kentucky Fried Chicken outlet, well before the chain was re-branded under the flag of KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut. As assistant night manager, I learned that no wing, drumstick, breast or thigh, no matter how much contact it had with the floor, could not be redeemed as presentable extra-crispy through the wonders of the fryer.

headline: My Abortion, at 23 Weeks
text: KIRKLAND, Wash. — I BELIEVE that parenthood starts before conception, at the moment you decide you want a child, and are ready and able to create a safe and loving home for her or him. I support abortion rights, but I reject the false distinction between the terms “pro-choice” and “pro-life.” Here’s why.

headline: Profits Without Production
text: One lesson from recent economic troubles has been the usefulness of history. Just as the crisis was unfolding, the Harvard economists Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff — who unfortunately became famous for their worst work — published a brilliant book with the sarcastic title “This Time Is Different.” Their point, of course, was that there is a strong family resemblance among crises. Indeed, historical parallels — not just to the 1930s, but to Japan in the 1990s, Britain in the 1920s, and more — have been vital guides to the present.

headline: Judges Order California to Free Prisoners
text: LOS ANGELES — Continuing the more than 20-year battle over California prisons, a panel of federal judges ordered the state on Thursday to immediately begin plans to release inmates from its overcrowded prisons.

headline: How the U.S. Got Broadband Right
text: AS senators consider President Obama’s nomination of Tom Wheeler to lead the Federal Communications Commission, some observers have painted a dire picture of the state of Internet availability in America. One legal scholar, Susan Crawford, has argued that “prices are too high and speeds are too slow,” though she supports Mr. Wheeler, a venture capitalist and former telecommunications lobbyist. Other critics have called for new government policies to “fix” the telecommunications industry.

headline: Outcome of E-Book Case Could Hurt Competition, Apple Lawyer Says
text: In battling the government’s charges that it engaged in e-book price fixing, Apple has warned a judge that what is at stake is not just healthy competition in the book industry, but the way business is conducted between retailers and providers of everything from music to books to movies.

headline: Military Says Law Barring U.S. Aid to Rights Violators Hurts Training Mission
text: WASHINGTON — A 16-year-old law that bars American aid to foreign security forces that violate human rights is drawing unusual fire from some top military commanders who say it undermines their ability to train the troops to fight militants and drug traffickers.

headline: In Ali’s Voice From the Past, a Stand for the Ages
text: I woke up Thursday morning and heard a familiar voice that I thought was part of a dream: Muhammad Ali was discussing why he had refused to be inducted into the Army.

headline: Philippines Warns That It May Pull Peacekeepers Out of Golan
text: The future of the United Nations peacekeeping force in the disputed Golan Heights was thrown into further doubt on Thursday as the Philippines, which provides one-third of the force’s soldiers, warned that it might withdraw them unless they receive heavy weapons and protection to survive any attacks by warplanes, tanks and chemical munitions deployed in Syria’s civil war.

headline: The Humanist Vocation
text: A half-century ago, 14 percent of college degrees were awarded to people who majored in the humanities. Today, only 7 percent of graduates in the country are humanities majors. Even over the last decade alone, the number of incoming students at Harvard who express interest in becoming humanities majors has dropped by a third.

headline: Is It Time Yet for the Fed to Slow Down?
text: Charts showing Federal Reserve assets, S.&P. 500 stock index, unemployment rate and employment-to-population ratio.

headline: Social Awakening in Brazil
text: The huge street protests sweeping across Brazil this week caught almost everyone by surprise. But maybe they shouldn’t have.

headline: Documents Detail Restrictions on N.S.A. Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON — Since the disclosure of National Security Agency surveillance documents by the British newspaper The Guardian began this month, President Obama, top intelligence officials and members of Congress have repeatedly assured Americans that they are not the target of the N.S.A.’s sweeping electronic collection system.

headline: A Pledge of Allegiance to Partisan Policy
text: The Supreme Court on Thursday imposed an important limit on how far the government can go in controlling the speech of a group that takes government money.

headline: The Fed’s Next Move
text: The recent announcements by the Federal Reserve have generated huge interest — and, on Wall Street, a sell-off costing the Dow Jones industrial average more than 500 points in two days. Only six weeks ago, the Fed was talking about continued “downside risks to the economic outlook.” On Wednesday, however, it said these risks had diminished since last fall, and that it expected further improvement to drive the jobless rate down to 7 percent by mid-2014, at which point it would end its stimulative bond-buying programs.

headline: Dispute Over Falklands Intensifies
text: The protracted dispute between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland Islands appeared to harden further on Thursday, as the British side dismissed any thought of inviting the new Argentine pope to help mediate, and the Argentines rejected a March referendum that showed the islanders want to remain British.

headline: Marijuana Crops in California Threaten Forests and Wildlife
text: ARCATA, Calif. — It took the death of a small, rare member of the weasel family to focus the attention of Northern California’s marijuana growers on the impact that their huge and expanding activities were having on the environment.

headline: Europe’s Finance Ministers Start Negotiating Guidelines on Failing Banks
text: LUXEMBOURG — European Union finance ministers on Thursday began to negotiate rules for rescuing or closing failing banks, regulations considered crucial to promoting financial stability in the region.

headline: Shot-Blocking Skills Give Miami an Edge
text: MIAMI — All season, the Miami Heat had been appreciated for their ability to succeed with a small lineup that often featured Chris Bosh, a true power forward, at center. The Heat, the N.B.A.’s defending champions, won 27 consecutive games at one point in the regular season and reached the finals for the third straight year with the familiar assortment of furious dunks and heady passes by LeBron James, some deft plays from Dwyane Wade, some strong perimeter offense from Bosh and plenty of 3-pointers from a plethora of role players, including Ray Allen.

headline: Marijuana and Minorities
Two Economies in Turmoil, for Different Reasons
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, meant to deliver two dollops of good news on Wednesday: the economy is doing better, and the Fed is determined to keep it that way. He announced that the Fed would extend one part of its stimulus campaign, suggested that it might extend another part, and offered new details about the timing.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 21, 2013
text: “One hundred thousand people, we never would have thought it. It’s like the taking of the Bastille.”

headline: Hernandez Remains Focus of a Media Swarm
text: BOSTON — News helicopters circled the sky above the Back Bay neighborhood on Thursday afternoon after Aaron Hernandez, the Patriots tight end whose home was searched by the police this week after the death of an acquaintance, drove his white sport utility vehicle here from his home in North Attleborough, Mass. Reporters followed breathlessly, evoking comparisons to the pursuit of O. J. Simpson by the police in 1994.

headline: White House Offers Stealth Campaign to Support Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The hide-out has no sign on the door, but inside Dirksen 201 is a spare suite of offices the White House has transformed into its covert immigration war room on Capitol Hill.
