headline: Savile Row for Summer
text: LONDON — Green grass as far as the eye can see, gentlemen in vanilla-white suits and rakish straw hats, cricket bats as a fashion accessory — could anything be more quintessentially British?

headline: Quintessentially British
text: Suzy Menkes visits Lord’s Cricket Ground as the craftsmen of London’s Savile Row gather to show their work.

headline: Daily Report: Apple Says Antitrust Case Challenges Way Most Business Is Done
text: In battling the government’s charges that it engaged in e-book price fixing, Apple has warned a judge that what is at stake is not just healthy competition in the book industry, but the way business is conducted between retailers and providers of everything from music to books to movies, Brian X. Chen reports in The New York Times.

headline: Religious School Bombing Kills 14 in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least 14 people were killed and 28 injured in an attack on a Shiite religious school in northwestern Pakistan on Friday, police officials said, while Taliban militants claimed responsibility for killing a provincial lawmaker and his son in the southern port city of Karachi.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | N.B.A. Champions
text: In the article “Pushed to Limit, James and Miami Repeat as N.B.A. Champions,” Howard Beck writes about Game 7 of the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Sprint Raises Clearwire Bid
text: SPRINT RAISES CLEARWIRE BID  |  With a new bid for Clearwire, Sprint Nextel is hoping to end a battle that has lasted weeks for the wireless network operator. Sprint raised its bid on Thursday to $5 a share, 47 percent higher than its last proposal and also higher than rival offer from Dish Network of $4.40 a share, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. Sprint’s new bid values Clearwire at about $14 billion.

headline: Brazil Tries to Calm Protester Concerns, Rebuking Violence
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — With cities across the nation heaving in the biggest protests in decades, President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil convened an emergency meeting of top aides on Friday and announced that she would pursue measures touching on some of the grievances stirring the unrest, including a national transportation overhaul and the use of all oil royalties for education.

headline: Summer Reading Contest | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
text: In The Times this week: Zack Snyder, director of “Man of Steel,” explains how he created a scene from the film.

headline: Clear Women’s Favorite, and Big Four Get Back Together
text: The question was how to beat Serena Williams at Wimbledon this year.

headline: A Wardrobe Malfunction
text: Dear Diary:

headline: The Unusual, Hidden Tennis Courts of Paris
text: PARIS — Searching for court time in Paris? You might be able to book one atop a train station, an Aston Martin dealership (with a view of the Eiffel Tower), a chapel, a fire station, a parking garage a stone’s throw from the Pantheon or even a supermarket. There are also courts on the ground floor if you’re afraid of heights. Paris is a compact city. It can be crisscrossed on bike in under an hour. City planners have had to be creative to squeeze courts into the city’s confines. As a result, there are a host of unique courts packed into the most unusual spaces. Here’s a look at some of the most memorable.

headline: The One-Handed Backhand’s Vanishing Act
text: With another Wimbledon fast approaching, let’s first settle the issue of extinction by reassuring tennis connoisseurs everywhere that there will always be one-handed backhands — one-handed slice backhands.

headline: Finding Focus in Coffee Shop Chatter
text: Mike Mason speaks with Anahad O’Connor about a new Web site that offers coffee shop noise to help make workers more efficient.

headline: Wimbledon Draw: Nadal and Federer Land in Same Quarter
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The biggest news out of the draw ceremony for this year’s Wimbledon came when the fifth chip was pulled and the No. 5 seed, Rafael Nadal, landed in the same quarter as No. 3 Roger Federer, the defending champion, and in the same bottom half as No. 2 Andy Murray, who has No. 6 Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in his quarter.

headline: Mediobanca to Sell Stakes
text: LONDON – Mediobanca announced plans on Friday to sell stakes in a number of Italian companies for a combined 1.5 billion euros, or $2 billion, as the financial giant looks to untangle itself from the country’s struggling corporate sector.

headline: Bookshop Memories in a Changing India
text: In the summer of 1984, two years before I was born, my father, Ajit Vikram Singh opened a small corner bookshop, Fact & Fiction, in South Delhi’s Vasant Vihar area, opposite a decrepit cinema hall that would screen films like ‘The Sex Life of Animals’ to a packed audience. Nearly 30 years later, it’s disheartening to see him disillusioned with the Indian book industry.

headline: LeBron’s Odds of Catching Jordan
text: On Thursday, after LeBron James and the Miami Heat won their second consecutive N.B.A. championship, I noted on Twitter that James was on the same pace as the Chicago Bulls great Michael Jordan. Both James and Jordan won their first championship at 27 and their second at 28, I wrote. Jordan went on to win four more N.B.A. titles, for a total of six.

headline: Michael Dell Defends His Leveraged Buyout Offer
text: Michael S. Dell on Friday defended his $24.4 billion bid to buy control of Dell Inc., arguing that an alternative proposal by Carl C. Icahn would severely weaken the computer company.

headline: Music Video Premiere | The Latest from the Saxophonist Colin Stetson, Featuring Justin Vernon of Bon Iver
text: The saxophonist Colin Stetson loved a series of abstract, visually rich videos created by the videographers Isaac Gale and David Jensen in 2011 for the indie rock band Bon Iver, with whom Mr. Stetson has recorded and toured. So when it came time to make a video for “Who the Waves Are Roaring For” — a haunting track from his latest solo album, “New History Warfare Vol. 3: To See More Light,” that features plaintive, distorted vocals from Bon Iver’s Justin Vernon — he got in touch with the duo.

headline: China’s Credit Squeeze Relaxes as Interest Rates Drop
text: BEIJING — China’s credit squeeze eased Friday after lending resumed among banks and financial institutions that had been desperately seeking cash through the week in the interbank market.

headline: F.A.A. to Consider Relaxed Rules for Devices on Planes
text: 7:56 p.m. | Updated A working group assigned by the Federal Aviation Administration to research the use of electronics on airplanes is expected to recommend relaxing the ban on portable devices during takeoff and landing.

headline: Taliban Consider Canceling Talks With U.S. and Afghanistan
text: DOHA, Qatar — Taliban leaders were debating on Friday whether to cancel peace talks with the Americans and the Afghan government because of criticism of their use of their flag and formal name at their new office here.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Hawk Wakawaka Wine Reviews: Lives in wine: a visit with Stu and Charles Smith of Smith-Madrone, Napa Valley mountain men who make great wines. — Eric Asimov

headline: Britain Releases the Last of Its X-Files
text: LONDON — Britain’s front-line defense against alien invasion from outer space has fallen victim to spending cuts, according to documents released on Friday.

headline: Series Was an Exclamation Point for James and for Stern
text: MIAMI — If there was one thing we knew about a thrilling N.B.A. finals that carried David Stern on its shoulders to the finish line of his three-decade playoff run as commissioner and chief baby sitter, it was that the series and the season would not conclude with Jeff Van Gundy signing off the network telecast by suggesting the Miami Heat consider trading LeBron James for Dwight Howard.

headline: Putin Puts Pensions at Risk in $43 Billion Bid to Jolt Economy
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Faced with meager growth worldwide and a worrisome ebbing of Russia’s own oil and gas revenues, President Vladimir V. Putin announced an ambitious and risky economic stimulus program on Friday along with a novel amnesty plan for imprisoned white-collar criminals that was intended to improve investor confidence.

headline: Morgan Stanley Cleared to Buy Rest of Wealth Management Business
text: Morgan Stanley plans this month to buy the remaining stake in the wealth management joint venture it formed with Citigroup in the depths of the financial crisis.

headline: ‘Live, From the House of Souvlaki ...’
text: Gilda Radner, John Belushi, Bill Murray and other “S.N.L.” cast members hanging out in Times Square in the 1970s.

headline: The 6.9.13 Issue
text: Readers respond.

headline: Buddy Cianci Enjoys Life Without ‘the Squirrel’
text: Your terms as mayor of Providence, R.I., have been called Buddy I [1975-1984] and Buddy II [1991-2002]. There has been a lot of talk lately that you are going to run again in 2014, for Buddy III.  I enjoyed being mayor, but talk radio and television give me a lot of exposure, and I can do things on my own terms. People once in a while will say: “We need you back. Will you run again?” My usual answer is, “Why would you wish that on me?”

headline: My Kids Are Obsessed With Technology, and It’s All My Fault
text: A few months ago, I attended my daughter Josie’s kindergarten open house, the highlight of which was a video slide show featuring our moppets using iPads to practice their penmanship. Parental cooing ensued.

headline: My Manhattan Fantasies Realized. Sort Of.
text: A night that involved two Manhattan fantasies began with my wife and me and time to kill in the West Village. Last December we stopped into a bar to get a drink before meeting friends for dinner. The place was one of those meticulously set-designed mirages meant to evoke a speakeasy, lighted by softly glowing Art Deco fixtures. The drinks had names like Mata Hari and required muddled juniper berries.

headline: Horticulture Heist
text: My wife and I love plants. While walking through our local shopping center, we noticed a particular plant that we both liked and decided to get it for our patio. We visited two local garden centers; neither had the plant. My wife thought she could grow it from cuttings, so we went back and took about three or four cuttings from one of the many plants that were scattered around the shopping center. The plant was not hurt or damaged in any manner or form, but my gut instinct told me that this was wrong. Was it? JULIAN SOLOMONS, HUNTINGTON BEACH, CALIF.

headline: Max Brooks Is Not Kidding About the Zombie Apocalypse
text: “I’ve never seen a zombie movie where someone drank from a puddle and died of explosive diarrhea.”

headline: Who Made That T-Shirt Cannon?
text: “It weighed 90 pounds, including the tanks,” says Tim Derk of the T-shirt cannon he helped invent when he worked as the Coyote mascot for the San Antonio Spurs in the 1990s. “It was like carrying a TV set on your back. The gun was probably at least four feet long. It used a cast-iron pipe — the kind that goes into the floor underneath your commode. It just weighed a ton.” Of course, someone else might have tried the stunt before Derk, but when he dressed up as “Rambote” — Rambo meets the Spurs’ Coyote — and sprayed the cheap seats with freebies, few sports fans had seen anything like it.

headline: Autopsy on Gandolfini Finds Actor Died of ‘Natural Causes,’ Family Spokesman Says
text: 11:14 a.m. | Updated

headline: Portrait of the Musician as a Young Reader
text: The drummer Ahmir Thompson, better known as Questlove, a co-founder of the Roots, has written many times about the formative music in his life. Now that he’s an author — of the recently published memoir “Mo’ Meta Blues” — I was curious about what reading material shaped his childhood.

headline: Pride and Perseverance
text: Out to lunch with a friend one day in 1969, the British novelist Barbara Pym was doing what she always did — gathering details of the life around her as if they were jewels dropped in her path by a generous deity. “Why aren’t more of these elderly ladies wearing canvas shoes?” she scribbled in her ever-present notebook. “In the restaurant all those clergymen helping themselves from the cold table, it seems endlessly.” Then she stopped abruptly. “But you mustn’t notice things like that if you’re going to be a novelist in 1968-9 and the 70s,” she scolded herself. “The posters on Oxford Circus Station advertising Confidential Pregnancy Tests would be more suitable.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: WHAT DO WOMEN WANT?: Adventures in the Science of Female Desire,  by Daniel Bergner. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $25.99.) When it comes to the study of women’s sexuality, Bergner writes, there are fewer established facts than you would think.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE ART FORGER,  by B. A. Shapiro. (Algonquin, $14.95.) In 1990, 13 works of art were looted from a Boston museum, including a Rembrandt, a Vermeer and several sketches by Degas. Shapiro’s nimble mystery revisits this brazen theft: more than two decades on, a stolen Degas painting seems to resurface and Claire Roth, a talented yet struggling artist, is lured into reproducing the long-missing masterpiece.

headline: Inside the List
text: PRIMATOLOGY: Readers of Carl Hiaasen’s new Florida mystery, “Bad Monkey” — it enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 3 — won’t be surprised to learn that there is, in fact, a bad monkey in its pages: Driggs, an animal performer who works on Johnny Depp’s pirate movies until he’s caught masturbating on wigs in the costume trailer. “My vision of the monkey was of a show business monkey that just crashed and burned,” Hiaasen said on NPR recently. “Sort of a Lindsay Lohan of monkeys.” He added that he was struck by pop culture’s recent turn toward the simian: “In every movie it seems you go to now, and TV sitcoms and everywhere you look, there’s sort of a gratuitous monkey,” he said. “I wanted a monkey with a back story.”

headline: Charged Images
text: When a supposed friend and collector tells the painter-art star Eric Fischl: “You’ve got to face it, man. You didn’t make the cut” — meaning that after rocketing to the top in the art boom of the 1980s, his prices aren’t holding in the ’90s, he’s no longer one of the artists who matter — I felt sucker-­punched myself. Fischl says the collector was just being matter-of-fact, but really? One of the many reasons to read “Bad Boy” (written with Michael Stone) is how vividly it recreates the precariousness and ambivalences of life in the upper tiers of the international art world. But the collector’s jab also alerts us that it’s a rise-and-fall story we’ve been reading, not just a jolly succession of triumphs.

headline: Legend Retold
text: Even in its fragmentary and unfinished form — about 40 pages of text, a bit more than four cantos of what was evidently intended to be a much longer narrative poem — “The Fall of Arthur” is recognizably the work of J. R. R. Tolkien, veteran of the Great War and future author of “The Lord of the Rings.” This is an incomplete but highly compelling retelling of perhaps the most famous and familiar legend in the British tradition, a retelling the author’s son and literary executor, Christopher Tolkien, believes was begun in the early 1930s and abandoned by 1937. Perhaps not coincidentally, that was the year “The Hobbit” was published, offering readers their first glimpse of a fantasy universe that would shape the imaginative life of the 20th century and beyond.

headline: Just Around the Corner
text: Before reading this rich, sensory novel, my literary familiarity with Sri Lanka came mostly from Michael Ondaatje’s rollicking memoir, “Running in the Family.” But it was enough of an introduction, with all its extravagant, hilarious dysfunctions, to pique my interest in the island nation. Ru Freeman’s assured second novel is a much quieter yet rewarding portrait of a community of families on a dead-end road in Colombo, the country’s capital. They are a mixed lot on Sal Mal Lane: Sinhalese, Tamils and Burghers, descendants of European colonizers. Down this road live the comfortably middle class and the dirt poor; the sick, the heartbroken and viciously prejudiced; youngsters vivacious with talent, or misshapen by abuse; and a few residents in their middle and later years who are roused by the arrival of the Heraths, a family with four lively children.

headline: The Beloved Country
text: In 1992, when the mujahedeen arrived in Kabul, young Qais Akbar Omar “expected to see heroes in uniforms and shiny boots.” Instead, the Holy Warriors had “beards, mustaches and smelly shoes that wrapped up stinky feet.” Omar’s father and grandfather were hopeful, but the liberation was short-lived. Soon, fighting broke out across the city. “It was like when a forest catches fire,” Omar writes; “both the dry and the wet burn.” The family retreated to their basement before the onslaught of rockets and snipers forced them to abandon their home altogether. Piling into their Volga, Omar and his mother, father, three sisters, baby brother, two aunts and seven cousins set out for safer ground.

headline: Natural Lawyer
text: Most of us live our partisan politics through the media, which generally means cross-firing tweets, posts and cable news shows about the latest scandal as interpreted by a rotating stable of Washington strategists, party faithfuls and pundits. But behind the klieg lights, there has always been a less topical, more abstract debate between liberal and conservative academics and philosophers about the nature of human flourishing and the political and social institutions that best promote it.

headline: Bless the Borrowers
text: Robert Kuttner’s title refers, first, to the “medieval institution” that was the fate of improvident souls in England who could not repay their debts, including Daniel Defoe. In 1692, Defoe was committed to King’s Bench Prison in London, where he began to agitate for a change in the legal system. Forcing debtors to rot, Defoe not disinterestedly pointed out, was injurious to both parties, since “after a debtor was confined in prison both he and the creditor lost through his prolonged distress.” Society responded, eventually, with bankruptcy laws, but it is very much Kuttner’s point in “Debtors’ Prison” that we — America and Europe in the age of the financial crisis — have yet to absorb the principal lesson of Defoe’s “bitter experience.”

headline: When Two Paths Meet
text: Deploying flatulence as a plot device takes nerve. Chaucer got away with it in “The Miller’s Tale,” thanks to the bawdy, rowdy nature of the story. In her ambitious new novel, “Questions of Travel,” the Sri Lankan-Australian novelist Michelle de Kretser gets away with it too, when her main characters, Ravi and Laura, finally have an encounter that seems like a prelude to some greater connection — or at least a reckoning or revelation. But the moment passes with Ravi’s gas. This willful non-event is the culmination of de Kretser’s cool play with conventional reader expectations about how much, and how meaningfully, two disparate lives should matter to each other when they finally converge after pages and pages of parallel-track narratives.

headline: Do as I Say
text: At first glance, it would seem that Wendy Moore, a lively English journalist and social historian, has written an account of Victor Frankenstein’s reluctant endeavors to present his monster with the wife the lonely creature so desperately craves. Not so. Moore’s extraordinary subject is the compellingly repellent historical figure Thomas Day, a children’s book writer and ardent abolitionist.

headline: Illiberal Arts
text: More than a century ago, the president of Harvard, A. Lawrence Lowell, issued a warning to America’s colleges and universities. “Institutions,” he said, “are rarely murdered. They meet their end by suicide. . . . They die because they have outlived their usefulness, or fail to do the work that the world wants done.” Most of the institutions he had in mind are still around today, but the doomsday talk is back. William J. Bennett, secretary of education under President Reagan, and Jeffrey Selingo, an editor at The Chronicle of Higher Education, believe our system is self-­destructing. Their tones are different — Bennett and his co-author, David Wilezol, write in an expectant mood of good riddance, while Selingo is sympathetically alarmed — but their views are grimly consistent. College costs are up. Learning and graduation rates are down.

headline: Natural Born Killers
text: The Italian criminologist Cesare Lombroso makes for an unlikely hero. In the late 1800s, Lombroso proposed that criminals were evolutionary throwbacks who could be identified by primitive features like sloping foreheads and large jaws, and he went on to posit an evolutionary hierarchy of the races, with northern Italians at its apex. Such ideas inspired Mussolini’s racial laws in the 1930s, and are at the core of some of the ugliest social movements of our time.

headline: Inside Story
text: Why would you read a six-­volume, 3,600-page Norwegian novel about a man writing a six-­volume, 3,600-page Norwegian novel? The short answer is that it is breathtakingly good, and so you cannot stop yourself, and would not want to.

headline: Annus Mirabilis
text: If Christian Caryl had set out to write a book about 1968, showing how the many convulsions and uprisings of that astonishing year were connected, his task would have been an easy one. It might be difficult to prove cause and effect between, say, the May events in Paris and the chaos at the Democratic convention in August, but as people might have said at the time, something was in the air. It wasn’t mere coincidence that led to youth revolts all over the world. In the case of 1989, such connections are even more obvious.

headline: How Crowdfunding Worked for One Timely Start-Up
text: Last fall, I wrote a post about the crowdfunding campaign of a start-up known as braGGs. The company, based in Alexandria, Va., has developed a patent-pending bra for women who have had reconstructive breast surgery — “reconstructed bras for reconstructed girls,” as the Web site puts it.

headline: What I Love | Rick Elice and Roger Rees
text: The couple share a duplex in Emery Roth’s storied masterwork the Beresford, on Central Park West.

headline: Upstairs at the Beresford
text: When the actor Roger Rees and the playwright Rick Elice became a couple in 1982, work kept them in separate cities: first London, then Los Angeles for Mr. Rees, New York for Mr. Elice. Jet lag was chronic, the frequent-flier miles many.

headline: Farm Bill’s Fate in House Bodes Ill for Immigration Reform
text: WASHINGTON — The story of the 113th Congress was on display during a single afternoon this week.

headline: ‘Despair’
text: A clip from the Yeah Yeah Yeahs new song, "Despair," which was shot on the observation deck of the Empire State Building.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The State of Higher Education
text: This week, Andrew Delbanco discusses two new books about the state of higher education; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Andrew O’Hehir talks about “The Fall of Arthur,” by J. R. R. Tolkien; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: The Fork Less Taken
text: The North Fork of Long Island is designed by nature for exquisite sunsets and private contemplation.

headline: On the North Fork, the Un-Hamptons
text: Around 75 miles east of New York City, just past the “Rip van Winkle” revival unfolding in somnolent Riverhead, the Long Island Expressway ends in a blaze of commercial glory at the Tanger Outlets. Soon after that, Long Island succumbs to a severe case of geological split personality and sprouts an intriguing pair of sibling peninsulas. Naturally there’s a bit of a rivalry.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The State of Higher Education
text: This week, Andrew Delbanco, Julie Bosman, Andrew O’Hehir and Gregory Cowles.

headline: One Coalition Partner Quits Greek Government
text: ATHENS — Greece’s fragile three-way coalition was dealt a serious blow on Friday, the anniversary of its creation, when its smallest party withdrew to protest Prime Minister Antonis Samaras’s shutdown of the state broadcaster, the latest in a series of unilateral decisions that have enraged his partners in government.

headline: Summer Shows Its Stripes, Woven in Orange, Green and Brown
text: As the pasty hordes descend on Jones Beach on Long Island for the first weekend of summer, rentals of umbrellas, striped in the traditional orange, green and brown, will suddenly shoot into high demand. For the park, the umbrellas are a modest side business, in place since its Jazz Age opening. For beachgoers, they are a $10 concession to worried mothers and lecturing dermatologists, a bright buffer from the blazing summer sun.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Grading Higher Education
text: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Andrew Delbanco reviews two new books about the state of higher education in the United States. Mr. Delbanco writes:

headline: Reasons to Get a Flu Shot
text: The flu vaccine is far from 100 percent effective, but researchers have calculated that over the past six years it has prevented millions of illnesses and tens of thousands of hospitalizations.

headline: The Idea of Bonnaroo
text: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss this year’s Bonnaroo music festival.

headline: The Farmers’ Market: Strawberries
text: Strawberries are now in abundance at the farmers’ market. Here are ideas for ways to use them beyond rinsing and popping directly in your mouth (nothing wrong with that).

headline: Remembering James Gandolfini, Remembering Staten Island
text: The first thing I did after hearing the news of the death of James Gandolfini, who died suddenly Wednesday in Italy at age 51, was eat a bowl of shredded wheat. Then I spent 30 minutes on the treadmill. While I was on the treadmill, I thought about Anthony Salvio.

headline: Working to Revive a Movie House That Lived in a Palace
text: A nonprofit organization is conducting a fund-raising campaign to help it show films at the United Palace Cathedral in Washington Heights.

headline: The Gun Report: June 21, 2013
text: “So, Heidi,” began the email to Heidi Yewman from Michele Kort, her editor at Ms. Magazine. “I wanted to let you know that, in the comments to the gun-nut post below, someone put your address out there. I’ve been super careful NOT to approve any comments that mentioned where you might live.”

headline: S.E.C. Has a Message for Firms Not Used to Admitting Guilt
text: The days of cop-out settlements in big securities cases may be waning.

headline: In Harlem, Looking for Something Not Hotel-Like
text: As a singer and actress, Esther Joy Stilwell lived out of a suitcase for six years. After her graduation from the University of Oklahoma, she performed throughout the world, touring in “Cats” and Monty Python’s “Spamalot.”

headline: Happy to Be a Puppet
text: Is being an artist a gift or a curse? That question is at the heart of “A Dancer’s Dream,” a sinister and whimsical reimagining of two Stravinsky works, “The Fairy’s Kiss” and “Petrushka,” in which a young woman is blessed (or is it burdened?) by the realization that she is a ballerina.

headline: Animated Family Fun in Macao
text: If you see Shrek wandering a resort in Macao, don’t be surprised. The Las Vegas of Asia, as it’s often called, is poised to expand its appeal beyond serious gamblers to families with the July opening of the new DreamWorks Experience at Cotai Strip Resorts.

headline: Learning to Spot Frailty
text: Doctors should screen all adults over age 70 for frailty, a medical syndrome that affects 5 percent to 10 percent of people in this age group, according to a new consensus statement from six international medical organizations.

headline: After Adversity, a Passion Unchecked
text: Asked by a student about her musical inspirations after a recent Baroque master class at Juilliard, the violinist Rachel Barton Pine gestured toward the stickers of heavy metal bands plastered on her violin case. “When they’re onstage, they’re getting everyone headbanging,” she said. “Within classical music my goal is to do the same thing, to give 150 percent and get everyone caught up in the emotions.”

headline: Sprint May Be Off the Table, but Dish’s Deal Appetite May Remain
text: Charles W. Ergen is regarded as one of the wiliest negotiators in the business world. But in a little over a week, Mr. Ergen, chairman of the Dish Network, has been dealt two tough hands, one at Sprint Nextel and the other at Clearwire.

headline: He Likes His Horror Personal and Global
text: LOVELL, Maine — Rosie’s General Store serves breakfast all day, and it’s the type of place where residents of this town of 1,140 will stop in to buy lottery tickets, a loaf of bread or the special jumbo lobster roll. It’s also the inspiration for the Sweetbriar Rose, a diner in Stephen King’s 2009 opus about a small town cut off from the outside world by a mysterious and impenetrable dome.

headline: European Ministers Agree to Stricter Tobacco Laws
text: LONDON — Cigarette packs in Europe would have to carry bigger health warnings, and cigarettes with menthol or other flavorings face a total ban, under an agreement that European Union ministers struck on Friday after spirited negotiations.

headline: Video: Yeah Yeah Yeahs Perform Atop Empire State Building
text: In its 82-year history, the top of the Empire State Building has been the site of countless family outings, marriage proposals and, of course, one very memorable date gone awry. But as near as we can tell, it had never been the site of an indie rock performance, not a preapproved one anyway.

headline: Beyond Tony Soprano
text: James Gandolfini’s memorable movie performances suggested a great film career in the making.

headline: Touring, the ‘Wyoming Way’
text: BOISE, Idaho — The pounding on his cargo-van doors started as soon as Jalan Crossland’s head hit the pillow. After a thousand miles of rough road and his fifth straight night onstage, the bone-tired banjo man had kicked off his boots and collapsed on the mattress in his old Dodge 3500 outside Pengilly’s, the saloon here where he and his fellow musicians had jammed well into the early morning.

headline: Just Another Career Criminal Writer
text: LOS ANGELES — On a set so authentically dressed to resemble a boxing gym that you could almost smell the mildewed towels, a man on the floor was howling in pain as two burly-looking goons dragged him by the ankles. Anyone familiar with the work of Ann Biderman, the creator of the series being shot, “Ray Donovan,” would instantly recognize that the scene incorporated three of her favorite subjects: violence, Los Angeles and thugs.

headline: Not Too Young for the Blues
text: If you ask Buddy Guy who embodies the future of blues guitar, he will point to a 14-year-old boy from Massachusetts named Quinn Sullivan. “Remember that name,” Mr. Guy said in a recent interview. “He sounds like Eric Clapton, B. B. King, me, Hendrix, everybody, man!”

headline: Mediobanca’s Stake Sales Are a Hopeful Sign for Italy
text: There are many reasons to worry about Italy’s prospects, but Mediobanca is no longer one.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Monsters University’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Monsters University."

headline: Summer Bean Salads
text: Bean salads are a great choice for summer picnics, and most recipes can easily be adapted to accommodate any vegans in the crowd. This week the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman turns to summer bean salads:

headline: Food Network Drops Paula Deen
text: Paula Deen, the self-proclaimed queen of Southern cooking and a sugary mainstay of the Food Network, was dropped by the network on Friday, after a bewildering day in which she failed to show up for an interview on the “Today” show and then in two online videos begged her family and audience to forgive her for using racist language.

headline: For Episcopal Church’s Leader, a Sermon Leads to More Dissent
text: Curaçao, the Dutch island off the Venezuelan coast, is nice this time of year. Actually, it’s nice any time of year. The temperature is in the low 80s and the seawater is nearly as warm. It must be a nice place to give a sermon. But for Katharine Jefferts Schori, since 2006 the presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church in the United States, memories of Curaçao will always be associated with the controversy that greeted her upon her return — another controversy in what has already been a rocky tenure as the head of a troubled, shrinking church.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Gettysburg, Pa; Quebec
text: Gettysburg 150th, Pennsylvania The Gettysburg 150th anniversary commemoration will observe the Battle of Gettysburg for 10 days from June 28 through July 7 in Gettysburg, Pa. Some 400 events focused on the Civil War are on the schedule: battle re-enactments featuring horse-drawn cannons and cavalrymen on horseback, soldier encampments, living history programs and special tours and exhibitions, including the opening of the Seminary Ridge Museum. Visitors can walk in the footsteps of Confederate soldiers in the mile-long Pickett’s Charge Commemorative March, led by National Park rangers representing each of the assaulting brigades. Gettysburg College is showing a 15-minute film about the Gettysburg Address throughout the summer, and offering Witness to History, a historical walking tour app of the college and town, both free.

headline: A Lifetime of Changes, From ‘Roommate’ to ‘Spouse’
text: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Selling Park Avenue Condos at $250,000 a Minute
text: Harry B. Macklowe flew an Emmy-award-winning film crew to southern England, hired the famed tightrope walker Philippe Petit and bought the song rights to a Mama Cass classic, all for a four-minute movie to market his latest condominium development.

headline: A 1930 Theater’s Beauty Survives
text: A nonprofit group that recently held a film premiere at the United Palace in Washington Heights hopes to turn it into a place for special movie events.

headline: Suzuki Faces Possible Air Bag Recall, Complicated by Bankruptcy
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether air bag problems warrant recalling about 205,000 Suzuki vehicles, the 2006-11 Grand Vitara and the 2007-11 SX4, according to a report posted on the safety agency’s Web site.

headline: The Art of the Chosen People
text: Like New York, the art world has a lot of Jewish people. The sole curatorial theme of “Jew York,” a sweeping joint exhibition at the Zach Feuer Gallery in Chelsea and Untitled on the Lower East Side, is works by the chosen people, but it has no specific agenda beyond that. “I just wanted to put everyone in the room together and see what happens,” Feuer explained, “and not make some grand academic statement about Judaism.” Feuer and Carol Cohen and Joel Mesler of Untitled (all members of the tribe) approached the exhibition in a hands-off way that defied stereotypes about both art-world types and the Jewish people. They simply asked artists to submit whatever work they wished. Of the 100 they approached to participate, only four or five didn’t want to be “outed.” (All happened to be of a certain generation that came to prominence during the 1980s.) Several others responded with the news that they were not, in fact, Jewish.

headline: Ireland’s Turnaround May Not Be So Rosy
text: TWO years ago, even as other troubled European economies continued to deteriorate, some economic statistics seemed to indicate that Ireland’s troubled economy had turned the corner and was growing again.

headline: Video: Slow-Moving Burglar Carries a Cane
text: The plastic brace on the man’s right foot is trailing straps, and there is a cane in his hand. He takes little steps, and his hip rolls each time he sets down his right foot. There is nothing furtive about the man, whose image was captured by a surveillance camera for a few seconds as he hobbled down a sunlit street in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, one morning last month. So why are the police looking for him?

headline: This Week’s Movies: ‘World War Z,’ ‘Monsters University’ and ‘A Hijacking’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics offer their thoughts on “World War Z,” “Monsters University” and “A Hijacking.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Action on Expanded Gambling as Albany’s Legislative Session Sputters to End
text: ALBANY — Lawmakers agreed on Friday night to ask voters to authorize expanded casino gambling across New York State, but planned to end their annual legislative session without approving new measures to combat corruption in the capital.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 21.
text: Pictures include a canine graduation at Grand Central Terminal, Sal Albanese in Queens, and workers atop St. Patrick’s Cathedral in Manhattan.

headline: Cecil Taylor Wins the Kyoto Prize
text: The improvising pianist Cecil Taylor, a pioneering, influential and highly experimental musician and a longtime Brooklyn resident, is one of this year’s recipients of the Kyoto Prize, awarded each year by the Inamori Foundation in Japan, the foundation announced on Friday. Mr. Taylor, 84, is this year’s laureate in the category of arts and philosophy; different fields across technology, science, art and philosophy are considered on a rotating basis, and there has been a recipient in music every four years. (The last musician laureate in 2009 was the conductor and composer Pierre Boulez.) The prize comes with a cash gift of 50 million yen (approximately $510,000), to be given at a ceremony in Kyoto in November. This year’s other laureates are the electronics engineer Dr. Robert H. Dennard and the evolutionary biologist Dr. Masatoshi Nei.

headline: The Sweet Spot: ‘Cinematic Kryptonite’
text: In this week’s episode, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the sour experience of seeing a movie that’s “not very super.”

headline: Disappointing Fall for ‘Rock Center,’ a News Program With Big Ambitions
text: If “Rock Center With Brian Williams” has proved anything in the last year and a half, it is this: However hard it is to gather an audience for any kind of show in prime time, for news programming, the task is even harder.

headline: S.E.C. to Require Admissions of Guilt
text: In some settlement cases, the Securities and Exchange Commission will now demand that defendants go beyond the current “neither admit nor deny” standard.

headline: In Europe, a Few Coins for a Wealth of Culture
text: I figured I might someday take an amibitious cultural jaunt through Europe, catching a classical concert at La Monnaie in Brussels, a musical off Las Ramblas in Barcelona, and cutting-edge dance performances in Berlin — all from the best seats in the house. I just imagined it would have wait until I retired as the Frugal Traveler columnist and retrained as, say, a plastic surgeon to the stars.

headline: A Rinse and a Roll on a River in Nepal
text: I will admit that after 25 days of third world travel with my future in-laws, my motives for going off to paddle some difficult white water last year were complex. Yes, I’ve been a kayaker for a decade, and the Bhote Koshi River, which pours down the Tibetan Himalayas into Nepal — rated Class V during high water, but in winter “a classic Class III,” according to one outfitter — appeared to be within my abilities.

headline: North Korean Diplomat Blames United States for Tensions but Calls for Peace Talks
text: In a mix of diplomacy and bombast, North Korea’s ambassador to the United Nations called Friday for the United States to accept its recently revived proposal for direct peace talks, even as he blamed the Americans for all tensions on the Korean Peninsula starting with the war more than 60 years ago.

headline: Home-Cooked Challenge: Kids in the Kitchen
text: The Home-Cooked Challenge isn’t about what we’re subtracting from our kitchen — or at least, it shouldn’t be. It’s about what we’re adding. I’ve been focused on what’s not here (snacks and other processed and prepackaged foods) mostly because we turn to those easy alternatives so readily. Unless I took the snack foods out, I knew from experience that we’d keep turning to them.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Ramen, takoyaki (fried octopus) and sushi: those are only some of the foods that will be served during Mitsuwa’s Japanese Gourmet Fair through Sunday. The megamarket, located in Edgewater, N.J., will bring together local vendors and some from Japan who will feature more than 100 products.

headline: Image of the Day: June 21
text: A prayer meeting in Jammu and Kashmir for the victims of floods that struck the north Indian state of Uttarakhand.

headline: Oracle and Salesforce: a Data-Sharing Deal
text: Some of the best trash-talking in tech may be over. The Oracle Corporation and Salesforce.com, two of the more contentious competitors in software, are about to announce a close alliance involving software delivered via cloud computing.

headline: Catching Grief and Little Else, Goalie Moves On
text: CHICAGO — Blackhawks goaltender Corey Crawford faced a crush of news media at his locker Friday afternoon. He spoke in French to reporters from his native Montreal, and then in English. The topic, no matter the language, was the same: his glove.

headline: There’s a Fly in My Tweets
text: ROCHESTER — MANY important public health questions are difficult and costly to answer. What kind of risks do highly localized sources of pollution, like dry cleaners that use volatile chemicals, pose to the health of nearby residents? Are people with many friends healthier, or do those friendships increase the likelihood of infectious disease? Do frequent visits to public spaces like bars, gyms and restaurants affect a person’s health?

headline: Flooding Inundates Part of Canadian Province
text: Heavy rains have contributed to flooding in parts of the Canadian province of Alberta, where officials said Friday that about 75,000 people have been displaced from their homes. Swollen waterways burst banks, streets were flooded and in at least once instance the wreckage of a house was swept away by raging waters in the Bragg Creek area.

headline: Shares in Gogo Slip in Market Debut
text: After a promising debut, shares in Gogo Inc. have hit some turbulence.

headline: Top D.J.’s to Headline the TomorrowWorld Festival
text: The organizers of one of Europe’s largest electronic dance festivals plan to stage a three-day concert near Atlanta in September, and have secured a lineup that includes most of the top D.J.’s in the world, including Tiesto, Afrojack, David Guetta and Calvin Harris.

headline: Appeals Exhausted, Astor Case Ends as Son Is Sent to Jail
text: Anthony D. Marshall, the disgraced 89-year-old son of the Manhattan society doyenne Brooke Astor, finally surrendered on Friday to begin a prison sentence for stealing millions of dollars from his mother during her final years of life, ending a seven-year legal odyssey that came to define his own waning years.

headline: Billboard Will Not Count Jay-Z’s Sales From Samsung Deal
text: Billboard has decided it will not count in its chart tally a million albums that Jay-Z plans to distribute through Samsung as free downloads to owners of its Galaxy mobile phones.

headline: F.A.A. May Relax Restrictions on Electronic Devices on Planes
text: If you’re reading this just as the flight attendants are making the “shut down your portable electronic devices” announcement, take heart. Soon you may not have to speed-read your final words before taking off. The F.A.A. is considering loosening its ban on portable electronic devices during takeoff and landing, Nick Bilton and Jad Mouawad report. That’s right. You and your fellow passengers may be able to keep on texting and e-mailing and shopping and playing video games until you’re above the clouds. A decision is expected in September.

headline: The Sparks Flew Before They Even Met
text: Lindsay Benner, a professional juggler, honed her talents at Fisherman’s Wharf in San Francisco after graduating college. As the finale to her street performance there, Ms. Benner would select two men from the audience, climb up and stand on their folded arms, then juggle flaming torches above their heads.

headline: The Sweet Spot: ‘Cinematic Kryptonite’
text: In this week’s episode, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the sour experience of seeing a movie that’s “not very super.”

headline: Kids Love the Darndest Things
text: The students in Cathy Gabel’s fifth-grade class at Central School in Mamaroneck, N.Y., have become fans of the magazine’s regular ‘‘Who Made That?’’ column, which explores the origin stories of everyday objects. Earlier this year, some of the students wrote to Pagan Kennedy, who writes the weekly column, and were encouraged after receiving a thoughtful response. “Ever since that day,” Gabel wrote to me in an e-mail, they “have felt a deep connection to the article, running to see the magazine section when it arrived on Saturday mornings, barely able to wait until Monday morning to discuss it in class.” They were “thrilled to see an entire issue” devoted to their favorite magazine feature, and sent us this photo of them showing their approval. You can also see this photo on the Reply All page in Sunday’s magazine.

headline: Vitoria Rother
text: Vitoria Rother, 17, student.

headline: Paula Deen Issues Video Statements
text: 5:42 p.m. | Updated A third video has surfaced in which Ms. Deen apologized to Matt Lauer for missing her appearance on the “Today” show on Friday.

headline: Friday Night Music: Belated Toronto Edition
text: OK, I screwed up: last Friday I was in Toronto, and I gave you a French singer; then I headed for France. I should have saved Zaz for this week, and given you a Toronto band last week. But anyway, here’s Toronto-based Austra. Not at all my to my usual taste, but I’ve featured them once before — they may be electronic, but I do find some of their songs echoing in my head days after:

headline: Silvia Dias
text: Silvia Dias, 31, economist.

headline: Love of a Garden Is a Thorn in This Relationship
text: The venerable New York Grand Opera Company recently ended decades of summer performances under the skies in Central Park, citing what its conductor, Vincent La Selva, called the increasing unpredictability of the weather.

headline: Tapping Artisanal Beers and Booze at Hotel Bars
text: Hotel restaurants have long poured private label wines. But with the rise of artisan distilling and craft brewing, bespoke selections are now the toast of hotel bars around the world.

headline: Secrets, Non-Secrets and Leaks
text: Sometimes you can understand why the government keeps secrets –because those secrets could endanger lives or derail military operations, or simply because they might be embarrassing. No one should have been shocked when the Obama administration was outraged at Edward Snowden’s leaks of documents describing massive surveillance of Americans by the National Security Agency.

headline: As the Baseballs Fly Farther in Japan, the Game’s Commissioner Is Criticized
text: TOKYO — If the cover-up is often worse than the crime, the Japanese version of that axiom may apply to Ryozo Kato, the commissioner of Nippon Professional Baseball.

headline: London Symphony Orchestra and Chorus: ‘Der Freischütz’
text: In his last years the eminent conductor Colin Davis, who died in April at 85, had debilitating stretches of poor health. But he was clearly inspired for a concert performance in April 2012 of Weber’s opera “Der Freischütz” with the London Symphony Orchestra and Chorus and an impressive cast. LSO Live recently released a vibrant recording drawn from two performances at the Barbican in London.

headline: Daniel Wohl: ‘Corps Exquis’
text: No disrespect to the participants on “Corps Exquis” (New Amsterdam), the deliciously lovely new album by the French-born New York composer Daniel Wohl, but I can’t easily imagine the music on the disc being performed live. In fact, the nine selections on the CD are part of an evening-length, multimedia performance piece, meant to be played by real people in real time. Even so, I have a hard time imagining how these vivid, detailed and engaging compositions might sound in three-dimensional space.

headline: Alan Feinberg: ‘Basically Bull’
text: In 1613 John Bull left England for Flanders, where he soon took up a position as organist at Antwerp Cathedral. If his reputation as a composer and keyboard virtuoso preceded him, so did fame of another kind. “The man hath more music than honesty and is as famous for marring of virginity as he is for fingering of organs and virginals,” wrote George Abbot, the archbishop of Canterbury. Of all Elizabethan composers, Bull had the most picaresque life, punctuated with fistfights, adultery and, possibly, a stint as a spy. But it is in his astonishingly virtuosic and forward-looking compositions that his roaming curiosity reveals itself fully.

headline: Looking Back At California
text: With solo shows by Paul McCarthy, Ken Price and James Turrell on view, New York is having a major California moment, and it expands exponentially with the opening on Sunday of “State of Mind: New California Art Circa 1970” at the Bronx Museum of the Arts. Originating at the Orange County Museum of Art in Newport Beach, Calif., this group show focuses on the blossoming of Conceptual art, performance, video and installation work on the West Coast in the 1960s and 1970s as alternative art spaces and artist-run galleries grew in number and university art departments accommodated avant-garde practices.

headline: A Reunion For ‘Mourner’
text: If you saw Wallace Shawn’s “Designated Mourner” the last time it was produced in New York, you are one of a lucky few. That’s because the play, a series of monologues about intellectuals and artists living in an unnamed Western country under a brutal regime, had a production so intimate that it played to an audience of 20. Good news for those who couldn’t secure what was one of hottest tickets that last time, in the summer of 2000: The original cast (Mr. Shawn, Deborah Eisenberg, Larry Pine) is reuniting for a revival at the Public Theater.

headline: Exile in Paris, The Soundtrack
text: Paris was yesterday. So were the soulful ballads that come out of Dale Turner’s sax in “ ’Round Midnight,” Bertrand Tavernier’s 1986 tribute to black expatriate jazz musicians in 1950s Paris — a melancholy slow jam of a film. Its story of a worshipful young Frenchman (François Cluzet), who watches over the alcoholic Dale, could easily be cloying, and sometimes is. But Mr. Tavernier knew what he was doing when he cast the real-life sax man Dexter Gordon as Dale. Tall and elegant, Gordon wanders through the film and Paris like a living, breathing, muttering monument, capturing something ineffable about exile in every distracted glance toward the heavens.

headline: Stravinsky, With Puppets
text: In May 2010, during his first season as music director of the New York Philharmonic, Alan Gilbert showed what a night at the symphony could be if a conductor thinks big. Working with the director and stage designer Doug Fitch Mr. Gilbert presented an exhilarating production of Ligeti’s bleakly satirical opera “Le Grand Macabre,” resourcefully transforming Avery Fisher Hall into an opera house and drawing a dazzling account of this challenging modernist score from the Philharmonic players. The following spring Mr. Gilbert and Mr. Fitch collaborated again on an enchanting production of Janacek’s “Cunning Little Vixen.”

headline: The Rise and Fall Of a Tabloid Dream
text: Excluding commercials, “Anna Nicole,” a made-for-television movie Saturday night at 8 p.m. on Lifetime, is only about 90 minutes long. That seems like a not very generous allotment for the task at hand: telling the story of one of the most eventful, calamitous pop-culture lives of recent years.

headline: Moves From Brazil, By Way of France
text: Although visually spectacular, the rambunctiousness of hip-hop dance can make it hard to transfer it from the street or dance club, where it can appear unfettered, to the formality of the stage, where its energy must be contained within bounds. One internationally successful attempt to theatricalize hip-hop is Compagnie Käfig, a French-based troupe of Brazilian dancers that’s bringing two productions for an all-male cast to the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival.

headline: Popcast: The Idea of Bonnaroo
text: This week: The 12th Bonnaroo music festival, which wrapped up last Sunday in Manchester, Tenn.

headline: Big Ticket | A Floor Full of Light, Sold for $13.5 Million
text: An elegant loft that commands the entire 15th floor of the Franklin Tower, an 18-story luxury condominium at 90 Franklin Street in TriBeCa, sold for $13.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: For a Fee, Seeking Owners of Unclaimed Money
text: NOT long after his mother died in December 2010, John Sinclair said he began receiving calls from a company that claimed it had found money belonging to her, which it would divulge for a fee. Mr. Sinclair, a social worker outside of Cleveland, said he ignored the calls until a few months ago.

headline: 2004 Showdown Shaped Reputation of Pick for F.B.I.
text: WASHINGTON — If it were not for a now famous scene in a hospital just blocks away from the White House, it is unlikely that James B. Comey would have been standing in the Rose Garden on Friday to be introduced as President Obama’s nominee for the director of the F.B.I.

headline: Food Matters | A Winning Seafood Spot in Venice
text: “It might surprise some people, but seafood isn’t represented all that well here,” said the chef Greg Daniels about the Los Angeles waterfront community of Venice. Formerly the executive sous chef at the Jean-Georges restaurant Perry St. in Manhattan, Daniels headed west to change that with Salt Air, a new “beach bistro” that was opened this week by the restaurateur David Reiss and the socialite couple Moise and Carol Ann Emquies on the trendy shopping strip of Abbot Kinney Boulevard.

headline: Week in Review: Cracking Down on Consultants
text: Regulator in New York sets tough bank fine. | Regulators are divided regarding consultants. | Consultants may face tighter rein from Albany. | Headhunter for the rich turned on them, says Andrew Ross Sorkin.

headline: Umbilical Adventures of Sons and Mother
text: “The Silver Cord,” a musty 1926 play by Sidney Howard, has little to hold the interest of a modern audience, but the Peccadillo Theater Company’s revival of it at the Theater at St. Clement’s at least gives you a few things to think about during the frequent moments when your attention may wander.

headline: Catsimatidis’s Theatrical Bond With La Guardia
text: Ask anyone running for mayor of New York City which municipal chieftain they most admire, the answer is bound to be Fiorello H. La Guardia, the diminutive firebrand who brought airports, wisecracks and man-of-the-people populism to City Hall during the Great Depression and World War II.

headline: In a Conductor’s Playlist, Some Daunting Chasms
text: Anyone who’s ever compiled a playlist for a radio show, dance floor or iPod knows that the main objective is picking cuts that sound good together. There’s a special joy in hooking up tracks that are intrinsically connected, especially if the glue in the seams doesn’t show. The program Alan Gilbert assembled for the concert that the New York Philharmonic presented on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall — the third installment in the “Gilbert’s Playlist” series — succeeded on both counts.

headline: João Renato da Silva
text: João Renato da Silva, 47, computer instructor, São Paulo.

headline: Quinn Goes to Bat for Theater Troupe Over Parking Fees
text: The play is apparently not the thing to catch the conscience of the New York City Department of Transportation, which has billed the Drilling Company for the parking spaces the theater troupe uses for its free Shakespeare in the Parking Lot performances, and has required the company to purchase automobile liability insurance.

headline: William
text: William, 25, computer technician.

headline: Sabrina Menedotti
text: Sabrina Menedotti, 22, writer, São Paulo.

headline: Madalena Vilar
text: 19, student, São Paulo

headline: In Immigration Reform, Republican Support for Citizenship Hinges on Obstacles
text: Two Republican senators reached a deal this week on a plan to strengthen the border security provisions of the immigration overhaul currently working its way through the Senate. Many G.O.P. legislators have said that tough border security measures are needed to garner enough Republican votes to pass a bill that also provides a path to citizenship for immigrants living in the United States illegally.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Pakistan, Indonesia, Singapore and India.

headline: Real Estate Q & A
text: Buying a Tenant-Occupied Condo

headline: For CNN, Fame Trumps News on Sunday Nights
text: CNN unveils its Sunday-night makeover this weekend, and if the goal was to look a little bit more like every other cable channel, then mission accomplished.

headline: The Calm Before the First Serve
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The reporter sitting next to me said he loved the All England Lawn Tennis Club on days like Friday.

headline: Favorite Summer Dishes: One Vote for Porgy
text: Summer has officially hit town. It would be impossible to select the most summery dish in New York City (please feel free to offer your own nominations below), but I believe a strong case could be made for the the Caribbean-style porgy at Má Pêche.

headline: Maurizio Cattelan’s Shocking Window Displays at the Palais de Tokyo
text: When the Italian polymath Maurizio Cattelan announced his retirement from the art world in 2011 on the eve of a major retrospective at the Guggenheim, few people really believed him, and for good reason. The perennial prankster has continued to produce imagery via Toilet Paper, the salacious biannual he creates with the commercial photographer Pierpaolo Ferrari. Since its inaugural issue in 2010, the magazine has regularly published 2-D works with the same eccentric qualities as Cattelan’s sculptures. (An anthology was released last year.) Its spreads are scabrous and surreal, cartoonish and sublime: an eyeball staring from a man’s mouth, a playing card held between a woman’s buttocks, a half-eaten bar of soap. Though much of the work will elicit laughter, Cattelan and Ferrari take it very seriously. “Toilet Paper images are the realization of everyone’s most intimate, hidden and unspeakable desires and urges,” Cattelan said. “What makes a Toilet Paper image is the attempt to say something terrible while staying quiet.”

headline: Family Tragic in Its Own Way, and Comic in All the Others
text: Aunt June is a special kind of born-again Christian, and not just because she is played by Eve Plumb, who will forever be the put-upon middle daughter of “The Brady Bunch.” June may pray for her sinful relatives right in front of them (and she considers listening to NPR a sin). She may take courses at Oral Roberts University. But at the end of the day, June relaxes in a designer negligee given her by a male admirer (although her divorce, at least her second, is not final) and enjoys numerous glasses of wine.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Morningside Heights co-op on the top floor of a prewar building; a West Village one-bedroom with a shared garden; and four-bedroom in Brooklyn Heights with two baths.

headline: São Paulo Protesters Speak Out
text: Demonstrations against an increase in bus fares in Brazil started in São Paulo. They have since spread through the country and expanded in scope to criticize public services and corruption.

headline: Ex-Enron Chief’s Sentence Is Cut by 10 Years, to 14
text: The prison sentence of Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron who spearheaded the pervasive fraud that destroyed the energy company, was reduced by 10 years on Friday after a federal judge approved a deal between his lawyers and prosecutors.

headline: Brother, Can You Spare My Sanity?
text: Here they are, New York, the ultimate brother-and-sister act, a pair of genetically matched hams who combine the narcissism, fearfulness, shabbiness and splendor of every actor who ever walked the boards. They are also competitive and codependent in a fierce, scary way that is particularly associated with show people and siblings. Just put them on a stage, then step back and watch them burn, possibly to a pile of ashes.

headline: Crazy, Wacky and Elegant
text: “I had this idea of all the holidays you can think of, but somebody had taken them before me,” said the designer Richard Mishaan about his dining room for the first Holiday House Hamptons, a show house with a festival theme opening Sunday. Not to be discouraged, Mr. Mishaan, one of 24 designers outfitting a 7,900-square-foot building in Bridgehampton, N.Y., painted his walls the sublime azure of a glacial lake, added bright blue miniatures of the “Venus de Milo” and “Winged Victory of Samothrace,” and declared the room a celebration of the French artist Yves Klein’s birthday.

headline: Homophobia in the Ring Delivers Fatal Blows
text: ST. LOUIS — Toward the end of Terence Blanchard’s “Champion,” which received its premiere this week at the Opera Theater of Saint Louis here, the protagonist, Emile Griffith, relives the terror of being attacked by homophobic thugs. “I killed a man and the world forgives me; I love a man and the world wants to kill me,” he sings despairingly.

headline: Paying Artful Homage
text: Thursday was art appreciation day in fashion. It started with a morning press conference at the Guggenheim Museum, where Dior, with the designer Raf Simons present, announced its sponsorship of the Guggenheim International Gala honoring James Turrell and Christopher Wool.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A Cos Cob contemporary on 1.19 acres bordering the Mianus River and 1920 house in Pelham with additional living quarters above a three-car garage.

headline: When Too Much Is Just Right
text: “I JUST WENT to this amazing party in Venice,” said Barbara Berger as she walked into the lobby of the Four Seasons hotel on Monday morning, lugging a cheap red wheelie to a table in the lobby.

headline: Who Needs the Critics? Go Cryptic Instead
text: For all but the most knowledgeable pop-music fans, Jay-Z’s three-minute commercial during the N.B.A. finals last Sunday might have been perplexing. The black-and-white spot showed a rumpled Jay-Z working on music in a studio. Its documentary style created the impression the viewer was eavesdropping on a session as the rapper talked with producers in poetic terms about an album. It ended with a cryptic text message on screen, “The Next Big Thing Is Here” and below it the Web site magnacartaholygrail.com.

headline: Cacio e Pepe With Favas and Peas
text: Melissa Clark adds fava beans and fresh peas to a classic Italian dish of pasta with black pepper and cheese.

headline: Molly: Pure, but Not So Simple
text: At a party not long ago in Park Slope, Brooklyn, Kaitlin, a 22-year-old senior at Columbia University, was recalling the first time she was offered a drug called Molly, at the elegant Brooklyn home of a cultural figure she admired. “She was, like, 50, and she had been written about in the Talk of the Town,” said Kaitlin, who was wearing black skinny jeans and a tank top. “This woman was very smart and impressive.”

headline: Set for Changes, Rangers Introduce Vigneault as Coach
text: The Rangers introduced Alain Vigneault as their coach Friday, ushering in a more creative and attack-minded approach to hockey. But the occasion was almost as much about who was not there — primarily John Tortorella, the Rangers’ previous coach, and Mark Messier, the former Ranger who was passed over for the job.

headline: These Beans Look Better Undressed
text: I knew that in Italy they don’t necessarily peel their fava beans. But I wasn’t prepared for the actuality when I ordered cacio e pepe pasta with favas at a small trattoria in Rome on a recent vacation.

headline: She’s Done With Washing It Away
text: I’m 57 but look like an old lady. That’s because my hair is gray.

headline: From the Middle Ages to the Middle-Aged
text: THERE ARE MANY magical perks in the Harry Potter universe that we might want in our world, but we can be thankful that others stay firmly bound between book covers. Foremost among them: the Dementors, those floating wraiths made of mildew and hate who suck all the youthful life out of you like some malevolent spiritual vacuum cleaner.

headline: Bright Spots Amid Low Ratings for ‘Hannibal’
text: The ratings for the NBC drama “Hannibal,” which stars Mads Mikkelsen as the serial killer Hannibal Lecter, have almost been as scary as the character himself.

headline: An Advice Book by a 28-Year-Old? Not Quite
text: There was a crucial moment in the life of Kelly Williams Brown when she realized that she had not made the necessary leap into adulthood: she was moving into a new apartment, and her furniture, made of particleboard, disintegrated in the rain.

headline: Names (And Campaigns) That Rankle
text: As it reintroduces the Cherokee nameplate, Jeep says it is sensitive to concerns about racial stereotypes. In the past, some automakers were not so cautious.

headline: Finding Unclaimed Assets, for a Fee
text: In a just-published Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan examines businesses that charge fees to reunite people with unclaimed assets. States have more than $40 billion in their unclaimed property programs, from paychecks and insurance deposits to stocks and retirement accounts.

headline: Tesla Fast-Tracks Battery Swapping While Fighting a Legislative Attack
text: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=shdHVGYQonQ

headline: They Didn’t Pack Sunscreen, or Anything Else
text: When you hear about “Naked and Afraid,” the new Discovery reality series that puts a woman and a man in the jungle for 21 days with no food, water or clothes, questions arise. Some have to do with sunscreen, but the two important ones are:

headline: Kia’s Great Pretender
text: From style to features, the 2014 Forte comes across as a pricier midsize car trapped in a slightly smaller body.

headline: Daredevil’s Latest Test: Remaking Japan’s Democracy
text: TOKYO — AT age 70, Hidetoshi Masunaga still skis, doing so in a manner that would terrify people half his age. He dons a helmet, points his skis straight downhill and barrels along like a one-man rocket in a test of his own courage and physical endurance.

headline: Devices Given to Chinese Legal Advocate Had Tracking Spyware, N.Y.U. Says
text: BEIJING — Dissidents inside China have long been accustomed to a lack of privacy in their daily routines. Phone conversations are monitored, e-mails are read and public security agents trail human rights activists when they venture outside their homes.

headline: A Pretty Package With a Lot of Toy Surprises Inside
text: Every automotive underdog might take a hint from the Kia Forte: if you’re a back-bencher in a house of big names, it can’t hurt to make your car pretty.

headline: As Hezbollah Fights in Syria, Life Changes in a Lebanese Border Town
text: HERMEL, Lebanon — The procession was small as Hezbollah funerals go, just a few hundred people winding past wind-tossed olive trees through this remote Bekaa Valley village. Still, the mourners honored the fighter killed in Syria with the usual solemn choreography: the coffin draped with a flag, the uniformed Boy Scouts bearing his portrait, the women carrying babies and wreaths of roses.

headline: When Cars Assume Ethnic Identities
text: Coming to a showroom near you for 2014: the first sport utility vehicle in its class equipped with a 9-speed automatic transmission. It’s also the first to offer a parallel-parking feature. And, in 4-wheel-drive models, the rear axle disconnects automatically, for fuel efficiency.

headline: What Difference a Fee Makes
text: A change in plan fees of just 1 percentage point could make a difference of 17 percent, or $15,000, over 20 years in the value of a hypothetical retirement account starting with $25,000.

headline: The Baby Name Remix
text: From locations to inanimate objects to names that scream swagger, musicians and their partners are known for extending their creativity to naming their children.

headline: Providing Kim Kardashian and Kanye West’s Baby With Direction
text: Maybe they should just call her Kimye. When Kim Kardashian and Kanye West had a baby girl on June 15, the Twittersphere went agog over possible baby names. It starts with a K. It doesn’t start with a K. And so on. By Friday morning, when “North West” was reported by TMZ and others, the name became a trending topic on Twitter worldwide.

headline: The Man Who Captured a Times Square That Is No More
text: This weekend’s Look section features rare photographs of the early “Saturday Night Live” cast hanging out in New York City in the mid-’70s. The pictures are from a larger series taken in Times Square by a photographer named Kenneth Siegel, who died at the age of 44 in 1994.

headline: Wright’s New York Showroom, Now Just a Memory
text: A small landmark of New York City architectural and automotive history disappeared recently, almost without notice. The theatrical auto showroom designed by Frank Lloyd Wright at 430 Park Avenue, at 56th Street, had displayed a number of European brands over the years, notably Mercedes-Benz from 1957 to 2012.

headline: Ford Brings Back the Dial
text: Have the Luddites won, or has common sense prevailed?

headline: Summer Inspiration From Vietnam
text: When it comes to fresh Vietnamese-style rolls like this one, which usually contain a few cooked prawns, along with herbs and rice vermicelli, a few questions tend to arise.

headline: What Else Could a $30 Billion ‘Border Surge’ Buy?
text: Yesterday we learned that two Senate Republicans have joined forces to revive the immigration legislation that’s wallowing in Congress due to inter-party bickering. Bob Corker of Tennessee and John Hoeven of North Dakota are calling their deal a “border surge.” As Lawrence Downes wrote on this blog, “This obviously calls to mind similar surges in harsh desert regions where the United States is deploying troops and drones.”

headline: Niese’s Injury Is One Step Back for Mets’ Staff
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Mets this week seemed to be accelerating faster than ever toward their often-discussed but still-hypothetical future, when a successful club will coalesce around a young pitching staff.

headline: Prospect Park Lake, 8:45 A.M.
text: On Thursday, the mallard ducklings hatched. On Friday they went for a walk and soaked in the sun.

headline: The Train Line Fixer
text: As assistant chief transportation officer for New York City Transit, Pamela Elsey plans repairs, maintenance and capital improvements on all 24 subway routes, which run over 660 miles of track and serve more than 5.4 million riders daily. Ms. Elsey, 59, started as a railroad clerk in 1985, selling tokens. She was soon promoted to a tower operator and then a train dispatcher. In her nearly 30-year career with the transit agency, she has been superintendent of all but one of the departments she now oversees. A Brooklyn resident, Ms. Elsey rides the subway daily.

headline: The Cost of Admission
text: Doing good work doesn’t come cheap. Here is a sampling of what it would cost to attend a benefit for some of New York’s most prominent social and charitable institutions. (One mitigating factor: a portion of the ticket’s face value is usually tax deductible.)

headline: The Women Who Really Run the House
text: Forget good help. You can’t find help, period.

headline: Only Their Accountants Know for Sure
text: They may be at the same events, but the prices paid by two archetypal New York socialites (one newly arrived on the social scene, the other an established grande dame) to attend five big-ticket galas during the city’s nine-month social season can vary widely.

headline: Cacio e Pepe With Any Firm Vegetable
text: Fava beans star in this week’s column and video; I add them along with green peas to a variation on cacio e pepe, pasta with black pepper and cheese.

headline: Norma Shelley Saratoga Regional
text: Justine Cushing and Melih Ozdil were the most successful players from New York City at the Norma Shelley Saratoga Regional in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., from June 10 to 16. They won one pair event, and with Joel Wooldridge of New York City and David Grainger of Roseville, Calif., captured two team titles and tied for a third.

headline: What Price Generosity?
text: Just the muted click of cameras announced their arrival the other night at the Conservatory Ball, the annual spring fund-raising party of the New York Botanical Garden. Alighting on a swatch of crimson runner and posing gamely for photographers were the Fendi heiress Fé Fendi, swathed in a Carolina

headline: In Europe to Hunt a Killer? Pack an Accent
text: “Crossing Lines,” an appealing crime series that begins Sunday night on NBC, might not get the respect it deserves for a couple of reasons. Structurally it resembles other shows centering on a superstar team of detectives, each with a specialty. It’s scheduled as a summer throwaway and on a night that, for the two-part premiere, pits it against the season finale of “Mad Men.” And it has the kind of multinational production lineage that can suggest a network is trying to fill out its lineup on the cheap.

headline: Rattlestick Season Includes World Premieres and Five-Play Cycle
text: Rattlestick Playwrights Theater’s 2013-14 season will include new plays by Off Broadway veterans like Charles Fuller and Craig Lucas, alongside works by the rising stars Samuel D. Hunter and Halley Feiffer, the theater has announced.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Flapper’s Delight
text: The flapper style of the Roaring Twenties, improvised by many guests at Jazz on Governors Island, has been a popular look on the party circuit this spring.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: 250 Million Messagers, and Instagram Videos
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Flavors of Cuba, at Full Volume
text: I looked forward to visiting Dolce Cubano, a new waterfront restaurant at Stamford Landing, because its owners also run ZaZa, an Italian gastro pub I like in downtown Stamford. I was in no way disappointed, despite an excruciatingly high decibel level (even on a Monday night).

headline: Protests Bridge Brazil’s Social Gaps
text: Demonstrations by students against a bus fare increase have evolved into countrywide protests with citizens of all backgrounds denouncing the government.

headline: Sicilian Protest Imperils Exhibition
text: When it began its tour at the J. Paul Getty Museum in April, “Sicily: Art and Invention Between Greece and Rome” was supposed to crown years of effort by some American museums to patch up relations with Italy over claims of looted antiquities.

headline: Mediterranean Favorites in a Relaxing Oasis
text: Nemea Greek Taverna is close enough to Mamaroneck’s lively main street to be convenient, yet far enough away to serve as a relaxing oasis. The quiet dining room is a haven for those wanting a leisurely meal or simply a glass of wine and a snack.

headline: East on North Fork, a New Winery
text: The 62-acre Kontokosta Winery in Greenport, the easternmost winery on the North Fork, opened this month with a sizable portfolio of eight wines, featuring impressive reds.

headline: The Look and Flavors of the Greek Isles
text: Roslyn, with three excellent Greek restaurants, probably has better Greek food than many towns in Greece. The first to appear, in 2008, was Limani, an elegant, expensive place that served fish priced by the pound. (It now has conventional menu pricing.) Next came MP Taverna, in 2011, a more rustic spot with lots of dark wood and very reasonable prices. Now a new restaurant, Kyma (pronounced KEE-ma), is staking out a spot between the other two in its pricing and its décor.

Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor whose leak of agency documents has set off a national debate over the proper limits of government surveillance, has been charged with violating the Espionage Act and stealing government property for disclosing classified information to The Guardian and The Washington Post, the Justice Department said on Friday.

headline: Entering a Monstrous Family Business
text: “YOUNG FRANKENSTEIN” at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport becomes truly hilarious toward the end, when Dr. Frederick Frankenstein and his creation, a giant, green-faced Monster, pair up for a glittery soft-shoe to Irving Berlin’s “Puttin’ on the Ritz.” But even before then, the production is delightfully entertaining — not what one might expect given the critical drubbing the musical received after its 2007 Broadway opening.

headline: California Pushes for Immigrant Health
text: LOS ANGELES — When Congress passed President Obama’s health care overhaul, a critical compromise provision was that immigrants living in the United States illegally would not be allowed access to publicly subsidized health insurance. Even now, as lawmakers in Washington are debating an overhaul of immigration laws, leaders from both parties are arguing that no federal money should be spent on health care for immigrants on their way to obtaining citizenship.

text: THE Dow Jones industrial average has nose-dived more than 500 points, or over 3 percent, since the Federal Reserve chairman Ben S. Bernanke’s somewhat upbeat, if ambiguous, statement on the economy on Wednesday. Hurrah!

headline: Brazil’s Vinegar Uprising
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — LAST week I watched a video of a man arrested for possession of a bottle of vinegar. The man, a journalist named Piero Locatelli, was covering the protests here when a policeman asked to search his backpack. Like other demonstrators, he had brought some vinegar. The idea is that breathing through a cloth soaked in vinegar neutralizes the effects of tear gas, though this doesn’t really seem to work. The police claim that the product can be used to make bombs, but this is even less true.

headline: Rivers Still Coaches Celtics, but Trade Is Not Ruled Out
text: The on-again, off-again discussions between the Boston Celtics and the Los Angeles Clippers over the fate of Celtics Coach Doc Rivers took a strange turn Friday when the Celtics scheduled a news conference with Rivers and General Manager Danny Ainge, then canceled it 90 minutes later.

headline: Confidence From Chief of SoftBank in Sprint Bid
text: TOKYO — In 2005, SoftBank was in dire straits. The scrappy Internet services company had booked a $1 billion loss the previous year, its largest ever. A campaign to enter Japan’s strictly regulated cellphone business had failed. Its share price, which had soared with the Internet bubble, had fallen to less than a tenth of its height in 2000.
