headline: Mr. Christie vs. Affordable Housing
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has tried to undermine the state’s commitment to affordable housing at every turn. In addition to trying to dismantle the independent state agency that oversees affordable housing development, he has sought to weaken the state law that prohibits local governments from using zoning to exclude housing for poor and working-class people.

headline: Supercharged Saturday
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Back on the planet Krypton, Superman was not faster than a speeding bullet, nor was he more powerful than a locomotive. Quite the opposite. He was born under a red sun, according to comic-book dogma, and its red rays canceled out his innate Kryptonian powers. But upon reaching Earth, Superman discovered that the kindly beams of our yellow sun had the opposite effect on him, endowing him with super-strengths like the ability to, say, leap tall buildings in a single bound.

headline: Turkish Capital Heats Up as Protests Subside in Istanbul

And around midnight in Turkey’s normally staid capital, riot police officers beat back chanting protesters with pepper spray and tear gas.

headline: The Lawsuit and the N.C.A.A.
text: In 1951, a man named Walter Byers became the first-ever executive director of the N.C.A.A., an organization that at the time was both toothless and penniless. That year, the N.C.A.A. had been forced to abandon its short-lived “Sanity Code,” an effort to rein in excesses in college athletics. Byers, who had been an assistant at the Big Ten Conference, was given a room at the Big Ten for his office. He had one employee: his assistant. He was 29 years old.

headline: Farmers Say Bill’s Defeat Complicates Planning for Planting Season
text: WASHINGTON — On Thursday afternoon, staff members at the Farm Bureau, the country’s largest agriculture trade group, were putting the final touches on a news release congratulating House members for passing a farm bill. But as more and more members cast their votes, the trade group realized that the bill was going to go down in defeat.

headline: Helicopter Crashes in Nicaragua With Senior Officers on Board
text: A helicopter carrying senior officers of Nicaragua’s air force, including its second highest-ranking member, Col. Manuel Antonio López García, crashed Thursday, and all 10 people on board are presumed dead, military officials said Friday. Officials said a team had recovered the body of one of the passengers, Col. Mario Alberto Jirón López, who was in charge of a repair base, as well as other human remains and pieces of the MI-17 military helicopter. After attending a training mission near Lake Managua, in the northwestern region, the group was on its way to Managua, the capital, when the crew reported the need to make an emergency landing. A special commission has been formed to investigate the cause of the crash.

headline: Egyptian President’s Supporters Rally
text: Huge crowds of Islamist demonstrators packed a Cairo traffic circle and several surrounding streets on Friday in a show of support for President Mohamed Morsi as he approaches the anniversary of his inauguration as Egypt’s first freely elected leader. Many Egyptians are discontented with Mr. Morsi over his running of the country and the state of the economy, and his opponents are calling for mass protests on the anniversary, June 30, that they hope will drive him from power. Friday’s protesters, most of them from the Muslim Brotherhood and other Islamist groups, marched under a banner saying “No to Violence” and accused the opposition of trying to subvert the democratic process. Egypt’s intense political polarization and violent language from activists on both sides have raised fears that the anniversary protests will unleash new unrest.

headline: 2 More Educators in the South Are Charged in Test Cheating
text: A test cheating ring that spanned 15 years across three Southern states ensnared two more educators this week.

headline: Brazil’s World Cup Winners Support Protests
text: Lat Updated, Saturday, 8:53 a.m. One day after peaceful protests in Rio de Janeiro and other cities descended into chaotic street battles between protesters and the police, and tensions boiled over between factions within the demonstrations as well, a congressman who once helped Brazil win a World Cup railed against the cost of staging next year’s tournament.

headline: Breaking Medicine’s Color Barrier
text: On Jan. 7, 1863, just six days after the Emancipation Proclamation authorized African-American men to serve in the Union Army and Navy, Dr. Alexander T. Augusta, a freeman born in Norfolk, Va., wrote to President Lincoln requesting to serve as a surgeon “to some of the coloured regiments, or as physician to some of the depots of ‘freedmen.’” The 37-year-old Augusta had attended Trinity Medical College in Toronto; as he explained in his letter, “I was compelled to leave my native country, and come to this on account of prejudices against colour, for the purpose of obtaining knowledge of my profession; and having accomplished that object … I am now prepared to practice it, and would like to be in a position where I can be of use to my race.”

headline: North Carolina: Gunman Injures 4
text: A man opened fire in a law firm and a Walmart parking lot in Greenville, N.C., on Friday, injuring four people before being captured, the police said. The gunman fired a shotgun at one person at the Kellum Law Firm, then crossed a busy street and shot three more people, Police Chief Hassan Aden said. The authorities have not released the suspect’s name. The police exchanged gunfire with the suspect, injuring him. The victims and the suspect were being treated at a hospital.

headline: Game 7 of N.B.A. Finals Draws High TV Ratings
text: The Miami Heat’s defeat of the San Antonio Spurs in the N.B.A. finals averaged nearly 17.7 million viewers on ABC, the most to watch the Spurs play for the league championship. The higher numbers were helped by a series that went seven games and because the Spurs’ opponent was the LeBron James-led Heat.

headline: Escaping to a Tiki-Chic Hot Spot in SoHo
text: The ideal three-hour tour at Gilligan’s, a pop-up oasis in the sun-dappled yard of the SoHo Grand Hotel, seems to be a languorous loop among the bars. The nautical theme at this three-week-old tiki-chic hot spot hits you over the head with a coconut. Life preservers, white bamboo walls, palm trees, a wooden captain’s wheel, the server’s red shorts: all accounted for. The people who brought the bar Moby Dick’s to the Hamptons last summer have brought the Hamptons to Manhattan this time. The succinct menu features wood-fired rectangular pizzas and other items from the center grill; the fit and fashionable guests pay in advance and receive a numbered buoy to place on their picnic table. Celebrities seem to blend in, and dogs get their own water dishes. Music wafts pleasantly, and the after-work vibe is so jaunty, you might never want to leave.

headline: Rookie’s Big Night Feels Like the Good, Old Days of a Few Weeks Ago
text: During the first part of the Yankees’ season, the baseball world marveled at the contributions made by the cast of castoffs the team had assembled. These Yankees were a gritty bunch, an easily likable group because they had been so lightly regarded, unlike past Yankees teams that were littered with All-Stars at every position.

headline: Running on Israel Time
text: Jane Eisner, 57, who in 2008 was named the first female editor in chief in the history of the 116-year-old Jewish Daily Forward, moved to New York last year after four years of long-distance commuting from the Philadelphia suburbs. She and her husband, Dr. Mark Berger, an oncologist, live in a three-bedroom apartment on Riverside Drive in the 80s with their dog, Charlie. The couple try to spend Sundays taking in the culture of the city, in between running, doing some work and seeing their grown daughter — one of three — who lives in Brooklyn.

text: Q. I don’t remember when, but there was a New York City political campaign that included a jingle:

headline: The Signs of the Brazilian Protests
text: A look at the variety of slogans employed by protesters in Brazil.

headline: Last Call for ‘the Saloon Priest’
text: The Rev. Peter Colapietro was playing down the fuss — the goodbyes from the neighborhood people, the Mass scheduled for Sunday to celebrate his years at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church, in the shadow of Times Square. “I’m just moving to the East Side,” he said.

headline: Envisioning Higher Office, Going by Texas Rail
text: The Railroad Commission of Texas may seem like a regulatory backwater. It oversees regulation of the oil and gas business in Texas, and when that involved prices and production limits and such, it was a powerful force indeed. A lieutenant governor gave up his job for a spot on the commission; a speaker of the House did the same thing.

headline: A Policy Keeps Some Texas Doctors From the Delivery Room
text: When Jeff Alling, a family physician, moved to Wise County more than 20 years ago, he was one of only two doctors in the rural North Texas community qualified to deliver babies. Since then, he has delivered more than 2,000.

headline: A Jazz Mission, Not in a Jazz Age
text: At a time when the jazz world feels increasingly irrelevant, Meghan Stabile is a woman on a mission: to make jazz matter to the hip-hop generation.

headline: New York Finally Realizes Tacos Are Breakfast Food
text: Texas food typically doesn’t thrive outside Texas — especially not in New York, the culinary punch line to San Antonio-based Pace Picante Sauce’s old series of television commercials, in which a campfire cook tries to serve salsa made in the Big Apple.

headline: The Making of a Modern Impresario
text: Nights just seem to go like this for Meghan Stabile. It was a Thursday in mid-May, at the nightclub Drom in the East Village — just a small gig by a young jazz pianist trying to build an audience for a very esoteric series of concerts that he called Music and Architecture. Ms. Stabile, 30, had been hired to promote the show through e-mail and social media. She scanned the sparse crowd for familiar faces, exchanging hugs, CDs, promises to work together soon.

headline: The Disney World Urbanism of a C.E.O. Candidate
text: Money often has a way of breeding extreme confidence in those who have ample supplies of it — leading some wealthy people to believe, for instance, that if they know how to walk they will be able to go helicopter skiing, that if they’ve read “Anna Karenina” perhaps they could teach a course in Russian novels.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 9 P.M. (Starz) TO ROME WITH LOVE (2012) In this tribute to the Italian cinema of the 1950s and ’60s by Woody Allen, a retired, and overly psychoanalyzed, music promoter (Mr. Allen) travels with his wife (Judy Davis) to Rome, where their daughter (Alison Pill) has lost her heart to an earnest lawyer devoted to left-wing causes (Flavio Parenti). Meanwhile in this shuffled anthology, a young newlywed loses her way to the Trevi Fountain and into the arms of a movie star while her befuddled husband tries to keep his relatives in the dark, substituting a prostitute (Penélope Cruz, above with Alessandro Tiberi) for her at dinner. An ordinary Roman (Roberto Benigni) is plunged into a swirl of media celebrity. And a fledgling architect (Jesse Eisenberg) finds his relationship with his kind, if bland, girlfriend (Greta Gerwig) blown to smithereens when her neurotic actress friend (Ellen Page) shows up for a visit. Alec Baldwin plays the older architect — a ghost? a specter of the younger man’s self? — who witnesses the ordeal. “One of the most delightful things about ‘To Rome With Love’ is how casually it blends the plausible and the surreal, and how unabashedly it revels in pure silliness,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The limitations of ‘To Rome With Love,’ as frothy as the milk atop a cappuccino, are finally inseparable from its delights. Some of the scenes feel rushed and haphazardly constructed, and the dialogue frequently sounds overwritten and under-rehearsed. But this may just be to say that we are watching late-period Woody Allen. Complaining would be as superfluous — though also, perhaps, as inevitable — as psychoanalysis.”

headline: When the Himalayas Poured
text: The floods in northern India have killed more than 600 pilgrims in Uttarakhand state. As rescuers comb the debris of the mountainous state, hundreds of bodies are expected to be found in the coming days.

headline: From Today’s Paper: Heavy Toll Mounts in India’s Flooding
text: Above, a man pleaded with a soldier to allow him to board an army helicopter on Friday as the death toll from monsoon flooding in mountainous northern India reached nearly 600.

headline: Greg Mankiw and the Gatsby Curve
text: A number of people have already piled on to Greg Mankiw over his defense of the one percent (pdf). Yet I do have something to add.

headline: Debased Economics
text: John Boehner’s remarks on recent financial events have attracted a lot of unfavorable comment, and they should. Actually, I think even the stuff most commentators have shied away from — he talks about the Fed “deflating” when I think he means either inflating or debasing, or possibly is doing a Sarah Palin and merging the two — is significant. I mean, he’s the Speaker of the House at a time when economic issues are paramount; shouldn’t he have basic familiarity with simple economic terms?

headline: J.W. Anderson and the Addictive Rush of Fashion

headline: The New New Thing in U.S.-Indian Relations?
text: Sometime early in the last decade, official Washington discovered India’s “strategic” value. The emblem of this revelation was the Bush administration’s civil-nuclear agreement, unveiled with great fanfare in 2005. The agreement was technically designed to allow peaceful nuclear cooperation with India despite its status then as a nonproliferation pariah, but the real purpose, as one architect of the accord put it, was to “forge the strategic partnership based on common values that had eluded both countries for many decades” and demonstrate how valuable Washington “deemed the U.S.-Indian partnership to be in meeting U.S. grand strategic objectives.”It was an act of faith: two big, diverse, sometimes exasperating democracies, the United States and India would surely find a way to do wonderful things together. India would be an ally in global causes, a counterweight to China, a shining example of democratic development.

text: NEW DELHI — Flash floods and landslides in northern India have killed at least 1,000 people in the Himalayan state of Uttarakhand in the past week, an official said Saturday, and with thousands missing or stranded the toll was expected to rise.

headline: Pilati Quietly Makes His Debut at Zegna
text: MILAN — The Italian designer Stefano Pilati has worked at Prada and Yves Saint Laurent, where he was creative director of women’s and men’s fashion for nearly a decade. At YSL, Mr. Pilati often seemed a square peg in a round hole, although, to be fair, no one has gotten the fit quite right except for Mr. Saint Laurent. Mr. Pilati put a lot into those collections — fabric research, religious symbolism, art references — and in a way they suffered for it. Sometimes you longed for the palliative of a beautifully cut suit or dress.

headline: Like His Successor, Bush Is Going to Africa
text: WASHINGTON – It’s not often that Africa sees a visiting American president, much less two. But as President Obama travels across the continent next week, so will his predecessor, George W. Bush.

headline: Data Security Is a Classroom Worry, Too
text: LIKE many privacy-minded parents of elementary students, Tony Porterfield tries to keep close tabs on the personal information collected about his two sons. So when he heard that their school district in Los Altos, Calif., had adopted Edmodo, an online learning network connecting more than 20 million teachers and students around the world, he decided to check out the program.

headline: Guided by Sheffield, Journeyman Pitcher Is Now a Star
text: CINCINNATI — If you want a luxurious tropical getaway, closer than you think for a great price, Gary Sheffield has the spot for you. Near the Sunshine Skyway Bridge on Florida’s Gulf Coast, across from Skinny’s Place, the best hamburger joint around, is the Anna Maria Island Beach Resort.

headline: Blue Jays Are Beginning to Pick Up the Pieces
text: Alex Anthopoulos did not build the Toronto Blue Jays’ roster with hopes of winning just half the time. The Blue Jays have had enough mediocrity over the last two decades, and they expected to contend this season.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Men’s Shorts That Are Loose, but Refined
text: There’s a longer, fuller type of shorts on the runways so far this season, and not the athletic Airtex kind made for shooting hoops. More tailored and often pleated, this version is inspired by the shape of colonial-era Ghurkha shorts, with a fixed waist and a slightly ballooning leg. Alexander McQueen’s airy, cuffed ivory pair evoked “Brideshead Revisited,” while James Long’s black nylon jacquard model had a more techy look. Kolor showed a surfer-inspired floral printed style with a dropped paper-bag waist attached to a more fitted, contrasting waistband, which created a layered effect. Get to work on those gams, guys, because these shorts aren’t for spindly shanks.

headline: After a Decline in Offense, Some Want a Livelier College Ball
text: OMAHA — Trea Turner of North Carolina State was so sure he had cracked a go-ahead three-run homer in the eighth inning against U.C.L.A. on Tuesday that he flipped his bat and pumped a fist.

headline: Trainers Are Drawn to Britain for Racing’s Prestige
text: ASCOT, England — The queen won the Royal Ascot Gold Cup here Thursday, stopping for a moment the continuous parade to the winners’ circle by Irish horsemen. No, the fix was not in. It was the first time a reigning monarch’s horse had won the meeting’s signature race in its 207-year history.

headline: Variety: A Complicated Villain
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Cryptic crosswords are always complicated, but today’s puzzle offers not only challenging clues to decipher but a theme to match. More on the theme in a minute.

headline: Kerry, in Qatar, Warns Taliban While Also Building Support on Syria
text: DOHA, Qatar — Secretary of State John Kerry warned Saturday that the newly opened Taliban office here “has to be closed” if the insurgents do not respond to demands that they negotiate in good faith.

headline: Researching a Tennis Legacy, and Uncovering a Potential Injustice
text: The world is a daunting haystack when looking for century-old needles. For a good portion of her adult life, Anna Wilding has made it a pastime, searching for artifacts and information on her great-uncle, a long-deceased tennis champion named Tony.

headline: Spurs’ Strategy, Built Over Years, Falls One Win Short
text: After their grueling victory over the San Antonio Spurs, LeBron James and Miami Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra made sure to point out that this series, and these Spurs, were the toughest test they had faced in their three years together.

headline: Murray Is Querrey’s Pick to Win Wimbledon
text: STOKE PARK, England – When it comes to picking a potential winner of a Grand Slam, most players chose to tread safely, doling out the kind of well-honed response that carefully avoids committing to any definite conclusions. In short, the kind of response that had Ernests Gulbis sputtering into his morning coffee.

headline: Despite Assurances by Brazil’s President, Another Day of Demonstrations
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Another round of demonstrations unfolded in cities throughout Brazil on Saturday, after many in the country’s sweeping protest movement angrily dismissed an effort by President Dilma Rousseff to address their broad demands.

headline: 2 Executed by Hamas as Informers
text: GAZA — The Hamas authorities in Gaza on Saturday executed two Palestinians convicted of providing information to Israel, raising to 16 the number of Gazans executed by the Islamic militant group for spying or other crimes since it took control of the Palestinian coastal territory in 2007.

headline: Helene Gayle of CARE, on Managers as Dual Citizens
text: This interview with  Helene D. Gayle, president and chief executive of CARE U.S.A., the anti-poverty organization, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Zimmerman Judge Bars Testimony On 911 Call
text: SANFORD, Fla. — The screams are clearly coming from a distraught male, whose repeated cries for help end abruptly with a gunshot. What is not clear from a recording of a 911 call, however, is the identity of the screamer: George Zimmerman, the volunteer community watchman, or Trayvon Martin, the unarmed 17-year-old he killed that night.

headline: For a Top Draft Prospect, Lightness Weighs Heavily
text: In the N.B.A., perhaps more than any sport, how tall and how heavy, or light, a player is matters. Football may require size at certain positions, baseball may value height in pitchers, but at every position in basketball, a player’s height and weight become a continual topic of discussion.

headline: Jil Sander
text: There were pops of color, patterns and reflective materials in the spring 2014 collection.

headline: N.B.A. Teams Disregard Stiletto Sneakers
text: When is a 7-footer not 7 feet tall? When he is at the N.B.A. draft combine. This year there are 12 players among the top 100 available who are listed in most places as being at least 7 feet tall. But for many of them, the 7-foot mark comes from shoes and optimism, as only one of them stands 7 feet without the assistance of footwear and rounding to the nearest inch.

headline: For Dell Investors, a Safety Valve
text: AFTER months of sometimes fractious debate on the merits or demerits of the proposed Dell Inc. buyout, decision time nears for the company’s shareholders. Investors have until July 18 to tender their stock to Michael Dell in his proposed $13.65-a-share deal that the special committee of Dell’s board has overseen.

headline: Jil Sander: Spring 2014 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Despite Lockout, Fans of N.H.L. Have Tuned In
text: Once upon a time, the National Hockey League’s owners locked out their players.

text: Health Care Systems,

headline: Health Care Systems, Lost in Translation
text: To the Editor:

headline: Another Side  of the Minimum Wage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Teammates Again Expected to Be Top Picks in N.H.L. Draft
text: TORONTO — Cam Russell was not going to make the same mistake he made with Sidney Crosby.

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Players to Watch at Wimbledon, Beyond the Perennial Contenders
text: The Wimbledon fortnight begins Monday with Novak Djokovic, the men’s No. 1 seed, hoping to reclaim the title he won in 2011 and with Serena Williams trying to add another Grand Slam title to her résumé after winning the French Open this month. But several other players are capable of making deep runs in the tournament. Here is a look at some of them.

headline: Halving the Portion, but Not the Price
text: PERHAPS this has happened to you.

headline: A Haven for Salmon, and for Salmon Fishers
text: MURMANSK, Russia — My fly skittered across the current in front of our jet boat on the Lower Tomba beat of Russia’s Ponoi River, darting erratically as the tension on my line increased. Suddenly, there was a violent splash, and I felt a significant tug. Then nothing.

headline: Event After the U.S. Open Brings a Bit of Relief
text: CROMWELL, Conn. — Few would disagree that the star of the 2013 United States Open was Merion Golf Club. Merion, a 101-year-old course outside Philadelphia, disproved claims that it was not long enough or fierce enough to challenge today’s professionals.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, June 23
text: “The Fed isn’t just the U.S.’s central bank. It’s the world’s central bank.”

headline: The Formula Behind the Voting Rights Act
text: The Supreme Court ruled that a formula used to define which areas fell under Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act was unconstitutional.

headline: Lee Bowes of America Works, on the Quest for Jobs
text: I SPENT most of my childhood in Boston. My parents were liberals who were very involved in social causes. My four siblings became artists. One brother, who has died, was a painter, and a second one still is. The third one writes, and my sister is a musician. Starting around the age of 9, I took private violin lessons and sang in a choir. Then in high school, my sister and I took a trolley after classes to a music conservatory for additional lessons.

headline: A Clinic Braces for Change
text: Patients and caregivers at Family Health Centers in Louisville, Ky., wonder how the Affordable Care Act will affect them. Part I in a series about the new health care law in action.

headline: Comparing Patient Profiles
text: Family Health Centers, a group of seven nonprofit health centers in the Louisville metro, has a large share of poor and uninsured patients..

headline: The Disestablishment of Marriage
text: AT first glance, the prognosis for marriage looks grim. Between 1950 and 2011, according to calculations by the University of Maryland sociologist Philip Cohen, the marriage rate fell from 90 marriages a year per 1,000 unmarried women to just 31, a stunning 66 percent decline. If such a decline continued, there would be no women getting married by 2043!

headline: When Your Office Is Someone Else’s Home
text: I WORKED in a business office for Verizon for seven years, but in 2006 I became one of its facilities technicians. In addition to installing fiber optic cables in people’s homes, I climb telephone poles to check customers’ cables and make service calls when there’s a problem. For example, if one of our set-top boxes hooked to a television needs to be rebooted, I’ll be assigned to do that.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Ermenegildo Zegna Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: A Scout’s Binder
text: Howie Garfinkel’s binders are meticulously kept despite their age and odor, and together they constitute a kind of informal biography of an 83-year-old obsessive basketball enthusiast. Here are some excerpts.

headline: Scout is a Five-Star Original in Basketball
text: The typewritten newsletter, reeking of tobacco smoke, is dated March 22, 1966. It contains dozens of succinct scouting reports on high school basketball players as well as a kind of conversational cover letter, full of inside jokes and the occasional literary flourish.

headline: The Federal Reserve’s Framers Would Be Shocked
Sunday Dialogue: Will Training More Doctors Improve Health Care?
text: Some readers say a better allocation of resources or healthier lifestyles are the answer.

headline: Social Networking in the 1600s
text: LONDON — SOCIAL networks stand accused of being enemies of productivity. According to one popular (if questionable) infographic circulating online, the use of Facebook, Twitter and other such sites at work costs the American economy $650 billion each year. Our attention spans are atrophying, our test scores declining, all because of these “weapons of mass distraction.”

headline: Approving Federal Judges
text: Judicial confirmation rates for three presidents.

headline: Rested Red Bulls Back in Action
text: It has been more than three weeks between league games for the Red Bulls — a time in which the club moved into a new training center and was supplanted in first place.

headline: A Zombie Scare With a Zombie Chaser
text: WASHINGTON — I LOVE my monsters, sacred or straight up.

headline: The Endless Battle Over Judicial Nominees
text: WASHINGTON — ONE of the easiest sentences for a political journalist to write is some version of “Both sides do it.” And one of the easiest arguments for an advocate to make is a version of “Only the other side does it.”

headline: Why a Health Insurance Penalty May Look Tempting
text: OFTEN, when the government wants you to do something, it makes you pay if you don’t. That would seem to be the case with Obamacare, which penalizes companies for not providing health care. But in that penalty, there could be a paradoxical result: dropping health coverage could save companies a lot of money.

headline: Andrew Warren
text: Admirers call the entomologist Andrew Warren “Lord of the Butterflies.” He is senior collections manager for the McGuire Center for Lepidoptera and Biodiversity at the Florida Museum of Natural History, president of the Lepidopterists’ Society and creator of the Butterflies of America Web site.

headline: Emerging Markets, Hitting a Wall
text: A GROWTH slowdown in the so-called BRICS nations — Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa — could be impeding the expansion of the global economy. That’s serious enough, and indeed we are seeing unrest in Brazil over stagnant living standards. Yet a graver problem may be lurking behind the headlines — namely, that sustained, meteoric growth in emerging economies may no longer be possible.

headline: How to Daydream
text: THERE is nothing wrong with spending vast quantities of time fantasizing about imaginary realities far away from the cheerless hardships of modern life. The problem is that people are daydreaming incorrectly. Because of widespread misuse, daydreaming has achieved the rank stigma of slothful procrastination.

headline: America Can Take a Breather. And It Should.
text: THE United States is currently enjoying an unprecedented respite in the foreign policy arena — a temporary relief from the normal rigors of history that allows us to take stock at home and abroad.

headline: Syria Scorecard
text: ISTANBUL — IF you look at it from 30,000 feet, what we’re actually dealing with in the Middle East today are the long-delayed consequences of the end of the Ottoman Empire. When the Ottoman Empire collapsed as a result of its defeat in World War I, the colonial powers Britain and France were right there, for their own interests, to impose their own order on the diverse tribes, sects and religions that make up the Arab East. When the British and French left after World War II, they handed power, in many cases, to monarchs, who, in many cases, gave way to generals, who, in all cases, kept their diverse populations in line with iron fists.

headline: Where Did Our ‘Inalienable Rights’ Go?
text: NOW that we sense the magnitude of our government’s effort to track Americans’ telephone and Internet transactions, the issue finally and fully before us is not how we balance personal privacy with police efficiency.

headline: The Misnomer of ‘Motherless’ Parenting
text: SOMETIMES when my daughter, who is 7, is nicely cuddled up in her bed and I snuggle her, she calls me Mommy. I am a stay-at-home dad. My male partner and I adopted both of our children at birth in open domestic adoptions. We could fill our home with nannies, sisters, grandmothers, female friends, but no mothers.

headline: Movies of the Future
text: EARLIER this month, at a symposium at the University of Southern California film school, George Lucas and Steven Spielberg predicted the collapse of most megabudget movies, and with it the end of Hollywood as it now exists. This sounds like bad news for popcorn sellers. But Mr. Lucas and Mr. Spielberg had intriguing ideas about what might come next.

headline: Young and Isolated
text: In a working-class neighborhood in Lowell, Mass., in early 2009, I sat across the table from Diana, then 24, in the kitchen of her mother’s house. Diana had planned to graduate from college, marry, buy a home in the suburbs and have kids, a dog and a cat by the time she was 30. But she had recently dropped out of a nearby private university after two years of study and with nearly $80,000 in student loans. Now she worked at Dunkin’ Donuts.

headline: Don’t Count on Calorie Counts
text: THE chicken salad hero at Lenny’s, a chain in New York, has 213 more calories than the tuna salad on the same kind of bread. I did no research to bring you this information. On the big menu board at the Lenny’s around the corner from me, where I sometimes grab a perfunctory lunch, the calorie counts of every item are clearly posted. The city made this mandatory for such restaurants about five years ago, hoping that informed gluttons might be reformed gluttons: that if we had more knowledge about where our efforts to slim down were going wrong, we’d have more power to change them.

headline: The Soaring Cost of the Opioid Economy
text: Narcotic painkillers are now the most widely prescribed class of medications in the United States.

headline: French Relish Cycle of Scandals Featuring Sarkozy-Era Officials
text: PARIS — The French love their political scandals, especially when there is a change of power at the presidential palace, the Élysée. Knives come out, grudges get pursued and those whose power was so intimidating a few short months ago face investigations.

headline: Profiting From Pain
text: THE use of narcotic painkillers, or opioids, has boomed over the past decade as drug makers and doctors have promoted them for a new use: treating long-term pain from back injuries, headaches, arthritis and conditions like fibromyalgia. Insurers have also grown to see pills as a cheaper way to treat chronic pain than other methods.

headline: Preparing for Health Care Overhaul in Louisville
text: Nonprofit health centers are on the front line of the changes that the Affordable Care Act will usher in.

headline: Happier Spending
text: SQUARE WALLET, an innovative new app, is changing the way we spend our money. Here’s how it works: you link your credit or debit card to the app, shop, take your items to a cashier at a participating retailer and, as the company’s Web site says, “simply say your name at checkout to pay.” Your name and photograph appear on the register, the cashier gives you a nod, and you walk happily out the door with your artisan shade-grown organic coffee.

headline: Organize the Desk, and the Mind Follows
text: ALEXA VON TOBEL, 29, founder and C.E.O. of LearnVest.com in Manhattan. LearnVest is a personal finance Web site.

headline: The Great Disconnect
text: THIS January, as President Obama began his second term, the Pew Research Center asked Americans to list their policy priorities for 2013. Huge majorities cited jobs and the economy; sizable majorities cited health care costs and entitlement reform; more modest majorities cited fighting poverty and reforming the tax code. Down at the bottom of the list, with less than 40 percent support in each case, were gun control, immigration and climate change.

headline: New York City Gets Legislature’s Nod to Install Speed Cameras
text: ALBANY — New York State lawmakers voted on Saturday to allow New York City to install cameras to catch speeding motorists near schools.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Jil Sander Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Airline Merger Mania
text: If you are flying this summer, be prepared to pay more for your ticket and extra fees to check your bag and select your seat. The flight is likely to be fuller than it was last year, and you will have fewer choices of airlines on most routes than you did several years ago.

headline: Extreme Budget Cuts of 2014
text: The most shameful achievement of the House Republican majority has been the elimination of $1.5 trillion in discretionary spending through 2022, which has already held back the economy from substantial growth and done real damage to people and communities that depend on government dollars. The widespread pain caused by this year’s sequester is the best-known aspect of these cuts, but caps that will continue to limit virtually every program for nine more years will also be extremely harmful.

headline: A Modest Nuclear Agenda
text: President Obama’s latest nuclear weapons proposals, announced last week in Berlin, were a disappointing example of what happens when soaring vision collides with the reality of obstructive Republican senators, a recalcitrant Russia and a convergence of regional crises.

headline: The Decline and Fall of the English Major
text: In the past few years, I’ve taught nonfiction writing to undergraduates and graduate students at Harvard, Yale, Bard, Pomona, Sarah Lawrence and Columbia’s Graduate School of Journalism. Each semester I hope, and fear, that I will have nothing to teach my students because they already know how to write. And each semester I discover, again, that they don’t.

headline: Sharapova Gives Pretournament Interview a Touch of Soap Opera
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Pretournament news conferences at Grand Slams are normally fairly predictable, rote affairs.

headline: Long Island Power Authority Scrutinized Over Consulting Fees
text: The Long Island Power Authority, which came under scathing criticism after its hobbled response to Hurricane Sandy, is facing new scrutiny after a commission found evidence of “highly questionable” billing practices and “exorbitant” expenses charged by a consultancy that was deeply involved in the authority’s business, according to a state report released Saturday.

headline: For Solazyme, a Side Trip on the Way to Clean Fuel
text: STARTING when they became friends in freshman year at Emory University in Atlanta, Jonathan S. Wolfson and Harrison F. Dillon would take off into the mountains of Wyoming and Colorado for weeks at time. They spent their days hiking in the wilderness and their nights drinking bourbon by the campfire, talking big about how one day they would build a company that would help preserve the environment they both loved.

headline: Contribute to Our Reporting in Louisville
text: As part of a continuing series on the impact of “Obamacare” in Louisville, Ky., The New York Times would like to hear from people who live or work in the Greater Louisville, Ky., region about how the law may affect their experience with the health care system.

headline: A Louisville Clinic Races to Adapt to the Health Care Overhaul
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — One morning last month, a health clinic next to a scruffy strip mall here had an unlikely visitor: a man in a suit and tie, seeking to bring a dose of M.B.A. order to the operation.

headline: Lopsided Draw? Top-Seeded Men Say Not Quite
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Novak Djokovic, Andy Murray and Rafael Nadal know the men’s singles draw looks lopsided, with second-seeded Murray, third-seeded Roger Federer and fifth-seeded Nadal in the same half. But to that they say, “Not so fast.”

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 23
text: There was good news last week for the Senate proposal to overhaul immigration, as two Republicans struck a deal on border security with the group of eight senators working on the bill. Now it looks likely that the proposal will see a vote before the Fourth of July recess.

headline: Human Rights Advocate Says He Was Beaten as Russian Officers Watched
text: MOSCOW — A prominent Russian human rights advocate said he was kicked and beaten during a forcible eviction before dawn on Saturday that came amid mounting pressure on civil society groups that publicly criticize the government.

headline: At Georgia Restaurant, Patrons Jump to Defend a Chef From Her Critics
text: SAVANNAH, Ga. — The line of Paula Deen fans waiting for her restaurant here to open grew throughout the hot, muggy morning Saturday.

headline: Obama to Unveil Climate Plan on Tuesday
text: President Obama said Saturday that he would make a major speech on Tuesday to unveil his second-term plan to curb the causes and effects of climate change, a plan expected to include limits on carbon dioxide emissions from existing power plants.

headline: Versace
text: Sports and military were among the themes presented in Donatella Versace’s spring 2014 men’s collection.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Versace Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Versace: Spring 2014 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Stranded in Milan
text: MILAN — When the women’s shows are running in Milan, the city feels a little inhospitable. The traffic is terrible, nobody can get anywhere as fast as they would like to, and the shopping excursions feel like a Happy Meal without the toy.

headline: Struggling Wells Doesn’t Start but Does Rise to the Occasion
text: On Thursday afternoon, when Vernon Wells was still part of the Yankees’ starting lineup, he said he appreciated Manager Joe Girardi’s faith in him despite his staggering offensive struggles. He added that he needed to repay Girardi’s belief in him, and soon.

headline: Obama Previews an Upcoming Global Warming Speech
text: 7:06 a.m. | Updated |Three years after President Obama’s science adviser, John P. Holdren, said that the president was planning a “major speech” on addressing human-driven global warming, it’s coming — on Tuesday at Georgetown University. The speech comes a few days after White House officials said the administration was moving forward on the long process of regulating carbon dioxide emissions from existing power plants.

headline: Sight of Tortorella Sends Vancouver Into a Tizzy
text: John Tortorella is on the verge of becoming the next coach of the Canucks, and the Vancouver fans and news media appear anything but happy about that prospect.

headline: Two-by-Fours
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — You might have guessed from the title “Two-by-Fours” that the constructor Patrick Berry has crammed in a little extra puzzle this Sunday. That’s right, everyone, it’s a rebus. If you’re solving on paper, make sure to write extra small. If you’re using your computer and need a quick refresher on how to enter multiple letters into one square in Across Lite, here’s a link to an excellent explainer.

headline: Medical Tests for Duda
text: PHILADELPHIA — Mets outfielder Lucas Duda was sent to New York for tests on his left oblique Saturday, after Duda complained about soreness after Friday’s game against the Phillies.

headline: Task Force Gives Insight on U.N. Nominee
text: WASHINGTON — Samantha Power made her name as a writer, with a fierce, unsparing account of why the United States did so little to prevent genocide during the 20th century, a failure she attributed to a “ruthlessly effective” American political system.

headline: Son and Heir? In Britain, Daughters Cry No Fair
text: LONDON — Viewers of “Downton Abbey” spotted the family-destroying potential of primogeniture in the first episode, when the Titanic sank and Lord Grantham, father of three daughters, was left with no obvious heir.

headline: Privacy and the Threat to the Self
text: In the wake of continuing revelations of government spying programs and the recent Supreme Court ruling on DNA collection – both of which push the generally accepted boundaries against state intrusion on the person — the issue of privacy is foremost on the public mind. The frequent mantra, heard from both media commentators and government officials, is that we face a “trade-off” between safety and convenience on one hand and privacy on the other. We just need, we are told, to find the right balance.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Cases Redefining Legal Equality
text: WASHINGTON — Within days, the Supreme Court is expected to issue a series of decisions that could transform three fundamental social institutions: marriage, education and voting.

headline: Mexico Pursuing Vanished Victims of Its Drug Wars
text: MONTERREY, Mexico — Rosa González cannot shake the memory of the state investigator who was too afraid of reprisals to take a full report, the police officer who shrugged when the ransom demand came, the months of agonizing doubt and, most of all, the final words from her daughter before she disappeared.

headline: Following a Star, Kerry Applies Personal Touch
text: DOHA, Qatar — Secretary of State John Kerry flew to Moscow early last month, determined to involve Russia in a new push to try to end the carnage in Syria. After a two-and-a-half-hour meeting with the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, and a private stroll with Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, the two sides announced they would convene a conference in Geneva to bring representatives of the Syrian government together with the opposition, possibly by the end of May.

headline: FEMA Denies Texas Request for Full Disaster Aid, Rankling Stricken Town
text: WEST, Tex. — When the federal government declined to give Texas officials all the disaster aid they sought after a deadly fertilizer plant explosion here in April, it not only outraged local leaders struggling to rebuild but also raised another, politically thornier issue.

headline: When Temptations Get in the Way
text: Two of the biggest and most popular United States tournaments are the North American Open and the National Open, both held each year in Las Vegas. And that can be a problem.

headline: Awaiting a Supreme Court Ruling
text: The New York Times asked readers how Supreme Court decisions on gay marriage might affect them. For Hampton and Michael Catlin, a binational couple, the ruling could determine where they live.

headline: Six-Run Mets Comeback, and Then Abrupt Defeat
text: PHILADELPHIA — Deliverance for the Mets lasted “about five minutes” at Citizens Bank Park, third baseman David Wright said. He scampered home from first to tie Saturday’s game against the Phillies with two outs in the ninth, capping a six-run comeback, only to watch Philadelphia’s Kevin Frandsen giddily jog past him at third after a game-ending home run for an 8-7 win.

headline: Slurs Against Italy’s First Black National Official Spur Debate on Racism
text: ROME — When Cécile Kyenge accepted the post of minister of integration in Prime Minister Enrico Letta’s center-left government, she knew that as Italy’s first black national official she would be breaking new ground. What she may not have expected was the stream of racial slurs that have accompanied her first eight weeks in office.

headline: Police Use Water Cannons on Istanbul Protesters
text: ISTANBUL — Turkish police on Saturday used water cannons to scatter thousands of people who had gathered in Taksim Square here to commemorate four people killed during the nationwide antigovernment protests that have gripped Turkey for more than two weeks.

headline: Two Killed in Stunt Plane Crash at Air Show
text: The sky was a clear blue above the Dayton International Airport in Ohio on Saturday, and Jane Wicker, a veteran aerial daredevil, or wing walker, was where she loved to be: hanging from the wing of a vintage biplane performing stunts at an annual air show.

headline: Blackhawks’ Top Threats Break Through
text: CHICAGO — While sitting at the Chicago Blackhawks’ hotel before Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals on Wednesday night, defenseman Brent Seabrook turned to the team captain Jonathan Toews and asked what he was thinking. Toews, who had one goal in 20 postseason games, replied: “Nothing. What are you thinking about?” Seabrook gave him a glare. Toews changed his answer.

headline: Martin Bernal, ‘Black Athena’ Scholar, Dies at 76
text: Martin Bernal, whose three-volume work “Black Athena” ignited an academic debate by arguing that the African and Semitic lineage of Western civilization had been scrubbed from the record of ancient Greece by 18th- and 19th-century historians steeped in the racism of their times, died on June 9 in Cambridge, England. He was 76.

headline: A List of the Dogs Banned in Beijing
text: On Sept. 5, 2003, Beijing passed the overall regulation on dog breeding. The rule, which took effect on Oct. 15 that year, stipulated among other things that “large and vicious dogs” were not allowed in “key management areas” in Beijing. The rule defined those areas — the districts that make up the heart of the capital — but not the dog breeds.

headline: Beijing Police Seek ‘Large and Vicious’ Suspects (With Wet Noses)
text: BEIJING — A boisterous 6-year-old golden retriever with tousled strawberry blond hair and a weakness for boiled carrots, Dou Dou hardly looks like Public Enemy No. 1.

headline: Paula Deen on Race in 2012 TimesTalk
text: The Times’s Kim Severson asked Paula Deen her thoughts about race relations in the South during a TimesTalk event last year.

headline: ‘Communist’ Is Still a Dirty Word in Vietnamese Immigrant Enclaves
text: OLYMPIA, Wash. — The cold war may have ended, but in the Vietnamese community here in Washington State, the muscle memory persists.

headline: Sam Most, Who Helped Bring the Flute Into the Jazz Mainstream, Dies at 82
text: Sam Most, a flutist who helped bring his instrument into the modern jazz mainstream, died on June 13 in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Michael Baigent, Writer Who Sued Over ‘Da Vinci Code,’ Dies at 65
text: Michael Baigent, a writer who gained wide attention when he filed an ultimately unsuccessful lawsuit contending that the novelist Dan Brown had stolen his ideas and used them in the best-selling thriller “The Da Vinci Code,” died on Monday in Brighton, England. He was 65.

headline: Boston Brings the Hits, but Chicago’s Speed Wins the Game

headline: We Were Middle-Class Once, And Young
text: As I noted the other day, Greg Mankiw (pdf), in his defense of the one percent, seems oddly oblivious, among other things, to the extent to which America has changed since he was young. We are a much more unequal society now, and as a consequence arguably one with a lot less intergenerational mobility too.

headline: Paris Barclay to Lead Directors Guild of America
text: LOS ANGELES — Paris Barclay, whose extensive television directing credits include episodes of the “Sons of Anarchy” and “Glee” series, was elected president of the Directors Guild of America at the union’s biennial convention here on Saturday. Mr. Barclay succeeds Taylor Hackford, a film director who had served as president since 2009.

headline: Taliban Peace Talks

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 10 P.M. (Lifetime) DEVIOUS MAIDS Subtitle this new series, which counts Eva Longoria among its executive producers, “Desperate Housekeepers.” Five maids bound by their personal struggles navigate the upstairs-downstairs attitudes of their Beverly Hills employers in this take on the telenovela “Ellas Son ... la Alegría del Hogar.” The story begins as one of their peers, Flora (Paula Garcés), is murdered in the home where she works during one of the year’s fanciest society events. Marisol, played by Ana Ortiz, works for some troubled newlyweds and tries to learn the truth about Flora’s death. Dania Ramírez is Rosie, who left her son in Mexico to work as a maid and nanny for a couple of uppity actors. Roselyn Sánchez is Carmen, an aspiring singer who would like her pop-star employer to help jump-start her career. And Zoila (Judy Reyes) and her teenage daughter (Edy Ganem, above right with, from left, Ms. Sánchez, Ms. Ramírez and Ms. Reyes) are the maids for an emotionally unstable but very wealthy woman. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley said that despite amusing touches, the show is “relentlessly arch and tongue in cheek in a way that seemed fresh when ‘Desperate Housewives’ began in 2004, but now is less so.” She added: “There is more to these hard-working women than their laundry skills — they are called devious for a reason — but the story lines and dialogue may be a bit too cute and contrived to hold viewers’ interest for long.” It’s the cast, she said, “that commands attention.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Militants Kill 10 Climbers in Himalayas of Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In one of the most brazen attacks on foreigners in Pakistan in recent years, gunmen disguised as paramilitary police shot dead 10 tourists, including one American, and their Pakistani guide on a mountain-climbing expedition in the country’s rugged north, officials said.

headline: Pregnant, Pill-Free and Panicked
text: Because I’ve lived so long with anxiety, there were lots of things I figured I’d never, ever do — having children was one of them. In fact, in my 20s, before I’d managed to stumble on the combination of drugs and exercise that allows me to be as sane as I can expect to be, I was so sure I’d never give birth that I got a tattoo of a giant koi fish extending from one end of my abdomen to the other.

headline: Home-Cooked Challenge: Lessons of a Week Without Junk Food
text: Earlier this month, I declared the Home-Cooked Challenge: A Week Without Processed Foods. After the first weekend, I defined my goal: a return to better-planned meals after a season of over-reliance on pizza and pasta, and going cold turkey on the packaged snacks, chips and cookies that had gradually taken over our pantry.

headline: June 23 Updates on Snowden’s Asylum Pursuit
text: Two days after the United States charged him with espionage, Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who has admitted to disclosing classified information about the country’s government surveillance programs, left Hong Kong and is now seeking asylum in Ecuador, the foreign minister of Ecuador posted on Twitter. As our colleagues Keith Bradsher and Ellen Barry report, Mr. Snowden took a flight to Moscow, where he remained at the airport on Sunday. The Lede will be providing live updates.

headline: Employers Test Plans That Cap Health Costs
text: Hoping to cut medical costs, employers are experimenting with a new way to pay for health care, telling workers that their company health plan will pay only a fixed amount for a given test or procedure, like a CT scan or knee replacement. Employees who choose a doctor or hospital that charges more are responsible for paying the additional amount themselves.

headline: Even the Greats Aren’t Safe in Wimbledon’s First Week
text: Wimbledon’s original No. 2 court, called the graveyard court because it was the site of so many upsets, is gone. But as we saw last year when Lukas Rosol, an obscure Czech player ranked 100th, sent Rafael Nadal packing, the first week at Wimbledon can still be an adventure for the game’s top seeds. Nearly every great champion has crashed out of Wimbledon prematurely at least once.

headline: 6 Are Killed by Worker in Shanghai
text: HONG KONG — A factory employee in Shanghai bludgeoned a colleague to death and shot dead five other people in a spasm of violence apparently set off by a business dispute, the city’s police authority said Sunday. It was a rare instance of a gun rampage in China, where few civilians own firearms.

headline: Monsters and Zombies Overrun the Box Office
text: Cuddly monsters and swarming zombies, both forcibly marketed, dominated North American theaters over the weekend. The animated prequel “Monsters University,” from Disney’s Pixar, was No. 1 as expected, taking in an estimated $82 million — an exact match to the opening-weekend total in 2001 (after adjusting for inflation) for “Monsters Inc.,” which ended up taking in $740 million worldwide.

headline: Food as Foe in a Test of Family
text: Despite its prickly tone and not terribly likable characters, Lionel Shriver’s “Big Brother” has the muscle to overpower its readers. It is a conversation piece of impressive heft. For one thing, this novel’s thoughts on obesity make it Ms. Shriver’s most topical book since “We Need to Talk About Kevin,” her unflinching story of a mother’s efforts to understand a teenage son responsible for a school shooting. And now, with nonfiction books about food and dieting everywhere, Ms. Shriver has shaped a dysfunctional-family novel around, as she puts it, “the elephant in the room.”

headline: Wildfires Ravage Colorado, Causing Vacationers to Flee

headline: Inspired, He Tells Her Stories With Songs
text: Athena, Hera, Aphrodite and Persephone were among the Greek female deities whose origins were described in raw contemporary language by the actor and singer Norbert Leo Butz in his brilliantly audacious show, “Girls, Girls, Girls,” at 54 Below on Friday evening. Each goddess inspired at least one song in this mash-up of Greek mythology, Jungian archetypes, personal family history, and rock ’n’ roll that translated Freud’s age-old question — “What do women want?” — into savage, realistic story songs.

headline: As Social Media Swirl Around It, Supreme Court Sticks to Its Analog Ways
text: WASHINGTON — Chad Griffin, a gay rights advocate, has arrived twice this month at the Supreme Court with his bags packed, ready to fly off to a rally if the court rules on same-sex marriage. Ted Olson, a veteran lawyer who argued the case, will be sitting in court on Monday, just in case. And Lisa Blatt, a Supreme Court litigator, is one of many Washington court watchers who will be eagerly refreshing her Web browser.

headline: Before Trying to Defend His Title, Federer Takes a Look Back
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Roger Federer has spent a lot of time in recent days talking about history and legacy.
