headline: Standing Up to Bully and Closing In on the Cup
text: CHICAGO — The Boston Bruins’ captain, Zdeno Chara, is the tallest player in the N.H.L., and maybe the meanest, his reputation as intimidating as his 6-foot-9 frame. In the Eastern Conference finals, he delivered a punch to the chin of the Pittsburgh Penguins’ Sidney Crosby, who had recently returned from a monthlong absence after jaw surgery. The Quebec government once held a criminal investigation into a hit he made on Max Pacioretty of the Montreal Canadiens.

headline: Jon Stewart as the Jon Stewart of Cairo
text: Jon Stewart is on a sabbatical from his duties as host of Comedy Central’s “Daily Show With Jon Stewart,” but that has not stopped him from appearing on television. Last week, he was a surprise guest on “Al Bernameg,” or “The Program,” the Egyptian equivalent of “The Daily Show” that is filmed in Cairo and hosted by Bassem Youssef. Mr. Stewart was brought on stage wearing a black hood and introduced as a captured foreign spy.

headline: Hulu Faces a Nebulous Future as It Seeks a New Owner
text: This year Hulu reached a milestone: viewers streamed more than one billion videos on the site in a single three-month period.

headline: ‘A New Typology of Custom Design’ for Lapo Elkann
text: MILAN — Has anyone ever gotten more mileage out of his grandfather’s hand-me-downs than Lapo Elkann? For years, the Fiat heir and fashion plate has mined the sartorial back pages of his forebear, Gianni Agnelli, a man who dressed with originality along with being an industrial magnate, a ferocious sportsman and model of the Italian playboy.

headline: Taking a ‘Poor Man’s Church Organ’ to Heavenly Heights
text: “Well, I was originally a drummer,” J. P. Jofre, the 29-year old master of the bandoneón, said one recent afternoon when a visitor to his Harlem apartment asked whether he came to the accordionlike object he was holding by way of another instrument. Drumming, it turned out, was only the beginning of the musical path of this prolific composer, who moved to New York from Argentina five years ago.

headline: The Rare Heroine Who Prevails
text: ST. LOUIS — In a recent interview the mezzo-soprano Alice Coote said that the opera industry was “very much still a male preserve,” adding, “It’s still a man’s world.” Few recent premieres have featured scores or librettos by women. But Czech lady librettists were common in the late 19th century, when Smetana wrote his now rarely performed “Kiss,” a comedy set to texts by Eliska Krasnohorska.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week includes the Chicago Fed National Activity Index for May (Monday); new orders for manufactured durable goods, the Standard & Poor’s Case-Shiller home price index and new-home sales for May (Tuesday); personal consumption in May (Wednesday); personal income and spending and pending home sales for May and initial jobless claims (Thursday); and the Chicago Purchasing Manager Index for May and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan final June consumer sentiment index (Friday). International data will include the Bank of England Financial Stability Report (Wednesday); Euro-area economic confidence, German unemployment, French consumer confidence for June, and Chinese industrial corporate profit and Japanese inflation for May (Thursday); and Japanese unemployment, household spending and retail sales for May, as well as Japanese automakers production and French producer prices and consumer spending for May (Friday).

headline: Life, Hermetically Sealed
text: You can say goodbye to your next two Monday nights, and possibly — if past for once is not precedent — the whole summer’s worth.

headline: Finding Honor in the Final Send-Off
text: The morbid meets the deeply spiritual in Christine Turner’s assured documentary “Homegoings,”  a portrait of Isaiah Owens, a Harlem undertaker, as he practices his profession: embalming and touching up human remains for display at viewings, and directing mourners and pallbearers at burial and memorial services. But the film, produced in part by the public-television series “POV,” and to be broadcast on Monday, in addition to a weeklong stint at the Maysles Cinema, is also a portrait of a sacrament as practiced in an African-American community, and a celebration of tradition, with public funeral marches (at one point a white-gloved and behatted Mr. Owens leads a procession including a hearse and horse-drawn buggy) and passionate gospel music.

headline: Recalling Larry Rosler at a 1963 National Pair Championship
text: A few people who could be top-of-the-tree bridge players give up the game to concentrate on family and career. One of those was Lawrence Rosler, who died on May 29 of acute myeloid leukemia in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 79.

headline: California Dreaming Adds Sweep to Jazz
text: Bill Frisell has had a lot of practice putting high concept into a humble package. Long hailed as one of the most distinctive and original improvising guitarists of our time, he has also earned a reputation — over the last 30 years, and especially within the last 10 or so — for teasing out thematic connections with his music.

headline: Don’t Call It ‘Theater’
text: “Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812” is part of a new crop of immersive theater experiences that challenge the notion that commercial theater is not profitable beyond Broadway.

headline: Harvey Stops the Phillies Until a Rain Delay Stops Him
text: PHILADELPHIA — When the rainstorm blew through Citizens Bank Park in the seventh inning, Matt Harvey had thrown 72 pitches, and Manager Terry Collins had a decision on his hands, with time ticking.

headline: Care for Caviar and Cocktails With That Musical?
text: A surly Russian prince wanders into the audience and snatches food from a diner’s plate. Another character startles theatergoers by joining their cocktail table. A lecherous rogue kisses a woman in her seat, while sexy dancers pass out love notes — embossed with red lip marks — to a few other patrons.

headline: Rapping About Darwin, for Knowledge and Glory
text: School was out for the week, but the lessons were just starting. Jahleel Cephus, 17, a sophomore from Validus Preparatory Academy in the Bronx, swayed to a hip-hop beat and dropped science: “Bioclast, foliation, and that granite,” he rhymed. “I can tell you something ‘bout an aphanitic.” On a screen behind him, the last word linked to a note explaining that it meant a volcanic rock. Students whooped in appreciation.

headline: Tavis Smiley to Be an Anchor for Online Radio Network
text: BlogTalkRadio, the seven-year-old Web service that lets anyone host a radio program online, is teaming up with Tavis Smiley, the public television and radio host. Starting Tuesday, Mr. Smiley will anchor a weekday show on BlogTalkRadio, varying from 20 minutes to however long he wants to talk, and produce programs from other contributors under the Tavis Smiley Network.

headline: British Invasion Reshuffles U.S. Media
text: On Thursday night, the host of “The Daily Show” riffed on Paula Deen’s liberal use of both butter and racial slurs, chatted about journalism with Tom Brokaw and parodied the gangster code of honor that has been in the news in the Whitey Bulger trial. Along the way, he did a honey-dripped Southern accent and dropped into a Cagney-esque wiseguy voice.

headline: Behind Bars, in Boats or Under a Bridge
text: More than a thousand events at this year’s Make Music New York, the daylong, citywide festival celebrating the summer solstice, were open to the public. But one concert took place behind closed doors — as well as iron gates and barbed wire. “Rhythm on Rikers” may be the least publicly visible component of this annual event, but it is also the most socially ambitious, bringing the joyful percussion music of West Africa into the prison on Rikers Island.

headline: An Elusive Ballet With an Elusive Heroine
text: “Swan Lake” is all contradictions. Its princely hero, like a knight of King Arthur’s Round Table on a quest, commutes between this world and an enchanted one. In the beautiful, transcendent purity that he finds by the lakeside, the ballet’s Romantic/classical dualism captures something at the core of what ballet is all about.

headline: Challenged, but Determined to Compete for the Tiara
text: The Special Olympics are commendable, but they’re not right for every child with a disability. “Miss You Can Do It,” a sweet documentary Monday night on HBO, looks at a completely different effort to celebrate achievement and boost self-esteem: a pageant in Kewanee, Ill., in which girls compete in categories reminiscent of the Miss America event.

headline: Egyptian General Warns Against Violence as Anniversary Approaches
text: CAIRO — The Egyptian military warned Sunday that it was prepared to act decisively to prevent chaos as fears rose that mass protests against President Mohamed Morsi planned for next week could ignite fresh violence between his Islamist supporters and the opposition.

headline: Mandela’s Condition Is Reported to Deteriorate to ‘Critical’
text: JOHANNESBURG — Nelson Mandela is in a “critical” condition, the South African president’s office said on Sunday evening, just over two weeks after the former president was hospitalized with a lung infection.

headline: Happy Campers
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — If you ever spent your summers at CAMP you probably built up a strong tolerance for sunburns and mosquitoes, but more importantly, you learned how to make a mean S’MORE.

headline: Chet Flippo, Journalist Who Championed Country Music, Dies at 69
text: Chet Flippo, a dean of pop music journalism whose profiles of artists like Dolly Parton, Willie Nelson, Waylon Jennings and Tanya Tucker for Rolling Stone magazine in the 1970s heralded vast new popularity for country music among broader audiences in the United States, died last Wednesday in Nashville. He was 69.

headline: Nova Makes Solid Return in Loss, Leaving Yanks With Tough Decision
text: The bewildering twists and turns of Ivan Nova’s season have taken him from the major league rotation to the minors to the bullpen and, finally, to a spot start on Old-Timers’ Day.

headline: A Multiplicity of Magazine Covers, and Just as Many Reasons
text: HOW many front covers does a magazine have? The logical answer — one — is outdated.

headline: Rights Unit Finds Bias Against Transgender Student
text: DENVER — A Colorado school district discriminated against a transgender first grader when it refused to let her use the girl’s bathroom, the state’s civil rights division has determined, a decision gay and transgender advocates say will have an indelible impact on how such cases are handled in the future.

headline: Hollywood’s Passion for Guns Remains Undimmed
text: LOS ANGELES — Almost a year after the theater shootings in Aurora, Colo., and a half-year after the killings in Newtown, Conn., one of the things that hasn’t changed is Hollywood’s enchantment with the gun, at least when it comes to selling the big movies.

headline: Make Music New York
text: A look at performances from this year’s citywide festival celebrating the summer solstice.

headline: Progress on an Immigration Overhaul in 5 Areas
text: The status of the immigration overhaul in the Senate and House.

headline: Matches to Watch at Wimbledon: Day 1
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Unlike the French and the United States Opens, which stretch the opening round over three days, Wimbledon annually aspires to complete all first-round matches in only two. To show off the speed with which matches can be completed on the fast grass courts, they even throw in a couple doubles matches, too. All this makes for a very busy opening day, with 18 courts hosting matches.

headline: Agency Rules School District Discriminated Against Transgender First Grader
text: Colorado’s civil rights division determined that a school district discriminated against Coy Mathis, 6, when it refused to let her use the girl’s bathroom.

headline: Critics Say Chicago Shouldn’t Aid DePaul Arena With Schools Closing
text: CHICAGO — Since 1980, the basketball team at DePaul University, the largest Roman Catholic college in the United States, has played its home games in the suburb of Rosemont, Ill., at a nondescript and, lately, mostly empty arena.

headline: At Prada: A Touch of Menace, A Bit of Soul
text: Speculating about Miuccia Prada’s intentions is something of a front-row game, and it’s not for the literal-minded. On Sunday night, at her spring 2014 men’s show, the clues included a tropical backdrop with the merest hint of helicopter rotors (“Apocalypse Now,” Ms. Prada?). But once the male and female models came out in silky print shirts with pinstriped suits and embroidered dresses with a 1940s feel, the show took a different course.

headline: Abbas Accepts Prime Minister’s Resignation
text: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Sunday accepted the resignation of his prime minister, Rami Hamdallah, who had asked to quit two weeks after being sworn into office.

headline: The Intersection of Golf and the Law
text: Golfers expect to encounter hazards or misfortune during a round of golf. We all end up in a bunker or out of bounds. But not many golfers expect to end up in court. Or jail.

headline: A Test Track for Tuning Up Supreme Court Arguments
text: WASHINGTON — On a Friday afternoon in April, a lawyer from California took his Supreme Court argument for a test drive, trying out themes and soliciting advice from five lawyers and law professors pretending to be justices. Such moot courts are a crucial feature of modern Supreme Court advocacy.

headline: Kerry Prods India to Cut Greenhouse Gas Emissions
text: NEW DELHI — Secretary of State John Kerry urged India on Sunday to begin to address climate change by reducing emissions of greenhouse gases even as it attempts to bring electricity to tens of millions of its citizens now living without it.

headline: Official Corruption in Mexico, Once Rarely Exposed, Is Starting to Come to Light
text: MEXICO CITY — Andrés Granier has a sumptuous wardrobe and lifestyle. He has bragged about owning 400 pairs of shoes, 300 suits and 1,000 shirts, collected from luxury stores in New York and Los Angeles. His purchases barely fit in his several properties, scattered throughout Mexico and abroad.

headline: At 90, a Queens Stadium Is Poised for a Comeback
text: After decades of languishing in obscurity and disrepair, one of the most famous sports and concert sites in New York will again reverberate with the sound of live music.

headline: Mosque Dream Seen at Heart of Turkey Protests
text: ISTANBUL — Three weeks before street protests spread across Turkey, the architect Ahmet Vefik Alp traveled to Sunnylands, the famous Southern California retreat for heads of state, where he presented his blueprint for a project in Istanbul’s Taksim Square that has been the dream of Turkey’s Islamist movement for decades: a large mosque that would honor the country’s Muslim and Ottoman heritage.

headline: At 35, Haas Still Dreams of Tennis Like a 7-Year-Old
text: At the French Open in Paris, Tommy Haas was deep into a fifth set with John Isner, and back in Florida, Nick Bollettieri was yelling and cursing at the television.

headline: Brazil, Fortune and Fate Turn on Billionaire
text: When the Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista appeared on the Charlie Rose show in 2010, he and his country were on a roll.

headline: Police Unit Taking Closer Look at Deadly Crashes
text: The woman’s body lay under a sheet on the darkened Brooklyn sidewalk, one all-white Adidas sneaker, one black sock. About 20 feet away, her other shoe mixed with the debris around a mangled Ford Fusion.

headline: Murray Hopes His Success Has Helped His Hometown Heal
text: WIMBLEDON, England — On the eve of Wimbledon on Sunday night, the BBC showed the one-hour documentary “Andy Murray: The Man Behind the Racket.” In addition to providing the Murray biography, the documentary recapped the past year of his career, during which he lost the Wimbledon final, won the Olympic gold medal at the All England Club, then captured his first Grand Slam title at the United States Open.

headline: Et Tu, Bernanke?
text: For the most part, Ben Bernanke and his colleagues at the Federal Reserve have been good guys in these troubled economic times. They have tried to boost the economy even as most of Washington seemingly either forgot about the jobless, or decided that the best way to cure unemployment was to intensify the suffering of the unemployed. You can argue — and I would — that the Fed’s activism, while welcome, isn’t enough, and that it should be doing even more. But at least it didn’t lose sight of what’s really important.

headline: Let Shooting Victims Sue
text: A BASIC function of law in a civilized society is to allocate the costs of harm to those who caused it. In the case of a gang shooting or terrorist attack, penalties are imposed on the gang member or terrorist. But what of the person who sold them their weapons?

headline: Make Gun Companies Pay Blood Money
text: GUN manufacturers have gone to great lengths to avoid any moral responsibility or legal accountability for the social costs of gun violence — the deaths and injuries of innocent victims, families torn apart, public resources spent on gun-related crime and medical expenses incurred.

headline: All-or-Nothing Strategy on Women’s Equality Legislation Ends With Nothing
text: In his State of the State address in January, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo described New York State as the “equality capital of the nation” and called on lawmakers to pass a 10-point Women’s Equality Act that would strengthen the state’s laws against sexual harassment, human trafficking, domestic violence and salary discrimination. Much of the legislation had widespread support.

headline: N.S.A. Leak Puts Focus on System Administrators
text: Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who leaked details about American surveillance, personifies a debate at the heart of technology systems in government and industry: can the I.T. staff be trusted?

headline: Only Syriza Can Save Greece
text: ATHENS — THE sudden closure of Greece’s state television and radio network, the Hellenic Broadcasting Corporation, known as ERT, on June 11 has led to a political drama. The network’s journalists and staff have occupied ERT buildings, and large crowds have gathered to show support. With transmitters dark, broadcasting resumed over the Internet, and soon stations all over Europe picked up the feeds. Overnight, a state-run organization that had long been reviled for corruption and cronyism became the voice of a democratic resistance.

headline: Taliban Flag Is Gone in Qatar, but Talks Remain in Doubt
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a possible easing of tensions that have held up an opening for peace talks by American, Afghan and Taliban officials in Qatar, the Afghan government confirmed the complete removal of an objectionable sign, flag and flagpole that had led the Afghan delegation to boycott negotiations.

headline: States Reined In by 1965 Voting Act Await a Decision
text: BEAUMONT, Tex. — There is little agreement on anything, even when it all started, but sometime in the last decade the Beaumont Independent School District became a battle zone.

headline: Don’t Spoil the Palisades
text: More than a century ago, the governors of New Jersey and New York decided that the great cliffs along the lower Hudson River deserved protection from builders, quarries and homesteaders. They wanted a long, green stretch of those palisades to be “beyond the reach of devastation.”

headline: Hands-Free Distractions
text: As Americans have become more aware of the dangers of using cellphones while driving, the makers of cars and mobile devices have increasingly sold hands-free and speech-recognition technologies as safer alternatives. But a new report presents compelling evidence that drivers who use such tools are as distracted as people who hold their phone to their ear. Even when drivers keep both hands on the wheel, the report says, a lot of mental energy is required to hold two-way conversations or talk coherently into speech-recognition devices.

headline: Anticipation Turns to Acceptance as California Awaits Marriage Ruling
text: LOS ANGELES — Less than five years after California voters approved a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage, the fate of that referendum — and the ability of thousands of gay men and lesbians to marry — is expected to be decided by the United States Supreme Court this week.

headline: Needed: A New Safety Valve
text: Congress’s new bipartisan task force on overcriminalization in the justice system held its first hearing earlier this month. It was a timely meeting: national crime rates are at historic lows, yet the federal prison system is operating at close to 40 percent over capacity.

headline: China Said to Have Made Call to Let Leaker Depart
text: BEIJING — The Chinese government made the final decision to allow Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, to leave Hong Kong on Sunday, a move that Beijing believed resolved a tough diplomatic problem even as it reaped a publicity windfall from Mr. Snowden’s disclosures, according to people familiar with the situation.

headline: Legislature Approves Bill Allowing Pharmacists to Give Meningitis Vaccination
text: The State Legislature has passed a bill permitting pharmacists to give meningitis vaccinations, a measure aimed at a deadly outbreak among gay and bisexual men in New York City.

headline: More Overreach by the N.Y.P.D.
text: The revelation in 2011 that the New York City Police Department was spying on law-abiding Muslims rightly attracted scrutiny from the Justice Department, which announced last year that it intended to review the program. The disclosure also raised troubling questions about whether the city was violating a federal court order that bars it from retaining information gleaned from investigations of political activity unless there are reasonable indications of potential wrongdoing. The purpose of that order was to discourage unjustified surveillance and prevent police from peering into people’s private affairs and building dossiers on them without legitimate cause.

headline: Inching Into Syria
text: REYHANLI, Turkey — In the border towns where Syrian rebels recuperate and resupply, the buzz is that the long wait for Barack Obama may be near an end. The excitement is not the result of the White House announcement on June 13 that the United States will supply light weapons to the groups seeking to overthrow the homicidal regime of Bashar al-Assad. Bullets and body armor won’t help much against Assad’s tanks, bombs and mortars. But the rebels say they see Obama’s hand in some bigger, less-publicized developments: the arrival of more and better antitank weapons, and rumors of long-withheld antiaircraft weapons. The heavier ordnance is coming from Europe, the gulf and — as The Times reported Saturday — from Libya. But it seems to be flowing now with a wink and a nod from the U.S.

headline: The Tax Haven Team in Monaco
text: MONACO — Monaco may seem almost comically tiny, less a real country than a glorified safe deposit box festooned with palm trees and Lamborghini dealerships, but it teems with interesting statistics. Population: 35,427. Number of nationalities represented: 125. Unemployment rate: 0 percent. Income tax rate: 0 percent.

headline: Firm Said to Be Reviewing Questions Raised About Ties to Long Island Utility
text: The consulting firm that a New York State investigative panel said had charged “exorbitant” fees for its services to the Long Island Power Authority responded on Sunday, saying it had been unaware of the commission’s claims before Saturday.

headline: State Rewards Home Care Firms Once Rebuked
text: Hunting for ways that the incoming governor could close a $2 billion budget deficit late in 2010, New York State officials scrutinized Medicaid spending on home health care, and made some startling discoveries.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Offering Snowden Aid, WikiLeaks Gets Back in the Game
text: WikiLeaks once again seized the global spotlight on Sunday by assisting Edward J. Snowden in his daring flight from Hong Kong, mounting a bold defense of the culture of national security disclosures that it has championed and that has bedeviled the United States and other governments.

headline: To Tip or Not to Tip
text: Should restaurants do away with tipping?

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: On Treating Obesity, the Disease
text: To the Editor:

Athletic Scholarships
text: To the Editor:

headline: Little New From Last Year in the Latest City Budget
text: What’s done is done.

headline: Lottery Numbers
As a Season Drags On, Batters Chase More Bad Pitches
text: Even the best hitters succumb. The season marches on, game after game, and they begin to flail. Picky in spring, they are ever more undiscerning come summer and fall.

headline: Soldiers Clash With Sunni Sheik’s Followers in Southern Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Clashes raged on Sunday in the southern Lebanese city of Sidon between the army and the followers of a hard-line Sunni Muslim sheik, paralyzing traffic on a main highway and leaving at least 12 people dead.

headline: Chambliss Ready to Part With Bat and Ball That Sent Yankees to World Series
text: The Louisville Slugger that Chris Chambliss used to hit one of postseason baseball’s most famous game-winning home runs has been living quietly at his home for nearly 37 years, sharing space with less famous lumber signed by Ozzie Smith and Red Schoendienst.

headline: In Debate Over Military Sexual Assault, Men Are Overlooked Victims
text: Sexual assault has emerged as one of the defining issues for the military this year. Reports of assaults are up, as are questions about whether commanders have taken the problem seriously. Bills to toughen penalties and prosecution have been introduced in Congress.

headline: This Time, Greater Will to Overhaul Immigration
text: WASHINGTON — Six years ago this month, re-election campaign looming, Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana joined 15 other Democrats to shoot down an overhaul of the immigration system, which she said encouraged “illegal behavior” with “a generous path to citizenship” for “people who have broken the law to enter this country.”

headline: Celtics’ Rivers Is Said to Be Heading to Clippers
text: The Los Angeles Clippers are poised to finally lure Coach Doc Rivers from the Boston Celtics, reaching agreement on an on-again, off-again deal that at various points was declared dead and against league rules.

headline: In the Bible Belt, Offering Atheists a Spiritual Home
text: BATON ROUGE, La. — It would have been easy to mistake what was happening in a hotel ballroom here for a religious service. All the things that might be associated with one were present Sunday: 80 people drawn by a common conviction. Exhortations to service. Singing and light swaying. An impassioned sermon.

headline: A Cherry Jubilee
text: Cherries have been having their moment these last few weeks at Los Angeles farmers’ markets. They’re in everybody’s market bags and on menus all over town, and not just on dessert lists. At the Westside Tavern in Los Angeles I recently ordered an appetizer billed as “Cherries and Goat Cheese” in bold print with “almond pesto, arugula, white balsamic vinaigrette” in finer print. What arrived was an attractive salad — a white rectangular platter lined with baby arugula tossed with a light vinaigrette and topped with halved cherries, small dabs of goat cheese and a nutty pesto. I’m not one for adding fruits like blueberries and cranberries to salads, but I found that I liked this combination a lot. Even sweet cherries have a tart edge to them, and the combination of their sweet/tart flavor and juicy but firm texture with the pungent arugula, creamy goat cheese and crunchy nuts worked well. The salad inspired me to work with cherries in other savory recipes.

headline: Out of Concrete and Drudgery Come Canoes That Float
text: URBANA-CHAMPAIGN, Ill. — It’s not easy making the unsinkable out of the unthinkable.

headline: Bruins and Blackhawks Hope Top Centers Can Play
text: BOSTON — Boston Coach Claude Julien gave what he thought was an informative medical update Sunday on the status of the Bruins’ star center Patrice Bergeron for Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals against the Chicago Blackhawks.

headline: A Place Where Art and Design Collide
text: Fused, a new exhibition space devoted to exploring the increasingly frequent intersections between art and design, opens this week in San Francisco’s Potrero Hill neighborhood. The gallery is a collaboration between Jessica Silverman (of the namesake San Francisco gallery) and the designer Yves Behar. As Behar was building a new office space for fuseproject, his multidisciplinary design studio, he decided to include a gallery space as well. “Traditionally, design agencies have an exhibition space to show their own work,” Behar said. “I found that to be a little static and boring. There are a lot of creative businesses in Potrero Hill and I wanted to provide a space where a conversation between designers and the art world could happen.” Silverman will curate a program of exhibitions for Fused’s first year, while continuing to run her own gallery.

headline: Rowboats for Retirement
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Steps for More, and Better, Sleep
text: I regret that for most of my adult life, I treated sleep as more a luxury than a necessity. There was always something more to do before I crawled under the covers and turned out the light. I realize belatedly that I might have been more productive — and a lot nicer to live with — if I had given sleep its proper due.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 24, 2013
text: “I think telling the story about male victims is the key to changing the culture of the military.”

text: palate •\ˈpa-lət\• noun

headline: Old-Timers’ Day at Yankee Stadium
text: The Yankees honored perennial favorites like Yogi Berra and first-time participants like Orlando Hernandez on Sunday during their 67th Old-Timers’ Day.

headline: Bollettieri Calls Djokovic the Game’s Most Complete Player, Ever
text: WIMBLEDON, England — When tennis coach Nick Bollettieri looks you in the eye and tells you that Novak Djokovic is probably the most complete player in the history of tennis, it’s time to sit up and listen.

headline: A Week in Pictures
text: A review of the week in sports, from the Miami Heat’s second straight title to synchronized diving in Germany.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 4:25 P.M. (HBO Signature) BIRDERS: THE CENTRAL PARK EFFECT (2012) Each year more than a million birds stop in Central Park as they migrate through the area in the spring and fall. And without fail, several hundred birders, above, are there to take in the sight. In this documentary the first-time filmmaker Jeffrey Kimball explores this phenomenon across four years through the stories of those who find joy in creatures “so alive, active, varied and beautiful,” says Anya, a 15-year-old birder, who is shown alongside obsessives like Jonathan Franzen, the author of “Freedom” (which features a cerulean warbler on its cover), and Starr Saphir, who died in February and whose renowned walking tours made her the matriarch of Central Park bird-watching. Mr. Kimball also speaks to scientists, who call the concentration of birds there “the Central Park effect,” and who, each Christmas season, attempt to count the birds in the park to produce the annual report of birds in decline.

headline: News Quiz | June 24, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: India-U.S. Relations: The Search for a Transformative Moment
text: India and the world have changed dramatically in the past two decades. The relationship between India and the United States has strengthened spectacularly and brought substantive gain to both countries. It has also given birth to great expectations. The management and fulfilment of those expectations is crucial for the dialogue and partnership between the two countries.

headline: Matthew Weiner Discusses the ‘Mad Men’ Season Finale
text: When a “Mad Men” season begins with references to Dante’s “Inferno,” you know that at some point Don Draper is going to be put through hell. Abandon all hope, ye who read any further without expecting to have the season finale of this AMC drama spoiled for you.

headline: An Easy Fix for a Broken Keyboard
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Corrections: June 24, 2013
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Dead-enders in Dark Suits
text: The Bank for International Settlements is the central bankers’ central bank; accordingly, it tends to exhibit the prejudices of the tribe in especially concentrated form. In particular, it has been relentless in making the case for higher interest rates, on the grounds that … well, the logic keeps changing. For a while it was warning about inflation and commodity prices; when the inflation failed to materialize and commodity prices slumped again, it simply changed the argument to one against bubbles, plus the quite amazing argument that central bankers must not keep rates low because that would take the fiscal pressure off governments. Who, exactly, elected these people to run the world?

headline: Bobby (Blue) Bland, Soul and Blues Balladeer, Dies at 83
text: Bobby (Blue) Bland, the debonair balladeer whose sophisticated, emotionally fraught performances helped modernize the blues, died on Sunday at his home in Germantown, Tenn., a suburb of Memphis. He was 83.

headline: Florida Versus Spain, An Update
text: I’ve suggested on a number of occasions that one good way to understand the problems of the euro is to compare the experiences of Florida and Spain. Both had huge housing bubbles, fed in part by buyers of coastal holiday homes, which burst. Both suffered nasty recessions as a result. But then their destinies diverged, because one was part of a fiscal as well as monetary union, while the other wasn’t. As its economy shrank, Florida paid much less in federal taxes, even as federal spending in Florida rose; I’ve estimated the de facto federal aid to Florida in 2010 at around 5 percent of GDP. That’s aid, not loans; anything on that scale would have been inconceivable in Europe.

headline: Poll Finds Australians Uneasy About Chinese Investment
text: BEIJING — 9:37 p.m. | Updated From American pig farms to Club Med and British yacht makers, China’s appetite for overseas investment is growing fast and diversifying. Governments and businesses are quick to praise the trend, but what do ordinary citizens think?

headline: Asian Markets Falter After Central Bank Statement
text: HONG KONG — In its first direct comment about a credit crunch last week that raised concerns about the health of the Chinese financial system, China’s central bank insisted Monday that there was ample cash in the banking system but stressed that the country’s commercial banks needed to be better managed.

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 24
text: NEWS Edward J. Snowden arrived in Moscow on Sunday as American officials pressed Russia to turn him over and warned countries in Latin America not to harbor him or allow him passage. Peter Baker reports from Washington and Ellen Barry from Moscow.

headline: Leaker’s Flight Raises Tension Between U.S. and 3 Nations
text: WASHINGTON — Frustrated Obama administration officials pressed Russia on Monday to turn over Edward J. Snowden, the national security contractor who disclosed surveillance programs, while warning China of “consequences” for letting him flee to Moscow.

headline: Rocket Fire From Gaza Shakes Cease-Fire With Israel
text: JERUSALEM — The fragile six-month cease-fire between Israel and Gaza was shaken overnight Monday as militants from the Palestinian coastal enclave fired at least six rockets against southern Israel and the Israeli military responded with airstrikes against what it said were weapons storage facilities and a rocket launch site in the southern Gaza Strip.

text: Test your math skills with this question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “For Retirees, a Million-Dollar Illusion.”

headline: A Photographer vs. the Lasers
text: Humans have gazed upon the stars for millennia, contemplating our insignificance under infinite vastness. Staring at the night sky is humbling and joyous — unless you’re living on the streets. Then it can be downright terrifying.

text: In the article “Flood Toll Reaches 1,000 in India as Thousands More Await Rescue,” Basharat Peer writes about the devastation in that country.

headline: Nelson Mandela in Critical Condition for Second Day
text: JOHANNESBURG — President Jacob Zuma said on Monday that Nelson Mandela remained in critical condition for a second day in a hospital in Pretoria where he is being treated for a lung infection.

text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A Triumph of Trivia and Trivial at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The Wimbledon Compendium is stuffed in the media kits handed out to hundreds of journalists covering the tournament and stocked on shelves for sale to the public at the All England Lawn Tennis Club.

headline: New York Today: Prepare to Sweat
text: Updated, 12:33 p.m. | An oppressive start to the week, with a heat advisory in effect through Tuesday. Hot, muggy and gross are in the forecast, with temperatures in the low 90s, and the heat index in the upper 90s.

headline: Daily Report: ‘The Scariest Threat Is the Systems Administrator’
text: Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who leaked details about American surveillance, personifies a debate at the heart of technology systems in government and industry, Christopher Drew and Somini Sengupta write in The New York Times on Monday: Can the I.T. staff be trusted?

headline: Test Tube Tomato
text: Retro Report: In the 1990s, entrepreneurs and scientists brought the first genetically engineered food to market.  The business crashed but biotechnology has flourished far beyond the produce aisle.

headline: You Call That a Tomato?
text: If you run out of things to talk about with friends, mention that you can’t get a tomato that tastes like a tomato anymore. People’s eyes will light up in recognition. They will tell you that they have been disappointed by tomatoes and tricked by tomatoes. Tomatoes at the supermarket look just like tomatoes — red, firm and juicy, and some even have little pieces of vine attached, a particularly authentic touch.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Jim Rutenberg on What Happens When Obama’s Campaign Wizards Go Corporate
text: Jim Rutenberg, national political correspondent for The Times, wrote this week’s cover story about the potential transformation of the advertising industry as the young data analysts who helped get Obama elected turn to the private sector.

headline: Live Stream | Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Gucci
text: The live stream has ended – go here for scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Dimitrov Is Surprise Among Betting Favorites for Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Djokovic. Murray. Nadal. Federer. Tsonga. Del Potro. Dimitrov. Berdych. As the 127th Wimbledon gets under way Monday, those are the top eight male contenders for the title, according to Ladbrokes, one of the largest gaming companies in Britain. Why is Grigor Dimitrov, the 29th seed, up there with the big boys?

headline: Tenet to Acquire Vanguard Health Systems for $1.8 Billion
text: Tenet Healthcare said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Vanguard Health Systems for roughly $1.8 billion in a deal that will put Tenet into new markets.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Firing the Founder
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: South Africa Recalls the Birth of the Rainbow Nation
text: LONDON — In what must be a bittersweet memory for South Africans, Monday marks the 18th anniversary of a sporting triumph that heralded the birth of the Rainbow Nation.

headline: Flight Departs for Cuba, but No Sign of Snowden
text: After leaving Hong Kong Sunday and reportedly staying overnight at a Moscow airport hotel, Edward J. Snowden was expected to board a flight Monday to Cuba as part of his journey to escape federal espionage charges filed against him for disclosing documents about United States surveillance programs.

headline: Off The Dribble’s Content Is On the Move
text: Thank you for visiting Off the Dribble. This blog’s regular features, including live game analysis, reader discussion, news and notes from Howard Beck, Nate Taylor, Beckley Mason and others, can now be found on the Pro Basketball section front.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Calvin Klein Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Telefonica to Sell Irish Unit for $1.1 Billion
text: LONDON – The Spanish telecommunications company Telefónica agreed on Monday to sell its Irish unit to Hutchison Whampoa of Hong Kong for up to 850 million euros, or $1.1 billion, the latest effort by the European company to reduce its large debt burden.

headline: Vodafone in $10 Billion Deal
text: VODAFONE IN $10 BILLION DEAL  |  Vodafone, the British telecommunications giant, agreed on Monday to buy the German cable operator Kabel Deutschland for 7.7 billion euros, or $10.1 billion, DealBook’s Mark Scott reports. The announcement concludes months of speculation about the German company, which also had received a preliminary approach from John C. Malone’s Liberty Global. Vodafone said it had offered Kabel Deutschland’s investors 87 euros for each of their shares, representing almost a 40 percent premium on the German company’s stock since a potential Vodafone deal was first reported in February.

headline: A Guide to The Times’s Supreme Court Coverage
text: This week is expected to be one of the more consequential ones at the Supreme Court in recent years. The justices have yet to rule on 11 cases from the 2012-13 term, including the four most closely watched: two on same-sex marriage and one each on affirmative action and the Voting Rights Act. The court will issue rulings sometime after 10 a.m. Eastern on Monday, including potentially on one or more of those major cases.

headline: Hasty Exit Started With Pizza Inside a Hong Kong Hideout
text: HONG KONG — Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who has acknowledged leaking numerous documents about American surveillance operations around the world, planned his escape from Hong Kong over a surreptitious dinner of pizza, fried chicken and sausages, washed down with Pepsi.

headline: Chinese Activist Praises Taiwan’s Democracy
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Chen Guangcheng, the legal activist who left China with his family amid a diplomatic crisis last year, praised Taiwanese democracy on Monday while refusing to talk about controversies in the United States.

headline: K.K.R. to Buy PRA, a Clinical Testing Company, for $1.3 Billion
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed on Monday to buy PRA International, a provider of clinical laboratory testing services for drug makers, from another private equity firm, Genstar Capital.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Prada Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Gucci
text: Floral prints are paired with bold colors at Gucci.

headline: The Test You Want To Fail
text: MOSCOW — I didn’t exactly fail my civics exam, but I came very close: 78 out 100 is the worst I have ever scored on any exam. Sure, I had not taken a test in a while — if you don’t count grammar and logic tests that circulate on Facebook, which I ace — but when an independent Russian television channel, TV Dozhd, was staging an experiment, asking successful grownups to take standardized high-school graduation tests on air, I decided to take obshchestvoznaniye, or civics. My comrades in humiliation were a former opposition presidential candidate, two political activists, a music talk-show host and a very young reporter who had a clear advantage: She had recently taken the test for real.

headline: Gucci: Spring 2014 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Sacrificing for the Stanley Cup
text: We have entered the N.H.L.'s favorite part of the playoffs, the part where its bright, shiny Stanley Cup becomes the biggest star. Because the Chicago Blackhawks lead the Stanley Cup finals, 3-2, and can win the league’ prize Monday night, it will be brought to Boston’s TD Garden and you are supposed to focus on nothing else. It is so special, the N.H.L would love you to believe, that it is worth everything the players are sacrificing to win it — teeth, ligaments, vital organs, potentially the ability to remember spouses’ names someday — while league officials actively forget that elbows to heads really probably should be against the rules, even in the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: Dell Special Committee Criticizes Icahn Proposal, Again
text: A special committee of Dell Inc.‘s board again criticized a stock repurchase proposal by Carl C. Icahn on Monday, arguing that his plan suffered from a financing shortfall that made it less valuable than the company’s planned $24.4 billion sale to Michael S. Dell.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Allegheny Front: On saving the pawpaw, a native North American tropical fruit that deserves to be better known. — Melissa Clark

headline: Mass Layoffs at a Top-Flight Law Firm
text: Layoffs are a brutal reality of corporate America. During fallow periods, publicly traded companies, including the big banks, routinely cull their ranks. The country’s largest law firms, by contrast, have historically taken a kinder, gentler approach, rarely firing employees en masse.

headline: Civilians Flee and Soldiers Die in Clashes in Lebanon
text: SIDON, Lebanon — Tanks careened through this seaside city, gunfire crackled along near-deserted streets and thick smoke rose from the hilltop neighborhood where followers of a radical Sunni cleric clashed for a second day on Monday with the Lebanese Army, killing at least 12 soldiers. The deaths were the army’s worst losses since the conflict in neighboring Syria began fueling sporadic skirmishes in Lebanon two years ago.

headline: Justices to Hear Case on Obama’s Recess Appointments
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether President Obama violated the Constitution last year when he bypassed the Senate in making three recess appointments to the National Labor Relations Board.

headline: One Man’s Attempt to Create a Fertilizer Compound That Won’t Explode
text: “I hope this pans out. It’s in the early stages.”

headline: Gary David Goldberg, Television Writer And Creator of ‘Family Ties,’ Dies at 68
text: Gary David Goldberg, a writer and producer who created warmhearted television shows, most notably “Family Ties,” a leading comedy of the 1980s that propelled Michael J. Fox to stardom, died on Saturday at his home in Montecito, Calif. He was 68.

headline: Live Analysis of Supreme Court Decision on Affirmative Action
text: The Supreme Court ruled Monday that lower courts did not apply a sufficiently high level of scrutiny to the University of Texas’ use of race in admissions decisions, sending the case back to one of those lower courts to be reconsidered.

headline: Clash of Styles in Court Opens Trial in Trayvon Martin’s Death
text: SANFORD, Fla. — Using George Zimmerman’s own words, prosecutors on Monday opened the case against him by portraying Mr. Zimmerman as a gun-toting vigilante who “profiled” Trayvon Martin as someone who was “up to no good” and, with a gun in his waistband, set out to stop him.

headline: June 24: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Here’s the Apartment; Now Let’s Go Hang Gliding
text: When Dan Critchett, a real estate agent, meets a buyer at an open house, a potential client he hopes to woo, he shakes the buyer’s hand and offers two business cards. The first is fairly standard, a red rectangle that identifies him as an agent with Stribling & Associates, who can help you buy or sell a home. The second offers something else.

text: Season 6, Episode 12, Finale

headline: Affirmative Action’s Contentious History
text: Sam Tanenhaus on the history of affirmative action, a program that dates back to the presidency of John F. Kennedy and has stirred debate for decades.

headline: Justices Step Up Scrutiny of Race in College Entry
text: WASHINGTON — Courts must take a skeptical look at affirmative-action programs at public colleges and universities, the Supreme Court ruled Monday, in a decision that is likely to set off a wave of challenges to race-conscious admissions policies nationwide.

headline: How My Restaurant Adventure Came to an End
text: Editor’s Note: For more than two years, Bruce Buschel chronicled his experiences creating a restaurant on this blog, from picking a name to hiring a chef to marketing a sustainable seafood menu. In a series of posts this week, Mr. Buschel explains why Southfork Kitchen will not be opening in Bridgehampton, N.Y., this season.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: June 21-23, 2013
text: Last Wednesday, there was a note posted atop Slate’s interactive gun-death tracker, which we quote at the end of each post:

headline: Gandolfini Funeral to Be Held at St. John the Divine in Manhattan
text: The funeral for James Gandolfini has been scheduled for Thursday at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Morningside Heights. Mr. Gandolfini, the actor and star of “The Sopranos” on HBO, died from a heart attack at 51 last Wednesday in Rome.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Gucci Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

text: Edgy and polished activewear were presented on the spring 2014 runway.

headline: How Minorities Have Fared in States With Affirmative Action Bans
text: In states that have banned affirmative action in college admissions, prominent public universities have tended to enroll fewer black and Hispanic freshmen.

headline: Deals in the Works Involving 2 Luxury Retailers
text: High-end fashion still has plenty of appeal for Wall Street as two of the biggest luxury brands tested their worth to the market.

headline: Debt Relief Firms Are Charging for Free Programs
text: Private student debt relief companies are charging sometimes exorbitant fees for help with government assistance programs that borrowers can apply for themselves, at no charge.

headline: Teenager’s 1988 Sexual-Abuse Conviction Was Justified, Report Says
text: Jesse Friedman, the Great Neck, N.Y., teenager whose role in a sexual abuse case a quarter-century ago was portrayed in the Oscar-nominated documentary “Capturing the Friedmans” and came to symbolize an era of sensational, often-suspect accusations of child molesting, was properly convicted and should not have his status as a sexual predator overturned, according to a three-year review that was released on Monday.

headline: Two Blogs Worth Reading
text: This week, let me pass along some of the more absorbing blogs and Web sites I’ve come across recently, other corners of the online world where people are talking about aging and caregiving from very different perspectives.

headline: First Male Seed Is Beaten at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England — With threatening skies and a morning chill on intimate Court 12, Fabio Fognini became the first seeded player male to be ushered out of the men’s singles at Wimbledon, falling to unseeded Jurgen Melzer of Austria, 6-7 (5), 7-5, 6-3, 6-2. Fognini, an Italian who was seeded 30th, was ill tempered throughout the match. He threw his racket four times, bickered with the French chair umpire Pascal Maria, and even seemed annoyed with the ball boys and girls, who were stoicly shivering in shorts and skirts.

headline: Excerpts From Snowden’s Letter Requesting Asylum in Ecuador
text: Speaking at a news conference in Vietnam on Monday, Ecuador’s foreign minister, Ricardo Patiño, said that his government was considering a written request for asylum from Edward J. Snowden, the former national security contractor accused of espionage by the United States.

headline: The Odd Dice Puzzle
text: This week’s puzzle was presented in the first round of the 2009 Dutch Mathematical Olympiad.

headline: Edward Snowden’s Mad Dash
text: He may be in Moscow, or perhaps he slipped away already to Cuba, Ecuador or Venezuela. Wherever Edward Snowden winds up on his increasingly desperate flight from American law enforcement, one thing is clear: he will not wind up in a country that cares about civil liberties in the United States.

headline: The Other Snowden Drama: Impugning the Messenger
text: As a pure story, it’s tough to beat the Snowden saga. Man of intrigue? Roger. Crusading reporter? Check. A powerful government in hot pursuit? Yessir. Unclear agendas by foreign countries? Most certainly.

headline: $40,000 Organ Prize Goes to Juilliard Student
text: The Longwood Gardens International Organ Competition, a new contest open to pipe organists between the ages of 18 and 30, has chosen its first winner. On Saturday, Benjamin Sheen was named as the recipient of the Pierre S. du Pont prize, which at $40,000 is one of the largest cash awards for a pipe organ competition. Mr. Sheen was chosen after a recorded audition process that lowered the pool of participants to 10. They were then asked to perform for a panel of judges on Longwood’s 10,010-pipe Aeolian organ.

headline: What Song Makes You Nostalgic?
text: Perhaps it’s the song that was playing the evening he proposed. Or the sound of an Israeli folk tune that in an instant returns you to the summer camp of your childhood. Music has the power to evoke poignant memories from our past, making us feel sentimental for a time long gone.

headline: The World Turns for Mad Men and Women
text: It was a far, far better thing that he did than he could have done.

headline: Instagram Video and the Death of Fantasy
text: Over the weekend, I went to a sunset picnic on a rooftop in Brooklyn. The evening couldn’t have been more picturesque — a group of stylish women chatting and lounging on blankets, framed against a lavender and glittering cityscape.

headline: Cost Savings Make Vodafone Deal Palatable
text: Cost savings make Vodafone’s punchy bid for Kabel Deutschland palatable. The London-listed mobile giant has offered a hefty 10.7 billion euros ($14 billion), including debt, for Germany’s largest cable operator. Skeptics think Vodafone can be ponderous and profligate in mergers. But this looks acceptable – provided Vodafone can reap the promised financial benefits.

headline: Berlusconi Is Sentenced to Seven Years in Sex Case, but Can Still Appeal Verdict
text: ROME — A Milan court on Monday found former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi guilty of paying for sex with a minor and abusing his office to cover it up, handing him a seven-year jail sentence and banning him from public office for life.

headline: The Rise of the Minimalist Workout
text: In an article under his byline for Sports Illustrated in December 1960, “The Soft American,” President-elect John F. Kennedy lamented the state of the nation’s fitness. As president he exhorted citizens to plunge into activities like 50-mile hikes.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Bittersweet Win for Danes at Le Mans
text: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gYH_kjJQKUY

headline: Archimedes: Separating Myth From Science
text: For the last time: Archimedes did not invent a death ray.

headline: Walkabout – 6/24: Bike-Sharing in North America; Medical Tourism in Malaysia
text: Move Over, Citi Bike According to this guide to bike-sharing programs in North America, Minneapolis is challenging New York City’s claim to the largest system in the U.S. (Jaunted)

headline: French Businessman Held in Corruption Case
text: PARIS — The French police on Monday arrested Bernard Tapie, a businessman and politician at the center of a political corruption scandal, for questioning. Mr. Tapie can be held for up to four days without charges as the authorities investigate accusations of abuses in an arbitration panel that awarded him $528 million in 2008, when Christine Lagarde, now the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, was France's finance minister. Investigators are looking into accusations that the arbitration was rigged by the government of former President Nicolas Sarkozy; Mr. Tapie was awarded the money after the panel had decided he was cheated of the proceeds of the sale of Adidas, which he had owned. Ms. Lagarde has been questioned and is considered only a witness in the case, but her chief of cabinet at the time, Stéphane Richard, now the head of France Télécom, is a suspect in the continuing investigation. All those cited in the investigation say they did nothing wrong.

headline: Q&A: Saving the Phone’s Battery Power
text: Q.

headline: Rajaratnam Conviction Upheld by Appeals Court
text: A federal appeals court has upheld the conviction of Raj Rajaratnam, the former hedge fund manager who was charged with orchestrating a vast insider trading conspiracy.

headline: Sharapova Wins, Then Volleys Williams Questions
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Maria Sharapova was all business Monday as she fought through a challenging first-round match against the former No. 1 junior player Kristina Mladenovic. And after Sharapova closed out a 7-6 (5), 6-3, she tried to douse any more discussion of her verbal sparring with Serena Williams.

headline: In Management Shake-Up, Warner Bros. Puts TV and Movie Units Under One Executive
text: LOS ANGELES — Warner Brothers on Monday announced a new leadership team for its film division while informing the staff that Jeff Robinov was leaving as the motion picture group’s president. Combined with a shake-up at its television unit, the moves greatly concentrate power at Hollywood’s largest studio in the hands of one executive.

headline: Nadal Loses to 135th-Ranked Player in the First Round
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Arms folded and lips pursed, Lukas Rosol stared at the television screen on Monday as Rafael Nadal lost on the fresh first-week grass of Wimbledon to another player with a low profile and a ranking in triple digits.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Dressy, but Tieless
text: The necktie, that ultimate signifier of being “dressed up,” will always have a home in a man’s wardrobe. But it’s taking a breather this season, in favor of a simple shirt buttoned all the way to the top. Dolce and Gabbana, who have long been major purveyors of the skinny black tie, opted to go without in presenting their luxe cream and black three-piece suits. (Meanwhile, the streaker who crashed the runway after the show went without his entire outfit.) Stefano Pilati’s quietly sophisticated collection, his first for the luxury fabric and tailoring house of Ermenegildo Zegna, featured jackets and pants in contrasting jacquards, again sans tie. And Jil Sander‘s trim cropped trousers and fitted jackets were shown in a pared-down fashion, with just a simple shirt. Sometimes, less is more.

headline: Texas Reaches Death Penalty Milestone
text: On Wednesday, Texas is scheduled to execute its 500th death-row inmate since the Supreme Court restored capital punishment in 1976. The state has executed nearly five times as many people as Virginia, the second state on the list.

headline: Affirmative Action Survives Another Test
text: Read the related editorial on this case.

headline: In Surprise, Emir of Qatar Plans to Abdicate, Handing Power to Son
text: DOHA, Qatar — Sheik Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, the absolute ruler and emir of Qatar, who used his tiny nation’s oil and gas wealth to alter the course of events across the Middle East, siding with rebels in Syria and Libya, negotiating peace in Lebanon, hosting a United States military base and backing the militant group Hamas, told his family that he would abdicate and transfer power to his 33-year-old son, a Qatari official confirmed on Monday.

headline: India Flood Rescue Hindered by Rain and Landslides
text: Rain and landslides have limited efforts to rescue the victims of floods in the northern Indian state of Uttarakhand. Military helicopters were unable to fly there for most of Monday, and the Indian Meteorological Department warned of “very severe” rain in the next three days. Several roads were further damaged by new landslides. Thousands of stranded pilgrims and villagers in flood-stricken areas remained in need of food and medicine. Five thousand pilgrims have been stuck for more than a week in Badrinath, a major pilgrimage center in the mountains. In New Delhi on Monday, India’s home minister, Sushil Kumar Shinde, said that more than 1,000 flood victims could be found dead once debris was removed. That number was considered a very conservative estimate. It was widely feared that the dead would number in the thousands. The Indian government was making preparations for mass cremations of the victims.

headline: Glimmerglass Festival Names Colaneri Music Director
text: The Glimmerglass Festival, an opera and theater company located in Cooperstown, N.Y., announced on Monday that Joseph Colaneri has been named as its new music director. Mr. Colaneri has served as a member of the conducting roster at the Metropolitan Opera for 15 seasons and is set to conduct the Glimmerlgass Festival’s production of Verdi’s “King for a Day,” which will run from July 21 to Aug. 24. His new duties as music director will include conducting one or two productions per season and consulting with Francesca Zambello, the company’s artistic and general director, on repertory and casting decisions. He will assume the position in October.

headline: For Women in Weiner Scandal, Indignity Lingers
text: Customers taunt Lisa Weiss. “Talk dirty to me,” they joke. “We know you like it.” Colleagues refuse to speak with her. Strangers mock her in nasty online messages.

headline: Poll Shows Lead for Democrat on Eve of Massachusetts Senate Election
text: BOSTON — The most recent poll in a special Senate election in Massachusetts showed the Democratic candidate, Representative Edward J. Markey, leading Gabriel Gomez, his Republican challenger, by 10 percentage points.

headline: Smart Ticks
text: Q. I RECENTLY REMOVED A TICK FROM BEHIND MY EAR, A COMMON FEEDING PLACE. HOW DOES THE TICK KNOW TO TRAVEL FROM ANKLE TO HEAD?

headline: Same-Sex Marriage: Landmark Decisions and Precedents
text: A timeline describing key legal cases leading up to the Supreme Court decisions on same-sex marriage in June 2013.

headline: Really? The Claim: Taking a Walk After a Meal Aids Digestion
text: THE FACTS

headline: Marketer Has New ‘Bee’ in Its Bonnet: Frozen Meals
text: A venerable seafood brand is making its way off the shelves of the canned-goods aisle of the supermarket and into the freezer cases.

headline: Before Kerry Visit, Netanyahu Goes to West Bank
text: BARKAN, West Bank — Highlighting the obstacles to Washington’s push to revive the Mideast peace process, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Monday made a rare appearance in the West Bank to dedicate an elementary school in a Jewish settlement.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: A Taste of Pride Garden Party and tasting to benefit The Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Community Center will take place from 6 to 10 p.m. Monday at Hudson River Park’s Pier 84, at the West Side Highway and 44th Street. More than 30 restaurants will be participating. General admission tickets are $99 and will be on sale after 5:30 at the will call tent.

headline: Lessons of the Great Recession: How the Safety Net Performed
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Making Misconduct a Crime
text: A persistent criticism since the financial crisis hit has been the lack of any significant prosecutions of senior executives at the financial firms that received billions of dollars in taxpayer-financed bailouts. In Britain, the Parliamentary Commission on Banking Standards suggested adding a new law to allow the prosecution of British bank executives when they recklessly engage in misconduct that puts the bank and its customers at risk of severe losses.

headline: A Model Campaign
text: Union Maj. Gen. William S. Rosecrans ran his army on his own schedule. In the middle of the country in the middle of a war, he would not be rushed. For nearly five months after defeating Confederate Gen. Braxton Bragg’s Army of Tennessee at the Battle of Stones River on Dec. 31, 1862-Jan. 2, 1863, he remained encamped at Murfreesboro, Tenn., refitting and training the victorious Army of the Cumberland, importuning the War Department repeatedly for more horses and improved arms for his cavalry, and waiting for the spring crops in Middle Tennessee to mature so that his animals would have a ready source of subsistence when he advanced.

headline: Pakistan Premier Says Former Military Ruler Will Be Charged With Treason
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said Monday that his newly installed government intended to press treason charges against the former military ruler Pervez Musharraf, setting up a potential clash with Pakistan’s powerful military.

headline: Final Play in Pulitzer Winner’s Trilogy Set for Second Stage
text: “The Happiest Song Plays Last,” the new drama by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Quiara Alegría Hudes and the final work in her Elliot Trilogy about an Iraq War veteran, will be part of Second Stage Theater’s 2013-14 season, the theater announced on Monday.

headline: Rubella Epidemics in Japan and Poland
text: Japan and Poland are both experiencing epidemics of rubella, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued travel warnings suggesting that women who are pregnant or might be consult their doctors before visiting either country.

headline: A Day At The Beach (Personal and Unimportant)
text: Omaha Beach, that is — someplace I’ve always wanted to visit, and now I have. This was yesterday — it was cold, windy, and raining occasionally, which was actually historically appropriate. Here’s the draw at Vierville, which is where the famous opening scene of Saving Private Ryan is supposed to take place:

headline: A Guide to the Supreme Court Decision on Affirmative Action
text: An analysis of notable passages in the justices’ opinions.

headline: Image of the Day: June 24
text: The Indian cricket team won the I.C.C. Champions Trophy in England on Sunday.

headline: CUNY Union Endorses de Blasio
text: Four years ago, the union representing 25,000 faculty members and other employees at the City University of New York endorsed William C. Thompson Jr. in his underdog bid to unseat Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Gucci in Flower
text: Italian men do love their games, and several designers at the spring shows in Milan responded with zest — Massimiliano Giornetti of Ferragamo, with parkas and bomber jackets loaded with straps and fasteners, as well shirts abstractly detailed with numbers. For Moncler Gamme Bleu, Thom Browne recreated a kind of cricket pitch, in his extreme fashion.

headline: The Condom Conundrum
text: Only 5 percent of men worldwide use condoms despite public health campaigns, so the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is joining the effort and issuing a challenge.

headline: Accessorizing With Condoms
text: Bidia Deperthes, from the United Nations Population Fund, explains how the organization attempts to de-stigmatize condoms by enlisting people to turn them into wearable art.

headline: Changing Society Through the Etiquette of Same-Sex Weddings
text: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay and Lesbian Manners” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: An Anti-Modern Lodging
text: Many members of private and university clubs join for the gym, the dining rooms and the people they will be with, but upstairs there often is another crowd: overnight guests who are drawn to the club’s central location and reasonable rates but who are not put off by restrictions like cellphone bans, and furnishings that can be outdated.

headline: Comfortable Condom Conversations
text: Amy and Max are among many couples that test condoms for science research. They say the communication about protection is a key barrier to use.

headline: A Live Conversation About ‘Just Kids’ by Patti Smith
text: 9:32 p.m. | Updated We have concluded our live discussion of “Just Kids,” the award-winning memoir of friendship and artistic aspiration in a vanished New York, by the rocker, poet and consummate romanticist Patti Smith. But you can still share your thoughts and questions in the comments section below.

headline: The Rise of Disability
text: The share of working-age Americans receiving federal disability payments has roughly doubled in recent decades. It rose from 23 of every 1,000 workers in 1980 to 47 of every 1,000 workers in 2011. Put differently, 5 percent of the potential work force is more or less permanently out of action. That’s not good.

headline: If Jack Daniel Were a Beekeeper
text: It’s tough keeping up with all the new flavored spirits: honey, cherry, cinnamon, apple, maple syrup.

headline: Recent Ex-Senators Find Soft Landings on Corporate Boards
text: Departing senators are finding that the life of an ex-lawmaker can be lucrative. In recent months, several have found spots in corporate boardroom, even if they have no direct business experience in the industries wooing them.

headline: Cotton Club Musical Headed to Broadway With a New Name
text: “Cotton Club Parade” – a musical revue about the famed Harlem nightclub – will begin performances on Broadway in October with a new name, “After Midnight,” the producers said on Monday. No casting was announced, but the producers are in talks with Fantasia Barrino, the Grammy Award winner and American Idol champion, to join the show, according to a person familiar with the negotiations who spoke on condition of anonymity to reveal the confidential discussions.

headline: A Panda Escapes From the Zoo, and Social Media Swoop In With the Net
text: There was an important Supreme Court ruling early in the day. An international fugitive was possibly on a flight from Moscow to Cuba. The Dow was diving. But in the nation’s capital, Rusty the red panda, who disappeared from the National Zoo, hijacked the news cycle on Monday.

headline: A Sampling From Opening Statements
text: Clips from opening arguments by the prosecution and defense teams in the George Zimmerman murder trial in Sanford, Fla.

headline: Depending on the Kindness of Strangers, and Finding Them Generous

headline: Millions of Years On, Still Evolving

I have been guilty of declaring a movie meh based only on its trailer. I once said that Caribbean cruises are meh, having never been on a Caribbean cruise. It isn’t a perfect science.

headline: Solar Boat Harnessed for Research
text: Last year, after it became the first solar-powered boat to circumnavigate the globe, the Turanor Planetsolar could have taken its 5,500 square feet of photovoltaic cells and eight tons of lithium-ion batteries and sailed off into the sunset.

headline: Rethinking the Condom, the Incredible Shrinking Workout, Your Brain on Coffee Shop Noise
text:
Behind the search for new ways to make, and sell, safe sex; get fit in the time it takes to boil an 
egg — or maybe less; if your brain is feeling sludgy, just listen to someone order a double-shot, half-cafe with soy milk.

headline: Office Romance: A Post-It Note Is a Post-It Note Is a Post-It Note
text: Common office supplies, while they can seem indispensable, don’t remain the same forever. It would be no easy task to find a typewriter sitting on someone’s desk today. I doubt there is one in The New York Times building. Telex machines are gone, as are the hot-glue rollers that the designers used for paste-up. The telephone, once in constant use, now sits largely forgotten on most desks (just about everyone prefers e-mail). But some nondigital office items remain. Post-it notes, which were invented in the late ’70s and were once described as the “solution without a problem,” are now in constant use. Rare is the computer screen that doesn’t have a couple stuck along its edges. Other items, like scissors, have been around for centuries. The rubber band was patented in 1845. The modern staple and staple remover came along in the 1930s. In this second installment of the “Office Romance” series on the 6th Floor Blog, I look for beauty in these objects.

headline: Owner of Hudson’s Bay Explores a Deal to Buy Saks
text: Will the owner of two of the oldest department store chains in North America be adding a third to his collection?

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photos from India, Lebanon, North Korea and Indonesia.

headline: By 5-4, a More Hostile Workplace
text: There’s an editor I work with closely on the editorial board who did not hire me and does not have the power to fire me. But in journalism, in general, editors are higher on the totem pole than writers and, as such, their judgments, assignments and daily instructions matter a lot.

headline: Mariah Carey to Join New York Philharmonic Benefit Concert
text: The New York Philharmonic said on Monday that two unusual stars (unusual for the Philharmonic, anyway) would join the orchestra for a concert in Central Park on July 13: Mariah Carey and Joe Torre.

headline: Seaport Museum Loses an Institutional Backer
text: Having struggled to make a go of the South Street Seaport Museum in the wake of Hurricane Sandy, the Museum of the City of New York has decided to pull out of running the troubled institution.

headline: Air Pollution May Have Suppressed Storms, Research Suggests
text: To the ever-growing list of ways humanity seems to have altered the earth, add another candidate: Air pollution may have had a major soothing influence on storm cycles in the North Atlantic.

headline: Paul Giamatti to Appear on ‘Downton Abbey’
text: Television’s most popular Yorkshire estate is about to receive another high profile visitor: Paul Giamatti has been cast to appear in the Season 4 finale of “Downton Abbey,” according to a statement released by Carnival Films, ITV and “Masterpiece” on PBS on Monday.

headline: Kawasaki Faces N.H.T.S.A. Inquiry Over Possible Stalling Issue
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating a possible stalling problem that could affect almost 10,000 Kawasaki motorcycles.  The inquiry covers 2013 Ninja 300 models, according to a report posted on the agency’s Web site.

headline: Clues in the Cycle of Suicide
text: On average, about 700 Americans kill themselves each week — but in the fine-weather weeks of May and June, the toll rises closer to 800, sometimes higher. Every year, suicide peaks with the tulips and lilacs — increasing roughly 15 percent over the annual average to create one of psychiatry’s most consistent epidemiological patterns. It may seem perverse that the period of spring and early summer, as the psychologist Kay Redfield Jamison puts it in her splendid book “Night Falls Fast,” should contain “a capacity for self-murder that winter less often has.” Yet it does.

headline: When Brevity Is the Soul of Wall Street Research
text: The gloom over Wall Street in recent days has prompted lots of commentary from analysts trying to make sense of the markets.

headline: Lamb Meatballs in 20 Minutes
text: Meatballs are not the kind of thing one would usually think of as quick-and-easy-dinner fare. All that rolling and frying can take forever, making meatballs a weekend project for a leisurely afternoon.

headline: Vevers Lands Top Spot at Coach
text: Coach found its new creative director this week, announcing Monday that Stuart Vevers, who has been the creative director of the Spanish luxury label Loewe since 2008, will replace the departing designer Reed Krakoff. Mr. Vevers’s title will be executive creative director, the company said.

headline: Under Installation, Vocal Colors
text: When I moved to New York in 1993, I felt fortunate to have arrived in time for the saxophonist, composer and bandleader John Zorn’s 40th birthday. Mr. Zorn marked the occasion, which arrived in September, with a monthlong concert series at the Knitting Factory on Houston Street, where much of his avant-garde work had been developed. With few exceptions, Mr. Zorn presented a different project every night. In September 2003 he celebrated his 50th with a monthlong series at Tonic, a now-defunct downtown nightclub.

headline: Michel Richard Set to Open a New York Restaurant and Bakery
text: Michel Richard, the Washington-based French chef, will make his debut in New York in coming months with a pastry shop and restaurant in the New York Palace hotel.

headline: Slapping, Stroking and Sighing, They’re Anything but Academic
text: The dancer-choreographer Jennifer Monson is a poet, a dramatist and an eccentric. Though an infrequent New York performer, she has been active for three decades; I’m sorry I did not see her work until this year. Over the weekend, as part of the La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival, she presented “Jennifer Monson and Friends/NY/Urbana,” a triple bill that included a duet that she danced and choreographed with Niall Jones. I watched that program on Sunday; on Saturday I watched a quadruple bill of work by three other choreographers. Ms. Monson’s dancing was by far the most striking.

headline: Merkel Offers Her Election Manifesto
text: BERLIN — Angela Merkel’s governing conservative party hopes to return the chancellor to a third term in office by offering voters a generous mix of increased social benefits for mothers, a continued push to consolidate Germany’s budget and a vow not to raise taxes, and shrugging off criticism that its campaign promises amount to little more than bloated pandering.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | June 17 – June 24, 2013
text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events that made news this week.

headline: W Hotels Will Promote Human Rights Campaign
