headline: Three’s a Trend | Men’s Wear Gets a Dose of Flower Power
text: There has been such a bountiful crop of large-scale floral prints in the men’s collections so far, you could be forgiven for thinking that designers had switched from Prosecco to Miracle Gro as their drink of choice. Frida Giannini of Gucci updated the label’s traditional floral prints, presenting mismatched jackets, silk scarves and pants in clashing colors. Tom Ford, who said during the salon-style presentation that he was “in a floral mood this season,” took his silk evening jackets and evening slip-ons to the hothouse, covering them in organic patterns. And Miuccia Prada‘s man took a steamy trip to the Pacific, slipping into a tropical print shirt and carrying a hibiscus-emblazoned suitcase. The hula girl is optional.

headline: The Olympic Curse
text: ISTANBUL — I arrived in Istanbul in mid-May, planning to stay for a few weeks and take advantage of the distance to write about Rio de Janeiro, where I live.

headline: Justices Say Law Doesn’t Require Child to Be Returned to Her Indian Father
text: An American Indian child being raised by her biological father should not have been taken from her adoptive parents, the Supreme Court ruled Tuesday, saying that a federal law devised to keep Indian families together did not apply in the case.

headline: Private Equity Finding Exits Easier Than Buyouts
text: Private equity is finding the egress a lot easier than the entrance.

headline: A History of Voting Rights
text: For much of the 20th century, voting remained a contentious issue, but the Supreme Court struck down Section 4 of the 1965 Voting Rights Act on Tuesday, suggesting that conditions have changed.

headline: A Small Bluetooth Speaker Named Boom
text: Just in time to annoy the people on the neighboring beach blanket, Ultimate Ears has produced the aptly named Boom, a Bluetooth sound dock that is both compact and loud.

headline: Betaworks Unveils Its Highly Anticipated Digg RSS Reader
text: Last summer, Betaworks, a technology incubator in New York, raised eyebrows when it announced it had bought the remains of the once-hot social news site Digg for half a million dollars.

headline: President Obama’s ‘Climate Action Plan’
text: President Barack Obama’s sweeping plan to address climate change that sets ambitious goals and timetables for a series of executive actions to reduce greenhouse gas pollution.

headline: Revisiting the I.R.S. ‘Scandal’
text: If it weren’t already clear that the White House never ordered the Internal Revenue Service to crack down on its political enemies, the most convincing piece of evidence was released yesterday: a document showing that the agency didn’t just scrutinize Tea Party groups applying for tax exemptions, but also those with names including the words “progressive” and “occupy.”

headline: Perry Ellis Splits With Duckie Brown
text: Perry Ellis, it turns out, is still not ready to return to the designer market. A year into a collaboration with the Duckie Brown designers Steven Cox and Daniel Silver, the company is pulling the plug on its upscale collection known as Perry Ellis by Duckie Brown, according to the designers.

headline: Disney Drags the Beach Blanket Out of the Attic and Gives It a Shake
text: LOS ANGELES — Next month Disney Channel’s young viewers will be introduced to a movie genre — the beach party film — that hasn’t been popular since their grandparents were teenagers.

headline: The Gun Report: June 25, 2013
text: The opening statements in the George Zimmerman trial are over; the case is finally under way. Was Zimmerman a vigilante who took advantage of Florida’s absurd “Stand Your Ground” law to shoot a young, innocent black boy for the crime of wearing a hoodie? Or was he someone who was genuinely threatened—by an unarmed 17-year-old!—and fired his gun in self-defense? Here at the Gun Report, we are rather skeptical of the defense, but notwithstanding that, the larger problem here is that laws like Stand Your Ground practically encourage vigilantism, and a Wild West mentality. The reader comments from the pro-gun advocates in this forum often stress the gun violence committed by out-and-out criminals, but what has been striking to us since we began compiling this report a month after the Newtown massacre is how many deaths are not the result of criminals bearing arms—how many are accidents, or shots fired in anger, or, on occasion, George Zimmerman-style examples of vigilantism. All of this violence could be stopped if the country had the will.

headline: Immigration and the Labor Market
text: Are American workers are about to experience unwelcome new competition for their jobs? The bill moving through Congress to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws, if approved, would give employers access to expanded visa programs that would admit hundreds of thousands of immigrant workers, of both low and high skills, to toil in workplaces from strawberry fields to technology companies.

headline: Forecasts for Visa Seekers
text: Restrictions have eased and technology has improved, but is it simpler for Americans to get visas?

headline: Can Baby-Making Really Wait?
text: I was 40 years old the first time I discussed fertility with a gynecologist. It was actually a month before my 41st birthday, and Solomon (now my husband) and I were slowly moving toward getting engaged after 16 months of dating. So I wanted to do some pre-pre-fertility planning: get a mammogram, a Pap smear, the works, before we married and stopped birth control. I had heard that if you’ve been on the pill for years (as I had since my late 20s), it’s better to clear your body from its effects for a few months before trying to conceive.

headline: Sprint Shareholders Approve Sale to SoftBank
text: Shareholders of Sprint Nextel voted on Tuesday to approve the sale of a majority stake to SoftBank of Japan for $21.6 billion, ending months of tension about the fate of the company.

headline: ‘Under the Dome’ Opens Big for CBS
text: CBS appears to have found a legitimate summertime hit in its adaptation of the Stephen King novel “Under the Dome,” whose first episode drew an audience of more than 13 million Monday night.

headline: Coach Puts Swimming Back on the Front Burner
text: BALTIMORE — The next goal Bob Bowman hopes to cross off his list is making a blue cheese soufflé, which seems like a breeze compared with his previous project, making Michael Phelps the most successful Olympian ever. That pursuit had a preparation time of 16 years, and the execution, in a pressure cooker, required continual watchfulness and a precise mix of so many ingredients that Bowman was physically and emotionally spent by the time Phelps was done.

headline: O’Brien Wins Lifetime Achievement Prize for Military Writing
text: Tim O’Brien, the author of “The Things They Carried” and “In the Lake of the Woods,” among other works, has been named as the recipient of the 2013 Pritzker Military Library Literature Award for Lifetime Achievement in Military Writing. The $100,000 prize is to be presented on Nov. 16 at the library’s annual gala. Mr. O’Brien, whose work has often been inspired by his own experiences while serving in the Vietnam War, is the first fiction writer to win the award. In previous years it has been given to writers like James M. McPherson, a Civil War historian, and Rick Atkinson, whose best-selling Liberation Trilogy chronicles the role of the United States military in World War II.

headline: Consortium in Canada Plans Rival Exchange to Curb Rapid Trading
text: OTTAWA — A group led by the Royal Bank of Canada announced plans on Tuesday to set up a rival to the Toronto Stock Exchange, with the aim of circumventing the rapid-trading systems that have come to heavily influence the markets.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Gender Identity
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Baseball Lifer
text: Doc Edwards played with Mickey Mantle and managed the longest game in history. He has a few stories to tell from more than a half-century in professional baseball.

headline: A Baseball Lifer Adds Chapters, a Game at a Time
text: SAN ANGELO, Tex. — In the clubhouse for the San Angelo Colts baseball team, a squat shed of concrete and corrugated metal planted in dust just beyond the left-field fence, a white-haired lifer named Doc Edwards is telling another story when — bam! — a sound like a gunshot goes off. He keeps talking.

headline: London Theater Journal: Hard-Boiled in ‘Chimerica’
text: LONDON — It’s hard to run away from home these days. I crossed the Atlantic on Sunday and on Monday found myself back in America. Or “Chimerica,” to be exact, a morally muddled but cleanly delineated intersection of the American and Chinese empires, which is also the name as well as the setting of Lucy Kirkwood’s hit play at the Almeida Theater.

headline: Glenview Seeks to Replace Board of Hospital Group
text: An investor in Health Management Associates, the for-profit hospital system, proposed on Tuesday to replace the company’s board with a new slate of candidates.

headline: Lawsuit Challenges North Dakota’s Abortion Limits
text: A women’s rights group filed a lawsuit in federal court on Tuesday to block the country’s most stringent abortion law, a North Dakota ban on abortions as early as six weeks into pregnancy.

headline: Google Adds Malware Statistics to Transparency Report
text: In an effort to draw awareness to just how unsafe the Internet has become, Google will be adding statistics about malware to its transparency report.

headline: Wheelies: The Let’s Sit Down and Talk Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring new from around the Web:

headline: Simple Photos From South Korea Light Up the Grand Galleries of Versailles
text: For the past four years, morning till night, the South Korean photographer Ahae, 72, has taken up to 3,000 digital photographs each day of nature, undisturbed — the setting sun, ripples of water, foraging deer, woods dusted by a snow flurry — from a single window on the first floor of his home near Seoul. Starting today at the Orangerie garden at Versailles, 200 of his large- and medium-format prints from the project will be on view for the first time in 10 linear galleries.

headline: Bottoms Up: Beer-Flavored Ice Cream
text: They are two of summer’s signature indulgences. But ice cream and beer, one a childhood staple and the other a primal toast of adulthood, have long worked opposite ends of the picnic.

headline: Why It’s Hard to Build Emergency Savings
text: Despite improvement in the economy, more than a fourth of Americans have no emergency savings. And those who do manage to sock away some money in basic savings accounts get abysmal interest on their funds and sometimes have to pay excessive fees.

headline: Court Rules on Voting Rights Act
text: The Times’s David Leonhardt talks about the implications of the Supreme Court’s decision to strike down a key part of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

headline: A Lean, Ripe Wine to Pair With a Peppery Pasta
text: With the richness of cheese, sharpness of pepper and garden earthiness of peas and beans, you need a wine that can lift and penetrate. My immediate thought: a ripe yet lean sauvignon blanc, with acidity present and accounted for, as in a juicy apple. For ethnic parallelism, an Italian sauvignon from Friuli-Venezia Giulia, though they are tough to find. You could also opt for a bottle from the Sancerre satellites, like a racy, refreshing Pouilly-Fumé or Quincy. Avoid New World sauvignon blancs, which would probably be less incisive. Many other whites would work, like a Fiano di Avellino or, if you can get it, a carricante from Mount Etna. And, since the world yearns for pink in summer, why not a dry Provençal rosé that’s more mineral than fruity? Have a glass while shucking favas.

headline: Managing the Summer Child-Care Scramble
text: Summer evokes images of long afternoons, lounging in a hammock or splashing at the pool. The reality is often less idyllic, especially for working parents — even for those who, like me, work from home.

headline: Keeping a Steady Hand on a Montauk Club
text: “When we first started the Surf Lodge years ago, everyone asked why we would open a place in Montauk, which is an hour away from everything else in the Hamptons,” Jayma Cardoso said. “They all said no one is ever going to go there.”

headline: A Stakeout Grinds On in Airport Limbo
text: MOSCOW — The airport transit area here where Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive American national security contractor, is believed to be planning his next move has a Burger King, a T.G.I. Friday’s and a bar called Pub, or as rendered in Russian, “Pab.” It also has a vast number of locked doors, something you might not notice without spending 17 hours looking for Mr. Snowden.

headline: Snowden, Through the Eyes of a Spy Novelist
text: FOR a spy novelist like me, the Edward J. Snowden story has everything. A man driven by ego and idealism — can anyone ever distinguish the two? — leaves his job and his beautiful girlfriend behind. He must tell the world the Panopticon has arrived. His masters vow to punish him, and he heads for Moscow in a desperate search for refuge. In reality he’s found the world’s most dangerous place to be a dissident, where power is a knife blade and a sprinkle of polonium. For now he’s safe. He’s of use to his new Russian friends. But if they change their minds ...

headline: A Move for the Frugal Traveler
text: Starting this week, the Frugal Traveler column is changing its format — though you’ll barely notice the difference. This blog will no longer be updated, but the column will continue as articles — the same sort you see across nytimes.com. Photos will be more prominent and you’ll still be able to share your thoughts and advice. And you’ll be able to scroll through links to the current and archived articles just as you can now by going to the Frugal Traveler topic page. Change your bookmarks from the page you are on now to to the column page — and watch nytimes.com/travel for weekly Frugal columns. And, as always, you can follow me on Twitter and Facebook.

headline: Democratic Donors to Attend Fund-Raising Meeting for Pro-Clinton Group
text: Two dozen of the Democratic Party’s leading donors will gather for breakfast with allies of Hillary Clinton in New York on Thursday to discuss raising money for a pro-Clinton “super PAC,” according to people with knowledge of the event.

headline: Ecuador Risks Trade Problems With U.S. if It Grants Asylum to Snowden
text: QUITO, Ecuador — President Rafael Correa of Ecuador has more than just the ire of United States to consider as he weighs an asylum request from Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive intelligence contractor trying to dodge American authorities.

headline: Housing Market Shrugging Off Rise in Mortgage Rates
text: Mortgage rates may be inching up, but they have not put a damper on the American housing market’s rebound.

headline: Image of the Day: June 25
text: U.S. secretary of state, John Kerry’s three-day visit to India comes to an end.

headline: Living on East End Avenue
text: An Upper East Side oasis  along the East River has drawn a recent surge of families.

headline: Last-Minute Hotel Bookings Made Cheaper
text: I’m not accustomed to staying in places like Room Mate Emma, a slick boutique hotel in Barcelona. But there I was one Sunday in May, and for only 74 euros (about $99 at $1.33 to the euro). That rate, which I got through the last-minute hotel booking app Blink, was 15 euros less than the price listed on the hotel’s Web site — and a full 65 euros less than the lowest rate for several Sundays later. It was an irresistible deal.

headline: East End Avenue: A Gated State of Mind
text: East End Avenue is not the kind of thoroughfare that casual visitors to New York are likely to stumble across while searching for restaurants, theaters or clubs. They’d have to be looking for it. The neighorhood that it anchors, hugging the edge of the Upper East Side like fuzz on a peach, runs only 13 blocks or so. Most of its transsecting east-west streets end in cul-de-sacs, giving the area an almost gated feel: cars are not likely to pass through on their way to somewhere else.

headline: Running, a Fight and Then a Shot, a Witness Testifies in Zimmerman’s Trial
text: SANFORD, Fla. — The first prosecution witness to testify about what she heard outside her town house here the night Trayvon Martin was killed came under relentless cross-examination on Tuesday from George Zimmerman’s chief defense lawyer, who sought to question not only the consistency of her account but also whether she was antagonistic to the defendant.

headline: The Tigers Invade the Union
text: On June 23, 1863, Gen. Robert E. Lee’s Army of Northern Virginia began to cross the Pennsylvania state line. Gen. Jubal Early’s division led the way, and among Early’s veterans were approximately 1,600 Louisiana Tigers in Gen. Harry T. Hays’s brigade.

headline: At Day’s End, Teachers Pause to Reflect
text: Aliza Eliazarov captured portraits of New York City schoolteachers at the end of the day — a moment of meditation and, often, exhaustion.

headline: Holder on Voting Rights Act Decision
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., an outspoken supporter of the Voting Rights Act, responded to the Supreme Court’s ruling on Tuesday.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Dsquared Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: An Assault on the Voting Rights Act
text: The conservative majority on the Roberts Court issued another damaging and intellectually dishonest ruling on Tuesday. It eviscerated enforcement of the Voting Rights Act, in which Congress kept the promise of a vote for every citizen. But it did not rule on the constitutional validity of the idea that some places have such strong records of discrimination that they must seek federal approval before they may change their voting rules. Instead, the 5-to-4 ruling usurped Congress’s power and struck down the formula that it has repeatedly reauthorized to determine which states fall into that category.

headline: Vigil for Mandela Continues as Family Members Hold Emergency Meeting
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — Singing crowds gathered outside the hospital where Nelson Mandela, South Africa’s former president, lay in a critical state for a third consecutive day on Tuesday, as family members held an emergency meeting at his ancestral village.

headline: In First, F.D.A. Rejects Tobacco Products
text: The Food and Drug Administration announced on Tuesday that for the first time it had begun exercising its power to regulate cigarettes and other tobacco products, an authority it was given under a 2009 law supported by President Obama.

headline: Texas Students on Affirmative Action
text: Students at the University of Texas at Austin react to the Supreme Court’s decision to send the affirmative action case involving their school back to a lower court.

headline: Why Smoking Rates Are at New Lows
text: The smoking rate among adults in the United States has dropped again, an encouraging trend that experts on smoking cessation attribute to public policies like smoke-free air laws and cigarette taxes, as well as media campaigns and less exposure to smoking in movies.

headline: Inspired by Collins, a High School Coach Comes Out
text: When the soccer player Robbie Rogers and the N.B.A. center Jason Collins recently came out as gay professional athletes, it was hailed by many as a historic time. Barriers had been broken. Attitudes in pro sports locker rooms were being changed.

headline: Clearwire Deal Is a Lesson in High-Stakes Bidding
text: The bidding for Clearwire shows that takeovers are sometimes just a poker game, albeit with billions in the pot. Depending upon how well the directors play and when they decide to fold or up the ante, shareholders can be up or down billions of dollars.

headline: Two Court Rulings Related to Race
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nashville Symphony Averts Foreclosure on Concert Hall
text: The Nashville Symphony Association said on Monday it had reached an agreement with creditors to pay an $82.3 million debt to avoid foreclosure and prevent the sale of its concert hall, the Schermerhorn Symphony Center. The deal comes only days before the hall was scheduled to be put up for auction and after months of negotiations about how the symphony would repay the remaining balance of a $102 million bond issue that financed the original construction of the hall, which opened in 2006. Details of the agreement were not disclosed but Martha R. Ingram, a symphony board member, former board chairwoman and noted philanthropist, contributed a large sum to help resolve the matter.

headline: Obama Unveils Climate Change Plan
text: At Georgetown University on Tuesday, the president outlined steps to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and combat global warming through a series of executive actions.

headline: New Boundaries for the Districts API
text: The new political maps are here, just in time for this year’s city elections.

headline: A Guide to the Supreme Court Decision on the Voting Rights Act
text: Analysis of notable passages from the justices’ opinions.

headline: The Intricate Endgame for Dell
text: What is going on with Dell? It’s not what you think as the options for Dell’s shareholders, other than a takeover by Michael S. Dell and Silver Lake, look increasingly limited.

headline: Lafayette
text: Inside Andrew Carmellini’s newest restaurant.

headline: Robson Soothes Angst Over State of British Tennis
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Going into Laura Robson’s first-round match against 10th-seeded Maria Kirilenko on Tuesday, British tennis players not named Andy Murray had won all of one set in seven matches at Wimbledon.

headline: Officials Seize a Picasso Offered for Sale in New York
text: Federal officials have seized a 1909 Picasso painting at the request of the Italian government, which said its owners face embezzlement and fraud charges in Italy.

headline: Over a Century Old, a Carousel Is Given Landmark Status
text: The Cyclone is one. So is the Wonder Wheel. And now a carousel that has been delighting children for over a century has joined the list.

headline: French Class Is in Session
text: In some corners of the food media, the opening of Andrew Carmellini’s new restaurant, Lafayette, was written about the way successful nuclear tests are covered on North Korean television. Some of this was because of Mr. Carmellini’s record as a chef and restaurateur. His first two places, Locanda Verde and the Dutch, are so well loved that he would probably draw a crowd if he sold nothing but Lorna Doones and ginger ale.

headline: No Relief as a Losing Streak Reaches 17 Matches
text: WIMBLEDON, England – Vincent Spadea ended what was believed to be the longest losing streak at the highest level in tennis history 13 years ago at Wimbledon. He upset Greg Rusedski to snap a 21-match barren spell.

headline: The Riches of Hawaii, With Jack Johnson
text: Jack Johnson, 38, is an Oahu native, a former professional surfer, and a popular singer-songwriter who will release his sixth album in the fall. The Johnson Ohana Charitable Foundation, which he founded with his wife, Kim, supports many organic and sustainable-food-related programs in Hawaii. He spoke by phone from Oahu about the riches of Hawaiian food and the symbolic power of pancakes.

headline: Mattek-Sands Goes High Tech
text: Bethanie Mattek-Sands may have lost in the first round of Wimbledon to the No. 7 seed Angelique Kerber in straight sets, but the former Top 30 player says she is a winner in the burgeoning field of on-court tennis technology.

headline: Grisham’s ‘Time to Kill’ Coming to Broadway
text: A stage adaptation of “A Time to Kill,” John Grisham’s legal thriller about a young white lawyer defending a black man for a revenge murder in Mississippi, will open on Broadway in the fall, the producers said on Tuesday.

headline: Dueling Pitchers, Swapped Interpreters
text: On the surface, Tuesday night’s matchup at Yankee Stadium between the two best Japanese pitchers in baseball was intriguing. Hiroki Kuroda and Yu Darvish, the proven veteran and the flashy newcomer, reprised their duel from last season when the Rangers and Darvish, then a rookie, won, 2-0, at Texas.

headline: Where Can a Fugitive Hide?
text: If you were a fugitive from the American government, where would you go? Off the grid? Or to a sympathetic anti-American regime?

headline: Headliner: Splitty
text: There are restaurateurs who serve only burgers but with abundant variations and condiments. Not Andrew McDowell, whose new spot (above) may have the shortest menu in town: three steamed bao buns. That’s it, except for cocktails to accompany the three: pastrami with kimchi sauerkraut, vegetarian mushroom and onion, and a sweet “banana splitty” with Nutella, toasted marshmallows and caramel, $6 each. The chef, Andrey Ayrapetov, once had a barbecue place in Oakland, Calif. Mr. McDowell, who is an owner of Pete’s Candy Store and Doris, both in Brooklyn, considers himself a pioneer in this part of Clinton Hill. “This neighborhood is about to pop,” he said: 415 Myrtle Avenue (Vanderbilt Avenue), Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; (718) 643-2867; splittyny.com.

headline: Chris Brown Charged in Hit-and-Run Case
text: The Los Angeles City Attorney’s Office has filed two misdemeanor charges against the singer Chris Brown in connection with a minor traffic accident in the San Fernando Valley on May 21, a move that may affect his probation on an assault conviction.

headline: Geography, Not Voting Rights Act, Accounts for Most Majority-Minority Districts
text: The Supreme Court’s decision on the Voting Rights Act on Tuesday — which struck down one provision of the law outright, neutered another and set a precedent that could eventually threaten the rest of the legislation — may reduce the pressure on states to create majority-minority districts when they engage in Congressional redistricting after each decennial census.

headline: GQ Makes a Splash in Milan
text: A fraternity of designers celebrates Jim Nelson’s 10th year as GQ’s editor.

headline: Ways to Study the U.S. Supreme Court With The New York Times
text: Updated: Feb., 2016

headline: Car Sharing Grows With Fewer Strings Attached
text: BERLIN — Marc Clemens, founder and chief executive of Sommelier Privé, an online wine service, gave up owning a car a year and a half ago. When he wants to drive to work in the morning, he checks his smartphone to see where a particular BMW, Smart car or Mini is parked and takes it.

headline: On Voting Case, Reaction From ‘Deeply Disappointed’ to ‘It’s About Time’
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday said he was “deeply disappointed” with the Supreme Court’s 5-to-4 decision ruling a central piece of the 1965 Voting Rights Act unconstitutional, and he called on Congress to pass legislation protecting access to voting.

headline: Meaty and Mighty
text: Eggplant is often called “meaty,” by which we mean what, exactly? Substantial? Versatile? Flavorful?

headline: Greek Plan May Reward Some Bank Executives
text: LONDON — Even as European taxpayers grimace at the escalating cost of bailing out Greece’s banking system, the banks’ top executives are poised to potentially strike it rich.

headline: In Italy, a Cocktail With a Splash of the Sea
text: Hotel bartenders have been known to choose cocktail ingredients from on-property gardens or beehives, but rarely the beach. Now one Amalfi Coast resort in Italy has dipped into the Mediterranean to make its new quaff, the Nettuno, or Neptune.

headline: After Loss, Querrey Complains About Tomic’s Use of Injury Timeout
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Bernard Tomic just doesn’t seem to be able to escape controversy, and his antics during his five-set win over Sam Querrey on Tuesday led to Querrey accusing him of unsportsmanlike behavior.

headline: Front Burner:  A New Gelato Shop, Lobster Rolls for a Cause and More
text: To Indulge: An Italian Gelato, as a Brazilian Would

headline: The Making Of | A 19th-Century Victorian House in London, Built With Mirrors
text: In the latest off-site commission of the Barbican Gallery in London, the Argentine artist Leandro Erlich has created a surreal new artwork in the Borough of Hackney. Located on an empty lot on Ashwin Street near Dalston Junction station, Dalston House is the latest in a series of projects by Erlich that seem to defy the laws of physics, challenging audiences’ sense of reality. Visitors will be able to hang out the windows and scale the walls of Erlich’s replica of a late-19th-century Victorian terraced house. Although these death-defying activities might appear to break all health and safety regulations for a public art project, they’re perfectly safe: it’s all an illusion, created with mirrors. Here, the artist explains how he realized his vision.

headline: Hotel Review: Hotel O in Paris
text: RATES

headline: Rising to Glory on the Wings of Ducks
text: Robert Steiner is not a household name, but on Friday, with the issue of the new federal duck stamp, he begins a yearlong run as one of the most visible artists in the United States.

headline: Duck Stamps Through the Years
text: On Friday the Fish and Wildlife Service will announce the winner of its annual Duck Stamp Contest. The contest dates to the 1930s.

headline: After Twists, Turns and Horn Calls, a Huntress Gets Her Shepherd
text: Tchaikovsky’s “Swan Lake” has become, with his “Nutcracker,” the most popular ballet in international repertory. Yet in December 1877, only months after its premiere, he wrote in a letter of first hearing Delibes’s “Sylvia” (1876), “Never before has there been a ballet with such grace, such melodic and rhythmic richness, such superlative scoring.” To another friend he wrote, “If I had known this music earlier, I would not have written ‘Swan Lake.’ ”

headline: Milan Men’s Spring 2014 Accessories
text: Accessories from the spring 2014 shows in Milan.

headline: A Culinary Birthright in Dispute
text: From her first televised “y’all” in 1999, Paula Deen has worked harder to promote Southern food than anyone in the modern media era, wielding frosted hair and frosted doughnuts as her weapons.

headline: Forgoing a Fight, Senators Confirm Commerce Secretary
text: WASHINGTON — Senators pick their battles, and by Tuesday, members in both parties had decided not to have one with President Obama over his nomination of Penny Pritzker, the billionaire hotel heiress, to be commerce secretary. In a 97-to-1 vote, they confirmed her to join the cabinet.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Afghanistan, Lebanon, Brazil and India.

headline: Qualifier Draws Unusual Amount of Attention
text: WIMBLEDON, England – A qualifier ranked 107th would not normally draw enough requests from journalists to warrant being placed in the main interview room at Wimbledon – especially after losing.

headline: Flying to New Zealand, and Then Beyond
text: Once fliers have made the long-haul trip to New Zealand – nonstops between Los Angeles and Auckland are 13 hours – three-hour flights to Australia and Fiji may seem like a relative breeze.

headline: The Great Abortion Filibuster
text: Republicans in Texas, always hip to the latest trends, are trying to ban abortion after 20 weeks and impose new restrictions on providers that would sharply reduce the number of clinics in the state. And they don’t want to include an exemption for women who were victims of rape or incest. The bill’s sponsor, Rep. Jodie Laubenberg, said such an exemption wasn’t necessary because: “In the emergency room they have what’s called rape kits where a woman can get cleaned out.”

headline: $1.2 Million Disappears From a Passenger-Jet Shipment of U.S. Currency
text: When passengers boarded Swiss International Air Lines Flight 17 from Zurich to New York City last weekend, they probably had no idea that the cargo hold beneath their feet was also functioning as a bank vault, carrying tens of millions of dollars.

headline: Cut Adrift by Its Would-Be Rescuer, Seaport Museum Seeks a Lifeline
text: Wanted: One responsible steward for a beleaguered museum that chronicles New York City’s maritime history through ships and artifacts and has been under water literally and figuratively over the last few years — struggling to pay the bills, and then flooded by Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Excerpt: 'Rantoul and Die'
text: Matthew Pilieci and Derek Ahonen in a scene from Mark Roberts’s new play.

headline: Scholar Asserts That Hollywood Avidly Aided Nazis
text: The list of institutions and industries that have been accused of whitewashing their links to the Third Reich is long, including various governments, the Vatican, Swiss banks and American corporations like I.B.M., General Motors and DuPont.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week: Giorgio Armani Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Escaping a Broken Marriage in a Ruined Town
text: If you describe the plot of “Rantoul and Die” to a friend, as I did, you will probably find yourself muttering, “but it’s still really funny, I swear.”

headline: One Dublin Day in June, Consumed by Errands and Eros
text: It takes audacity to adapt James Joyce’s “Ulysses” for the stage. No wonder Patrick Fitzgerald’s “Gibraltar” — starring himself and Cara Seymour, now at the Irish Repertory Theater — is subtitled “An Adaptation After James Joyce’s ‘Ulysses.’ ” Any stage version can only graze the book’s infinite layers. But there are plenty of those layers here.

headline: The Big Man Under the Afro, and His Music
text: Whenever I read a book by a musician, groupie, rock critic, producer, record mogul or roadie, on the end pages I keep a running tally of the songs I’m aching to download when the reading is done. Most times, the longer the list, the better the book.

headline: Home-Cooked Challenge Wrap-Up: A Week’s Worth of Dinners
text: In the name of the Home-Cooked Challenge, I yanked all the junk food (all the packaged food, really, since I don’t think it’s exactly fair to my beloved Effie’s Oatcakes to call them junk) from our pantry in the hope that when snacking wasn’t so easy, we’d snack less and think about our snacking more. The too-easy to grab snacks still aren’t back as we work out a compromise between making junk food a coveted forbidden fruit and the snack free-for-all into which we had descended.

headline: Scene City: Party at the Source, in the Hudson Valley
text: Scenic Hudson honors Andre Balazs for preservation work.

headline: Party at the Source, in the Hudson Valley
text: Who needs the East End? On Saturday night, a high-profile gathering formed alongside a vegetable patch in Staatsburg, N.Y., not far from Rhinebeck in Dutchess County, where a wall was covered in photographs recently taken by Annie Leibovitz.

headline: Documentary Under Cover as a DIY Guide to Success
text: Introduced as a brash manual for the novice drug dealer, Matthew Cooke’s documentary “How to Make Money Selling Drugs” is a condemnation of the war against drugs, but buttonholes the audience with a relentless voice-over. You can make this amount of money a day by selling cocaine, we’re told, and soon you’ll go from chump to millionaire.

headline: ‘Demand’
text: The Parents Transparency Project released a new ad calling on all mayoral candidates to "stand up" to the teachers' union.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Pandora vs. Musicians, and Prism Against the Secret Web
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: A Lifetime of Songwriting, as Sung by Her Children
text: When she died in 2010 at 63, the Canadian singer-songwriter Kate McGarrigle left behind a trove of wonderful songs and recordings, most of them made with her sister Anna. Among the other musical gifts she passed on to later generations are her children, Martha and Rufus Wainwright, who possess two of the most beautiful voices in the world. It may be enough to say that “Sing Me the Songs That Say I Love You,” Lian Lunson’s new documentary, weaves together these strands of McGariggle’s musical legacy, as her son and daughter perform a selection of their mother’s work.

headline: A Different Approach at Google Ventures
text: Google Ventures is 10 miles and a world away from Sand Hill Road, the home of start-up investing.

headline: Snowden Stays Safe in Moscow Airport
text: The Times’s Ellen Barry reports from Moscow, where the Russian government decided not to accede to demands from the United States that it capture Edward J. Snowden.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Former CNN Anchor Brings Teacher Misconduct Into Mayoral Race
text: She lobbied New York state leaders, spoke out in opinion pages and waged war on Twitter. Now Campbell Brown, the former CNN anchor, has taken her campaign for stricter teacher misconduct laws to the New York City mayoral race. Ms. Brown and a new group, the Parents’ Transparency Project, recently announced a $100,000 television advertising campaign across seven channels. The ads urge the candidates to make it easier for the city to fire teachers accused of sexual misconduct.

headline: ‘Arab Idol’ Winner Returns to Palestine to Cheers and Unease
text: KHAN YUNIS REFUGEE CAMP, Gaza Strip — The winner of “Arab Idol,” a one-time wedding singer who made it big, returned home here on Tuesday to both excitement and unease.

headline: Patience for Reopening Latino Cultural Space Is Gone
text: The Julia de Burgos Cultural Center, a city-owned building in East Harlem, has long been an important hub for the neighborhood’s Latino population. Named after a renowned Puerto Rican poet, the five-story building served as a place for local artists to showcase their work and residents to gather to celebrate birthdays, hold funerals, discuss community affairs and dance salsa.

headline: Calm Returns to Lebanese City, but Tensions Remain
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — With shattered glass and bullet casings still littering the streets, businesses reopened and people went back to work in the coastal city of Sidon on Tuesday after a 48-hour battle between supporters of a radical Sunni cleric and Lebanese troops that left dozens dead. But in the aftermath of the battle, involving some of the worst mayhem since Lebanon’s civil war, resentments simmered and political questions loomed.

headline: Basquiat Painting Draws Top Price at Christie’s
text: LONDON — An untitled 1982 painting by Jean-Michel Basquiat depicting two large figures surrounded by the artist’s graffiti-like scrawls sold at Christie’s here on Tuesday night for $29 million. The oilstick-on-panel, which had been expected to bring about $23 million to $30 million, was bought by an unidentified telephone bidder.

headline: William Hathaway, Senator From Maine, Dies at 89
text: William D. Hathaway, a Democratic politician whose election to the United States Senate from Maine in 1972 ended the career of his Republican opponent, Margaret Chase Smith, the first woman elected to both houses of Congress, died on Monday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 89.

headline: Yankees Say Desire to Cut Payroll Won’t Hinder This Season’s Spending Needs
text: The Yankees’ desire to trim their payroll to below the luxury-tax threshold of $189 million for next season will not hinder their ability to improve the roster this summer if it meant adding salary, Randy Levine, the team’s president, said Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Moves to Abandon Costly Reactor Fuel Plant
text: WASHINGTON — The Energy Department is moving toward abandoning a half-built factory that has cost $3.7 billion so far and was intended to make reactor fuel out of plutonium from retired nuclear bombs — part of an agreement with Russia to shrink the world’s supply of nuclear bomb fuel after the cold war.

headline: Court Ruling on Voting Act May Affect New York City
text: The impact of the Supreme Court’s decision Tuesday to strike down part of the Voting Rights Act may be seen in New York City as early as this September in the mayoral primary.

headline: When Congress Abdicates
text: I have gone over Chief Justice John Roberts’ majority opinion in today’s Voting Rights Act decision twice, and each time it has persuaded me that the V.R.A. should be revised in light of current conditions without persuading me that this is a question that the Supreme Court should be adjudicating. But rather than rehearsing my frequent complaints about how conservative judges have grown overly comfortable with their own style of counter-majoritarian activism, I’ll just express my agreement with Ramesh Ponnuru’s take on both the V.R.A. case and the looming gay marriage decisions, which he published before today’s ruling was handed down:

headline: Matches to Watch at Wimbledon on Day 3
text: In the beginning of the second round, play shifts back to the bottom halves of the men’s and women’s singles draws, which are no longer as loaded as they once were with the shocking exit of Rafael Nadal.

headline: Scientists Find Canadian Oil Safe for Pipelines, but Critics Say Questions Remain
text: Diluted bitumen — the blend of thick Canadian crude that would be shipped by the proposed Keystone XL pipeline — is no riskier to transport than other types of crude oil, a new study has found, a conclusion that came under sharp attack by environmentalists.

headline: Royal Bank of Canada Gains by Putting the Brakes on Traders
text: The spoils on Wall Street generally go to the firm that is the fastest and most opaque. But one upstart contender is trying a distinctly counterintuitive approach.

headline: Telling Identical Twins Apart by First-Round Results at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Kristyna has blond hair, a Maori-style tattoo, and likes Paulo Coelho novels. Karolina is more blonde, has two Maori-style tattoos and prefers Nicholas Sparks. A 6-foot left-hander, Kristyna won the junior singles title here; Karolina, a 6-1 right-hander, claimed the same prize at the Australian Open.

headline: Housekeeper in New Jersey Accuses Peruvian Diplomat of Human Trafficking
text: A Peruvian woman has accused a top official at Peru’s mission to the United Nations of entrapping her in a life of involuntary servitude in the New Jersey suburbs, forcing her to work as many as 16 hours a day, 7 days a week for little or no compensation.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: Recent Sale

headline: Losing Ground on Nook, Barnes & Noble Ceases Its Own Manufacture of Color Versions
text: Barnes & Noble has conceded that it cannot compete head-to-head with the iPad and the Kindle Fire.

headline: G.O.P. in House Leaves Immigration Bill in Doubt
text: WASHINGTON — With the Senate days away from passing the most significant immigration legislation in a generation, House Republicans say they feel no pressure to act quickly on a similar measure, leaving the fate of the bill very much in doubt despite solid bipartisan Senate support.

headline: There’s a Nice Jaguar Parked Across From the House That Appeared in ‘Mad Men’
text: Spoiler Alert: If you haven’t seen the season finale of “Mad Men,” stop reading now. If you have, or if you don’t care that much about “Mad Men” then please proceed.

headline: Poll Finds Rural Voters Are Divided on Federal Role
text: Voters in some of the nation’s most rural areas, long considered a mainstay of small-government sentiments, have mixed views about the role federal policies should play in their lives, according to polling released Tuesday by the Center for Rural Affairs.

headline: Copter Crash Kills 19 as Flood Rescue Efforts Strain Indian Air Force
text: DEHRADUN, India — Ever since flash floods struck a mountainous area of northern India last week, 60 Indian military and civilian helicopters have been navigating fog, rain and treacherous Himalayan valleys looking for survivors and recovering bodies as part of the biggest airborne rescue and recovery operation in the history of the Indian military.

headline: Smith’s Contract Move Puts His Knicks Future in Doubt
text: J. R. Smith, the Knicks’ mercurial sixth man, has declined his $2.93 million contract option for next season and will become an unrestricted free agent on July 1.

headline: Massachusetts: Cardinal Bars a Priest’s Speech
text: Cardinal Sean O’Malley has barred a prominent Austrian priest from speaking in a Roman Catholic parish in the Archdiocese of Boston because the priest advocates the ordination of women and married men as one solution to the priest shortage. The appearance by the priest, the Rev. Helmut Schüller in Boston on July 17  is part of a cross-country speaking tour sponsored by 10  liberal Catholic groups that are pressing the church for change. The Archdiocese of Boston said that its policy, like the practice in other dioceses, is to prohibit individuals who promote “positions that are contrary to Catholic teachings” from speaking in Catholic parishes and at church events. Father Schüller helped lead an “Appeal to Disobedience” backed by about 400 priests and deacons in 2011, and was later stripped of his formal title of monsignor. His talk in Boston has been moved to a Unitarian Universalist church, but he is scheduled to speak at a Catholic parish in Detroit and a Catholic college in Pennsylvania.

headline: After Decades Among Yankees and Mets, a Shutter Stops Snapping
text: “When I met Pop at the old stadium, he had a booth in the back of my pizza station, Main 11,” Alva Robinson said. “We got to be friends — swapping pizza and pictures. I do popcorn now. I’m the popcorn lady. But I always made sure Pop had his ice water, soda.”

headline: Chinese Investors Pursue U.S. Property Deals
text: First, it was the Japanese. Moneymen from Tokyo blew into the United States to buy famous pieces of the American landscape, from Rockefeller Center in New York to the Pebble Beach Golf Links in California.

headline: Filibuster in Texas Senate Tries to Halt Abortion Bill
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Texas Democrats tried to prevent Republicans from passing a bill on Tuesday that would give the state some of the toughest abortion restrictions in the country, even as Gov. Rick Perry appeared ready to keep lawmakers in town to give the bill another chance.

headline: Let Them Eat Soccer
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — SINCE early June, protests that began out of anger over public transit fare increases have spread across Brazil, filling the streets of São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro and dozens of other cities with hundreds of thousands of demonstrators. On June 13, the police cracked down violently and the protests mushroomed. Finally, after seven days, the government of President Dilma Rousseff pushed governors and mayors to cancel the fare increases they had presented as the inevitable price of a modern market economy.

headline: Talk to Iran’s New President. Warily.
text: THE election of Hassan Rowhani as Iran’s new president has created a sense that there are new possibilities of progress on the nuclear issue; we need to respond, but warily. Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, allowed Mr. Rowhani to win the election recognizing that he had run against current Iranian policies that have isolated the country and invited economically disastrous sanctions. But it isn’t clear why Mr. Khamenei allowed such an outcome, and here are some theories that have been proposed:

headline: The True Deservers of a Food Prize
text: If Secretary of State John Kerry’s G.M.O.-boosting speech announcing the World Food Prize at the State Department last week is any indication of his ability to parse complicated issues, he might be better off windsurfing. Because Kerry appears to have bought into the big ag-driven myth that only by relying on genetic engineering will we be able to feed the nine billion citizens of our planet by 2050. And he enthusiastically endorsed granting this mockery of a prize to three biotech engineers, including Robert Fraley, executive vice president and chief technology officer at Monsanto and a pioneer of genetic engineering in agriculture.

headline: The Chief Justice’s Long Game
text: IN an opinion brimming with a self-confidence that he hides behind a cloak of judicial minimalism, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., writing for a conservative Supreme Court majority in Shelby County v. Holder, cripples Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act.

headline: C. S. Lewis, Evangelical Rock Star
text: In 2005, Time magazine called C. S. Lewis the “hottest theologian” of the year — 42 years after his death. That same year, a cover story in Christianity Today hailed him as a “superstar.” To this day Lewis, who published the first of his children’s books about “Narnia” in 1950, remains deeply compelling for many evangelicals, more so than for Catholics and mainline Protestants. Why?

headline: Army to Cut Its Forces by 80,000 in 5 Years
text: WASHINGTON — Gen. Ray Odierno, the Army chief of staff, said Tuesday that the Army would institute the largest organizational change since World War II by eliminating combat forces from 10 bases across the United States, part of a planned reduction of 80,000 active-duty troops over the next five years.

headline: At Last, an Action Plan on Climate
text: President Obama has long believed, as have we, that the surest way to address the threats of climate change is to put a price on the carbon emissions that power plants, cars and other users of fossil fuels emit in great quantities, without cost to the polluters but at great cost to the planet. Congress has refused to enact such a program, so Mr. Obama has now stepped forward with measures he can pursue without Congressional consent.

headline: Bittersweet Achievement on Climate
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA’s announcement on Tuesday that he will use his executive authority to regulate carbon-dioxide emissions from existing power plants, and to finalize rules for plants that have yet to be built, is reason to celebrate — but also an occasion for mourning. The announcement reflects Congress’s refusal to pass serious laws to curb greenhouse-gas emissions. Ultimately, if America is to fully contribute to an effective global response to the perils of a warming planet, Congress must stop dithering.

headline: Reforms for Chinese Banking
text: In an eerie echo of the financial crisis of 2008, the rates at which Chinese banks lend to each other shot up last week, sending a wave of panic through global stock and bond markets. The sudden jump highlighted systemic problems in the country’s financial system that will test the ability of Beijing’s new leaders to reform the world’s second-largest economy.

headline: A Hunger for a Better Life May Lead to the N.B.A.
text: ATHENS — His new passport says he is Greek, but Giannis Adetokunbo has lived a struggling immigrant’s life. He has peddled goods on city streets to feed himself and his brothers. While other families ferried off on island vacations, his often changed apartments in search of cheaper rent.

headline: Taliban’s Divided Tactics Raise Doubts Over Talks
text: DOHA, Qatar — When the Taliban opened their political office in Qatar last week, stepping into the halogen glare of TV cameras, it was the first time in a dozen years that the world had gotten to see members of the insurgents’ inner circle — and they seemed different. Urbane and educated, they conducted interviews in English, Arabic, French and German with easy fluency; passed out and received phone numbers; and, most strikingly, talked about peace.

headline: Dropping Out of College, and Paying the Price
text: David Beltrán has a solid understanding of the benefits of a college education. The 22-year-old from Queens — a journalism major at Brooklyn College — has seen too many friends drop out only to find themselves working at a fast-food counter or at a construction job. “They are getting by, but they are not very happy.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Annals of Spying, at Home and Abroad

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 26, 2013
text: “Congress — if it is to divide the states — must identify those jurisdictions to be singled out on a basis that makes sense in light of current conditions. It cannot simply rely on the past.”

headline: Dimitrov Likes the English Weather
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Wimbledon was bathed in glorious sunshine Tuesday, but the soaring temperatures are not expected to last, with rain predicted to come later in the week.

headline: F.T.C. Tells Search Engines to Label Advertising as Such
text: WASHINGTON — Search engine companies should more clearly distinguish on their Web pages between advertising, paid content and the results of an Internet search, the Federal Trade Commission told two dozen search engine providers on Tuesday.

headline: The Blackhawks’ Comeback, in Perspective
text: BOSTON — Even the Chicago Blackhawks had trouble comprehending their electrifying comeback Monday night. Trailing the Bruins, 2-1, with 76 seconds remaining in Game 6, the Blackhawks scored two goals within 17 seconds — the first by Bryan Bickell and the second by Dave Bolland — to secure the Stanley Cup.

headline: Passing Up a Good Deal
text: College graduation rates in the United States are failing to keep up with those in other advanced nations despite a high return on investment.

headline: New York Moves to Require Audits of Preschool Special-Education Contractors
Commercials With a Gay Emphasis Are Moving to Mainstream Media
text: WHEN Expedia decided to begin running on television this month a commercial it had introduced online in October, about a father’s trip to attend his daughter’s wedding to another woman, the media plan was drawn up to include Logo, the cable channel aimed at gay and lesbian viewers. But the commercial is also running on networks watched by general audiences, like CNN, History, MSNBC and the National Geographic Channel.

headline: Prospects in the House
text: Few of the Republican senators who voted for the border security deal come from states with large House Republican delegations.

headline: Report Finds Lapses in United States Aid Efforts in Haiti
text: MEXICO CITY — The agency managing some of the United States’ signature projects to rebuild Haiti after the 2010 earthquake has yet to spend a large amount of the money Congress authorized and has scaled back planned housing because of delays and complications, according to a report Tuesday by a government watchdog.

headline: Call Up Davis? When Time Is Right and Pitchers Are Right-Handed
text: CHICAGO — Ike Davis has shown signs that he may be rediscovering his power swing, but he is not being rushed back by the Mets, even as a roster hole exists.

headline: Corrections: June 26, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Four Score and Three
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Let’s talk about how AGE is just a number.

headline: In Brooklyn Neighborhood, Multiplying Massage Parlors Cause Residents to Fret
text: The question has puzzled the neighborhood of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn: Do so many residents have strained backs and overstressed muscles, or is something else going on?

headline: From Minors to Yankees, and Playing a Major Role
text: Outfielder Zoilo Almonte was so focused on making daily progress in the minors that he barely considered when a promotion to the Yankees might come.

headline: Prosecutors Drop Charges Against E.M.T.
text: Prosecutors on Tuesday dropped charges against an emergency medical technician who had been accused of not helping a pregnant woman who collapsed and later died in a Brooklyn cafe.

headline: Elizabeth Ann Stribling-Kivlan
text: Ms. Stribling-Kivlan, 34, is the new president of Stribling & Associates, a residential real estate brokerage firm based in New York. The company was founded in 1981 by her mother, Elizabeth F. Stribling, formerly the president and now the chairwoman.

headline: Czech President Defies Governing Coalition in Naming Premier
text: PRAGUE — President Milos Zeman of the Czech Republic appointed his leftist economic adviser as prime minister on Tuesday, openly defying the choice of the outgoing center-right governing coalition, which is ensnared in a corruption and bribery scandal.

headline: Obama Puts Legacy at Stake With Clean-Air Act
text: With no chance of Congressional support, President Obama is staking part of his legacy on a big risk: that he can substantially reduce greenhouse gas emissions by stretching the intent of a law decades old and not written with climate change in mind.

headline: Man Sentenced to 9½ Years in ’10 Attack on Cabdriver
text: Nearly three years ago, Michael Enright asked a taxi driver if he was a Muslim. When the driver answered yes, Mr. Enright yelled Muslim-based insults and lunged through the partition with a knife, stabbing and slashing away.

headline: Germany, Belgium and France Make Arrests in Reported Plots
text: BERLIN — Scores of special police officers raided at least nine sites in southern Germany and Belgium on Tuesday after what the German authorities said was a tip about an Islamist plot involving two men of Tunisian origin who were planning to stage terrorist attacks involving explosives and remote-controlled model airplanes.

headline: John L. Dotson Jr., Publisher of Beacon Journal, Dies at 76
text: John L. Dotson Jr., a prominent journalist who became one of the nation’s first African-American publishers of a general circulation daily newspaper and who guided the paper, The Akron Beacon Journal of Ohio, to a Pulitzer Prize for a series on race relations, died on Friday at his home in Boulder, Colo. He was 76.

headline: Most Watched Stanley Cup Finals Since 1994
text: The Chicago Blackhawks’ six-game Stanley Cup finals victory over the Boston Bruins averaged 5.76 million viewers on NBC and the NBC Sports Network, the most watched finals since 1994.

headline: Records Sealed in Murder Case Involving Hernandez
text: A Massachusetts judge sealed the records of the district court overseeing the murder investigation involving Patriots tight end Aaron Hernandez. Attleboro District Court Magistrate Mark E. Sturdy said all records relating to the death of Odin Lloyd, whose body was found less than a mile from Hernandez’s home in North Attleborough on June 17, would be kept from public view.

headline: Big Labor Group Endorses Quinn
text: After years of feeling shut out of City Hall, the city’s influential unions were hoping this year to maximize their effects on the mayor’s race by coalescing behind one labor-friendly candidate.

headline: Mexico: Official Assails Migration Bill, Saying Fences ‘Are Not the Solution’
text: Mexico broke its silence on Tuesday on the effort by the United States Congress to overhaul immigration laws, saying more border fencing and security measures approved by the Senate on Monday would not help control migration and could deter trade. “Fences do not unite us,” Foreign Minister Jose Antonio Meade told reporters. “They are not the solution to the migratory phenomenon and are not consistent with a secure and modern border. They do not contribute to the development of a competitive region.” Mexico has largely kept quiet on the immigration debate, fearing a backlash, while privately making it known to lawmakers that it supported the idea of providing a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants. The Senate bill would provide such a path, but would also nearly double the number of border agents and complete 700 miles of fencing. Mexico has long chafed at the border wall and has recently pushed for easing cross-border trade.

headline: Weiner Gets a Step Ahead of Other Democrats in Poll
text: For those who dismissed former Representative Anthony D. Weiner’s last-minute entry into the 2013 mayor’s race as a futile exercise in narcissism, think again: He is now leading the field by a small margin.

headline: Beyond Black and White, New Force Reshapes South
text: The Deep South was, quite literally, a black and white world in 1965, when Congress approved the Voting Rights Act, sweeping away barriers that kept African-Americans from the polls.

headline: Changes in the American Rankings
text: WIMBLEDON, England — While the number of Americans in the upper reaches of the ATP rankings is not what it once was, the United States still boasts 18 men in the top 200. This is the order of the 18 American men going into the top 200, with their ATP rankings in parentheses.

headline: Richard Matheson, Writer of Haunted Science Fiction and Horror, Dies at 87
text: Richard Matheson, whose novels, short stories, screenplays and teleplays drew the blueprints for dozens of science fiction and horror movies and television shows, died on Sunday at his home in Calabasas, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Filip Topol, a Rock Musician of the Czech Revolution, Dies at 48
text: Filip Topol, a Czech rock musician whose intense vocal style and manic piano playing with his band, Psi Vojaci, lent a coarse but poetic soundtrack to Czechoslovakia’s Velvet Revolution in 1989, died on June 19 in his apartment in Prague. He was 48.

headline: Evening Is Full of Yankees Shots
text: The most notable development concerning the Yankees on Tuesday night did not occur in the Bronx, or on a baseball field, or even in a training room, as so often has been their fate this season. It materialized over cyberspace, first in the form of a misguided Twitter post fired off by the team’s most controversial player, and then in a scathing response by General Manager Brian Cashman, whose already waning patience with Alex Rodriguez was tested yet again.

headline: Dialing Up a Hit? Influence Over Musical Is in the Crowd’s Hands
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Seven minutes into his new musical, “Somewhere in Time,” the Broadway producer Ken Davenport leapt off his stool at the back of the theater the other night, and began pointing. Not at the stage, but at a nearby laptop that showed — in a fever-chart line — the reactions of 60 audience members as they turned hand-held dials among three choices: “Love this part,” “Neutral about this part” and “Hate this part.”

headline: With Wheeler Shaky, the Mets Show Life but Ultimately Fall Short
text: CHICAGO — After Zack Wheeler’s first start last week, the Mets were cataloging all the exciting things they had seen. After his second one Tuesday night, they were listing the things they hoped to see him improve upon.

headline: Elliott Reid, Sleuth in ‘Gentlemen Prefer Blondes,’ Dies at 93
text: Elliott Reid, a character actor familiar to television and movie audiences and probably best remembered as Jane Russell’s love interest in the 1953 film “Gentlemen Prefer Blondes,” died on Friday in Studio City, Calif. He was 93.

headline: Lebanon: Bank Settles Case With U.S.
text: Federal prosecutors announced Tuesday that a Lebanese bank linked to what they described as a vast money-laundering operation by Hezbollah, the militant Lebanese Shiite organization, had agreed to a $102 million settlement. The settlement will come from $150 million impounded by the Justice Department last August from the bank, the Lebanese Canadian Bank, which is now in liquidation. Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, said in a statement that the settlement “shows that banks laundering money for terrorists and narco-traffickers will face consequences for their actions, wherever they may be located.” A federal lawsuit filed in 2011 placed the bank at the center of what prosecutors and drug enforcement officials said was a scheme in which it laundered the proceeds from sales of Colombian narcotics and used cars that were exported from the United States. The lawsuit said the bank then repatriated the laundered money to Lebanon, where Hezbollah received a portion. Hezbollah dismissed the lawsuit as propaganda.

headline: A Popular Myth About Running Injuries
text: Almost everyone who runs (or has shopped for running shoes) has heard that how your foot pronates, or rolls inward, as you land affects your injury risk. Pronate too much or too little, conventional wisdom tells us, and you’ll wind up hurt. But a provocative new study shows that this deeply entrenched belief is probably wrong and that there is still a great deal we don’t understand about pronation and why the foot rolls as it does.

headline: From Leucadia, a Final Letter to Shareholders
text: It would be a stretch to classify the letter to shareholders as a literary genre. But for some companies, like Berkshire Hathaway or the Leucadia National Corporation, these annual dispatches are eagerly consumed not only by shareholders but also by interested observers.

headline: The Perils of Significant Misunderstandings in Evaluating Medicaid
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Word of the Day | preamble
text: preamble •\ˈpre-ˌam-bəl, pre-ˈ\• noun

headline: China: Astronauts Return Safely
text: Three Chinese astronauts returned safely to earth on Wednesday after a 15-day mission that included docking exercises, a televised science demonstration for children and a phone call from their country’s president, Xi Jinping, state television reported. The Shenzhou 10 capsule landed in northeast China, ending China’s fifth manned space mission. China is seeking to master the skills and technology needed to operate a manned space lab for long stretches, and the crew on the latest flight practiced rendezvous and docking exercises with the orbiting Tiangong 1 space module, a small prototype of such a lab. China first sent an astronaut into space in 2003, and government engineers have said they may eventually try to send an astronaut to the moon.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (CBS) BIG BROTHER A new crop of 16 contestants moves into a redesigned house to play a game that’s been tweaked for the 15th installment of the show. In the first twist of the series, three houseguests will be nominated each week for eviction, instead of the usual two. In the second, viewers can vote for the houseguest they believe is playing the best game, with the winner anointed that week’s “Big Brother M.V.P.” Before the arrival of the houseguests, the cast of “The Talk” — Sharon Osbourne, Sara Gilbert, Sheryl Underwood, Aisha Tyler and Julie Chen (above, the “Big Brother” host) — moves into the house for an abbreviated version of the game, at 2.

headline: No Nachos for You, General Zod, We’re on Weight Watchers
Richard Matheson’s Tales on Film
text: Here is a modest sampling of scenes from horror movies that were based on Richard Matheson’s novels, short stories, screenplays and teleplays. Related Obituary »

headline: News Quiz | June 26, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Asian Markets Calmed by China Central Bank
text: HONG KONG — Mainland Chinese stocks slipped slightly on Wednesday, and European and many other Asian markets edged higher, as investors reacted to moves by China’s central bank late Tuesday to assuage concerns about a lingering credit squeeze in the country’s financial system.

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 26
text: NEWS Ever since flash floods struck a mountainous area of northern India last week, 60 Indian military and civilian helicopters have been navigating fog, rain and treacherous Himalayan valleys looking for survivors and recovering bodies as part of the biggest airborne rescue and recovery operation in the history of the Indian military. As of Tuesday, the operation had rescued more than 12,000 people. The flooding, which began June 16, triggered by monsoons, has killed at least 1,000. But the rescue operation is not without hazards of its own. On Tuesday, a helicopter crashed into a mountain, killing 19 aboard. Hari Kumar reports from Dehradun, India.

headline: U.S. Is a ‘Hacker Empire,’ Says Chinese Military Analyst
text: BEIJING — For more than an hour Wednesday morning, a Chinese military analyst excoriated the United States over what state-run media here calls “Prismgate”  — the revelations of National Security Agency surveillance by Edward J. Snowden, a former N.S.A contractor.

headline: Clinics in Jeopardy
text: A proposed state law requiring all abortion clinics to be licensed as ambulatory surgery centers could force many of Texas’ abortion clinics to close.

headline: In Texas, a Senator’s Stand Catches the Spotlight
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — She was a state senator Tuesday morning. By Wednesday, she was a political celebrity known across the nation. But also hoarse, hungry and thirsty.

headline: 27 Die in Rioting in Western China
text: HONG KONG — At least 27 people died in rioting in far western China on Wednesday, when protesters attacked a police station and government offices and the police fired on the crowd, state media said. It was the worst spasm of violence for years in Xinjiang, a region troubled by tensions between Uighurs, an overwhelmingly Muslim ethnic minority, and China’s Han majority.

headline: Australian Prime Minister Is Ousted by Party Rival
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Former Prime Minister Kevin Rudd on Wednesday pulled off one of the most sensational political comebacks in Australian history, ousting in a party vote Prime Minister Julia Gillard, the woman who replaced him as leader of the Labor Party in a 2010 coup.

headline: With Snowden Gone, Hong Kong Focuses on U.S. Surveillance
text: HONG KONG — The abrupt departure from Hong Kong on Sunday of Edward J. Snowden, the American former national security contractor, with the explicit approval of the Hong Kong government, has drawn the ire of the United States. But in Hong Kong the focus remains on Mr. Snowden’s exposure of American intelligence-gathering operations in Hong Kong and mainland China.

headline: How Raja Ravi Varma Changed Indian Illustrated Art
text: NEW DELHI— In 1881, Sayaji Rao Gaekwad III, was looking for a painter to create his portrait as the newly crowned maharaja of Baroda, a princely state in Western India. As always, he sought the help of his mentor, Thanjavur Madhava Rao, the diwan, or chief minister, of his state, who had held the same position in the princely state of Travancore in southern India from 1857 to 1872.

headline: Mongolia Re-Elects Leader to Another 4-Year Term
text: HONG KONG — Mongolians appeared Thursday to have re-elected their president to a second four-year term, giving him half the vote needed to avoid a runoff election in a race that focused on demands that the resource-rich country do a better job of distributing wealth to its citizenry.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 26, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question, created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article “From Apple, an Overhaul for Mobile and the Mac.”

headline: Bringing Invisible Stories to Instagram Followers
text: A year after Radcliffe Roye went to New Orleans to photograph survivors of Hurricane Katrina, his archives were crammed with hundreds of 4-by-5 images that sat unseen and unpublished. He wonders now whether, if Instagram had existed at the time, he would have had a better opportunity to share the voices of the people working to rebuild their city.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A History of Voting Rights
text: In the video “A History of Voting Rights,” Sam Tanenhaus explains that voting has been a contentious issue for much of the 20th century, but that the Supreme Court struck down Section 4 of the 1965 Voting Rights Act on Tuesday, suggesting that conditions had changed.

headline: Aggregate Supply, Aggregate Demand, and Coal
text: I’m back — and, as you can see from the time of posting, jet-lagged up the wazoo. Also, now I have to deal with matters parental, which means very limited blogging for a while.

headline: Supreme Court Bolsters Gay Marriage With Two Major Rulings
text: WASHINGTON — In a pair of major victories for the gay rights movement, the Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled that married same-sex couples were entitled to federal benefits and, by declining to decide a case from California, effectively allowed same-sex marriages there.

headline: Bridging the Income Barrier at Top Colleges
text: The Hamilton Project, a Washington group affiliated with the Brookings Institution, has released a report calling for the expansion of a recent experiment aimed at persuading highly qualified low-income students to apply to top colleges.

headline: The Early Word: Dismantled
text: Today’s Times

headline: The Cars at Coney Island’s Mermaid Parade Didn’t Look Like Mermaids
text: CONEY ISLAND – During the winter, downtown Coney Island can be a bleak place. As you step out of the train station and onto Surf Avenue, the streets are cold — devoid of color, people, life. The plastic shopping sack tumbleweeds that occasionally roll by only accent its blue-tinged emptiness.

headline: New York Today: Stonewall Celebration
text: Updated, 11:52 a.m. | There were shouts and tears of joy at the Stonewall Inn in the West Village, a birthplace of the gay rights movement, after the Supreme Court struck down the federal Defense of Marriage Act.

headline: Hong Kong’s I.P.O. Market Cools
text: HONG KONG–After a spring thaw that included several big offerings, Hong Kong’s market for new stock listings may be back on ice.

headline: Jail Workers Said to Face Charges in Rikers Inmate Beating
text: A former high-ranking official of the New York City Department of Correction and nine current correction officers and supervisors will be charged on Wednesday in connection with the severe beating of an inmate on Rikers Island, the authorities said on Tuesday.

headline: Paula Deen’s Crumbling Empire
text: On the “Today” show, Paula Deen responded to criticism over her use of racist language. Later, Wal-Mart announced it was dropping her products.

headline: Gardening Advice for Aging Bodies, Part 2
text: Patty Cassidy, the author of “The Illustrated Practical Guide to Gardening for Seniors: How to Maintain Your Outside Space With Ease Into Retirement and Beyond” (2011, Anness), has been answering readers’ questions about aging and gardening. Her first set of answers is here.

headline: The Suicide Detective
text: For reasons that have eluded people forever, many of us seem bent on our own destruction. Recently more human beings have been dying by suicide annually than by murder and warfare combined. Despite the progress made by science, medicine and mental-health care in the 20th century — the sequencing of our genome, the advent of antidepressants, the reconsidering of asylums and lobotomies — nothing has been able to drive down the suicide rate in the general population. In the United States, it has held relatively steady since 1942. Worldwide, roughly one million people kill themselves every year. Last year, more active-duty U.S. soldiers killed themselves than died in combat; their suicide rate has been rising since 2004. Last month, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced that the suicide rate among middle-aged Americans has climbed nearly 30 percent since 1999. In response to that widely reported increase, Thomas Frieden, the director of the C.D.C., appeared on PBS NewsHour and advised viewers to cultivate a social life, get treatment for mental-health problems, exercise and consume alcohol in moderation. In essence, he was saying, keep out of those demographic groups with high suicide rates, which include people with a mental illness like a mood disorder, social isolates and substance abusers, as well as elderly white males, young American Indians, residents of the Southwest, adults who suffered abuse as children and people who have guns handy.

headline: My Restaurant Adventure: Why I Started Talking to Brokers
text: Editor’s Note: For more than two years, Bruce Buschel chronicled his experiences creating a restaurant on this blog. In a series of posts this week, Mr. Buschel explains why Southfork Kitchen will not be opening in Bridgehampton, N.Y., this season.

headline: Daily Report: Barnes & Noble Changes Course on Nook
text: Barnes & Noble conceded on Tuesday that it could not compete head to head with the iPad and the Kindle Fire, Michael J. de la Merced reports in The New York Times.

headline: War Deaths in Syria Said to Top 100,000
text: LONDON — An opposition monitoring group that has tracked Syria’s widening civil war said Wednesday that more than 100,000 people had died in the 27-month-old conflict, with pro-government forces taking far more casualties than rebels seeking the overthrow of President Bashar al-Assad, while civilians accounted for more than one-third of the overall fatalities, the biggest single category.

headline: Live Analysis of the Supreme Court Decisions on Gay Marriage
text: The Supreme Court is expected to rule on two cases involving same-sex marriage on Wednesday, shortly after 10 a.m., concluding one of the more consequential weeks in recent years at the court.

headline: UBS’s French Unit Fined $13 Million in Tax-Evasion Inquiry
text: 3:00 p.m. | Updated PARIS — French authorities said Wednesday that they fined the local unit of UBS, the largest Swiss bank, 100 million euros, or $130 million — the most possible under French law — over lax internal controls that enabled the bank’s sales representatives to help French clients evade taxes.

headline: Wall Street’s Tortoise and the Hare
text: WALL STREET’S TORTOISE AND THE HARE  |  The most successful firms on Wall Street are often those that are fastest and most opaque. But the Royal Bank of Canada has risen up the ranks in stock trading in the United States by “embracing a rather Canadian restraint and prudence,” Nathaniel Popper writes in DealBook.

headline: As Rulings Are Announced, Cheers and Tears Among Waiting Crowd
text: WASHINGTON — For more than two weeks, gay rights advocates stood at the steps of the United States Supreme Court waiting to hear decisions from the justices about two cases affecting millions of gay men and lesbians across the nation. With each day that passed without a ruling, they left disappointed.

headline: Sprechen Sie Denglish?
text: LONDON — Germany is undergoing one of its periodic bouts of angst over the seemingly unstoppable spread of Denglish, an Anglicized hybrid that purists believe is corrupting the national language.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Dispelling a Myth About Running Injuries
text: Dispelling a popular myth about running injuries, car sharing grows with fewer strings attached, where to recycle your old electronics and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Welcome to New York, Soldier
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Breaking It Down: Unorthodox Stroke Can’t Prevent Djokovic’s Win
text: Florian Mayer’s whole game is an enigma, but his unorthodox forehand will stop you in your tracks. The mysterious stroke is part windmill, part sling, and his huge backswing flails away like a medieval mace that no coach in his right mind would ever teach a young student.

headline: Tip of the Week: Make a Desktop Wallpaper Slideshow
text: Tired of your static desktop background? You can create wallpaper slideshow that cycles through your summer vacation photos to liven up the workday between spreadsheets.

headline: ‘Catfish’ and the Truth About Our False Online Selves
