Based on a treatment originally called “Whither Mankind?” by its writer and prime mover, the novelist and social prophet H. G. Wells, the movie that eventually emerged, as produced by Alexander Korda and directed by William Cameron Menzies, bore the less-pretentious title “Things to Come,” though this was still a film with a massive agenda. Wells and his collaborators meant to offer a stern, though ultimately hopeful, vision of humanity’s halting progress across the century to come.

headline: Riders to Watch at the Tour de France
text: Chris Froome, Britain

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 10 P.M. (NBC) ANN CURRY REPORTS: A FACE IN THE CROWD When he was 22, Richard Lee Norris accidentally shot himself in the face and was dramatically disfigured. He lived the next 15 years as a recluse before choosing to risk facial-transplant surgery. In this special with Ann Curry, right, Mr. Norris, now 38, speaks about the procedure at the Shock Trauma Center at the University of Maryland Medical Center in Baltimore, where the Department of Defense has supported research to treat wounded soldiers returning from Afghanistan and Iraq. Some of that financing made it to Dr. Eduardo D. Rodriguez, who performed Mr. Norris’s transplant. In March 2012 a Marine was struck by a van and taken to the center, where it was determined that he would not survive his brain injuries. After learning that their son had features compatible with those of Mr. Norris, his parents made the decision to donate his face. “It’s the most extensive and most comprehensive face transplant in medical history,” Dr. Rodriguez says.

headline: N.B.A. Draft Replay
text: The 2013 N.B.A. draft started with a surprise pick by the Cavaliers and continued with suspense until the end.

headline: Rick Perry Sounds Off on Texas Lawmaker and Filibuster
text: Two days after State Senator Wendy Davis of Texas vaulted into the political spotlight for helping defeat a bill restricting abortion rights by staging an 11-hour-long filibuster, Gov. Rick Perry said it was unfortunate she had not learned that “every life matters,” given that she was the child of a single mother who went on to earn a Harvard law degree.

headline: News Quiz | June 28, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Au Revoir, Rendezvous
text: Today will be the final day for IHT Rendezvous. We have had a blast — there is really no other word for it — connecting with our global readership. We have engaged — and you have engaged us — in smart and often touching commentary about the world we share.

headline: Migrant Plan Poses Risks for Australia, Leader Says
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Prime Minister Kevin Rudd of Australia on Friday used his first news conference since regaining the country’s top leadership position to warn that policies proposed by the leader of the opposition risked dragging Australia into a military conflict with neighboring Indonesia.

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 28
text: NEWS President Obama, who has begun a weeklong trip to Africa, had been hoping to meet with the ailing Nelson Mandela, as he did in 2005, when he was a senator. Michael D. Shear reports from Dakar, Senegal.

headline: Relatives Still Searching for 3,000 Missing Pilgrims
text: UTTARAKHAND — #8212;A big projector screen in the police control room in Dehradun, the capital of Uttarakhand, was alive with pictures of the latest batch of rescued pilgrims. Hundreds of relatives of missing pilgrims were making inquiries, checking photographs of the latest arrivals of rescued pilgrims and crosschecking call details and last locations of mobile phones of the missing.

headline: U.S. Prism, Meet China’s Golden Shield
text: BEIJING — On Tuesday, shortly before China escalated its criticism of the United States over its global surveillance programs, saying they showed not just the “hypocrisy” but also the “true face” of the U.S., a Beijing lawyer named Xie Yanyi filed a public information request with the police asking about China’s own surveillance operations.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, June 28, 2013
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Chinese Official Sentenced to 13 Years in Sex Scandal That Was Exposed on Internet
text: HONG KONG — Lei Zhengfu, a Chinese official who became a symbol of corruption, was convicted of taking bribes and sentenced to 13 years in prison on Friday in a scandal that exposed the sordid deal-making in Communist Party politics.

headline: Ex-Party Treasurer Is Held in a Spanish Tax Inquiry
text: MADRID — The former treasurer of Spain’s governing Popular Party, Luis Bárcenas, who has been at the heart of a widening corruption investigation, was being held on Friday after a judge decided that he presented a flight risk.

headline: A Fairy Tale in Transylvania
text: When Rena Effendi went to Transylvania to photograph hay for National Geographic, she envisioned a fairy tale, someplace almost medieval. But when she arrived in the Gyimes valley, she was disappointed. The scenery had been spoiled, she thought, by modern architecture.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Paula Deen’s Crumbling Empire
text: The video “Paula Deen’s Crumbling Empire” summarizes a week of criticism of the celebrity chef after her deposition in a workplace-discrimination lawsuit came to widespread attention.

headline: Florida Family and 4 Others Missing at Sea Off New Zealand
text: HONG KONG — Rescue teams were searching the waters between Australia and New Zealand on Friday for a schooner carrying seven people after their boat went missing in stormy seas.

headline: Cleric Arrested in $26 Million Plot, Leaving New Blot on Vatican Bank
text: ROME — A Vatican official. A private plane. And 20 million euros in cash.

headline: The Specialized Turbo: An Electric Bicycle With Scooterlike Speed
text: Unless you live around the corner from your job, riding a bicycle to work is serious business. The die-hards seem not to care, either sloughing through the traffic on busy thoroughfares or duking it out with an equally intense rival: distance, which pits riders against fatigue and travel time.

headline: The Early Word: Approved
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: New York Today: The Big Escape
text: Updated, 12:36 p.m. | With school out, the exodus from the city begins.

headline: My Restaurant Adventure: Gone Fishin’
text: Editor’s Note: For more than two years, Bruce Buschel chronicled his experiences creating a restaurant on this blog. In a series of posts this week, Mr. Buschel explains why Southfork Kitchen will not be opening in Bridgehampton, N.Y., this season.

headline: Obama, en Route to South Africa,  Says He Bears Message of ‘Profound Gratitude’ to Mandela
text: JOHANNESBURG — President Obama arrived in South Africa on Friday evening, saying he was bearing a message of “profound gratitude” to Nelson Mandela, the stricken former leader, and that he would defer to Mr. Mandela’s family on whether to visit him.

headline: Daily Report: Dispute Over Tech Companies’ Motives in Immigration Debate
text: Technology companies say there are not enough skilled workers in the United States, while the labor lobby contends that there are eligible workers, but the industry prefers cheaper labor from abroad, Somini Sengupta reports in The New York Times.

headline: Summer Reading Contest | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
text: In The Times this week: The Supreme Court ruled in several major cases, including two that bolstered gay marriage.

headline: U.S. Takes Aim at Corzine
text: U.S. TAKES AIM AT CORZINE  |  Jon S. Corzine, a veteran of Wall Street and New Jersey politics, faces the biggest fight of his career: a showdown with the United States government, DealBook’s Ben Protess writes. Federal regulators sued Mr. Corzine on Thursday in connection with the collapse of MF Global and the apparent misuse of customer money during the brokerage firm’s final days. Mr. Corzine ran the firm until its bankruptcy in October 2011.

headline: Junya Watanabe
text: Looks from the spring 2014 collection in Paris.

headline: Junya Watanabe: Spring 2014 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Defying Family to Forge a Family of Their Own
text: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Friday Reading: Weighing Buzz Cuts Vs. Head Lice
text: Weighing buzz cuts vs. head lice, fewer women get early C-sections, how to scan a signature for digital documents, and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Brazil vs. Spain: Best in World Meets Best in History
text: LONDON — And then there were two. The final game in the Confederations Cup on Sunday comes down to Spain, the best team in the world, against Brazil, the best in history, in the Maracanã, unquestionably one of the most evocative soccer stadiums on earth.

headline: Wells, Hitler, and the World State
text: John Holbo has a fun post about the old H.G. Wells-based movie Things to Come, which embodied a vision of the future that used to be quite popular among intellectuals — that of a temporary dictatorship, not of the proletariat, but of the scientifically literate meritocracy, which would give way to liberal democracy — plus some truly terrible fashion choices — once the masses had been sufficiently educated.

headline: BlackBerry Posts Loss, Despite New Phone
text: 8:59 p.m. | Updated Additional reporting and analysis were added to this post.

headline: A Library of Discards
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Whitewater Down
text: When Barack Obama was elected, I was sure that it would be the Clinton years all over — that he would be subjected to an endless series of claims of “scandal”, creating the sense of a tainted administration even though all the alleged scandals would turn out to be either trivial or nonexistent. Remember, after all those years of front-page headlines and $70 million in public funds, the Whitewater investigation came up dry.

headline: British Government Takes Step in Selling Stakes of Bailed-Out Banks
text: LONDON – The British government’s long-awaited sale of its stakes in the Royal Bank of Scotland and the Lloyds Banking Group is inching closer.

headline: The All-Important Present Moment
text: 1. Andrei Tarkovsky’s 1979 film “Stalker” may be the slowest movie ever made. At 163 perversely action-sapped minutes, it makes shifting tectonic plates look positively sprightly by comparison.

headline: The Artist Who Talks With the Fishes
text: Four years ago, the Australian-born artist Natalie Jeremijenko stood at the edge of Pier 35 in Downtown Manhattan, trying to start a conversation with some striped bass. Just north of the Manhattan Bridge, she and several collaborators dropped 16 tall buoys into the East River. The buoys were fitted with submersible sensors that monitored water quality and with LEDs that flashed when fish swam by, charting the Piscean passage. “I fell into the river four times installing it,” Jeremijenko recalls. “You have no idea, just standing on land, how ferocious those currents are!”

headline: Q&A: Reorganizing the Video Library in iTunes 11
text: Q.

headline: The 6.16.13 Issue
Two Paths for Charitable Giving: From the Head or From the Heart
text: OUR dog Lucy died this week, and it got me thinking about the role she played in making both my wife and me more charitable.

headline: How Diane von Furstenberg Is Like a Cowboy
text: Next year, your wrap dress will turn 40. If my great-granddaughter enrolls in the Fashion Institute of Technology, what do you think they’ll say about the dress?  It will definitely be in the book. At 25, I had no idea I would be creating something that would be so meaningful. When I first started, my motivation was to be independent, so I created this dress, and in no time at all I lived an American dream. Fourteen years ago, I started again, because I realized that young girls were buying the old dresses in thrift shops. My motivation then was to prove to myself and the world that it hadn’t been an accident the first time.

headline: From Marginal March To Mass Movement
text: ISTANBUL — I am prepared to give the Turkish government the benefit of the doubt: I don’t want to think it believes its own propaganda. But even pretend-outrage can get out of control.

headline: Is It Wrong to Skip the Commercials?
text: Is it ethical to DVR a TV show and then fast-forward through all the commercials while watching it? G.G., LOS ANGELES

headline: Dangers of Distracted Walking
text: Driving a car while talking or texting on a cellphone is a widely recognized risk factor for accidents. Now a new study reports that a growing number of people who walk while talking or texting are ending up in the emergency room.

headline: Love, Lost and Found, on the Staten Island Ferry
text: A summer night spent aboard the Staten Island Ferry.

headline: A Ship of Love Passing in the Night. By Day, It’s the Ferry Again.
text: The riders eye the outdoor perches first, pressing, grinding, deploying well-placed elbows, angling closer, closer to the edge that overlooks the water.

headline: After Rulings, Same-Sex Couples Grapple With Diverging State Laws
text: WASHINGTON — In the dining room of their town house here, David Huebner and John Barabino were the picture of prosperous domesticity this week. A housekeeper padded about, work on their outdoor patio continued and their 3-year-old son, Miles, napped upstairs.

headline: The Nets Go Big, Bold and Old
text: Once the news that the Boston Celtics and the Brooklyn Nets were orchestrating a gigantic trade broke Thursday afternoon, the N.B.A. draft might have gotten a little inferiority complex. Sure, it was still a prime-time show and it could still boast the annual ritual of booing Commissioner David Stern, and hey, it had Hakeem Olajuwon dropping by in a tux to remind Stern how long ago his first draft pick was. But all of that became background noise behind the Trade That Would Change Everything — or will change everything for five minutes until Brooklyn realizes that Paul Pierce and Kevin Garnett are a combined 147 years old.

headline: 4 Die in Egypt as Unrest Spreads Across Country
text: CAIRO — At least four people are dead across Egypt, including a 14-year-old boy, after antigovernment protesters ransacked Muslim Brotherhood offices on Friday and tens of thousands of supporters and opponents of President Mohamed Morsi held dueling rallies in the capital, Cairo.

headline: The Scene at Ground Zero of Uttarakhand Floods
text: RUDRAPRAYAG, Uttarakhand —The flash floods in Uttarakhand have caused damage in all the hilly districts of the state, but no district has experienced as much devastation as Rudraprayag, home to the Kedarnath shrine, which draws thousands of pilgrims every summer.

headline: Everything but the Win for Reynolds at Wimbledon
text: Bobby Reynolds did not win at Wimbledon on Thursday, or did he?

headline: Fleet Street Is Dead. Long Live Fleet Street!
text: LONDON — A mundane errand this week took me back to Fleet Street, the birthplace and erstwhile beating heart of Britain’s newspaper industry.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
text: When a Possible Guest Is in Prison

headline: A New Home for Clemente: On a Pedestal in the Bronx
text: Like a bronze god descending from the heavens, Roberto Clemente was gently placed atop a black granite base on Monday morning. A handful of hard-hatted souls watched in wonderment as construction workers secured him. Clemente – the Pittsburgh Pirates outfielder, humanitarian and, some would say, martyr – finally graced the state park in the Bronx that bears his name.

headline: Kerry’s Mideast Diplomacy Intensifies as He Shuttles Between the Two Sides
text: JERUSALEM — Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Israel on Friday for his second round of discussions with Israeli leaders in less than 24 hours as the pace of discussions about reviving the Israel-Palestinian peace talks heated up.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Food & Wine: Carnivores don’t have a monopoly on summer. Vegans can grill, too. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: At Men’s Fashion Week, Back to Babbitt
text: If there was any doubt that American tastes and traditions have been on designers’ minds, it was finally put to rest with the red, white and blue checked sports jackets and Western bandannas that Kim Jones showed on the Louis Vuitton runway. Oh … and there was a wood-frame outline of a Shaker building in the background.

headline: Viral Justice
text: KABUL — Every week now it seems, I see on my Facebook news feed that some poor Afghan cop has been beat up. It’s a sign of progress.

headline: Build a Summer Blockbuster
text: Do you have what it takes to produce Hollywood’s next summer blockbuster?

headline: June 28: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Uncertainty at the Fed as Markets Oscillate
text: It can’t have been the send-off that the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, was hoping for.

headline: Disappearing in Place
text: The Chinese artist Liu Bolin is a master of camouflage, blending his way into large murals like the ones at 5Pointz in Long Island City, Queens, where he recently did a performance.

headline: Snowden’s Father Hints Son Could Return to Stand Trial if Conditions Are Met
text: Edward J. Snowden’s father told NBC News that his son, the former National Security Agency contractor who is holed up in a Moscow airport without valid travel documents, might agree to return to the United States to stand trial on espionage charges if certain conditions are met.

headline: Wheelies: The End of an Era Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Rosie Perez Came to Our Softball Game. In Spirit.
text: Last summer, after The New York Times Magazine lost a crushing softball game on a walk-off home run to New York magazine, its archrival-once-removed, I reflected on my favorite quotation from the Rosie Perez oeuvre: “Sometimes when you win,” she told Woody Harrelson’s character in “White Men Can’t Jump,” “you really lose. And sometimes when you lose, you really win.” She provided no real proof, but whatever, it still helped me feel better — or at least to replace my feelings of loss with feelings of confusion.

headline: Recall of the Wild
text: We are wreaking havoc on the planet. Scientists predict that half of all living species will be obliterated by the end of the century, and in this age of man-made destruction it seems obvious we should try to salvage some of what’s left. But as Jon Mooallem discovers in his ambitious and fascinating first book, “Wild Ones,” American conservation today presents a far greater conundrum than deciding what to save or even how to save it. Such efforts force us to reconsider our relationship with other species and to confront what may be our obsolete fantasy of “wilderness.” Most of all, they force us to rethink the human animal.

headline: Tinker, Tailor, Reporter, Thriller
text: Scratch a journalist, especially a foreign correspondent, and more often than not you will find a frustrated thriller writer. We cover riots, revolutions and coups; we get arrested, shot at, tear-gassed, all the while gathering experiences and material that are the very stuff of human drama. It seems a natural progression to use our notebooks to create fiction as well as factual writing.

headline: Made in L.A. | Two Resources for Interior Design on North Highland Avenue
text: “L.A. is mysterious,” says David Netto, an interior designer and writer. “You have to learn about places from word of mouth.” In a new video series, Netto explores the city of angels and finds inspiration in his surroundings. Here, he visits Blackman Cruz and JF Chen, two cavernous decorating stores on North Highland Avenue.

headline: Method to the Madness
text: In his tales of Gothic horror, Edgar Allan Poe gave the world a fine collection of neurotics, paranoids and psychopaths. But none are quite as deranged as the narrator of “The Cask of Amontillado.” His name is Montresor, and his story opens with a threat: “The thousand injuries of Fortunato I had borne as I best could, but when he ventured upon insult I vowed revenge.” What a wealth of pathology is revealed in these words; it becomes immediately clear that the “thousand injuries” Montresor mentions are less harmful to him than the “insult” he claims to have suffered.

headline: Paperback Row
text: PRIVATE EMPIRE: ExxonMobil and American Power,  by Steve Coll. (Penguin, $18.) Bookended by two man-made disasters — the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska in 1989, and the BP Deepwater Horizon blowout in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010 — Coll’s mammoth portrait of Exxon Mobil reveals the corporation’s inner workings and vast influence, and abounds in empire-size figures. (If revenue were counted as gross domestic product, Exxon Mobil would rank among the top 30 countries.)

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: TRANSATLANTIC,  by Colum McCann. (Random House, $27.) This worthy companion piece to “Let the Great World Spin” takes on the lives of men and women who have chosen to leap across the ocean from Ireland to the New World or back again.

headline: In Africa, Competing With Beijing
text: As President Obama visits Senegal, South Africa and Tanzania this week, critics are faulting him for not going to Africa sooner and for lagging behind China’s leaders in capitalizing on the continent’s potential. While there is truth to the complaints — there are good reasons to intensify top-level American engagement in Africa — there is also more to the story.

headline: The Agony of Ecstasy
text: If you’re bookish and you don’t know the name Tao Lin, you’re probably over 30. Among 20-something readers, he’s an established phenomenon, a kind of literary typhoon and tycoon. Not that Lin has made much money from his books (or so, at least, he reports). He seems to be writing for the best reason, the only reason — because he’s a writer. He may well be one of those crazy, splendid people who, as Charles Bukowski put it, if marooned on a desert island would use a stick to scratch stories in the sand.

headline: El Comandante’s Farewell Tour
text: Fictio cedit veritati. Fiction yields to the truth.

headline: Transplant
text: Chicago, the mid-1980s: Anchee Min, newly arrived from Shanghai to study at the School of the Art Institute, was invited to a meeting of the college’s Communist Club. “Tell us about Red China!” urged the ardent American students. “Tell us your firsthand experience!”

headline: Double Vision
text: From Shakespeare’s “Comedy of Errors” to “The Parent Trap” and beyond, twins have provided rich fodder for our stories. Mistaken identity makes for great farce, and, paradoxically, identical twinship provides a way to examine what makes us different. Curtis Sittenfeld’s new novel, “Sisterland,” offers an intriguing look at what it might be like to have a double. Not the long lost double from whom you’ve been separated for most of your life, but the double who shares your room, your clothes and, in the case of these psychic sisters, some of your more disturbing thoughts.

headline: Too Large to Fail
text: Pandora Halfdanarson is a dedicated settler: she has settled for stepmotherhood; for marriage to an ascetic perfectionist; for an unlikely career as the owner of a small business, Baby Monotonous. She has settled in New Holland, Iowa, where she makes commissioned talking dolls, each primed with a list of remarks (“I don’t have that many credit cards”; “I owe it to myself to have a few nice things”) guaranteed to razz a customer’s loved one.

headline: Escape From New York
text: If you know the musical “1776,” you know the plot of Joseph J. Ellis’s breezy new book. It’s a stirring and conventional story. A handful of famous men struggle to create a republic against insurmountable odds. In the long run, their greatest challenge is the problem of slavery. But the most immediate threat is the military might of Britain. Toward the end of June 1776, as the Continental Congress nears a vote on American independence, the first of 427 royal ships carrying 1,200 cannons, 32,000 soldiers and 10,000 sailors appears off Long Island. Things look dire, a point made repeatedly in the musical by a soldier bearing gloomy reports from George Washington, the commander of the Continental Army.

headline: That a Nation Might Live
text: The battle of Gettysburg was a human and environmental catastrophe and, for the United States, almost the beginning of the end of its existence. Any historian contemplating this event faces numerous daunting problems — apart from the fact that thousands of books and articles have already been published on the Gettysburg campaign. The ghastly scale of bloodletting has to be explained. The battlefield contest itself involved the highest possible political and national stakes. And although this may be the most documented battle ever, the historian must use a vast supply of unreliable postwar recollections as sources. Such issues never stem the tide of writers drawn by the intellectual challenge (or by the charms of the subject’s market).

headline: Stand by Me
text: Ladies, if you want your kid to grow up to be a writer (and who doesn’t?), here are some simple steps you can take to give your progeny a leg up: 1) Be glamorous. 2) Go bonkers.

headline: Small Betrayals
text: In “My Flame,” one of the stories in Lily Tuck’s new collection, “The House at Belle Fontaine,” a woman finds out, long after her ex-husband’s death, that he repeatedly slept with his teenage niece. The girl is also dead, having driven drunk. So betrayal, in a not uncommon phenomenon, has a longer life than its perpetrators: the many intervening years cannot prevent the protagonist from feeling “shocked and duped.” Such a bald statement of feeling is rare for Tuck, a writer chary with reports of her characters’ inner lives. We’re not often privy to their reflections; their thoughts tend toward memories that are not especially emotional, or local observations or desires. “She hoped the bus would not be late as it was her day to car pool.” “It might be nice, for a change, to have another female in the house.” “Dr. Harris-Mehta’s white coat, Helen notices, is buttoned up the wrong way and, briefly, she is tempted to reach over and fix it.”

headline: Sightseeing
text: “A tiny, perfect, whittled trinket found bedded in the sand”; “a brightness quivering against the coming rain”; “a modern-day Venus” who inspires “a fin-de-siècle fever”: these are a few descriptions of the young wife in “Orkney,” Amy Sackville’s masterfully self-contained second novel. If they sound dismayingly vague and romantic, that’s because the words belong not to the writer, but to the narrator, Richard, a professor who has recently married his most gifted student. She asks him to take her to the sea, and he gallantly makes arrangements for a honeymoon in the northern Scottish archipelago of Orkney, giving no thought to what she will do once he must return to his academic responsibilities. “We talked once of her working on her doctorate with me,” he muses, “but that would be impossible now.” When he thinks of their future, he imagines “a perpetual breakfast table.”

headline: What Made Him Tick
text: By the time I was 300 pages into Ray Monk’s formidable biography of J. Robert Oppenheimer, I couldn’t imagine why anyone in his right mind would have chosen this man as director of the secret laboratory that built the first atomic bomb. If the whole thing had failed, what a harebrained scheme it would have seemed.

headline: Extreme States of Mind
text: Frank Bidart got noticed during the 1970s and ’80s for poems that did not sound like poems at all: a disjointed monologue by a serial killer, another by Ludwig Binswanger’s anorexic and ultimately suicidal patient Ellen West and, later, disquisitions on the history of philosophy, in spiky free verse full of capital letters, italics, white space and unconventional punctuation. Bidart’s extreme typography helped him convey extreme states of mind; it also helped show how his lines ought to sound, read aloud. More recent and more traditionally lyrical books have taken on well-defined topics: “Desire” (1997) was largely about sex, “Watching the Spring Festival” (2008) about beauty.

headline: Inside the List
text: MOON SHADOWS: Toward the end of “The Right Stuff,” Tom Wolfe’s exhilarating look at America’s early space program, there’s a riff about the pressure facing astronauts’ families: “The Astronaut’s Wife had been converted from an individual to a performer, at least for the duration of the flight — ready or willing or good at it or not. It had become an immutable part of the drill: at the completion of the flight the astronaut’s wife had to leave the house and confront the Beast and all his cameras and microphones and submit to a press conference and answer questions and be the perfect Astronaut’s Wife with merely the entire world watching. It was this grim prospect that truly lacerated one’s heart while Mr. Wonderful was aloft. It was this that gave the test pilot’s wife a royal case of nerves in the space age.”

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Dexter’
text: Showtime’s venerable drama about a serial killer in search of his soul may be called “Dexter,” but it has always been the Dexter & Deb show. The performances of Michael C. Hall as the diffident psychopath Dexter Morgan and Jennifer Carpenter as his ferocious, intensely vulnerable, hilariously profane adopted sister, Deb, are the yin and yang of the series. Dexter’s protectiveness of Deb helps to redeem him; she is, in Ms. Carpenter’s hands, so vivid and appealing that we like him for loving her.

headline: Off the Charts: A Policy That Worked
text: Since Nov 3, 2010, when the Federal Reserve announced what became known as QE2, or the second round of quantitative easing, stock prices have risen. Inflation expectations and interest rates are not far from where they were then, despite recent increases. Gold prices soared, but have now fallen back, and the dollar, after losing value in 2011, has recovered.

headline: Obama Completes First Leg of Africa Tour
text: President Obama ended his visit to Senegal and headed to South Africa. His last stop was Tanzania.

headline: Here Comes the Sunscreen
text: Parents applying protective lotion to their (often reluctant) children.

headline: What It Takes to Make New College Graduates Employable
text: MY older son graduated from high school last week and has started a pleasant job as a summer lifeguard. In four years we expect to attend his college graduation, and we hope the time there leaves him with great experiences, a love of learning and some idea how to get and keep a job.

headline: Queens: The New Frontier for a Brooklyn Blogger
text: Jonathan Butler founded the Brooklyn blog Brownstoner in 2004, but he didn’t quit his day job until 2007, when the blog’s popularity had clearly taken off. He has since expanded his other Brooklyn-based enterprises, founding the successful Brooklyn Flea and Smorgasburg outdoor market business with a partner, Eric Demby. In May, Mr. Butler started Queens Brownstoner after acquiring the site QueensNYC.com and rolling it into his brand.

headline: A Celebrity Chef Appeals to a Legacy of Black Forgiveness
text: Well before controversy exploded around Paula Deen, she had decided to title her forthcoming cookbook “New Testament.” The name was intended to wittily refer to the television chef’s adoption of a healthier approach to Southern cooking in light of her own diabetes. Now, however, the biblical reference serves as much more than a pun.

headline: Predictions on Fed Strategy That Did Not Come to Pass
text: ON the day after Democrats lost control of the House of Representatives in the 2010 midterm election, the Federal Reserve announced it would purchase $600 billion in Treasury securities — a program that quickly became known as Q.E.2, for quantitative easing.

headline: Investors Wary of Alliance Talk for Peugeot
text: PARIS — Would it make sense for one troubled carmaker with huge losses and acres of idle factory space to acquire another troubled carmaker with the same problem?

headline: Equal Status, Kemo Sabe
text: In 1996 a “Don Juan DeMarco”-era Johnny Depp went off into the Mojave Desert to make his first, and so far only, feature-length foray into directing. After the weird and wonderful trifecta of “What’s Eating Gilbert Grape,” “Benny & Joon“ and “Ed Wood,” Mr. Depp was cresting the early summit of his career as a movie star. Though notoriously unsuccessful at the box office, Mr. Depp could have probably collected his usual multimillion-dollar payday for any of the top projects in Hollywood then — much as he did with the coming “Lone Ranger.” What he chose instead was “The Brave,” also a movie about an American Indian, but one who agrees to be the subject of a snuff film.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘The Heat,’ ‘White House Down’ and ‘I’m So Excited!’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “White House Down,” “The Heat” and “I’m So Excited!” See all of this week’s reviews here.

headline: A Bowl of Cherries
text: Cherries aren’t often the featured ingredient in a dish; they are more likely to be nibbled on as a delicious snack between meals. But now that it’s the peak of cherry season, it’s time to showcase these edible, healthy treats on your dinner table.

headline: Ford and Mitsubishi Issue Recalls
text: Ford will recall about 12,500 of its 2013 Explorer, Taurus and Lincoln MKS models to fix a problem with a child safety lock, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. In another action, Mitsubishi said it would recall about 3,200 Outlander Sports from the 2011 model year in the United States because the glass sunroof may come off.

headline: Mom and Dad, Let’s Talk Real Estate
text: In this city of 350,000-plus co-op apartments and an aging population, it’s a quintessential New York story. A couple has owned an apartment for decades. Long after the children departed the nest, the parents have stayed, rattling around in quarters too large for their needs. Yet even if the apartment has grown shabbier, its value has soared.

headline: Billy Crystal Reads  for an Audience, Prompting Laughter and a Surprise
text: When Billy Crystal read selections from his forthcoming book on Thursday night, the audience was expecting an evening of laughs. They got them — but they also got something they were not expecting.

headline: A Cocktail to Cap a Hot Summer Week
text: I don’t drink cocktails frequently. But it’s been a long, hot week, and I can’t think of anything more refreshing and relaxing right now than this bracing drink I tried recently at ABC Cocina, the new pan-Latin-tinged small-plates restaurant from the Jean-Georges Vongerichten team.

headline: Image of the Day: June 28
text: A grey egret in Guwahati, Assam.

headline: Llodra Is Quizzed After Retiring From Singles but Not Doubles
text: WIMBLEDON, England – If it was any other Grand Slam event, maybe Michael Llodra would have gotten off lightly. But given the elevated number of journalists from British publications at Wimbledon, he did not escape.

headline: A Man’s Death, a Career’s Birth
text: OAKLAND — It had been nearly a year since Ryan Coogler last stood on the arrival platform on the upper-level of the Fruitvale Bay Area Rapid Transit Station, where 22-year-old Oscar Grant III, unarmed and physically restrained, was shot in the back by a BART transit officer in the early hours of New Year’s Day 2009.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Fall of Raj Rajaratnam and Galleon Group
text: This week, Anita Raghavan discusses her new book, “The Billionaire’s Apprentice”; Jon Mooallem talks about “Wild Ones” and endangered species; Adam LeBor on the difficulty of writing thrillers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Fall of Raj Rajaratnam and Galleon Group
text: This week, Anita Raghavan, Jon Mooallem and Adam LeBor.

headline: Tight Lips Over Who Started Fires in Sumatra
text: PONTAIN MEKAR, Indonesia — Sitting in a makeshift security post on a hilltop overlooking scorched earth as far as the eye can see, the last thing Hendro wants to talk about is fire.

headline: Who Everybody Is
text: In 1992, a group of authors formed a rock band and made a not-so-glorious noise at a book convention in California. The Rock Bottom Remainders included Dave Barry, Stephen King, Amy Tan and several other best-selling authors. For years the Remainders played occasional shows of 1960s covers.

headline: In Paris, a Plan to Be Friendlier
text: Paris is trying to be more tourist-friendly.

headline: Bank of America Hires Veteran Financial Services Banker From Moelis
text: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has hired John Binnie, a veteran financial services banker, as a vice chairman of its global financial institutions group, according to an internal memorandum sent within the investment bank on Friday.

headline: After Protesting Conditions, Dimitrov Is Defeated
text: WIMBLEDON, England — After the rain here abated Friday afternoon, play resumed on the outer courts at Wimbledon around 1:30 p.m., a delay of two hours. Of all the matches suspended Thursday, the one on Court 3 between 22nd-seeded Grigor Dimitrov and Grega Zemlja resumed in the most precarious spot.

headline: Made in L.A. | Design Inspirations
text: In a new series, the interior designer and writer David Netto explores Los Angeles and finds inspiration in his surroundings. In this episode, Netto visits Blackman Cruz and J. F. Chen.

headline: The Gun Report: June 28, 2013
text: As we head into what will doubtless be another hot and violent weekend, here are some recent news items to think about:

headline: The Truthiness Is Out There
text: OK, this is awesome. Dylan Byers at Politico gets Erick son of Erick to respond to my observation that, although he rants about the rising prices of milk and bread — which somehow has something to do with pundits riding the Acela — the truth is that milk and bread prices have been flat for about five years, and in particular have gone nowhere despite all that money the Fed has printed. And Erickson’s response is, hey, it isn’t true, but people feel that it’s true:

headline: A Drifting Skill, Illicitly Acquired, Saves the Day
text: A few years ago, I wrote an article for the Automobiles section about the advanced teenage driving courses offered around the country that go beyond the typical drivers ed courses. In general, I found them valuable. After all, the statistics on teenage driving fatalities are alarming, and as a parent of four, I was also alarmed after I once listened to a driver’s ed teacher drone on, simply reading from the manual while the students nodded off. What could they possibly be learning in that environment that would keep them safe?

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in California and Wisconsin
text: Napa Valley Festival del Sole, California During this festival from July 12 to 21 the area’s vineyards become a destination, and not just for oenophiles. On July 12, Audra McDonald, above, will perform Broadway show tunes at the Tuscan-style vineyard Castello di Amorosa in Calistoga. Many other performances and talks are on the schedule.

headline: What I Learned From My Daughter’s Wedding
text: Many years ago, in the predigital world, when my friends and I graduated from college, we scattered across the country to begin our first jobs.

headline: London Theater Journal: The Empire Crumbles
text: LONDON — The empire is so over. No, not the British one. That’s been dead for ages. I mean the American one, which I have now had the chance to watch disintegrating on both sides of the Thames. My first show in London was Lucy Kirkwood’s sold-out “Chimerica” (at the Almeida in Islington), which portrayed the waxing of the East (as in China) versus the waning of the West (as in you know where).

headline: Watching and Waiting in South Africa
text: The Times’s Marcus Mabry reports from Johannesburg, where South Africans are closely watching Nelson Mandela’s condition.

headline: In California, Celebrating Gay Marriage With Travel Deals
text: The recent Supreme Court rulings on same-sex marriage will affect a number of aspects of American life, and travel is one of them.

headline: Contraceptives Stay Covered in Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — Despite strong resistance from religious organizations, the Obama administration said Friday that it was moving ahead with a rule requiring most employers to provide free insurance coverage of contraceptives for women, a decision that has touched off a legal and political battle likely to rage for another year.

headline: Three Unsayable Words
text: Brad DeLong finds Allan Meltzer inveighing against quantitative easing, and notes that Meltzer’s story (in which it’s all Obama’s fault) is completely at odds with data on both investment and interest rates.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Dries Van Noten Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Carlotta Manaigo.

headline: Bylsma Picked for Olympic Job
text: The choice of Dan Bylsma as coach of the United States men’s hockey team at the Sochi Olympics in February — which will be announced on Saturday — comes as no great surprise, despite his lack of international experience. But it is also notable for what it says about John Tortorella, once thought to be the favorite for the job, and how he harmed his chance to coach the American team.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Fall of Galleon
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Frank Partnoy reviews “The Billionaire’s Apprentice,” Anita Raghavan’s detailed look at the spectacular fall of the Galleon Group hedge fund when its founder, Raj Rajaratnam, and Rajat Gupta, the former head of McKinsey & Company, were each convicted of securities fraud. Mr. Partnoy writes:

headline: At Sardi’s, Carrión Is at a Loss on the Theater
text: The campaign trail has taken New York City’s mayoral candidates all kinds of places — the A train, the Harvard Club and a geodesic dome on Rockaway Beach — in their quests for votes.

headline: Connecting Crime Scenes Present to Past
text: The Times's Serge F. Kovaleski on how investigators connect the dots between current and old criminal investigations, like the two cases pending against the N.F.L. player Aaron Hernandez.

headline: Varied Alliance to Press House on Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Even as they were popping corks on Thursday night after a strong bipartisan vote in the Senate to pass an immigration bill, supporters of the overhaul were laying plans for the far more difficult task of moving something similar through the Republican-controlled House.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: La Maison du Chocolat, which has four boutique locations in the city, will offer free tastings of its strawberry and classic chocolate ice cream flavors until 6 p.m. today.

headline: Facebook to Shield Ads From Offensive Content
text: Facebook said on Friday that it would remove ads from pages that contain controversial content, as it tries to protect advertisers from appearing next to offensive material beyond their control.

headline: Noodles & Co. Proves Irresistible in Tough Week for I.P.O.’s
text: 6:32 p.m. | Updated

headline: Could Brothers and Sisters Share a Cabin at Camp?
text: Our two kids will attend overnight camp this summer for two weeks. They’ll join their bunkmates and sleep, for the first time in their lives, in separate spaces.

headline: Fewer Hospitalizations for C.O.P.D. Patients
text: You don’t see supermarket products emblazoned with ribbons to help support research on chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Major corporations don’t sponsor walkathons for thousands of cheering supporters.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Parks and Trepidation
text: A. O. Scott and David Carr are joined by the architecture critic Michael Kimmelman to talk about public spaces and projects which, at times, can lead to political upheaval ... and even revolution.

headline: A Romance in the Style of Byron or Keats
text: He met her, he said, “as words on a page.”

headline: The Sweet Spot: Parks and Trepidation
text: In this week’s episode, A. O. Scott and David Carr are joined by the architecture critic Michael Kimmelman to talk about public spaces and projects which, at times, can lead to political upheaval … and even revolution.

headline: To Explain the Fed, Choose a Vice
text: The search for the best metaphor to describe the tapering of the Federal Reserve’s monthly bond purchases later this year rolled forward on Friday.

headline: Big Ticket | Park-Centric Luxury for $17.53 Million
text: Three is a charm for the collaboration of Zeckendorf Development and its go-to architect, Robert A.M. Stern, at 18 Gramercy Park South. As a sequel to the jaw-dropping sales they logged by building the billionaire magnet 15 Central Park West, this smaller-scale but equally park-centric luxury condominium represents their first crack at refurbishing a landmark in a fussy historic district, and their third closing of the month again netted the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. Several more of the 16 homes there are in contract.This time the floor-through residence was No. 11 (the previous sales were Nos. 9 and 5). The cost was precisely $17,539,356.25 — the original asking price of $17,225,000 plus transfer taxes. And the closing gift from the sponsor was the usual $350 key that opens the locked gates of Gramercy Park, Manhattan’s only truly private park.

headline: Christie’s Leader Returns Ancient Bronzes to China
text: At a ceremony in Beijing on Friday, the family of one of France’s wealthiest businessmen officially returned to China two bronze animal heads that were among the treasures looted in the 19th century from the imperial Summer Palace near Beijing by invading British and French troops.

headline: Nets’ Sales Pitch to Stars: This Isn’t East Rutherford
text: Once upon a time, about three decades ago, the New Jersey Nets installed a parquet floor at their arena in East Rutherford in a transparent attempt to mimic the storied tradition of the Boston Celtics. Unfortunately, the Nets had no workable business foundation to go along with the floor.

headline: T-Mobile to Pay $308 Million for More Spectrum
text: T-Mobile USA, the fourth-largest American carrier, has agreed to pay $308 million to pick up a swath of spectrum, the radio waves that carry phone calls and data. The spectrum would enable the carrier to expand its new fourth-generation wireless network in 29 cities for 32 million people, the company said Friday.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Junya Watanabe Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: Health-Centric Homes, for a Price
text: Coming soon to a neighborhood near you: an empathic multimillion-dollar home that passively treats the occupant’s body like a temple. The second coming of sustainable real estate, it will fuse green technology with nourishing all-about-me amenities and direct them indoors. Homebodies, take note: the residence is designed to make the people it shelters healthier.

headline: Patriots Put Principles on Display
text: The moment the police led Aaron Hernandez away in handcuffs, he became expendable to the New England Patriots, despite the millions of guaranteed dollars that remained on his contract and the long legal process yet to play out.

headline: Sharing a Potluck of Links, Not Food
text: More and more, we are looking to consume less and less — at least when it comes to online content.

headline: Ask a Location Scout
text: The final subject in Metropolitan’s Q. and A. series will be Kevin Breslin, a location scout for television commercials who has arranged thousands of shoots, including the New York Lottery “If I Had a Million Dollars” spots.

headline: Temp Workers, Permanent Problems
text: I found my first job out of college through a temp agency, which sent me to a brand-name bank where I stood in a windowless closet in a polyester-blend suit and heinous square-toed shoes filing carbons of personal portfolio data for individual-wealth-management clients. I was grateful to be hired, but during those humid, lifeless hours, I did think fondly of the days when I shoveled horse manure for $5 an hour.

headline: Sony Begins ‘Upfront’ Sales of Ads for PlayStation 3
text: Sony has already taken part in the upfront market for the sale of commercial time ahead of the 2013-14 season, for properties like the GSN cable channel and the Crackle digital video Web site. Now, the company is expanding the upfront selling process to the PlayStation 3 video game system.

headline: Robson Riding a Pop Culture Wave
text: WIMBLEDON, England — After an emphatic straight sets upset of No. 10 Maria Kirilenko in the first round, Laura Robson faced a different sort of pressure in her second round match, playing the role of the overwhelming favorite.

headline: Tank Topics
text: I was at a burger joint in Nashville with my wife and young daughter. A tough-looking guy in his late teens or early 20s came in wearing a tank top with a vulgar statement printed on it. [Trust the man, readers. This shirt was not family-friendly.] Amazingly, two older women joined him, one of whom seemed to be his mother. I am all for freedom of speech, but I found the shirt offensive. I was also embarrassed for my family, the other patrons and even his mother. We prevented our daughter from seeing it, but what else could I have done?

headline: 2 Hard-Charging Oligarchs Returning to Global Energy Market
text: LONDON — They were once the partners of the British oil giant BP, until that arrangement spun apart in turmoil and litigation.

headline: Comme des Garçons
text: Rei Kawakubo showed her spring 2014 collection in Paris.

headline: Where Win-A-Trip Winners Are Now
text: Erin Luhmann is a Minnesotan student of journalism who won Nick Kristof’s win-a-trip contest this year, and will be traveling with him to report on development in Africa next week. For her first blog post, Erin checked in on former win-a-trip winners, to get a sense of where they are now and how the trip affected their career paths.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene Video: ‘Laurence Anyways’
text: Xavier Dolan, the writer, director and editor of “Laurence Anyways,” discusses a scene from his film about the male-to-female transition of Laurence, played by Melvil Poupaud. In this scene, after Laurence comes out to his mother (Nathalie Baye) as transgender, the two have a conversation.

text: Paris

text: Paris

headline: A Comeback on Chile’s Coast
text: There were hundreds of brightly colored houses clinging to a labyrinth of hills in Valparaíso, Chile. The cobblestone streets were a maze. The Andes were in the distance, and the azure Pacific Ocean glittered from beyond.

headline: Givenchy: Spring 2014 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Getting Your Feet Wet at Water Parks
text: The first moments inside a water park complex almost always jar your senses. A rush of moist, chlorine-scented air fills your nose. Bright, cartoon colors, not to mention characters, surround you. And then there is the continuous loop of pop tunes vying with an endless whir of water — splashing, spraying, gurgling, rushing, dumping. On this last point, a caution to the uninitiated: if a bell or gong sounds, it is worth glancing up since it is likely to be a warning that some enormous vat of water overhead is preparing to dump its contents, and everyone but you knows it.

headline: Restaurant Report: Tamerò Pasta Bar in Florence
text: The dining scene in Florence is mostly dominated by well-established trattorias, either tucked away in neighborhoods far from the city center and frequented by locals or situated in the heart of town and overrun with tourists. The opening of Tamerò late last year breaks this pattern: it’s a hip spot in the residential Santo Spirito area that serves modern renditions of food from all over Italy and beyond.

headline: Their Kingdom and a Horse
text: Friends and fellow poets knew the couple belonged together. The two of them, however, took a while to discover that.

headline: The Return on College, Around the World
text: As my colleague Eduardo Porter wrote this week, there are major returns from going to college. This is true around the world, but it is especially true in the United States.

headline: The Conviction Integrity Review of People vs. Jesse Friedman
text: Read the Conviction Integrity Review of People vs. Jesse Friedman.

headline: Movie Review: 'White House Down'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "White House Down."

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 28
text: Subjects include a rally in the Village after a ruling on same-sex marriage, umbrellas at Jones Beach and a retirement celebration for a beloved principal.

headline: When an Assignment Abroad Is Over: What Will You Miss Most?
text: PARIS—A friend who has lived and worked on three continents offered some advice when I moved to Paris for a job three years ago.

headline: Dripping With Opportunity, Some of It Wasted
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Fans who came to the All England Club on Friday probably could be forgiven if they thought they were getting the leftovers.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Maison Martin Margiela Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Why No Byline or Named Source for an Article About a Leak Investigation?
text: A careful reader of The Times, David Smollar of San Diego, makes some astute observations about an unusual article in Friday’s paper. The article caught many people’s eyes because it lacked a byline. It also quoted Jill Abramson, the executive editor, and it used an unnamed source to confirm an NBC News report that a retired Marine officer, Gen. James E. Cartwright, is a target of a leak investigation about American cyberattacks on Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: A Courtship With Its Own Song
text: Wendi Bergamini, a Broadway actress, and the composer and lyricist Michael Weiner did not meet during a show. But he did turn her initial brushoff into a song for his new Broadway musical, “First Date.”

headline: An Indian Artist Extends Her Reach
text: The poetically named Shantala Shivalingappa was born in India, but raised in Paris, where she trained in Kuchipudi, a South Indian classical dance style, with her mother, the well-known dancer and choreographer Savitry Nair. Ms. Shivalingappa, who will perform at Jacob’s Pillow this week, is generally acknowledged as one of the greatest current practitioners of Kuchipudi’s flowing lines, percussive footwork and dramatic narratives.

headline: Professor’s Work, Then Beethoven
text: The faculty of Columbia University will be bolstered by an important addition when the Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas begins a professorship at the school this September. Mr. Haas, a composer associated with the French spectral school, in which timbre and resonance are particularly important, has dazzled with otherworldly pieces like “In Vain,” a psychedelically beautiful soundscape performed in pitch darkness. On Tuesday at the Austrian Cultural Forum, the conductor Michel Galante and the Argento Ensemble will perform the American premiere of the original version for soprano and eight instruments of Mr. Haas’s “Atthis” — a work inspired by the love poems of Sappho. (7:30 p.m. Tuesday, 11 East 52nd Street, 212-319-5300, acfny.org; free.)

headline: Regular Guys at Iwo Jima
text: With support-the-troops sentiment strong these days, occasionally a movie will use real soldiers or veterans in scenes. “Act of Valor” is a recent example. But the precedents for this go back a long ways and include “Sands of Iwo Jima,” the 1949 saga starring John Wayne as the classic irascible sergeant named Stryker. The film is too formulaic and jingoistic to be considered great, but maybe it’s just right for Fourth of July week. It plays on Thursday at 4 p.m. and Saturday at 2 p.m. at the Museum of Modern Art, part of the monthlong exhibition “Allan Dwan and the Rise and Decline of the Hollywood Studios.”

headline: From Brooklyn, an ‘Ode to Joy’
text: The mission is a mouthful — “to invest the experience of public space with wonder, to resurrect art history from the bowels of despair, and to impregnate the institutions of art with the joy of man’s desiring” — but since it’s from the Bruce High Quality Foundation, that brash, Brooklyn artist collective, it won’t elicit so much as a blink from art world insiders. There is, however, considerable curiosity surrounding “The Bruce High Quality Foundation: Ode to Joy, 2001-2013,” which runs through Sept. 22 at the Brooklyn Museum. Included in the show are photographs, videos, paintings, installations — the works (even a 10-foot-tall inflatable rat.)

headline: Neighbor Describes Witnessing Confrontation in Florida Murder Case
text: SANFORD, Fla. — A prosecution witness who saw portions of the altercation between George Zimmerman and Trayvon Martin on Feb, 26, 2012, took the stand on Friday, bolstering the defense’s contention that Mr. Zimmerman was on the ground being beaten by Mr. Martin when the fatal shot was fired.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Heat’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Heat,” starring Melissa McCarthy and Sandra Bullock.

headline: The Many Sides of a Violist
text: A common way to map the reach of the violist and composer Eyvind Kang is to enumerate his affiliations. For years he has been a regular collaborator with the performance artist Laurie Anderson; likewise with the jazz guitarist Bill Frisell. He has also done sturdy work with the doom merchant Stephen O’Malley, and provided fine filigree for singer-songwriters like Beth Orton and Laura Veirs. Genre, or any clear iteration of style, is probably the least illuminating handle on him.

headline: An Uphill Battle Daily in Court
text: In 1961 Clarence Earl Gideon was arrested on charges of stealing soda, beer and a small sum of cash from a pool hall in Panama City, Fla. Unable to pay for a lawyer, he represented himself at trial, and was later convicted and sentenced to five years in prison. Mr. Gideon appealed his conviction to the Supreme Court, which ruled unanimously that the right to counsel in a criminal case is fundamental to the American justice system. Fifty years after that landmark case, Gideon v. Wainwright, some 15,000 public defenders nationwide represent the majority of the 12 million people arrested annually who could not otherwise afford counsel.

headline: Something Off Key at a Gospel Choir
text: Few crucibles test the mettle of adolescents as thoroughly or harrowingly as all-male prep schools, where lads on the cusp of adulthood bend, warp, grow and sometimes shatter. The hothouse atmosphere of such institutions has proved a fertile environment for dramatists from Robert Anderson (“Tea and Sympathy”) to Alan Bennett (“The History Boys”). Now Tarell Alvin McCraney, the author of the brilliant “Brother/Sister” trilogy, brings his singular sensibility to the subject with “Choir Boy,” which opens on Tuesday at the Manhattan Theater Club.

headline: Rising Rates, and the Rent vs. Buy Decision
text: Mortgage rates have been rising, making it a bit more expensive to borrow to buy a home.

headline: The Many Rebellions of ‘Dobie Gillis’
text: If you enjoy a study in contrasts, first spend an evening watching any of today’s teenager-centered television offerings — on CW, ABC Family, even TeenNick or the Disney Channel. Then sample a few episodes of “The Many Loves of Dobie Gillis,” which ran from 1959 to 1963 and was one of the first shows to depict life from the teenage perspective.

headline: Wearing a Wire at the Opera, Secretly, of Course
text: The Metropolitan Opera House has been justly acclaimed for its excellent acoustics. And not just in the choice seats. Many opera buffs assert that the best seats in the house are the most affordable ones: up in the balcony and family circle.

headline: Another Giant Slayer Makes a Quick Exit
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Roger Federer is out of Wimbledon, and now, much less surprisingly, Sergiy Stakhovsky is, too.

headline: Daniil Simkin, Standing Out, Reaching Out
text: There was no shortage of technical prowess during an American Ballet Theater matinee of “Le Corsaire” at the Metropolitan Opera House in early June. In the central roles, the Russian stars Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev were earning thrilled bursts of applause for the height of their jumps and the speed of their multiple turns.

headline: Violence Erupts Anew in Volatile Chinese Region
text: HONG KONG — Violence erupted on Friday in China’s volatile far western Xinjiang region, the second time in two days that tensions between the largely Muslim Uighur minority and Chinese security forces have brought bloodshed to the area.

headline: People Will Say They’re in Love, and They Are
text: Charlotte d’Amboise, the actress now playing Fastrada in Broadway’s “Pippin,” thought that her romance with Terrence Mann would last about as long as an intermission.

text: Tyler Farr

headline: Movie Review: 'I'm So Excited'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "I'm So Excited."

headline: Week in Review: Corzine’s Legal Battle May Last Years
text: Suit accuses Jon Corzine of a failure at the helm. | Cost of public projects is rising, and pain will be felt for years. | Bank gains by putting the brakes on traders. | Exit from the bond market is turning into a stampede. | Andrew Ross Sorkin says that economists are asking: Did Ben Bernanke tip the Fed’s hand? | Mass layoffs at a top-flight law firm. | Deals in the works involving two luxury retailers.

headline: Melissa Clark Answers Your Pie Questions
text: Now’s your chance to perfect your techniques for making pie crust, topping and summer fruit filling. Melissa Clark of the Dining section will answer your questions in a live chat on all things pie, just in time to bake for the Fourth of July. So join Ms. Clark on Dining’s Facebook Page on Monday, at 4 p.m. Eastern time, and bring your questions. Happy baking!

headline: This Week's Best-Seller Lists
text: The Times's Pamela Paul and Gregory Cowles discuss the top-selling books of the week.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Celebrating Orwell’s ‘1984,’ and Uber in Taipei
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Christie’s Marriage Problem
text: Among the questions left unanswered by the Supreme Court’s ruling on the Defense of Marriage Act is whether a majority of the justices actually think all Americans have an equal right to marry. So while the federal government can no longer treat gay and straight married couples differently, the individual states can keep discriminating.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 28
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

headline: After Political Appointment in Bulgaria, Rage Boils Over
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria — Delyan Peevski’s mother used to head the national lottery and leads a growing media empire with strong political and economic connections in this small, impoverished and notoriously corrupt Balkan nation. So perhaps it was not surprising that the appointment of Mr. Peevski, 32, to head the powerful State Agency for National Security sparked protests that have been attended by thousands every day over the past two weeks and show no sign of losing steam.

headline: As the Tides Shift, a New Flagship Docks
text: Big flagship luxury sedans are relics. Artifacts left over from a time when social standing was reflected in the length of a car’s wheelbase and how upright its grille stood. A time when Mercedes wasn’t reaching down-market and Hyundai wasn’t aiming for the heights. Back when the sight of a new Cadillac put a company’s employees on high alert that the boss was on site, and not just that some drone in Section G had leased a CTS.

headline: Meet the New Boss ...
text: The Lexus LS 460 gets a new face for 2013 and an interior fit for a captain of industry.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 28
text: More photographs.

headline: “After ‘Before Midnight'”: A Short Screenplay
text: This week’s Riff examines how time exists onscreen — including in the recent film “Before Midnight.” That movie is the third in a trilogy, each produced nine years apart and each following two characters, Jesse and Celine, as their lives overlap and intertwine — often through long, digressive, yet oddly profound conversations. (Here’s more on the films and their co-star and co-writer Julie Delpy.)

headline: When Fuel Economy Improves, but Filling the Tank Costs More
text: The math seems so straightforward: as engines get smaller and fuel economy improves, the cost of driving will fall, right?

headline: Splitting Hairs on Required vs. Recommended
text: Given the price difference between regular-grade and premium gasoline, car buyers should always consider the vehicle’s fuel requirement, as listed in the owner’s manual, as part of the total cost of ownership.

headline: ‘Catfish’ Returns to Average Numbers
text: In January, “Catfish: The TV Show,” the documentary series on MTV that follows Nev Schulman and his videographer, Max Joseph, enjoyed a brief moment in the spotlight when when the Notre Dame football player Manti Te’o became the most high-profile example of someone who was “catfished” — that is, the victim of a hoax involving a faked online identity. But so far, any interest from that incident has not translated into higher ratings for the show.

headline: Nice to Meet You ... Again
text: Are the pixels making us pixilated? In my case, it goes like this: I’ll run into a Facebook friend whom I haven’t seen in more than a decade. Reminiscing about the party we met at in, say, 1998, I’ll recount how all of us revelers had gone up to the roof that night with sparklers.

headline: Empanadas, the Pies With a Passport
text: The empanada is the little meat pie that could, a native of Spain that traveled the world, touching down in Latin America, the Caribbean, Eastern Europe, Africa, South Asia and the British Isles.

headline: Yuvi Alpert’s Holiday in Havana
text: The men’s accessories designer Yuvi Alpert creates pieces that are informed by the ways the modern man moves through the world. There’s an appealing international flavor to his simple, elegant, unbling-y jewelry line Yuvi by Yuvi Alpert (the latest collection shows in Paris this weekend); and Men in Cities, his monthly limited-edition releases of affordable men’s accessories, like wallets, bracelets and neckties, is meant to simplify shopping for guys on the go.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A ‘Thor’ That Wows
text: At No. 9 on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week is Volume 1 of “Thor: God of Thunder,” which reprints the first five issues of the latest series devoted to Thor, one of Marvel’s top heroes. The series is written by Jason Aaron and illustrated by Esad Ribic. The first word to describe the result of this creative team is: Wow.

headline: Getting Japan to Spend
text: TOKYO — Daisuke Horii just collected his summer bonus. It was only slightly more than last year, but enough to compel the 34-year-old shopping mall clerk to Tokyo’s electronics district to look for some high-end speakers.

headline: Taking a Cue From Bernanke a Little Too Far
text: Financial advisers have been fielding calls from shaken investors in recent weeks, particularly retirees, who are nervous that a bond market crash is on the horizon.

headline: French Businessman Investigated on Suspicion of Fraud
text: PARIS — Bernard Tapie, a wealthy businessman and erstwhile politician, is being formally investigated on suspicion of fraud in a corruption scandal that centers on a $535 million state payout to him in 2008, the office of the Paris state prosecutor and Mr. Tapie’s lawyer announced on Friday.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A five-bedroom stone- and brick-faced ranch in Plainsboro, N.J., and a four-bedroom wood-frame house in Port Chester, N.Y.

headline: Riske Finally Breaks Through at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England — It took 18 points in the final game of her second-round match at Wimbledon for 22-year-old Alison Riske of Pittsburgh to do something she’d never done before in her career: win a match point at a Grand Slam.

headline: Angst at the A.S.P.C.A.
text: One of the first times Cindy Adams went to a board meeting of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, tempers flared.

headline: A Vacation Under the Sea
text: Travelers may be able to sleep among the ocean’s depths, surrounded by coral reefs, in two luxury underwater hotels planned for Dubai and the Maldives.

headline: Do You Wanna Know a Secret?
text: THE revelation that the National Security Agency has been secretly amassing huge amounts of data about Americans’ phone and Internet use has sparked a lively debate about the proper role of secret information in a free and open society.

headline: App Smart Extra: To-Do Lists, File Sharing and Other Home Worker Needs
text: This week’s App Smart column was all about apps for smartphones and tablets that can help home workers make the most of their time and the quiet environment. This is a handy trick because for some people, like your columnist, many out-of-office working tasks can actually be carried out on a tablet or phone — no PC required.

headline: High-Performance Machines With Zero Horsepower
text: Imagine your new Lamborghini racing down the road, the wind tousling your hair, the tires straining through a corner, the adrenaline pumping.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week, the Sun Also Sets
text: MILAN — Henry James, of course, said it best.

headline: How to Decide Where to Give
text: In a Wealth Matters column published today, Paul Sullivan takes a look at what inspires people to give to charities, and how that inspiration affects the philanthropies they support. Some donors direct their charitable contributions to organizations that can measure the impact of their work, while others, like Mr. Sullivan and his family, place more importance on a sense of personal connection to a cause.When deciding whether to give money to a charitable cause, do you place more emphasis on metrics or emotion? What causes have you felt driven to support, and why?

headline: On Nuclear Waste Bill, Senators Look to Public for Help
text: After the Obama administration abandoned plans in 2009 to bury nuclear waste at a repository in Nevada’s Yucca Mountain, a spot chosen by leading senators more than 20 years earlier, a study commission recommended that a new location be picked through “a consent-based process.”

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A one-bedroom on East 51st Street, a Park Ave. co-op with 10-foot beamed ceilings and a Brooklyn three family built in the 1930s.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Egypt, Syria, the Philippines and Senegal.

headline: Everyone’s a Dancer at the Philharmonic
text: In the original 1911 scenario of the ballet “Petrushka,” with music by Stravinsky and choreography by Fokine, the opening scene takes place in the bustling St. Petersburg square during the Shrovetide Fair. There are rowdy crowds, street hawkers, drunken revelers and puppet shows.

headline: Abbott’s All Set for Governor to Make Move
text: Greg Abbott has a shiny political résumé, an astonishing amount of money in the bank and has geared up for a statewide campaign with careful and deep planning on the ground and in the air.

headline: Take a Phrase, Wrap It in a Song, E-Mail It on Friday
text: Most Monday nights when he’s not on the road, the Austin singer-songwriter Bob Schneider tests at least one new song in front of an audience at the Saxon Pub.

headline: Characters Finding Their Voices by Singing in the Choir
text: At the all-black Charles R. Drew Prep School for Boys, the official school song is the Presbyterian hymn “Trust and Obey.” But the striving upperclassmen begin a day there by belting out the civil rights anthem “Keep Your Eyes on the Prize.”

headline: In 9/11 Museum to Open Next Spring, Vastness and Serenity, and Awe and Grief
text: “You thought it was as bad as it would get, and then it got worse.”

headline: Secret Court Declassifies Yahoo’s Role in Disclosure Fight
text: In the secret court that authorizes national security surveillance requests, everything is considered confidential — even the existence of communications between companies and the court. But this week, the court drew back the curtain slightly, declassifying the fact that Yahoo was the company that fought the court in a momentous case in 2008.

headline: Where Astros Played, Conventioneers in Suits Could Gather
text: HOUSTON — Ryan Bokros was 8 years old when he attended his first baseball game at the Houston Astrodome. It was 1985. The dome was bursting with people, the famous scoreboard bright with lights and the space bigger than anything he had ever seen.

headline: A Week of Beauty and Joy
text: If you define a balletomane as someone who cares primarily about dancers, then the balletomane’s peak season is American Ballet Theater’s annual eight-week run at the Metropolitan Opera House. The luminaries include international visitors like Roberto Bolle, Natalia Osipova, Ivan Vasiliev and Diana Vishneva. Next week brings the company debut of the remarkable Danish dancer Alban Lendorf in “The Sleeping Beauty.”

headline: Playing Up the Spicy Aspect of a Summer Fruit Pie
text: Summer isn’t just fruit-pie season in my kitchen. It’s crumb-pie season, too. Because while in theory one could put a crumbly brown-sugar topping on any kind of pie, tangy, high-acid summer fruit pies work best.

headline: Dipping Into Eastern Modes, Spicing Up the Tarantella
text: Traditional songs at rocket speed: that’s the music of Canzoniere Grecanico Salentino, who played a breakneck, euphoric set at Joe’s Pub on Thursday night. Songs that may date back millenniums flew by in a whirlwind of tambourine rhythms and the call-and-response of raw voices that also aligned in harmony. Silvia Perrone, a dancer in a bright red dress, twirled and skipped at center stage, barefoot.

headline: Games of Hide and Seek and Experiments for Horns
text: They can do majestic and they can do scary. They do heroic really well. And they’re experts at wake-up-and-face-Judgment-Day.

headline: Campaigning Hard for Presidential Plays
text: Lyndon Baines Johnson was a larger-than-life figure, no doubt, but is Broadway big enough for two plays about that president?

headline: Makeshift Thrones Fit for No King, and Angels Unfurling Their Wings
text: Rachel Cohen and Jody Sperling call their double bill, which opened at Danspace Project on Thursday, “Wood & Silk: A Shared Evening of Textural Choreography.” You can’t actually touch their work, but the common denominator is an interest in combining moving bodies with various kinds of material. The aesthetic is homemade, and the potentially wondrous alchemy of simple things and imagination comes with the risk of pitiful bareness if the magic doesn’t happen.

headline: Motion Picture Academy Seeks to Expand Membership
text: LOS ANGELES — Reversing a policy that has more closely restricted membership in the last decade, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Friday invited an unusually large group of film professionals — 276 in total, including the actors Milla Jovovich and Joseph Gordon-Levitt — to join its ranks.

headline: Friday Night Music: Elephant Revival, The Pasture
text: Dango Rose directs me to a video from their upcoming album. I like this in particular because you can see Bonnie Paine’s footwork — she’s playing a soundboard as well as the washboard:

headline: Plum Chutney Crumb Pie
text: Melissa Clark adds homemade fruit chutney to a plum pie. It’s as easy as making applesauce and brings a layer of complexity to a summer fruit dessert.

headline: From Across the Pacific, Good Old American Fare
text: A tense and elaborate crime drama ending in a Peckinpah-style shootout. A classic tear-jerker about a woman doing menial labor to support her ungrateful son. A loopy, candy-colored musical. A warmhearted biopic about a national hero.

headline: Art Fatigue in London
text: LONDON — The spring auctions here, which ended on Thursday night, were a sharp contrast to those that recently took place in New York. There was not a night in London over the last two weeks when sales reached nearly $500 million, as happened in May at the Christie’s evening sale of postwar and contemporary art in New York.

headline: Snapchat Without the Chat
text: It’s like Instagram without the corollary of regret and recrimination: Snapchat is touted as “the fastest way to share a moment with friends.”

headline: Variations on the Plum Crumb Pie
text: In my recent column and video, plums take center stage in a spicy crumb-topped pie. But summer pie should be all about ease. And if you can’t find plums, do not run around town looking. Substitute blueberries or peaches, or a mix of the two. A rhubarb-strawberry combination would work well too, though you might have to increase the sugar to make up for rhubarb’s astringency.

headline: Dylan Lauren: Giving an Active Life a Splash of Color
text: Dylan Lauren, 39, is the daughter of Ralph Lauren and founder of Dylan’s Candy Bar. She lives with her husband, Paul Arrouet, on the Upper East Side.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Urban Druids
text: Summer is the time of the solstice and Manhattanhenge, when the setting sun aligns with the grid of the city's cross streets, illuminating facades on both sides with a lacy tracery.

headline: Experts and Juniors on Bridge Base Online
text: Except in July and August, every Wednesday at 11 a.m. Eastern time, two experts partner with juniors from around the world for an hour on Bridge Base Online. These sessions are arranged by Valerie Westheimer of New York City and Paula Mittleman of Boynton Beach, Fla., and kibitzers are welcome.

headline: Syrian Rebels Claim Big Gains in City Where Protests Began
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rebel fighters in southern Syria claimed on Friday to be in control of most of the city of Dara’a, the cradle of the 2011 uprising against President Bashar al-Assad, after having battled his forces there for two weeks. The assertions, if confirmed, would represent a rare military victory for the insurgency, which has been struggling since it lost the stronghold city of Qusayr near the Lebanon border on June 5.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: Jon S. Corzine faces a federal suit over the collapse of MF Global, Ireland slipped back into recession and problems with counterfeit food and liquor have grown.

headline: No One’s Seen It, but Netflix Renews It
text: Netflix, unlike so many of its rivals on cable and broadcast, doesn’t share any ratings, so we won’t know how popular “Orange Is the New Black” is after the show has its debut on the service. But we can surmise that it is already pretty popular inside Netflix.

headline: Portrait of a Young Model in Paris
