text: I loved this shot from the backstage at Ann Demeulemeester’s show — the romantic gloom of it. The picture captures the mood of the collection, with its lean silhouette, wide-striped trousers, modified cloche hats, and flowers embroidered in jet black.

headline: Berluti Holds a Picnic, Givenchy Misses
text: I’ll have more to say about Berluti and the clothes of Alessandro Sartori in my review of the Paris men’s shows, but what a fabulous party he and his boss, Antoine Arnault, threw tonight at Hotel Sully — just a wee shack — in the Place des Vosges. Much of the fashion/cocktail action took place in the grass-covered courtyard and then there was a barbecue. Hamburgers, hot dogs, kebobs, salads, and French fries, served buffet style.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 28
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a rally in the Village after a ruling on same-sex marriage, umbrellas at Jones Beach and a retirement celebration for a beloved principal.

headline: Video of Deadly Clashes in Alexandria, Egypt
text: As my colleagues Kareem Fahim and David Kirkpatrick report, violent street battles gripped Egypt on Friday as supporters and opponents of the country’s Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi, held competing protests that devolved into fierce clashes in several cities. The violence was particularly fierce in the port city of Alexandria, where three people, including one American citizen, were killed and the local headquarters of the Muslim Brotherhood, of which Mr. Morsi is a leader, was set ablaze.

headline: 17 Years Have Passed and Date-Krumm Plays On
text: WIMBLEDON, England – When Serena Williams was just 15, Kimiko Date-Krumm was competing in the Wimbledon semifinals. It’s such a long time ago that Date-Krumm said  that she can barely remember the tournament and it is doubtful either player could have dreamed that 17 years later they would face each other on Court One for a place in the last 16.

headline: The Wrenching Story of Her Abortion
text: To the Editor:

headline: City Homicides Drop Sharply, Again; Police Cite New Antigang Strategy
text: The number of homicides on record in New York City has dropped significantly during the first half of the year — to 154 from 202 in the same period last year — surprising even police officials who have long been accustomed to trumpeting declining crime rates in the city.

headline: Cohen Declines to Testify in SAC Insider Case
text: Steven A. Cohen has declined to testify before a grand jury, raising the stakes in the government’s long-running insider trading investigation into his giant hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors.

headline: Is America a Leader in Broadband, or a Straggler?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gay Couples Who Sued in California Are Married
text: LOS ANGELES — The two couples who sued to overturn California’s ban on same-sex marriage were married late Friday afternoon, just hours after the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, lifted the stay that had been in place.

headline: A Manhattan Bar Crawl of Sorts, With Thefts on Tap and on Tape
text: It was a busy Friday night in March at Petite Abeille, a Belgian cafe on East 20th Street near Stuyvesant Town. Regulars lined the bar. Everybody knew one another, which made it all the more shocking when one of the women shouted, “My wallet! Someone stole my wallet!”

headline: Deadly Clashes in Egypt
text: Cairo saw dueling, but peaceful, rallies on Friday by supporters of President Mohamed Morsi and antigovernment protesters while demonstrations in other cities turned violent.

headline: A New Respect for Marriage
F.B.I. Will Fight the Mafia With Fewer Investigators
text: The New York office of the F.B.I. confronts an array of challenges — from cyber and financial crime to global terrorism — that would have been unimaginable half a century ago when it first squared off in earnest against the mob. And so, in recent years, more and more agents have been assigned to those modern threats and fewer to the L.C.N., the bureau’s shorthand for La Cosa Nostra.

headline: Suicide by Pills Is Cited in Death of Guantánamo Detainee
text: WASHINGTON — A Yemeni detainee who was found dead last year at the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, committed suicide by taking an overdose of psychiatric medication, according to a military report made public on Friday.

headline: How Is Your Bond Portfolio Allocated?
text: This week’s Your Money column addresses the big sell-off in the bond market, in which a fear of rising interest rates has caused investors to dump their funds.

headline: Pub Fare for High Rollers
text: A piece of advice for those venturing to eat at Dan Rooney’s, a new restaurant at the ever-expanding Empire City Casino at Yonkers Raceway: after consigning your car to a valet, take the escalator to the second floor, weave your way through the chiming slot machines and, just beyond the case of silver trophies, step out onto the terrace overlooking the racetrack. There, at dusk, one can watch beautifully gaited harness horses as they trot around the same dirt oval where Seabiscuit once outran his competitors.

headline: An Adoptee Returns to South Korea, and Changes Follow
text: SEOUL, South Korea — ALL her life, Jane Jeong Trenka struggled to belong.

headline: Pikes Peak Veteran Rod Millen Races to the Clouds Once More in an E.V.
text: A few years ago, Rod Millen might have laughed at an offer to race an electric car in the annual Pikes Peak International Hill Climb. Millen, 62, is a nine-time winner in the famed Race to the Clouds, including five victories in the Unlimited division.

headline: Zoilo Almonte Gains Attention for Hot Start and His First Name
text: Baseball has had at least 22 players go by the nickname Heinie. There have been three players named Urban, three named Hideki and three with the first name Rogers. But until Zoilo Almonte was summoned to the Yankees from the minors, there had been only one Zoilo.

headline: Bloomberg Says Math Backs Police Stops of Minorities
text: Ratcheting up the rhetoric over New York City’s stop-and-frisk police practices, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Friday that the Police Department stopped white people too frequently, and nonwhites not frequently enough, in investigating murder suspects.

headline: Protests in Brazil
text: To the Editor:

headline: Social Skills, on the Wane
text: To the Editor:

headline: Making ‘Killer Angels’
text: One-hundred-and-one summers after the Battle of Gettysburg, a family of four stopped their Nash Rambler at the site during a 1,000-mile drive from the New York World’s Fair to Tallahassee, Fla. The father was a New Jersey-born former boxer, paratrooper and policeman who became a creative writing instructor at Florida State after enrolling to study opera. Before arriving at the park he had published dozens of science-fiction short stories, but nothing about history. But he had researched several Gettysburg participants for the trip, and he fascinated his daughter Lila and son Jeff with stories of his favorites while the family walked the grounds. They ended up staying for several days, because Michael Shaara was in the early stages of creating his masterpiece novel, “The Killer Angels.”

headline: Hepatitis Threat Forces Another Frozen Fruit Recall
text: The Food and Drug Administration said on Friday that it had identified another product contaminated with Hepatitis A, which was the cause of a recall of frozen organic berries earlier this month.

headline: Jesuits in the New World
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Tight Race, Quinn’s Troops Hit the Streets
text: In the Bayside section of Queens, a volunteer had barely begun her sales pitch for Christine C. Quinn’s mayoral campaign when the middle-aged man who answered the door cut her off. “She was the one responsible, in the City Council, for giving Bloomberg a third term,” he barked. “I hold that against her.”

headline: Farmers Look to New Ways of Irrigating in a Drought
text: DUMAS, Tex. — Deep in the Texas Panhandle, where the decline of the Ogallala Aquifer has left farmers fearful for their future, Harold Grall is hoping his field of tiny green corn plants will survive with minimal watering.

headline: What Do You Reveal Onstage?
text: Ah, yes. Back to the songwriting series! I’ve missed writing about songwriting. Maybe you’ve missed me, too, a little. Why do we write songs, by the way? Usually we write for a reason — to express a feeling, to tell that boy what we think of him, or to sing the baby to sleep. Sometimes we write songs to be famous, but not usually. The best songs are useful in our daily lives. So therefore anywhere we sing a song can be a kind of stage.

headline: On Grass, Riske Is in Her Element
text: Alison Riske knows how to play on grass. She broke through at Birmingham three years ago, getting through three tough qualifying matches, then making a deep run to the semifinals, where she lost in three sets to Maria Sharapova. The All England Club gave her a wild card that year, but Riske lost a close match to Belgium’s Yanina Wickmayer in the first round.

headline: Shopkeepers and Now Restaurateurs, Too
text: The look of Gifford’s, which opened for business in Kent in February, sends a clear signal that this is a different kind of restaurant from its predecessor, the long-running Doc’s Trattoria. The co-owners, Michael Moriarty and James Neunzig, had the interior redesigned with vibrant blocks of color that evoke the work of the artist Josef Albers.

headline: With Pierce and Garnett, Nets Get Upgrade in Scoring and Snarling
text: The lights will go up, the “Broook-lyn” chants will resume and, in the giddy haze of opening night at Barclays Center next fall, a brooding, solitary figure will approach the basket stanchion closest to the home team’s bench — and ram his head into it. Repeatedly.

headline: Transit Union Spurns Lhota
text: In January, when Joseph J. Lhota, the former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, announced his run for mayor, the leader of the largest union of transit workers in the city was asked if the group would consider endorsing Mr. Lhota’s candidacy.

headline: Bhutan Is No Shangri-La
text: DAMAK, Nepal — BEFORE my family was expelled from Bhutan, in 1992, I lived with my parents and seven siblings in the south of the country. This region is the most fertile part of that tiny kingdom perched between Tibet and India, a tapestry of mountains, plains and alpine meadows. Our house sat in a small village, on terraced land flourishing with maize, millet and buckwheat, a cardamom garden, beehives and enough pasture for cows, oxen, sheep and buffaloes. That was the only home we had known.

headline: Scavenger of Golf Balls Is Found Stabbed to Death
text: For most golfers, every shank, hook and slice is agony. But for the people who scavenge the ponds and rough edges of golf courses, the little white balls that land out of play are as good as cash.

headline: Visit by Obama Is Overshadowed by Mandela Vigil
text: JOHANNESBURG — Nelson Mandela always wanted to go quietly. Despite his stature as a global icon, he sought a dignified withdrawal from public life in recent years; privately he told aides of his desire for a quiet funeral, stripped of pomp.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Something About Wimbledon Agrees With Lisicki and Pironkova
text: WIMBLEDON, England — For two women playing third-round matches Saturday at Wimbledon — Sabine Lisicki and Tsvetana Pironkova — the slick grass has proved a fast track to the business end of tournaments in a way that other tournaments have not.

headline: Planted, Grown, Gathered and Dropped Off
text: Earlier this month, when sugar snap peas, arugula, spinach and strawberries began to appear at East End farm stands and local farmers’ markets, they also turned up on the doorsteps of some Long Island residents.

headline: Gulbis, Knocked Off Course by Malaria, Fights Her Way Back on Tour
text: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. — Her caddie, Greg Sheridan, was the first to grow alarmed at her growing list of symptoms. Something seemed definitely off about Natalie Gulbis’s condition.

headline: A Preview of the 9/11 Memorial Museum
text: Jarring transitions between the serenity of vast spaces and the grief of destruction and loss will meet visitors to the exhibition space.

headline: Publisher Drops Book Deal With TV Chef Paula Deen
text: Paula Deen got a rare bit of good news on Thursday: Her new cookbook hit No. 1 on the best-seller list at Amazon.com, as thousands of fans — many of them springing to her defense as she faces accusations of racism — ordered the book months before its October release.

headline: Expect the Unexpected
text: Every once in a while, something happens that challenges your entire view of the order of the universe. For instance, this week the U.S. Senate actually passed something. Meanwhile, in Texas, liberal Democrats and the abortion rights movement won a huge political victory.

headline: Dinner Before the Show, or Just Dinner
text: There are several kinds of dining experiences to be had at the flashy Nico Kitchen + Bar, tucked into the eastern end of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in downtown Newark. You might choose an evening when there’s a performance next door and the place is humming with fans who can pass directly into the theater at showtime. Or you might opt for a quieter night, when the enormous main dining room feels as cavernous and calm as a cathedral. In that case a better choice might be one of the handsome brown banquettes in the bar area, which can be bustling at happy hour but intimate a bit later on. Or maybe lunch, when there are “lots of suits” from the nearby office buildings and government offices, as Nico’s guiding force, Ryan DePersio, put it in a telephone interview after several recent visits.

headline: Horse-Butchering Plan Gains as U.S. Agrees to Inspect
text: A plant in New Mexico that plans to slaughter horses to produce meat for human consumption moved a step closer to operation on Friday when the Agriculture Department said it would provide legally required inspection services.

headline: Cultural Revolution Vigilantes
text: Even now, nearly six months later — during which time Amazon.com has been flooded with hundreds of negative reviews condemning her; a Web site was set up attacking her; and her friends and colleagues have been bombarded with e-mails denouncing her — it is a little hard to understand why Ping Fu’s memoir, “Bend, Not Break,” has aroused such fury in some quarters of the Chinese immigrant community.

headline: Honda Fit Is Recalled 2nd Time to Fix Switch That Could Cause a Fire
text: Honda said Friday that it was recalling about 686,000 vehicles worldwide for a second time, because its initial attempt to fix an electrical problem that could cause a fire was not adequate.

headline: Proper Partner
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — So there’s this guy named Joe Krozel, and he likes to break records. He’s done it a lot (No, I am not going to go count. Just trust me on this) and his thing seems to be looking for new ways to push the envelope.

headline: While N.S.A. Leaker Stays in Hiding, Russian TV Builds a Pedestal for Him
text: MOSCOW — While Edward J. Snowden has remained mysteriously hidden from sight during his visit to Russia this week, Russian television has been making him a hero.

headline: Glossy Ibises Are Like 21st-Century Pterodactyls
text: Along the Atlantic coast, summer afternoons arrive on the wings of the glossy ibis (Plegadis falcinellus). These dark birds seem to appear magically, suddenly haunting shallow mud flats and wet meadows where just minutes earlier none had been.

headline: Dangerous Divisions in the Arab World
text: Even in a region where violence has become all too commonplace, the killing of four Shiite men in Egypt last weekend seemed particularly vicious. According to news reports, a cheering Sunni Muslim mob armed with clubs, swords and machetes raided a house in a Cairo suburb where about 30 people were marking a religious festival and beat, stabbed and lynched the four men. Video footage showed the victims’ bodies, bloodied and motionless, being dragged through the streets. Among those killed was a prominent Shiite cleric, Hassan Shehata.

headline: A Damaging Decision on Generic Drugs
text: Consumers grievously harmed by generic drugs may find it virtually impossible to win compensation for their injuries as a result of a Supreme Court decision issued on Monday. By a narrow 5-to-4 margin, the court overturned lower court rulings that had awarded a New Hampshire woman $21 million for pain and suffering and other damages.

headline: American Mayors: Let Them Smoke Pot
text: It has been more than seven months since voters in Colorado and Washington State chose to legalize marijuana for recreational use, in contravention of federal drug laws. It has been more than three months since Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. told the Senate Judiciary Committee that he would announce his department’s response to the new statutes “relatively soon.”

headline: Senegal Cheers Its President for Standing Up to Obama on Same-Sex Marriage
text: DAKAR, Senegal — In Senegal, never mind about same-sex marriage: gay men and lesbians are abused by the police, beaten and sometimes tortured, with impunity. They are threatened by mobs, mocked on the front pages of newspapers and subject to criminal prosecution for being gay. And the persecution is even more severe elsewhere in West Africa.

headline: F.D.A. Approves a Drug for Hot Flashes
text: The first nonhormonal drug to treat hot flashes won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Friday, offering a new alternative to menopausal women.

headline: The Zimmerman Trial
text: This first week of testimony in the George Zimmerman trial has proved to be nothing short of fascinating.

headline: Corrections: June 29, 2013
text: NATIONAL

headline: Sex and the H.I.V. Morning-After Pill
text: I RECENTLY had a serious H.I.V. scare after an episode of unprotected sex. The next day, at Whitman-Walker, a clinic in Washington that specializes in treating gay patients, I began a monthlong regimen of the drug Truvada, a form of post-exposure prophylaxis, or PEP. It has to be taken within 72 hours after potential contact with the virus that causes AIDS. The price tag would normally be $1,200, but I was able to get a subsidy the manufacturer gives to low-income earners.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Former Mexican Governor Gets 11 Years for Taking Drug Bribes
text: MEXICO CITY — A former Mexican governor was sentenced on Friday to nearly 11 years in prison in the United States after pleading guilty in New York to a federal charge of conspiring to launder millions of dollars in drug cartel bribes to allow cocaine to move freely through his state.

headline: Reactions to DOMA on Social Media
text: The Supreme Court’s decision to overturn the Defense of Marriage Act on Wednesday sparked a wave of video reactions on Instagram and other social media.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 29, 2013
text: “One hundred years from now, no one will be alive who remembers 9/11. The story has to tell itself.”

headline: Masterpieces, Revised by a Playful Restorer
text: Few people in the art world will forget an incident that occurred a little over a year ago, when a parishioner in a church near Zaragoza, Spain, took it upon herself to restore a fresco of Jesus — and ended up ruining it. It’s unlikely that Kathleen Gilje’s exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich will receive as much attention as the hapless Cecilia Giménez, whose story immediately spread on the Internet. But if Ms. Giménez offered a tragicomic lesson in the pitfalls of do-it-yourself conservation, “Revised and Restored: The Art of Kathleen Gilje” shows the work of a skilled practitioner-turned-artist who consciously blurs the lines between restoring art and making something new.

headline: N.F.L. Star and Murder Victim: Where Diverse Paths Crossed
text: BOSTON — Odin Lloyd did not own a car, so, just after dawn, he would pedal his bicycle from his Fayston Street home past blocks checkered with overgrown yards and rusted fences in one of Boston’s roughest neighborhoods.

headline: After Leaks, Obama Leads Damage Control Effort
text: WASHINGTON — Standing in the grand presidential palace in Senegal this week, President Obama detoured from his diplomatic mission to Africa to offer a message to his own constituents back home.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Inspired by Nature, Tweaked With Satire
text: On a sunny afternoon last month, John Alexander sat in his studio in Amagansett, surveying a boatload of motley figures on a large painting in progress he had titled “Lost Souls.”

headline: Updates to Drivers’ Education Reflect New Dangers on the Road
text: DES PLAINES, Ill. — The drivers’ education simulator lab here seems straight from the 1970s: A dozen teenagers tucked into low-slung black vinyl drivers’ seats, their steering wheels creaking in unison as a grainy movie plays and a narrator’s grandfatherly voice gently asks, “Are you identifying the potential signs of conflict?”

headline: Jim Hudson, Who Intercepted Pass to Help Jets Win Title, Dies at 70
text: Jim Hudson, the defensive back whose interception on a trick play helped propel the Jets’ storied upset over the Baltimore Colts in the 1969 Super Bowl, died on Tuesday in Austin, Tex. He was 70.

headline: Celebrating the Evolution, and Craft, of Boat Building
text: IN HIS PLAINTIVE 1989 SONG “The Downeaster ‘Alexa,’ ” Billy Joel gave voice to the plight of Long Island fishermen suffering after a ban on striped bass fishing that went into effect a few years earlier. The ban was one of the factors, along with increased regulation, overfishing and aggressive development on the Long Island coast, that helped cause the waning of the fishing industry, and in turn, a perhaps less obvious decline: that of the boat-building trade.

headline: Sabathia, in Bid for 200th Victory, Veers From Dominating to Defeated
text: BALTIMORE — Through five innings Friday night, C. C. Sabathia looked as if he might earn his 200th win in grand style. He had not allowed a hit and was pitching as sharply as he had been all season.

headline: A Peek Inside the 9/11 Memorial Museum
text: A tour inside the National September 11 Memorial and Museum in New York, as it unveils some of the exhibits that will go on display when it opens to the public.

headline: Adm. Frank B. Kelso Dies at 79; Tied to Tailhook Scandal
text: WASHINGTON — Adm. Frank B. Kelso II, who retired under pressure as chief of naval operations in 1994 in the aftermath of rampant sexual misconduct by Navy officers at an aviation convention known as Tailhook, died on Sunday in Norfolk, Va. He was 79.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Out to the (Extremely) Old Ball Game
text: Men in uniform are not traditionally jeered at for being “unmanly.”

headline: Harvey Is Sharp, but Bullpen Is Not
text: The futility of the 2013 Mets can ruin any night, even one when Matt Harvey pitches. On another evening when Harvey, the Mets’ ace, was dazzling, the bullpen collapsed and cost him a victory.

headline: Mets’ Wheeler Scouts Harvey and Himself
text: The most meaningful games the Mets will play this year are the ones that cast an eye toward future seasons, when the team hopes to contend. For that reason, any Matt Harvey start is worth watching, but so are starts by the prized rookie Zack Wheeler.

headline: Arizona Is Fertile Ground for New York Matzo
text: YUMA, Ariz. — Here, on a Christian farmer’s land  five miles from the Mexican border, lies the holiest of fields for some of New York’s most observant Orthodox Jewish communities. Wheat harvested on these 40 acres is destined to become matzo, the unleavened bread eaten by Jews during the eight days of Passover.

headline: An Island Lifesaver
text: All ambulance workers have their war stories. Ben Jones has them going back to World War II.

headline: All Eyes on the Elephant
text: In his work “Topsy: The Startling Story of the Crooked-Tailed Elephant, P. T. Barnum and the American Wizard, Thomas Edison” (Atlantic Monthly Press, $27), Michael Daly vividly revives a rollicking pachydermal tale that riveted New Yorkers a century ago and still survives in a gruesome YouTube video.

headline: Rangers Decide to Keep Richards
text: The Rangers announced Friday that they would not use their remaining compliance buyout this summer, ensuring that Brad Richards will return to the team for at least one more season.

headline: Stanzas for a Romantic Season
text: Pop songs never seem to mention winter love or autumn love. But summer love — now that’s a genre all its own. Guilt-free and removed from the usual fidelities, summer love is the troubadour of romance: it entertains and distracts us, and then moves blithely on. The following poems were “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are their subject headings.

headline: N.F.L. Won’t Promote Enrollment in Health Insurance Under New Law
text: The National Football League is not participating in an effort with the Obama administration to help promote enrollment in health insurance plans under the new health care law, a spokesman said. The statement came after two Republican Senate leaders wrote to the heads of six major professional sports organizations, including the N.F.L., expressing concern that they would help encourage people to sign up in the new health insurance programs set to begin next month. Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary for health and human services, has been in talks with various groups to help with enrollment efforts. But the senators, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and John Cornyn of Texas, warned that doing so might not be a good idea. “Given the divisiveness and persistent unpopularity of the health care law, it is difficult to understand why an organization like yours would risk damaging its inclusive and apolitical brand by lending its name to its promotion,” the senators wrote.

headline: Hardaway’s Name Is Familiar, but His Game Is Not
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Tim Hardaway Jr. stared at his No. 5 Knicks jersey, surrounded by photographers prepared to capture the moment. Hardaway, the Knicks’ first-round pick, then flashed a familiar smile as cameras clicked.

headline: A Night Owl With a Canine Alarm
text: Mark Elijah Rosenberg is the founder and artistic director of Rooftop Films, which has been screening new independent films atop various New York City buildings every summer since 1997. The group has since branched out to farms and boats, among other venues, and has screened films in at least a half-dozen other cities. Mr. Rosenberg, 38, lives in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, with his wife,  Stephanie Frances Skaff, a musician and writer, and their dog, Dizzy.

headline: Taking Back Hernandez Jerseys
text: The New England Patriots are offering new jerseys to all fans who want to get rid of the ones they bought with Aaron Hernandez’s name. Hernandez is being held in jail on a first-degree murder charge. The team has released him and removed all Hernandez jerseys from its souvenir store at Gillette Stadium. The team said fans could go to the store on the weekend of July 6-7 for a free jersey of comparable value. (AP)

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (Lifetime) ANNA NICOLE (2013) Agnes Bruckner, above, plays Vickie Lynn Hogan, a Texas high school dropout and single mother who takes a job as a dancer at a topless bar and changes her name. As Anna Nicole Smith, she marries the octogenarian millionaire J. Howard Marshall (Martin Landau) and earns comparisons to Marilyn Monroe in a Playboy pictorial. But her husband’s death brings an end to her financial support, and drinking, pill-popping and drastic weight fluctuations take their toll. Soon her son, Danny (Graham Patrick Martin), dies of an overdose while visiting his mother and newborn sister in the hospital. Not long after, Anna dies. Rounding out the cast are Adam Goldberg, as Anna’s boyfriend Howard K. Stern; Virginia Madsen, as her mother, Virgie Arthur; and Cary Elwes, as Marshall’s son, E. Pierce Marshall.

headline: Shaking Up the Stage
text: Dixon Place, the Lower East Side performance space, has been host for all sorts of odd and eyebrow-raising work, but Gregg Mozgala may have introduced a new kind of discomfort this month with a scene that found him sucking on Sara Buffamanti’s toes.

headline: The Mob and Angela Clemente
text: At the end of February, a 300-page report, tersely titled, “New York Systemic Corruption,” was received for review by the Justice Department’s Office of the Inspector General in Washington. In three bound volumes, it detailed a series of oft-made, and explosive, allegations: that in the 1990s, while trying to stem the Colombo family war, federal prosecutors and agents for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York knowingly allowed two moles in the mob to kill while they were on the government’s payroll.

headline: Camping for Feminism
text: On Thursday morning, Courtney Cook, a 17-year-old art student from Winnetka, Ill., who was spending the week with her mother at the Jade Hotel downtown, sat in the Lexington Avenue offices of the nonprofit group Choices in Childbirth and talked about her maternal fantasies. “I’d like to have a baby like right now,” Ms. Cook explained to a group of peers and educators, “but I know it’s not a good time.” Although she doesn’t plan to have a child until she is 30, she had become obsessed with motherhood after hours of watching “A Baby Story,” a reality series on the procreation-obsessed cable network TLC. Such is the extent of her fascination that she keeps pictures of nurseries on her Pinterest board.

headline: U.S. Student Killed in Egypt Protest Was Drawn to a Region in Upheaval
text: The American student who was killed in Egypt on Friday during street protests in Alexandria was an idealist, an Arabist and a linguist, drawn to the Middle East despite — or perhaps even because of — its political unrest, friends said.

headline: Unable to Visit With Mandela, Obama Honors His Legacy
text: JOHANNESBURG — The possibility of a meeting between the two historic figures — the first black president of the United States and the first black president of South Africa — was so tantalizingly close. But with Nelson Mandela fighting for his life in a Pretoria hospital, President Obama abandoned his hope for a visit and instead on Saturday used every stop here to talk in emotional and sweeping terms about what Mr. Mandela meant to the world, and to him.

headline: Visit by Obama Is Overshadowed by Mandela Vigil
text: JOHANNESBURG — Nelson Mandela always wanted to go quietly. Despite his stature as a global icon, he sought a dignified withdrawal from public life in recent years. Privately he told aides of his desire for a quiet funeral, stripped of pomp.

headline: The Weekend Word: Covered
text: In Today’s Times

headline: Violence in Restive Chinese Region Prompts Crackdown
text: HONG KONG — China’s Communist Party leadership has started a security crackdown in the far western region, Xinjiang, vowing to apply “high pressure” methods after two outbursts of violence there in recent days pitted members of the Uighur ethnic minority against police forces, state television reported Saturday.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Givenchy Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Who’s a Journalist? A Question With Many Facets and One Sure Answer
text: Behind almost every correction in The Times, there is a story. In the case of the correction about Alexa O’Brien, the story is a particularly interesting one.

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Acelaland Versus Mayberry
text: Hmm. One thing I’ve noticed in recent discussions is that on the right, the Acela — America’s only sorta-kinda high-speed passenger train — has become a symbol of liberal elitism. What’s that about?

headline: The Always-Wrong Club
text: Aha. Floyd Norris reminds us of the 23-economist letter from 2010, warning of dire consequences — “currency debasement and inflation” — from quantitative easing. The signatories are kind of a who’s who of wrongness, ranging from Niall Ferguson to Amity Shlaes to John Taylor. And they were wrong again.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Berluti Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Paul Venables, on Asking for the Toughest Jobs
text: This interview with   Paul Venables, founder and executive creative director of Venables Bell & Partners, an advertising agency in San Francisco, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Cahill Returns Not a Moment Too Soon for Red Bulls
text: The Red Bulls will attempt to avoid on 0-fer, 0 for June, when they face the Houston Dynamo on Sunday afternoon in the club’s first home game since the first day of the month.

headline: Risk for Redskins in Makeover of Team Mascot
text: Few teams in the N.F.L. have faced more pressing off-season concerns than the Washington Redskins, whose star quarterback, Robert Griffin III, hopes to be ready for training camp as he continues to rehabilitate his surgically repaired right knee.

headline: After Fighting Mobile Trend, Intel Now Embraces It
text: Intel, which became a global behemoth by making the chips that drive most of the world’s desktop computers and laptops, missed the mobile revolution. In tablets and smartphones, the company is a bit player.

headline: Dior Homme
text: The complete spring 2014 collection shown in Paris.

headline: Christian Dior: Spring 2014 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Mariano Rivera: A Singular Pitcher
text: As Mariano Rivera walked to the mound June 19, a Yankee fan might have felt a pang of doubt. A combined 18 walks and hits had pockmarked his previous five and two-thirds innings over eight outings, more base runners, according to the Elias Sports Bureau, than Rivera had ever allowed over any other eight-game stretch in his major league career.

headline: Rangers Have Needs but Not High Picks
text: Gordie Clark, the Rangers’ player personnel director, hopes to add defensive depth and a goaltender in the N.H.L. draft on Sunday.

headline: Egypt, Its Streets a Tinderbox, Braces for a Spark
text: CAIRO — Thousands of members of the Muslim Brotherhood, many wearing hard hats and armed with makeshift clubs, are camped near the presidential palace in anticipation of a battle to defend their ally, President Mohamed Morsi. In three days of protests against him around the Nile Delta, gunmen have killed at least five Brotherhood members and set fire to several of its offices.

headline: For the No. 1 Pick, the Avalanche May Set Aside Sentiment
text: Sunday’s N.H.L. draft at Prudential Center in Newark will begin either like a fairy tale, or like a fairy tale overturned. It all depends on whether the Colorado Avalanche take defenseman Seth Jones with the first overall pick or choose the talented center Nathan MacKinnon instead.

headline: Variety: An Alarming Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — I’ll confess, I had never heard of a “ha-ha” before today’s discussion. That may have slowed me down. You just don’t see too many of them in the part of the Bronx where I grew up.

headline: It’s No Secret Lakers Want Howard Back
text: LOS ANGELES — When two billboards with an image of Dwight Howard accompanied by the word “STAY” went up last week in Los Angeles — one on Hollywood Boulevard and the other across the street from Staples Center — it was rather unbecoming.

headline: President-Elect of Iran Says He Will Engage With the West
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s president-elect, Hassan Rouhani, said Saturday that he would engage with the West and fulfill his electoral promises to allow more freedom for the Iranian people.

headline: Kerry Extends Israel Trip Amid Speculation on Talks
text: JERUSALEM — In a hectic day of shuttle diplomacy with senior Israeli and Palestinian leaders in two capitals, Secretary of State John Kerry struggled on Saturday to close a deal to revive dormant Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

headline: Best Brother Was Saved for Last, Bobcats Think
text: The Zeller brothers each took a turn being Indiana’s Mr. Basketball. They reached a combined height of just under 21 feet, and each attended a powerhouse athletic university. But like most of the groups of three or more brothers to make it to professional sports, one will probably stand above the rest.

headline: Actors Today Don’t Just Read for the Part. Reading IS the Part.
text: Gabra Zackman is a new kind of acting star: she is heard, but unheard-of.

headline: Horschel’s Mantra: Clothes Make the Man
text: BETHESDA, Md. — Billy Horschel had a 50 percent success rate during his early days as a professional golfer. It had nothing to do with hitting greens in regulation or keeping the ball out of the rough. It had everything to do with having his wardrobe vetted by his wife, Brittany.

headline: At Wimbledon, Promise, Steeled by Early Trauma for Gómez
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Lucas Gómez, the Mexican national junior tennis champion, was humbled at the French Open in early June. He was beaten, 6-1, 6-0, in the third round of the junior tournament by second-seeded Nikola Milojevic of Serbia after expressing strong belief in his ability to win.

headline: Eddie Plank: A Favorite Son of Gettysburg
text: GETTYSBURG, Pa. — This week’s commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the Battle of Gettysburg, the turning point in the Civil War, might also bring renewed attention to Eddie Plank, a relatively unappreciated baseball star in the early 20th century who spent most of his life here. The battle, fought on the first three days of July in 1863, stamped Little Round Top, Seminary Ridge and Pickett’s Charge into America’s military lexicon.

headline: The Padres’ Season Doesn’t Add Up
text: When the San Diego Padres lined up along the third-base line at Citi Field on April 1, they did not look like contenders. Their opening day third baseman was the journeyman Cody Ransom. The right-hander Andrew Cashner, a perpetual ace in waiting, was again a reliever. The starter that day was Edinson Volquez, with Clayton Richard to follow in Game 2.

headline: ‘A Gallant Officer’
text: One day during the summer of 1863, in Union-occupied Nashville, Tenn., Anna Rhoads visited the headquarters of Gen. Walter C. Whitaker and requested a meeting with him. Perhaps to her surprise, he granted one.

headline: New Kind of Baseball Bat Is Tapered for Safety and Comfort
text: Bats have not changed much since Honus Wagner became the first player to have his name burned onto a Louisville Slugger. True, they are lighter now, with rounded ends, and since Barry Bonds used it, many players have switched to maple from the traditional white ash. But the general shape is unchanged.

headline: Who Sets the Terms for Interviews?
text: TAKING a summertime break from the weighty issues of leaks, false balance and anonymous sources — to which I’m sure to return — I am again hanging out the public editor’s shingle. I will do my best here to answer what I call Perfectly Reasonable Questions from those who read The Times closely and with a critical eye.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Our Notions of Gender
text: When a child identifies with the other gender, what to do?

headline: Thomas A. Drake
text: Thomas A. Drake is a former senior executive at the National Security Agency who, in 2006, leaked information to the press about wasteful government spending and alleged snooping on the citizenry.

headline: Stuck Team Bus Gives First Stage a Chaotic Finish
text: BASTIA, France — The Tour de France’s first visit to Corsica started uneventfully Saturday as riders rode calmly out of a picture-perfect harbor town under sunny skies.

headline: June 29: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: David Rogers, Stage Adapter of Offbeat Material, Dies at 85
text: “Flowers for Algernon,” Daniel Keyes’s novel about a mentally handicapped man who is temporarily transformed into a genius, has been read by millions and recreated in many forms, including the 1968 film “Charly” (playing the title role, Cliff Robertson won an Academy Award). But singing along with any version was impossible until David Rogers reinterpreted it as the musical “Charlie and Algernon.”

headline: Takin’ It to the Streets
text: THE former C.I.A. analyst Paul R. Pillar asked this question in a recent essay in The National Interest: Why are we seeing so many popular street revolts in democracies? Speaking specifically of Turkey and Brazil, but posing a question that could be applied to Egypt, Israel, Russia, Chile and the United States, Pillar asks: “The governments being protested against were freely and democratically elected. With the ballot box available, why should there be recourse to the street?”

headline: Germans Loved Obama. Now We Don’t Trust Him.
text: BERLIN — IN May 2010, I received a brown envelope. In it was a CD with an encrypted file containing six months of my life. Six months of metadata, stored by my cellphone provider, T-Mobile. This list of metadata contained 35,830 records. That’s 35,830 times my phone company knew if, where and when I was surfing the Web, calling or texting.

headline: Democrats Get a Gift From the Roberts Court
text: BACK in the days when Republicans were reading polls through rose-colored glasses and imagining a Mitt Romney landslide, one of their most plausible arguments was that many pollsters were simply misreading the likely composition of the electorate. There was no way, this theory ran, that core Democratic constituencies would turn out at the same rates as in 2008, when Obamamania was at its peak. Instead, 2012 was set up to be what the conservative writer Ben Domenech called an “undertow election,” in which reduced turnout among young voters and minorities would drag the incumbent down to defeat.

headline: A Nation of Brewmeisters
text: Eighty years after the end of Prohibition, Mississippi has become the last of the 50 states to legalize one of the more innocent offshoots of the era of the Drys — home brewing, a hobby long suppressed in the states but lately generating a frothy head of popularity. Assorted limits remain in states and localities about the amount of beer that can be brewed as well as bans on transporting home brew into the community. But after some moralizing debates this year about demon beer, Alabama lawmakers repealed the total ban in May; in Mississippi, home brewing becomes legal on July 1.

headline: The Talented Justice Kagan
text: Elena Kagan is the first Supreme Court justice appointed in almost 40 years who wasn’t a judge before she arrived at the court. In a good way, it shows. Since she was sworn in three summers ago, the evidence has mounted that she is achieving a goal that other justices say they strive for and yet seldom attain: writing readable judicial opinions that non-lawyers can understand.

headline: Mandela and Obama
text: GATHERING valedictory material on Nelson Mandela as he faded in a Pretoria hospital the other day, I came across a little book called “Mandela’s Way.” In this 2010 volume, Rick Stengel, the ghostwriter of Mandela’s autobiography, set out to extract “lessons on life, love and courage” he had learned from three years of immersion in Mandela’s life.

headline: The Best Hope for France’s Young? Get Out
text: THE French aren’t used to the idea that their country, like so many others in Europe, might be one of emigration — that people might actually want to leave. To many French people, it’s a completely foreign notion that, around the world and throughout history, voting with one’s feet has been the most widely available means to vote at all.

headline: The End of Car Culture
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA’S ambitious goals to curb the United States’ greenhouse gas emissions, unveiled last week, will get a fortuitous assist from an incipient shift in American behavior: recent studies suggest that Americans are buying fewer cars, driving less and getting fewer licenses as each year goes by.

headline: Souring on Shark Fin Soup
text: WHEN I was a kid, shark fin soup was de rigueur at wedding banquets. Somebody got married, and slurp — there we were, eating the stringy soup at an elaborate 10-course affair in a private party room in Chinatown. It was pleasing, but in the salty, gelatin-thickened way of Thanksgiving gravy. Shark fin itself is virtually tasteless — the soup’s flavor relies heavily on chicken stock, ham and a generous pour of Chinese red vinegar. We ate it because everyone else did, and everyone else ate it for the same reason.

headline: I Love L.A.
text: The photographer Lloyd Ziff revisits Los Angeles, the place of his childhood dreams.

headline: I Love L.A.
text: Frank Lloyd Wright said, “Tip the world over on its side and everything loose will land in Los Angeles.” Oscar Levant said, “Behind the phony tinsel of Hollywood lies the real tinsel.” I say, “I love it all.” I love the real tinsel and the phony tinsel, too.

headline: Why Healthy Eaters Fall for Fries
text: LAST Tuesday, Connor Moran, a limit-the-red-meat, increase-the-greens, eat-salad-for-lunch kind of guy, stopped into a Bronx Dunkin’ Donuts for his usual black coffee, no sugar, no cream.

headline: Berdych Continues His Dominance Over Anderson
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Tomas Berdych of the Czech Republic shrugged off a first-set service lapse and powered his way to a 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, 7-5 victory over Kevin Anderson of South Africa.

headline: Booze as Muse
text: MY first real job in journalism was as a junior editor at Esquire, a magazine with a venerable literary pedigree. I imagined myself having three-martini lunches with Tom Wolfe, and explaining to “Tom” (surely we would be on a first-name basis by the third martini) that his latest 25,000-word article was not bad, exactly, but needed another run through the typewriter before we could even think of publishing it.

headline: Lost: Pink Dog With Sneakers. Return to West Hollywood.
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — This city’s new dog is certainly conspicuous: fluorescent pink, weighing as much as a grown man, wearing sneakers on his paws and a water bottle strapped to his back.

headline: A Not-So-Powerful Federal Reserve
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Gospel According to ‘Me’
text: The booming self-help industry, not to mention the cash cow of New Age spirituality, has one message: be authentic! Charming as American optimism may be, its 21st-century incarnation as the search for authenticity deserves pause. The power of this new version of the American dream can be felt through the stridency of its imperatives: Live fully! Realize yourself! Be connected! Achieve well-being!

headline: For a Day, Wimbledon Turns Most Hospitable to the 20-and-Under
text: WIMBLEDON, England — On a day that featured 31-year-old Serena Williams defeating 42-year-old Kimiko Date-Krumm, youth had its moment in the sun. Yes, the sun was out at Wimbledon on Saturday after two days of on-and-off rain.

headline: Curtis W. Tarr, Innovative Leader of the Draft, Dies at 88
text: Curtis W. Tarr, who as director of the Selective Service System in the later years of the Vietnam War sought to make the lottery system for the military draft fairer by reducing the number of student and medical deferments granted to young men, died on June 21 at his home in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 88.

headline: The New Prostitutes
text: Take the Long Hill Road exit off I-95 in eastern Connecticut and curl south toward the waterfront city of Groton and you’ll find each of the places that briefly employed Maureen Brainard-Barnes. There is the TJ Maxx and the AutoZone and the Stop and Shop. And the Chester’s chicken counter, where she made the potato wedges. And the shopping center with the Groton Cinema 6, where she picked up discarded snacks from the carpet in exchange for free admission and a bag of popcorn.

headline: No Letup on the Right to Choose
text: Wendy Davis, a Texas state senator, got national attention last week for her marathon filibuster against an extremist package of abortion restrictions. Ms. Davis’s dramatic gesture is unlikely to stop the hard-right Texas Legislature from passing the bill, and there are many similar measures around the country that are part of a nonstop attack on women’s reproductive rights by Republican lawmakers and anti-abortion groups.

headline: A Gun Maker Moves On
text: One of Connecticut’s gun manufacturers, PTR Industries, is departing the state in a melodramatic huff for gun-friendly South Carolina, complaining about the tightened gun safety laws enacted in Hartford by conscience-stricken legislators following the Newtown gun massacre of 20 children and 6 educators last December.

headline: Buford Hold the High Ground
text: Neither side in the Civil War lacked for blowhards and glory seekers among its general officers corps. Many still command our attention 150 years later, and theirs are the names we often tend to recognize, while the steady, unassuming sort – those who did their jobs and sought no recognition – have often gone unheralded.

headline: The Future of Voting Rights
text: When five justices of the Supreme Court disabled the Voting Rights Act last Tuesday, they left it to Congress to find a new formula to restore one of the great landmarks of equality and once again protect the nation’s most fundamental democratic right. That is unlikely for the moment given Congressional dysfunction, as the justices certainly knew, but it is hardly impossible in the months and years to come.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, June 30
text: “Around the world, food fraud is an epidemic.”

headline: Have a Great Vacation (if It’s Approved)
text: JUST about every time I plan a vacation, I worry that I won’t be able to go. You can’t leave, my boss might say, because we’re just too busy to spare you. (In that case, I think indignantly, they’d better reimburse me for the plane ticket and the hotel room.)

headline: Politics Aside, a Common Bond for Two Economists
text: ONE of the cool things about hanging around a place like Harvard, where I have been a professor for almost 30 years, is that you get to meet some supertalented people long before the world recognizes their talents. I had a vivid reminder of this just a few days ago, when President Obama appointed Jason Furman as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, a position that I held under George W. Bush.

headline: Tremors From the Fed’s Grand Experiment
text: BEN S. BERNANKE and the Federal Reserve have been conducting a gigantic monetary experiment aimed at reducing unemployment, speeding up the economy and reviving the housing market.

headline: How Audubon Society’s Chief Took Wing From Journalism
text: I WAS born in California, but I moved every year that I was in grammar school. My father was a sales manager for Paper Mate, and it moved him around. I lived in several states, and the experience shaped me: change became normal and inevitable. I decided that I could roll with it or be crushed by it, and I learned to roll with it.

headline: No English!
text: MADRID

headline: Stealth Wear Aims to Make a Tech Statement
text: THE term “stealth wear” sounded cool, if a bit extreme, when I first heard it early this year. It’s a catchy description for clothing and accessories designed to protect the wearer from detection and surveillance. I was amused. It seemed like an updated version of a tinfoil hat, albeit a stylish one.

headline: Local Officials Asked to Help on Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — The White House is recruiting mayors, county commissioners and other local officials to promote and carry out President Obama’s health care law in states like Florida and Texas, where governors are hostile to it.

headline: The Real John Roberts Emerges
text: This time a year ago, the conservative chief justice whose vote saved President Obama’s health care law was a figure of mystery. In fact, “The Mystery of John Roberts” was the title I gave to one of my Opinionator columns for The New York Times last summer. The right-wing blogosphere had turned on him venomously. Liberals didn’t know what to make of his crucial vote, or of him. What was his game? Was he for real?

headline: The Cochrane Collaboration
text: The Cochrane Collaboration, which pushed Roche to release clinical trial data about Tamiflu, is an international network of experts who conduct exhaustive analyses of medical treatments.

headline: Breaking the Seal on Drug Research
text: PETER DOSHI walked across the campus of Johns Hopkins University in a rumpled polo shirt and stonewashed jeans, a backpack slung over one shoulder. An unremarkable presence on a campus filled with backpack-toters, he is 32, and not sure where he’ll be working come August, when his postdoctoral fellowship ends. And yet, even without a medical degree, he is one of the most influential voices in medical research today.

headline: Kvitova, Hoping to Regain 2011 Form, Advances at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England — On a Friday at Wimbledon 12 years ago, Tim Henman was on the verge of beating Goran Ivanisevic and advancing to the men’s final. He breezed through the third set, 6-0, and led in the fourth, 2-1.

headline: Generous Goodbyes
text: C.E.O.’s often walk away with millions in stock, bonuses and retirement benefits when they leave their companies. These 10 departing executives received the 10 largest exit packages in 2012.

headline: How the Figures Were Calculated
text: TO measure the amounts that chief executives were paid last year, Sunday Business asked Equilar Inc., an executive compensation data firm, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings.

headline: Executive Pay by the Numbers
text: Here are the 200 most highly-paid chief executives at U.S. public companies in 2013. The list, compiled by Equilar, an executive compensation data firm, includes firms with revenue over $1 billion.

headline: Golden Parachutes Are Still Very Much in Style
text: MOST employees who leave a company are typically offered modest severance — in some cases a corporate pension, and perhaps a retirement party hosted by co-workers. For many chief executives of corporations, the rewards are far, far richer.

headline: An Unstoppable Climb in C.E.O. Pay
text: WHEN we made our annual foray into the executive pay gold mine in April, chief executives’ earnings for 2012 showed what appeared to be muted growth on the year. The $14 million in median overall compensation received by the top 100 C.E.O.’s was just a 2.8 percent increase over 2011, the figures showed.

headline: Sore Arm Doesn’t Deter Gee in Victory Over Nationals
text: Early Saturday morning, Manager Terry Collins explained that the Mets would have to monitor Dillon Gee from start to start, grant him extra rest when possible and show general precaution while handling his forearm tendinitis, which has flared up and pained him on a sporadic basis this season. Collins left open the possibility of Gee’s going on the disabled list at some point.

headline: The Cool of Veronique Nichanian
text: The top trends for next spring are suits with mismatched trousers, the shirt jacket, neat windbreakers, ocean-to-sky shades of blue, and faded pencil stripes and dot prints. At Hermès on Saturday night, Veronique Nichanian managed to hit all of those notes, and not break a sweat.

headline: Bylsma Takes Dream Job as U.S. Men’s Hockey Coach
text: It is not a prerequisite for becoming coach of the United States Olympic men’s hockey team, but Dan Bylsma has watched “Miracle,” the movie about the 1980 squad coached by Herb Brooks that won the gold medal.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Dior Homme Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: California Couples Line Up to Marry After Stay on Same-Sex Marriage Is Lifted
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The words “spouses for life” echoed throughout City Hall on Saturday as hundreds of same-sex couples were married in stairways, rotundas and seemingly every open space in the building.

headline: Matching Wits
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — The first theme entry I solved in Alex Vratsanos’s and Jeff Chen’s “Matching Wits” puzzle was the venerable father of modern blues MUDDY WATERS, so as a nod to him, today’s blog post will be written in the rhythm of a blues riff.

headline: Rena Price Is Dead at 97; Catalyst for the Watts Riots
text: Rena Price was in her kitchen in the Watts section of Los Angeles on Aug. 11, 1965, when a neighbor came to tell her that the police were arresting her 21-year-old son, Marquette Frye. She immediately raced to the corner of 116th Street and South Avalon Boulevard, her red-flowered dress billowing.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 30
text: With the exact whereabouts of Edward J. Snowden unknown, Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, will join ABC’s “This Week” on Sunday to discuss how his antisecrecy group has helped Mr. Snowden in the wake of his disclosures about the National Security Agency.

headline: Ghana’s Crackdown on Chinese Gold Miners Hits One Rural Area Hard
text: MINGLIANG, China — To the people of Shanglin County, gold is a curse.

headline: Vows: The ‘Showmance’
text: Leslie Stifelman and Melissa Rae Mahon, of the musical “Chicago,” have been performing together on Broadway for seven years. Their son, Jack, was born in March.

headline: Philip E. Slater, Social Critic Who Renounced Academia, Dies at 86
text: Philip E. Slater, a social critic and author, pursued success in the conventional way in the first half of his life. He studied hard, graduated from Harvard, became a tenured professor of sociology and wrote a best-selling book, “The Pursuit of Loneliness.”

headline: In Support Groups for Gay Military Members, Plenty of Asking and Telling
text: ALBUQUERQUE — During his eight years in the Air Force, Staff Sgt. Justin Lahl grew adept at keeping his sexual orientation a secret — wincing inwardly when fellow airmen made homophobic wisecracks, nodding with a smile when others would caricature gay people for laughs.

headline:
Justice Still Elusive
in Factory Disasters
in Bangladesh
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Inside Courtroom 21, the two judges peered down from high wooden chairs as lawyers in formal black robes presented their motions. Activists and victims watched from the back. And a few steps away, a portly man with a thick black beard remained silent. He was the suspect. He did not seem especially nervous.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Comme des Garcons Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: Republicans Paint Clinton as Old News for 2016 Presidential Election
text: WASHINGTON — Stuart Stevens, the top strategist for Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign, declared to an audience of reporters at a breakfast last month that electing Hillary Rodham Clinton would be like going back in time. “She’s been around since the ’70s,” he said.

headline: Johannesburg Center Is Helping to Preserve the Legacy of Mandela
text: JOHANNESBURG — Sello Hatang pulled open a long, yellow drawer and grabbed a cream-color parchment. It declared Nelson Mandela an honorary citizen of the State of Washington.

headline: Ecuador Leader Says Biden Called About Asylum Request
text: QUITO, Ecuador — President Rafael Correa of Ecuador said Saturday that Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had asked him in a telephone call not to grant asylum to Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive former security contractor wanted in the United States.

headline: Makarova Caps Disappointing Showing for Russian Women
text: WIMBLEDON, England — When Ekaterina Makarova lost in three sets to Petra Kvitova early Saturday afternoon, she capped a disappointing showing for the Russian women at Wimbledon. Makarova, the No. 25 seed and the last Russian woman remaining in the tournament, fell 3-6, 6-2, 3-6.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Miharayasuhiro Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Hoping a Yankees Revival Starts With a Loss
text: BALTIMORE — The Yankees had what for them seemed like a breakout game Friday, despite its ending in a 4-3 loss to the Baltimore Orioles. They outhit the Orioles by 11-5 and scored three runs, far better production than they could muster Thursday, when they were stifled in a two-hit shutout.

headline: Syria Attacks Rebel-Held Area in New Push to Retake City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian military used airstrikes and heavy artillery to assault rebel-held areas of the central city of Homs on Saturday, residents and antigovernment activists said, as the government renewed efforts to retake that perennially restive and divided city.

headline: After Protests, Brazilian President’s Popularity Plummets
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The approval rating of Brazil’s president, Dilma Rousseff, plunged in June to 30 percent from 57 percent, reflecting swelling anger against the government since protests spread to more than 100 cities in recent weeks in a broad repudiation of political corruption, deplorable public services and costly stadium projects for the 2014 World Cup.

headline: Last Words of the Condemned
text: Texas has executed 500 inmates since it resumed carrying out the death penalty in 1982. Read selected excerpts of inmates’ last words.

headline: After Rare Struggles, Park Reasserts Her Dominance at U.S. Women’s Open
text: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. — For three months, the world’s best female golfers have been waiting for Inbee Park to falter, stumble, collapse under the growing weight of her dominance over the L.P.G.A. Tour.

headline:
Taking Outsize
Role in Syria,
Qatar Funnels
Arms to Rebels
text: WASHINGTON — As an intermittent supply of arms to the Syrian opposition gathered momentum last year, the Obama administration repeatedly implored its Arab allies to keep one type of powerful weapon out of the rebels’ hands: heat-seeking shoulder-fired missiles.

headline: Mixed Day for Tomic Siblings
text: WIMBLEDON, England — It was a mixed day for the Tomic family. While Bernard Tomic had one of his best wins of the year in knocking off Richard Gasquet in four tight sets, his younger sister Sara had a Wimbledon debut to forget.

headline: From America’s Busiest Death Chamber, a Catalog of Last Rants, Pleas and Apologies
text: HUNTSVILLE, Tex. — Karl Eugene Chamberlain went to his neighbor’s apartment that night in Dallas under the pretense of borrowing sugar. He returned later, forced her into a bedroom, bound her hands and feet, raped her and then used a rifle to shoot and kill her. His victim, Felecia Prechtl, 29, was a single mother with a 5-year-old son.

headline: Seppi Is Proving Unbeatable, if Stretched to Five Sets

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 10 P.M. (Showtime) RAY DONOVAN If Hollywood honchos need anything fixed, Ray Donovan (Liev Schreiber) is the man they call. Working with two associates — Avi (Steven Bauer, above center with Mr. Schreiber and Katherine Moennig) and Lena (Ms. Moennig) — he cleans up messes for studios and law firms, primarily Goldman/Drexler, led by his confidant and mentor, Ezra Goldman (Elliott Gould), and his partner, Lee Drexler (Peter Jacobson). But Ray’s life is a mess. His wife, Abby (Paula Malcomson), a hard-core Boston Southie, is still adjusting to living in the Los Angeles suburbs. His brother Bunchy (Dash Mihok) was abused by a priest and has the alcohol problem to prove it. Another brother, Terry (Eddie Marsan), boxed too long and developed Parkinson’s. And the ghost of their little sister, who committed suicide when she was a teenager, haunts them all. Now Ray’s father, Mickey (Jon Voight), a gangster with the Irish mob, has been unexpectedly released from prison. The Season 8 premiere of “Dexter,” which finds Deb (Jennifer Carpenter) giving Dexter (Michael C. Hall) the silent treatment, leads in at 9.

headline: Historic Mistake Watch
text: When the Fed began its talk of “tapering” asset purchases, I warned that it might turn out to be a “historic mistake”. I guess the historic bit is still up in the air; but the mistake aspect is now glaringly obvious. Bond prices have plunged, and the Fed’s attempts to inform markets that they’ve got it all wrong have only modestly mitigated the impact.

headline: ‘Monsters University’ Holds Off ‘White House Down’ at Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — Big guns and heavy star power took aim at the weekend film box office, but “Monsters University,” an animated frolic from Disney’s Pixar unit, was still standing when the dust settled. In its second weekend, “Monsters University” had about $46.2 million in North American ticket sales, and about $171 million in domestic sales to date. That put it well ahead of “The Heat,” a heavily armed action comedy starring Melissa McCarthy and Sandra Bullock. “The Heat” placed second with $40 million in weekend sales for 20th Century Fox.

headline: Via Stravinsky, a Girl and a Doll, Rapturous and Mechanized
text: The story told by the New York Philharmonic program “A Dancer’s Dream” last week was curious, even chilling. In a program note, the director-designer Doug Fitch called it “a kind of über fairy tale,” amalgamating themes shared by fairy tales around a single young woman “who slips into the world of her own imagination and is swept away by muses to become a ballerina.” Yes, but a ballerina of a particularly restricted kind. That heroine was played by the New York City Ballet principal Sara Mearns, and the program’s particular fascination was that it extended her in two directions we’ve never seen before. She began, in Stravinsky’s “Baiser de la Fée” (“The Fairy’s Kiss”), as a child; she ended it, however, in his “Petrushka” as a dancing doll.

headline: Brick Announces Lineup for Game Play Festival
text: The Brick Theater in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has announced the lineup for the 2013 Game Play festival, its annual fusion of live theater and video games. Among the shows to be presented are “Legendary, Maybe,” in which digital puppeteers use characters from World of Warcraft and Far Cry 3 to adapt stories written by the Roman historian Livy; “No Oddjob,” a one-man show written and performed by David Lawson that explores what happens when video games seep into your dreams; and “That Cute Radioactive Couple,” a comedy inspired by post-apocalyptic games like Fallout and BioShock, written and directed by Charles Battersby. The festival begins on Friday and runs through July 28. A complete schedule is at bricktheater.com.

headline: Still Stepping Into the Unknown and Testing Fate
text: The saxophonist and composer Wayne Shorter turns 80 on Aug. 25, and he has started the commemorations early. On Friday night at Town Hall, in the centerpiece of the Blue Note Jazz Festival, Mr. Shorter’s longtime quartet headlined a triple bill that attested to his immense and continuing influence on jazz.

headline: Senegal Detains Ex-President of Chad, Accused in the Deaths of Opponents
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The former president of Chad, Hissène Habré, who is accused of the killing and torture of thousands of opponents, was arrested here on Sunday by the Senegalese police, said the organization Human Rights Watch.

headline: Working to Combat the Stigma of Autism
text: Autism, or the fear of it, chased one Korean mother from her Queens church. “I very carefully told the mom: ‘I think your child is a little different. Why don’t you take the test for autism?’ ” said the Rev. Joy Lee of the Korean Presbyterian Church in Flushing. “She told me, ‘Oh no, my child will be O.K.’ So then she quit. After that, she did not pick up the phone.”

headline: A Peacock in Spite of Himself
text: “This is R&B 101,” Bruno Mars announced Saturday night at Barclays Center, fixing a stare on one woman in the audience. He cued the band to crescendo, and then to stop on a dime, leaving empty air just as he exhaled a silky “damn.” Afterward he paced the stage with an exaggerated peacock strut while encouraging his bandmates to try to outsuave him. “I don’t mean to toot my own horn,” Mr. Mars said when they were done, his megawatt smile turned up to gigawatt, “but, ‘Beeeeep!’ ”

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Information to be released includes the Institute for Supply Management’s report on manufacturing in the United States, China’s manufacturing purchasing managers index, the Bank of Japan’s second-quarter business conditions survey, euro area unemployment and the Consumer Price Index (Monday); United States factory orders and auto sales, Brazilian industrial production and a report on unemployment in Spain (Tuesday); ADP employment report, initial weekly jobless claims from the Labor Department, trade balance figures and Challenger job cuts in the United States (Wednesday); and the United States jobs report and unemployment rate and Canada jobs report (Friday).

headline: Heirs Fight Museums to Reclaim Art
text: Marty Grosz, son of the German artist George Grosz, seeks the return of some of his father’s works that were acquired by the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

headline: ‘Crazy Rich Asians’: Guilty Pleasure, or Cult of Opulence?
text: There was a time when Ming vases qualified as big-ticket Asian artifacts. But in Kevin Kwan’s “Crazy Rich Asians,” a dizzily shopaholic comedy of crass manners, the only Ming status symbols worth talking about are Leo Ming’s climate-controlled clothes closet where the shoes are kept 15 degrees warmer than the fur and cashmere, and Leo Ming’s private plane.

headline: Belgian Wins a Day After a Bus Blunder
text: AJACCIO, Corsica — Near the start line in Bastia, Corsica, on Sunday morning, fans and journalists milled about in the bright sun as they waited for the team buses to arrive. Typically, they would have been hoping to catch a glimpse of their favorite riders or chat with a team manager for the latest scoop.

headline: Family Camping Trip Packed With Phantom Selves, Hopes and Dreams
text: You never feel quite the same way about a public place once you’ve seen dance happening in it. Space and architecture that are usually governed by ordinary pedestrian activities become transformed by movement — sometimes by music and drama, too.

headline: Museums Faulted on Restitution of Nazi-Looted Art
text: Not until 1998, when 44 nations including the United States signed the groundbreaking Washington Principles on Nazi-Confiscated Art, did governments and museums formally embrace the idea that they have a special responsibility to repair the damage caused by the wholesale looting of art owned by Jews during the Third Reich’s reign.

headline: Trumpeting a Michelangelo (Cue the Trills of Dissent)
text: FLORENCE — It was a traditional celebrity sighting — the craned necks, the jostling elbows, the syncopated symphony of snapping cellphone cameras. But in this case, the object of intense scrutiny was a slightly larger-than-life statue of the young St. John the Baptist. Newly restored, it was being presented in a museum here as a lost work by Michelangelo.

headline: Awaiting Values Versus Sitting Back: A Precipitous Call
text: Examine the diagramed deal and auction. If you were asked to analyze the bidding, what comments would you have? (East’s redouble indicates exactly three-card heart support and any hand strength.)

headline: Knicks Near Deal to Add Raptors’ Bargnani
text: Andrea Bargnani, a bust as the N.B.A.’s top pick in 2006 and a payroll albatross in Toronto, could have a new distinction: the Knicks’ marquee acquisition of 2013.

headline: In a Swiss Limbo, Sadly Bracing for Expulsion
text: Worlds collide with the utmost courtesy in “Special Flight,” a somber and beautifully modulated documentary filmed at a Swiss detention center for undocumented immigrants and asylum seekers.

headline: Who Wants to Sail With This Ship of Trolls?
text: It’s a good thing the earth is flat, because that means the Honor, the yacht that is the focus of the new Bravo reality series “Below Deck,” is bound to sail over the edge someday. That would presumably relieve us of the obligation to pay any further attention to the people on it.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Kenzo After-Party
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Decisive Confrontations
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — O.K., I’ll say it: every now and then Will Shortz surprises me.

headline: Jennifer Lopez Faulted for Turkmenistan Show
text: The singer Jennifer Lopez has drawn scrutiny for performing at an event on Saturday night in Turkmenistan and singing “Happy Birthday” to the country’s president, Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov, who was in attendance. According to The Associated Press, a publicist for Ms. Lopez, above, said in a statement on Sunday that said she would not have appeared if she had known that there were human rights issues in Turkmenistan. Mr. Berdymukhammedov has been criticized by human rights organizations for a pattern of oppressive rule since he became president in 2006. The statement also said that despite Mr. Berdymukhammedov’s presence, the event was not political. It was hosted by the China National Petroleum Corporation, which made the birthday request toward the end of the concert, and Ms. Lopez “graciously obliged.” Her fee for the performance was not disclosed.

headline: Oops, Forgot Where I Hid All the Loot
text: The comedy-caper “Ghanchakkar” forgoes Bollywood’s signature song-and-dance sequences but runs at signature length, almost two and a half hours. The movie fills the time usually allotted for musical interludes with plot and more plot, but also with character.

headline: A Gay Pride March With Added Spring in Its Step
text: Marriage, of course, was the word of the day this year.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Paul Smith Spring/Summer 2014
text: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Dodig Is a Winner Amid the Withdrawals
text: WIMBLEDON, England – After three rounds, the 2013 tournament tied a Wimbledon record with 13 retirements and withdrawals in singles, and no one has benefited more than Ivan Dodig.

headline: Legal Merger Shows Rise in Criminal Defense Status
text: There once was a time when most of New York’s top law firms shunned criminal defense work, turning up their noses at assignments they viewed as unprofitable and déclassé.

headline: In Conservative Wyoming, Signs of a Thaw on Same-Sex Marriage
text: LARAMIE, Wyo. — For State Representative Cathy Connolly, Wyoming’s only openly gay legislator, this winter brought a rare moment of promise: her bill to create domestic partnerships advanced further than anything like it in the history of this deep red state — sailing through committee and onto the floor of the full House. Victory seemed possible. But when a crucial vote came, the bill failed.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Home Crowd Was Waiting for Wheeler’s Fastball, but So Were Nationals
text: It is rare these days that the Mets expect a large home crowd, but with a David Wright bobblehead giveaway and the rookie Zack Wheeler’s eagerly awaited home debut, Citi Field was a lively place Sunday.

headline: Mars Promotes Bite-Size Snickers, Following Hershey’s Cue
text: COPYING the strategy of the Hershey Company, its archrival Mars has introduced a bite-size Snickers, which it will begin promoting on Monday through advertising and social media.

headline: Alain Mimoun, a Top Runner, Dies at 92
text: Alain Mimoun was a virtual unknown in international track and field when he won a silver medal for France in the 10,000-meter race at the 1948 London Olympics. The Algerian-born Mimoun soon became one of the world’s most brilliant distance runners.

headline: The Rev. Norman Eddy, a Minister in East Harlem, Dies at 93
text: The Rev. Norman Eddy, a Yale-educated minister from Connecticut who settled in a blighted East Harlem neighborhood in 1951 and helped start a pioneering drug treatment program, a tenants’ group, a housing project, a credit union and the myriad self-help organizations that have sustained his work there for over 60 years, died on June 21 in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Journalism, Even When It’s Tilted
text: In a refracted media world where information comes from everywhere, the line between two “isms” — journalism and activism — is becoming difficult to discern. As American news media have pulled back from international coverage, nongovernmental organizations have filled in the gaps with on-the-scene reports and Web sites. State houses have lost reporters who used to provide accountability, so citizens have turned to digital enterprises, some of which have partisan agendas.
